description:
Just wow ... I had never tried Burmese food before I was in SFO and local friend suggested this place, I was kind of hesitant as I recently turned vegetarian and wasn't sure if they had many vegetarian options but man i am glad took my friends advice. So many vegetarian options. I ordered the following vegetarian dishes (has egg) and I am definitely coming back whenever I am in SFO.
Thai tea salad.. you have got to try this appetizer
Mandalay special Burmese noodles vegeterian
Balada

So delicious definitely coming back here next time
author: Anurag S.

description:
Ok food, terrible service!!! I think this restaurant is super over rated with below average food!!! 

We ordered three noodle specials (two with Chicken, one with tofu) and one Mongolian lamb. We also ordered tea, and coconut drink. 
They didn't bring our tea, we asked waitresses about the tea. It seems they don't understand English, every time they said yes and then nothing happened. We also didn't have any dedicated waitress, each time one new person was showing up. They brought the Mongolian lamb first and didn't bring the rest of the food for about 10 minutes. They were literally serving our food one by one with delay! The noodles tasted good but lamb was not good at all!
author: Delasa A.

description:
Food was fine, but the wait wasn't worth it. 
When we arrived there was already a long line and we dutifully added our names to the clip board list as is customary. After 45 minutes we were finally "next" for some time. A number of groups came in all at once behind us and the hostess who had already reassured me several times that we were next when she checked the list,  called a party of 4 behind us who had literally just arrived. When I protested she insisted another table was opening up and that it was more suitable for our party of 3. Another 15 minutes later she finally seated us at a table for 4. 
Sorry, but that's simply not cool.
author: Soccer P.

description: Initially tried to go to burma superstar but was repelled by their ridiculous wait/line of people. On the suggestion of a friend who lives in the area came here instead and i'm so glad I did. The wait here was far shorter and I thought the service and food were waaaaay better. All the food we ordered was flavorful and came out pretty quickly. The service here was excellent as it seems like their wait staff work as a team for the entire place. The dishes I enjoyed the most was the mongolian beed and mandalay chicken. The beef was flavorful with just a hint of heat while the chicken was a good balance of sweet. This is my new favor place for burmese in the area and i will be back to try their other menu items.
author: Peter P.

description:
Lucky find!

It was lunch time, I was starving and pressed for time. I do not know Richmond District that well and no promising lunch spot were in sight where I was until I ran into Mandalay. I first walked by, but luckily had a change of heart and made U-turn. The place is hard to miss because it is painted sunshine yellow, inside and out!

Mandalay has been around since 1984 and has changed ownership at least once, but according to what I read before writing this and experienced for myself it was the more recent owner who was the "better cook" and managed to change the fortunes of the restaurant.

I am not familiar with Burmese food so I asked the server to bring me his favorite and a cup of Burmese ice tea (It is very similar to its cousin from Thailand!). The noodle dish I was served had Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas, fried onions and a couple of other things in it that I do not remember, but it was delicious. 

The servers were great and very friendly. I wish I had more time to explore the dessert menu, but I had to run. Hopefully next time.
author: Afshin A.

description:
This place is so cute and cozy! Decent-ish neighborhood parking (you may have to circle a few times).

Came here with a friend on a Friday night at around 6:30pm ish and got seated right away. :)

It's a tight race for my favorite dish, but I think I have to go with the mango & chicken! The waiter recommended getting the coconut rice with the chicken, which I really liked! Coming in as a close first was the Balada (kind of like a roti) It's kind of like a thick fried crepe-ish like dish with a curry sauce in the middle.

We also ordered the tea leaf salad as the appetizer & asked for lettuce to be put in (thanks to fellow yelpers), it was pretty good. But not my fav. of the night! The Burmese Iced Tea was pretty bomb as well (same as Thai iced tea - but according to the waiter with Burmese tea ;) ).

This place is really cozy to eat @, lights strung all over the place & the food is really good too! Definitely do recommend coming in a little early because it was really busy that night!
author: Melanie T.

description:
I visited Mandalay for dinner recently with a party of five.  We selected Mandalay because of their stellar reviews and the fact that they take reservations.  It was a Wednesday night and they were slammed!  

Four of us had never been, so we deferred to our friend Scott C to lead the charge on our family-style order... but of course, I chimed in with a few dishes that sounded too good to miss, and nothing disappointed.

From the potsticker and salad appetizers to the eggplant and green bean veggie dishes and the shrimp special, fried rice and noodle dishes, there wasn't a "downer dish" amongst them... The staff was great in that they portioned everything for our group, but they weren't so great with refilling beverages.  I sat with an empty water glass for the majority of our time there.  I did, however, order a coconut water that was tasty and festive!

I know there are plenty of solid Burmese options in the Bay area, but I'm not so lucky back home in Phoenix... Everyone in our group arrived hungry and left full and had some extremely tasty Burmese dishes in between.  We were too full for dessert, so I'm thinking that I may have to return and save room next time... or at least attempt to do so :)
author: Gabi M.

description:
I wasn't impressed as all these glowing Yelp reviews. I found almost all the dishes to be pretty bland and portion sizes small for the price. 

Yes, service was attentive and they take reservations which all are great things. I enjoyed my Mandalay Cooler which was an alcoholic ginger beer, but the food? Eh.

We did a family style tasting for 5 people and we ordered up tea salad, roti, volcanic beef, ginger chicken, special noodle and the  chili prawn and all of it was pretty weak in flavor. Nothing stood out, zero spice, and overall pretty unimpressive. It wasn't bad, just nothing memorable.

Also, you would think we would have needed to be rollled out of there. While we were full, there were zero doggy bags.

Overall, I've had way better Burmese food in the Bay Area. I get it if you live locally, but def not a destination spot.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Our team dinner at Mandalay meant a lot more than just sharing a meal. We were celebrating a colleague's birthday, us being reunited in San Francisco, and this being the the former favorite Burmese restaurant of someone very special to all of us. 

As you can see by the plethora of photos I took, we pigged out hard. This was my introduction to Burmese cuisine, and I have to say everything we tried was solid. It's safe to say we all walked away full and content.

My absolute favorite was the Roti bread that hit the table. So good that it gets its own paragraph! Like, OH MY GOD, this was undeniably life changing. The texture, the aroma, the richness, the flakiness, the chewiness. I had to practically beg my coworkers for an extra piece!

We sampled so many items that it was sensory overload. The noodles, the salads, the satay, the soups, the desserts - there wasn't anything that disappointed. 

Overall, the four stars go back to the service because it was extremely scattered. The servers were all very nice, don't get me wrong, just inconsistent. One of the fun elements of Mandalay is when they add the finishing touches to dishes at the table. 

My first crack at Burmese food was a success, I hope to try it again sometime!
author: Matthew C.

description:
We ordered a million different thing and there wasn't anything I wouldn't ravage again on a moments notice. That being said, there were definitely some stand out apps and mains that are a must have. I'm just gonna go down the list and try to remember everything we had...

Drinks!
Lychee special cocktail - Almost everyone at the table got one and they took forever. They came out at different times and it's probably the only thing I didn't like about my meal. It was insanely sweet to the point of undrinkable. My coworker and I split a bottle of wine and were happy with that

Apps!
***Must Have***The Tea Leaf Salad - As many have mentioned, this dish is so delicious. It doesn't look like anything exciting so I honestly thought it would be a flop but when you mix everything together it creates a flavor my mouth had never witnessed before

Fried Rice Cakes - These were surprisingly tasty and very shareable. Great item to get with a group.

Mango Salad - So fresh and so clean clean. This dish is beautiful and could honestly be served as a mango dessert.

Sizzling Rice Soup - They brought out a bunch of small bowls so we could all share. I enjoyed the flavor of the broth but it wasn't super memorable.

Satay Chicken - It was good but if you've had one chicken on a stick, you've had em all amiright? Nothing against this dish but it didn't have the unique factor the other apps did.

Mains!
Burmese Curry Lamb - I am not a huge fan of lamb but this was so tender and full of flavor. A surprising win.

***Must Have***Special Noodles - The bar was set high as we had heard all about these noodles. We had 2 orders of chicken and 2 orders of shrimp. They're very similar and really depends on what your choice of protein is.

***Must Have***Lychee Coconut Prawns - This dish came out late after one of the desserts so many people had already thrown in the towel. This was the one thing I picked out so I had to try. The people that did indulge were amazed. Don't forget about the lychee's and pineapple in the juice of the bowl... just as good as the prawns. Dump the leftover juice over your coconut rice. You'll thank me later!

Sides!
Fried Squash - These were simply okay. It was a nice extra to have on the table but not a stand out.

Dry Pan Fried String Beans - These were excellent and reminded me of how I do beans at home. Definitely a good shareable side for the table.

***Must Have***Coconut Rice - We all had a small bowl and it was so good! I would say this is great to have if you're sharing and want some rice on your own too.

Desserts!
We had a few and nothing really was amazing. We had already had plenty of mango but that's always a winner. I guess the black rice with ice cream on top was probably my favorite out of the handful we had.

Must Haves!
Looking for the perfect dinner for two? Stick to the must haves... Tea leaf salad, an order of special noodles, Lychee and Coconut Prawns, Coconut rice as a side, and decide if you want dessert here or stop somewhere on the way home. Don't forget that bottle of wine either!

Service!
We had a great experience at Mandalay for a group of 8 or 9 people. Some of the service was amazingly accommodating like putting two orders of Special noodles on one plate to save room on the table and making sure everything worked for our large group to share. Other things like super long wait times for drinks and one of the mains coming out after some of the desserts was odd. They were super busy and we ordered a ton so it was a win in our book overall.
author: Scotty C.

description:
So pleased with my first ever Burmese food experience thanks to the deliciousness served by Mandalay.

On our annual work trip, one night each team can choose a restaurant of their liking to dine together. Team Southeast selected Mandalay, as it was a special restaurant for all, and I am so happy we went with this one.

I did my research and was told one must order the Tea Leaf Salad as well as the special noodles. Thankfully, our team came hungry and we ordered a few of each of those things and then some!

What didn't we order. I would suggest to order a bunch of different dishes, and share with your group. For starters:
- Fish Cakes
- Tea Leaf Salad: this was to die for. The flavor combo of tea leaves, fried garlic, ground shrimp and sesame seeds with the dressing was unlike anything I had ever had before. A little acidic, but super well balanced at the same time. I loved every bite! Plus the presentation is pretty theatrical - they mix it all for you tableside.
- Mango Salad: so refreshing! Spiralized mango for the win.
- Sizzling Rice Soup: this had pieces of crispy rice with a super tasty broth.
- Satay Skewers: a solid choice and definite crowd pleaser.
- Balada: you must order this. Its a cripsy pancake with the most delicious dipping sauce ever.

For mains we ordered so many special noodles. These were amazing. These also come prepared tableside and the mixture of textures from the flat noodle, coconut chicken and then crispy noodles on top kept me coming back for second tastes (and thirds).

Overall - the food was awesome, I am so bummed we don't have Burmese food in Miami! Mandalay takes Yelp reservations, so that is great for a group. I would highly suggest reservations, as the place was packed. 

Service was mostly speedy - except it did take half my team 45 minutes to get their cocktails, which was a bummer. However, once it did appear, the drink was great! I would definitely get the lychee cocktail again!
author: Diandra L.

description:
I've never been or heard of Burmese food prior to Sunday. I'm always game to try new foods so I thought why not. We took a recommendation and our taste buds led the way to this amazing place.

When you walk in you're greeted w/ Christmas lights on a palm tree, lights and such hanging from the ceiling, colors galore and great music. We were quickly greeted as soon as we sat down. I ordered a type of jasmine tea. It came in a wine glass w/ a flower in it. The heat makes this flower bloom. It's pretty cool to do w/ time lapse. The tea comes scolding hot and they tell you it. I didn't actually start drinking it until about half way through our meal. 

We started w/ the Tea Leaf Salad (salad prepared with imported burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing). They mix it up for you at the table so if you want a picture you better get it quick! All the flavors of this masterpiece were amazing. Unfortunately there was too much crunching for me. 

Singapore Style Noodle (Rice noodle with prawn, chicken & pork with curry spices). This is my jam!!! Everything about it. The flavors how everything works. I'd come back here solely for this right here. 

This place was turning tables while we were there. Everyone left w/ smiling faces and happy bellies from what I saw, including us. This is def gonna become one of my new staples of San Francisco!
author: Kevin Z.

description: Cute little Burmese place just down the street when you can't get into Burma Superstar. I love their Burmese altar and you can sip on tea while you wait for a table. Food was really good too. My only complaint being the tea leaf salad was quite greasy since their serve with without the romaine but maybe that is the traditional approach.
author: Sai J.

description:
The place looks good but the food was lacking a little something.

Tea leaf salad: no lettuce or leafy greens aside from the tea leaf paste so it was a little too strong/salty. I liked all the nuts and seeds - nice and crunchy but there was a bit too much peanuts compared to the other ingredients.

Balada: pretty good. Flaky, nice layers, soft, lightly crispy. Best part was the sauce that came with it. 

Mandalay special noodle: I liked the noodles and the overall flavor but the sauce still seemed a little too liquidy to me. I also didn't like that they used dried noodles as the crispies in this dish - they just ended up soggy.

Burmese style chicken curry: average flavors. Nice pieces of chicken. Typical curry. Good portion. 

Pork stew in pumpkin with sour mango: kinda disappointing. I was expecting the actual pumpkin bowl to be softer and cooked well-done so we could actually eat it. But nope. It was hard and you could only eat the few chunks of pumpkin inside. The pork was tender but not that amazing. I didn't taste any mango or sour mango. Just tasted like a regular pork and pumpkin stew. 

The prices were pretty high for average food. The service was fine/good. The food is overall fine but probably won't be coming back just because I don't think the dishes are worth the price.
author: Rachelle C.

description:
My friend and I wanted to try this place again, and I'm glad we did.  We thoroughly enjoyed our meals and service.

We ordered chicken samusas and pot stickers to start.  Both were yummy and a good way to start the meal.  And I got a coconut drink that came with young coconut and tapioca.  It was so refreshing! I tried really hard not to finish it so quickly.  In the end, it ended up like my dessert as it was sweet (but not too sweet).

I got the Mandalay chicken with white rice.  It was delicious, and had a nice garlic flavor.  I'm sure they would've made really good leftovers as I'm sure the flavor would've intensified.  But I gave it to my dad, and he devoured it.  He said it was good, so I need to go back and order more just for myself.

My friend and I arrived just before the dinner rush, so we received attentive service.  The last time I dined here, service wasn't so attentive, and the restaurant had packed tables to the brim.  I noticed this time that the tables were more spaced out, and they added seating in the bar by the door.  So I think they found a way to easily manage those dinner rushes that they still have.

I need to note that the business owner messaged me regarding my previous review, invited me to come back, and offered an appetizer on the house.  I did not take him on that offer, but I definitely appreciate the gesture.  I wanted to come back on my own, and I'm happy to have dined here again.  I need to come back to order the Mandalay chicken again.. and maybe some green beans.
author: Vira P.

description:
This was my first time checking out a Burmese restaurant but some friends suggested coming here and it did not disappoint. 

I recommend doing what we did and getting about 4-5 dishes and sharing them all. It really lets you get a sampling of all this place has to offer and everything we had was great. Lots of great and unique flavors in all the dishes. 

On a Friday or Saturday night, I would call ahead to put your name in. We called and were told it was a 25 minute wait. By the time we walked over our table was immediately available. 

My only knock on this place would be extremely high prices for bottles of wine...everything over $35. This place is good but not fancy enough to justify those prices for a bottle. Beer is like $6 so that's your best bet or a glass of the house wine is $8 which isn't bad either.
author: Matt M.

description:
In town for a work trip and we decided as Mandalay for our team dinner. As we arrive for this highly anticipated meal, the facade and inside are so similar to many other San Francisco establishments I have been to. But like many of those places, the cramped interior and forgettable front entrances are no indicator of the food. Burmese food is not something you can get regularly in most cities. So I am always happy to have it when I come to SF.

Mandalay's service started off very much on the wrong foot. The forgot three people's drink orders and took the first two courses to even come out. We had to ask numerous times about it, and when it finally came, I was a little disappointed in the drink itself. Far too sweet for my taste. I was very bitter by this experience... but only good things from there. All of the food we had was incredible. I was not very excited about the mango salad until I took the first bite. It was absolutely incredible. The crunchy bits really made it a spectacular dish. The fish cakes were a late addition to our table, but really glad we got them. This might have been my favorite dish and up there with the special noodles. Speaking of... get the special noodles. Enough said. The fried eggplant is also worthy of an order and went WAY too fast. The shrimp and satay were really good. But definitely overshadowed by the other dishes we had. The sizzling rice soup was one of my most hyped dishes that fell a little flat. Really cool sounding dish, but the flavor was again overshadowed by everything else.

Besides the poor service to start, everything was fantastic. I think the biggest downfall is that we had SO many different things, that many outshined others.
author: Will B.

description:
Really...really like this spot.

Naturally everyone compares this place to another local competitor that also has locations in Alameda. 

I think without question...this place is better and I've been to the "other" spot many times and am a fan.

We had from fave dish to least fave-

Mandalay Special Noodle- Absolutely delish. Must get. Just a different type of taste than any other noodle I've had. 

Tea Leaf Salad-  Also a staple when we go to other spot but this place is on par

Curry Beef- Very tender delicious pieces in a savory broth  

Balada - Which is a roti type dish delish with the sauce

Samusa with Chicken- Very good and the veggies it came with were also solid 

Dry Pan Fried String Bean- pretty good but not a must have

Mango Chicken-  I liked this dish but I'd get it without the jalapenos/peppers b/c it made it a bit too hot for my liking

Coconut Rice- Was just o.k. 

The prices are a bit high, but it's SF and it's to be expected.  Our final bill for all of the above was around $150 I believe.
author: Rod M.

description:
Prelim Review:

Mandalay is a fun, Burmese restaurant in the Inner Richmond that serves Chinese-like food with many Indian influences. With strong flavors, a very wide variety of menu items, and accommodations for large groups, it's the perfect place for adventure eating and big raucous celebrations. 

Mandalay's strengths are also its weaknesses and a few of the dishes that we ordered here were a bit over-seasoned and others just had odd flavor combinations. The décor and loud atmosphere may also not be ideal for a romantic date. 

Overall Mandalay is a great restaurant for groups willing to go out of their comfort zone for food. It's unfortunately a bit far from the major public transit lines but I would recommend the trip over here for people who live on the west side of the city.
author: Andrew H.

description: Best tea leaf salad in the city. Authentic Burmese food, nice staff and a great place for family-style food!
author: Theresa Thao N.

description:
Inside, Mandalay's beautifully decorated dining room is always bustling and busy. My group was seated right away for dinner, and though the service was friendly and attentive, the food left something to be desired. That being said, the first dish we started with--the tea leaf salad was quite delicious! The classic tea leaf salad consists of fermented tea leaves, peanuts, sunflower seeds, sesame seeds, and fried garlic chips, so as you might imagine, there's quite a lovely crunch to every bite! 

The moo hin nga catfish chowder was distinctly acidic, but the soup could definitely have used more solid components. The mushu shrimp was a rather greasy stir-fried mixture of shrimp and vegetables, and the crispy tea-smoked duck served with buns on the side wasn't particularly flavorful. We had the Mandalay special noodles with chewy housemade noodles, coconut chicken, shredded onion, and fried noodles on top, but the flavor complexity of this dish was underwhelming and I could only taste the saltiness of it. Finally, we had the green papaya salad, dressed with garlic chips and ground shrimp, which was a nice refreshing dish to end the meal. 

By the time we left the restaurant, however, all I could taste was MSG in the back of my throat. Though the service and atmosphere of Mandalay were nice, the dishes were relatively expensive for what they were, and many of the dishes have definitely been modified to cater to Americanized tastes. While not bad, Mandalay just isn't on the same level as Burma Superstar when it comes to the food.
author: David K.

description:
One of my faves! The food is absolutely delicious and the service is fantastic and warm. Perfect for a chill date night or big group dinner with friends. 

Highly recommend the green beans, the ginger salad, either eggplant dish (naked or basil), spicy tofu w/ veggies... I could go on forever.
author: Caroline B.

description:
Have you ever found yourself trying to eat at Burma Superstar (https://www.yelp.com/biz/burma-superstar-san-francisco-2), aka THE BEST restaurant ever, only to give up because the wait was atrocious? Sadly, this happened to me years ago on my birthday. The wait-time at Burma was around two hours ON A WEEKDAY, which we weren't down for. The hostess directed us to B Star Bar, their sibling restaurant (https://www.yelp.com/biz/b-star-bar-san-francisco), but it did not come close to matching the experience one gets at Burma Superstar. 

But, there is one restaurant that does: Mandalay. My girlfriend and I were looking for a lunch spot to cap off a scenic hike along the coast. I originally suggested Burma Superstar, but that of course flew out the window since the line was HELLA LONG. We decided to give Mandalay a try and it turned out to be a positive experience! 

Mandalay is located in San Francisco's Inner Richmond neighborhood along California Street (between 5th and 6th Avenue). I dig this location because of its convenience and accessibility. For one, Inner Richmond is quite calm compared to other parts of the city (e.g. Sunset, Mission, etc.). As a result, traffic should be light and you don't need to worry too much about finding street parking. If you choose to take public transportation (good for you!), plenty of transit lines go through here. Furthermore, Mandalay is legit ONE STREET DOWN from Burma Superstar! Waiting too long at Superstar? Come here! When we arrived at ~1pm on a Sunday, the place was only a third full. 

For the most part, Mandalay offers many of the same Burmese staples that are found at Superstar. For example, this restaurant also has Samusas, Tea Leaf Salad, and Nan Gyi Dok. However, you'll find many options here that you won't get at Superstar (e.g. Singapore Style Noodle, Mango Salad, etc.) because Mandalay is a FUSION between both Burmese AND Chinese. Large menu = happy me. As far as pricing goes, you're looking at approximately $11-$15 per dish - fairly similar to Superstar. My girlfriend and I got the Mandalay Special Noodle, Tea Leaf Salad, Burmese Curry Beef, and a side of Coconut Rice. Here's what we thought:

-TEA LEAF SALAD (8/10): I always love the explosion of flavor that comes along with a good Tea Leaf Salad. It's hard to mesh different ingredients together, but Mandalay makes a solid attempt. I felt like the soft texture of the peanuts and the diced tomatoes blended flawlessly with the crunchiness of the garlic chips and the sesame seeds. Plus, the addition of jalapeno slices was a nice, spicy touch. It all came together wonderfully with a sweet/sour mixture of lemon juice, grounded dried shrimp, and tea leaves. The only downer was that I wished it had chopped lettuce. 

-BURMESE CURRY BEEF (7/10): Their Curry Beef reminded me of a delicious Rendang. The sauce was creamy, savory, and oh so fragrant! I found the beef to be quite chewy and it soaked up the sauce like nothing. This dish also came with potatoes, which I appreciated because I love potaters. However, I thought the beef/potatoes could have been cooked a bit longer as some pieces were a bit hard. If anything, I'd just get this dish for the sauce - perfect topping for rice! 

-MANDALAY SPECIAL NOODLE (8/10): Shoutout to my friend Tina for suggesting the Mandalay Special because it was fire! In a nutshell, this dish was virtually a carb version of the Tea Leaf Salad. The noodles were super soft, the lime/lemon coconut sauce added an intense, sour flavor, and the chicken was SO TENDER. Also, gotta love the fried noodle toppings because that was like the icing on the cake! My only con was that they could have given us more chicken. 

-COCONUT RICE (7/10): The Coconut Rice came out fluffy, and I loved that they gave a nice bed of fried coconut strips too! It was lacking in the aroma department (couldn't smell it all the way from the kitchen like you could at Superstar), but this was not a bad choice for a side. 

-SERVICE (7/10): Service was pretty decent here. The employees were fairly quick to respond when we needed something, and they made sure to refill our cups with water when they were getting empty. I'm always a fan of Burmese restaurants because the waiters/waitresses make sure to describe their dishes to you when serving them! 

-ATMOSPHERE (10/10): One of my favorite parts about Mandalay was the ambiance. From head to toe, this restaurant was DECKED OUT with paintings, ornaments, and greenery; I really felt like I was being transported to Myanmar/Burma. It just goes to show that a little effort can go a long way in transforming an old building into a beautiful masterpiece. 

If you're looking for a decent alternative to Burma Superstar, Mandalay has got you covered. Overall, the food here is pretty awesome. Plus, you get the added bonus of an amazing atmosphere as well as NOT HAVING TO WAIT. I give Mandalay a "Nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
I've had dinner here now 16 times this year and am finally getting around to writing the review this place deserves. Just this year this restaurant has taken the top spot as my favorite place to dine out in SF, possibly the entire solar system!

Love the yellow and green paint of the building, the ornate artwork juxtaposed with christmas lights. I just love the vibe in here.

We see the same people working every time, hustling hard and turning tables efficiently without rushing people. 

As a vegan leaning vegetarian, everything I have consumed here has been delicious, consistent and on point. Every single time. There are not many restaurants that I will willingly dine out at because most places use a lot of low quality ingredients, oil, or some other unknown additives. I know that Mandalay is quality because after every meal I have only felt amazing, with no digestive distress/aftermath. This is how I ultimately determine the worth of a restaurant, how does the food make me feel after I consume it? I believe that when the food is made with positive intent, in a positive environment that how you feel after you eat it will manifest in the body.

Many dishes can be made vegetarian, and the servers even remember my dietary restrictions. Forget the wait at that other hyped Burmese place up the street and just come here. That other Burmese place is just a glorified Panda Express in my opinion. Mandalay is the real deal. I have never waited over 20 minutes for a table on the weekend for two people, even at peak dinnertime.

This place is so delicious it is a must go when people are visiting in town. 

Favorite vegetarian dishes are:
samusa soup 
ginger salad 
rainbow salad
kaw soi dok noodle 
naked eggplant
walnut broccoli tofu
coconut rice
tompoi rice
author: Travis B.

description:
I wasn't impressed by the food at Mandalay during my recent Saturday night visit. I ordered the burlada (bread appetizer with curry-like sauce), tea leaf salad, fish soup, and the Burmese style noodle. Of all the items mentioned, my favorite was the burlada because the bread was warm and fluffy, the sauce was very flavorful and not too salty. 

The tea leaf salad was missing the greens of lettuce or etc. I thought the chef forgot to add an extra component, but when I looked at pictures of other tea leaf salad, the chef didn't forget. The crunch factor was there, but I felt that it needed to be eaten with something else, whether lettuce or over rice.

The fish soup was ok, flavorful, but not much substance within the soup. The noodles weren't anything special. 

Service was good and continuous. The wait staff even explained why there's a delay of bringing water, they were in the midst of washing more glasses. 

Wait time was about 30-40 minutes after putting down my name. You can call to get your name on the list, but if your name was called and you're not there yet, you're out of luck. That's what happened to me.
author: Jean L.

description: Nice gem of a restaurant. I haven't had a dish that I didn't like here. The service is fantastic. I love the bling on their Buddha statue. I recommend reservations for dinner.
author: Regina G.

description:
Downgrading from 5 stars to 4.  I still really like this place but didn't quite have the stellar experience on this latest visit.

The moo hin nga fish chowder was as delicious as ever... but it's now served as small or medium-size individual servings.  We opted for medium cup-size servings at a cost of $7 a cup.  $21 for three servings of soup seems excessive.

The tea salad tasted great but the portion has gotten smaller. That's merely a different way of increasing the cost per serving size.

The Mandalay special noodle salad was as good as ever.  Thank you for not reducing the portion size.

We ventured into dishes we hadn't tried before and would not recommend them.  One was a tea smoked duck with pumpkin.  It was good but too sweet.  The server took the dish and spent 5 minutes deconstructing it in front of us and then reconstructed it into 4 servings.  We then had to deconstruct her work to serve the portions that we wanted individually.  That was 
bizarre.  The other dish was a bird's nest seafood special.  Usually bird's nest dishes are made of something unusual and tempting to eat such as shredded taro.  This was nothing more than wheat flour.  And inside this fried tortilla bowl was a small serving of seafood in a very thick, syrupy, sweet sauce.

We plan to return some day when in the area, but will no longer make a special trek.
author: Lee K.

description:
I am so lucky to have a boyfriend that lives within walking distance of Mandalay! We both regularly order takeout from here, at least a few times a month and it never disappoints! But I was able to actually go in person earlier this week for dinner, and I'm glad I had the opportunity to dine-in and finally leave a much overdo review. 

The restaurant is generally always busy; however, busy just means that tables are always filled, but the wait time is not unreasonable. We waited for about 15 minutes for a table of 2 on a Monday night, which I did not think was unreasonable at all especially for SF. Also, if you're ever concerned with the wait time to dine-in, takeout is always 10-15 mins MAX, which is fantastic on those weeknights when we want a quick but worthwhile meal! 

The inside is beautifully decorated, and always bustling and busy. Keep in mind that while this restaurant isn't small, it does get very noisy like most Asian restaurants, something that I do not mind at all because who doesn't like being social? The service is excellent, they are very attentive without being in your face, and the servers as well as the owners are very pleasant people! 

Our go to dishes are the Burmese Style Curry Chicken, Burmese Curry Lamb, Mandalay Chicken, and Dry Pan Fried String Bean (to which we generally add Seafood or Tofu). We also love the chicken samusas as an appetizer as well! Also love the Burmese Iced Tea - unlike Thai Iced Tea, this actually tastes like tea and is strong! 

Also, P.S., there is another Burmese restaurant in the Inner Richmond area that constantly has an absurd line with an even more ridiculous wait time always (which I will not name), however Mandalay is 10x better than this place! Mandalay is so underrated, but seriously it is the best Burmese restaurant I've been to, and we will continue to come back regularly!
author: Abi R.

description:
Definitely more authentic than Burmese Super Star nearby and Burma Cafe in Daly City. But I would say it became more fushion-y than last time we visited 2 years ago & 3 years ago. Decorations and ambience is excellent. Service is still excellent. 

We ordered fish cake salad, Sour Leaf (Chin Paung Jaw) w shrimp, & burmese style curry catfish (bone in). We came just for fish curry coz I remembered being amazing last time we came. This time the curry paste tastes different, masala they use or spices they use is a bit off. U might like it but it wasn't my cup of tea. But fish itself taste delicious. I loved with bone. It wasnt hard to take off with fork. 

Oh talking about tea, as much as it is annoying to drink hot tea out of wine glass, I can't resist fresh jasmine smell & fancy look.
author: Heather S.

description:
I have lived here for over thirty years and have always heard about how good the Mandalay is. Recently, I put my foot down and made a special trip just to eat there. Now I'm mad at myself for driving by so many times while thinking, "Oh yeah, Mandalay, ... next time."  

Now it's "next time". The restaurant itself, which has been there for decades, looks and feels as fresh as when it opened. The colors are cheerful and bright, the furnishings are like new, and the room is sunny all day.

I have gone back twice, and must say, I like lunchtime there, with a friend. I'll have to go back and try dinner, though I expect the experience will be nearly identical. 

This is a family owned restaurant and it felt like a family atmosphere. No fewer than three people came by, each with a smile, and made sure we had all we needed and that we were happy with our choices, and their quality. Everything was just right, but I felt confident that if there was any problem they would have been anxious to rectify it, gladly.

The food was crisp, and brightly flavored. The flavor combinations are not pan-Asian, they are distinctly Burmese. We love the Tea Leaf Salad, of course. From what I have read, everyone does. The Burlada was warm and delicious, and come with yummy sauce. The Shrimp Curry was luscious, with Coconut Rice. We loved the Eggplant Basil dish as well. 

We enjoyed nice Ginger Lemonade with our meal, a perfect refresher with some spicy dishes, too.
author: James G.

description:
I saw an episode of Check, Please on PBS. The one person on the show recommended it, it was her favorite restaurant.  After watching the show I wanted to see for myself. I was not disappointed the food was very authentic with lots of great favor.
The service was excellent. I would go back again.
author: Clifford L.

description: Mandalay is excellent - and a great place to go if you have a hankering for ahem, Burma Superstar, but you don't want to wait in that annoying line, or settle for its sister restaurant B Star. The truth is, Mandalay is just as good, if not better in that it has a slightly larger menu with simple to ornate dishes. Lots of vegetarian options as well. I've been coming here for about a decade and I feel like most of the dishes are packed with flavor, but healthy flavor. Very little additives; the star ingredients do the work here. Their tea leaf salad is not as fancy and plentiful as the B-Star franchise - but it's still incredibly delicious and has all the mainstays of the traditional dish. Service is always friendly and efficient. I love the decor too, it makes for a sunny day when it's cold and gloomy outside.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Good food. I love the pancake and the honey walnut prawns. I also order lamb or one of their great soups most of the time I'm there. Everything here tastes great and the staff is very kind. Definitely worth trying if you like Burmese food or looking to try for the first time. If it's your first time here, order the jasmine tea. It's fun to watch it open and it's great for a photo-op. I also enjoy the coconut tapioca drink. 

The restaurant is kind of small, but I've gotten used to tight spaces in SF and having grown up eating in chinatown, etc. It can be a little loud at their busy hours, as well, but these things do not bother me.
author: Olive T.

description: I fell in love with Burmese food after eating here. The interior is bizarre with Christmas ornaments hanging from the ceiling, a neon palm tree near the entrance, and not to mention the wait staff dressed in traditional outfits. Besides that, the food is amaaaaazing (getting hungry writing this...). We typically get the tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, mango salad, and the beef curry. I've had tea leaf salads at other Burmese restaurants (Burma Superstar) and none compares to Mandalay's. From the fresh colorful ingredients to the way the waitress explains each component and mixes it - it's amazing!
author: J Y.

description:
I heard that Mandalay is way better than Burma Superstar so I had to try it! I made reservations for a Friday night by calling the day before, but when we arrived they told us that we had to put our name on the waiting list anyways though we would get priority. We ended up waiting about 15-20 minutes past our reservation time to be seated. If this is the case, I don't really see the point in taking reservations...

Besides that, the food was delicious! The tea leaf salad was my favorite thing we ordered and the pancake with curry dipping sauce was equally amazing! The beef curry was a bit tougher than I thought it would be and the Mandalay beef was different than what we expected - it tasted like General Tsao's Chicken (but obviously beef). Overall a great meal, but a different selection than at Burma Superstar, so I wouldn't necessarily say it's better, but it's definitely more of a family run business vibe while Burma Superstar is a bit trendier.
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
First, food was 5 stars.

We were seated at a table that had yet to be wiped down and the service felt a little pushy, specifically in the beginning. These are the reasons for the 4 stars.

The service was friendly, food came out in a timely manner and they were great at keeping the water glasses full. 

Now onto the food-perfectly cooked green beans, delicious noodle dish, samosas were so yummy, tea leaf salad full of flavor, spicy eggplant dish was perfect balance of sweet and spicy and orange chicken morsels were mouthwateringly delicious.
author: Kayla B.

description:
I actually prefer this place over Burma Superstar. And Mandalay happens to be right down the block, plus the wait time is significantly shorter which is a huge bonus when I'm hangry lol. 

The interior of the restaurant is gorgeous with its Burmese decor hung on the walls. It's dim-lit inside, yet ironically radiant too. 

The Balada is a must-get for sure. I've also tried the Ong No Kaw Soi (coconut chicken noodle soup) and that was also superb. But the all-star dish for me is definitely the Mandalay Beef, which compliments perfectly well with Tea Leaf Salad.  

This place is a solid choice to bring your family, friends, or even go on a date. 

Exceptional and authentic food. 

This has definitely become one of my favorite restaurants in the city!
author: Eva L.

description: This is my absolute favorite restaurant in the Inner Richmond. It has the authentic vibe missing from the more "upscale" Burma superstar, and the relaxed but gorgeous atmosphere is magical. It has the original tea leaf salad and the rice is to DIE for. Get the coconut rice with caramelized onions on it... you won't know this is what rice was missing until you try it. Also, great service. I'm friends with the staff at this point I go so often.
author: Amelia F.

description:
Has it really been three years since my last update? Mr Rinky andI were fortunate to be treated to Mandalay for our birthdays by our sweet friends D and J.

It's a good thing we don't live closer AND have lots of money......OMG....so delicious.  There's food to die for and then there's food to kill for.....okay i won't be killing anytime soon but the food is so good it's LICK YOUR PLATE good.....well at least D and I would lick our plates.

We started off with the marvelous tea leaf salad.....even though they explain all the ingredients as they mix them in  ....in the back of   mind I think there must be something magical ,,pixie dust ...they put into all of their food to make it so delish.

The balada came next...a crispy pancake with chicken curry dipping sauce. It was really difficult to share this.  So good.

We continued with the samosa soup which is best and soothing on a cold rainy day but on ANY day it's wonderful.

J wanted the chicken satay...which came with four skewers of chicken but it seemed like it would have been nice to have a side of peanut sauce.

The broccoli with tofu and walnuts came next  The description says the broccoli is steamed and covered with a special sauce.  I've tried to relplicate the dish at home but my dish only got a B minus compared to their A Plus version.  

We got brown rice and coconut rice to go with our food. Yum

Our last dish was another masterpiece......Mandalay Special Noodle
Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top. Since Mr Rinky is vegan and doesn't eat eggs we had the dish with rice noodles.....Can food be too good?   Next time we go there I think each of us would like their own noodles....

So that's my review of Mandalay.......easily TEN stars
Can you tell this is my FAVORITE restaurant?

Also the staff is terrific.....warm and welcoming......and able to remain that way despite the crowds.  Plus the couple that owns the restaurant is  often there and always waiting on the customers and bussing the tables.
author: Rinky N.

description:
3.5 STARS

I was craving a tea leaf salad. Wanting to try a new spot, the roommate and I ordered delivery from Mandalay for lunch. We placed the order via DoorDash on Sunday, April 23rd at 1:01pm. It arrived at 1:50pm. We live in Outer Richmond.

*Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok): Salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic, sesame seeds, green peppers and dressing, no peanuts ($12.50)
*Mandalay Special Noodle: Burmese flat noodles with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder, lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top ($13.50)
*Pumpkin Curry Chicken ($16)
*Samusa (With Chicken): A mixture of grounded curried meat and potatoes ($10)
*Balada: Burmese crispy pancake with Curry dipping sauce ($9)

My favorite dish was the tea leaf salad. A good amount of ingredients. Although I do like my tea leaf salad with a bit more lettuce. But that's just my prefer as I adore lettuce. The roti like pancake with curry was also pretty good. The bread had a nice chew and wasn't too oily. I did find the curry a touch too sweet though. Added sambal to counteract that and give it a kick. The samusas were nice and crispy. Kind of like fried comfort food. But I didn't like the sauce that came with it. Ended up using curry instead. The noodles were okay. Lots of stuff going on, but part of me wanted them to be a little saucier. My quick fix was to add a little curry and sambal. I didn't like the pumpkin curry at all. It was a little too starchy? Not sure if that's the right word, but maybe it was due to the pumpkin? Also, I found it too sweet.

Some solid dishes and some I'd skip. But I could definitely make a good meal out of their tea leaf salad, samusa, and balada.
author: Elena N.

description:
We got the last table on a Friday night and there was a small line when we left.

The veg food we got was really good (though overall I don't think Burmese is usually as good as Thai) and the server was well-versed in what was and wasn't veg, so that was nice. The service overall was very good, with essentially a large ensemble cast of friendly and mostly attentive servers, so we never had to wait for "our" server because of any of the employees was willing to help with anything, which made everything run smoother.
author: Veg V.

description: This is definitely my favorite Burmese restaurant in SF. I have been coming here for about 18 years and they have never disappointed me/us. Great service and great food!
author: Alvaro B.

description: I'm a newbie to Burmese food. A friend of mine had his birthday dinner at Mandalay and I've always wanted to try their cuisine. I'm so glad I went. Their food was amazing! I will definitely go back and try more dishes. I highly recommend Mandalay but definitely make a reservation. They're so popular that even on a weeknight it gets packed.
author: Z.C. V.

description:
The best place for dinner in San Francisco.

Mandalay goes back to the late 1970s. Not many know that this was the first Burmese restaurant outside Burma, today Myanmar: in those years, the country used to be a military dictatorship and it's only been less than a decade that it opened its borders to tourism. I used to go there on a weekly basis in the 1980s, now that I've shortly returned to stay at my mom's relatives to get some UCB certificates I had lost around in the world, I can confirm that almost nothing has changed. Prices are a bit steep, just as they used to be. Portions are a bit small, as they used to be.

Myanmar is located down at the bottom of China, with Thailand on one side and India on the other. There are elements of each of those cuisines in the mix, along with foods from Burma's several regional cuisines, marked by a delicate blending of flavors that is uniquely Burmese. On your first trip to Mandalay go ahead and order the signature dishes: Tea Leaf Salad and Mohinga, along with whatever entrees catch your fancy. Also, plan not to be in a hurry when you go. It's a no-reservations, sign up and wait kind of place.

Mandalay on California Street in San Francisco is - for me and only for me - the best restaurant in San Francisco. Gracious service, gorgeous flower arrangements, and always excellent, tasty food with beautiful presentations make Mandalay my very favorite restaurant in San Francisco (I'm getting old and repetitive, I know). The place is cozy with an Asian decor, yet the tables are comfortably spaced. The service is always friendly and and very efficient.

I went there with an empty stomach since more than 24 hrs. so I started with the Balada appetizer, a delicious crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce. Then I had Lap Pat Dok, a tea leaf salad with lentil seeds, fried garlic, sesame seeds, and peanuts that is an exotic taste delight. This salad is a must have!! Next I ordered the Rangoon Spicy Fish, an old time favorite of mine. 

I missed (too full even to walk, this requires more than one trip) the Samusa soup, described as "Soup made of bean base, curry leaf, broken samusa, lentil, crunchy yellow bean, cabbage, onion and mint leaf", and Mango, the vegetarian Egg Roll, the Basil Spicy Pork, all these are mandatory to try. Even the Tangerine Wheat beer was great.

This was one of the best Asian meals I've ever had in my whole life!
author: Grazia B.

description: Our 1st visit was perfect, so perfect we're afraid to go back!  Found parking in front, seated in less than 10 mins (and there were several people waiting-easy to squeeze in 2), waited on almost immediately (we decided what we wanted while waiting to be seated) and served quickly, efficiently and very friendly. The food was excellent.: the dense, crispy pancake with yellow curry dipping sauce for an appetizer was disgustingly delicious, we wolfed it down; we split the Ong No Kaw Sei (chicken noodle soup) which was rich and flavorful; and finished with the Kaw Soi Dok (Burmese style noodle), a unique dish which is hands down one of my new favorites. Go eat here!
author: Kim G.

description:
FANTASTIC! Best meal we've had in SF after living here for a month. Tea leaf salad was excellent, a true Burmese experience! The Mandalay Special Noodle was delicious too and the lime leaf in it, was so good. Both dishes were hand tossed at the table. 

The food on other people's tables were so colorful and looked delicious. Professional, attentive service and an authentic atmosphere. Great experience! Highly recommend.
author: Anna E.

description:
My friend and I visited on a Friday night around 8. The wait was about 5 minutes, which wasn't bad at all considering the popularity of this place. Sadly, we weren't impressed. 

The pork stew was the best of what we ordered. However, I don't find it worth the price point as there were only 3 chunks of pork and a couple chunks of pumpkin. The coconut rice we ordered tasted great though. The noodle dish we ordered was pretty underwhelming as well, lacking in flavor, and also came out of the kitchen lukewarm. The half order of crispy chicken was nothing special; don't bother ordering this dish. 

1 star for the food; there are many great Burmese places in the city. The additional star is for the friendly service as we were consistently checked up on. If you are claustrophobic, do not dine here. The tables are placed very closely together. There is decent amount of street parking in the area. I probably won't be back.
author: Kristi T.

description:
I saw the number of the reviews and ratings and thought it was too good to pass up. When I got in I was a liiiiitle disappointed because it looked like every other Chinese restaurant you might find in China Town. There weren't that many people and I admittedly made a few comments while ordering... (you'll see what I mean) and then they brought the Mandalay Chicken w/ Mango over. I took back everything bad I said.

It was kinda slippery if that's a way to describe chicken but the sauce was amazing! I'm honestly not sure how to describe it beyond salty/savory but it has some flavors I wasn't very familiar with and went awesome with the mangos. It looks fairly simple just chicken and mango with some onions and jalapeños but wow the little drip of sauce in the plate was so tasty! Make sure to try some of their hot sauce they bring the table, it's not really spicy but it has some great flavor!

I'm surprised it didn't come with rice but when I ordered they told me it was coconut rice. I've had a lot of coconut rice before but the one here you can really taste it cooked into the rice!!! I'm so excited to come back and try some other dishes. 

About 18 for chicken and rice. Felt kinda pricey. Food was worth though.
author: Frank C.

description:
The flavors here are to die for. You must try: Tea Leaf Salad (~$12.50), Mandalay Special Noodle (~$14), jasmine tea (the tea bag BLOOOMS into a flower), the Burmese national dish Mohinga (~$12.50). 

The staff is super nice and will treat the birthday girl/ boy very well (with some surprizes at the end too). Worth it!
author: Ting T.

description:
I'd say that Mandalay was my first exposure to Burmese food and you absolutely cannot go wrong by starting here. While the restaurant is busy, it's not packed and service is quick and feels personal as your food is served to you and semi-prepared and mixed in front of you at your table (depending on the dish you ordered of course).

Burmese food is colourful, flavourful and intimidating if it's something you've never had before. To be honest, I went over the menu, then wound up looking at what other people around me had ordered and trying to match up what they had on their plates with what the description was on the menu! Since I'd never had anything like this before, I wanted to try something different so I chose the Mandalay Special Noodle with tofu since the yellow pea powder kept grabbing my eye whenever I saw plates go past (you really can't help notice that bright yellow ingredient!)

Our plates came out and the Special Noodle plate is deconstructed: the noodles, pea powder, vegetables, tofu and sauce are all separated on the plate. The server then puts them all together right there in front of you and mixes it all up, so you get to see half the fun of the preparation process.

The flavours are strong and intense, but this is worth experiencing. There's nothing overpowering and I loved what I ordered. I can't wait to try more!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Old Mandalay fan but haven't been in a few years. 
Pros: tasty chicken yellow curry and great chicken potato samosas. Service attentive. Crowd interesting. 
Cons: I have a battery assist bicycle and asked if I could charge my battery there while I ate. After some fits and starts they refused to do it. It uses about 4 cents an hour of electricity when charging. 
I don't think that was it but it was surprising being mid afternoon and not that busy.  I did run out of juice near home as predicted. 

The house wines used to be Kendal Jackson.  It was admittedly generous that they poured this label as house wine. The house wine is now Woodbridge and the glass I got besides being Woodbridge was corked. I didn't drink it. 

So.... my 3 star resting is based on the wine/battery stuff.
author: James T.

description:
Mandalay might look like a dated venue from the outside, but once you settle down inside, you'll find that the Burmese fare here is quite decent and reasonably priced, given the portions.

I enjoyed the Mandalay special noodle (Burmese flat noodles with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas, powder lime juice, onion, and minced fried thin noodles) as well as the Rangoon beef (marinated beef with spices, sauteed with tomato, onions, and green chili). Nothing was too sweet or too spicy - it was all perfectly decent. 

Service was courteous, and the venue is basically one large dining room that can fill up quickly on the weekends. It's a good, inexpensive choice for groups large and small.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I've been coming to Mandalay since the womb. This classic, OG Burmese restaurant serves authentic, no frills, food.

Favorites: 
Samusa (either)
Samusa Soup
Tea Leaf Salad
Nan Gyi Dok
Coconut Rice
Burmese Style Curry Chicken
Spicy Tofu w/ Vegetables
Sauteed Pea Shoots
author: Shannon M.

description: Absolutely love this place. Definitely a must whenever me and my fiancé are in town visiting, which is frequently. The food is delicious and filling. The ambiance is great and the staff is friendly and attentive to your needs. Serving sizes are pretty big, so very much shareable if you are going on a date or going with a group of people. Like most places in SF, this place is also vegetarian friendly as well. The Mandalay Special Noodle is one of my favorite dishes to get here. So many options to choose from all so delicious.
author: Phillip V.

description: The food itself is 4stars but I am very annoyed at how they upsold and made us buy 2 extra dishes even after we ordered 3 appetizers and 4 entrees for 5 adults. I said we will order more later and the waitress still insisted that it won't be enough . In the end we had leftover food worth 3 dishes.
author: Balu V.

description:
Why is this place in business? The service is so awful, I really really wonder why people like it or ever come back. I've never been treated with such disrespect as a patron at a restaurant, and from reading other reviews, it's clear it's not a one-off bad night for them, but a serious flaw in their service approach.

Came here on a weeknight, not busy, no reservations for a birthday with a party of four. They sat us quickly, but the experience went downhill from there. We ordered water and our appetizers/entrees within ten minutes of being seated (we had to wait that amount of time to be greeted). After taking our order, waitress whisks away and isn't seen again. We chat, watching as other parties are seated around us. After 20 minutes, our appetizers have not arrived. As someone in the service industry, I think to myself, okay, maybe the kitchen is backed up, no biggie. 

Another 10 minutes and no food of ours has arrived, but I notice that the tables who got seated after us receive their entire order. We ask a food runner if he can check on the food- he gives us a puzzled/frantic look and I watch as he tries to spot our server. It is clear to me that she had completely forgotten to put in our orders at all, because I watched her then talk to the kitchen and enter in our orders on the computer. No apologies or explanation. After over 45 minutes of being seated with just water, we get the one appetizer we ordered. It takes another 10 minutes for the entrees to get here, albeit not at the same time. The food was subpar- the samosa soup we had ordered was soggy and disappointing. 

Server comes to ask how the food is, we say that it's fine but we were disappointed to have waited so long. We get our check and they haven't comped a thing or given any apologies. This is not service. 

My friend went back a few months later to try again, only to again wait over half an hour for entrees (while other folks seated after her get their food first). They kept trying to take her plates away, she told the busser she'd like to keep her plate and she picked it up anyway, to the point where she had to forcefully take her plate of food back. They tried to bus full or half amounts of beer- ATROCIOUS! We will never, EVER come back. I'd rather wait two hours for Burma Superstar than to ever come back here and feel the way this place makes me feel.
author: Hannah H.

description: Great food! Love the Mango Salad and the Mango Chicken.  Portions are on the small side.
author: Elaine T.

description: Portion size was very small for the price. The tea leaf salad did not have any lettuce and was tiny and weird tasting.
author: Supriya S.

description:
We are a big fan of Thai food but decided to try Burmese food for a change. The place was bustling but we were seated within 10 minutes. 

We ordered the following:

Rainbow Salad (billed as 20 ingredient salad and the server mixes the ingredients in front of you - average salad)
Spicy Tofu with Garlic Sauce (my order - tasted average, like any other Asian stir fry)
Burmese Style Curry Chicken (my husband really liked this, he loves Thai curry and this was slightly different)
Nan Gyi Dok  (my daughter is a big noodle fan but found this to be average in taste)
Rangoon Spicy Fish (my son liked this, just the right amount of spices)

The servers were polite and efficient, the food was good, portions were decent, and prices were slightly high.
author: Sherry H.

description:
Our Cousin took us here on our recent visit to SF. Never had Burmese food before. It's a mix between Thai and Indian food. 

We were so impressed with this place. Our cousin arrived before us and had a table right away. It was 2p on a Saturday. I was told they are normally very busy. There is usually a long wait. The place was still busy even though it was between lunch and dinner. 

Service was impeccable. The flower tea was so unique and beautiful. All the dishes that we had were vibrant, flavorful and delicious. I can see why our cousin takes all their visitors to this place. We will definitely be back when in SF again. 

Coconut rice, saffron rice, tea leaf salad, chicken curry noodles, volcano beef and some shrimp dish. All amazing!
author: Nikki A.

description:
Was actually taking an uber a month ago to another Burmese spot, and it turned out the driver was Burmese. He said this was his actually his favorite restaurant so i decided I needed to come check it out. 

It is a bit dated inside. It looks like they haven't remodeled it in 30 years or so. It is clean, just the decor and everything is a bit old school. 

The menu was robust. Lots for the vegetarian and meat eater.

The food was good, not amazing. Started with the tea leaf salad, how would I not right?! I have been to a few Burmese places and it has traditionally been mixed with some lettuce as well. Not sure what is the standard right way(if there is one).

The eggplant was OK. Skinned and fried. The sauce was really thick and sweet. The beans were a bit oily and a slightly spicier sauce. They had a little side of crushed chilis in oil which helped spice things up.

The people were really nice and overall would definitely recommend it for anyone wanting to try an alternative to the other existing and well known Burmese places.
author: Sean M.

description: Tea Leaf salad is a MUST. The Okra Prawn dish was fabulous, the Burmese lemonade was delicious, everything was incredible.
author: Zahra H.

description: Will not return. Nothing outstanding but the hot tea, presentation excellent. Service was attentive. Wasn't impressed with food. Balada was tasteless without the curry sauce. Rainbow salad couldn't taste ingredients but the salad dressing. Mandalay Special Noodles we both didn't enjoy. We both will not return.
author: P M.

description:
Three and a half stars. 

Several people told me they preferred the food at Mandalay to the food at Burma Superstar and I'm torn. I think the food at Burma Superstar is probably better than the food at Mandalay but overall, I would probably come back to Mandalay in the future if the wait at BSS is as long as it often is. Mandalay is still busy but no where near as insane, they take reservations, and the restaurant is much less crowded so you can actually hear the people you are dining with. 

Food wise, my favorite thing by far was the shrimp and okra. Absolutely delicious, the flavors were simple - garlic mostly, but everything was well cooked and each bite had a ton of flavor. The balada - basically roti paratha - was also really good, and came with a massive paratha, larger than I've seen at most other places. Loved the sauce with it also. The  singapore noodles (made vegetarian but without tofu) were also pretty good. 

Everything else we tried was pretty average, with some things lacking flavor. The spicy tofu with vegetables was alright, but nothing special.  The burmese fried rice had zero flavor and was prety dissapointing; same with the pumpkin chicken curry- I wished it had a lot more flavor and more pieces of pumpkin. 

Service is a bit chaotic, as you don't have a dedicated waiter but instead everyone kind of serves every table. They had a shortage of menus and kept trying to take ours away, eventually making us use 2-3 menus for a table of 6. One waiter was a bit curt and rude too- we asked him about one of our appetizers as it had been a while, just to make sure they were making it. He told us it wasn't "fast food" and had a fairly weird response where he almost chastised us for asking. The waiters also had a tendency of trying to clear plates when we were either not done or just barely done which created a bit of an uncomfortable dining experience. 

All in all, I'd give them somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. I would consider coming back and probably ordering the things I enjoyed the most like the shrimp and okra while skipping a lot of the other options on the menu. 3 stars for now.
author: Seema U.

description:
I give Mandalay one star for the complete lack of service. This happened on three occasions:

1. Making a reservation for 8:00pm and being seated at 8:20pm after being on time and having groups who did not have a reservation seated before us.

2. The food came out one dish at a time over the course of 40 minutes so the food served at the beginning was cold by the time the last person got their entree.

3. The staff was incredibly aggressive about removing food before we were finished, asking several times to take dishes before we were done with them. 

Overall, this was an unacceptable experience and I do not recommend coming to Mandalay under any circumstance
author: Andrew M.

description: Stop by here for an early dinner and we ordered the papaya salad and the eggs okra Curry they both were very sweet customer service was okay steady stream of clients coming in we probably won't come back again
author: Jasmine H.

description: Had dinner here tonight, ordered the rainbow salad, vegetarian soup, Mandalay noodles, and the special of the day, prawns with peppers and basil. The best part of the meal was the salad, but the other dishes were just so-so, maybe I was expecting too much after reading all the yelp reviews. The prawns tasted previously frozen, the noodles were like mush, but the service was kind and friendly. I'd much rather go to anyone of the Burma Superstar restaurants, or my favorite one in the town of Larkspur.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
Finally made it to Mandalay! Before I moved to SF a few years ago, I didn't even know what burmese food was and now I can't get enough of it. There are so many amazing burmese restaurant options in SF and I'm not mad about it. Mandalay is not my absolute fav but still a great choice if you're looking for Burmese food in SF. 

The food itself was so so good and flavorful but there were a few things that I was disappointed by. First of all, the portion sizes here are a bit disappointing. We ordered 2 tea lead salads and the 2 salads combined looked smaller than the size of one tea leaf salad at Burma Love. Speaking of tea leaf salads, there is no lettuce in this salad (which is maybe why the portion is smaller?) which I was bummed about. Other than these 2 things, I like this restaurant a lot. The service is great too!
author: Ilana B.

description:
Love this place! We had the have been here a couple of times and I absolutely love what they have here. One of my favorite things to get when we come here is the Burmese tea 
Salad! It is a must! So flavorful and crunchy. The food is so tasty and the service is good. 

Last time we were there we tried the mango lassi and the coconut drink. They are absolutely delicious if you want to try a sweet drink.
author: Mariana V.

description: The server tried to "upsell" noodles to my soup that already came with noodles...She was actually pretty rude. They still had their Christmas decorations in May, and the restaurant had an offensive odor. I wish I had just walked out!
author: Bogee B.

description:
It was Saturday night and we got to the restaurant around 6:30pm. We got seated right away and got our menus. I ordered Jasmine tea and it actually came with the actual flower which was pretty cool. You can see the flower opening up in the hot water. As for the food, my friend and I ordered tea leaf salad, mango chicken and coconut soup. 
Tea leaf salad was good but I think I prefer it with some lettuce. It tastes similar to other Burmese places I've been to but I think it tastes better with the lettuce to be honest. I didn't know that you can order with the lettuce until I read other people's review on the tea leaf salad which was a bummer. Next time!
Mango chicken was good. The chicken was flavorful and the mangoes were sweet. The chicken was juicy and not dry at all which was good. 
The coconut soup was also another good dish to try. The coconut soups I've had from other restaurants are pretty salty but this one was pretty good. 

Overall our time at Mandalay was pretty good. The service was great and I liked that the servers checked up on us every so often. I would love to try other things on the menu next time!
author: Monica W.

description: A friend recommended Mandalay to me on my recent SF trip, so naturally I had to check it out. Our wait was not too bad considering it was a Saturday night (~25min for 5 ppl) and the popularity of the Burmese restaurants around the Richmond district. The tea leaf salad, while highly spoken of on Yelp, is not all that Mandalay has to offer for your tummy! The tea leaf smoked duck for example is definitely worth a try--a totally different preparation of roasted duck and it's sooo tender. Also delicious on the menu: the roti with curry appetizer, mango chicken, and mandalay noodles. Frankly, I don't think you can go wrong with anything on their menu! Other pluses, absolutely terrific service and great ambiance. Mandalay makes for a great spot for any kind of meal, be it celebrations, romantic dinner, or a family/friends outing. Will definitely be back if I'm ever back in the Richmond area!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Came here with my gf and her friend for a much needed fuel up. 
Staff seemed friendly enough... 
Had a manager that said we could have half veggie and half chicken samosa only to have lady who I can assume was the owner, tell us that they won't.
My gf ordered the tea salad and was disappointed it didn't come with lettuce, just a bunch of nuts which I suppose is the traditional way. So no fault on them for that. But she did order a dish and asked if she could have fried tofu added to which she was told that it wouldn't taste good and that the normal soft tofu would be better. 
My gf gave in only to wait another 20 minutes where they dropped off the check and when I inquired about the dish she immediately made it seem like we canceled the dish with a final "there must have been a miscommunication." 

It was bizarre hearing her tell us it was our fault and to think the miscommunication was a justification of what had happened is preposterous. I would think a server should be clear if a guest had made an actual order or not with a simple, "Would you like anything else?" Especially if they asked to order another entree.

Prices were pretty expensive for a $$ rating. Service was not accommodating nor consistent. 

I won't say it was a horrible time but it did leave a bad impression and won't be coming back.
author: Shaun S.

description: Yum yum yum!! Stumbled upon this place by accident and was so happy we did!! We got the walnut broccoli tofu and also tea leaf salad. Both were absolutely delicious. I'll definitely come back here.
author: Magda M.

description: Good food. When you want Burmese and can't stand the thought of waiting for an hour trapped bretwixt the hipsters on line at Burma Star, just go up to Mandalay. It gets busy, the lighting is bad, they've crammed in a few too many tables to create any ambience to speak of, and on weekends the wait staff can't wait to get you out (seriously, they will come grab food trays half full and try to take your plate away between bites!) so I took one star off, but the food (esp. the tea leaf salad) is really good. try on weeknights when it's a little more quiet.
author: Tricia M.

description: We visited Mandalay last night for dinner. I loved everything about this place. It has maybe the craziest decor I've seen in a very long time but some how you feel good sitting in the packed house of eaters. My favorite dish was the house noodles. I could eat that dish three times a week. We will return.  NOM!
author: C J.

description: The food and flavors here are great :) parking is frequently a challenge tho . Also no reservations, I think? The interior is ornate and a little dated, gets a little packed! - friendly service and !tea leaf salad!- my favorite. Enjoyed big group dinners here and small intimate gatherings... They always do an excellent job.
author: Coco J.

description:
Came here on a Monday night at 8pm and had no wait even though the restaurant was packed.  Service was also quite fast.

We started with the tea leaf salad which doesn't come with lettuce since they have a different "crunchier" preference for their version.  We then had mango chicken with rice and it was absolutely delicious -  the flavors were amazing and the jalapeños were perfect.  We then finished with the Mandalay special noodles which were also so delicious with an interesting flavor profile and different fun textures since there was crunchiness and soft noodles plus cilantro and coconut flavors.  Loved the side of hot sauce too.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Siv L.

description: Would give it 6 stars if I could! I came here to eat twice the past week because it was my birthday and wanted to treat myself :) Absolutely delicious food, love the Special Noodle dish and the tea leaf salad. They also do decent portion sizes for wine! Very well seasoned, nuanced food and excellent, friendly service as well. My #1 go-to in the Bay Area!
author: Ella W.

description: Always LOVE the food here and I've been going to this place since 2005. However, one thing that always trouble me is that even when they take reservations, they don't actually hold the table for you. Multiple times I've made reservations and aways ended up waiting at least 10-15 minutes when showing up. The last time I was there I made a reservation for 5 people for 8pm. We showed up on time and were not seated until 8:30. And no one apologized that we waited even with reservation. I always wondering why would they take reservations if that doesn't mean anything to them. Will probably not going back there for a while
author: Hien L.

description:
I know I'm seriously a sheltered person. Blame it on my insecurities or the way I was raised.  Well when a friend suggested meeting up here for the first time I was a bit hesitant as I've never had Burmese food before. It was more important to me that we meet up so I was more than willing to try it.

I looked up online to see what Burmese food was all about. It has several different influences consisting of Chinese, Indian & Southeast Asian. I thought to myself that I'm good with that as I've eaten each individual cuisine separately! I instantly went to Yelp for reviews & tips on this particular restaurant. It actually looked promising!

I checked google map to see if parking was tough which it could be so we parked a couple miles away in Japantown where we love to frequent! We used Lyft to get ourselves there. All of us met up early before the restaurant actually opened.

We walked in early and they seated all five of us right away.  We decided to eat Chinese family style which meant sharing all of our dishes. The waiter wouldn't seat us five at a circular table which requires six people. It was okay as all of us were very courteous and passed all of our dishes all around to take pics and get our food.

First came out the traditional tea leaf salad. The waiter showed us our dish and waited patiently for us to take our pics. He then gingerly mixed the salad to prepare it for us savoring it. I totally enjoyed it as unique and flavorful as it was!!! I loved the mix of the grains and nuts. This was uncharted territory as I have never had this before but I enjoyed it to the fullest!

Next the waiter brought out the rainbow salad. Now he was super quick to mix it right away. So unfortunately I missed out on pics of the initial salad. It was truly amazing in taste even with a little spicy kick. It was more of a noodle salad much more different than the nut/grainy tea leaf salad.

After the two yummy salads we had three more entrees to feast on. Our waiter initially insisted on us ordering more food but we were satisfied with our choices. Out came the curry beef, mango chicken, Singapore noodles & coconut rice.

Wow. Wow. Wow. I've been truly missing out on Burmese food. Everything was so very delicious and on point. I could kick myself for waiting so long to try this kind of food.

By the time we finished our lunch it looked like the restaurant was almost full to capacity. I can understand why as the hype is real. You are paying for the quality so it can get a bit pricey. But I did see that they do take credit cards here. Another plus was that they had a restroom available. 

Hopefully one day we will be back!!!
author: Karen K.

description:
