This might be the best Burmese place in SF. Their Tea Leaf salad is delicious and does not contain any lettuce like almost every other one in the city. Their service is excellent.

You may have to wait 30-45 min as there's usually a line to get in, but obviously​ it's more than worth the wait. This is also a great place to go on Holidays like Christmas as they're always open!

Go get some tea leaf salad :) I want me some now just writing this review.
author: Anubhav J.

description:
I have been enjoying this location in the neighborhood for several decades.  l suggest ordering family-style, even for lunch.

A good tasting variety includes the tea leaf salad with Jalapenos and roasted garlic, mango salad, Singapore noodles, Mandalay beef, Shaking Duck with spinach and pumpkin, and coconut rice.

Try their Special Jasmine Flower Art Tea or the fresh coconut.

But, do save room for desert!  Black Sticky Rice with Coconut Ice Cream and Sticky Rice with seasonal Crash Sweet Mango.

Typical of San Francisco neighborhoods, parking can be difficult.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I'd say food wise this place is not as good as Burma superstar but there's no wait and service is quick so it's easier to come here if you want your Burmese food fix!

The tea leaf salad here doesn't have any lettuce and the portion sizes seem smaller than Burma superstars. Nevertheless it tasted similarly.

The coconut rice here isn't as sweet or fragrant which was disappointing. We also got the fish stew which was decent. 

The service here is much better and they're very fast with orders. Would come back here to try more dishes!
author: Sunny K.

description: Went there for a friend's birthday and invited my family a few days later. Both times I had a good experience and the food and handmade drinks are out of this world! I don't think there's anything to avoid on the menu. It's not too spicy, which is usually my pet peeve about Indian and Thai food. None of that with Burmese cuisine. Had to try their dessert special: sweet potato cake, vanilla ice cream and fruit slices. So worth it!
author: Matthew C.

description: This place is great. The service is super friendly, the food is quick, and you don't have to wait in line as long as Burma Superstar. They have great decorations. It's comfortable and well heated. They really should have five stars not four.
author: Lucy E.

description: We were all invited to join family and friends at the sf location. The hostess ordered for the table so we didn't realize exploring the menu the way we wanted to. However, the green tea salad and raw green papaya salad...together are incredible. Worth going back just for those. Really small place, not much parking but typical of many sf places.
author: Sanaa H.

description: I recently went to Mandalay with my family for a birthday. I've been a loyal customer for over 5 years and have never had a problem till my last visit . The food was good as usual but when I paid my bill I left a 20% cash tip with my credit card for the bill .The waiter then loudly came out afterwards and said no tip was left , this was very embarrassing especially when I was paying and I'm a repeat customer who always tips and even when I pick up to go . After this experience , I will never go back . Bad communication with the guy in charge and the wait staff ..
author: Salvador S.

description: Love this place! Ginger lemonade, tea salad, mango chicken, and Burmese noodles were all delicious. Plenty of seating inside. Perfect for big groups eating family style.
author: Joe M.

description:
Fav was the samusas soup. Had some crispy cake like thing in it that was quite tasty.

Also got tea leaf salad. It kind of smelled like poop, was a different taste but nothing too special.

Curry lamb was average. Like musselman curry maybe.

Service was 5 stars though! 5 different people asked if wanted anything to drink since our water didnt come yet. Also apologized that we had to wait. Very friendly as well as i recorded how they made tea salad.
author: Sean L.

description:
Mandalay was great! I never had Burmese food before so I didn't know what to expect, but the food was delicious and the service was excellent. They even had a fobby happy birthday audio track for people's birthday! 

We ordered the tea leaf salad and rainbow salad both traditional without the lettuce.The tea leaf salad was a combination of nuts while the rainbow had veggies and noodles. Both were good and very light and easy to eat. Then we ordered samusas, mango chicken, string beans and the mandalay noodles. They were all amazing. I loved the mango in the chicken as it was soft and cooked to perfection and the mandalay noodles had a crunchy component to it which I really enjoyed. Don't forget to order some coconut rice with your meal as well! Overall, this place went above and beyond my expectations. The wait wasn't even too bad on a Friday night. I'd say we waited maybe 20 minutes. I will definitely come back here again!
author: Tim W.

description:
My first experience with a Burmese cuisine. Started off with the Burmese Ice tea which was tasty!! Chicken Satay and Volcano Lamb was delicious. I must say the the experience was impressive. 

Pros: Taste and Quantity
Cons: parking
author: Vinodh Kumar C.

description:
I discovered this restaurant years ago and fell in love with the Green Tea Salad. 

Today I got back to the restaurant, and my experience was suburb! From all the flavors and textures in every delicious meal we ordered to the extremely attentive and not annoying service I have been blown away! 

The day before I had an opportunity to dine at RN74 one of the Michael Minna's restaurants where our server did not bother to bring us items we ordered. Today I am eating at the Burmese restaurant in outskirts of the city, and the service was outstanding. 

Want to give big thanks to the continued high-quality food preparation and the delightful service from everyone who works here. 

Today we ordered in addition to the tea leaf salad, asparagus chicken and eggplant with brown rice. Both dishes were appetizing, and we loved it very much.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Good food good service good vibes

Got the tea leaf salad and volcano beef, would recommend both
author: Lawrence J.

description:
Food was good but here are my pain points and will never go back.

- Made reservation for 9 adults + high chair for 7:30pm accepting the T&C that cancellation within 24 hours would result in a charge of $10 per person. Arrived 5 minutes before the reservation but was made to wait outside in the cold for a little over an hour. We were seated by 8:30pm

- The server comes to our table, showed us the drink menu and then starts rushing to place order. I asked him to bring us water for the table and give us a few mins to decide on our drinks. He comes back takes half the order and then goes back to place the order for water which he forgot. He then returns to take the order for the remaining drinks
- About 8:45ish. He comes and takes order for appetizers again in two part. The second time around he mentions that we better be ready with main course order when he comes around next else we will need to take it to-go as he has a lot of people waiting outside. I had to ask him to repeat himself to believe it. He mentioned kitchen overflowing, people are waiting so he needs to flip the tables

This was a family/friend event after a long time and I thought it unfair to create a scene and ruin the evening for the rest of people there. We paid our bill and left.
author: Kunal V.

description:
Mandalay is one of the top Burmese restaurants that i've tried so far! I'm a bit new to Burmese food, but everything was soo good here! I came with 2 of my girlfriends and we decided to order 4 dishes.

- Tea leaf salad: One of the main things to remember about the salad here is that it does not come with lettuce!!! You must ask for the lettuce when you order, or they will assume you want it the "traditional way" without lettuce. I'm not sure if I would order it without the lettuce because I can imagine the fermented tea having a very strong taste, so we ordered lettuce with ours. The salad had the perfect blend of savory flavors and had the perfect ratio of lettuce to crunchies. It had a little heat too from the jalapenos. Tea leaf salad is a must order at any Burmese place!

- Mango chicken: I would say this was one of my favorite dishes here! The chicken was covered in a sweet sauce and went very well with the mangoes. Usually I don't like cooked or even warm fruit but I enjoyed this dish a lot. The chicken was not dry but perfectly cooked.

- Balada: This was a Burmese pancake (sort of like a "roti") with a curry dipping sauce. The pancake is a bit on the thicker side so it is definitely filling! It was more on the dough-y side than flakey (like banana island) and the curry dipping sauce was thick and had a strong curry flavor.

- Mandalay special noodles: Yumm!! These noodles came unmixed to the table and it was mixed in front of us (same with the tea leaf salad). It had fried noodles (yay more crunchies) on top which added more texture to the soft noodles! There was an abnormally large amount of cilantro in it, so maybe ask your waiter to omit that if you're not a cilantro lover haha. The curry sauce was on the thinner side but still good. 

Service was very friendly and we were actually seated pretty quickly for a Sunday night! I would love to come back to try more menu items! It's a good idea to come in a larger group to try a variety of things, rather than coming with just another person and only getting to try a few. Our total ended up being $20 each, which isn't too bad because we ordered 4 things!
author: Tara A.

description:
This place is OK. Serving sizes are small and let me just put it out there that this restaurant is absolutely WAY too small for all their employees to be using ear pieces...so so EXTRA!! Seems like this place really takes pride in what they serve. 

Now the food..that leaf salad was way too small to serve 3 people...I could of ate that myself! None of the other menu items really stood out to me. Came here because I was craving the tea leaf salad but def not worth it for the price with the amount they give. Not impressed, pass.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Very good!  Food was attractive, fresh and prepared wonderfully.  Taste was excellent.  Service was top notch, all were helpful and cheerful!  Atmosphere was comfortable.  
We arrived about 4:30, without reservations and were sat immediately.  However when we left their were people lined up waiting.
You will enjoy and want to come back soon!
author: Babs Z.

description:
This is my favorite Burmese place in SF. I feel it's more authentic in decor and cuisine, than you'd get at the other Burmese restaurants popping up which I feel are more hipster.

As always, get the Tea Leaf Salad. A must. 
Ong No Kaw Soi (coconut Chicken Noodle Soup). I order this every time... then usually get an order to go as well for later lol. 
Mandalay Special Noodle, also really good, with a lot of great flavors.
author: Mandi W.

description:
This was my first time at Mandalay - the food was delicious and the staff friendly. However, I had a difficult experience because I was trying to surprise my boyfriend with his favorite dessert after dinner (Mitchell's ice cream). I requested no singing or acknowledgment of his birthday because he doesn't like that sort of thing - which was respected for the most part. 

I had called the restaurant beforehand and spoken to the manager explaining that I'd wanted the ice cream to come out after dinner - he said no problem. I got there early and they were very busy. I gave the ice cream to one of the staff, asking her to put it in the freezer, and she said she would tell her manager. I "went to the restroom" a couple of times just to make sure no signing would happen and to ask them to bring out the ice cream. Once I sat back down one of the staff members came over to me and told me the ice cream was melted and offered to bring out their homemade ice cream - I thought perhaps as a courtesy for their mistake. I was very confused as to why the dessert I brought was not put in the freezer as requested, but agreed. 

I was also charged the mango ice cream. I liked the food, and overall the experience was nice, but this was pretty frustrating. I know that they were busy, but I also made several attempts before arriving and during my meal to make sure my request was clearly understood. It did not feel like it really mattered to them one way or another if this (pretty simple, all things considered) request was done correctly.
author: Tatiana G.

description:
Stumbled upon this restaurant after going to the De Young Museum. I was super hungry and was drawn in by the bright yellow exterior and the prospect of eating delicious noodles. 

I ordered the nan gyi dok (noodles with curry coconut chicken). Service was quick and my food arrived in 5-10 mins after ordering. The waiter was very nice and asked if I had ever had this dish before. I said no, and he kindly introduced each of the delicious components that made up the dish, and then mixed the noodles for me so all the flavors were blended together perfectly. The nan gyi dok was scrumptious and savory with a nice fresh note of cilantro. 

I also had to badly charge my phone. While they weren't able to seat me near an outlet, the manager offered to charge my phone at the cash register counter, which was above and beyond what I would expect in customer service. 

Overall, the restaurant seems to have quite a few regulars and I'd love to come back to try more of the delicious stuff on the menu.
author: Connie K.

description:
Yo, skip the line at Burma superstar and head here instead. Burma superstar is way overrated! The hype ain't real there.
Go to Mandalay and get some REAL Burmese food. I've had authentic Burmese food when I was in Northern Thailand (Burma is Thailands neighbors for those of you with American geography haha). 

I'm sorry Burma Superstar you ain't the shit Mandalay takes the cake on that.

Must order the tea leaf salad (duh!) and Mandalay special noodle.
author: Amber T.

description: I always take out of town guests to Burma Superstar, mostly for the name and to demonstrate how agonizing the wait is at every single popular restaurant in SF. But Mandalay is my local neighborhood secret. It's still popular, but they have a bigger space, take reservation for larger groups, and the wait is no where as insane. Price is great for the amount of food (ex. ordered $87 worth of food to go last Friday, food was ready for pick up in 20min, fed myself and two hungry dudes, and the leftover lasted me two more meals). Excellent service and friendly staff. The food is just as tasty as Burma Superstar, if not better. If you are looking for delicious Burmese food and don't give a crap about restaurant brand, then Mandalay is your best bet!
author: Nana L.

description:
Good grief WTF happened here! The service is ATROCIOUS

Asking for tea... asking for water... asking for our bill... We asked for everything multiple times from various staff. WHAT HAPPENED!? This place isn't that big! I turned into a grumpy asshole there last night. 

Portions seemed smaller than they were in the past too. I left still hungry..
author: Susy C.

description: A nice burmese joint in the inner richmond area. Had the tea leaf salad, mandalay chicken and the burmese fish curry. I'd give it 3.5 stars. I've had better burmese food in Burma (of course!) but also in the bay area. That being said, its' still pretty good food. Very nice decor as well, they have given it a very authentic burmese feel.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
Good place. Nothing spectacular but has a good vibe and the food is priced well. There was a little bit of a wait but the lady was nice and offered to order drinks to get us going if we wanted.

Dinner
* Rangoon Lamb (Good)
* Burmese Style Curry Chicken (Good)
* Tea Leaf Salad (Ok)
* Coconut Rice (Good)
author: Kristofer E.

description: This is the best Burmese cuisine I've had hands down. The dishes are full of flavor, the ambiance is great and the service is like no other. This is one of those restaurants that is perfect for taking out-of-towners to. Try all of their salads, especially the tea leaf. It's so nutty and balanced and most importantly isn't watered down with lettuce like other tea leaf salads I've tried.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I've never understood why everyone is so hung up on Burma Superstar. Mandalay is obviously the cuter, tastier, more authentic option just a couple of blocks away.

The only bad thing about this place is having to make a choice on what you want to eat, based on their vast menu. Take friends so you can eat all the things.
author: Reishi A.

description: Really liked this place.  It's a great alternative to Burma Superstar.  However, make sure you add lettuce when you get the tea leaf salad - it doesn't automatically come with it.  Also the burlada is AMAZING.  Highly recommend that.
author: Amanda B.

description:
My first time here with a few friends. This place is small and lighting is very dark. We ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, mandalay special noodle, hot sizzling soup, pan fried string beans, coconut rice and two dessert (sweet potato -hot, and coconut jelly-cold). 

Honestly the food is just average and they have super tiny portions. 

I think I have tried better Burmese food else where. Don't think I'll come back. Four girls, the cost was $93 without tip.
author: Yuri Y.

description: Dope food with the atmosphere expected of a casual Asian restaurant. My really liked the balada as an appetizer and the tapioca drink. Docked down to three stars though because of the painfully slow service - food came out pretty quickly but we just could not get our check. I'll be back because of the food, but might just get it to go so I don't have to deal with the wait...
author: Jason X.

description:
I don't know much about Burmese food, but I know I like it! A friend recommended this restaurant. I had not heard of it at the time, so I was surprised when I found the restaurant was busy and there was a bit of a wait. Since then, I've been to Mandalay a handful of times and left satisfied each time.

The restaurant is a bright green & yellow on the outside with an even funkier interior. There are a bunch of Christmas lights strung up, some statuesque artwork on the walls, neon-lighted palm trees, and a gong. The gong is my favorite piece.

Burmese Iced Tea - as far as I can tell, not much difference from a Thai iced tea
Ginger Beer - very sweet, minty, citrus-y and refreshing

Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok) - salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing:
First, the ingredients are presented on a plate that looks nothing like a salad. The server drizzles some dressing on top, and expertly mixes everything together until it resembles something like peanut dip. The flavors are complex, very savory, crunchy, and slightly spicy. I could eat two plates  of this stuff.
I've had a couple of tea leaf salads in the past that had a lot of lettuce. Mr. Joy, who grew up on homemade Burmese food said that a traditional tea leaf salad doesn't have lettuce. The lettuce is simply a filler.

Coconut Rice:
Fried coconut strands resembling shoestring fries lie on top of a bowl of rice. So simple, but makes the rice better.

Balada - Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce:
This must be the Burmese version of roti or paratha. I appreciate that it is cut in 6, which makes for easier sharing. It is very soft, almost crepe-like, but savory. The curry dipping sauce is really good too, very creamy and not too spicy.

Burmese Style Curry Chicken - Burmese style yellow curry chicken with potatoes:
very tender chicken with smooth & creamy curry, and potatoes soaked up curry flavor. It's a rather small portion.

Mandalay Special Noodle - Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion, fried thin noodle on top:
The coconut broth is very creamy and quite sweet while the cilantro brightens it up a bit. The flat noodles are silky smooth, almost slippery, while the fried noodles add crunch and texture. The dish could use a little more chicken though. 

Most of the dishes seem very similar to other types of Southeast Asian dishes, which makes sense, since a lot of the culture and cuisine overlapped over time. The only dish that I felt was completely new to me was the tea leaf salad, so I always order it. Other than the tea leaf salad, I aim to try new things when I come here. The other soup & noodle dishes are delicious, albeit all pretty similar. Perhaps I'll try their pumpkin curry and okra next time. The service here is pretty good too.
author: Joy W.

description:
Obsessed. I have been back a few times since last year and I am addicted. Whenever someone says "where do you want to go" and I am in the vacinity of here. We go. =) 

Mandalay Special Noodle may be my favorite dish in all of the Universe. Yes, THE UNIVERSE. I need to learn how to make this deliciousness. The very first time I came here, I had food envy because someone else ordered this. Now I make sure at least on order is on the table at all times. I can't explain the flavor profile beyond delicious, refreshing and delightful so you will just have to experience it for yourself.

The service truly depends on the day; I have had amazing service and I have had sub par service. However, I know to expect this so I am not even worried about that because I know my tastebuds are in for a treat each time I step in here. While you are in the small waiting area, you are able to order drinks so that helps with the wait time. But, if you have a party of 5 or more, make a reservation! 

My go-to:

Balada - Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce.

Samusa w/ chicken or veggie. - A mixture of grounded curried meat and potatoes.

Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok) - Salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with Lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing.

Mandalay Special Noodle - Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top.

Coconut ice cream - Yes. Yes. Yes. (if you have room lol) 

Ugggggg, I wish Postmates would deliver to me in Florida =)
author: Colleen B.

description:
I am part Burmese. The food here is okay: not as westernized as Burma Superstar, aka it's a tad more authentic. I am so annoyed at the small portion sizes and the exorbitant prices -- one tiny serving of curry should not cost $16!! -- but I also understand this is SF. 

What I really did not like is the management, whom I did not get good vibes from. The place is quite small and I was skeptical that the staff was running around with headsets & microphones. I've never been to a restaurant that was so tightly controlled, which gives me pause. The servers are a bit over eager and/or easily distressed, which made for an anxious eating experience.
author: Kristina L.

description: Great menu. Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken, Mandalay Noodles. Dry Fried String Beans. Bustling atmosphere and most everything is delicious.
author: Ben A.

description:
Tiny portions, I do not recommend. Definitely not worth your money, there are much better places to eat in the city. Plus the place has bad lighting and it does not look clean. 
Yeah...TINY PORTIONS!
author: Sam T.

description:
We love it! The service is good and very friendly.
Nummy!!!
The food is excellent. The decor is really pretty.

A legit restaurant. They know u r there for great food, so they serve you great food! Simple as that.
author: Mary N.

description: As a pescatarian, this place rules over Burma Super Star.  This place never disappoints, so it's my go to restaurant for any company visiting from out of town.  Love the nan gyi dok (noodles) and platha (appetizer).  Great service.
author: Tina H.

description:
2 stars because Food is good, service is bad which will prompt me to not come back. 

Rude waitress (She came as soon as we sat down demanding we order our drinks and appetizers and I asked for some time and instead got crabby and walked off) rude hostesses (called our name but wanted to attend to a bigger party instead and made us get up and wait another 5 minutes for another table) The wait time is LONG.
author: Maria N.

description:
My uncle bought food from Mandalay for my aunt birthday dinner.
It was so good.
We ordered the coconut rice, the curry, and the salad.
SO GOOD.
author: Candice L.

description: Food was good, but service was bad. Worst dining experience ever. The waiter was rude, arrogant and pushy. He was not willing to listen and rather impatient. Not something you would expect at a restaurant.  We have always enjoyed the food and service at Mandalay, but today's experience spoilt it once and for all. I was surprised because the restaurant wasn't even that crowded tonight.
author: Rahul M.

description: Bright and friendly interior with amazing food and lovely staff! Don't waste your time at Burma Superstar - this place is way better and feels more authentic.
author: Jenna C.

description:
3.5* for the food, bumping up to 4 stars for the excellent service. 

I dined here with friends on a Sunday night and luckily there was no wait. This was my first time trying Burmese food, so I didn't want to have high expectations.

We started out with the tea leaf salad. Note that this isn't your typical salad. In fact, it has no lettuce and it's more of a shareable dish. Skip this salad if you don't like peanuts. We also had the hot and sour soup with shrimp, okra and other vegetables. One of the highlights of the night. It was very flavorful and almost tasted like a Burmese twist on Jambalaya. 

We then moved onto our main dishes that we shared among the table:
Mandalay Special Noodles - Very heavy dish with an almost milky base. It was a little too buttery for my taste, but I liked lemongrass and fresh squeezed lemon juice on top. The dish could use more coconut chicken.
Burmese Curry Beef - Plenty of sauce, flavorful, but a bit too greasy. The meat was soft and paired well with the coconut rice 
Mango Chicken - Dry, but balanced out the other saucy dishes. I thought that the mango would add a nicer flavor to it
We also ordered coconut rice and sautéed pea shoots. I loved the coconut rice! It was soft and with a subtle hint of coconut.

The service was excellent. Our drinks were constantly refilled, our server was very helpful and the food runner did a great job presenting and mixing our dishes.
author: Helen C.

description: Great food. Great service. I particularly liked  walnut honey coconut battered shrimp.
author: Peter N.

description: Scallops were bad. Appetizers better than main courses. Tea leaf salad was perfect. But pricy so I'd rather go to Burma Superstar
author: marjorie m.

description: The food here is great! Very good flavors and the staff is ON TOP OF IT!!! (If I had a clapping emoji I would add one right here). We came here on a busy night but were luckily seated. I really liked how they asked us if we wanted anything to drink while we waited and also made sure we were doing okay while waiting. The only downside is the expensive price. Oh and also! Everyone needs to try their mango lassi. Soooooo good. I really liked it!
author: Monica L.

description: Everything was pretty good, but not mind blowing in any way. Portions were a little bit on the small side.
author: Liv R.

description:
Love the place , service & menu. This was an experimental visit and I must say it was worth a try. We ordered the tea leaf salad, basil chicken , satay, samusa , coconut water , asparagus chicken , beans fry , coconut rice , okra egg curry and saffron rice. 
Every order was made to perfection , the flavors were very balanced and spice levels apt. The staff was very courteous and advised us the specials based on our taste and preference. 
The place looks a bit rustic from outside, but the setting is quite nice from within. 
The pricing is a bit on higher side, but the quality balances it out. 
Must visit if you like coastal, sautéed or stir fry type foods.
author: Sreejith K.

description:
Eating here for second time. I feel both the food quality and server delight has gone worse. Not only we found the food to be average quality (salty, cold) but also the fact that people were super rude to all of us. First time too I felt we were rushed but gave them a benefit of doubt. 

Won't be coming again here.
author: Sujay M.

description:
My fave Burmese in SF so far, and I've tried most of the biggest names! Mandalay's food seems to be more about the curry flavors with a light tamarind hint. Plus, their Tea Leaf Salad (something else I've ordered at all the other Burmese spots) is the only one I've had that doesn't come with lettuce, and I like it SO much better this way. No soggy leaves, but a well balanced (and textured) salad. 

The kitschy year-round Christmas decor is almost so over-the-top that it works. The service was good, they are a bit of the cut-to-the-chase style, but they are efficient and get their stuff done.

THE WAIT
About 30 minutes at 7:30pm on a Sunday for four. There were 4 or 5 parties ahead of us when we got there.

COST


SALAD
1. Lap Pot Dok (Tea Leaf Salad. Prepared w/ imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted w/ lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic chips, peanut, sesame seeds, green pepper & chef's special dressing. $10.75) - 4.5 stars
Best Tea Leaf Salad I've had in the city! I like their take without lettuce. The crunchy fried lentils holds everything together. Very nicely done.

SOUPS1
1. Ong No Him Yee (Coconut Chicken Soup. Burmese style coconut chicken soup w/ onion, served w/ cilantro and lemon. $11) - 3.5 stars
A bit heavy for me, and a little light on the flavors (could've had more kick, more sweetness). But the soup had a good thick texture, and it did taste amazing with coconut rice. My boyfriend absolutely loved this dish!

NOODLE & RICE
3. Mandalay Special Noodle (flat noodle w/ mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder, shredded onion, lime leaf, top with fry noodle. $12.50) - 4 stars
The fried noodle crisps really gave this dish that extra kick of crunch. I like the curry flavor, the tamarind was a little strong but I'm extra sensitive to it.
author: Ziyan C.

description: We absolutely loved this gem of a restaurant! By far our favorite place so far in San Francisco. Definitely get the tea leaf salad! Can't wait to try it again someday.
author: Shanna S.

description: Came here as I have seen the crowds before...what a horrible place: The food was disgusting: Chicken tasted like rubber mixed with pieces of fat. The beef was so hard cooked that you needed pliers to cut it...and the portions so small that we left hungry.
author: Christina C.

description:
Favorite thing about going to SF for work? Having group dinner with my co-workers. Mainly because we find some awesome places - but also because, you know...I work with some really cool people. Ok, mainly cause the food is killer.

The night before we came here Mandalay was actually at the Yelp offices - they catered dinner for us. I was too busy running my mouth and didn't get to try a single thing. Everyone went on and on about how amazing it was so I was so pumped when my boss said we were going to hit it up for dinner the next day.

After one of the wildest Uber rides ever, we made it here safe. We were waiting for the other half of the group so decided to order some sangria while we waited. The sangria was delicious - and potent. It comes with lychee, which were a nice treat to bite into once the glass was empty. 

First thing you need to know (now that that super long intro is done haha) - Mandalay Special Noodles. Get them. You will thank me. These are Burmese flat noodles with coconut chicken. The flavors in the dish are incredible - and they add some crispy noodles to the top for some awesome texture. 

We also got the samusas and the tea leaf salad. Both were super solid. I'd say I'd recommend the tea leaf salad - but get both if you can. Yea, I just recommended a salad.

We ended with the coconut ice cream - and it was delicious.

Overall this was one of the better meals I had on my last SF trip - and that's saying a lot.
author: Blue A.

description: The very first in original Burmese restaurant in San Francisco. Most everyone in my family loves Mandalay over any other place. This place is always busy usually I just order for takeout. My boyfriend and I can't get enough of this place, if you're ever in the area stop by and try it out you won't be disappointed. Mandalay noodles are my favorite! Also the tapioca drink is a good dessert
author: Sasha M.

description:
Just ate one of the best meals of my life here: 
Mango Salad
Tea Leaf Salad
Mandalay Special Noodle
Beef Curry
Chicken Asparagus
Eggplant
Both specialty rices
YUM!!!
There's NOTHING like it!
author: Summer B.

description:
Mandalay Special Noodle, I'm dreaming until the glorious day when I can order you again. 

My first time having Burmese food did NOT disappoint. I had no idea what to expect which made the experience all the more fun. 

Start with the balada, a crispy pancake served with addictive curry sauce, or the samusa, very much like an Indian samosa. If you like spicy, they have the chili paste in the middle which I used to my heart's content. 

We also tried the tea leaf salad. Made with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted lentil seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts and dress, it may sound strange, but trust me, it works. All the ingredients are presented separate on the plate and then mixed by the server in front of you! It's crunchy and super flavorful. Something I'll never be able to recreate myself so yet another reason to return. 

Now for the main course. Don't think twice and order the Mandalay Special Noodle. My whole table wanted to order it and to be more interesting, some switched to avoid not being able to try other dishes. While their other plates were good, these noodles stole the show. The creamy curry sauce, coconut chicken, fresh cilantro, crispy onion and crunchy noodles on top all mix together perfectly for such a flavorful dish you HAVE to try. 

I was too full for dessert but stole some bites of mango and sticky rice. Delish! 

To sip, they have wine, beer, teas, and even sangria! The sangria came with lychee which I enjoyed. 

The staff here was super friendly and hospitable. It's a cozy place that's not trying to be "hip" and instead, doing what it does, and doing it pretty darn well! 

Until next time, Mandalay.
author: Cassie P.

description: This was such an awful experience. I ordered lamb curry, and when they tried to give me beef curry I corrected them but was then told that they did not have the lamb curry option that evening. They made no mention of this when I was ordering. I picked out what I wanted instead and asked for a discount because of the trouble. Apparently we were being waited on by the "manager" who claimed he could do no such thing, so I handed the menu back and didn't give them my business. When they brought out the other food for the table  there was an order missing and the "manager" was very polite to him even though he screwed up. I am a woman and was not given nearly the same amount of respect as a paying customer. Instead, when I handed the menu back the man snapped at me about not shoving the menu in his face, which I did not do. Appalling service.
author: Megan G.

description:
I would consider re-experiencing one of the worst Uber rides of my life for an entire week -- dude reeked of weed, blabbed my ears off, and couldn't drive very well -- if it meant that I could either 1) move Mandalay to Atlanta or 2) live upstairs for the next decade (assuming I could pay the exorbitant rent that comes with San Francisco). What a memorable meal!    
*****
I. FOOD & DRINK
If you haven't had Burmese food before, it's another flavor-sexy-yum-yum Southeast Asian cuisine that has curry, noodle and rice dishes as well as salads and soups with their own unique twists. They also have drinks that you can order while waiting and eating that are pretty outstanding. Their cooks and bartenders slay, yo. All delicious!

*Samusa: Burmese style samosa/ sambusa filled with a meat and veggie filling with a nice kick to it. Wonderful appetizer to start off with, and I totally recommend it.

**Sizzling Shrimp: A bell pepper, shrimp, and spice orgy that comes out on a hot iron-serving skillet. Pretty good. 

**Mandalay Special Noodle: Slightly al dente flat noodle with beautiful coconut chicken, spicy yellow peas powder, fried thin noodle on top, with a touch of lime juice -- it want to stuff my face with this everyday.

***Coconut Ice Cream: It was like an adult wet dream.... Not to get weird or anything. 

II. SERVICE
Even though they were super slammed and  a few hiccups occurred, they held it down like pros.

III. ATMOSPHERE/ DÉCOR
It's festive with awesome Burmese artifacts and paintings that didn't come off as corny. I'm definitely feeling the vibe. Music isn't overly obnoxious, either.

IV. PRICES
Very reasonable for an expensive neighborhood.

V. OVERALL
It's definitely a San Francisco must, and I can't wait to return.
author: Jonathan T.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco! My family has been coming here for years. Must haves: mango salad, special noodles, COCONUT RICE, BALAVA SO GOOD!! Getting hungry again just thinking about it
author: Sarah J.

description: Great food, great service, great experience. I frequently find myself dinning at Mandalay and would highly recommend the restaurant to both locals & visitors.
author: Brian K.

description: This is a good place to go when you have a large group or when Burma Superstar is way too packed and you really want your Burmese fix. I've had their tea leaf salad and the coconut chicken noodles - both are decent dishes, but for whatever reason, this place lacks pizazz. Friends who ordered fish chowder mentioned there wasn't much fish compared to other places they had tried. Everything is good, but not superb. Solid three stars though!
author: Lauren C.

description: Outstanding in every way, from the hospitality of the owners and waiters to the food prepared with the utmost care  awesome cuisine. Love it.
author: Sam K.

description:
Great alternative to Burma Superstar. Gets busy on a Friday night so be prepared to wait. Attentive and prompt service. Reasonable prices except for dessert. Interior decor was fab and glamorous. Perfect for a date.

The food was delicious and almost comparable to Burma Superstar. We ordered the following:

- tea leaf salad: delicious by has LOTS of nuts and less lettuce
- mango chicken: delicious, taste reminds me of Panda Express orange chicken
- coconut rice: subtle coconut flavor, not as moist as Burma Superstar
- curry beef: large cubes of beef, average taste
- samusas: chicken version, delicious when dipped in the housemade chili sauce
- black sticky rice w/ coconut ice cream: wow! the hot rice combined with the refreshing taste of the ice cream was the perfect finish to our meal. portion size is very, very small given the price though, so probably would not get again.

Overall, I would return again. The atmosphere and the food are worth coming back to and the prices are reasonable.
author: Jane C.

description:
I have been craving OKRA and went to Mandalay hoping they would have it. BOY THEY DID NOT DISAPPOINT. They had an AMAZING shrimp and okra dish which honestly was so good I wanted to have a SECOND order of it (but I had self control and didn't). They were VERY generous with the Okra and it was so fresh and the plump shrimp was so delicately flavored and It was WAY better than any other place I've been in the city. Needless to say next time I want okra I will be ordering from Mandalay - takeout!

the restaurant was packed on a Wed night but we got a seat right away for a table of 4. the male wait staff honestly was a little unorganized with the one glass of wine we ordered at our table (they asked us I think 3x what  red we wanted ) but I know it was the guy's second day on the job. the ladies with the headsets were more than attentive to us so that DEF made up for it. 

the noodles we got - the burmese 3rd one down on the menu (the nonspicey option) - sorry not sure what it's called were "the best i've tasted in a long time" according to the hubs. 

The dessert was a little disappointing as far as the portion size ratio to price ($8) for the agar jello dessert but it was OK. The samosas were on the small side but flavorful. 

Still the Shrimp and Okra was amazing. and oh and so was the Tea Leaf Salad. that was good too.
We will definitely be back for those. and that is why I rated it 5*
author: Win H.

description:
WOAH! SENSORY OVERLOAD!

I feel so lucky my first Burmese cuisine experience was here at Mandalay. The fried eggplant was the star of the show! I have never felt such a perfect crunch ever! My mind exploded with all the flavor from the first bite! I didn't care for eggplant until that moment. Our table also ordered the walnut prawn, tea leaf salad, balada, and Mandalay beef. I felt like I was eating pure umami. 

After such a "foodie-tastic" experience,I plan on making reservations for every trip up to SF.
author: Josh M.

description: I would never think to eat at a Burmese place, but Mandalay was a real surprise.  It's definitely an adventurous choice for me, but it has become a family favorite any time we're in San Francisco.
author: Dale L.

description:
Excellent food, good service, cool ambiance, reasonable prices. Yes please. 

Let me go straight into the dishes that you NEED to order:
 - Balada (Pancake with curry sauce)
 - Tea leaf salad
 - Mango salad
 - Coconut Rice

I also had the chicken curry which was good, but not outstanding. 

I was recommended this place and have returned multiple times. 

It does get busy so be prepared to wait if you don't have reservations.
author: David S.

description:
I think this is superior to the hyped up Burma Superstar. The service and wait staff are always attentive and the restaurant with its decor feels like Christmas year round. 
.
I have to ask for a few of the dishes I order to either be less salty or less sweet and they never have an issue accommodating my requests.
.
Their fish dishes and the Mandalay mango chicken, which is lightly crisped, tender not rubber chewy with a few zippy hot pepper slices and fresh sweet mangos with the flower tea are among my favorites. Do look at the many other reviews here I am certain they have many dishes that you will like.
author: Caesar A.

description:
no idea why this restaurant get a good review.
Tiny dishes. We ordered 4 items, with a kid.
We thought we might order too much. Thinking
we could always pack the leftover, we went ahead
the order. Then at the end of the dinner, I barely ate much
the other two still competed for food.

In regard of the taste, nothing special, so many minute items in
the Rain bow salad, you don't know what actually taste it is!

We never return. Yes, the waiting staff constantly yanked our
unfinished dishes away, annoying!
author: Lucy D.

description: Came here to celebrate a birthday. We were able to make reservations for 8 on a Sunday afternoon, so that's a definite plus. The inside was decorated like a museum - the quirky jewelry and ethnic pieces were an interesting addition to the venue. The staff was kind and attentive. NOW.... the food. Yum :) Vegetarians will leave full and happy. We got the basil eggplant (perfectly spiced and delicious), vegetable chow mein (cooked perfectly with the right amount of veggies), Singaporean noodles with prawns (a tad salty, but that might just be me), the balada (THIS WAS AWESOME...I COULD EAT THIS ALONE), and tea leaf salad (this is a must try if you've never had it before because of its unique taste...I can't say I'm the biggest fan, but I appreciate the composition of flavors and textures). Parking was easy to find.
author: Henna S.

description: The food and service here are AMAZING; the restaurant is gorgeous and the staff runs like a very well-oiled machine. It isn't cheap and you'll shell out a good amount if you want a few different dishes, but bring a larger group and get a variety. I love their special noodles!
author: Rachel A.

description:
Outstanding Burmese food you have to try. Quick and friendly service. All food was fresh and flavorful 
Recommend the tea salad and duck. Smosa we're good as well
author: Matthew L.

description:
Service was very attentive. The waiters and hosts were consistently checking with us to see how things were going AND with a smile!! Couldn't ask for better service.  A nice restaurant even for a date- quiet enough for conversations even on a busy night. Food was delish so I'll definitely be back! The mango chicken was flavorful and the mango was sweet but not overpowering. The pumpkin chicken curry was really good- tasty and the chicken wasn't dry. The tea leaf salad was a little spicy given the amount of jalapeno and the samosas we're likely fried and good!
One thing though, the price point is slightly steep for what it is but it won't deter me from coming back :)
author: Sen S.

description:
Waitstaff was very friendly as always.
Got tea leaf ($12) and mango ($11) salads, a good balance of spicy and sweet. 
$16 beef, lamb and seafood entrees! Almost anything on the menu is $11 or more these days... so reluctantly goes a star... sigh... I'd splurge here with guests, but get my blue collar lunch craving filled at Burmese Kitchen.
author: Drew B.

description:
MY FAVORITE BURMESE restaurant in the city (and I've tried them all). My mother was born in Burma, and I grew up eating authentic Burmese food. Nothing beats homemade but this comes pretty close. 

If you're looking to try real burmese cuisine, here's what you need to order:
- Tea leaf salad 
- Balada
- Fish chowder
- Coconut chicken soup (#1 top fave ever)
- Burmese style noodle (Kaw soi dok)

The waiters are burmese for the most part and are dressed in traditional burmese garb. The wait is nothing compared to Burma Superstar....not sure why people would wait hours to eat there.
author: Emily Y.

description:
My wife and I tried Mandalay for lunch as part of a group of a dozen or so, none of them Burmese, but two of them regulars at the restaurant.  This was, as far as I recall, my first experience with Burmese food; certainly, at least, the first in many years.  I was favorably impressed.
  
The restaurant is a typical Inner Richmond storefront; the interior is done up in dark wood and yellow-green paint.  Decoratively rather "busy"--there are dozens of what appear to be Christmas tree ornaments hanging from the ceiling.   We were seated immediately, though several in our party had not yet arrived and a sign at the entrance said they wouldn't seat a party until everyone was accounted for.  Drink orders were taken at once.  Several of us, including my wife, ordered flower tea, which I gather is something of a house specialty:  hot tea in a stemmed glass, into which a large flower bud of some sort is placed, and gradually opens.  Clever, though the flower is more a matter of presentation than flavor.  Indeed, presentation is a strong point of Mandalay; everything had great visual appeal as it came to the table.

Wait staff were friendly and efficient.  We encountered no language difficulties.

Chopsticks (plastic) and Western silverware are both at every place setting.

We sampled a number of unfamiliar dishes recommended by the two regulars, all of them good to excellent.  Our browsing included:

- Rainbow Salad--a colorful mix of some 20 ingredients, including noodles,  in a simple oil dressing.

- Green Papaya Salad--shredded papaya, onion, cucumber, and tomato, plus nuts and something of the bacon family, in a peanut-y, mildly spicy dressing.

- Mango Salad--Similar to the papaya, but  of course sweeter.

(Other salads on the menu include ginger, tea leaf, and chicken.)

- Balada--A bread that looks rather like Indian naan, but which has a layered, flaky texture, and is served with a mild peanut sauce.

- Basil Spicy Pork--Chunks of very tender pork in an only mildly spicy yellow curry sauce.  

- Pumpkin Pork Stew with Sour Mango--Another clever presentation; the pork curry, similar or identical to the spicy pork above, is served using a small scooped-out pumpkin as a bowl. 

- Basil Spicy Eggplant--Vegetables in a slightly sweet/tart sauce, gaining a certain amount of heat from red pepper flakes.

Surprisingly, rice is not included with the entrees, though white or coconut rice can be ordered separately.

There are a number of lunch specials in the $10-$12 range, and lunch combos at $12.50 to $15. 

The beer list is small, about eight items, of which the only one new to me was Myanmar, from, of course, Myanmar.  This was a 650-ml bottle of what turned out to be a rather bland blond lager; well, one more brew for my life list, but not something I'd be likely to order again, especially at $9.  Next time (and there /will/ be a next time, though the place is a bit far from us), I'll just stick with the old reliable Singha.  There's also a wine list, but no hard liquor.

This being the Richmond, street parking is scarce, and is limited to two hours even on the unmetered side streets.  And the two hour limit is apparently enforced; someone, presumably a parking enforcement officer, marked our tire while we were in the restaurant.  For anyone coming from within the city, public transportation might be a better option; they're right on the 1-California MUNI line.
author: Alan F.

description:
It's been so long since I've been to this spot. I'm a huge fan of Burmese cuisine -- the first time I visited was with my dad and his sister. They're Burmese - so if they love this place, that's a good sign!

Brought Brett here with me today and we both loved the curry chicken and curry chicken noodle stew! We loved it so much we ordered a fresh batch of curry chicken to bring home! 



Love the fact the waitress wears authentic Burmese dresses and they are attentive with their service.
author: Alissa H.

description:
This was wretched. I don't understand how it has the reviews that it does. 

Ginger drinks (both ginger beer drink (which i guess is actually ginger, beer...) and cooler) - sugar syrup with mint leaves. hard pass.

Samosas - perfectly fine. not special. Wouldnt be surprised if they were from a box though...

Mango salad - repulsive. Like a bad slaw that couldn't. If mango is the main ingredient a basic tip would be using decent mango.

Hot and sour soup - thank goodness they brought vinegar and soy sauce with it. I've never had to add either of those to hot and sour soup...they specifically brought it out for the soup. So, they know it tastes gross and needs soy sauce and vinegar to cover it up? I mean, good that at least they know...

Burmese beef- ABSOLUTELY RANCID. This sealed it. My friend and I each took one bite. He managed to get his down. I almost threw up and spit it out. It tasted like spoiled shrimp. The texture was like a koosh ball wad of sinew and nasty. They asked how it was and immediately took it away (literally the whole serving minus the two small pieces...one of which was still available in chewed form in my napkin) when we said it was bad. But they did not replace it. Then DID NOT TAKE IT OFF THE CHECK. We brought that up before paying and they said they'd take care of it. Nope. Still charged us the full amount. 

Brokedown disgusting place. Expensive for what it is even if it was good. Dirty, tired, total lack of quality. 

DO NOT EAT HERE.
author: Ryan B.

description: This place is great- especially the samosa soup. If it wasn't $13 a bowl, I'd eat it 2x a week. Everything is good. Kid friendly and a warm open family dining room vibe.
author: Rex L.

description: Smelly place and food is mediocre! Definitely wouldn't recommend this place. Didn't like anything we ordered.
author: Rima M.

description: This review is based on service only.  Food is good, it was even better in the beginning in sense portions have becoming smaller and smaller. I've been going for 6 years. The woman who acts as a server/manager was nothing short than rude. She interrupted me not one or two but three times while I was ordering, did not acknowledge my request to please if possible use less butter or oil when making my order. She also turned away and started speaking to another employee while taking my order. Unacceptable behavior especially toward customer. She always has been bit off, I usually don't pay attention. I've always thought the rest of the employees are great. It made me feel really uncomfortable
author: Diana T.

description:
Popped in here the other day for lunch with friends.  We needed to see if this place was as good as.........or better, than nearby Burma Superstar.

We shared the following:

Myanmar beer- lousy (it tastes as watery as Corona, so what's the point?)
Tea leaf salad.........outstanding!!!
Green papaya salad............delicious!!!
Beef curry...................so yummy!!!
Mandalay noodles..........my favorite!!!

Overall, ambiance, service and food were excellent.  Although BS still remains my favorite go to place for Burmese cuisine thanks to their ambiance, food and spectacular service by Fanny and Queena, Mandalay is now another favorite and a must try for anybody who enjoys good ethnic food.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Authentic Burmese in Inner Richmond. Standouts include tea leaf salad YUM, balada, Burmese noodles (house special). 

APPS
Balada (roti) with curry dipping sauce - favorite snack, didn't disappoint
Samusa - tasty savory bites (mini samosas)

MAINS
Tea Leaf Salad (lentil seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts) - a complex riot of flavors and texture, well-done
Mandalay Special Noodle (soft Burmese flat noodle with coconut chicken, lime juice, onion, topped with fried thin noodles) - loved this dish, satisfying without being overly heavy
Pan-fried string beans with ginger, chili sauce, ground shrimp. Similar to she ji dou (Szechuan fried string beans) - super fresh
Rangoon Beef (marinated beef with spices sauteed with tomato, onions, green chili) - was a bit sweet for my tastes but friends enjoyed this dish.

Burmese friend prefers this over Burmese Superstar - am a believer! Popular among locals so Mandalay gets packed, definitely make rezzies for groups.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Very friendly and sweet service.

I really enjoyed the dishes we shared.

We started with a refreshing mango salad. Very flavorful with herbaceous and acidic flavors. 

We shared the Mandalay Noodles and Mandalay Beef. Again, both flavorful dishes. The Mandalay Noodles had different textures from the soft flat noodles and fried thin noodles which I enjoyed, and the Mandalay Beef was fried and airy but still meaty. It wasn't as spicy as I was expecting.

We came a little after they opened for dinner on a weeknight. I think the restaurant was completely full by the time we left. 

I can't wait to return and try more dishes.
author: Maya S.

description:
So everyone's talking about that other Burmese place down the street, yeah yeah. But I personally think Mandalay is the real deal (and way less crowded and a little bit cheaper).

My family was in town and I was tasked with finding a place to eat. Originally we were planning to go to that other Burmese place, but they were closed, so we ended up at Mandalay. I hoped that Yelp was right and the food would be just as good. Turns out, I think it's better (and possibly more authentic).

Here's what you should order:
1. Tea Leaf Salad - To be honest, I'm not as into Tea Leaf Salad as everyone else seems to be, but it's very flavorful, super unique, and bound to impress.
2. Mandalay Special Noodles - There's a rule that if something is called [Name of Restaurant] Special [Dish] you should probably order it because it's probably awesome. Definitely satisfies the rule here.
3. Balada - Because I am a sucker for things that consist of a fried carb and curry. And because the curry that comes with this is possibly better than all the other curries on the menu (save it!)
4. Coconut Rice - Not technically a dish, but I'm a big fan of the coconut rice they serve here.

We tried a few other dishes on the menu and they were also pretty great, so you probably can't go too wrong here. The staff is also super friendly and helpful so ask for recommendations! General rule of thumb: Go for the food that seems more "different" and not like something you could order at a Chinese restaurant and you'll probably have a fun and delicious experience.
author: Brittany C.

description:
Mandalay:
"Have you tried Burmese food?" My cousin and fellow Yelper, Cindy Q. asked me prior to my trip to SF. Nope, definitely no authentic Burmese food in Hawaii, where I'm from.

So we made a special trip to Mandalay on California Street. The ambience in the restaurant is very ethnic and relaxing. With paintings hung from the wall, and adorable sculptures all around,  I appreciated the vibe they have going on. 

Being the noob in Burmese cuisine, my cousin ordered for all of us:
-Tea Leaf Salad: ingredients separated on the plate, mixed at the table. So so good! Garlic chips, chick peas, sesame seeds, jalapeños, tomatoes and of course, chopped fresh dried tea leaves. A must order!
-Rainbow Salad: 20 ingredient salad, a little lemony for me, but delicious noodles, purple cabbage, bean sprouts, carrots and others, mixed table side.
-Burmese string beans: SO YUM! Spiced to perfection, these beans are so delectable. 
-Balada: Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce. A MUST order as well.

Overall, amazing service, good food and fresh ingredients.  I would recommend Mandalay to anyone!
author: Celina Q.

description:
Don't remember too much about the food here because I went almost a year ago, but I bookmarked this place for a reason. 

Will definitely try this place again if I come back to the area. All I remember were the food and drinks were good albeit pretty busy and crowded.
author: Raymond W.

description:
I've been to Mandalay a number of times and it's consistently good! 

There are a number of Burmese restaurants in the area, and while it's not as trendy as say, Burma Superstar or B Star Bar, the wait is usually not as bad. I prefer the environment/atmosphere at B Star Bar, but Mandalay's food is just as good (if not better) and less fusion-y. I've even come around peak times on the weekend and there was no wait. It's also easy to make reservations for large groups here.

My favorite items to get:
- Tea leaf salad (duh)
- Mandalay special noodles (a MUST order)
- Coconut rice
- Naked eggplant

Their drinks are also really tasty. Get the mango lassi or Thai iced tea!
author: Valerie L.

description:
This is my favorite Burmese restaurant!!! This review is so long overdue as I've been coming here since I was a kid. My family is from Burma (but we're Chinese) so Burmese food has always had a special place in my heart and reminds me of my grandparents and my great grandma. 

Favorite dishes:

Mohinga (fish soup) - the best!!!
Ono causwe (coconut curry soup) - really good but super rich because of the coconut
Pepper fish soup - sooo good, reminds me of a simple Chinese broth soup
Mango shrimp - love that sweet and savory combo
Tea leaf salad - my family orders this and they love it but I don't eat it
Coconut rice - the one I make is good but why can't I replicate this at home???
Samusa - delicious! Just like the ones we would buy from some random lady in Daly City
Paluda (Burmese jello sundae) - my favorite!

Mandalay is my favorite and I wish this restaurant was in LA since I live there now. When I'm visiting home I always come here.

Don't go hangry because they always have a long wait!
author: Aisha W.

description: Wow! Amazing food and excellent service. Order the rainbow salad & Mandalay Special noodle. Both were very delicious. Their ingredients were super fresh and I was tickled by the witty and eclectic decor.
author: Rachel L.

description:
This spot is good but just doesn't compare to Burma Superstar around the corner. It's definitely the ugly stepchild, in my opinion! 
The tea leaf salad is better at BS. The service is better. 

BUT! I do think the beef and chicken dishes are better here, for what that's worth. 

If the line at BS is too long, this is an acceptable substitute. 

Pro-tip: put your name down at both and see who gives you a rose first.
author: Amy R.

description: Love Mandalay. Have been going for years, and it never disappoints. The food is consistently delicious, service is very friendly and efficient, and I love the decor - especially all the orchids and fresh fruit on the beautiful altar. Great place to eat-in for lunch or dinner. Take-out too!
author: E. G.

description: Incredible Mandalay special noodle signature dish, I live in the inner Richmond and have been to a load of local restaurants (including Burma superstar) and I don't think I've had a better dish then this one! Highly recommend!
author: Charlie W.

description:
Mandalay is oh so yummy! I've been here a couple of times and the only complaint I have is the fact that parking around this area is almost impossible! Aside from the parking, the foods great. I ordered the tea leaf salad, basil chicken (which was extra tender!), the Mandalay special noodles, samosas and the mango sticky rice for dessert! 

The tea leaf salad wasn't amazing and I expected it to be and it's probably not something I'd order again. Not too sure if the tea leaf was just too strong but what I did enjoy was the basil chicken, and the Mandalay noodles which were my favorite. The noodles had a yummy coconut milk flavor and the basil chicken was extremely tender. Sooo yummy! 

For dessert, the mango sticky rice was an obvious choice and  not sure if it's because I love sticky rice or if I just love the combination of warm coconut rice and mangos. Can't wait to come back!
author: Shelly W.

description:
Awesome, but pricey (compared to the other two nearby Burmese places).

Inner Richmond seems to be the heart of burmese food in the city, with Burma Superstar, Mandalay, and B Star all within a few blocks of each other. Mandalay seems to be the most pricey, upscale, and easiest to get into of the three. That's not super my scene, so I'll probably default to Burma Superstar - or B star, if they have a line (unless someone else is paying, of course ;) )

The good news is that the food is outstanding. We tried the Mandalay Special Noodle, which was just amazing - bursting with flavor. It was a large amount of food but we polished it off because it was so good. We also got the Lamb Rangoon, which was super delicious. The only downside being portions aren't quite as big as the competition, either. 

Would I come back? Maybe. But I'd go to either of the other two, first.
author: Chris S.

description: This place is pretty good. Until a serving spoon arrived that was not even clean (tons of dried leftover food on silverware). They resolved the problem but that seemed to kill the experience for me.
author: Gregory W.

description:
This is by far my favorite Burmese restaurant and I love Burmese food, so my standards are pretty high! We ordered the mango chicken with a side of coconut rice, the Mandalay special noodles and a fish filet dish. The flavors are so unique yet so comforting. I can't even explain it. It blows my mind. The mango chicken is not too sweet and pairs really well with the coconut rice, which is the best coconut rice I've had. It's moist and fluffy and I could eat this everyday of my life. The Mandalay special noodles is the best! It is a must try. It's a whirlwind of different flavors that work together so harmoniously. It blows my mind. I've been to many Burmese food places, but they take the W on this one. Hands down, the best noodles ever. The fish filet dish (I don't remember the name) had bell peppers, onions and had a soy saucy kind of sweet sauce. It was also very good.

This is my go-to for Burmese food. Service is good, but this place is popping during dinner and weekends. I recommend that you call ahead of time. But seriously...I will gladly walk 6 blocks for parking just to enjoy food from Mandalay. Obviously parking is a nightmare in this area, but the food is so worth it.
author: Em P.

description:
Average.  Not horrible, but disappointingly the worst Burmese food I've had in the city.  Went for take out, and noticed that the restaurant was full of only Caucasian people--sorry, not a good sign when it's an Asian restaurant.

~$11-$16 per dish, and portion sizes were good.  I tried the mango chicken, Mandalay beef, coconut rice, tea leaf salad, and dry pan-fried string beans.

Mango chicken was deep-fried, but soggy because of the large chunks of mango, and there were peppers but no spiciness.  Mandalay beef was deep fried and sat atop slices of oranges and lettuce, which also made it a bit soggy, but this was the best dish of my selections.

Coconut rice was a bit mushy, but average.  Tea leaf salad was very peanutty and a bit bitter.  Dry pan-fried string beans also seemed a bit soggy, and though the description states there is chili sauce, it was only faintly spicy.

Overall, PASS on this place, and go to the slightly more expensive and way more crowded Burma Superstar half a mile away--they have the flavors and textures down.
author: Vanessa O.

description:
I just love it here. It's worth the wait. The food is delicious, the staff is friendly and helpful, vegans vegetarians and meat eaters will all be very happy

Here's what we got:
- fried eggplant and squash sticks (just get the eggplant)
- samusa (potato)
-tea leaf salad (no shrimp or fish sauce)
-naked spicy eggplant. THIS IS THE BEST DISH. ORDER THIS AND COCONUT RICE AND YOU WILL BE SO HAPPY. Super thinly coated and fried chunks of eggplant in a mildly spicy sauce (actually not spicy at all and we ordered "medium") the crispy outer layer gives way to soft, melt in your mouth eggplant. I'm getting mouth wet just thinking about it and I just ate it.
-Mandalay special noodle with tofu - the lime leaf and cilantro make this creamy coconut noodle dish just next fucking level.
author: Hallie C.

description: Love the food. Love the people. Love the atmosphere. Hate the parking. But it is near bus stops.
author: Suzy Y.

description: I love this spot. The food is really good and the service is great. I would have never guessed it was a good place from the outside, just walking by, but I'm so glad I tried it. It's become a regular dinner spot.
author: Jessie A.

description:
Mandalay was an interesting change of pace from our usual Asian food outings.  As is the case with most people who are reviewing Mandalay, the wait at Burma Superstar was insane (even at 5:15pm...).  Not to be thwarted from our quest for Burmese food, we came to Mandalay, which had no wait (but did when we left at around 6:45pm). 

Our favorite dish was the Kaw Soi Dok (Burmese style egg noodles)

We also ordered and enjoyed: 
Vegetable samosa soup--just the perfect amount of spicy.  Had falafel pieces inside.  For five people, we had to increase the order size to 1.5 orders. 
Rainbow salad--interesting mix of vegetables and different kinds of noodles.  
Mandalay fried rice--very heavy on the curry flavor. 
Chicken Satay--pretty average.  
Spicy Basil Eggplant and Walnut Broccoli Tofu--these two dishes reminded me more of Chinese food, not necessarily Burmese food.
author: Alison L.

description: Food was delicious. Waiter and crew were struggling with the crowd but were friendly. The hostess was awful. Rude. I could go into detail but that would just water this down. I hope she isn't the owner and if she isn't, then they should find a new hostess.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Mandalay is fantastic.

They really are. 

I've had the opportunity to work with Mandalay a handful of times now on work related catered events. Each time Mandalay has delivered exceptional food with impressive service. When setting up bigger orders for events - they have always been helpful and prompt to respond, especially when it came to any questions or concerns about their menu.

Mandalay is a small business and it shows in all aspects of their restaurant. The amount of care that they put into their service and their food is remarkable. If you're looking for unique and phenomenal food experience - whether it's catered or a lovely night out - go to Mandalay.

I highly recommend the following items:

Mango Chicken
Tea Leaf Salad
Green Beans
Coconut Rice
Balada
Mandalay Special Noodle

Though honestly everything on their menu is on point.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Pro:
-Friendly staff
-Good portions to share family style
-Mango lassi is freshly squeezed and made!

Improvement:
-the tea leaf salad could have more leafy greens like the ones in Burmese Superstar
author: Linda K.

description:
I come here with friends who love this place, and while I like it, I can't really see what everyone else raves about. I do like the atmosphere though. It's generally very busy but it's not too noisy and people all seem to be having a good time so that is pleasant enough for me. I do have one major qualm re: what happened the last time we were here, and that is a problem with the service. We were a huge table (14 of us) and while I completely understand that we would not get our food all at once (they were making it to order one at a time - I appreciate that) but they could have reassured some of us that had to wait that our food was on the way. Some people at out table got second dishes before I and my partner were served at all. We had to watch people eat for at least 15-20 minutes before we got our food. 

Secondly, I ordered a drink which did not come until more than halfway through my meal. If I had not been in such a large group and did not want to upset anyone else at the table, I would have told them to take the drink back when it arrived as it was simply too late. Oh, and we reminded them about the drink at least twice but it made no difference. 

I was kind of surprised at the lack of sensitivity re: the service. These folks have been in business long enough, and even I recognize the wait staff after years of visits, so Mandalay people really ought to know enough about handling customers for this not to have occurred.
author: Cobie T.

description:
Very popular Burmese place. Hubs loves the Tea a Salad. I got the pumpkin pork stew, which I normally love. Pork was overly salted and no pumpkin really-surprising. 
Mathis was a Check pls pick that all the diners loved. It's ik but not a destination
author: Dina L.

description:
The food here is excellent. The staff are friendly and always attentive. The ambiance is very comfortable.  Customers are always smiling while eating the delicious food. 

They have amazing vegan options.
author: Nilesh B.

description:
Terrible service.

(Table of 2, on a Saturday afternoon)

Examples of things that happened (which would be fine individually, but combined they made for a terrible experience):
 * It took several minutes to be greated with menus after we had been seated. (And the seating process consisted of a staff member waving us over from across the room.)
 * Our drinks arrived serveral minutes apart, with no explanation or apology, so we were left wondering whether they had forgotten.
 * Pacing was way off. Entrees came out separately. Less time passed between the appetizer and the first entree than the first entree and the second. (Also without explaination or apology.)
 * At no point did any of the staff check in to see how we were doing.
 * Getting the table cleared took forever. Getting the check took forever. Getting the check back took forever. All told, 20 minutes passed between when we finished eating and when we walked out the door.
author: Zach S.

description: This place has lost its flavor.  I've been coming here for nearly a decade and I would regard this as the best Burmese restaurant in SF over Burmese superstar and Burma Love.  The tea leaf salad was well balanced and abundant.  The Moo Hing Ga (catfish soup) was hearty, rich, full of flavor.  We tried it recently and not only did the prices hike up almost 50%, the food quality sank 50%.  The tea leaf salad was skipping out on the fried scallions and fluffed with too much peanuts.  The soup was flavorless and watered down.  It's sad that greed ruins authenticity.  Never coming back.
author: Joe V.

description: I gave them 4 start just because is a little to pricey but other wise their food is pretty tasty and good. My favorite dish here is their mango salad even know the rest is so good too!!!
author: Carolina C.

description:
after spending an hour in a flotation chamber, this place is perfect to bring harmony to your body in restorative foods!!  so we had a couple of burmese? drinks...one mango which was sooo tasty and the other was a tapioca drink...mmmm...ginger salad to start....so fresh and flavors just exploding on your palate....just the best!! then we had an eggplant dish which is wonderful and "pretty"....do we care what food looks like?  heck yah....its not often that we get a beautiful color of purple on our plates so its extra special with the asian eggplant....we ordered a curry dish which was also good but i can't remember what kind of protein was in it....hmmmm  no dessert this time as we were gonna go get some frozen yogurt on our way home....

note: there is another burmese restaurant that is "more famous"...burma star?  but my GF says the food here at Mandalay is much better!!  ciao bella!!
author: Doug U.

description:
Friend gets the Burmese iced tea.
It comes out dark orange with a layer of condensed milk on top.
Everyone: It looks like Thai iced tea.
Friend: It tastes like Thai iced tea.
Me: You know what makes it Burmese iced tea?
...
You're drinking it in a Burmese restaurant!

I don't think I would recommend the Burmese iced tea (though it does make an excellent sassy start for a Yelp review); nonetheless, most of their menu is unique Burmese food and not just generic Asian stir-fry dishes. The marketing helps too, with names of dishes branded to sound captivating and exotic ("Rangoon Three Ingredients"...how enticing!)

They feature a number of well-known Burmese specialties like nan gyi dok (Burmese pad Thai) and tea leaf salad (probably the most famous Burmese dish thanks to social media pictures of this photogenic salad). Some dishes are more pan-Southeast Asian like Singaporean style noodle (that neon yellow noodle dish that most people aren't familiar with). Menu prices are somewhat above average with entrees over $10, but then again that's rather standard for SF nowadays. We have made an interesting observation that the portion sizes for carby dishes like noodles and fried rice are significantly larger than the meat/veggie dishes--important to keep in mind so you don't fight for parking in the Richmond and sit through the waiting time for much-anticipated Burmese food only to go home hungry, because the non-carby dishes are really quite small. 

TEA LEAF SALAD (salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing): More bold than most tea leaf salads I've had, probably because there's no lettuce to dilute the flavors. However it also means that the pungent taste of the fermented tea leaves and lemon zest is quite strong, so it's best enjoyed as a shared appetizer. My friend got it as an entree and was unpleasantly surprised by how it became progressively salty and sour, but when sampling small bites you'll appreciate the aromatic complexities.

MANDALAY SPECIAL NOODLE (Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top): Pricier than the other noodle dishes, but special indeed! The combination of mild spice, coconut, and yellow pea powder tastes similar to nan gyi dok, except the lime juice makes more interesting and the fried noodle topping really stands out--the tantalizing contrast between the crunchy noodles with the soft rice noodles soaked in coconut milk was perhaps the most memorable part of the meal. In my opinion there is way too much cilantro though--reminds me of when my mom buys too much fresh parsley and adds massive amounts to everything--it threw off the balance and made it too medicinal-tasting (I'm adamant about finishing my veggies, so my solution was just to suck it up and mix in more of the cilantro first so I could enjoy the rest of the noodles afterwards).

COCONUT DRINK: Haven't had young coconut since my childhood, so getting the coconut at Mandalay was very satisfying and refreshing. They give you a spoon to scrape off the bits of coconut on the inside, but I wish they gave me a fat boba straw so that I could slurp up the coconut pieces along with the juice.

Service was friendly and there's a notable Burmese-themed decor throughout the restaurant. However the ambiance was perhaps too authentic, because it was a bit stuffy and the humidity was reminiscent of summers in Southeast Asia.
author: Edna C.

description: I feel like this restaurant has modified their menu to accommodate a westerner's taste buds. I know this is a popular restaurant; There was a wait even on a Monday evening. Every dish was so expensive and the portions are small! Nothing was particularly spicy. The tea leaf salad portion was small. The Volcano beef, though delicious, was only enough for 4 people (2 small pieces of meat each). I've had better Burmese food elsewhere that serves larger portions at a lower price.
author: Emi K.

description: We've been easily 15 times and bring every guest we host here. The flavors are excellent and authentic, the staff is super friendly, and the wait for a table is short. Skip Burma Superstar for this place. I highly recommend the Mandalay chicken, the house noodle, the coconut rice, and the mango salad.
author: Celie H.

description: I get it. Cost of living standards are always added to product and services, and this is reflected here. Overall the food was good, however, if one is into value, this place may not fit the bill. Rainbow salad was fresh and inviting, yet portion size was relatively small to share. We also ordered Walnut Shrimp and stir fried beef special ($20.95) that was overpriced.
author: Brian J.

description: Better than average food, not super stellar. Prices are a little high for this kind of food and place. Actually tried to charge $10 for veg dumplings until I had to tell them the menu said $8. I won't run back unless I was in the area.
author: Daniel W.

description: Walnut prawns are a must!  The coconut rice and chicken satay were also very, very good.  Presentation was awesome and the wait wasn't as at all, just make sure you write your name on the list!
author: Rebecca S.

description: Great service for this lesser known Burma Superstar. I would recommend the tea leaf salad, for sure, the Balada (a savory layered crispy pancake) and the Nan Gyi Dok (noodle dish).
