The flavors are amazing and the service is great. My team came here after a race because they were open later and the restaurant stayed open for us. The rainbow chicken was also tasty.
author: Christina C.

description: Very crowded, yet the wait wasn't that bad.  The food is delicious except for the Tea Leaf Salad.  I like it is served with some heart romance lettuces.  The fish soup is very good.  The service is very nice. When I asked the waitress to exchange another clean spoon, it took her less than a min to give me a new and clean spoon along with an apology.  I would come back since the food is so yummy!
author: Jackie H.

description: I love this place, the food is so good in sf . The price is also very good. I will be back !!! Thank you
author: Hayley F.

description:
Great neighborhood burmese place. Tea leaf salad is classic. Get the spicy soup.
You can't really go wrong with ordering.

For big groups they will make a bigger portion to share family style. Great service.
author: Ryuta O.

description: Mandalay is a medium sized locally owned restaurant that feels like the chinese restaurant you grew up going to.  It has a comfy and colorful ethnic decor.  I have been a customer for years and they have been consistent in their service and quality of food.  Almost everything (veggie dumplings not so great) I have tried has been tasty. Lately I go to Mandalay for their salads.  I have had the tea leaf, ginger, and green papaya salad.  All are delicious .
author: Cin D.

description: Casual and surrounded by a wonderful hodge podge of fun vibrant decor. The food and presentation is always lovely and so are the people who work here.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I love zesty flavor and I was craving for some of that tastiness upon coming here!  

You must get their Signature House Noodles!  With freshly squeezed lemon juice wedge, light creamy coconut sauce that is tossed up with noodles and chicken, it was slurpaliciously delicious!

I do recommend their Tea Leaf Salad when ordering up a starter appetizer and yearning for something tingling the palate!  They mix up the salad on the spot!  It was quite delightful to watch!  Compared to other Tea Leaf Salads that I have had before, this one was very nutty with cashews.

Their Sauteed Beef dish was okay!  I didn't care for it or there is something better that may fare better off the menu!

Their decor is nice and colorful and service is better than the norm for Asian cuisine restaurants!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Much better than the highly overrated Burma Superstar. The downside is people like me spreading that word because it's much busier now. They deserve it.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Came here again and it was amazing! Better than my first experience. Burma superstar had an hour and a half wait so I walked over here and was seated in 10 minutes. 

You MUST try the balada! It's the Burmese pancake with curry dipping sauce. So flaky and doughy. It basically melts in your mouth. 

I also tried the mango prawns - just as delicious as the mango chicken. I can't get over the delicious mango pieces and the prawns are sizzled to perfection.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Got the tea leave salad. It was great! Don't get it if you're allergic to peanuts. It was delicious!

The duck was really good. The pumpkin was surprisingly yummy, and I don't like pumpkin that much. 

I also got the mango lassi but it wasn't as thick as the ones you get at an Indian restaurant. The waiter was super attentive. He split the food for us. That's the fifth star.
author: Raquel A.

description:
This is a really good alternative to the other more crowded Burmese restaurant a few blocks away.  While the food here is really good, some of the dishes reminded me of Thai food instead.

I had come for lunch with a few friends and had a variety of dishes.  One of the dishes I loved was the Rock Cod with Eggplant, which I think was the special.  Mild slightly spicy, the cod was soft and the eggplant and sauces were delicious.  The Mandalay Noodles is another dish I recommend, which is a mixture of crunchy noodles and curry.

Great service, great food, I'm definitely coming back again.
author: Karen L.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because the Mandalay Special Noodle is why the invented the phrase "flavor explosion."

   ---   ---   ---

I hate cliches, and do my best to avoid them. But when I eat these wondrous noodles, all I can think of is FLAVOR EXPLOSION. 

One of my favorite things about San Francisco is that there are so many different cuisines that can be found here. And one of my favorite things about eating different cuisines is activating taste buds that have mostly sat dormant for years. I'm not sure if that's the actual science of how taste buds work, but let's roll with it.

I was lucky enough to dine at Mandalay, but my favorite experience was when they visited our office. They brought EVERYTHING. And everything I tried was absolutely 5-stars and beyond. I only wish I had cherished it more. It was a pretty social setting, and I don't feel that I gave the food the respect that it deserved.

So I apologize for the lack of specific recommendations outside of those noodles. You better get those if you know what's good for ya.
author: Brett N.

description:
Been here several times. Nice well-decorated place to take a visitor.

Things I've had here:
- Tea Leaf Salad: 5/5. A must-have if you've never tried it before.
- Rainbow Salad: 5/5. Great alternative to tea leaf salad.
- Side of Coconut Rice: 5/5. You can never go wrong with coconut rice, but here it's especially good.
- Spicy Tofu with Vegetables: 3/5. Nothing wrong with it, but I personally wasn't crazy about it.
author: Kaito C.

description: Mandalay's food is soooooo good. Always consistent, never disappoints. Have been going here for years since hearing about it.  Hadn't been back to Burma Superstar since  discovered. Had a visitor in town wanting the tea leaf salad. It was a Tuesday so we had to hit up Burma Superstar, my last trip there. Food is great and all but no comparison to my beloved Mandalay. Samusas, House Special Noodle and Tea Leaf Salad(all vegetarian) are a must have every time.
author: Leigh E.

description: So excellent! I have been here multiple times and it never disappoints. My boyfriend and I went tonight and had a great experience. He has celiac disease, and the waiter carefully explained which items on the menu were gluten free (very good selection). Each time a dish was served, he again confirmed it was gluten free which we appreciated. The rest of the wait staff was also very attentive and polite. We got the rainbow salad, mango chicken, beef curry, and nan gyi dok noodles. All were great! I would highly recommend the noodles, and although we liked the rainbow salad, I still think the tea leaf salad is best.
author: Lindsey G.

description: Excellent service. Waiter was very helpful in recommendations. Mandalay special noodles were so good!
author: Rachel Q.

description:
Really cute place for either lunch or dinner, and prices are very reasonable. I love that the interior has ornaments hanging from the ceiling, and the walls are yellow! 

Having heard this place is my uncle's favorite for Burmese food (he is Burmese, so I trust him!), my friend and I decided to check this one off our foodie adventure list today for lunch. After reading several reviews, we both went for their noodle dishes. We shared the Mandalay special noodles (11.25) and the Nan Gyi Dok (9.95). Both of them contained coconut chicken with split yellow pea powder and onion. Only difference between the two is that the style of noodles are different (Mandalay special noodles are flat, Nan Gyi Dok is made with round spaghetti-like noodles) and there is lime juice with fried bits of noodles that top off the Mandalay. Both dishes are so flavorful! This was my first time trying out Burmese food, and I wouldn't mind coming back again to try new dishes!

Along with the delicious food, the service was excellent as well. It was cool to see the cook squirt the lime juice on the noodles and mix it up in front of us for a mini show.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday and they were super hospitable! The service is superb! 

We got the tea leaf salad, the samosas and the palada to start! Their tea leaf salad was definitely really good. Lots of differing flavors and textures. Not such a huge fan of peanuts personally, but still really good!

Then for the main course we got the smoked duck and the mandalay beef. There were only a few pieces of duck, but the few pieces were enough. The one thing I really really liked though was the kabocha pumpkin on the bottom. It was smooth, sweet and creamy. 

All in all, their service was a 10/10 and their food was superb! Would come back again!
author: Janet K.

description:
I popped my Burmese food cherry here at Mandalay, and I just can't get enough.

I haven't had to wait here for more than 15-20 minutes both times I came here for dinner.  The service here is great and the food is amazing!

So far, I've tried the Samusa, Tea Leaf Salad, Kaw Soi Dok (Burmese Style Noodle), Mandalay Chicken, Burmese Style Curry Chicken, Mandalay Beef, Mandalay Eggplant, and Ragoon Beef.  Everything I've tried here was delicious and would recommend them all.

My favorites are the TEA LEAF SALAD, KAW SOI DUK, MANDALAY BEEF, AND MANDALAY EGGPLANT.  

The Tea Leaf Salad has so many flavors and textures that meld so perfectly.  I especially love the crunchiness of the fried garlic and the mouth watering dressing!  The flavors are a combination of sweet, salty, tangy, and savory-- umami for sure.  This is one item I would order every time I come here.

The Kaw Soi Duk noodles are egg noodles toasted with fried onion and that oh so crunchy fried garlic.  It also has cucumber slices, ground split beans, and mixed in with a tangy but sweet dressing.  I've also ordered this both times I came here so I highly recommend this dish. 

The Mandalay Beef here reminds me of a better version of Beijing beef I'd order at Chinese restaurants.  The Mandalay Beef is fried beef slices, sauteed with garlic and hot sauce.  I love garlic and spicy food, so this was definitely one of my faves. 

The Mandalay Eggplant here is amazing!!  It has the same flavors as the Mandalay beef, but I especially love the crunchy fried outer layer of the eggplant and the soft inside.  This is cooked so perfectly!

I would want to come here every time I'm in the city!
author: Stacey K.

description:
I wanted to like this place more than Burma Superstar but I just couldn't do it! The prices are slightly cheaper, but not by much. If the prices were significantly cheaper, that might have swayed my vote. 

The coconut milk curry soup was very delicious. As was the tea leaf salad. 

Mandalay is good but Burma is great.
author: Sam A.

description:
We love the food at this restaurant.  It is some of the best Burmese food in the San Francisco Bay Area.
We have been to this restaurant many times over the years.
The last two times I ate here, I felt rushed.  A few weeks ago, we celebrated our wedding anniversary and we were so rushed through our dishes that there was no more room on the table to put the food and yet they were pushing to make room.  They need to let people eat their appetizer first, before bringing on the next dish.  As my husband said, they would probably have put the plates on our heads, if they could have.
I ate here last night.  There were two wait staff standing behind my chair as we finished to leave.  I couldn't even push back, because one of them was standing behind my chair...saying how much they appreciated our business.  I had to say excuse me, but can I get out?  By the time, I made it to the door, our table had been cleared, prepared with silverware and the next customers were on their way to it.  By the way, we weren't that far from the front door.  Maybe 12 feet.
My recommendation to the management here, is to slow down.  Your food is good, but I do not want to be rushed when I am out for dinner.
author: Nick H.

description:
The car dealership of restaurants.

This place is popular for good reason:  the food is delicious and reasonably priced (entrees starting around $12.50, salads starting around $10).

But it seems the aim of the staff is to:
1.  Sell.
2.  Upsell.
3.  Move you along to keep the $ coming in.

I am a calm and composed person, but if our recent "doctor," who was forcibly removed from his overbooked United flight can "put on a scene," so can I.  I am too agreeable, sometimes, but at one point I should have stood up, upending the table and smashing dishes.  You would have too, if you had a waiter standing by to remove your last plate while you were consuming the final portions of your meal.

Throughout my time, here, the waiters were on hyper-alert.  As soon as a course was consumed the dish was whisked away.  What originally came across as orderliness and attentiveness unveiled itself as step 3, above, when the above mentioned scene/final-straw occurred.  I literally had one piece of meat on my plate, and the waiter was literally standing by, waiting for me, as I was reaching down with my chopsticks to pick up the meat.  

We're not talking about me mulling over a grain of rice left on a plate, where it's questionable whether the patron is finished, or not, we're talking about:  eat that piece of meat so I can grab your plate and you can get a move, on.

Then, another waiter instantly came by to wipe down the table, lifting/moving the flowerpiece/center arrangement, while we were still seated.

I would like to encourage upfront complaint, instead of our ridiculous passive-aggressive Yelp back-hitting.  I did not and left a tip.  For the future, if I encounter situations like these I am not going to leave a tip plus I will complain to management.  THEN I may or may not leave a review like this.
author: Tom B.

description: Food here is good, but portion is small. The server was pushy when we were ordering , he kept trying to recommend all these dishes to us while we were trying to look at the menu.  He was trying really hard to sell the dishes and I was put off by that. I much prefer Burma Superstar over this place or even Burma Cafe in Daly City
author: Lucy C.

description: I love Mandalay. Way easier to get into than Burma, but just as good in my opinion. The staff seem nice and prompt. Some favorites are the samusa soup, tea leaf salad, Mandalay noodles, mango chicken and balada. Yummy coconut rice to add on the side. My ONLY downside is it's nowhere near as good as takeout. I definitely save the noodles, and such for only eat in, but the salads or just meat dishes are still alright for takeout.
author: Kaitlin S.

description: Ordered the tea salad and nan Gyi noodles but weren't exactly taken away with the dishes. The best dish was probably the lamb but even then I was disappointed with the overall meal. Parking is of course horrible but they have tea outside while you wait! The service was very hospital but the food didn't do it for me.
author: Esther L.

description:
After seeing a Check Please! Episode on Mandalay, it's been on my "to go" list and finally got to try it for dinner. Most people are probably more familiar with the other popular Burmese restaurant in the area, but the first Burmese restaurant in San Francisco is Mandalay when it opened in 1984.  For those not familiar with Burmese cuisine, it can be best described as a blend of Chinese, Thai and Indian flavors.  

Arriving at 6pm on a Saturday, we put on name on the waitlist and in ten minutes we were seated.  After ordering our drinks, we checked out the menu and decided on:

Chicken Samusas (4) - filled with ground chicken and potatoes.  A nice crispy appetizer that came with marinated cucumber slices and a mild hot sauce.

Tea Leaf Salad - salad prepared tableside that consists of Burmese tea leaves, toasted Lentil seeds, grounded shrimp, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts and dressing. Mandalay's version did not have lettuce, which the waiter said the authentic version did not have.  Without lettuce, the minced tea leaves was the star of dish. 

Mandalay Special Noodle - Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder, lime juice, onion and topped with fried thin noodles that is prepared tableside. Very tasty with the coconut dressing. Nice contrast with the soft flat noodles and crispy noodles. 

Rangoon Beef - marinated beef with spices sautéed with tomato, onions and green chili.  Beef was tender and flavorful.

Rainbow Chicken - pan fried chicken breast with fresh slices of sweet mango, pineapples and vegetables. Chicken was moist and the dish was so colorful with the fruits and vegetables.

Pumpkin Curry Pork Stew - special of the day.  This was served in a kaboucha squash. The chunks of pork in a curry sauce was tender and can be cut with your fork. 

Coconut rice - we ordered a couple of bowls. The coconut infused rice was so tasty.  Complemented the pork stew very well.   For the portion though, it was a little pricey. 

It was a great dining experience.  The food was tasty and flavorful and the service was friendly.  Our waiter was very helpful in describing the dishes and giving recommendations.
author: Al L.

description: This place is expensive, given the size of the portions. We ordered a Burmese style catfish curry which was tasty, but I think we had 3 pieces of fish in a few spoons of sauce. Just not worth the 16.5 dollars we paid. Decent food, price point doesn't make sense.
author: S G.

description: I went here for the first time three years ago and was so impressed that I remembered it when I went back to San Francisco this weekend. My group of vegetarians were all very impressed with the wonderful selection and flavor. Service was great and I was literally shocked at how fast our food came out. It might have had something to do with us being there shortly before closing.
author: T K.

description: Great place with great food... the service is great! The food is so good! Could not stop eating the coconut rice with tofu curry...hahaha but the music was interesting since it's Christmas !! Order the tea leaf salad, Burmese noodle and the tofu curry!
author: Nayana R.

description: After several consecutive meals of pizza/pasta, we were in the mood for something with a different flavor profile and vegetable-heavy. We came here on a Wednesday evening around 7:00 and were seated right away-- but make no mistake, the place was nearly at capacity. In fact, shortly after seating is, our server moved us to another table in order to accommodate a large party that had just walked in. We are vegetarian and we ordered the rainbow salad, the Mandalay naked eggplant (which was more sweet than spicy), and the Mandalay special noodle. Everything was fresh and delicious-- we particularly enjoyed the lightly pan-fried eggplant dish in a thick sauce. We were happy that when we told our server that we were vegetarian she immediately told us which noodle dishes had fish sauce in the noodle base paste so we could choose accordingly. We enjoyed the Mandalay noodles and would totally order again-- it's unlike other Chinese/Thai noodle dishes in taste. Overall, this place hits the spot for Burmese food, the service is attentive and unassuming, and is as good as any of the more well known places in the city. We'd recommend it and would come back!
author: T K.

description:
I love Burmese food! Being a fan of Burma Superstar, I was surprised to hear from locals that Mandalay is better. I had to find out for myself if the word on the street is true. 

For those who haven't had this cuisine, Burmese food is almost a cross between Thai and Chinese. Everything is better shared family-style so you can try different things. Here's what we got for a party of 4 and a child:

TEA LEAF SALAD---This is not your typical vegetable salad. It consists of tea leaves, grounded shrimps, peanuts, fried garlic chips, lentil, and sesame seeds. For me, Burma Superstar wins on this category because they add lettuce on top of all the ingredients. I love how everything tastes but it's just missing more greens. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?selected=r0FEz-SqT4DO5AMAcvl3Bw#u_t9gYO8MEKgNIT68YcRUA

MANGO CHICKEN--- Sauteed with real mangoes, onions, and chili, the chicken is pan fried and has a sweet mango glaze. Imagine orange chicken but this one's their mango version and way better. Superb dish! It's really the cubed mangoes that sealed the deal for me. I highly recommend! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?selected=r0FEz-SqT4DO5AMAcvl3Bw#17BOkoSzDI8I79abcNyzFA
 
PUMPKIN PORK STEW--- Wonderful presentation! Served inside a pumpkin, the stew reminds me of a Thai dish (more like a Panang). It has that beautiful sweet and sour aroma from the pumpkin and mango with a slight hint of curry spice. It tastes phenomenal! Add some sauce to your rice and you'll get hooked! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?selected=r0FEz-SqT4DO5AMAcvl3Bw#xBe97etm16eiI1bIC1bohw

RANGOON BEEF--- Marinated beef sauteed with onions, tomatoes, and chili. Almost like Mongolian beef, if you will. Delicious and flavorful, it's perfectly paired with their coconut rice. Yumm! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?selected=r0FEz-SqT4DO5AMAcvl3Bw#D4YsirXdYpZNA6FBgfVT-A

MANDALAY SPECIAL NOODLE--- We ordered this with fried tofu instead of meat. Prepared with coconut milk and lime juice, this refreshing and flavorful noodle dish is probably my favorite here! The marriage of flavors worked together like magic. MmmmHmmm! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?selected=r0FEz-SqT4DO5AMAcvl3Bw#9ODcI5FPpDD6Ojj53AeCFA

COCONUT RICE is the only way to go for a perfect pairing to all the dishes mentioned above. It's pretty much white rice cooked in coconut juice or milk. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?selected=r0FEz-SqT4DO5AMAcvl3Bw#4yc_h4-I4I2ox38Tj07z4A

Oh and don't forget to try their GINGER LEMONADE. It reminds me of a ginger ale without the fizz. A bit on the sweet side but nothing a few drops of water can't fix. 

The restaurant was packed when we came but the wait didn't take too long. Their turnaround is fast because everything is quick. SERVICE is efficient and everyone here are all smiles. Very nice staff! It almost feels like they're one big happy family.  

Would I come back? Definitely! Mandalay and Burma Superstar remains my top two Burmese restaurants. Not sure if one is better than the other but I love both equally!
author: Marissa S.

description:
I have a confession to make.

I had never tried Burmese food until I moved to San Francisco! And I wasn't at all sure what to expect.

On a Saturday evening on my way back into the city from wine country, my vegetarian friend and I decided to embark on an epicurean adventure and give Burmese a go. 

We found rockstar parking in front of Mandalay.

We were seated immediately. Really, no wait on a Saturday night? Believe.

The service was warm, inviting, and affable.

The tea leaf salad, mango chicken, and coconut rice ROCKED my world.

It was one of the most fulfilling meals I had in some time... and on the way cheap.

Eating out doesn't get more perfect than this! #1 on my 2014 resolution list: eat at Mandalay more often.
author: Jelena Z.

description:
The food is simply not good.
I've had so many people recommend Mandalay I'm really disappointed!

The coconut chicken noodle soup was kinda bland except for the overpowering fish odor.  way too much fish oil!!!  I couldn't eat it.
The samosas were ok.  Very greasy.
The best part of the food I got was sadly the pickled carrots that came with the samosas. 
The servers/hosts were kind.
author: Chelsea D.

description: Too oily and overall not that great tasting. That's our bottom line. We started with the Tea Leaf Salad at the recommendation of the owner (I believe). It comes on a big plate and they tell you about each ingredient then they mix it all up in front of you. You then dish it to your own plates. Despite being crunchy (fried garlic, peanuts, etc) it was soggy with oil. TWe had Singapore Style Noodles. They were decent but not particularly memorable. We also had the Basil Spicy Pork. This also seemed oily though not to the extreme of the Tea Leaf Salad. Again, tasted okay but not any "wow" to it. We were asked how spicy we would like our dishes and we said medium. They came out quite mild. The two entrees, a Mango yogurt drink (lassi?), the salad and a small bowl of steamed rice was just over $50 with tax but before tip.
author: Ross W.

description:
Food: Fantastic! This is only the second time I've had Burmese, the other being at B star. I wouldn't say that one is better than the other, but that their dishes offer similar versions of the same things and they have different strengths. We split 3 dishes and a tea leaf salad between 3 of us and would have been fine with 2 entrees and the salad. 

We ordered:

-Mandalay Noodles: Delicious! Light and not overly heavy or sauced as some Asian noodle dishes tend to be. 
-Tea Leaf Salad: Great version of this. The texture was just as important as the flavor. 
-Mango Chicken: Probably our least favorite, but not horrible. Basically mango and chicken as expected. 
-Walnut Prawns: The walnuts weren't as good as other places I've had it, but the prawns were large and pleasant with the sauce. 

Atmosphere: crowded, but clean. They played a birthday song overhead for a customer which was different. Had it happened multiple times, it could have been annoying, but for the one time, it was a cute way to celebrate. 

Service: felt rushed, but they were prompt and polite.
author: Susan G.

description:
Brilliant food! I think this topped Bruma superstar for me. Took around 5 mins to get seated on a Sunday afternoon. The service is not all rushed, they let you just enjoy your time there. Very courteous staff. We got both the tea leaf and rainbow salad, very comparable to Burma. The garlic string beans very immaculate, it was a delicacy, just about cooked perfect and crisp with garlic chips in there. The saffron rice will put a lot of Indian places to shame, what flavor! They serve this hot sauce with their food that's yum. Make sure to get the fancy jasmine tea , literally blooms for you!

The only gripe, parking around isn't easy to find, so prepare to spend some time hunting for that elusive spot!
author: Ashish K.

description:
Since 1984, Mandalay has graced SF with it's presence with authentic Burmese food.    Violently competing with its nearby popular competitors of Burma Superstar and whatnot, it stands its ground with cozy dishes with a whiff of tropical zest. The interior design was strikingly bold filled with a heartwarming ambience. 

Party of 2 on a Friday night with my yelp friend, Casey N., and it was about a 25-35 minute wait. Waitresses were all extremely friendly, helpful and welcoming. 

Tea Leaf Salad (lap Pat Dok): 3.5 stars. Salad prepared with imported burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing. The salad consisted a little more peanuts than I would like but it was still good. They didnt let me take a picture of it for some reason.... the waitress stopped me and said "sorry no pictures allowed..." I'm so confused.. how did 400 people get their pictures up on yelp..? OH WELLS... snuck the other pictures in!

Pumpkin Curry Chicken: 4 stars. Curry chicken cooked with pumpkin and potato. It was absolutely delishly creamy and I felt like the chicken were super moist and tender countered with the dynamic curry that elevated the dish. The reason we chose this dish was because....It came in an actual pumpkin....SAY WHAT....?!?  LOL sorry I'm easily amused. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?select=ovvJYfnltkpX1s5cbgmQNg#X-ETSgHPWx1MuAu1zuoePg

Mandalay Special Noodle with shrimp: 4 stars. Mixed in front of you, Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top. The tangy taste of the dish enhances the smoothly flavored noodles. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?select=ovvJYfnltkpX1s5cbgmQNg#ovvJYfnltkpX1s5cbgmQNg

Mandalay Beef: 3.5 stars. Fried beef slices sauteed with garlic and chefs delicious hot sauce. Expected a super dry dish but to my surprise it was very moist and not extremely spicy.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mandalay-san-francisco?select=NMoGsh8FMPWciEFjyI3Dtg#NMoGsh8FMPWciEFjyI3Dtg

Our total came out to about $65. 

I apologize for the bad picture qualities... I'll stop being lazy and bring out my dslr more often now. All in all, a really good quality restaurant with good food, service and ambience.
author: Chena N.

description: Honestly, the food didn't live up to the hype. Service was quick and very accommodating. The highlight of the night would be the tea leaf salad. Unlike Burma superstar where it has a lot lettuce fillers, you can really taste the ingredients. You can definitely taste the tea part and it has a wonderful crunch in every bite. I also got the lamb curry. It was mediocre at best. Meat wasn't tender and curry was way too salty. My boyfriend had the pumpkin pork stew. It was nicely presented but it was just okay. Way better than the lamb curry though. We also had the khao soi which was not that bad. The cucumbers gave it a refreshing taste. Sadly, I won't be coming back.
author: Ada H.

description: Food is tasty though a little pricey for the amount of food. Customer service not the most pleasant. I specified absolutely no peanuts for my takeout. Good thing I looked in bag...top order was covered in peanuts. The order was redone and I added an order of samosas...didn't have menu and was unpleasantly surprised at the price for 4 pieces, but that's on me...they never have takeout menus and have done takeouts the last few times (2 toddlers at home for dinner) and current prices aren't online. Little things can encourage repeat visits!
author: Gale H.

description:
Mandalay is one of my go-to restaurants in SF if I want a delicious, memorable meal with friends or family. The food never fails to impress, the service is great, and most of the dishes are on par with Burma Superstar (and the wait is way shorter!). 

The Tea Leaf Salad is a must if you're here for the first time. Watching them mix the ingredients is a mesmerizing and oddly therapeutic experience in itself. The salad doesn't look that appetizing and appears more like a concoction that should be smeared on bread, but don't be afraid to try it! Great texture and the combination of spices is insane. I prefer the version that includes lettuce and it feeds more people if you're sharing. 

The Mango Chicken and Mandalay Chicken are two of my favorites dishes here. The Mango Chicken is definitely one dish that Mandalay does better than Burma Superstar. I've also had the Burmese Curry Lamb which is tender, rich, and earthy, the Rainbow Shrimp,  and the Mandalay Special Noodles - all delicious as well! The portions are on the smaller side, but they end up being the perfect amount of food and the quality of the dishes makes the price more than worth it!

When it's really busy, the service can become a bit sluggish, but during slower times, I've experienced some of the best service here; very genuine, friendly, and attentive. The restaurant has a good amount of seating with larger banquet style tables towards the back, so they can accommodate larger groups. If you come during prime dinner hours, esp. during the weekend, be prepared to wait ~45 minutes and don't forget to write your name down on the clipboard hanging on the wall at the front!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Awesome place and great decor, very tasty food as well!! The tea leaf salad isn't as robust as some other Burmese places nearby, but still excellent. The Mandalay Special Noodle and Three Seafood Curry dishes were also very tasty!
author: Andy L.

description: We were very impressed with the food here. The Burmese noodles and Tea Leaf Salad's were amazing! The wait staff were very friendly and helpful. The price was reasonable. We were a party of 5 and shared 6 dishes and we each had a non-alcoholic drink. The price came to approx $34 per person.
author: Ken H.

description:
Is it possible to mix heroin and ecstasy into a tasty soup? They must have cracked that code here because their coconut chicken soup is addictive and delicious. 

Creamy broth, good chunks of chicken, egg, and cilantro. MMM-good.

Their tea leaf salad is one of the most popular here as well, and they mix it fresh at your table. The strong leaves, wonderful crispy peanuts make for a wonderful mouthful of zen.

Green papaya salad has just enough sweetness and tang to make it a refreshing salad.

Mandalay eggplant: Crispy fried eggplant, skinless and  flash fried with a sweet sauce.

Rainbow chicken: Sweet, fried chicken with peppers (non-spicy).

Their coconut noodles are also delicious with cilantro and lemon.

Their coconut rice is plain, but good with the entrees.

And their mango sticky rice is sweet and their mango is fresh.

I've been here multiple times, and have eaten almost all their food...

So why only 4 stars? Because of the cleanliness. Their was an old slice of stale orange underneath my plate, and my friend's water with lemon had a small knat in it.

The food however is great here.
author: Jack R.

description:
We came to Mandalay after first trying to go to Burma Superstar, where the wait was too long. This was my first Burmese experience and, let me tell you, I was very satisfied!

Four of us ordered and shared all of the dishes that our waitress recommended (Tea Salad, Special Noodles, Chicken Curry, and a few others). Everything was absolutely delicious and not to mention affordable and not too busy -- the food came very quickly. I will absolutely be returning!
author: Nico C.

description:
Food was A+ and the resturant offers great service and atmosphere. A very busy and popular place, but so worth it. We came here for a birthday dinner, we were a group of 5. We did it family style and ordered ~8 dishes to share. We were completely satisfied and stuff! And it was about 30 a person including tax and tip.

Took away one star because it was a ~20 minute bus ride from Montgomery Street Station
author: Heidi C.

description: Came here for lunch with my friend and ordered the Mo Hing Ga, Mandalay Special Noodle, and Balada with curry. It was all really delicious! Service was also really attentive and the staff was really friendly. Parking can be tough though, it took me some time to find a space near the restaurant.
author: Priscilla S.

description: My husband and I enjoyed the Mandalay for maybe 30 years - reasonably priced, outstanding flavors...and now, after a recent lunch visit the PRICE has been jacked up to around $15 for average dish and serving size miniscule. Vegetarian potstickers were undercooked, thick/pasty/starchy, with flavorless filling. Service is still friendly but the enchantment is gone, am sorry to say. Perhaps there is a new owner. Sadly, goodbye Mandalay.
author: Carolyn D.

description: I have nothing but great things to say about this place. The service and food are unbelievable. I came to visit my best friend who just moved to San Francisco and I had never tried Burmese food. It was honestly amazing and I will be coming back here the next time I come visit. The staff is so friendly and it was authentic. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lara K.

description: love their salads and chicken lettuce cups. Clean, nice without the hype and thrills of other spots in the city.
author: Nikki S.

description: Wow! Recently went here just to try it out. The food is delicious!! Also, the service is excellent. It gets very busy -- arrive early! I would come back here for sure.
author: Steph L.

description:
Called in at 8pm on a Saturday night to reserve a table for three 20 minutes prior to arrival. Host was kind enough to put our name down and texted a confirmation while we were on the road saying our table was ready. When we arrived, there were a few groups still ahead of us. Luckily, many of the tables were finishing up and paying their bill, so we didn't have to wait too long (~15 minutes). We ordered the following:

Moo Hin Nga - Delicious, creamy catfish chowder. It came with a side of cilantro and lemon to garnish as you please. There is an option to add noodles. We opted for noodles which were a nice addition to the soup.

Burmese Curry Beef - Big, tender chunks of beef and potatoes in a dark, flavorful curry sauce. Would have like for it to be spicy, but we just ask for chili sauce on the side. We had this with the wonderfully fragrant coconut rice topped with fried garlic.

Mandalay Special Noodle - This came with the ingredients separated and the server mixed everything at the table. This dish was on almost every table, so definitely order this. Loved the variety of textures, the creaminess of the coconut, the silkiness of the rice noodles, and the different flavors.

We were already stuffed at this point, but decided to look at the dessert menu. Two different servers came by and recommended the black sticky rice with coconut ice cream, saying it was their personal favorite. So of course, we had to try it. And they were so right - I think I've found my new favorite dessert! The fragrant, black sticky rice topped with creamy coconut ice-cream drizzled in a mildly sweet condensed milk all complemented each other perfectly. It was the perfect end to an amazing meal.

Total came out to $75 including tax and tip. We will definitely come back to try the rest of their menu.

Pros: delicious food, friendly service, warm festive ambience
Cons: small portions, might be a wait (reservations recommended)
author: Elaine L.

description:
...I don't know how to put this gently to my fellow Americans, whom I love very much. I'm a Myanmar-American -- born and raised in America. Grew up eating Burmese food cooked by my parents and old ladies. I've also been living in Myanmar for the last 4 years and eating actual Burmese food pretty much every day. 

Mandalay Restaurant does not serve real Burmese food in the slightest. This will come as a shock to a lot of you who swear by its "authenticity" and quality. I'm really not saying this to piss people off -- as an American, I sympathize (e.g. "Chinese" food in America tastes nothing like actual Chinese food in China). But Mandalay Restaurant is largely serving a kind of Chinese-American food with some Burmese touches. The tea leaf salad is probably the closest to the real thing, but not really. The Nan Gyi Thoke (big noodle salad) is a joke; it's not remotely close to the real thing. Almost all of the other food items on the menu are not really Burmese food at all.

Now nailing down what Burmese food is in a country as diverse as Myanmar is an impossible task -- samosas are in Myanmar, toshay is in Myanmar, faluda is in Myanmar, all Indian influence from the British colonial era. But they all have a Myanmar spin given how long they've been extant in the country. There are also ethnic nationalities' cuisines that are significantly different than Burmese cuisine -- Rakhine seafood, Kachin rice wine, etc. It's all incredibly delicious and I recommend you try it one day.

But none of that is served at Mandalay Restaurant. Or Burma Superstar, for that matter. Which is cool, they are good at what they do -- but don't call it authentic.
author: Michael L.

description:
many empty tables, but long waiting time
poor food, coconut chicken without chicken
poor service, rude waiter, forced us to order
poor environment, dirty dishes, dirty table, broken dishes
author: Frank C.

description:
I love this place!  When I have visitors from out of town, I make sure to take them here.  I feel like the only reason I go to B*** St** is because I am really far from that part of SF (like in the East Bay).  If I am in SF- there is no choice.  

Family owned and run restaurant that has the best food EVER EVER EVER
author: Melissa L.

description:
Supposedly the first Burmese restaurant in San Francisco, Mandalay doesn't have as much hype compared to Burma Superstar. Food options are very similar, lines are not as long, but service is definitely slower.

The Mandalay Special Noodle is my absolute favorite! There's great flavors and textures in this dish. The flat rice noodles are nice and chewy. The chicken is moist and tender. The fried thin noodles on top add a bold flavor as well as crunch. But what I love the most about this dish is the sauce -- the creamy richness of the coconut sauce pairs perfectly with the more subtle, citrus-y lime juice.

Nan Gyi Dok noodle dish is a close second. It's similar to the Mandalay Special Noodle, but spicier and more acidic because lemon, rather than lime, is used. The rice noodles are just shy of undercooked, because I find them to be too chewy.

The chicken mango is delicious! The dish as a whole is sweet, sour, and a bit spicy. I love the fresh and soft (but not mushy) yellow mangoes. The chicken is moist, tender, juicy, and the batter is so crispy. There's a great balance, proportionally, of ingredients in the dish -- chicken and mangoes are plentiful and onions aren't overabundant.

The tea smoked duck is dry, unfortunately. The flavors are good -- smokey and salty -- but the fact that the meat is dry and doesn't fall off the bone easily made eating it unenjoyable. The dish also comes with buns, scallions, and a sweeter version of Hoisin sauce.

Though I always order tea leaf salad at any new Burmese restaurant I try, I wasn't a huge fan of Mandalay's version. Yes, tea leaf is the main ingredient, but I thought the flavor was so strong compared to the dried shrimp, dried garlic, seeds and nuts. I had to "look" for the other flavors in this salad, but all I could predominately taste was the tea leaf.

Mandalay is spacious and accepts reservations for groups of five or more people. There's large, circular "family-style dining" tables, as well as plenty of smaller tables and booth-seating for four or fewer people. I love all the ornaments handing from the ceiling. Overall, there's a nice, warm, and welcoming feel to Mandalay. Service is very friendly, but a bit slow. Food takes a while to come out of the kitchen, and when the restaurant is packed, sometimes the wait staff confuses orders. Nevertheless, I prefer Mandalay slightly over Burma Superstar, and will come back here to satisfy my Burmese food cravings. Also, parking along California St. is easier (and not metered) compared to Clement St.
author: Priscilla W.

description: The food is amazing but the prices are high and servings are small.  I like this place because you can make reservations.  The service is good.  I don't drive, but street parking doesn't look like a problem and the 1 California bus comes right out front of the restaurant.
author: Marian W.

description:
Got here on a Saturday around 7:45pm. Waited 30 mins to be seated. I was sad that the other tables next to us were seated after us and they got two of their dishes before we ever got any of ours :/

What we ordered:
--Tea leaf salad - Love nutty and crunchy salads but I do wish they included shredded cabbage/lettuce bc it offers a crisp and fresh taste to tea leaf salads. This one was more hardy and a bit more stringent. Next time I want to try the banana blossom salad! 
--Mandalay special noodle - Very good! It's made of flat noodle, coconut chicken, yellow pea powder, some kind of fried crunchy noodle...I loved the kick of the sauce. Think this was my favorite dish this out of the four I tried this trip.
--Dry pan fried string beans - this was ok. It was a bit oily and a bit too salty for my liking. I expected it to have a little bit of a crispy crunch to it like the ones at Chinese restaurants but it was more limp.
--Balada with curry dipping sauce - pretty good. The pancake is buttery and more chewy than flowery. It's carb yummy. The curry dipping sauce was kind of watery so it was dripping all over once I got my piece to my mouth. I do prefer dipping sauces to be more rich and dense but the flavor was there (Burmese curries are a bit more on the mild side).

Last thoughts:
--I've been here twice. 1st time was my first time trying Burmese food and I was blown away. But after trying other Burmese places, feel like I still have yet to find a go-to Burmese restaurant that offers more bang for my bucks (average price per dish here is ~$12).
--Almost no Asian ppl here..why??
--Overalls, good food, relatively fast service, good portions; would recommend this place to a friend
author: Jade Z.

description:
Went to Mandalay since Burma Superstar was closed.  

Not as popular as Superstar, and the food portions seemed smaller.  Has the tea leaf salad here, and it is actually not served with lettuce (which is the more authentic way of eating it).  Also had the Mandalay noodles, samosas and Rangoon beef.  

Everything is freshly mixed together table side.
author: Hieu H.

description:
I don't even know where to begin. Maybe it's the dishes we ordered. But def won't be coming back. 

Started with the Samosas. Pretty bland. Tea leaf salad.. Nope. Just didn't do it for me. 

Burmese hot and sour soup.... Now not only did they bring it to another table. Did not let us know so we waited a little longer and my soup was cool but my boyfriends wasn't hot lol. I just can't with this restaurant. 

For our entrees we had birds nest and Catfish Red Curry. For the price of the birds nest and portion yeah and looked good. But mind you it's not traditional birds nest. Don't expect egg noodles. The crispy like exterior was super salty and they basically use honey walnut sauce. So if you like sweet dishes. Get this. The only reason this place is getting two stars is because of catfish curry. Not for the price. But at least one of our dishes were okay. It was two catfish steaks. Like 1/5 of a catfish with bland sauce for $16. 

All dishes came out to $75. Lame my boyfriend and I weren't at least satisfied with a dish.
author: Ninotchka A.

description:
The food was good, but the service felt so rushed.  From the moment we sat down there was pressure from the entire wait staff to order quickly. Once we finished with our meal, there was pressure to pay the check and get out! 

The constant pressure was annoying! It took away from enjoying the meal!  Will not be going back.
author: Ali T.

description:
Came here on a Friday night. Was in the mood for Burmese and didn't want to deal with a ridiculous wait at other Burmese restaurants. There was 9 groups ahead of us and total wait from arriving to be seated was 15-20 mins so not bad. 
 
Interior is quite spacious though looking from the outside you wouldn't guess. Inside maintains a very traditional Burmese theme. 

Ordered Mandalay Chicken, Mango Prawns, Balada (roti like bread), and Sweet Potato dessert. My first impression when the food came out was "wow, the portions are so small despite what the pictures lead you to believe". There was two of us and one entree was barely enough to fill me up. The Mango Prawns had total 5-6 pieces of prawns and this is miniature size prawns you buy in seafood packets in Asian markets. The Sweet Potato dessert was literally 1.5x0.5. That it seemed like we were ordering dessert from the kids menu. 

Mandalay chicken and the Balada somewhat redeemed this place for me but for the price and small portions I rather eat somewhere more fitting to feed adults.
author: Jude N.

description: The food is outstanding, and you can get a table with no/minimal wait. Definitely as good as Burma Superstar (and I hope it remains a bit of a secret, so we can continue to get a table without a line!), maybe even better.
author: Joey K.

description:
This may be my new favorite Burmese restaurant in SF!

Food- favorites of the night were the fish chowder and kaw soi dok. At first it feels a bit watery compared to others I've had, but once I add some cilantro and lemon in there and tasted the soup more closely, I think it's quite perfect. Super perfect would be some rice vermicelli added in there! But then it wouldn't be just a soup. Hence, it is a quite perfect soup. The Kaw soi dok noodles were a delicate yet chewy texture with just the right balance of flavors with a tiny spiciness, it had some crunchy lentils(?) in there- Overall, the flavors and textures were complete. Pancake itself was okay, but the curry sauce for it was really good. Tasted some fish in there which added another layer of wonderful flavor. Tea leaf salad was very very crunchy with lots of roasted peanuts; it tasted really fresh and not too salty (some places' are way too salty), only bad thing was that it just too much peanuts for me. Four dishes and the three of us were completely satisfied and satiated, we even took a doggie bag with two slices of pancake and a couple bites of kaw soi dok to go!

Ambiance/decor: nothing quite like it in SF I'd have to say. The lighted fake Palm tree near the door was rather interesting. Interior was well decorated with plants and busy with paintings (?Fabric elephants) and statues/sculptures(?). Sorry, it was so busy in there and I was so taken by the food I can't recall! 

Service: super friendly staff. Our order was correct and food came out pretty quickly. Despite the fact that the three of us squeezed into a table that normally fits two, we made it work, carefully stacking and rearranging our plates and glasses to fit everything. Staff came by quickly to help us clear whatever we didn't need often so we didn't feel too uncomfortable.

Overall, great food and a wonderful experience. Will be back again. It gets pretty busy after 7pm with sign-up wait list and people waiting at the door. However, reservations are available for large parties! ;P
author: Iris H.

description:
We love this restaurant we come from many travels and this is our first stop of all the restaurants in the city. We love the food and beautiful people who work there. thank you very much carry-on. The sizzling rice soup rainbow salad and the green beans and seafood dish are to die for!
Anya M f
author: Anna S.

description:
Horrible service, but tasty food.  They need to figure out the hostess situation. So odd that the hostess can't seat people without the owner permission. We were skipped over twice, no apology what so ever.

We ordered:
Tea leaf salad- one of the best I had

Balada- pancake is too thick and doughy, but curry dip is really good

Catfish chowder soup- surprisingly tasty and light

Mandalay Beef- DO NOT ORDER, thick batter beef where all I taste is the batter and can't tell if the tiny piece of meat is beef, pork or something else

Okra prawn- my favorite, okra is cooked just right with a little crunch and flavorful
author: Happi Y.

description:
One of our all time favorites!  We returned to Mandalay tonight after a while, and were very happy to find the food as good as we remembered it.

We loved the lamb curry, platha, and tea leaf salad - these three dishes are phenomenal!  We also enjoyed the Khao Soi noodles and Rangoon Three mixed seafood dish.  The spicy tofu with vegetables was the only average dish.

The service was decent.  Our only complaint was that we were originally seated at an uncomfortably small table (they squeezed our party of 4 into a table meant for 2), but they moved us early into our meal when a larger table opened up.

The decor is nice and there is a lot of beautiful traditional Burmese artwork on the walls.
 
We love Mandalay and will continue to come back!
author: Barnali D.

description:
Stunning food.  Bright yet romantic interior. Staff in traditional dress. Even the cutlery and plate are solid and satisfying.

The sparkling wine on offer is from the Côte d'Or , near Dijon, and it is lovely, and inexpensive.

Mandalay is beguiling in every way.
author: Patricia P.

description:
I don't understand what the hype is all about. 
First, they didn't seat us for more than half an hour even though we had a reservation. 
The tea leaf salad and samosa soup were below par. 
The service was terrible and the hostess was very rude. 
I've had much better food at Burma Superstar and Rangoon Ruby.
Never coming back here and will most definitely not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Rohini A.

description:
While I was devouring my meal last night, on an admittedly empty stomach, I thought - is this the best meal I've had all year or am I just really hungry? 

I decided to sleep on it, wake up, and really analyze my experience. After a bit of contemplation and reflection, I realized that yes - this certainly was the best meal I've had all year. My taste buds poured while I danced through the memories of crunchy candied walnuts, coconutty noodles, and crunchy, perfect okra. If you're a vegetarian (or any human, really), follow my lead:

What we ordered and what you should order: 
1. Samosas (vegetarian) 
2. Chin Hin Yee (Burmese hot & sour soup) - vegetarian
3. Mandalay special noodle (vegetarian) 
4. Walnut broccoli tofu (WINNER!!!!!)
5. Coconut rice 

Please do as I say and make your mouth happy, ok?
author: Tori M.

description:
Having been to Mandalay, B-star, and Burma Superstar each at least 2 - 4 times now, I'd say in terms of quality: Burma Superstar, then B-star, then Mandalay.

The place has less of a wait than Buma Superstar likely because (a) it is less popular and (b) the place has more tables. The service is just fine.  It is the food that sets them apart.

The menu doesn't overlap too much, actually, between the two. Though Mandalay also has a tea leaf salad that I would say is by and large about the same as Burma Superstar. Personally, I'm just not that into the tea leaf salad anyway.

We ordered the Mandalay lamb --- it was not good. The lamb was overcooked and coated heavily in this gooey, greasy, sticky, sweet and spicy sauce. It's like Panda Express, but way pricier. 

The coconut rice is OK, but I think Burma Superstar's is fluffier. 

We also got the Mandalay special noodle, which really is just plain noodles simmer in coconut + lemongrass broth. It's not bad, but nothing interesting and I'm not a carb fan to begin with.

Overall, the menu is less intriguing (and less "burmese" since this place has a heavier Chinese influence) and the food is just less refined.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Really good food here. The tea leaf salad is a must. It isn't as green as the tea leaf salads a few blocks away at B-star/superstar because adding lettuce is apparently not a traditional part of that dish. It's quite good either way, maybe because fermented tea leaves are awesome. 

Most of the other dishes are quite decent, though nothing really stands out. Only the tea leaf salad is a constant between visits. The service is slightly better than average for an asian restaurant with really good food.

I would come here more often if they took reservations small groups. But I've been told that I needed a party of more than 4 before they would let someone make a reservation.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Marin Headland trail run completed at 1:30. Showered and ready to go at 2:30. Say, the weather is perfect, but is it perfect for a nap on a Saturday afternoon? The answer is always yes. Woke up at 3:30. Asking myself, should I cancel my optometrist appointment in West Portal in lieu of food? Who cares that one's running out of contacts when one's absolutely hungry and it's closing in on 4 PM and I've yet to eat my first meal? Dressed, dragging my tired ass, out of the door but not before phoning to just to make sure. The last time we drove all the way to outer sunset and nothing was open at 4 PM on a Sunday. Thankfully this was not that.

In truth I am ready for something other than Burma Superstar. En route, I check out the busy and not so busy area of the burbs. It's mildly irritating for I was famished and California street seemed so far away coming from the Park side.

Seated. Ordered. Reassessing the scene. It feels like a touristy place found in a medium size European town. Very local residential. This is what's so funny about this stretch, between 5 and 9th on California, where this restaurant resides, it felt like I was back in Munich for some reason. It could pass for any number of cities that are not quite world class but medium in size and status. Think: Guangzhou, China; Munich, Germany or Prague, Czech Republic, but at the same time, it could also pass for a residential district of a major metropolis, like when you hear people say, "Oh, that's for locals.". Like the 10th arrondissement of Paris, or that ally street I took in Istanbul while searching for the spice market. There is a lot of energy, but not the kind you would see in other parts of the city of San Francisco, as in it's understated because it's nothing too special but special enough to raise rug rats, and I mean it in the best possible ways.

In short, this is a funky, out of place neighborhood, and the restaurant itself also felt out of place. 

That said, at 4 PM we received excellent service. The food was great. The special seemed worth checking out: we got the shaken pork belly but I called it pork belly mountain. The Burmese rainbow salad was good but note that it's got noodles in it. The last dish we ordered was a Burmese noodle dish, which reminded me of Laotian and Balinese food for some reason. 

My companion was very interested in my opinion. "Do you like it?" I answered "Yes of course." I was starving. I could have liked sweet and sour pork at this point, but the food was very good. It took me back to Bali of all places. 

A perfect Saturday afternoon indeed. Good food, strange neighborhood, and great partner-in-crime to explore the ethnic food scene with.
author: Victoria E.

description: Food is always good, servers are nice, and restaurant is cute. Our favorites are the mandalay special noodles and balata.
author: Tina L.

description: This is one of my favourite places. The tea leaf salad, rainbow salad and sizzling rice soup are all on point. Would continually return, even though it's a bit pricey.
author: Linh D.

description:
First: music is horrible. I wanted a Monday lunch, not a Friday night in a club playing house and hip hop music.
Second: we are from out of town and searched for a kid friendly place for lunch. This is the absolute opposite. Although they do have highchairs, they do not have a kids menu, and they will not accommodate your children in terms of food. We could not just get a simple side of vegetables (no dish under $12). She said "we have the option that you can order something and share with your children". How is this an option? I think I can figure that out myself, thanks.
Third: there was a HAIR in my husbands dish. They did offer to remake it and we passed, so they reduced it from the bill...
Fourth: apparently they do not have a delivery entrance, as all the deliveries were being made right past us as we ate lunch. The plumber, the food, and the toiletries. Kinda gross.
As for the food: it tasted great, just too bad all of the above happened (yelps fault on hours? And being kid friendly?)...
author: C F.

description: I would never have found this place if my buddy didn't live near here, and we get the munchies after a party, which is when a bunch of us showed up here. Boy does everything taste unbelievable, pretty much everything on the menu is phenomenal and super tasty, especially because they make it as spicy or not as you want, and I can't take too much heat, unless I drink a sip of beer after every bite, but I told my therapist I'm cutting down and I'm trying to keep my word to her LOL. Anyway, their version of thai tea is pretty rad and totally the bomb, so I can guzzle those down with the best of them. The sambusa and roti version is awesome, oh and they also do vegetarian options great--trying to be healthier and eat less meat, to go along with the less alcohol.
author: Mack L.

description:
Hands down my favorite restaurant in SF. And that's saying a lot! We moved to San Jose and this restaurant is one of the main reasons I miss living in the city so much!

You have to try their Tea Leaf Salad and their Mandalay Special Noodle (my go-to order).

The staff is so friendly.

The only downside is that this place gets slammed Fri-Sun nights (it's a very small, beloved restaurant), but it's always worth the wait! 

I wish I could give more than 5 stars!
author: Morgan R.

description:
I love yelp and check please....but dang son....when the word is out the word is out.

6pm on a Saturday night and 20 people crowding each other to get a table...ha ha...it is nice to get there a tad earlier. It was worse when we left at 7:45.

Food is still solid after all these years. It is not cheap...but it is good quality food.

Ambiance is great, less pretense and hipster quotient than Burma superstar...and cleaner. Nice decor, Nice help, and nice presentation.

The four of us had rainbow salad, pumpkin curry, noodle special, rice, walnut shrimp(this aint a burmese dish...but it was good), and a great beef dish.

Cost was 80 bucks..not bad....They got us in and out (per our request to be at an 8 oclock show).

Check out this place...but be prepared for the wait
author: David G.

description: Better than the more well known B-Star and Burma Superstar. The food here is always so good. Plus, the staff are fast and friendly. One of my favorite food spots in SF!!
author: Adelle K.

description: Everything is nice and good here. Reason why I not giving full stars is based on the portion size, they priced it based on fine dining pricing which to me I think is pricy comparing to most of the Burmese restaurant. This place is not fancy restaurant, very casual restaurant and I don't think the food here is authentic Burmese food. All food I ordered tasted great, but very "Chinese" cooking. I'm an Asian and I from Asia. I know all Asian food. Staffs is nice and hygiene level good.
author: Unyo N.

description: Have I never reviewed this always crowded place? Mary Mother of God I've been remiss. This place is five stars in most ways - the food is artful, delicious and prepared with care, and the service is consistently outstanding. These are really nice folks. The only thing that takes it out of five stardom is the prices. My date and I spent $55 for dinner there last night, which isn't bad - except that I'd already eaten, so it was really dinner for 1. Ok make that 1.2, I couldn't help nibbling, but still. Anyway, price aside, you should 100% try this place if you haven't been. It's excellent.
author: Nick C.

description: Have gone to Mandalay for years as our go to Burmese restaurant. Warm and efficient servers and all around delicious dishes. I will say the prices per dish are not cheap and the portions of the dishes not particularly large but the quality and taste of the food is always 5 star. Mango Chicken, Rangoon Beef, Naked Eggplant, House Special Noodles (mixed at the table), Coconut Rice and Papaya Salad are dishes you can not go wrong with. The desert combo of cold coconut gelatin pieces and warm sweet potato creations of the same shape are a wonderful finish. Love Mandalay!!!!
author: Steven B.

description:
Totally delicious food, although a lot of it has FAR too much sugar for my tastes- the popular salads, for instance. It's like man, you can get better flavors out of fresh ingredients and good quality sea salt, etc. You don't need a ton of vinegar and sugar.

Otherwise the specials, like the fish specials, are divine, albeit expensive, but you gotta pay more to eat here... it's just that kind of a restaurant.

Portions are also too small.

In other words this place has bomb food, but is somewhat pricey and the portions are lacking... and that's a combination that really pisses me off in a restaurant because it shows they're compulsively obsessed with eeking every last dollar of you, instead of producing a better dining experience at a slightly elevated cost to themselves.
author: Grizzle J.

description: One of the worst restaurant experiences we have ever suffered in SF.  Terrible service, overpriced food, terrible food.  Ordered the chicken samosas and did not taste one piece of chicken.  Jasmine tea was $5.00 a glass.  Ordered the tea duck and mushu pork, both of which took forever to arrive.  When the plates arrived, the duck was cold and had to be sent back.  The mushu pork was greasy and tasteless.  Left most of it on the plate.  Al this came to almost $60.00, wasted money.  Would not recommend this place to my worst enemy.
author: B. P.

description:
Delicious flavors, very fresh ingredients, perfectly cooked shrimp. Went with five friends - one a local - and we shared all our appetizers and main dishes. Another local had recommended this place. Service was attentive and friendly. What a wonderful new experience! 

Highlights:

Balada - crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce.  Like an Indian chapati and the yellow curry sauce was delicious. 

Tea leaf salad - small mounds of Burmese tea leaves, toasted red lentils, shrimp/fish sauce, fried garlic, green peppers, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing tossed at the table. Crunchy, textured, very tasty. 

Smoked tea duck - fatty and crispy duck slices topped with a curried squash mash. Beautiful presentation. 

Burmese curry with shrimp - the gravy was rich, tasted of tomatoes and onions (no cream) - shrimp cooked perfectly, sided with slices of cucumber, tomato and steamed/seasoned broccoli. 

Sizzling shrimp - on a platter with peppers, onions, water chestnuts, a sweet glaze. 

It was all phenomenal. Coconut rice was very tasty, too. Try the ginger mint lemonade. The Burmese iced tea was like Thai tea. 

I'd go back in a heartbeat next time we're in the area. No wonder the locals love it!
author: FoodGirl G.

description: Mandalay has a much shorter wait than Burma Superstar. I would argue the food is just as good too. I'm a big fan of the Tea Leaf Salad (I know that one's obvious), Mandalay Chicken, and Rangoon Beef. Added bonus, you can make reservations online.
author: Tyler D.

description:
I feel so lucky to live so close to all these Burmese restaurants.  Burma superstar and B star are both exceptional, however, I find myself only going to Mandalay.  

Everything I've ordered is good, rainbow salad, tea leaf, lamb curry ( great with coconut rice ), Mandalay chicken ( beats the hell out of Chinese orange chicken) and every noodle dish I've tried.  The must have dishes that make me choose Mandalay, though, are the pan fried okra prawn and sautéed green beans. The flanks are incredible. 

The staff is also great and I've found the wait time to be more accommodating than Burma...Thank you Mandalay!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Burmese food heaven. Went there because Burma Superstar had 40 people waiting in line. 

On a weekday at around 2pm, the place was packed however, we were seated promptly as luckily there were some open spots. 

Tried the Samusa soup for the very first time. Also had a veggie curry (suggested by the hostess) which was not on the menu with coconut rice. And of course tea leaf salad. Overall the food was excellent.
author: A. D.

description:
Who knew Burmese food could be so delicious?! As I've browsed through many Asian restaurants on Yelp, many of the Burmese restaurants in SF came to the top of the search. We saw a couple highly rated ones (Mandalay, Burma Super Star, etc)-- but we chose to go with Mandalay since Burma Super Star seems to always be busy.

Mandalay is a cozy restaurant, with great service. The waiters are attentive and welcoming, and best of all-- the food was BOMB :)

We ordered:

Tea Leaf salad
Mango Chicken
Burmese Curry Beef
Singapore Style Noodle
Smoked Tea Duck

The Tea Leaf Salad was one of the best things we've had that night. When it arrived at our table, I was surprised-- I didn't see a single leaf in this salad LOL. It was a bit confusing, and I was asking my friend, "Uh where are the leaves?" And she pointed out that the tea leaves are the dark substance that was fermented. Sounds gross, but the "salad" was so good-- it was a mixture of lemony, crunchy (lots of peanuts in there), and spicy-ish. Definitely a unique dish.

Everything else we had was great too, especially the Mango Chicken and Singapore Style Noodle. I wasn't that impressed with the Smoked Tea Duck though, because the portion was really small.

Mandalay is a great place to dine in and experience authentic Burmese food, but in my opinion, the portions are on the smaller side.
author: Grace H.

description: This place is far superior to Burma Superstar.  The ingredients are higher quality and the flavors seem more balanced and delicate.  My favorite things on the menu are: (1) the tea leaf salad (prepared at table); (2) the Moo Hin Nga, or fish chowder, which is especially good with a pile of cilantro and a few squeezes of lemon wedge that they bring to you; and (3) the Mandalay Special Noodle, which has a nice richness from the coconut chicken coupled with crunch from thin-fried onions on top.  There are also a bunch of pretty standard Thai restaurant offerings, like Thai iced tea and mango sticky rice for dessert.  Service is friendly and efficient, restaurant is tidy and well maintained.
author: Jonathan R.

description: I live right between Burma Superstar and Mandalay and I must say Mandalay is always my first pick. Not only is the wait shorter, but the food is consistently amazing and the staff is really nice. I'm a vegetarian and there are a ton of great options. I always order the tea leaf salad, mandalay special noodle with tofu, and the dry pan friend string bean. The tea leaf salad is so flavorful and the mandalay special noodle has this ridiculous sauce that is creamy and also citrus. I don't know how to explain but it's definitely worth trying. And string beans! The fact that they can make a single vegetable worth writing about means something. They're seriously amazing!
author: Sophie S.

description:
This review is not based on the food. Despite the food being extremely popular here and delicious, this is about the customer service which so happened to be short on proper hospitality. 

First off, we made reservations early on in the day and the host clarified we were in for 7pm. We got here 10 mins early and had all members of our party in attendance. We still had to wait an HOUR and watch as they let walk-in groups bigger AND some smaller than ours get seated. Luckily the host approached us and asked if we'd like to order before we're seated so we didn't have to wait any longer.

When the food came, the first few dishes came in order. Right after the 3rd dish/appetizer was served, the server dropped food on one of the individuals in our party. Good thing our friend had a sense of humor about it. Our server also did not check on us but once during our dinner. As soon as we'd get through about half of the dish or dishes, random servers seemed to want to clear the table and continuously came back even though it was pretty evident we were still working on our food (Seemed like they were almost rushing us to finish even though we waited an hr with reservations and yet only about 30mins elapsed since we were seated, did they run out of plates in the kitchen?) At the end of our dinner, the customer service was pretty unsatisfactory.

Food was about 7/10. Didn't wow us. The food was comparable to other Burmese food around the Bay Area, but to each their own according to personal preference.

Ambience was great. Soft music in the back ground, proper lighting and decorations.

Again, despite the food and restaurant itself being satisfactory , it all came down to the customer service which was poor.. 

Try it yourself maybe you'll have a better experience.
author: Aaron B.

description: The flavors and variety were incredible. The service was attentive and friendly. An amazing wine list for such a mid-range restaurant. Excellent experience and makes me want to go to Burma!
author: Eater S.

description:
I'm a big fan of Burmeses food,  I have been eating Burmese food for years and have Burmese friends that cook really good Burmese.  I've dined at the Burlingame location and always enjoyed my meal and had lunch at the San Francisco restaurant over a year ago when the food was much better.  

I recently brought an out of town guest here for lunch.  The food really has gone downhill.  The coconut chicken noodle soup was watery, barely had any chicken nor flavor, nor many of the usually condiments (fried corn, crispy garlic, etc).  The noodles also were not good.  The texture of the balada was different from what I'm accustomed to... it was thicker like a pancake, but good.  However, the dipping sauce was watery and made my stomach sick shortly after having lunch.  My brother had the mango chicken with samosas... only average and way overpriced.  Everything was so bland and watered down.  Portions were small.  Maybe we're more picky since we're HAPA (southeast asian)?  I had to apologize to my brother for the below average lunch.

Tea leaf salad is still good so extra star.
author: Angelique B.

description:
This place is a true 5 star.  Everything good written about it I found to be right on.  

We had a party of 14 and they accommodated us with no drop-off in service.  We had a wide variety of several different dishes and all the food, the flavors and the quality were exceptional.  The servers worked their butts off and were efficient, polite and good natured even after we closed the place down.  

It's crowded and loud and fun as hell. There was a birthday sing along with special dessert at one table down from us and then a wedding song and special dessert for my daughter & her guy when they found out she was getting married the next day.

I was impressed...
author: Moon S.

description:
Wow! I have only recently started to explore Burmese cuisine and visited a few highly recommended SF restaurants and thought that I would give Mandalay a shot.  Holy Moses! This restaurant instantly entered my top 5 in the city.  Amazing flavors, kind and courteous staff, good service and a check at the end which felt like we had been undercharged for our experience.  I will be a regular at Mandalay.

Everything that we ate was delicious, but the Volcano Beef was the show stopper.  Worth twice the charge.  My jasmine tea arrived in an oversized wine glass which confused me, but as it steeped, the little ball of tea expanded into an ornate flower in the glass. Very cool and very good.  Can't say enough - go there.
author: Bob M.

description: I and my wife thought the food was ok but nothing to brag about.  Honestly, it we were given a choice of coming back or trying something new (to us), we'd go for something new.
author: Dodeskaden L.

description: Woman owner or manager is gruff. We spoke Burmese to her and she wasn't very nice.  Food tastes more like Thai for some dishes.
author: Bart D.

description:
Great food! I've had Burma Superstar twice before, so, I've been a fan of Burmese food ever since. My friend and I ordered green tea leaf salad, special noddles, volcano beef, and string beans with seafood. For drinks, Burmese ice tea. We were here on a Wednesday night before fatsgiving. 

My friend never had Burmese food, so, I surprised her with the dishes above. Both of us enjoyed the well prepared dishes that filled our bellies up. The special noddles were fantastic, almost like tasting a thai curry dish, but with noodles!! The volcano beef was so tender and juicy. It went really well with the well cooked asparagus. The Green Tea Leaf salad, as always, was excellent with the lemon juice and so crunchy with all the nuts! Last, but not least, the string beans with seafood did not disappoint with the meat and the vegetables delivering flavor to our mouths. 

Service was excellent, no problem here. A bit much $$$ for the amount of food, but well worth it to take your lady friend out and impress her with a different style of food with quality. Highly date recommendation gentleman!!!

Overall: Excellent food, Excellent service, Great price
author: Nestor G.

description: The food here is so delicious. Like seriously, awesome. I wish I could come back here often. Unfortunately, pretty expensive. But, the flavor of all their entrees are good. I really like the tea leaf salad, though, as it's so fresh and surprisingly spicy. Their special noodles are good, though they definitely stick to your sides with all the coconut in there. Everything is good, just choose something.
author: Ruobin W.

description: AMAZING food. I ordered the Samusa Soup, the Rainbow Salad, and a Balada. All extremely delicious. Prompt service despite being pretty busy one of the times I went. Very friendly staff, and a gorgeous atmosphere. One of my favorites of all time.
author: Savannah K.

description:
Went with a group of 12. Super-delicious! Standout dishes were the Mandalay beef, a special beef dish, the fried chicken, the eggplant and the coconut chicken soup.

The service was great given the craziness inside the restaurant (the place was completely packed).
author: Juney H.

description:
This was great! My boyfriend and I were looking for a restaurant to eat out around 8:30pm on a Friday Night. Of course, I went on Yelp and searched restaurants around the area. Fortunately, I came across this Burmese restaurant! We've been dining at many Burmese restaurants lately and have grown very fond of the food! 

4 stars:
*AMAZING service. I was so impressed with how the waiters and waitresses tended to the tables. When we left the restaurant, the entire staff said Thank you! It was a pleasant surprise and truly made the dining experience a fantastic one.

*Delicious food. We ordered the Rainbow Salad that was jam-packed full of flavors! Tasty and an absolute must order! The orange chicken was pretty good too. It wasn't the absolute best, but it wasn't bad either.

*Decor was so-so. It's March and they still have their Holiday Ornaments hanging from the ceiling. That's great decor for the holidays, but given that it's spring time the ornaments just make the restaurant unappealing to the eye. 


I definitely want to come back and try other items on the menu and perhaps bump up this restaurant to a 5 star rating.
author: Briana H.

description: Quaint atmosphere makes it a very cosy and intimate ambiance in the restaurant. The food is amazing! Everything we got! If we stayed in SF longer we would have come here everyday for lunch and dinner to try out every dish on the menu! The tea leaf salad, pan fry string bean with seafood, walnut prawn and nan gyi dok was absolutely delicious!!! Definitely recommend it!
author: Beata M.

description: While visiting some family in SF we were asked if we wanted to try some Burmese food for dinner. I knew of Burma/Myanmar, but never really stopped to think about what the cuisine would be like. Always ready to try new foods, I jumped on the opportunity. There are actually two Burmese restaurants located in the same area, so be sure to go with Mandalay! It is hard to miss, with a bright yellow exterior and a green awning. There were many dishes to choose from, so we let our hosts handle the ordering. Of the dishes we got the most memorable was a tea leaf salad. This is a new concept to me: a salad with dried tea leafs, some dry lentils, and other more common salad ingredients.
