Each bite had a mix of crunchy and soft, as well as tang from the dressing and a characteristic tea taste expected of the leaves. I also really enjoyed their lettuce wraps with chicken. We got a beef dish as well as chicken skewers, and a couple noodle dishes. I would say that Burmese food is a mix of Chinese, Thai, and Indian flavored to make something unique and worth trying. On this occasion we did not dine-in. We picked up food and ate at home, but while I waited at the curb I noticed that Mandalay had consistent foot traffic and people hopping out of Ubers. I highly suggest eating here as all of the dishes turned out to have a new and refreshing twist to the more run-of-the-mill ethnic cuisines we are used to in the States.
author: Vats A.

description:
Pretty decent selection here, good for big groups so you can try some of several dishes. One of my faves is the catfish chowder (more like a stew) with noodles- just the right amount of savory flavor and noodle soup goodness to eat as your main entree alone.

We also ordered the kao soi which was okay, nothing memorable, and the tea leaf salad which is good but doesn't have the crunchy lettuce texture that I prefer from BStar. Fried crispy lamb and chicken were meh.

Would come here again for sure to check out the other dishes like coconut chicken noodle soup and the house special noodles. Overall good spot as long as your order the right dishes among many choices!
author: Nancy W.

description: Funky atmosphere, great for all occasions, I could imagine bringing my wife as a first date or an anniversary.   Smoked tea duck and the balada bread are a must try.   Noisy and jovial atmosphere.  Moderately priced.  Wait staff mostly friendly but busy.
author: shun p.

description: When we were visiting San Francisco my wife's burmese family treated us to this place which didn't disappoint. The owner came around and spoke Burmese and English asking how everything was. Unique dishes tea leaf salad ( though don't eat this late since it is tea leaves and have caffeine) and coconut based noodles. This place is family owned and run by family members so this place feels more like visiting family home and is worth a visit. Only thing I wish was this place was available in southern California.
author: Bryant N.

description: The food is awesome but over the years, the prices have risen to the point where it is no longer a good value. There are other Burmese restaurants in the Bay Area which give you more bang for your buck.  Service is just ok.
author: Chrys S.

description:
I went with a group of 8 so I was really excited to be able to try ALL OF THE DiSHES I wanted to try there! But alas, I was pretty disappointed. The flavors weren't all there. 

The tea leaf salad had a lot of nuts, and no salad. 
The roti with curry, wasn't very flavorful
the noodles were ok
the hot dishes were ok
the coconut rice was good

I think the whole time I was comparing this to Burma Superstar and B star so I'd say if you haven't tried the other two, you should go there instead.
author: Joanna S.

description: Unusual, very good. Pancake, tea salad, special noodle, smoked tea duck, rice, flower tea.
author: smoker d.

description: Went here for dinner with my Boyfriend and family. Had the food family style and loved EVERYTHING (6 dishes) Will definitely be coming back. I can see why they are always busy!
author: Kirsten J.

description:
As if this place really needs another raving review ...

The service here is great, the atmosphere is nice, and the food is so incredibly delicious and full of flavor!

I love the Special Noodles not only because it is so satisfying to the palate but also because it's one of the dishes the service staff will mix right in front of you at the table. So fun to watch.

If you're in a group, order multiple dishes and eat family style! Share and try EVERYTHING! Also, order the balada as an appetizer!

Or if you're eating alone ... You don't have to eat alone, I'll join you! How else will you finish your entree and have room for dessert?

The only not-so-good thing I have to say are things out of Mandalay's control -- the parking. It's the Inner Richmond and parking is and always will be a b*tch.
author: Sheena W.

description:
Funny how we had dinner here one night when my friend said it was really good.  When I came back to write a review, I realized that I had bookmarked this place because I wanted to try it.  Don't you love it when that happens?

I'm not going to go into detail about all the dishes we had since I think they've been nicely summarized by other reviewers.  What I will say is that the service was attentive, the decor was nicely themed out, and the food was great all around.
author: Lorie N.

description: I had friends from Switzerland visiting so decided to take them to Mandalay for dinner. They never disappoint in how good the food is. And the food again was very nice. The garlic beef was excellent although I would not order the mo shu pork again. Pancakes were cold when served. But overall really nice food and I definitely recommend their kitchen!! Then why 3 stars? The waiter was so pushy that if it would had just been me in there with my husband, we would have left! Even before asking about drinks he was very direct that we should order appetizers. We were not interested but he kept insisting. He even took my menu out of my hands while doijg it, showing what he meant to my friends on my menu and ignoring me completely. When the appetizer pushing did not work he asked about drinks. My friend wanted a diet coke but he was not having that. He kept pointing out other, more expensive, drinks. She had to keep telling him she just wanted a diet coke. When I just stuck to water he tried persuading me to have coconut water instead and was not pleased I did not want it. As I said. I would have left and gone elsewhere at that point if it would have been just me. When he came over to get the food order he again tried pushing the specials. This guy would just not let us make our own choices and kept pushing for the more expensive options. So food great, as all the other times I have been in here but service very disappointing in that next time I may opt to take my friends elsewhere.
author: Heidi H.

description: Perfect. Mango Salad, walnut broccoli chicken coconut rice, and ginger mint lemonade--all perfectly balanced in a comfortable atmosphere with attentive service. Thoroughly enjoyed this lunch following a hike at Lands End
author: KoAnn S.

description: I just love Mandalay's food. The owners who run the place are even lovelier. I have been visiting their restaurant for 15+ years and I'm still a big fan. Much love!
author: Moe T.

description:
Has it happened? Have I actually had the best meal of my entire life in San Francisco?

Oh, it happened. And it all went down at Mandalay.

A friend of mine had been talking about Burmese all week, and I wasn't too clear on what all the fuss was about. I'm not sure what I expected, but I certainly didn't expect my mind to be blown in such earth-shattering ways. I know this is pretty dramatic when talking about food, but you guys. YOU GUYS.

This place only takes reservations for groups over five, so see if you can get some friends to go... otherwise you might be waiting a bit. Even with a reservation we had to wait 15 minutes or so, but I get it now that I've had the food. Staff was so friendly the whole time, too, so that helped with the wait. We were seated in a cute little booth and got to take in the lively, busy atmosphere as we ate our way through the menu alongside a bottle of sparkling.

I'm going to give a rundown of what I had, and suggest ordering it all... I wouldn't change a single thing about my meal and am going to be repeating it next time. We started with the tea leaf salad (prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimp, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts, and dressing.) So much flavor, so crunchy, so many wonderful things happening. Next up was the coconut chicken soup, and it was the best version of this classic I've had so far. For my entree, I had the Mandalay Special Noodles, which is a giant, colorful, flavorful plate of Burmese flat noodles. mild coconut chicken, yellow pea powder, lime juice, onion, and fried thin noodles on top. Our server squeezed lime on top and mixed it right in front of me. Everyone enjoyed their entrees, but mine was definitely the star of the show. 

I am so glad I've been introduced to this incredible cuisine, and wish I could get it close to home. I'll be visiting Mandalay each and every time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Aimee K.

description:
Burmese food is awesome, and we were super excited to try this place because we are on a noodle quest for the city's best noodles. So we rounded up a bunch of monkeys and reserved a table at this popular spot in the city.

We still ended up waiting 20 mins+ for a table, when we arrived within 15 mins of our reserved time. I know the place is popular, but if it doesn't honour reservations then why allow them? 

They have big round tables, which is nice for big parties. We got some of their specialty tea and lemonade drinks, and they are pretty darn good. We then ordered quite a few dishes to share.

The kau soi dok was actually pretty good. It was different from the usual noodles -- apart from the usual savory and spicy flavour, there was also a bit sour and a bit sweet. The smoked tea duck was served kind of like Peking duck, with a smokier flavour, and the string beans were crispy and savory. The tea leaf salad? Same old, very similar to what other places offer. I was really disppointed with the curries though. First, the pumpkin curry was way too watery, and there were not a lot of chicken. Second, the lychee prawns, while pretty, was served in a very small portion. It only had 4 prawns, 4 lychees, and some pineapples!

We seemingly ordered quite a bit of food, but it ended up being just enough. Plus the staff didn't know what they were doing a lot of the time, especially when the table was full. We had to actively clean the table ourselves.

Overall the food was edible and had good flavours, but it was so not worth the wait. There are quite a few Burmese places in the bay area so be sure to try some of the other ones.
author: Alice C.

description:
Lunch on a Friday.

This restaurant is half about the show and presentation. They bring out the dish and mix it for you (tea leaf salad and special noodle).

Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok): Salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing-- It was good but felt like I was eating mainly nuts covered with sesame. Before mixing in front of you, they explain which ingredient is where on the plate.

Mandalay Mango Chicken: Pan fried chicken sauteed with fresh mango, onions and green chili-- Very flavorful and the chicken was nice and crispy on the outside 

Mandalay Special Noodle: Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top-- MUST try. Love the flat noodles and tasted very creamy.

Mandalay ginger lemonade: Barely taste ginger. Tastes more like a lemonade with a mint mojito kick aftertaste.

Felt like they need another waiter or two. I only saw one person taking orders and 2 bus boys/food mixers.
author: Lauren K.

description: Solid Burmese fare! Got the balada, the tea leaf salad, and the pumpkin chicken curry. The balada was a huge winner!
author: Peter N.

description: This place gets pretty busy. We made reservation for 8 people on Monday and the restaurant was full. The food here was good, but we didn't like the service.  We had a couple of kids and it felt like they didn't want us there the whole time. They tried to be friendly but it felt fake. Beware. We ordered two orders of the tea leaf salad, but when it came out, it looked like one order. How do we know? Because it wasn't enough, so we ordered one more order, and the portion looked the same as the first! The tea leaf salad was flavorful and I would also recommend the coconut chicken curry noodle.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Highlights
- This is on my list of restaurants on the regular rotation list. I LOVE this place!
- Never a long wait and service is always amazing. 
- Lemon served with water and straw included, check!
- Tea leaf salad: So many different ingredients, but they mesh so well and taste great. 
- Mandalay special noodle: Curry sauce with noodles, chicken, and some other items. Favorite dish. 
- Pea shoots: Tender, flavorful, and delicious. Must order. 
- Rainbow salad: It includes various types of noodles and a plethora of other ingredients. Refreshing version of the herty Mandalay noodle minus the chicken. 
- Soups are great too. Samusa soup fills the room with the aroma of spices and is very filling. 
- I've tried a bunch of things on their menu, but the ones I've listed are my absolute favorites that I always order. Trust!

Improvements
- None really, decor is the same year round with Christmas ornaments and other quirky random things. 

Tips
- Street parking isn't too bad if you roam around the neighboring streets and aren't afraid to walk a little bit.
author: Tracy T.

description:
My friend and I stopped into Mandalay yesterday for lunch after walking for an hour or so on Baker Beach. I knew I wanted Burmese from the moment I awoke that lovely Sunday morning, as Saturday I had spent most of the day in bed, nursing a wicked hangover. 

We shared the Papaya Salad, flavorful and crunchy, with sweet tomatoes and cucumbers on the side. Too many red onions for my taste, but I picked around them and enjoyed the slivered almonds and crispy fried onion pieces. I ordered off the menu for my lunch, the same dish as I had before with my mom, Pumpkin Tofu. It was just as good as I remembered. The pumpkin was filling, sweet, and rich, the tofu, light with custardy insides. I also ordered brown rice to be the bed for the yummy yellow curry sauce. Lots of green and red bell peppers, carrots, and green beans. It's a palatable and aesthetically pleasing dish that I recommend to anyone, not just non-meat eaters.

My friend had the Mandalay Special Noodle which was Burmese flat noodle (similar to a Linguini style noodle), mild coconut chicken, lime leaves, fried onions, lemon juice, and cilantro. The chicken was tender and cut into tiny pieces. I liked the freshness that the lemon juice added, but the lime leaves were bitter so I picked around them after trying a bite with noodles and chicken. 

The wait staff is friendly, the restaurant is a bit tacky decoration-wise (Christmas ornaments hung from the ceiling and light fixtures that look like they came from one of those stores in Chinatown where you're like, who would ever in their right mind buy one of those?), but it's not an art gallery, and I come for the food, so no harm, no foul.
author: Crystal C.

description: We went for lunch on a Friday.  The combination lunch entrees for $15 were a good way to sample the food.  Portion six was good! The green papaya salad was delicious. The two chicken dishes were very tasty the balata was a bit thick.  I prefer roti which is much thinner. Would love to try some of their other dishes!   The ambience and service were impressive! Highly recommended.
author: Doreen F.

description: Omg this place is amazing!! Get the tea salad, the noodles, and the chicken curry! So yummy!!!
author: Tuna A.

description:
I came here for the first time about 3 years ago and for some reason, I hated it.

Some friends wanted to try this place, so I decided to give Mandalay another try. 
OKAY I have no idea why I hated this place in the first place. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing. Maybe it was a bad day. Maybe I just had bad taste in food 3 years ago.  

This place is good! The tea leaf salad was my favorite dish. Honestly, it looks like a plate of random things, but when mixed together, it was a delicious blend of unique flavors. Everything complemented well. Mmmm crunchy and flavorful! The Mandalay Special Noodle and the Balada are also good! I would skip out on the mango chicken though..There were more mangoes than chicken. 

I thought it was weird that the server didn't allow photography/video-recording when he was mixing the special noodles. He literally told my friends to stop recording while he was mixing!!
author: Fanny H.

description:
How come nobody told me how garish this place is from the outside? I would've been here way sooner.

The manager requested NO PHOTOS; at my friends' suggestion, I drew a few noteworthy items I'd have otherwise shot.

depiction http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DvVmBab_ZB3p195VWYdpZQ&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA
From left to right:
Multicolored, banded, bead-stoned overhead lighting
Twist-handled, quailman-tipped silverware accompanying the Tea Leaf Salad
Weekend at Bernie's presentation of Mandalay Special Ginger Lemonade
Bendy straws(!) served in the water

:: Hi, welcome to Mandalay, what would you like to order? ::

BALADA $6.50: Pop open a tube of Hungry Jack biscuits, bake them, then eat them by peeling off and savoring layer by delectable layer. Translate that into more of an Indian pancake shape and serve it with a curry boat.

TEA LEAF SALAD (LAP PAT DOK) $9.50: Mixed tableside by a server. Duh, if you like peanuts & bar snacks, you'll like tea leaf salad. Sans lettuce, compared to the version at Pagan.

PAN FRY PRAWN WITH STRING BEAN $14.50: Bonus scallops & smelly squid. The portion was small for the price.

SHAKING DUCK $X: Didn't get to order it because they were out of duck. Instead, I got...

BURMESE CURRY LAMB $13.95: Less tender than I would've liked, less curry than I would've liked. Passable if not slightly subpar. The portion was even smaller for the price.

MANDALAY SPECIAL NOODLE $10.75: Included french onions. I don't recall seeing chicken as advertised, but they already had me at french onions.

HAAKE (NON-ALCOHOLIC BEER) $4.25: Nauseating - I do not recommend.

LEMON WATER $0: Bendy straws. Enough said.

FORTUNE COOKIES $0: Everyone but me got an obviously applicable fortune; mine was generic.

:: Hi, welcome to Mandalay, what would you like to order? ::

(Realizes he'd taken our orders a while back. Turns and leaves.)
author: Dan B.

description: Came for lunch on a weekend, surprisingly it was busier than we had expected.  We visited their website and saw that they were featured on Bay Area Check, Please.  We ordered a couple of things the guests on the show mentioned.  The flavor was good, as expected.  However, we did think the portions were on the smaller side, especially for the price.  So if you come in a bigger group, you may need to order multiple things.  Our group of four, each barely had a scoop of curry.  Parking is challenging as it's near residential neighborhood.
author: Kat L.

description:
Expensive. Bad Service. Loud. Stay away!
Very seldom do I post a review but when I have an experience this bad, I feel that I need to share. Wish I could give it 0 stars.

We made a reservation through Yelp and didn't get seated until 15 minutes after even though our table was available. There is not front door welcome staff to speak of when you get there. I had to flag someone down and let them know we were here.

We had a party of 9 and they jammed us into a table meant for 6, and in the middle of the restaurant.  When we moved the table to allow one of us to sit on the end, they made us move back. Because of our "large" party in the middle of the room, I was also ran into by a person in a wheelchair, twice.  ADA and the fire department should really look into this situation.

The food. Don't be fooled, go to Burma Superstar instead if you want Burmese food. I don't know what the Mandalay cooks were doing but everything was overcooked. Here's what we ordered:
Tea leaf salad - bland, too many peanuts.
Rainbow Salad - prepared ahead of time as the noodles were soggy sitting in the fish sauce
Fried Squash - thick batter
Tea smoked duck - Very dry and did not come with enough buns for everyone
Whole Cod - smothered in sauce and overcooked. 
Pumpkin pork stew - very little pork.
Shaking beef - Small...and sour.
Mango chicken - Panda Express orange chicken is better...by a lot.

Oh coconut rice experience. So we ordered 4 bowls of coconut rice and they brought it in a rice container. When I asked for a refill, they said, "this is not coconut rice". I wondered what the hell this could be then? After a few minutes, they brought out 2 small bowls of coconut rice. Something so simple should not be an issue.

Lastly, we were celebrating my wife's bday. They charged us $10 for cake service. All they did was bring out plates and played happy birthday over the LOUD speakers. They did not actually serve or cut the cake. I think charging $10 is pretty ridiculous for plates. Welcome to SF, I guess.  Hipsters unite.

If you've read through this whole review, congrats, cause you have the attention span of a normal adult human being. 

In short, Mandalay = bad food, bad experience.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Pro: Quick service, friendly staff and fantastic food. Our waitress recommended the volcano beef and it's probably one of the best beef plates I have ever tried. 

Con: For the amount of food, it's a bit on the pricey side. I wouldn't mind paying again though because it was delicious.
author: Veevi D.

description:
Best Burmese restaurant in the Bay Area hands down! A lot of the dishes I love don't even have meat in it. I can easily turn into a vegetarian if I get to eat here twice a week. The food is flavorful and every time we come here it seems that the food is even better than the last. We ALWAYS order the rainbow salad that has like 20 ingredients or so... Incredibly delicious and I can't get enough of that salad, we order the balada which is this delicious pancake like crepe thing. We also ordered two new dishes which was the string beans which I was addicted to and the Mandalay chicken which is great!

I recommend this restaurant to anyone who appreciates food and flavors that will satisfy all of your taste buds!
author: Reese E.

description:
Ok don't judge me...I had to look up Burma on a map. What I lack in my geography knowledge is made up for in my eating skills. 

I've been waiting to review Mandalay (what claims to be the first Burmese restaurant in SF) until after trying both this place and Burma Superstar (what seems to be the most popular Burmese in SF). I ordered similar if not the same items from both restaurants to get an equal comparison and I have to say, while both were pretty spectacular I think I gotta go with Mandalay. 

We ordered the Nan Gyi Dok, Rainbow Salad, Pumpkin Pork Stew, fried green beans, and coconut rice. Each dish was stellar. The rainbow salad (20 ingredients in this salad) is more noodley than veggie but the flavor combo is so unique. The Nan Gyi Dok is a coconut yellow curry with chicken and rice noodles. I had this at Burma Superstar too and the Mandalay version is  tastier IMO. The green beans was the surprising dish of the night. I mean, what could be so special about green beans? But really...they were super crunchy and had this salty-sweet-spicy thing going on.There's even dried ground shrimp mixed with them which sounds nasty but I seriously could eat these green beans everyday. While the presentation of the pumpkin pork was impressive (it's actually served in pumpkin!) it was actually kind of disappointing. It was good but Burma Superstar served a much larger portion since the pumpkin leaves less room for the stew. In addition, the meat here was a little bit tough (BS's pork was so tender!) And the pumpkin shell isn't cooked so you couldn't eat it. Never serve something on a plate that can't be eaten (I learned that from Chopped on the Food Network...lol but I totally agree! All that pumpkin put to waste!)

Overall Mandalay has a more relaxed ambience, more space, and friendlier/more attentive staff. I think the prices were a bit cheaper as well. Now if only I could get them to deliver to Fresno I'd have a real winner....
author: Miriam M.

description:
My first time having Burmese food and it wasn't at Burma Superstar. I'm not sure how different Burma Superstar is, but my meal at Mandalay blew my mind!

Tea Leaf Salad - must have, DUH! I usually don't like crunchy things, but I really loved this salad. The peanuts and other crunchies (should've paid more attention to the guy when he was explaining) added texture to the "salad". I like that the flavors were simple and underwhelming. You kind of have to go searching for it instead of having the flavors just hit you. A nice refreshing start to the meal.

Samusa Soup - Pretty standard soup, but very hearty, which was great on a misty evening.

Pan Fried Prawns with Okra - I love love love okra, but it's not a popular item. But first, the prawns were very fresh and cooked tender. The sauce was spicy, but not overwhelmingly so. I like the balance of sweet and spicy. The use of garlic and scallion is very Chinese in a way, which I love (so nostalgic)! The okra was cut into big pieces and cooked to just the right texture. It wasn't too tough or too soft. The slimy factor that most people dislike was at a minimum (I don't mind though).

Spicy Eggplant - I love eggplant so I'm always curious how many different ways it can be prepared. Of all the dishes we had, this was my least favorite, but that only means the other dishes were SO good! I usually don't like stir fry dishes drowned in sauce, and this one was. It was sweet, sour, and spicy - a little too many big flavors for my taste. But it does go very well with rice.

Mandalay Special Noodles - this was my favorite of the evening! Thick warm noodles tossed with coconut chicken and a creamy lemongrassy sauce and some caramelized onions. It was just amazing. Get this!

Tea Smoked Duck - they brought the duck with sweet bean paste, scallions, and buns, which reminded me of peking duck! It was very exciting. The duck is actually crispy, unlike peking duck. If you eat the duck without the sauce, it's actually not that salty. I prefer peking duck over this duck, mostly because I'm not a huge fan of crispy things. But with the sauce, scallion, and buns, it was delicious!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Got an awkward internet date on the horizon? Parents visiting? Cheat Day Sunday? Look no further, Mandalay is your place. 

Whenever my best friend comes to visit from SoCal, she insists for WEEKS in advance that we go to Mandalay. Keep in mind, this is the same girl who rarely branches out from a steak house or Italian restaurant, and yet, Mandalay is her "perfect meal." 

Sizzling Rice Soup, Tea Leaf Salad, Rainbow Salad, Samusa, and Basil Lamb. Mango cocktail if you really want to blowout your waist band. 

xoxox Mandalay. I'll be seeing you again soon.
author: Lauren L.

description:
I liked the decor, ambience and the food. We ordered mango chicken, asparagus chicken, mix vegetable n okra with shrimp. All dishes were good and quantity was enough for a single person. We ordered tea leaf salad but they didn't provide lettuce with it. We had sangria pitcher n that was good as well. One pitcher is enough for has approx 5 servings. They mentioned they would charge $18 but they billed us $20 for that pitcher. Not a big deal but try to be honest with the customers. 

I went there with 4 friends for my birthday dinner. My friends got a cake to celebrate my bday so they asked the waitress if they could help them with bringing the cake with candles n knife. We were surprised and disappointed when the waitress mentioned the restaurant charges $15 fee for helping cutting cake . That's simply ridiculous !!! I know $15 is not a big deal but the gesture itself is a put off.

I would have given a rating of 4 but knowing this cheap conduct I would not recommend people for going there for any celebrations.
author: Anu S.

description:
Dear Mandalay,

When I think of you so many questions cross my fragile mind and so many emotions consume my aching heart. What are you? Who am I? Why haven't we met before? How could I have lived my 29 years of life without experiencing the heaven that is your delectable Burmese cuisine? My tastebuds are aching... longing to reunite with you once again but sadly there is nothing like you in my city.  I am so sad and confused. Why me? Oh, the humanity!

Shall I liken thee to a summer's day? If I had to describe you, you would be the beautiful marriage between intense Indian flavor and spicy sweet Thai staples. Two of my favorite cuisines, yet even they do not do you justice. You, my sweet Burmese Beauty, offer an array of seafood, meat and vegetarian options that are packed with the seasoning and taste comparable to nothing I've tasted.

We tasted an array of dishes during my last night of my most recent trip to San Francisco. Tea leaf salad (presented as a colorful appetizer plate of grains, nuts and other lovely things with varying textures and tastes) which mixed together to create bursts of vegetarian bliss. The Balada.... Wow! It was pretty much a Burmese quesadilla, pancake, or whatever you want to call it. Flat warm, soft, and came with some impeccable sweet spicy dipping sauce. We finished off with a spread of curry prawns (one of my favorites), mango chicken, coconut rice, samusas (similar to Indian samosas) that literally had me researching flights to Burma with every bite.

Top off it off, the service was fantastic! The owner (Sherry) was sweet, helpful, attentive and generous. She went out of her way to charge my dying iPhone in the back during our entire meal, and brought my colleague a fried banana sundae to top off our amazing meal! Now that is going above and beyond. 

So there you have it. The best meal of my life. My newest discovery and latest obsession. We don't have Burmese food in Dallas (that I know of), so until I can save up for a flight to Burma (or at least San Fran again), I now need to learn how to recreate some of these dishes myself (wish me luck)! If you're in San Fran, this place is a must. One bite and you will be instantly pissed that you waited this long to indulge!
author: Helina G.

description: I went here with my partner late at night like around 8 or 8:30. They seated us and then completely forgot we were there for like 15 minutes. Finally I think the owner or general manager came and took our order. We got the tea lead salad and Mandalay Special Noodles with tofu instead of chicken. The tea leaf salad was amazing as always. Very flavorful and spicy. We ordered the special noodles with tofu but I think they forgot and it was was chicken instead. Overall I think going late at night when there are a ton of people is a bad idea because they might forget you are there.
author: Anne F.

description:
Tried it for the first time today, and I think of it as Avis.  They just try harder than Burma Superstar up the street.

I had the vegetarian soup with crumbled samosas in it, and the rainbow salad.  Both were really good, although I did like the salad the most.  It was REALLY good.  The service was great.  Really glad I stopped in, and will definitely be back!
author: Geri C.

description: I found this to be great but not as amazing as (yeah yeah, Burma Superstar). Although it is still 4 stars and the fact that it is not as hyped as Burma makes it VERY appealing. The tea leaf salad and the samosa soup are my absolute favorites.
author: Derek S.

description:
Don't look to me for an explanation of Burmese food. It's just something you have to experience for yourself, and I suggest you do ASAP. 

Tea Leaf salad, balada (some sort of magical pancake creation), curry prawns, mango chicken, veggie samusas, potsickers, and coconut rice were among the dishes enjoyed during my maiden voyage. Everything was served piping hot, plates were cleared efficiently, and Sherry and the staff were over-the-top friendly. 

Something I found particularly special about the Burmese food experience, each dish is served with a sauce especially made to accompany that particular dish. I'm a sauce girl, so getting to delight myself in sampling a variety of spices and flavors was icing on the cake. 

The tea leaf salad came out as the clear winner from me, mainly due to how unique it was - a combination of flavors I'd never experienced yet super light and refreshing. That is, until Sherry surprised our table with a fried banana sundae because she noticed me eyeing one at another table - now that's going above and beyond to create an experience for your guests. 

The only sad thing about my first taste of Burmese amazingness is that I have to wait for my next trip to SF to experience it again.
author: Gloria C.

description: I am hesitant to write a review as I don't want the line from Burma Superstar (around the corner) to creep on over to Mandalay. Mandalay is pretty crowded as it is and for good reason. The ambiance is warm and quirky, Christmas lights all year round! The food is super fresh and very flavorful. I am gluten intolerant and the staff is super helpful in guiding me to things I can eat.
author: J A.

description: Great food, good service, waitstaff dress nicely. Tea leaf salad is a classic (although like any such it might leave you with bad breath). I've gotten lots of good vegetarian food here. Thanks Mandalay!
author: Dan F.

description: Our friend recommended this place. We enjoyed it and will defiantly be back for more.
author: Alex D.

description: I'm a big fan of Burmese food, but especially the tea leaf salad, and I have to say that this place has thee best tea leaf salad I've ever had! Other food is good, but tea leaf salad is the highlight all the way!
author: Christina C.

description:
Walking distance from home - check
Friendly and fast service - check
Reasonable prices - check

The mango salad is so cool, fresh, tangy that I can't not order it, it starts every meal here. The Burmese hot and sour soup is also a winner. Other frequent feedings: asparagus spicy chicken, walnut broccoli chicken, rangoon beef, prawn with green bean... I'm salivating now.
author: Kathryn E.

description:
This is a really cute restaurant (great decorations, almost looked like Christmas). We had a dinner reservation at 830pm on a Thursday night, showed up a little early, got seated around 840. The place was pretty busy but still really good service and nice waiters/waitresses

Drinks
* burmese iced tea - same thing as thai iced tea, comes in a huge glass, very sweet (as usual)
* jasmine tea - big cup of hot tea with flowers that bloom inside
* mandalay sangria - did not order this but next time! 

Food
* tea leaf salad - this wasn't on the menu but we requested it so they brought it out; apparently the authentic version (like this restaurant's) has no lettuce; still really good
* balada - my favorite thing to order in all burmese places; very delicious!
* mandalay special noodle - flat noodles with tasty curry sauce and crispy onions; the tofu was average but I would definitely recommend the dish overall (plus, they bring out all the ingredients separately and mix it for you, explaining each portion)
* spicy vegetables and tofu - great mix of vegetables/tofu, really good flavor/sauce
author: Pallavi K.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city. Don't leave without having the tea leaf salad! 
Also, they catered food to my work the other day and we literally licked the trays clean.
author: Heidi A.

description:
Food is 5 star worthy, but I have to dock off a star for their extremely slow service...

My bf and I came here on a Tuesday night around 7:30pm and were super excited because there was only 1 party of 2 ahead of us. So we thought we'd be seated quickly...wrong. It still took 30-40 minutes for us to be finally be seated and we ordered right away, but the food also took so long to come out (one dish at a time). So glad we were doing family style. I was getting so hangry, especially because I just came from the gym.

But when our food slowly started to arrive, I understood why this place still holds its 4 stars.

Balada (5/5) - bigger than I expected. A whole pie of warm, flaky, dense, soft roti bread with delicious curry dipping sauce. Highly recommend!

Mango chicken (4/5) - looks like orange chicken and it's also both sweet and savory at the same time. Also comes with large diced mango and onions. It went really well with coconut rice! 

Coconut rice (5/5) - I love coconut rice and theirs was perfectly cooked - savory with a subtle sweet coconut taste. So good!!

Mandalay special noodles (5/5) - this was my favorite dish! The waitress mixes the flat noodles, crunchy noodles, cilantro and coconut chicken together at your table. I loved the crunchy texture combined with the smooth noodles and the cilantro provided a nice contrasting flavor to the sauce. The mild coconut chicken was also really good.

I'd definitely come back here for the food, but I'm going to aim for sometime during off hours next time because the wait was just ridiculous.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Not great Burmese good. I've definitely had better. Wandered out to the Richmond because of the great reviews but wasn't completely satisfied. First of all, we came here and looked for parking for over 30 mins before deciding to just pick it up because parking was crazy hard to find! 

We ordered the samusa soup and the mandalay special noodles. The samusa soup was much more watery than I like it - wouldn't recommend it. The noodles were pretty bland and were nothing special. Maybe I ordered the wrong things, but there are definitely better burmese places in the city than this!
author: Malika R.

description:
The one star is for the food, which was fine, but I'd give them zero stars if I could and will warn everyone to eat here at your own risk.

About the food: the chicken coconut curry soup was okay, but there was barely any chicken (or vegetables) in it at all. Nothing special. Mango chicken was mostly mango with fried chicken bits and served in a very small portion, especially for the price. We got a rainbow salad, too. Again, the portion was tiny. 

The worst part of the experience was the service. My friends and I felt like we were being hustled from the second we sat down to the moment we walked out the door. First, there was long-ish wait. No huge deal for a Saturday night. But as soon as we were seated, we were rushed through ordering, eating, and paying by a rotating crew of 4-6 servers and managers. Also, there were 3 of us -- we ordered 3 main dishes, 3 orders of rice, along with a drink for each of us. We weren't super hungry and just wanted to try the place. As another reviewer mentioned, we were upsold HARD and pressured to purchase an additional entree. The server said "Well, you're only getting 3 entrees. That won't be enough. You should get green beans, too." We replied that an entree per person would be fine for us, thanks. She persisted, insisting that we order green beans because "the portions are tiny and you will be hungry." We said that we'd start with the three entrees and order more if we needed. Her reply, unbelievably, was that we would regret that because "by that point, it will take a long time for the food to come out and you will not get it in time", admitting that their service/kitchen is slow and that their portions are inadequate (you'd think one entree plus rice would be fine for an adult meal) and trying to shame/scare us into ordering more than we needed. Bizarre.

As we were wrapping up our meal, it became clear that they wanted us to get out as soon as possible. I understand that turning tables = profit, but we were not finished eating. I think someone stopped by our table every 2-4 minutes on average to ask if we were done and/or to try to take away our clearly unfinished plates of food. Finally, the woman who tried to upsell us came back to the table and forced us to choose who was going to finish each dish ("which one of you is going to finish this one off?" before emptying the main platter onto someone's plate), serving us against our will and taking away all the other plates on the table. I ended up eating some more off a friend's plate once she took away mine and the main serving dishes. They wanted us out badly, and it was clear that the servers were trying their best at hiding the fact while tag-teaming to try to get us out. 

Finally, our bill came with a few surprises. We ordered a large soup to share among the three of us. She brought us three TINY bowls of soup and indicated that she had divided the large bowl for us into smaller portions since we indicated that we wanted to share. When the bill came, they charged us $21.00 instead of $12.50 for the soup and claimed that we ordered 3 small soups at $7.00 each instead of one large for $12.50. First, there was no $7.00 small soup option on the menu. Second, how on earth could you justify charging $7.00 for what amounted to a half cup of soup? Third, we simply didn't order that and asked them to remove the item and charge us only for the one large soup we ordered. The guy seemed unsurprised (likely because this has happened before, based on previous reviews) and simply removed the charges, replacing them with the original $12.50 for the soup. 

Then, looking at the updated bill, we realized that they had DOUBLED the price of our lemonades and tea. When we looked at the menu to verify, we noticed that there was a disclaimer at the bottom of the last page indicating that "Prices may change at any time for any reason with no notice". I guess that means that prices can change between the time you order and the time you pay? 

At that point, we were so exasperated and shocked that we just paid and got out of there as fast as possible. If the prices weren't so ridiculously high, especially for the quality of food and service, and if the servers and billing were both honest, I would shrug it off. But this place is NOT worth the expense or the headache, and I would warn anyone eating there to triple-check their bill for hidden charges before paying because they clearly do this to others, based on earlier reviews. I won't visit this dishonest business again.
author: Alex K.

description: I really enjoyed their tea leaf salad and their Burmese noodle dish. It is generally very busy even on weekdays so try to get here early for dinner!
author: Young Y.

description:
Came here nearly a year ago with my boyfriend. You can really feel the essence of this place with its decor. The servers are dressed in their Burmese attire and are very sweet.

For dinner, we ordered the Chicken Samusa which was good. The shape reminded me of a crab meat rangoon from my folks' place back in the day. I ordered the Nan Gyi Dok and teammate ordered the mango chicken, and the server helped us mix all the ingredients together. There's something about warm mango that I don't like, lol.

Food is good and restaurant is lovely.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Try the tea leaf salad...it is amazing!  So pretty, and so delicious.  Also, the Duck....the best!!!!!
author: ona j.

description:
We went here because we like Burma Superstar, and it was just as good. I've heard some people say it's better, but I would say they're both equally delicious.

We ordered the Broccoli Walnut Chicken--super delicious, much spicier than I anticipated.

Mandaly Beef was awesome. Deep fried beef in sweet and sour sauce.

Mango Chicken was flavorful, but too spicy for my taste. They serve it with whole slices of jalapeno and my mouth was on fire.

I totally recommend ordering the coconut rice with your meal. It's not sweet like a dessert, but still carries the coconut flavor.
author: Ashley E.

description:
This was the most memorable meal I've had outside of nyc and that is saying a lot.  We had two salads (tea leaf and Mandalay salad) which were both such a delightful culinary party in my mouth.  I loved how they mix the foods in front of you not only for entrainment value but also it Makes for a unique twist to the whole dining experience.  We   tried the Mandalay chicken with mango which was delicious as was the highlight of  the meal for me.  The mango and sticky rice for dessert was also nice.  Highly recommend for anyone whose up for a different delightful meal.  

I've never tried Burmese food but after this meal I'm up for traveling there.
author: Cynthia O.

description:
Cute little coloful restaurant in San Francisco, but decor is a little funny with ornaments hanging from the ceiling. Service was good and prompt. It gets very crowded during the weekend (not sure on weekdays), we waited 30-40mins.

Tea Leaf Salad - first time trying this unique salad, with a hint of tea leaf and vinegar flavors. Only thing was too much peanuts, which they put a little more tea leaves. Otherwise, its a good starter.

Tea Smoked Duck - a little dry looking, it does have the smokey flavor, I can't taste or smell any tea. It served with steam buns, a little dry too.

Mango Prawns - originally wanted to try Lychee Coconut Prawns, but they didn't have it that night. So end up with Mango Prawns. Juicy and sweet mangoes, savory prawns stir fried with mixed veggies.

Coconut Rice - rice with a hint of coconut flavors. It was good, but not to the point I would like to reorder.
author: Sandi C.

description:
Although not as ubiquitous as Thai food, Burmese cuisine has been some of the most delicious I've had, and Mandalay has become my favorite Burmese experience thus far. It's a bit of a trek for us from the Castro, but worth the visit.

We've visited Mandalay on random days and times-- the restaurant always seems half-full, but I've heard it gets busy during dinner. The place is permanently decorated for Christmas, with plenty of lights and ornaments hanging from the ceiling. Not fancy, but not divey either. 

We usually start with a Burmese beer at the Tea Leaf Salad, which can be made vegetarian. As is customary, the salad comes with all its components piled on a plate, and the server will prepare and mix it in front of your eyes. It's really hard to describe the flavor of a tea leaf salad, but it's a perfect mix of texture and flavor that we usually finish it all.

The menu is very straightforward and grouped by protein, much like other Asian restaurants. Walnut Broccoli and some sort of Noodles are the usual orders, and you must get the coconut rice. I've loved the coconut rice at other restaurants, and at Mandalay, it is so yummy-- served with fried shallots on top. The milky coconut just adds another dimension to what would otherwise be plain rice. It's something I actually find myself craving.

Mandalay has a charm about it that is backed up by amazing flavor. While other Burmese restaurants have a lot of hype, I'm happy to say that Mandalay is the place I have had repeat visits to, and I intend on continuing.
author: Bryan B.

description:
1. I waited literally 30 seconds to get seated (granted, I did call in to put my name down for two)
2. SUCH FRIENDLY SERVICE IT BLEW MY MIND
3. I dig the neon lights/exposed beams/confused holiday decorations and orchid set up. Really cozy.
4. DELICIOUS FOOD, perfectly shareable portion sizes.

Their special noodles, tea leaf salad, and rainbow salad are a little better than Burma superstar. I will definitely come back!

One con - HORRIBLE STREET PARKING
author: Colleen M.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. Family owned and good service. When I came here with my parents, the owners recognized us because we were in the same tour group in China (back in 2005). There's something about being stuck in Beijing traffic on a tourist bus- those bonds last. 

In all seriousness, I like this place better than Burma Superstar (a few blocks away). Mandalay doesn't have the crazy wait, and the food quality is great. The tea leaf salad and balada with curry dipping sauce are fantastic. Go here for a more "homey" experience. You won't be disappointed!
author: Joanna L.

description: Excellent family owned restaurant that is warm and welcoming and has great food and great service! I only wish they delivered. *hint, hint* ;)
author: sockanooni s.

description:
Mandalay is a popular restaurant...this you can tell by the large groups of people waiting outside of the front door to be seated.  The staff does a reasonable job trying to keep the line moving so even with the large crowd when we arrived we managed to get seated within about 20-30 minutes, no reservations.

The food was good but not superlative.  We started with the famous tea leaf salad, a unique dish that is mixed up in front of you at the table.  Really interesting flavors and something distinctive about coming to a Burmese (Myanmarese?) restaurant.  With a side of balada (slightly cripsy pancake, a bit like buttery naan that is a bit crispy) it was a really nice way to start the meal.

Unfortunately our entrees did not stand out (to me) as particularly unique.  I'm no expert on Burmese cuisine so as far as I know they were done just right...but the sense I got from my wife's red curry okra with fried eggs and my spicy naked eggplant (had to get it with a name like that) was of good quality Indian and Chinese food, respectively.  Again, the quality was good and I was happy with the food but it didn't stand out as a particularly unique experience...was similar to what we would have tasted in a good quality restaurant of either of those ethnicities.

It's not a complaint really, and the starters made the meal interesting.  But I am not in a rush to return since I've now checked the tea leaf salad off of my bucket list and the food was good but not great...I'd go back if the line was short but would not want to wait that long again.
author: Alan S.

description:
Called in before hand to put our name down on the list during a busy Friday Night. By the time we got there we were at the top of the list. If your deciding to go on a busy weekend night, defiantly call in first

Service: the restaurant  was packed, and even so they tried really hard to take care if us quickly and efficiently. When our server had not come by, the hostess came by to help him and take our order. Overall for a busy Friday night they did their best and fit that I appreciated their efforts.

Food: we got the ever popular tea salad, it looks simple, but I promise the flavors throw a punch and I couldn't stop devouring it. 
We also got the mango chicken and a prawn dish with a side of coconut rice. To drink we enjoyed a refreshing ginger beer overall it was an amazing meal and we will be back sooner than later. 
Keep it up!!!
author: Rebecky L.

description:
If you are tired of waiting in hour long lines for your Burmese fix, try this place!

I have been curious about Burmese food for a while, but it seems just about impossible to get into one without disneyland length lines! This place is just far enough off the beaten path that no one has seemed to find it and yet the food quality is just as good as the other super stars out there. I suppose the one thing I would say is that its a large and quiet place.  If you are wanting a hip and social crowd for your date night then this might not be the right spot for you, but this is the place for you if you want to take the family out and not wait in lines. 

For the first timers, make sure you get the Tea Leaf Salad!
author: Steven C.

description:
Overall 1.5 stars. 
3. 5 star for food but minus 2 stars for customer service as it was atrocious.
It was a weekend and we had to wait for 40 plus min. Wait was expected and hence not an issue. It's after we were seated the type of service was unexpected and that's my issue. 
Few minutes after we were seated, the person came to get our order. 
We ordered few drinks and few dishes. As we were first timers to this place, not sure of the proportions, we asked told him we would order more later if needed. The waiter immediately retorted back saying that they are serving second around as there are lot of  people waiting. Strike 1! 
The food came in all rushed with appetizers coming after the entrées were delivered. No sign of drinks yet. Strike 2!! Half way through our dinner, we had to tell them about our drink and asked them to cancel it. After few minutes later the canceled drinks arrived! We sent it back. The person tried to explain saying that they were in a hurry to get the food going and forgot to make the drinks. 
The food was decent, but with all the other disorganized delivery going on, could not enjoy it much. 
Then comes the bill, it was paid and did not leave any tip as the service was bad. As we were leaving they had the audacity to ask for tips even after that kind of service.  Strike 3!!! 
There are few other Burmese places (close by and throughout Bay area)  where the food is as good or better and customer service does not suck.
author: Vatsa S.

description: It gets super crowded, so reservations might be a good idea but I think we still had to wait a bit. Parking around the area can be tough sometimes. When we got seated, we were able to order drinks right away. The water didn't have enough ice to make it cool, but I liked how you could really taste the lemon. The Mango Lassi is what we usually get. The Burmese iced tea is basically Thai tea, which never goes wrong and the young coconut was good too. The Samusa is yummy and worth a try. I think coconut rice here is one of my favorites compared to other places. We had the Tea Leaf Salad and it was delicious, different from your normal salads. The pan fried string beans were amazing, considering that I never eat them but I think it was the seasoning. The Mandalay Noodle was also different, but it's worth a try. The curry lamb with potato was good. The Smoked Tea Duck wasn't bad either, but I'd probably skip it and try other things. Lastly, the Pumpkin Curry was okay, I didn't find it to be anything special. Overall, I like this place more compared to Burma Superstar. The service is good, not too bad but not the greatest I guess. The food comes out pretty quick in my opinion. The atmosphere is fine.
author: Maggie W.

description: Nice little restaurant and good service, went on a Sunday evening around 6pm and had no wait although I saw a line as we were leaving so come early to avoid wait times! We ordered the tea leaf salad, tea smoked duck and rangoon lamb. And of course some coconut rice to go with all of that yum! I thought the lamb was really good and the lamb taste was not overpowering, which was good! Tea smoked duck was also good and crispy. The tea leaf salad I thought was less acidic than I would have preferred and the sesame oil was tad too much so it made me want to take a break from it after eating a few spoonfuls of it. Overall a nice little Burmese restaurant!
author: Claire S.

description:
Excellent service for a crowded saturday night. Went with my family and my brother is in a wheel chair and they were so willing to accomodate for us which I thought was really nice, even asking people to scoot their chairs so that we could make a pathway for my brother's chair. This was my first foray into burmese food and it won't be my last.

Mandalay noodles were my favorite.
Tea leaf salad is also a must.
author: Samantha D.

description: Good food, friendly service and nice spot.  Fish chowder, spicy basil pork and coconut rice.  I'm looking forward trying other dishes the next time.
author: Felicity T.

description:
The food here is actually pretty good, but I wasn't terribly impressed with the service.  The hostess was working very hard, taking care of the front and noticed that we needed our check even though she was across the room.  The other staff though seemed to be slacking.  One lady was serving the table next to us and I ended up being sprayed in the face with lemon juice.  When our table got our noodle dish our waiter didn't mix it nearly as much as he did the table next to us.  You could see that the items weren't evenly distributed and as you ate it some noodles had more sauce that the others.  To be fair they were reall busy, but it seems like they always are.

Out of the food items, we ordered a lot since we were hungry.  My favorite dishes were probably the mandalay noodle and the smoked duck.  We also got the mango chicken, which probably was our least favorite items.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
My favorite Burmese restaurant in the city!

Although this restaurant is fairly small I suggest trying this place out with more people.

My picks:
***** Lap Pat Dok: tea leaf salad. salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic chips, peanut, sesame seeds, green pepper & chef's special dressing.
***** Rainbow Salad: salad with twenty ingredients served with chef's special dressing. 
***** Samusa (I like the Burmese style better than the Indian ones since these are crispier. Wonton wrapper on the outside, instead of the thicker dough)
***** Nan Gyi Dok: Burmese rice noodle with mild coconut chicken, split yellow peas powder, garlic, shredded onion and house special dressing.
author: Shir F.

description:
"That's not the Northern Lights! That's Mandalay!" -Maxim de Winter in Hitchcock's Rebecca.

Before all the film buffs chime in, I do realize the correct quote is "that's not the Northern Lights! That's Mand*erlay!" but! My point! Mandalay delivered a meal the other night that was Wonder of the World-worthy. Lucky you, San Franciscans, to be privy to experiencing it on the regular. I hear that some places serving up Burmese cuisine have such high demand, you have to wait hours for a table. The good news is that Mandalay accepts reservations, but even if you don't make one, there's a good chance for you to experience the magic sans fast pass.

For starters, the flavor and textures in the tea leaf salad are a riotous joy in my mouth. Oh the crunchiness! Oh the spice! Next time, I can't see myself not ordering this as my main course. for as much as I loved the Mandalay Special Noodle with tofu dish, I kept at that salad that I was supposed to share, only I probably ate the entire thing. I just... can't... stop thinking about it. I love how they come over to the table with the modest looking plate, all the ingredients delicately arranged with the tea leaf paste in the middle and mix it all there right in front of you. Nuts, spices, tea leaves... who woulda known this as a potential gastronomical delight??

The environs itself is similarly decadent, an abundance of altars laden with fruit and deities;  lit up palm trees decking the corners. If they know it's your birthday, expect a serenade. Cuz that's how they roll.

In closing, my first encounter with the incredible cuisine of Burma has left me with a deep, deep longing, baby. I am bereft for I currently reside in a city where there is nary a single Burmese restaurant. Give me tea leaf salad or give me death!!! I might perish with longing.
author: Joi B.

description: Had had a great time here. We ordered their Mandalay special noodles which were pretty good. We also got their tea leaf salad and it didn't really live up to the hype for us. But the service was good and attentive.
author: Patrick W.

description: First time I ever had Burmese food and this place was delicious. The garlic noodles, Walnut shrimp and tea leaf salad were delicious! Service was great and staff was super nice.
author: Aya O.

description: absolutely love this place. A local recommended this place and it was the best recommendation of a restaurant. The tea leaf salad is absolutely glorious. the rest of food is great but we came back for that salad!. service was also fantastic. Oh and the jazmine tea...beautiful and delicious!
author: Aura E.

description: Mandalay is my weekly go-to place for the best Burmese food I've ever had.  I'm addicted to their Pan Fried Green Beans, but also love their Hot and Sour Soup, Samusa Soup, Tea Leaf Salad, Basil Spicy Eggplant and Balada.  The staff here is extremely attentive...and know my favorite orders by heart.  It can get crowded for dinner, so arrive early!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Food: 3 Stars

Portion: 1 Star. Half of what they used to give but they serve it in small plates so it doesn't look like it's a tiny portion but when the serving spoon is the same length as the plate, it's obvious! Also, $3.50 for a Coke but an 8.5 oz can not a 12 oz can! Are you fucking serious?!!!

The manager is an idiot! He squeezes more people than a table can hold! The male waiter just puts the food anywhere on the table. 

Prices: Way, way, way, way, way expensive for what you get. $10 for 4 little Samusas!! $3.50 for 8.5 ounce Coke! Not even a 12 ounce can like before.

We have been going here for the last 20 plus years and because of social media this place has gotten so popular. The new generation doesn't realize that they are being screwed from what it used to be and the owners greed factor is very obvious. 

I highly doubt we will ever go back because of the reasons mentioned above.  Another place down the tubes. Where are the places that give any value?
author: Rod W.

description:
One of my coworkers made a reservation for 5 people beforehand - hence no wait when we arrived. Service was great! Although the one waitress spoke very low prior to mixing / when describing the ingredients in the Tea Leaf Salad and Mandalay Special Noodle dishes; I couldn't really understand her - no biggie. 

We ordered a number of items and shared. 
Though my absolute favorite items were as follows: Balada (Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce) AND the Mandalay Special Noodle (Burmese flat noodle, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top) - we ordered it with tofu. All in all, the food was delicious!
author: Pina U.

description:
I've passed by Mandalay a few times, without realizing they're the sister restaurant to Mingalaba, which is easily my favorite Burmese restaurant in the Bay Area. On the suggestion of a friend, her boyfriend and I came here instead of Burma Superstar, and ordered the:

* Tea Leaf Salad - What Burmese meal is complete without one of these! As flavorful as the ones at Mingalaba, but a bit saltier, with some minor flavor differences, and also possibly smaller.

* Mandalay Special Noodles - I'm not sure if these are the same as the house noodles at Mingalaba, but quite similar in any case, and just as delicious. 

* Mango Prawns - This was a bit of an odd order, but we wanted to diversify our protein a bit, and opted for seafood. Not a bad dish, but not exactly what I imagined (which was something more saucy), and a bit on the salty side, even when paired with rice.

So, be it due to poor memory, or actual difference in quality of the food, Mandalay wasn't as impressive as Mingalaba, but still good enough that it beats out having to wait in line at Burma Superstar.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The restaurant is quite a large space, so getting around isn't a problem.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Honestly, I'm a bit tired of going to the "Burma Superstar line too long substitute" places nearby. I've tried both B Star and Mandalay. Both failed miserably in replacing Burma Superstar quality and service. 

For starters, the services at Mandalay was pretty horrible, even for an Asian restaurant. They managed to seat us and not come by in the first 15 minutes to even give a menu or ask anything. This was probably a symptom of not having enough waiters and having too many diners. 

First mistake - ordering Manadalay Beef - which was I saw mentioned on many reviews here. Its basically just heavily breaded beef which is then deep fried and covered in an orange sauce. Your typical Orange Beef/Chicken dish found at any Chinese restaurant in America. It was decent but not worth coming here for such a generic dish.

Second mistake - they forgot a couple of our dishes we ordered in the chaos of weekend dinner rush and by the time we finished eating our generic dishes - we weren't in the mood for anymore. 

The only saving grace was the Kaw Soi dish - A Burmese egg noodle dish that was made very well and was very unique. 

I'd say - just wait in line for Burma Superstar b/c all the other Burmese options in the area just aren't worth it.
author: Henry W.

description:
GINORMOUS AMOUNTS OF THANKS goes out to Rinky N for the absolutely wonderful wedding gift & introducing us to the incredible Mandalay!

Receiving an extremely thoughtful gift certificate to Mandalay, the Mr & I thought well, this is a fab way to experience a new restaurant & new-to-us cuisine

Let's just say we waddled out of there true believers!

Started out w/ the Tea Leaf Salad & the Balada

Tea Leaf Salad was the most unusual salad I've ever had - lots of peanuts, garlic chips, sesame seeds & hot peppers mixed w/ this tea leaf paste - it was divine!  Best part was when we asked if they could leave out the ground shrimp & were told no problem.....love it!

Balada was like a fried, fluffy, doughy naan w/ this sweet curry sauce for dipping - eye rolls!

Main dishes included Walnut Broccoli w/ Tofu & the Coconut Rice.  The sauce on the tofu was slightly sweet & paired so very well w/ that coconut rice - believe the hype when people say to get this rice!  Light, fluffy & slightly sweet from the coconut milk they must use to cook it in.....there were no slivers of coconut but a nice pungent coconut taste - yum!

Also shared the Nan Gyi Dok - rice noodle with lentil powder & fried onion all in a flavorful oil-based sauce.  We asked for tofu to replace the chicken & they happily obliged.....I'm totally loving that we can get everything veggie!

Mango Lassis for dessert & they were creamy, sweet & tart - perfect ending to a perfect meal!

We had an early movie so thought we'd be the only people in the place at 5pm - but no.  There were already 3 other tables well into their meals & by the time we left, the place was packed, w/ people waiting to be seated & I can see why!!

THANKS again Rinky N for the lovely gift & for treating us to a wonderful new restaurant that will certainly be a well-frequented stop!!
author: Adrienne G.

description: By far and away my favorite restaurant in the city. Please don't go to Burma Love and think that's what the food is supposed to taste like. This is the real deal with a family that's been there for years. I've never had anything bad from there. The samusas, tea leaf salad, and house special noodles are my favorite things...and don't go thinking that green beans are boring! You must try them! I could eat here multiple times a week. It's busy & crowded in the little place, so not for the impatient or claustrophobic. The lemonade is really tasty, but far too sweet for me. My favorite Burmese restaurant of all that I have tried, not just SF.
author: Miriah S.

description:
Easily on par with Burma Superstar. Definitely better for a quiet lunch with family or as a date spot on account of the ambiance and the service. 

The Mango chicken, and lamb curry are must-haves. Pair them with the brown rice and the coconut rice respectively. The lap pat dok (tea leaf salad) and ging dok (ginger salad) are good but I'm not as much a fan as some reviewers.

The Special Ginger Lemon beer however (imagine the best Shandy you have ever had) is delicious.  If they had a balcony and San Francisco had more sunny days I might never leave.
author: Mike V.

description:
Food was great! Came here w/ my dad for dinner.
Started off with rainbow salad and had the Basil Prawns, Okra Prawns and one of the desserts (had cream of wheat in it and poppy seeds on top, not too sweet). 

Overall, the stars are really for the food as the service was sort of slow. We waited about 15-20 minutes for our entree. Granted it was super busy, it just seemed like they were understaffed. 

I really want to go back and try some of the other dishes--I had never had Burmese food before. It's the sort of place where you want to get "whatever they're having" at the table next to you because everything looks so delicious :)
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I only tried Burmese food a few years ago and became a huge fan after having it at Burma Superstar. I was hooked because of the one of a kind Tea Leaf salad.  Last night, I had the opportunity to try it again, except at the older, not as well known spot. From what I know it's been around since the 80's with a few changes in ownership, but with a credible following.

The place was packed with hungry diners from all sorts of demographics waiting to get into hole in the wall joint. Not only was I pleased by the tea leaf salad (love that there is no lettuce involved), but their pancakes, Burmese "orange" style chicken, walnut shrimp and salt and pepper shrimp all were excellent. What I was surprised about the most was their "naked" eggplant, lightly friend with sauce and peppers/onions. Their lemon ginger beer (yup, a beer cocktail) concoction was a nice way to compliment the meal.

For those who only know or patronize Burma Superstar, give this place a shot. It has a loyal following and slightly bigger portions. It's the original kid on the block and worth learning about this great spot.
author: Patrick Gabriel L.

description: Ordered from this restaurant via postmates. It was very good! We had the basil beef, chicken lettuce cups and spicy shrimp. I will definitely try other dishes in the future!
author: Mr.x T.

description: Looking for a bite in San Francisco and we drove past this bright beautiful building. It immediately caught our attention and we decided to give it a try. The inside was just as beautiful. Amazing food with quality service! Dessert was wonderful too!
author: Nikki K.

description:
If the lines at Burma Superstar are bumming you out (or just the overwhelming vibe of white, hipster pretentiousness), Mandalay is not only a decent alternative, it's a superior one. The space is bigger, and the staff are just as friendly but with a touch more homey warmth. 

And the food? The Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok) is a worthy rival--I felt the leaves were better fermented here, and the portions were bigger. The Rainbow Salad was also fantastic, with perfectly cooked noodles. We also got the Balada (crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce), which reminded me a lot of Malaysian roti in a good way. Our entrees consisted of Dry Pan-Fried String Beans and Spicy Tofu and Vegetables--simple, no-frills dishes packed with flavor. Those were accompanied by the Pampoi  (cinnamon rice with saffron), which was lovely. Finally, we got the Mandalay Sangria and Mango Lassi to help cool down. My Indian friend approved of the lassi and ranked it among the best she's had.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I don't have TOO much experience with Burmese food, but I've been to Burma Superstar and B-Star. I tried different dishes at every place and thought everything was delicious.

The tea leaf salad at Mandalay is a little too salty for me. But everything else was good, such as the walnut prawns, mango chicken, and vegetarian rice noodle dish.

Prices are reasonable and service is quick. Mango pudding dessert is on the house too!
author: Alysha K.

description: Some SF locals recommended this place for Burmese , esp after I said I wanted to go to Burma S. (I love Burma star!) we dropped by about 12 on a Monday and we were seated immediately. The food is amazing !! We had the tea leaf salad, mohingga fish soup, and one of the lunch specials - it was a roti with a small bowl of chicken potato curry. I had a jasmine flower tea.  Excellent service, excellent food. If anything, I consider it slightly more home style Burmese. The chicken curry was on point. The tea leaf salad could have been padded out with some lettuce or more tomato , but instead it was  all savory and texture - crunchy garlic , fried chickpeas / lentils, crunchy peanuts, delicious tea leaf. They brought a little tray of lemon wedges and cilantro for the table, which I love. And the mohingga!!!!! Piping hot and the perfect soupiness! Very impressed. Highly recommend !
author: Jasmine l.

description: First timer.. Soooo pleasantly surprised.  Friday night dinner, expected a wait to get a table and was so right.   That's what happens at great spots like this.   How can you go wrong with gracious service and awesome food, right!!  So many places to dine with great food but when there is a balance of great food, service and  very energetic environment only a experience is to be had.   This is the place for that!
author: Ric C.

description:
No one mentions the Ginger Salad.  That alone is worth the price of admission!  We get it every time (almost).  Green Papaya salad is great too.  And the Tea Leaf.  But Ginger is #1!

We have never ordered a dish we didn't like.  Portions could be a bit larger, but you can't have it all.  Servers are always doing their best in a very busy place.  Our neighborhood fave!  All of our out-of-town guests get a trip to Mandalay.
author: Nancy S.

description: This is not Burmese food. I'm Burmese. I know. Mohingha comes with fried fritters, noodles, cilantro etc. You don't charge people extra for noodles that is already supposed to be part of the dish. The owner & staff were rude. Burmese people are not rude. What a terrible place.
author: Sophia M.

description: Wow!  First visit here and I'm hooked. Excellent, flavorful food and great service! Tea leaf salad is extraordinary and the mandalay beef is unforgettable! Also had a an amazinf noodle/seafood dish but I don't recall the name. Yum!
author: Tony A.

description:
I'm new to Burmese, so was super excited to try Mandalay. Have made the mistake of not looking at Yelp photos of dishes before ordering ones from a new cuisine in the past, though, so I did my research beforehand last night!

What we had:
- Samosa soup: nice flavor; light and refreshing. Boo made a good point, though - that's it's overpriced for what it takes to make the thing, but still delish. We ordered one serving, and they brought it out for us in two bowls.
- Balada (pancake with curry sauce): this was beautiful, with just the right amount of moisture and crunch, but I was expecting something slightly more interesting. For Chinese food lovers out there, the consistency is similar to that of a scallion pancake; I thought it'd be flakier, for some reason. The curry sauce was relatively light, with a touch of sweetness.
- Tea leaf salad: amazing. Beautifully prepared, and so scrumptious to eat! When it came out, I wasn't sure it'd be quite enough food, but all those nuts and beans make for a filling dish.

I wasn't entirely sure this would be enough for two people, as they're lighter dishes, but it was the perfect amount (we also ordered coconut rice, which I didn't eat, and I was still full!). Definitely high quality stuff, with attentive service, and a really cool interior to the restaurant. And of course, being the oldest and definitely legit Burmese joint in the city, it was packed.

Eager to try out some other Burmese places, but I'd definitely recommend this one to anyone who hasn't been. :)
author: Shendi X.

description: Excellent food, prefer it over Burma Superstar. The flavours feel fresher and not as forced. Love their tea leaf salad and samusa soup.
author: Bhavya K.

description: Been coming here for over a decade for delicious versions of classic Burmese dishes like balada, tea salad, nan gi do (yellow chicken curry & rice noodles). But just recently tried their amazing shaking duck - layers of tea smoked duck, kabocha squash, & cooked greens in a mango sauce.
author: Stuart G.

description: Great food.  Tea Leaf Salad and Beef Curry was the must!
author: Nikki U.

description:
My wife and I have been eating at Mandalay 5 times a year for 16 years !!!
It is by far the best Burmese restaurant in San Francisco.
And it is one of the main reasons why we visit San Francisco so often from 3 hours away.
But the only time we can visit is on Tuesdays (our day off together) and being that
Mandalay is NOW closed on Tuesday it's killing us.
We stopped by last Tuesday and we were crushed.
A tradition of ours is now lost.
Say it isn't so?
author: MEAT M.

description:
I've eaten here many many times over the years and appreciate the kind service and the delicious food.  If you're looking for a delicious, non-alcoholic beverage, the mint lemonade is amazing.  In terms of food, I am obsessed with the tea leaf salad, pan fry okra prawn, pumpkin curry and their wonderful samosas.  

On a recent visit we tried the chicken salad, which was oddly sweet, and when coupled with the walnut prawns that we also ordered, well, it felt like we were eating dessert.  

The coconut rice was kind of a failure.  It was very lumpy and not very coconutty, nor was it hot enough.  The service was also kind of crappy - we were there at lunch time and I felt like we were being really rushed.  

I'm going to treat my latest visit as an anomaly and will continue going their for dinner when we're in the neighborhood.
author: .Hon H.

description:
The food was great at this restaurant.  Overall, the rating for the food and service was 3.5 stars.  Each dish is unique and, for the most part, flavorful and delicious.  My cohorts might disagree with my ratings.

5 stars - Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok)
5 stars - Fried Fish Cakes (Nga Pe Jaw)
5 stars - Mango Salad
4 stars - Pan Fry String Beans with Seafood
2 stars - Combination Fried Rice
1 star   - Mandalay Special Noodle

We ordered six dishes on our visit, and I gave high marks for the four dishes above because I enjoyed every bite.  The latter two dishes were my least favorite.  The fried rice was bland for my taste, but it was edible.  I did not like the Mandalay Special Noodles because the flavor profile did not agree with my palate, especially with the coconut milk.  I've had coconut milk in my food before, but this dish was a bit too heavy for me.

Service was just okay.  The lady who took our order was nonchalant.  Further, we had to ask for refills for water and ice because the wait staff took a while to refill our glasses.

I wished it was a 5-star experience given that my cohorts and I were in the City for just the day, but I will be visiting again next time I'm in the City and near this restaurant.
author: Leonard A.

description:
The catered food is better than eating in-restaurant. When does that ever happen?

The service is slooooooow. I had lemon squirted on me multiple times by the waitress making a salad at the table next to us. Our own waiter barely mixed our noodle dish (probably about 1/4 of the time that an adjacent table had theirs mixed). I waited forever for food and for my check, as well.

Their food was okay, but nothing blew me away. Tea leaf salad was good, but that's good just about anywhere. The Mandalay special noodles were flavorful but a little too soggy. The mango chicken tasted like cheap Chinese takeout. The tea smoked duck is awesome, though, and I love how they give you little buns to put the duck in.

Hmm... I don't know if I'll come back here unless I'm really craving the duck.
author: Kazu O.

description:
The food wasn't bad but extremely overpriced. Most dishes taste like any other Chinese food.
Prices were way out of line as same food can be had at Chinese restaurant at 1/3 of the price.
author: Dee B.

description: Had a great meal with terrific service. Had rather a long wait even at 5:30 pm on a Friday evening. Mongolian chicken was tasty and portion size was excellent. Did not go away hungry.
author: Graham H.
