description: Simply delicious. I recommend everything that my party ordered today. Drinks: Burmese ice tea, Mandalay special ginger lemonade, which comes with mint and is on the sweet side, and the Mandalay cooler. Appetizers: Burmese fried squash sticks and tea leaf salad (so good!!). Mains: pan fry string bean with seafood -- the scallops here were prepared very well -- and spicy tofu with vegetables. We also had the coconut rice and saffron and bay leaf rice. The saffron rice was our favorite.
author: Miranda F.

description: A friend brought me to this restaurant last year, and now I always make a point to visit for dinner when I am in the city. The decor is really quite something! It is entertaining to say the least. Expect to wait for a table, but know that the food is definitely worth waiting for. You show up and put your name on a list, and they turn the tables over quite quickly; I have never had to wait more than 30 minutes. I am vegetarian, so I always opt for the samosa soup. I can't even explain how delicious this broth is. My friends go wild over the tea leaf salad. With affordable prices and an eclectic atmosphere, this is a great place for small groups looking for amazing, authentic Burmese food.
author: McKenna P.

description:
Arrived at 6:30 pm on a Wednesday night. We were seated immediately.

We ordered the Cold Sake, which is delicious and I highly recommend... and a Tea Leaf Salad to start. The service was great and our waters never reached empty.

I'd say around 7:30 the place was at capacity, so you'll want to try to get there prior.

We also shared the Volcano Beef (Daily Special - Spicy) and the pumpkin squash chicken along with a couple orders of the coconut rice. Everything was very good and we pretty much cleaned our plates.

I'll definitely come back!
author: Richard C.

description: MAJOR PRICE HIKE! We've been going here for years and always one of our favorites, but in the last month or so prices jacked way up and no longer an affordable family restaurant. Mandalay beef is now $16 and chicken satay $12. Cheesy decor not so endearing anymore if their pricing is high end and usual lapses in service also no longer acceptable at these prices.
author: Paul W.

description:
Burma Superstar has some competition. Besides, they have "puppy seeds" on their menu. I kid, I kid.

I stopped in here with some of my SF Yelp pals, Angelo and Theron and we had quite a feast. Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken, Pumpkin Curry and one other dish I cannot recall. I let the boys order because they have eaten here several times.

I enjoyed all of the dishes. They don't have all of the same items I like at Burma (ie Fiery Chicken and Tofu) but it beats a two hour plus wait. We got here just before the rush but even still, the wait didn't seem nearly as long.

Four dishes, a cup of tea (which is a flower that opens in the water - yay science!) and four orders of coconut rice came to about $70 before tax.

Service is super efficient too. Not sure which place I like better but if I'm in the 'hood and I don't feel like waiting at Burma or B Star, I'll definitely stop in at Mandalay.
author: Amy J.

description:
Mandalay had free street parking nearby so popped in here for lunch. nice burmese ambience with the  hand stitched elephants and hanging ornaments.

eats: curry chicken lunch special(8.5)
-tart soup with cabbage and tofu ..
-strong curry taste with large pieces of tender chicken
-potato pieces semi-solid/semi-mushy..
-overall 4 stars for value and taste..

leftovers:
-seating kind of cramped against wall.
-strong flavors, not muted.
-service above average.
author: Victor G.

description: This place is insanely underrated ... which is the worst thing to say of a neighborhood eatery that you still want to eat at without waiting in ridiculous lines. But I have to hand it to Mandalay: the food is exceptional and exceptionally consistent.  The ambiance, though a little chintzy and definitely boisterous at times, is what you would expect of a place that hasn't either gone annoyingly hipster .. or become too expensive to still remain your regular weekday dining top choice.  The staff is always pleasant and accommodating.  You may wait 30 minutes for a table, but once you sit down the food will roll out as fast as you can handle.
author: Alex J.

description:
One of the best restaurant foods I ever had!
Its my husband's favorite restaurant in the Bay area and he grow up eating this kind of food!
Our favorites are: Balada, Samusa, Satay chicken, Lap Pat Dok, coconut rice, Fried chicken, Chow Mein, Moo Hing Nga, String beans...
The staff is very friendly! 
It's always busy but it's well worth the wait ;)
author: Iza K.

description:
This was the worst duck dish I ever had. The smoked tea duck is a cheap imitation of Peking Duck, which I don't believe is in Burma. As other reviews have noted it is dry and overcooked, and essentially not edible. I would have sent it back, but the person who suggested this place would have been embarrassed. Furthemore, I oriiginally had planned to order a different duck dish, which was probably a more authentic Burmese dish, but the waitress steered me into this higher priced item, saying everybody loves this one. Make that everybody but me and many of the other reviewers. Don't tbhey realize that a few of us might be Yelpers?

Another thing. I thoiught we were past the point where women were second class citizens and didn't deserve to see the price of the items on the menu. Get with it!

Most of the other dishes also were knockoffs of better prepared Chinese food. The only reason I can account for the crowded conditions for dinner is that the stuff is cheap.
author: Cliff L.

description: Food was decent...Service not so much.  We had one person arrive later, and THEY WOULD NOT ADD HIS ORDER to the kitchen!!  What??
author: Patty W.

description:
Had this from ZeroCater at work a few times.

The mango salad, spicy mango chicken, pumpkin tofu curry etc. are all delicious.  I gotta remember to bookmark this for when I want delivery at my own home!  Want to try the tea leaf salad and banana blossom salad.


---- DINNER ----

Tea Leaf Salad:  4 stars
Yummy, but for variety and refreshment I always prefer Rainbow Salad to tea leaf...

Rainbow Salad:  5 stars

Mango Chicken:  4.5 stars

Burmese Curry Lamb:  5 stars
I don't personally eat lamb, but feedback from my companions was unanimously positive.


---- DESSERT ----

They have an extensive dessert menu, I wanted to order at least 4 of their desserts!  This always gets brownie points from me, because many Asian restaurants can't be bothered to make legitimate native desserts (probably because it's labour-intensive and most Americans can't appreciate them).

Sui Gi Mok:  4 stars
A brown sugar semolina agar kueh / cake.

They also had the delicious-sounding Paluda Ice Cream (like cendol drink topped with ice-cream), Jao Jaw (agar cubes layered with coconut pudding), mango sticky rice, and lots more - now I wish I had taken a picture of the menu.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Always lively and energetic inside. Good service, great food. Everything comes out nice and fast so be ready once you order!

Also, try the tea with the flower in it, it's fun to watch.
author: mike t.

description: Been going to Mandalay for 25 years. Many childhood memories eating at this place. Over the past few years prices have gone up considerably and portions have shrunk drastically. I recently ordered two soups to go (~ $13 per soup). The portion for each was around 1.5 cups, giving me the impression that they confused my order with two sides of soup. Nope, that wasn't the case. The portions have literally become that small. On to the mango chicken I ordered. I thought I ordered chicken with mango sauce, but rather it seemed to be cubed mangoes with a spattering of chicken. 80% of the dish was literally cubed mangoes. In the past, I would've easily given Mandalay 5 stars without thinking twice. However,  I'm giving this place 1 star as it really pisses me off when a business decides to cut corners in order to increase profits. The influx of wealth in the area over the years has probably given them the impression that they can get away with this. RIP Mandalay. You'll always hold a special place in my heart.
author: Daniel F.

description:
After going here dozens of times, I've tried most of the menu by now, and everything is consistently delicious.

The Singapore Noodles are especially good, the best I've had. Perfect texture of the noodles.

Can't go wrong with the Mandalay Noodles either.

I could go down the list, but basically whatever you order is going to be great! Go with a group and share.
author: Andy B.

description:
Extremely rude sarcastic staff. Generic food (multiple dishes tasted very similar).

Our waiter asked us, very sarcastically, if we knew what "vegetarian" meant when we asked to clarify if there was a non vegetarian version of the samusa soup. He also seemed to insinuate that we would order food, eat most of it and then send it back to the kitchen.

The Mandalay chicken is a clone of General Tso's chicken. The tea leaf salad is a joke compared to the same dish at Burma Superstar.

Advice: go to Burma Superstar, and wait out the line. It's very much worth the wait. That's NOT what we did, even though in retrospect we should've done just that.
author: Spam F.

description: Only been here twice and orders the same thing both times: Burmese special noodles and the Rangoon beef. So uniquely flavorful. It also has a manageable line unlike the other place down the street. I just moved into neighborhood and excited to explore their menu, particularly because I can get it for takeaway. Only not giving five stars because I don't know how the rest of the menu stacks up but I'm happy to try
author: Marin P.

description: Th Mandalay Special Noodle is absolutely heaven. Seriously if I were about to be executed this dish would make it on my short list of last meals! Also, got to love the fact that it's always decorated like Xmas in there. Burma superstar how do you like them apples?
author: Everybody S.

description:
We were group of 7 people. 5 of us already finished our food and two of us didn't even get one dish after more than an HOUR!!!

We asked few times if there is any fish sauce in the food, two waiters said no (one of us is alergic to fish) and eventually the owners said that there is fish sauce in the dishes that we ordered.

We had high expectations from this place but we are really disapointed.
author: Tamar P.

description:
Service and food was excellent 

Appetizers 
Balada w curry sauce is a must try 
Veg pot stickers ... only 4 pieces was ok
Tea leaf salad was on point

Entrees
Volcano beef was a bit salty
Okra shrimp .... shrimp was very small and not fresh
Fish chowder soup was delicious 
Coconut rice was very fragrant

Overall,  food was pretty good.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Came here on a whim for lunch. Food is good, but a bit pricey.. hence the -2 stars.

I ordered the mango salad (~$9). It was super super fresh, with generous amounts of mango and a light dressing. So delicious! A bit expensive though, considering that it didn't come with any protein! 

The bf ordered garlic & basil beef with a side of rice (~$13 total). Beef was okay. Overall a bit oily, but that's what you expect for any Asian stir-fry. 

Service was good too- patient and friendly. Also, since we came during a late lunch hour, there was no wait at all. Probably wouldn't comeback since I've had better Burmese food elsewhere, but still a good dining experience.
author: Samantha C.

description:
A nice little burmese place.. We were craving Burmese and went to Burma super star but as usual there was a long wait here and so decided to give Mandalay a try.
There was a wait here too but not too much.
The place was crowded and tables were tiny but the food made up for everything.
We had the samusa soup which was yummy. The balada was like roti prata but that was alright.
We had  mandalay special noodles with tofu and that was sooo good..it was very flavorful and fresh.
Their dry pan friend string beans was amazing too and so was their tofu and vegetable curry.. We were stuffed and sooo full but I could not stop eating!!
I just have to come back to try other items.
author: Priya A.

description:
Very poor and unprofessional service. Food was hit and miss, which is atypical of other Burmese places we know. 

We ordered the Balada, which was served with a sauce. My wife has a shellfish allergy and I'm vegetarian. A few of us tasted it, and it definitely had fish or shellfish. We were told by two waiters that the sauce is vegetarian with no fish sauce. The third waiter said it's "completely vegetarian with a little bit of fish sauce" (?!?).

Later on, five of us got our entrees and finished eating, while two others were still waiting for theirs. 

Our friends returned the chicken curry dish, which just didn't look right.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Wow. This place really hit the spot.

I went with 5 others so we really got try try a few things including:
Samosa soup - fantastic
Rainbow salad
Mongolian beef - ORDER this!!
Chicken curry
Broccoli and walnuts with tofu - the walnuts were awesome
Spinach and garlic - our least favorite - but fine
Mandalay special noodle with Chicken
brown rice
They brought us some special sweet potato dessert on the house - which I did not care for but it didn't cost us anything...

It was $25/per person including tip (pretty reasonable)  AND I am excited to go back and try more things.

If you have not had Mongolian food before it is sorta a mix between asian food with a bit of indian influence.  

The service was fast and accurate, not overly friendly or anything.  I can imagine I will crave going back on the first rainy winter day.
author: Amy W.

description: Excellent Burmese restaurant! We found out about this by chance as we were coming back hungry from a hike in the land's end-china beach area a few months ago. It's been in our top 4 favorite restaurants in the City ever since. It offers a great variety of dishes, very tasty and tastefully presented. The staff is fantastic, sincerely friendly and attentive to every detail. I can't recommend any dishes in particular because we try new ones every time and they are always delicious. Highly recommended!
author: Raquel N.

description:
I haven't been back for years, so it was a nice to come back after all these years to see them doing so well. The food is delicious. 

The tea leaf salad had a boatload of peanuts and other nuts, but damn, still so good.
Kaw Soi Dok noodles - Yum love
Fish Chowder - so good with the cilantro and lemon and crunch.. not sure if there was supposed to be noodles in this too but it was delicious 
Balada - crispy chewy pancake and that sauce - to die for.. we had some left over and I was kind of sad they didn't pack the sauce in a ramekin or something for us. Doh!

Overall - the wait is not bad if you get there early enough. Once you hit the dinner rush, the wait can be an hour. Service is super friendly and fast. Also definitely tell them if you have a birthday in your party -- just do it! We witnessed another table with a birthday. Amazing!!!
author: Donna H.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city! Everything from the Balada to the Mandalay noodle to the sizzling rice soup is exceptional. The soups can be shared by two people. The portions could be bigger but the authentic delicious taste make up for that. This is truly a hidden gem of SF that is so much better than the overhyped Burma Superstar. I highly recommend the Balada, the chicken curry and the Mandalay noodles. The tea leaf salad is also exceptional!
author: Iman A.

description:
Part of the Great Noodle Quest (http://www.modernluxury.com/san-francisco/story/the-great-noodle-quest), I found the Kaw Soi Dok to be pretty good and just a small tweak from amazing.

To start from the beginning the staff are super nice and no wait at lunch. I mean super nice. I ordered the noodles and a coconut tapioca drink. First my drink comes out - a tall glass of coconut milk with small tapioca balls (which I expected) and a big straw. The drink is really too thick to be a drink and is more like a liquid dessert. It's pretty good when I think of it that way though there are chunks of stuff in it that I can't identify (coconut?). Turns out I also get a small cup of the soup of the day (corn soup - ok) and now I'm getting worried I won't be able to eat my noodles because I'm too full already.

The noodles arrive in a deep bowl, the kind with the holes built in for chopsticks. Except the noodles are piled so high in the bowl that the chopsticks are dirty and not usable. I assume they're just decorative and use the ones that are a part of my place setting. But the biggest problem with the deep bowl is that all the ingredients are distributed evenly and I can't mix them up together - it's just too unwieldy. So I feel like the noodles could have been really awesome and I just wasn't able to combine it properly. I actually didn't realize this until I ate my way further down and discovered new ingredients. I think this would be better served in a large shallow pasta bowl. I know this is a weird complaint.

Overall the food was good but not great. I'm not sure I would cross town for this again.
author: Jean K.

description:
Very solid restaurant.

Best Burmese restaurant I've had so far in the Bay Area.

Mango Chicken, Catfish Burmese Curry, Ginger Salad.

All entirely on point although I would order tea leaf instead of ginger salad.
author: Santiago S.

description:
Amazing! There is a line out the door for a reason. The food is delicious. Everything we ordered was perfect. I will forever be craving the rainbow salad and Balada. 

The staff is so pleasant. Everyone was nice, I forgot that we waited so long. They are so accommodating. 

Loved it!
author: Kristin F.

description: The tea leaf salad was pretty good. Service was a little slow, probably because it was packed. I liked the ambience.
author: Chahana S.

description:
All the people that don't get into Burma Superstar end up here. Both menus overlap on a lot of dishes, but not sure how or if they're any different taste-wise.

Good luck with parking. It took a couple of rounds before I could find a spot that I could barely squeeze into.

We had the Mango Salad for starters, I had the Mandalay Special Noodle, and friend had the Rainbow Prawn with jumbo prawn. Things duly noted were the crispiness of the pickled mango slices and the dressing, not too light or too heavy. Definitely a great appetizer for two. I got bored of the noodles after a couple mouthfuls. The only thought I had the entire time was that it tasted just like MAMA instant noodles. Not very special. I didn't have the prawn, but by the looks of it, jumbo definitely wasn't jumbo, or they just have very small prawn. The friend definitely didn't get her fill for 20 bucks.

Service was just as boring. Slightly friendly, but could've used some pizzazz. I did, however, find a nickel under the table next to ours. If only the food excited me as much as swiping that nickel did...
author: Peter L.

description:
Three words - tea leaf salad.

For starters, I would never have thought one could eat tea leaves, but I guess it could count as vegetables? This was amazing, had various textures due to the crunchy peanuts and was all around delicious. We ordered some other things, but the only standout for me was this salad... oh and the complimentary soup was really good too. Now it's a mission of mine to try tea leaf salads at other Burmese restaurants. Unfortunately there is only one in NY and it apparently sucks, so whenever I'm in SF, I'll have to get my fix. If you have to get one dish, this would be it, and it won't disappoint.
author: Corinna W.

description:
First visit to Mandalay, and what a solid disappointment.  Samosa soup was mostly broth, heavy on cabbage, and the portions were small.  Entrees took over 35 minutes to arrive (table next to us got theirs in 10) after our waiter flat-out forgot to put in our order.  Did he offer an apology?  Nope.  When the food finally arrived it was not worth the wait.  Pea shoots were tough and fibrous, oily, and not cleaned well.  I had a nice bite of sand while trying to enjoy them.  Mango chicken was unimaginative and poorly executed, with spongy chicken, little spice, and under ripened mango.  The rice wasn't even that good (we had both).

All in all, one of the more disappointing restaurant experiences I've had in a while.  I can't see myself having any reason to go back, especially with other, tastier, Burmese options in the area.
author: Aaron K.

description: Fabulous Burmese in a homey atmosphere.  I've had lots of dishes here and I've been delighted every time.  The Tea Leaf Salad is outstanding.  Highest ranking!
author: Gai S.

description: Not sure how this place has 4/5 star average. The food here is literally Chinese buffet food. All the staff speak mandarin and the items we ordered were of Panda Express level. The only thing that was OK was the tea leaf salad.
author: Eric Z.

description:
We got the:
Burmese curry chicken 
Spicy basil eggplant 
Sautéed spinach and garlic 
Mandalay special noodle 
Chin Hin Yee (soup, like Tom yum)

Small portions. Good, friendly service. Got right in at 6:30 on a Thursday, but then it filled up by 7:30 if not 7. Burma Superstar is better portion size/price, but didn't get the same items so not really comparable. Much bigger menu at BS too. Food came quickly. Pricey for the portion sizes.
author: Kris K.

description: One of my favorites, for vegetarians like me get the rainbow salad, tea leaf salad and the Samosa soup!  The naked eggplant is also amazing!  Better than Burma superstar in my opinion, and with shorter waits due to faster turnover and a larger restaurant. Food is very fresh and service is impeccable!  I always take out of town visitors here because most people haven't encountered burmese food before.
author: Sara S.

description: It's all good.  I love the coconut chicken soup so much... it always hits the spot.  The crispy chicken is hella good, mandalay chicken or beef is good too.  Oh and the mango prawns!  A bit pricey... The staff is usually very nice but there is always a wait for dinner.
author: Ems G.

description:
Tea Leaf Salad - this was fantastic - an authentic Burmese dish with amazing, savory flavors.  It arrives before everything is mixed together and they make a bit of a show of it mixing it at your table. 

Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup - Also amazing...the soup was hearty and rich with flavor.  This is one of those perfect bowls of soup on a cold day/night.

Mandalay Chicken - this was a bit disappointing...more of a Chinese inspired dish, it was basically Sweet and Sour chicken...not bad, but not all that fantastic either.  If you're looking to try something unique, I would not necessarily order this dish.

Overall, this was a fantastic restaurant and I would recommend it to anyone...it's in a casual setting with friendly and attentive service.
author: Ken G.

description: Good food, nice décor, excellent service.  Difficulty parking.
author: Sam S.

description:
First off i don't like pushy staff, I felt rushed, no ones likes to Be rushed. Especially if your at dinner. 
Mind you I haven't, been here in a while and it's really gone down. Prices have gone up, quality of food is horrible. The waiters are horrible, my friend asked about a dish, she wanted to know if she could add more veggies. Our waiter said no because it was pre-made....what does that mean? That alone should have told us to leave. It gets better, the waiter was so pusher he told my friend to order a veggie side dish if she warned more veggies. 

Overall: I will not be returning, service is horrible staff is pushy and food wasn't that great. For the amount I paid, I can get better food at other places.
author: Veronica V.

description:
Amazing food. Came in here with a group of friends and ordered a couple appetizers as well as individual entrees. Service was good, the restaurant was clean, staff was friendly. Be prepared to be overloaded by yellow and red, super vibrant paint job. 

Our group ordered the fried onion, and the potato pancake/naan thing with dipping sauce. The potato pancake was crunchy on the outside and chewy on the inside. The fried onion was unbelievable, think best onion rings ever. 

For entrees we got the coconut soup, Mandalay noodles, and an order walnut chicken. All of the above were very well prepared and tasty. The Mandalay noodles are put together right in front of you, which was a nice bonus. 

Overall a great place to grab a quick lunch.
author: Chris S.

description: I came here a few months ago and the food was great. But then I made the mistake of recommending my family to come. The people working may speak Burmese but they lost me when they gave us Mohinga without noodles. Then when we asked for noodles, the dude was like "this is a soup you don't eat it with noodles" uh dude I was born and raised in Mandalay til I was 15 don't tell me how you're supposed to eat Mohinga. I hope this place closes down or changes it's name because of the disrespect it gives to the country. Go home.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Bf's mama is from Myanmar and loves this place. If she approves it, then I second that! Mandalay is the best Burmese cuisine you can get in the Bay. (Burma Superstar is more Americanized and less authentic...sorry!) I've eaten dinner at Mandalay 3 times and lunch once. I love the food! The flavors can range from subtle to bold but definitely unique...influenced by the cuisines of India, Thailand and China. 

My fav dish is the Moo Hin Nha (fish cowder). Bf's mama cooks this at home and Mandalay's is just as authentic but with less toppings. We've also had the Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup), which was surprisingly light and delicate.  Other dishes we've ordered were Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok), Basil Beef, Mandalay Beef , Rangoon Three Ingredients (Seafood dish), Pan Fry Okra Prawn, Dry Pan Fried String Bean (bf always gets this when we go), Burmese Style Noodle (Kaw Soi Dok). Everything is delicious and usually there's a wait for dinner. Mandalay was featured on Check Please Bay Area a while ago, so I guess the secret's been out.

The service is great and one time we experienced a mishap where the waitress accidentally boxed our leftovers and gave it to another table. She was very apologetic and gave us $20 off of our tab.
author: Liv A.

description: IMO the food is too salty and the staff rushes you to eat. The food portions are small and doesn't have a whole lot of different flavors. The only flavor I tasted was a lot of fish sauce.
author: Sam M.

description: Oh my Gosh this was great food. The tea leaf salad was recommended and very interesting. I liked it a lot.   Not what I expected.  Also had the mango chicken dish.  Pretty good!  Had a spicy shrimp dish filled with jalapeños.  Amazingly good!!  But quite spicy.  Great for me just be prepared.  Service was perfect and so friendly!!
author: J B.

description:
Really Good Food & Good Service! 
The Tea Leaf Salad is amazing! Must Try!!!
Takes time to find a place since they don't take reservations. So be prepared to wait on a busy day. But they are pretty good with their walk in wait list.
author: Vikram C.

description:
AWESOME FOOD AND SERVICE.   Certainly more flavorful than burma superstar in my opinion.  

Mandalay beef
- very tender beef with good flavor

Pumpkin duck
- pumpkin was starchy and cooked to perfection.  duck meat was tender however it was very fatty

Special noodles
- buttery, tangy, tart, savory mix of flavors and textures - this dish will make your tastebuds dance with joy

Not sure about authenticity of the buttery fatty flavors (i think they either use butter, crisco, or lard instead of a vegetable oil) but it sure tasted good to me

Dessert was the coconut milk tapioca with ice cream - a light dessert which was very enjoyable between 2 people

the people who work here give amazing service, they literally split and plated every dish onto our individual plates and came by with a lot of water refills.  also each dish was explained to us and the history behind certain traditional foods.  their service rivals the service i recieve at steak houses.

overall i would recommend coming here with a party of 4 or less, due to lack of seating and long wait times i suggest you come early to put your name down.  its well worth the wait
author: Tina A.

description:
My second visit to Mandalay in SF and I love the food here. I think it is better than Burma Superstar. Everything we ordered was tasty well prepared and unique.  I love the fusion of flavors of Burmese food. 

You must get the tea leaf salad! I would ask them for suggestions on their most popular or highly recommended options off the menu.

There's usually a long wait, but it's worth it!
author: Anne Explores LA +.

description:
Mandalay is definitely legit.

The visit started off the wrong way, however. The waiter wouldn't let my friend take a picture of our food, citing that it's "management's request that no pictures aren't allowed". Wait...how are there 397 photos on yelp if not a single person is allowed to take pictures...?

Anyways, get the:

Tea Leaf salad and coconut rice: Standard staple for burmese food
Roti: omgah. It's cong you bing (for you chinese people) meets curry. so. effing. good.
Mango Chicken: Sounds americanized, doesn't it? CHICKEN IS COOKED PERFECTLY. MANGOS ARE NICE AND SWEET. GET ON IT
Pumpkin pork curry/stew: This was decent, but not the greatest. Pork was a bit on the dry side, but still nice and tasty.

We left no room for dessert. Every future visit, I will try and portion control myself. It may be impossible with such great food.
author: Andrew C.

description: This place is delicious! I have been here several times. The food is fresh and the service is great. Please try the mango lassi, you won't regret it! Tea leaf salad as usual is a favorite here.
author: Christina C.

description:
Highly recommend the following entrees (Mandalay is both consistent and delicious!):
- the Mandalay special noodles
- the mango chicken (not overly sauced, very tasty)
- the rainbow lamb
author: Amelia C.

description:
Who would have thought Burmese food was going to be my thing!!!  This was my first time having Burmese food and now I just need to figure out where to get it in LA, or might just have to move to SF. 

I couldn't have asked for a better place to try a new cuisine. Everything we ordered was so delicious. Got an order of the Tea leaf Salad Coconut Rice, Mandalay Noodles (my favorite), Mango Chicken and Basil Beef. Everything was too good. 

I got the Ginger Lemonade which was good, but might just skip it next time. 

We got there right at 5 on a Wednesday so there was no wait but as we left you could see it filling up.
author: Veronica R.

description:
3.5 stars

This is a cross between Burma Superstar and Yamo.  This is more of a sit down place like Burma Superstar, but a bit more friendly on the wallet with intimidating service like Yamo.

The tea leaf salad here has no cabbage, is that weird!?  Just all the yummy toppings and no cabbage...

Everything I ate here was good, but I wouldn't say it was gRRreat.  If I was taking someone to try some yummOlicious restaurant style burmese food, I would take them to Burma Superstar.  And if I wanted more street, I would take them to Yamo.  

The food was good/good enough, but does not hold a bud in my palette.  I would only come back to this place if it happened to be convenient.
author: Susan L.

description: I ordered the mango chicken which was very tasty! I love the idea of semisweet chicken with mango. The mango still tasted fresh and the chicken was great as well. Also the Burmese iced tea (Thai iced tea) was better than most iced teas. For dessert I had the coconut ice cream, which was sweet and coconuty haha. It was a great meal overall. It's great, tasty Burmese food.
author: Ismael P.

description:
On a Friday night at 8 pm with a party of 3 we waited about 30 minutes.  

As everyone else has noted, the tea leaf salad is a must order dish.  They offer it with and without lettuce (apparently without is the traditional Thai way).  We also had the beef curry with potatoes and coconut rice and the Mandalay noodles.  The beef curry was so-so (wouldn't order again) - the noodles were great.  Oh and we also had the sizzling rice soup which was excellent - very rich broth with chunks of chicken and crunchy rice.  Looking forward to coming here again to try more dishes.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Okay. What we ordered:

1. Chicken and Coconut Soup = BEST soup I've had in my entire life. It's liquid crack yo and I ain't even exaggerating. 

2. Rainbow Salad : so light and refreshing. Mixture of texture and warm grilled onions,veggies was perfection.

3. Basil Chicken : standard/blah/nothing to write home about.

4. Coconut Rice: texture was nice but I have to say I prefer this dish at Burma Superstar. The taste of coconut was more vibrant. And I think they have some crunchy goodness on top too that gives it its extra pizazz jazz hands.
author: Cin H.

description: I don't get how this place gets 4+ stars here. Food is decent but for the price it's not all that. We ordered a tea leaf salad, okra w shrimp, sauteed string beans w tofu, the mandalay noodle dish and the fish chowder. We thought it was more than enough for 3 people, and the waiter suggests another dish. Stupidly, we listened and got the smoked duck -- thankfully half order -- and it was WAY too much food. Then check arrives and they charged us for 3 individual soups. Not a single one of us finished our bowls. I specifically told her whatever the portion was to keep as such; we'll share accordingly. At what point do they decide to broaden the soup order for us wo asking if we wanted? I didn't even complain anymore. This place is overrated. Not going back.
author: Sylvie T.

description: Food was fantastic. We started of with balada and samusa very yummy, the sauces that came with each snack was tasty. Then we ordered the crispy rice and basil beef with the two different types rice and was extremely satisfied with our choices.
author: Caring C.

description: Fantastic food. Order the coconut rice, tea leaf salad, roti with curry sauce, lamb rangoon, sautéed string beans, and shrimp with okra. Explosion of flavors and terrific service as well!
author: Anjali V.

description: Delicious tasty and very veggie friendly! The wait staff are super accommodating and very courteous. Great local spot!
author: Pam C.

description: Still good but not as good as it used to be!  I remember this place as amazing so I took a lady friend intending to show off and was shut down by mediocrity. Thankfully I was able to make up for it in my own. Sad to see a place fizzle out like that.
author: David G.

description:
I decided to try Burmese food for the first time and came here to check it out because there wasn't a long line for lunch. We were seated right away but it took awhile before we were able to put our orders in because there was only two waiters in the whole restaurant. They were really busy for sure! 

The coconut chicken soup was the bomb. It's freezing outside and the soup was simply delicious. I loved the sautéed onions in it. I also tried the rainbow salad and it tasted mediocre, just wished the salad was a bit colder. There were so many ingredients in it that it was hard to taste anything. The curry beef was good, the sauce wasn't enough for the coconut rice so it was a bit dry for my taste. The coconut milk with tapioca tasted as expected, coconut bits with tapioca. 

My one problem with this place is the slow service here. Cmon, it's lunch time and I'm hungry! Come and take my order!
author: Maybo L.

description:
The food is good, but the service is horrid.

My friends and I had a reservation for 730 and we arrived early - what time did we finally get seated? 845. Were we completely starving? yes - did people with comparable groups who got there later get seated before us?

I would come back again because:

the tea salad is really good -  nice and crunchy with nuts and some veggies - but definitely not like the tea salad at burma superstar

the pumpkin curry actually comes in a pumpkin! it was good I'm not going to lie, but was I angrily and voraciously eating due to the bad service? yes.
author: Christine B.

description:
We were hiking in the Presidio and stopped by Mandalay for a late lunch on the weekend. Boy, was this place a great find! The tea leaf salad was very good, and the coconut rice hit the spot, but the standout for me was the chicken curry - a great balance of flavors and texture.

Also, service was excellent!

We'll be back!
author: Jessica W.

description:
Somewhere between a 3 and a 3.4?

Is there not always a certain amount of risk taken when recommending to family and long-time fam friends a restaurant based solely upon average Yelp ratings? I was a bit nervous as I turned onto California from Fisherman's Wharf to bring a full carload here. I hoped that NOT choosing C-town was going to be appreciated by my passengers (Ma and Pa included).

It had been, thus far, a pleasant and  memorable Saturday, Angel Island's 100th anniv. commemoration, an afternoon of warmth and remembrance.  I was emotionally moved by a deep sense of identity and pride for those Chinese who were detained at their own Ellis Island. There were several points in which my jaw grew taut, and I found myself swallowing some tears at the injustice, discrimination, and utter loneliness of my kinsmen.
*******
Oh Mandalay...why were you just OK? My new friend, Cindy W., nailed this review, as far as I am concerned. In so many regards, even though we chose different entrees, my sentiments were hers. The overall experience was pleasant, but I would hesitate to make a repeat visit here.

Burmese food: a somewhat tamer version of Thai, with the imported fermented green tea leaves a big sell, both at Burma SS and here. 

Ordered the following for 5:
Tea leaf salad (9.5)
Catfish soup (Moo Hing Nga) (9.5) 
Special noodle (housemade noodles) (9)
Burmese lamb curry stew (11.5)
Pumpkin pork stew (10.5?)
Lychee Coconut prawns (12?)
Coconut rice

I've tried this kind of salad before; Mandalay does not use any lettuce. Heavy on the sesame taste, and for some reason, the tea leaf flavor was found lacking and its flavor did not shine forth. Fish soup was definitely interesting texture and overall, quite nice, although, again, the flavor of the catfish was not the 'melody' here either.

Apps aside, our entrees were definitely above average. Portions here were on the scantier side of things (i.e. stews were just a hair filled above half the bowl), which made me sensitive to people having enough food (and great, there was a chef among us....ahem... not.. me). Though there was flavor in the food, I had hoped for so much more. Having had proper Burmese only twice before, it was difficult for me save relying on the trusty palate of yours truly.

The lychee coconut prawns: this dish did not work, and I so wished that I had read another reviewer's notes beforehand. The prawns are smaller than medium size, and felt the pairing did not go together, no. Pass.

Coconut rice: I know what fresh rice tastes like, and each time they charged us for another order of it, it just didn't taste fresh. Course it was weighted with the heaviness of coconut milk, but c'mon, i'm no chump ABC... I have a discerning eye and hard to believe the 'fluff' would be completely absent with the milk.

Service was prompt, courteous, unobtrusive, and efficient. Restaurant is in a quieter neighborhood and much easier to find parking. Decor is clean, nice use of their space.  

Dinner ran $70 something and a cool tip of $15. So sorry; I would like to have elevated my Yelp a bit more, as you were so accommodating, but I cannot do it.
author: Jana C.

description: One star because I didn't even get to try my food and I was here for over an hour and a half. Came here with about 8 people, we ordered and waited. People came in after us and got their food. I went and tried to get the attention of a young server but she avoided me and went to the back because she saw I was irritated . I complained to one of the ladies and she kept reassuring me that the food would come out. I am on a time crunch as I have to meet a friend from out of town so waiting for this long is rude and bad service. By the time the food came I had to go so I told her to cancel my meal. By then my party still hadn't gotten all their food. We had only gotten one dish between 8 people. Never coming back here again
author: Yung W.

description:
Came here after Lindy in the Park on Sunday: it is 1.5 mile walk, or (my case) a short drive followed by a long search for a parking spot.

Overall: an excellent place; a must-visit for anyone who likes Burmese or Thai food. A lot of people on Sunday afternoon were regulars, a couple at the next table was visiting the place on a regular basis for five years straight (the place itself is over 30 years old).

Menu is quite long, so few suggestions from patrons and staff that we liked: all soups are good, Papaya salad, "volcano" beef. Food tasted excellently and was quite reasonably priced: a full dinner for two people (we shared salad, soup, noodles and beef) was slightly above $70.

Restaurant runs as a well-oiled machine, service - for the type of place - is impeccable. Restaurant was almost full at 4PM on Sunday; at this off-peak time, walk-ins are possible (on weekends, the place is open from lunch to late dinner). I would expect that at any time that is even slightly more popular, reservations might be essential.

Parking is the only problem.
author: Dmitri V.

description: So amazing! The tea leaf salad, walnuts with tofu, balada bread was heavenly! There was no wait and I think just as good or even better than Burma Superstar. Super cute atmosphere as well and great service.
author: Lucy B.

description: This place was excellent.  Very tasty food and good service.  We got green papaya salad... loved it.. it was refreshing and tasty.. we got Balada which I didn't like that much.. I guess I was expecting something more like roti prata, but this pancake was too thick, chewy and doughy and the sauce was kind of bland and watery.  We got the special noodle which was delicious.  We got the mango chicken I think? It was super delicious.  We got basil prawn I think? super delicious.  But the two dishes I loved the most were the okra egg curry and the fried eggplant dish.  I love okra and I love egg and they were great together in a tasty sauce.  The fried eggplant was unbelievable!  Huge chunks fried to a perfect crisp on outside and gooey and steaming hot inside.  One of the best things I've eaten in a long time!  Its a super popular place so it was packed on a Friday night and very tight seating since we had a table of 8.  But service was great, food came out fast and furious.  Very happy w/ the meal.
author: Easter E.

description:
I love this restaurant! The only thing is that so do a ton of other people and they don't take reservations. Try to show up earlier to beat the crowds. 

My favorite dishes so far: rainbow salad, pumpkin pork, coconut rice. I'm looking forward to trying their other dishes too. Their drinks are awesome too.
author: Jade C.

description: Amazingly delicious food that doesn't disappoint! My typical order goes like this: balada with dipping sauce, tea leaf salad, okra egg curry. The Mandalay Special Noodle and Walnut Prawn are also delicious. I tend to order vegetarian, but will flex for the Pork and Pumpkin Stew. Oh, and they have a great birthday surprise!
author: Jenn F.

description:
Overall, a satisfying meal.

I really liked the samosa soup, the tea leaf salad could have used some more body, and the main dish we ordered was fine, but not memorable.

I had a tapioca coconut milk drink that was really unhealthy good.
author: Dimple B.

description: So the must- have here is the tea leaf salad. Overall very good Burmese food. The wait was 30 minutes, just a heads up.
author: Val K.

description: One of the best restaurants I have ever had . The food is amazing. I am gona die for it !!!!!!!!!!  Parking is hard thou.
author: Weston L.

description: Nice service and delicious food. There's option for everyone and if you're not very hungry you can share the dish.
author: Daniel P.

description: All I have to say is, "YUM, YUM, YUM, YUM!!!" Fabulous lunch with fabulous co-workers on a fabulous Friday!  :)
author: Nan P.

description:
This is one of my local neighborhood favorites! I love being able to walk here from our apartment. It just has so much charm... and a lot of flavor too. Be warned - it gets crowded. If you're going during peak hours on a Friday / Saturday night, be prepared to grab a beer and wait, especially if you're with a group of four.

Definitely go family style. If it's your first time, you have to get the balada. You also have to get their special noodles that they mix up for you at the table. That's half your meal - now just pick a protein and some rice, and you're good to go.

I have literally been impressed by everything I've eaten there. I was with a friend there this past week, and he ordered fish curry soup... I have to be honest that I found that to sound a bit gross, and if he weren't visiting from out of town, I probably would have told him to pick something else. Alas, the fish curry soup was delivered, and it was amazing. I'd say it was the highlight of my meal.

There's a certain place a couple blocks away that gets all the hype ~ I shall not mention it by name! The lines are twice as long there and the food is half as good. Do yourself a favor and give Mandalay a shot.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Mandalay may rival it's more popular rival Burma Superstar. However, Mandalay is just as good if not as good as Burma Superstar. 

Parkin is pretty rough in this neighborhood on weekends.
author: Carlos A.

description: The tea-smoked duck starts with tea that has been suspended in some god-forsaken river that runs through Mandalay which Google refuses to name, fermented for some unspecified period of time, then used to produce a duck that is cooked to delectable perfection and served with such other irreproducible delicacies as their withered green beans and so much more that I once witnessed it converting a die-hard bible-thumping meat-and-potatoes Christian to someone his wife would never again recognize. That's for starters.
author: Rick B.

description: Awesome time at Mandalay.  Had a mango lassi, with tea leaf salad, samusa, egg & okra, and Mandalay Special noodles.  So good it makes you want to go back soon.
author: Douglas A.

description: Not having real Burmese food before, I was unsure what to expect. First things off, this place is busy. Plan on waiting for at least a half hour especially for parties of four or more. Once seated, service is fast and attentive. One must have is the Burmese tea salad. Difficult to explain what flavors are in the dish, but it is exotic for the normal palate full of different flavors and textures. Interestingly, the salad is prepared table side, staring off with what lies like a collection of seeds a green paste, but when mixed, the taste is addictive. Same with the sautéed green beans. Definitely taste shrimp paste in this dish and serves as a great side dish for the mango chicken. Tender cuts of sautéed chicken complemented with chunks of sweet mango. I really enjoyed my first experience with Burmese food and hope to come here again.
author: Kris B.

description:
Come at 7 or before if you want to beat the crowd. We came on a Friday night around 6:30-7ish and only had to wait 5-8 minutes for a table for two, before getting seated. By the time we were done with our dinner, their entire waiting area was filled with people. Looked like at least a 45 minute wait. Restaurant is very cozy, with not a lot of space between adjacent tables. Perfect eavesdropping opportunity. 
Anytime I eat at a Burmese restaurant, I always have to order the tea leaf salad. Mandalay's tea leaf salad was good until after taking a few more bites, I started noticing the strong scallion flavor and it was a little too much for me. I think Burma Superstar's tea leaf salad is a lot better. Also tried the Mandalay noodles. The crispy noodles added great texture to the dish. The last thing we ordered was the mango chicken. This dish was just okay. 
The menu seemed to have a lot of delicious items. I already forsee myself coming back in the near future to try a curry dish and their eggplant. I LOVE EGGPLANT. I hope its good!
author: Amy X.

description: Seriously such good Burmese food! You have to get the Tea Leaf Salad. Pretty much anything else on the menu is guaranteed amazing. Super busy on weekends at night but honestly worth the wait.
author: Jelita A.

description: This place is so good. Every dish was excellent. Don't even remember what Burma Superwhat tasted like after this.
author: Randyl B.

description: Soup was tasty and entries were equally delicious. The place was bit crowded and ten of us sat on a table that can hold 8. Other than this issue, very satisfied with the quality of the food. Will visit again.
author: Tajinder S.

description:
So I went here for my birthday because I was in the mood for Burmese food and Burma SuperStar was not able to seat my family of 5 for another hour. I called Mandalay ahead of time and they said that they would have a table read for us right away. We get there and we have to wait for 15 minutes, which was not too bad. But we sat right in front of the kitchen door at a table the should have only sat three people comfortably but Mandalay stuck five of us there. There was not enough room for all our plates and glasses of water. 

We ordered: 

appetizer -- Chicken Satay
salad -- Tea Leaf Salad (lap pat dok)
soup -- Jia San Hinga (black pepper soup)
entree -- Rangoon Beef, Mandalay Chicken, Mandalay Special Noodle

Maybe we ordered the wrong dishes but a majority of the dishes were bland. The only dish that I would think about ordering again is the Tea Leaf Salad and the Mandalay Special Noodle. Both were the highlights of the night. The Tea Leaf Salad is an acquired taste but worth giving a try to see if you like it or not. The Mandalay Special Noodle tasted like it had a milder version of an Ong No Kaw Soi soup poured on top of noodles and it was so yummy. The chicken satay was dry and tasted like processed chicken breast. Also, there was a piece of hair stuck on one of the satay skewers. The Jia San Hinga, Rangoon Beef, and Mandalay Chicken could have been ordered from any Chinese restaurant. They did not taste bad, I just expected something more flavorful and authentic. 

The service was average. The waitress was really nice and gave us a new Chicken Satay appetizer after we pointed out the hair. She also spoke Chinese. 

Overall, I was disappointed with Mandalay. I expected so much more, since many Yelpers said it was better than Burma SuperStar. I have had Burmese food from friends who are from Burma. I would just go to Pagan on Clement or Burma SuperStar next time I am feeling the urge for Burmese food.

Two stars since I did like two dishes and the waitress tried to make sure that we were comfortable with the extra small table.
author: Andrew W.

description: A splendid gateway into the mostly uncharted landscape of Burmese cuisine.  Places like Mandalay are a principle reason why those of us from "Middle America" come to San Francisco.  Every item on the menu was pleasing to the palate and adventuresome without being too exotic. A particular tip of the hat to the mango chicken and string beans.
author: Ryan J.

description:
If the wait is 40 minutes or less, then go for it. If it's longer, skip it and save it for next time.

Side comment on their service at Mandalay: though it's obviously over-capacity, the owners/servers never lost patience with the customers like most Asian restaurants [unfortunately] do. They did the the subtle nudges encouraging you to decide on the orders prior to sitting down, pushing for you to then put in all orders at once (reinforced with subtle threats: "I guarantee you it will be an hour wait!"), and having the servers flocking by every thirty seconds or so to swoop away any unused or empty china, ALL WITHOUT PISSING ANYBODY OFF.

How do they do that?

The atmosphere is great. The decor is casual and very local Burma-esque, but the dim lights, foreign customers, and loud rumble of conversations made by 50% more people than allowed int he room, make Mandalay seem almost chic and hip.

Food ordered:
Mandalay Special Noodle
Mango Chicken
Tea Leaf Salad
String Beans
Mandalay Naked Eggplant something

Okay, two superstars of tonight's dinner are the tea leaf salad and the stir-fried eggplants. Let's save those for last.

1. Mandalay special noodle: flat rice noodles tossed in an assortment of spices, nuts, and lemon juice topped with crunchy fried noodle pieces. Refreshing, complex in flavor with the myriad of spices, fried shallots, and coconut juice. But dull in comparison to other dishes. This tastes a bit like Taiwanese tan-tan noodles mixed with coconut milk. Strange.

2. Mango Chicken: ok all I got was salty. The mangos are nice and firm, their sourness a nice offset for the salty chicken.

3. String Beans are string beans.

4. Tea Leaf Salad: fried garlic slices, tea leaves, peanuts, lemon juice, tossed in front of you. This is like getting a face full of burma thrown in your face. The ground tea leaves add a slight bitterness to the salad, while fried garlic added sweetness and some kick. This probably would not be a dish for you if you are not into very spice-intense dishes, but definitely worth the hype.

5. Eggplant: anybody who likes eggplant would love this! Large pieces of eggplant first fried then stir-fried, so it's crispy-almost-going-to-get-soft on the outside and so soft and creamy on the inside.

Definitely has become a new favorite just after one try.
author: Chia L.

description:
My favorite part about Mandaly is Sherry (the owner). She's such a sweet, sweet woman. Her food is incredible and there's no wonder why you often have to wait 45 minutes for a table at dinner time. Some of my favorites include the Singapore noodles, mango salad, nan gyi dok, and mango chicken. 

It seems like 3 dishes between two people is the fitting number. I'd also recommend coming for lunch as that's the least busy time. A bit on the pricier side but some dishes require a server coming to your table to prepare the food.
author: Tommy C.

description: It was good and fine but not special. Burma is actually a better restaurant but comparisons aren't necessary here. For good flavor and a quick seat, Mandalay is your go-to. I liked the chicken lettuce cups but beef basil was a bit too saucy for my liking. Super sweet service and bright decor make for a fine experience, but again, nothing special.
author: Jeff M.

description: The wait is long, but well worth it! I love the Mandalay Chicken, it's the perfect mix of sweet and spicy. Pair it with the Saffron Rice and Garlic Green Beans. It's a perfect combo packed with tons of flavor. The space is cute and a bit loud, but it's a fun place to eat and there is more space than Burma Superstar, which I also feel is a bit better.
author: Allison T.

description:
Delicious Burmese spot with perfectly crunchy tea leaf salad and stellar service. Get the Mandalay beef and coconut rice, yummy fried beef pieces with sweet onions! The special noodles are fresh with tasty chicken and coconut sauce too. Jasmine tea is pretty fancy- you'll see. 

We got a table for 2 in 15 minutes on a Sunday night, place was busy but not too crowded, 10% off if you are willing to wait outside (small host area.)
author: Jessica L.

description:
Mmmmm hmmmm.

In case you haven't read it in previous reviews - Tea Leaf Salad. Get The Tea Leaf Salad. The waiter will come down to your table with all the ingredients piled up on a board, so that you can see what goes into it before it all gets mixed right there in front of you. In the mix are lentils, garlic, sesame seeds, tea leaves (obvs!) chili, and lots of other super tasty super colourful stuff. 

The colour goes pretty well with the vibe of the place. Super happy staff, super psychadelic (in a Burmese way!) decor, and general good vibes. 

Everything else we ate here was also delicous and beautifully presented. Some of the best tofu I've ever tasted, mango salad that was bursting with flavour, and the coconut rice oh the coconut rice. So. Unbelievably. Good. 
 
I would highly recommend making the trip out to Richmond for it. Just for the love of God, make sure you get the tea leaf salad!!!
author: Emily C.

description:
My friend suggested to come here since it's San Francisco's first Burmese restaurant. I have never eaten here. Came here for lunch around 1 on Saturday and the place was almost empty. Not a good sign.

My worry was quickly overrun by the arrival of the samosa ($8) appetizer. Six pieces of crispy, but not greasy, samosa with curried ground chicken and potato. The wrapper is very thin and the filling very tasty.

Rainbow salad ($9.5) is prepared with twenty ingredients neatly arranged in a square plate. The waitress explained the ingredients, which include two kinds of rice noodles, chili powder, crispy fried garlic, diced potatoes, tofu, dried shrimp, fried onions, green papaya, roasted chilies, crushed yellow beans, cilantro, won ton chips, cabbage and a tamarind dressing, before mixing the salad for us. This is an explosion of flavors and textures to whet your taste bud. It tastes even better than that of Burma Superstar.

Basil Chicken ($9) is a bit of a disappointment. While the chicken is sauteed with fresh basil galore, the gravy is too thick and sweet, almost has a sweet-and-sour flavor. I would like it to be more spicy with basil.

Overall it's a good dining experience. The meal concluded with complimentary mango pudding.
author: Matt Y.

description: Best Burmese food in the city, by far! Every dish is so different, fragrant and colorful. The staff is great and truly cares about each table's experience. The tea leaf salad is my favorite dish on the menu. The pumpkin curry is great too...(and it comes in a pumpkin!)
author: Elise C.

description:
I've never had this type of food in my life.
We were all hesitant because of that.
The atmosphere was relaxing and the waitress was endearing.
She suggested us the tea leaf salad since we were newbies.
It was out of this world. I was so stunned, because when she brought it over we were all confused. This couldn't be a salad? Then she mixed all of the ingredients together quickly and handed us chopsticks. Upon taste testing, we knew this was something special. We knew what the hype on Yelp was about!
All of our food entrees were to die for, a real gem of San Francisco.
If you're near it, you better park your darn car and get some amazing lunch!
author: Shane H.

description: Green leaf tea salad is incredible, friendly staff
author: Magda G.

description: Better than Burma Superstar IMHO.  Best dishes are the tea leaf salad, fish chowder, mango chicken, Mandalay special noodles, and string beans (that I prefer plain or with scallops).  Non-Burmese dishes on the menu are not that good, but if you stick with the best dishes you won't go wrong.
author: Robert R.

description: Delicious food, great ambiance and service. Don't miss the lamb curry which was a-mazing. Went with a big group which they accommodated really well and gave us a chance to try many, many dishes.More traditional Burmese fare than at B-star, but very good quality and homey.
author: Jason O.

description:
Mandalay opened in 1984 and is known for being one of the best Burmese restaurant in the area and I have to say that they didn't deceived us! 5 of us went there and share 5 dished along with drinks.
The food: we had the tea leaf salad (a must have), the mango chicken (good but nothing out of the ordinary), the lamb curry, the Mandalay eggplants (the best dish of the night - fried skinless eggplants!) and prawn with okra (well done). Overall a pretty solid selection.
The drinks: we had a couple of mango lassi and a hot sake. Levers thing was fine. I don't think however the drinks here are as good as their food!
The service: fast and efficient! After waiting 10 minutes to get our table (we booked a table through their website) everything went pretty fast. Our order was taken within 5 minutes and the food came with another 5 minutes. The only cons here was that we were asked to leave once we finished our plates as other people were waiting.
author: Cedric L.

description:
Before eating here, I've never had Burmese cuisine. We came here for lunch and were able to try a couple things from the lunch specials menu. We got the balada and Burmese curry beef combo and the Mandalay special noodles. Balada is a dense and chewy fried pancake (reminds me of naan, but better), and was perfect for dipping in the curry. However, the special noodles stole the show. The server explained all the ingredients used in the noodles, since the dish is brought out with all the ingredients separated before being tossed together. The thick noodles were nice and saucy, and the fried crispy onions and fried noodles on top made it so much better. This dish typically comes with coconut chicken but is also available with tofu for the vegetarians out there.

Service was great, can get crowded and intimate during the lunch rush, but they also offer take out.
author: Melanie N.

description: I have been going to Mandalay for over twenty years, which should be some indication of how much I like it. Well priced, excellent food (significantly better than Burma Super Star and other Burmese restaurants I've tried), good service, nice atmosphere. Some good bets are the tea leaf salad, coconut chicken soup, Burmese hot and sour soup, mango chicken, okra prawns, Mandalay prawns (you have to ask - it is not on the menu), and dry fried string beans (with or without tofu). Coconut rice is not only tasty, but takes the edge off the spicier dishes. If you feel like wine, the Honig sauvignon blanc is delicious, and pairs nicely with most of the dishes.
author: Jethro B.

description:
The food was amazing! Went on a Fri night with a group of 8 ppl. Made reservations ahead of time (def recommended for larger group).
We had the Tea Leaf Salad & Rainbow Salad - both excellent!
We shared a number of dishes family style - Mandalay Noodles, Mango Chicken, Spicy Tofu, Basil Prawn, Pumpkin Pork and Beef were all delicious & very flavorful. 
Good service & reasonable prices. Highly recommend it!
author: Dora M.

description: Customer service was great. My friend and I ordered the Rangoon beef, walnut broccoli tofu, and chicken skewers. All were extremely tasty...highly recommend. I don't know how "authentic" it was, but if I had a bigger stomach, I definitely would've eaten another entree.
author: Airee K.

description:
Could this place be any more FANTASTIC?! I'm not sure that it can. 

I've been dreaming of the mango chicken ever since I ate it. I'm not sure why it took me so long to discover Mandalay. But now that it is on my radar... I will be back on a regular basis. 

We ordered the fantastic and flavorful tea leaf salad - there are no greens in this salad, but the flavors make up for it! The mango chicken - yummmm, basil beef - out of this world - we also ordered the shrimp with okra and coconut rice - don't forget the coconut rice!

The service was quick and attentive. Come hungry, be prepared for a wait... and you will not be disappointed.
author: Shannon H.

description: Good stuff! It can get quite busy at times so anticipate a wait. The quality of the food is great. Haven't gotten anything I don't like.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Love eating at Mandalay! Every time I come here with friends or family,  I am never disappointed! Must order: fish chowder, balada, mango salad and walnut prawns!
author: Judy L.

description:
This little gem that has been here for a long time is enjoying a little renaissance and it deserves to. Food here has great flavors , good portions, and a friendly staff that is attentive and courteous.
I've been here multiple times, have tried many dishes and never have I been disappointed. 
Volcano beef rocks if you like spicy. Any of the curries are just so tasty and balanced, papaya salad is one of the best in the area.  I can't say enough good things about this place. The hostess is awesome , their front alter is a testament to their devotion to good food
author: Matt A.

description:
First time trying Burmese food and it definitely did not disappoint! The beef and chicken dishes we ordered left an explosion of flavor in my mouth. 
Came with a group of 4 on a Sunday afternoon (2:30pm) wasn't crowded. 
Good Service. 
Interesting mix of music. (From top 40s from 5-10 years ago to "Take a boy" by Rihanna sung in an unrecognizable asian language).
Lovely decor!
COming back to try the Balada and Curry and much more!


We ordered:
SATAY CHICKEN: Came with 6 skewers. Chicken was cooked nicely but nothing particularly special in my opinion. Served with a small salad and garlicky peanut sauce

MANGO CHICKEN: I'm always a fan of anything with mango in it. Perfect combination of savory and sweet.

MANDALAY BEEF: Slight hint of spicy but the flavor is fantastic

PAN FRIED STRING BEANS: Started off fantastic but after getting too excited and eat a lot of it, started to think they were too salty. Despite that, it is still a dish I would order again without hesitation

COCONUT RICE: I am not a fan of anything coconut (unless its coconut milk in my curry) but this rice paired with the dishes was a nice touch. Good alternative the steamed rice.
author: Yolanda M.

description: Mango salad 4stars green tea leaf salad 4stars salt and pepper shrimp 31/2 stars Burmese ice tea 41/2
author: Ric H.

description: Great place for food. Service was very friendly and they always came by to check to see how we were doing. Some of the staffs' English skills were a little iffy but friendly nonetheless. Seems a great place for dates as loads of tables were for 2 people. Food was a little pricy for Asian food. We ordered a whole crispy chicken which was delicious. Eggplant was yummy and so was the pork dish. Recommend ordering the appetizer I believe it was a roti? Naan that you dipped into an amazing curry sauce. Would definitely come back.
author: Carol L.

description:
I picked up food from here and ate it at home, so I can't comment on the service.. but the food is fantastic! I got the: 

Balada (pancake with curry dipping sauce): It was slightly soggy by the time I got home, but still really good.

Mandalay Special Noodle: At first I panicked, because I didn't see any chicken, but realized that they chicken was mixed in with the curry sauce that they packaged separately. Whew. This was delicious! Loved the contrast in texture between the soft and crispy noodles.

Burmese Style Chicken Curry: This is basically a yellow curry dish with chicken. The thing I don't like about ordering curry at restaurants is that it's usually jam packed with potatoes with like one or two pieces of dry chicken in it. This dish was awesome though cause it was loaded with moist, flavorful chicken! Probably one of the best curry dishes I've had.
author: Christina L.

description: I like the place a lot, in the last two years and half I have been there many times for lunch (work nearby). Service is fairly good and prompt most of the times (well there is a waiter that is not that good but overall service is just fine). Plenty of street parking and prices above average but so is the quality of the ingredients. Despite the good food and service I truly believe that other Asian restaurants nearby are far better and less expensive.
author: Derek R.

description: Came here last night for the first time and was pleasantly surprised. Very prompt seating and service! The food was hot and fresh. The tea leaf salad doesn't come with lettuce, but I asked for some and they brought it to me. Mandalay is unpretentious and comfortable. It gets very busy so best to come a little early. I am looking forward to returning soon!
author: Jill S.

description:
My friend and I (both vegetarians) were starved after hiking and popped by for a quick bite before heading home. Upon first entering, I am immediately impressed by the decoration. Lots of Burmese cultural items and the lighting gave the place a homey vibe. The entire staff wore traditional Burmese clothing, which I thought was a great touch.

We were seated and given menus, but it took at least 5 minutes before someone came by so we could ask for water. After another 5 minutes or so we received our water and could place our order. The place seemed to be winding down from the lunch hour and with only 3 servers I can see why it took so long. 

We ordered the Mandalay special noodles & Mandalay special naked eggplant. Both were delicious! I loved the refreshing taste of the noodles and will definitely order it again next time. Eggplant was soft and tender inside yet crispy outside...so yummy! 

Overall a great place, but service could be a bit faster. Looking forward to trying new dishes next time!
author: Khanh T.

description: I live up in Santa Rosa and don't get down to SF as much as I like, but today I made a special point of returning to Mandalay after a few years.  I was not disappointed!  The service was quick and attentive and the food was amazing!  I haven't had such a great meal in a long time.  What I love most about this place is that the flavors are just so different from Thai or Chinese.  It's like falling in love again.
author: Rob N.

description: Simply The Best Burmese food ever! Everything in the menu is superb! My favorites? Mandalay Special noodles and the tea leaf salad with Mango Lassi :)
author: Tony R.

description:
TEA LEAF SALAD!

If for no other reason, go here for the Tea Leaf Salad.
I have liked everything on the menu.  Especially the Mandalay Chicken, coconut rice and did I mention the tea leaf salad?

The staff are all very helpful and friendly and do a great job of seating people quickly even though this place can have long lines out the door.

Seriously though...try the tea leaf salad!
author: Stacy Y.

description: This is as good as it gets for Burmese food. Honey really loves Burmese food. We came here for dinner. Parking in the Richmond district was okay. We had to park about a block away and walk to the restaurant. The outside of the restaurant is pretty ordinary. Inside looks pretty traditional and a little dark, which is fine. We were able to be seated before the dinner crowd came in. We ordered the samusa, tea leaf salad, kaw sol dok, and maybe another dish. The tea leaf salad was very authentic. It does not come with lettuce, cabbage, or romaine. After it was mixed, we both could smell the sesame. It tasted very very good and yummy. Other dishes were good as well. We really enjoyed dining here. Honey and I will come back to try other dishes.
author: Allan W.

description: Maybe I ordered the wrong thing or came on an off night, but this highly recommended alternative to Burma Superstar that one of my customers suggested was good, but not pulling me to come back.  Serving staff was nice enough.  Rainbow Chicken, although sounded great in how it was described, was nothing special and i thought chicken was dry.  The special rice with raisins & cinnamon was served lukewarm.  The Burmese Iced Tea was the best part -- tasted great and served in a fun, VERY tall glass.  The prices?  Yes, definitely better than Burma Superstar.   Only taking away 1 star at this point as i will prob give them a 2nd chance.   But another reviewer said that, with Mandalay, why bother eating Thai?   Well, at this point, I still prefer my fave Thai places to this.
author: Merrick W.

description:
A little pricey for some of the dishes.  

i was in love with the tea leaf salad but i've ordered it too many times that now i can't really order it anymore.  i definitely suggest it however if you have never tried it before.

the mandalay special noodles are amazing.  i really like their hto & sour soup and their rock cod fillet black pepper soup.
author: Hyla S.

description:
We ordered this for pick up and all the dishes were super yummy. 

This is what we ordered:

Yellow Chicken Curry - delicious, made with potatoes.
Chicken Satay - very good peanut dipping sauce.  Chicken was a little dry though.
Rainbow Salad - salad dressing was on the side and smelt like dirty feet. We didnt use it.  Also the salad was just okay for $10.  I probably wouldn't order this again.
Mango chicken - my friend loved this.
Basil spicy Pork - tasty but not that spicy.
Crispy chicken - no complaints here.
Coconut rice and Saffron rice.  - the saffron rice has some veggies in it and seemed fried.  It was tasty but I think everyone preferred the Coconut rice.

I would definitely recommend this place and I am sure we will visit or order again soon.

Tasty!!
author: Nicki D.

description: Went there today for lunch and I'm in love.  Better than Burma Superstar.  My favorites were the rainbow salad, Bermese style noodle (citrus dressing and refreshing), and the ginger lemonade.  Definitely want to go back and try more.
author: Helena M.

description:
OH. MY. GOODNESS.

I was looking forward to getting Burmese food all weekend when I was up visiting in SF. A friend recommended this place to us, so we went. 

First off, it's really hard to miss, because the outside is BRIGHT YELLOW AND GREEN. It was beautifully hilarious. The inside has lots of decorations, which I was very smitten with.

The service was great. They were very friendly and prompt. When I was ordering, the waitress even suggested that I get something else, and it was a great call on her part. I ended up getting the Mandalay Eggplant, which tasted HEAVENLY. I got the Balada, which was SO good, and HUGE. And I got a side of coconut rice, which went perfectly with the eggplant dish. I was so sad when I got full. I literally wanted to run outside, vomit everything up, and then order 3 new things. The food was just that amazing.

If you are visiting SF, go here. If you are from SF, go here. Just. Go here.
author: Deryck R.

description:
After watching an episode of Bay Area's Check Please at 3 am super stoned, I vowed I would try this place within a few days.  My xmas din was cancelled because my mom was not feeling well and being half jewish, I felt it only right to have azn food on xmas, plus nothing else was open.  I figured they would be slammed, so I ordered early for take out.  I did some research as to which dishes to try, and here is the list and my thoughts:

*Samosa Soup- AMAZING, possibly my favorite! Great texture in the soup and the broth tastes so good! 
*Balada- Tasty fried bread.  Happy I tried, yummy, but next time I will pass
*Pumpkin Curry Pork-Usually do not order pork but decided to try something different.  The pumpkin is heavy and creamy. Good but next time I would skip. 
*Special Noodles- Possibly better to eat at the table where it is mixed for you by the staff, I think I did a shitty job of mixing it, but it was a tasty sauce and interesting ingredients. 
*Mandalay Chicken- A total cowd pleaser.  Must order. Hard not to like. 

The place was packed xmas night, I felt bad for the staff. I enjoyed the food so much, I think I will go back tonight and try a few other dishes!
author: Chelsey G.

description: Second time here and it was as good as the first. Get the balada for an appetizer, so delicious. Service is awesome as well, love this place.
author: Vince P.

description: Everything I had was excellent, the service was fast and friendly, and the atmosphere was well-tuned. It could have benefited from some music, but otherwise this is a must-eat location.
author: Matthew S.

description:
The food is amazing. My faves include the okra shrimp dish and the tea leaf salad. Every bite was full of spice and flavor. 

Customer service was pretty good. No complaints here.

I most definitely will be back for more.
author: Ann S.

description:
BETTER than Burma Superstar and Yamo IMO.

I've been going here over the years (before Burmese food got popular!), as it was close to my house, and my dad grew up in Burma so we had that connection to the type of food. It was pretty easy to get a table before but with the recent explosion of Burmese popularity there is more of a wait (not as bad as BS though)

Great customer service, nice decor, great food. I'm a fan of moo hinga and the one here is real good. Haven't found a place that wowed me with their catfish soup yet, however, as the one my aunt makes is still the best I've had. Despite, won't hesitate to get it here. Tea leaf salad is pretty good too. They seem to be the most popular dishes but everything is tasty.

For a Burmese craving minus waiting (though food isn't as good) try Little Yangon in Daly City FYI.
author: Ian C.

description: Love this place. Interesting, complex flavors at a reasonable price. Tea leaf salad is a standout. Great food in a fun, quirky environment.
author: Dee R.

description:
Good alternative to the crowded Burma Superstar.  Price is comparable, and parking is easier.

Every main dish we tried are good.  Waiter could be a bit rush to clean your table and onto the dessert, which is the only disappointing items here.
author: daphne w.

description:
Mandalay is one of my favorite restaurants in the City. I love Asian food, so Mandalay was a must try for my husband and me. The first time we went was probably two and half years ago, and we continue to go often. The owners and wait staff are really considerate and kind. The atmosphere is unique - they tend to keep up Christmas decorations all year long, which is somewhat hilarious. I must say though it's one of my favorite SF restaurants, and one where I take most our friends and loved ones. Also, as a vegetarian, there are plenty of dishes to try and almost all of them are amazing. Here's my must try list including appetizers / dishes:

Samusa Soup - Vegetarian
Hot and Sour Soup - Vegetarian
Roti Canai
Mango Tofu - not on the menu but they'll make it 
Walnut Broccoli Tofu
Mandalay Special Noodle - Vegetarian

Parking is a bit tough if you go between 6:30pm til 8pm, also you may have to wait for a table. However, the longest I've had to wait is about 30 minutes, which isn't bad if you compare it to Burma Superstar. 

Happy Eating, and hope you enjoy.
author: Vrinda S.

description: From NJ visiting Napa and on our way back to SF stopped at Mandalay for a quick bite. Amazing place to eat!!! Had the tea salad which was out of this world and the Mongolian beef. Both dishes were a good size and great. Service was fast and friendly. Can't wait to go again. Need to find a spot like this in NYC.
author: Lee D.

description:
Sometimes the stars align, and you and your best friends are all simultaneously ravenous for Burmese food mere hours after your manager (shout-out to Kat F!) told you that a place called Mandalay in your neighborhood has life-altering Burmese food.

That said, my Saturday evening was amazing.
