How this place has flown under my radar for the year I've lived in the area, I'm uncertain and mildly enraged by. But all is right in the world now because my roomies and I nearly face-planted in all the goodness that is Mandalay last weekend.

This place is warm and cozy and bustling with parties of all varieties and ages. We slipped in riiiight before the rush (around 6pm) and sat next to a fabulous couple (decidedly regulars) who were thoroughly amused by our next-level intensity/excitement/audible real-time Yelp reviews. The tea leaf salad, mango chicken, mandalay special noodle, coconut rice, and balada are all essentials bursting with unique flavors. The staff run this place like a well-oiled machine, and they were so sweet and accommodating despite the constant waves of hungry customers.   

There's nothing like sitting around a table with people you love, completely filled to the brim with content, blissed out from sharing a culinary experience that makes you thank your lucky stars your life has led up to that exact moment of simple, pure happiness.
author: Meredith C.

description: Food was amazing. Very flavorful and everything had its own distinct taste. Smiling faces made it exceptional. They were very accommodating with us as we walked in very close to their closing time .
author: Pooja A.

description:
This was the first time back here in 15 years or so. And, it's as amazing as I remember! 5 stars for decor & service, 4 stars for the food! 
The Tea Salad remains the best I've had anywhere (I can't do Burmese & not order this dish).  The Mango Shrimp was delectable! Plump, juicy shrimp sautéed with onions, chilis & FRESH mango cubes. We requested a vegetarian version of the curry which came with eggplant, cauliflower, & all kinds of great veggies in a delicious sauce. The Mandalay chicken was good, but not my favorite (maybe I needed to try it with a different protein...tasted a lot like Orange Chicken). I have no intention of waiting 15 years again to go back!
Clearly, others know this is a gem. There was a line out the door within minutes of opening the doors!

Mingalaba & other peninsula wanna-be Burmese restaurants need to come see how it's done.
author: Surita G.

description: Came on a Saturday night and it was lively and crowded, but we didn't have to wait too long before getting a table which was nice. The staff were very friendly and everything we ordered was delicious. I'd never had Burmese food before so I wasn't sure what to expect, but I really enjoyed it. The flavors reminded me of Chinese and Indian cuisine mixed together. We ended up ordering way too much food for the two of us, but our favorites were the balada (like a crispy version of naan bread with an amazing curry sauce to dip in) and the tea leaf salad that they're famous for. We could have had a filling meal with just those two dishes!
author: Kaitlyn B.

description: Wonderful experience.  We had the tea leaf salad, fried egg plant and zuchini, a red curry dish, and a couple of others. The tea salad really steals the show. The toasted garlic chips - just brillant. Cant wait to get back and have it again.
author: Marguerite S.

description:
I came here for a workplace holiday get together. They were able to accommodate over 30 people as a group. They also accommodated our white elephant gift exchange by allocating extra space and putting up with our hooting and hollering. I hope it was entertaining. 

The place was clean and well decorated, including the bathrooms. It shows that the owners really take pride in the place. 

The chicken with mango tasted both spicy and sweet/sour. I liked the combination. The tofu and pumpkin curry embodies the holiday spirit - you can really taste the pumpkin. The papaya salad was crisp and tart. While not really my cup of tea, it tasted fresh. 

Full disclosure: I'm not sure how much everything cost, as work picked it up for me. But overall, I had a good experience. I'll come back.
author: J C.

description: Small and charming restaurant. Expect to wait for a table because they are busy which only speaks the the quality of food ... completely worth any wait. Also, it you are unsure about what to try, trust your server. Every recommendation we received was excellent. The food came out with perfect timing and the service attentive without being overbearing. My friends and I enjoyed the rainbow salad, crispy chicken, kaw soi dok, balada, and Rangoon beef.
author: Megan R.

description:
Really loved the food here. The tea leaf salad was a little different from Burma Superstar and Rangoon Ruby(no romaine) with tomatoes and green chillies. Very tasty!
We ordered green beans, eggplant with tofu and rice noodles. All the dishes were delicious and the service was friendly and quick. My daughter who typically dislikes eggplant kept asking for more! Highly recommended.
author: Sara V.

description:
After eating at Burma Superstar and being unimpressed, I was told to check out Mandalay just two blocks away. YUM! Ate here on a Friday night at 9pm and still had to wait about half an hour. However, there is a small waiting area inside so you won't have to wait outside! The service here is great, everyone was super friendly and were very attentive. 

We ordered the badala with curry sauce. The badala was super flaky and delicious! It was pretty filling for an appetizer. If there are only two of you, try not to eat it all to save room for the other items!

The tea leaf salad here was really good too! They serve it without cabbage so it's on the nuttier side but still very good.

The special noodles was probably my favorite dish. So many flavors and textures!

Will definitely be back!
author: Clarice C.

description:
BETTER than Burma Superstar 

Tea Leaf Salad is amazing!!

Lunch specials are great!!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
Burmese food? More like chinese food. Finding the parking is horrible already; the waiting time is exceptionally long (I got here at 6:30pm Saturday). Despite reservation, you still have to wait for everyone to turn up to get a table 
Food was OK (not exceptional). We ordered orange chicken (mandalay chicken), curry noodle, walnut shrimp, roasted duck, rainbow salad (not good, too much peanuts), 3 bowl of rice, 2-3 drinks. Total: $130+. To me, this is a Chinese restaurant with small portion and expensive price.
author: Anh P.

description: The food was good but the service is terrible. A waitress squirted lemon juice in my eye and only say sorry and walk away. They are also very pushy to get you to order more food. I had better experience with Burmese superstar.
author: Lily J.

description:
ohhhhhhhhhhhhh romantic. I'd say the most romantic casual burmese restaurant in SF. Come here for a quiet night out with yo honey. 
Flowers at each table. I love flowers , anywhere, everywhere.

esp a flower on the table in between you and the man you adore. 
*blushes*

Food is tasty. Ordered the sweet Manadalay chicken [which is really like chinese sweet and sour pork]. I appreciate waitress telling me what it was , almost in a cautious way of "are you sure you want to order this?" I still said yes but was not expecting it to be like swt sour pork. 
Everything else was dandy. Expect a little wait. Maybe 15-30 mins
author: Veranna N.

description:
I can't believe I've never written a review for Mandalay!!! Since my mom has been working in the area for over 18 years, I pretty much grew up on their food! I was just there this past weekend too! 

In middle school and high school, I always ordered the Mandalay Chicken. Loved it! Still love it! But not til I came back from college did I really start discovering their other amazing dishes! 

For awhile my mom and I would get the balada as an appetizer every time we went, then we switched to samosas and now we always order the papaya salad. They are all amazing!!

I was obsessed with their rainbow fish and rainbow chicken! I'll eat Rainbow anything if its from Mandalay! I also love their string beans and prawns. Amazing flavor. Lately, I've been craving their Mandaly noodles, I think I'll order it this weekend! 

Even my friend who moved back to LA requested Mandalay when she came to visit!! She dreams about the rainbow dishes as well.

Get it! Get it! Get everything I mentioned, I promise it's good!
author: A b.

description:
Wow. Amazing. Spectacular. Wonderful. 

The best Burmese in a 100 mile radius. Complex flavors, friendly service and a diverse menu. There is no reason not to give the food, service and ambiance 5 stars. 

I've only been here three times but have made a resolution to try everything on the menu before Christmas 2012, wish me luck.
author: Justin S.

description:
Really awesome lunch experience! Decided to come here because of the long wait at Burma Superstar and B-Star, and really glad we did!

We had the tea leaf salad, the nan gyi dok, string beans with tofu, and basil eggplant. Being vegetarian, the server was helpful in telling us what couldn't be made without fish sauce and/or ground shrimp. The food seemed to come in an illogical manner (salad first, but then the noodles cane last, way after everything else) but the taste was so good and price so reasonable that we didn't really mind.

To drink, we had the jasmine flower tea, which is really freaking cool - we had no idea it would open up in the tea! And the burmese iced tea was good but not particularly spectacular.

Overall, great experience and I will definitely be back!
author: Rohan N.

description:
First off, AMAZING FOOD.

I've been here on many occasions (birthdays, anniversaries, etc.) and Mandalay never ceases to amaze me! My go to food are:

- Coconut Rice
- Mango Chicken
- Mandalay Special Noodle

The food remains consistent all the time, and it's good enough to bring me back! It may be a bit on the pricier side, but not too much! If anyone asks about Burmese good, I immediately recommend Mandalay!
author: Angelo M.

description: Delicious food, great atmosphere and wonderful attentive service made this a must return to restaurant. We had tea leaf salad (server mixed table-side), coconut chicken soup (server divided and served in 4 cups to share between us), and a tofu veggie dish and pumpkin pork curry served in the pumpkin. We also loved the home made ginger lemon beer!
author: B S.

description: Would like to give more stars...coming here because many good reviews and good pictures of food. But with over 590 pictures already on yelp...manager said no pictures on table! Why ? Don't understand and no sign anywhere indicate "No photo Allow" .  Over all service still pretty good. Food , as Burmanese food price is good .. Food taste ,don't think is good enough for more than 3 stars . Best dish special coconut chicken noodles and their  pan cake is good ...sorry! No pictures allowed after manager said so.
author: Betty L.

description: I'm so happy to say that this was my first meal out in SF after moving here. The food was so good. I've been here twice now and have yet to be disappointed. The tea leaf salad is like a mini show the waiter(tress) does for you explaining everything it it. All the food is good and the mango lassi is really good too from what I remember. e. The place can get crowded though. If you have a large party, you need to make sure you make a reservation and that your whole party is there. They didn't seat our party til everyone was there. That being said, super good and I really enjoyed it.
author: Julie L.

description:
First time trying Burmese food - a good experience! We couldn't get a reservation to Burma Super Star and ended up coming here instead. Parking was ridiculously difficult but pretty typical of SF, as I understand it.

Overall it was pretty similar to Thai food. The tea leaf salad was interesting, and the green papaya salad was pretty standard. The pumpkin curry came in a carved pumpkin and was pretty cool, while the seafood curry was excellent too. The curries weren't too spicy either. The salt and pepper prawn came recommended by our waiter and was quite good, and the coconut rice went well with everything! 

The drinks were interesting too, you could get fresh coconut and mango lassi. I'd definitely come back to try out more Burmese food!
author: Jonathan K.

description:
The food is just so top notch YUM!!! I have never had better burmese food than gere. I normally go to other Burmese restaurants and this is better! It's authentic stuff. The door not so great, little outdated. The service is fast; the wait on busy nights can get ridiculous.  Yes, I will drive to this busy little spot for delicious food.
My fave was the Okra, prawns and greens, coconut rice and red leaf salad. The cocktails are pretty yum too!!
author: Ana A.

description: I love the tea leaf salad and mango salad. its the best.
author: Ankita J.

description: I've eaten at two other Burmese restaurants within the SF bay area and this one takes the cake. Their Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok) is the best I've ever had. My wife and I will make a special trip to the city for this place. There is always a line, and it's totally worth the wait. Two dishes I would recommend (other than the Tea Leaf Salad) is the Moo Hin Nga (fish chowder) and Pumpkin Curry Chicken. GREAT flavors.
author: Sara D.

description:
I don't really want to write a good review for Mandalay because we love it so much and its getting so popular its hard to get a table! Really great food in an unassuming atmosphere for a great price. We haven't had much we haven't liked here, but a couple favorites are the tea leaf salad and Mandalay special noodle. 

Get the fresh coconut for a drink - when you're done you can eat the coconut for dessert!
author: Dassance R.

description: Made a reservation for 8 for 7:00pm 8/4/16. They charge $10 per person if you cancel. When you arrive, if your entire party is not there, they won't seat you. They had an empty table just waiting for us and my Mom had to stand 30 minutes on her birthday. The food was pretty sour. We had tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, house special noodles... At the end we asked for the birthday song and they forgot. Burma Superstar, B star, and Mingalaba are better choices.
author: Chris H.

description: fun experience. Group of us and we were all new to Burmese so had waiter help us pick. Everything was delicious.
author: Margaret Y.

description:
Years ago, when it wasn't as well known, I liked Mandalay quite a bit.  Although their versions of my Burma Superstar favorites could never quite compare, their food was still pretty decent.  Throw in the fact that the wait (if any) was always rather short, and they were a solid alternative to Burma.  Now that they've started to develop crowds of their own though, Mandalay has lost a bit of its shine for me.  Why did you have to get so popular?!

After not coming here for a couple of years, I somehow ended up at Mandalay twice in ten days.  Random, I know.  Between the two trips, we ordered: Mandalay Chicken, Mandalay Noodles, Ginger Salad, Samusa Soup, Chicken Samusas, Basil Beef, Rainbow Salad, Tofu Kebat, and Walnut Broccoli Chicken.  Of those, the salads were probably the best, with a slight edge to the Ginger Salad (exactly the same as Tea Leaf Salad but with ginger instead of tea leaves).  The Mandalay Noodles were really flavorful once I removed the cilantro (blech), and I thought the Walnut Broccoli Chicken was a surprising highlight considering the non-traditional ingredients.  Although it can't compare to Burma Superstar's, the Samusa Soup wasn't bad, and the Mandalay Chicken was tasty, even if it's essentially like a sesame/mandarin/orange chicken-type dish.

On the flip, the Chicken Samusas, Basil Beef, and Tofu Kebat were pretty disappointing.  The taste of the Samusa was just average, and my friend noted the one he ate was lukewarm at best in the center.  The Tofu Kebat dish was really plain overall, and it tasted pretty bland for something that's supposed to be spicy.  It wasn't nearly as disappointing as the Basil Beef though.  Seriously, they could have changed all of the ingredients and it still would have tasted the same with all that sauce they threw on there.  It's especially painful that it was the one I had ordered to share.  Whoops...haha.

Service is okay - they gave out free beer the first time while we were waiting because it was so hot out, but the second time, even though we had reservations, we ended up waiting as if we had walked in and put our names down.  With the food not being as good as I remember, and with the difference in wait time smaller than before, I think I'd rather just go to Burma Superstar and tough it out.  The time saved isn't enough to overcome the difference in food.  Sorry Mandalay, you got a little too popular for your own good.
author: Mike L.

description:
I absolutely adore the food (especially the Tea Leaf Salad) at Burma Superstar and it's sister restaurant, B Star Bar. Seeing as both those restaurants can be crowded, I wanted to experience another Burmese restaurant. 

After doing research on Yelp, I decided on Mandalay because of its positive reviews and seemingly spacious interior. However, when I arrived with my BF on Saturday, I was greeted with a stuffy atmosphere, to the point where we both had a headache standing in the waiting area. Even after we were escorted to our table, the nauseousness failed to subside because of the lack of personal space. Each table was too close to its neighbor. Seeing the popularity of the restaurant, I can see how the owners wanted to accommodate as many diners as possible. However, the strategy made for a discomforting environment. 

We ordered the following:

TEA LEAF SALAD: What I love about Burma Superstar's Tea Leaf Salad is the complexity of the flavors, how all the different ingredients add a different kick with each bite. This could not be said for Mandalay's Tea Leaf Salad. I had read online beforehand that this particular salad contained "no filter," meaning it contained no lettuce or cabbage to curb the tea leaves. However, the lack of greens gave way to another overpowering flavor: peanuts. All I could taste in the "salad" was peanuts. Highly unappetizing.   

MANDALAY SPECIAL NOODLE: Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken.
I'm not sure what I was expecting from this. I'm a sucker for anything with thick noodles so I went with the "special" on the menu. This had really little flavor besides coconut milk and salt. There was a hint of the spice from the lemongrass but,  overall, nothing memorable or "special" about this dish.

We weren't the only ones unimpressed with our meal that night. The table to my left side complained to the owner about their fish dish, calling it overcooked to the point of being inedible. The table to my right had some issues in the timing of their dishes being brought out. It appeared that they assumed the waitstaff reversed their orders and were going to bring the salad at the end of the meal, but actually forgot it altogether. 

Bottom line: I would skip this place and go to the tried and true Burma Superstar, or its equally good counterpart, B Star Bar.
author: Sophia V.

description:
This was an incredible dining experience.  Each dish was a wonder of delight.  The soup, the chicken, the salad.  I'm sorry that I don't have the exact names of the dishes, but our party of five split 5 different dishes.  Each and every one was superb.
Great and friendly service.  Make a reservation though as it gets busy.
author: Teri O.

description:
Found this place on Yelp and took my out of town family here for a dinner on a Sunday night. Really glad we made reservations. We were running 30 minute late, so we gave them a call. They were nice enough to hold the table for us even though the place was packed. 

When we got there, they were offering other guests drinks for the long wait time. The servers and hostess were all very pleasant. The only thing I would warn is that they love to up sell you on their menu items. We ended up ordering way too much food. I would probably order one less dish based on their recommendation. They also seemed disappointed that we didn't order any alcohol. 

Onto the food. It was superb. Definitely one of the better Burmese places here. My out of town family all really enjoyed it. 

Coconut rice - This is a must order like many others have mentioned. 
Chicken satay skewers - Beautifully displayed. Good sauce, but the chicken was a bit dry. 
Pumpkin curry - This was very very delicious
Eggplant - awesome and so much better than expected. Must order as well. 
Mango chicken - This was good, but was not expecting a salad. 
Tea Leaf Salad- Good, but not as good as Burma Super Star. 

Would definitely come back for a casual meal.
author: Winny F.

description:
FIRST THING FIRST...TO AVOID FURTHER GRIEF TO THOSE TRYING BURMESE FOOD FOR FIRST TIME AND HEARING ABOUT AWESOME BURMESE BEEF CURRY STEW OR LOOKING FOR THAT DISH AT THIS RESTAURANT - ORDER:

""Burmese Curry Beef"" which is really good here. (DO NOT CONFUSE with Mandalay or Rangoon beef)  Yes.... I repeat this big point again later in the review for those more critical readers and for those who need a reminder at the end.

OK..now that's out of the way....on with the review.

===============================================

Not the best, and not the worst of Bay Area Burmese fare as I continue to sniff out restaurants reminiscent of my mom's home cooking.

Portion sizes are quite small compared to some other (IMO) Burmese restaurants in the Bay, with better flavors.

These are the dishes and my thoughts:

Moo Hin Nga (fish Chowder)  - broth is quite decent. what's with the lack of noodles... which is the way it's traditionally served.

Ong No Kaw Soi (coconut Chicken Noodle Soup) - broth was flatand doesn't have the traditional complex flavor of home cooked recipe. Again, no noodles in a dish traditionally served with noodles.

Tea Leaf Sald (Lap Pat Dok) - agree with other reviews that it is slim on the portion and missing the thinly sliced cabbage to compliment the texture of this hallmark dish

Green Papaya Salad - Not bad, just missing that je ne sais quoi compared to home and other BA Burmese restaurants.

Burmese Style Noodle (kaw Soi Dok) - again, the same as green papaya salad not bad but I've had better...the combination and proportion of ingredients is just as important as the ingredients themselves...and they miss it here.

Burmese Curry Beef (DO NOT CONFUSE WITH MANDALAY OR RANGOON BEEF) - the traditional burmese beef curry stew if that is what you are specifically looking for - we had to ask the owner to make sure it was  what we wanted...phonetically spelled "Ah me tha si pyan."  Home run here!  With a little more dry chili pepper, it was perfect!
NOTE*** they have 3 dishes that could be mistaken for the traditional burmese beef curry stew, THIS IS THE ONE YOU WANT - not Mandalay or Rangoon beef.

May come back if having a craving and in SF, but prefer my go-to restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Eddo C.

description: Today was my first time having lunch at Mandalay. My friend and I arrived right at 11:30am thinking we can beat the lunch crowd but we were told the restaurant won't be open until noon. Luckily we were not pressed for time and waited sipping coffee at a nearby coffee shop. I wanted to try the tea salad after hearing that it was comparable to Burma Superstar which I love. We ordered the Mandalay noodles, tea salad, and curry chicken. The noodles were a bit on the bland side but the tea salad and the curry chicken were delicious. Will certainly go back to try the other specialty dishes.
author: Katie L.

description:
Excellent food! Great service. Seating a bit close for comfort. Terrible parking. I'd definitely eat here again, but I'd look for a time without the rush. But that shouldn't keep anyone from eating here.

Tea leaf salad (no shrimp)
Coconut rice
Walnut Broccoli Tofu
Sautéed Spinach with garlic
Mandalay Special Noodle with Tofu
author: Jamal S.

description:
Not as uber amazing as it was made out to be on Check Please but still enjoyable. 3.5 stars but I'm rounding up.

Balada w/ Curry Sauce - Good not great. I really liked the curry sauce.

Mandalay Chicken - Your typical deep fried sweet sauce chicken w/ rice. Good not great. Decent sized portion and plenty to take home.

Samusa Salad - Very good. A little special and different than your run of the mill appies.

Mandalay Noodles - Good not great. Portion was good enough for dinner. Not enough to bring home for lunch the next day. Flavor was good. Reminded me of coconut curry noodles.

Dinner with soft drinks, tax and tip was around $50. 

Service was hit or miss but always friendly. There didn't seem to be enough servers. It took awhile to get our order in. And it took awhile to get our check - which probably effects the long wait for those waiting for a table. Table side mixing for the Mandalay Noodles. 

A little out of the way for me but I'd return. I definitely prefer Mandalay over Burma Superstar which I think its overpriced.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
I know it's going to appear like I'm obsessed with Burmese food, but considering the fact that I went to Mandalay two nights in a row maybe that appearance isn't totally inaccurate.

All the deliciousness of Burmese food plus the bonus of being able to make reservations makes this restaurant a great option for getting your Burmese fix. Be sure you make that reservation in advance! The line is nothing to be scoffed at if you just attempt walking in.

Top of list orders here - tea leaf salad, dry fried string beans, Burmese cooler (lemons + beer + ginger = delightful), samosa soup, and in my opinion the Mandalay special noodles are the the best in town.

One note (no stars added or subtracted) is that the place seems to be perpetually decorated for Christmas.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
This is one of my brothers go-to spots for Burmese/Chinese food in the city. He recommended the Tea leaf salad but I got the chicken Samosas instead. It was really good with their special sweet and sour type sauce. I will definitely try the Tea leaf salad next time though. We also got the Mandalay beef which just tasted like deep fried batter so I didn't really like it. And of course, we got friend rice as our base and it was good. Can't really go wrong with fried rice.The (alcoholic) ginger lemonade was amazing!  It has a refreshing taste and it's similar to a mojito since it has mint leaves in it as well. 

What was strange was that I was taking pictures of my samosa and the waitress came up to me and told me that pictures aren't allowed. I was a little taken aback since there was a proud Yelp sign at the front of the store so I thought they would be accepting to pictures and reviewers. She might've felt bad afterwards though because afterwards she brought us free mango desserts.

Overall, great experience and the inside decor is cute.
author: Serena H.

description: Have been going here to Mandalay Burmese Restaurant for years and referring friends also for many years.  Food is consistently excellent,  as well as their service.  Highly recommended Burmese restaurant in the San Francisco Bay area.
author: R H.

description: I love this place! My first time eating Burmese food and it was amazing! I had the Tea Leaf Salad, super nutty and garlicky with flavors I have never had before. The Rainbow salad with 20 ingredients was also really yummy! We got the Balada which was a naan like bread with curry sauce, very tasty, too! The Mandalay Special Noodle had a coconut milk sauce with wonderful and interesting flavors. We also had this spicy and sweet fried chicken wings with a cucumber salad, I don't remember what it was called, it was good! I will be back on my next trip to San Fransisco! Must-try!
author: Cara H.

description: Was on a time crunch and our favorite Burmese place was closed between lunch and dinner so we decided to stop by here.  We had the tea leaf salad which was good but not great.  We tried to take a picture of the salad and was immediately scolded saying we could not take pictures of anything.  I have never had this happen to me at a restaurant before.  Thought that was kind of odd and it definitely threw off the mood for the rest of our meal.  Everything I had was very lackluster, nothing was terrible, but nothing captivated me either.  I really wanted to like this place more, but I can't ever see myself craving anything here, except for maybe the zero wait, instant sit down.  But then again, there are reasons why there is never any wait here....
author: N. Danny S.

description:
I just happen to be in the area and starving and came across Mandalay.  It has pretty decent yelp reviews so we decided to give it a whirl.  

We were seated and the restaurant was pretty full for a Sunday lunch.  I immediately knew I wanted the tea leaf salad and we also chose the baladi and #1 entree under the noodle dish (forgot the name).  We flagged down the waitress and we ordered and waited. 

I was under the impression that the baladi and salad would be brought out together or at least timing wise to each other.  No that didn't happen here.  Salad out first and after we completely finish it they brought out the baladi.  Fine.  For 2 ppl the baladi is very filling (dough is thicker than most and pretty greasy).. I was waiting and waiting for the noodle dish so I could fill up on something else...and it just never came.  We finished the entire baladi and was so full we decided to tell the staff to box up our food.  As soon as we made that decision the noodle dish hit our table.  We immediately had it boxed and asked for the check.  

Overall I thought the food was good however the timing of the dishes were very slow.  I did think the dishes were a little on the pricey side as well.
author: Julie F.

description:
I have been wanting to go to Burma Superstar for a LONG time but the wait was just not appealing to me, I have heard good things about Mandalay so we gave it a try!  It was a cold rainy saturday evening, parking was not too bad, we were seated right away.  The staff is attentive and professional, the decor was pleasant! 

We had the following:
Appetizers:
Balada, very greasy and will NOT order again, the curry dipping sauce was good.

Tea Leaf Salad, I should have taken a pic before the waitress did her little table side presentation, it looked pretty nasty after she mixed it up but it was DELICIOUS, not sure we will get it again unless we are with more people to share, a little goes a long way as its rather oily

Main course:

Mandalay Special Noodle, OMG amazing!!! I was the winner of tonights meal choice, fresh and delicious...I highly recommend this dish, noodles were cooked perfectly and the addition at the table of lemon and cilantro added a ton of fresh flavor to the dish..LOVE

Prawn Curry, hubby did not fare so well...The curry flavor was "ok" but the prawns were overcooked and some still had the shells on, he was not pleased and tried to steal my Mandalay Special Noodle..HAHA

Overall the meal was good, we will go back again and perhaps I will up the rating a star or two...
author: Linda N.

description: First time trying Burmese food and I wasn't disappointed. Everything tasted so fresh and delicious. The tea leaf salad was effing amazing! The service was awesome as well. The staff was very friendly. I'll definitely come back the next time I'm in the city. Bring your friends!
author: Martin D.

description:
Some of our friends had recommended this place to us and we decided to give it a try since we've enjoyed the Burmese food we've had at Burma Superstar and at Minglalaba in Burlingame.  We ordered the tea leaf salad, mango chicken, and the Mandalay Special Noodles.

The tea leaf salad was okay...  the one at Burma Superstar is definitely the standard, in our opinion.  This one had a lot of nuts and was very crunchy.  So crunchy, in fact, that my jaw was literally tired from the crunch and I had to take a break from eating it.  Mango chicken was okay as well, but I do like this dish better at both places I mentioned.  The Mandalay Special Noodle was the big winner for us here, I loved the taste, textures, and flavor.  I'd definitely recommend this dish to my friends!  Bonus for the mango pudding at the end of our dinner.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Wow wrote my name on the list & was never called. They replaced the old list with a new list and started crossing names off like they totally forgot about us. Not only that but they offered to bring us drinks while we waited and then never followed through! Somehow they remembered to bring drinks for the patrons sitting next to us though. Really irritating that I've been sitting here for 57 minutes & counting without any acknowledgment that we've been waiting here far longer than anybody else that's next to us!! Will update if I ever get seated, I'm sure the food is great but I guess I'll never know because as far as this place is concerned I guess we don't even exist.

Edit: They apologized for losing our name which is understandable in a place as busy as this. However they still completely forgot to even bring my girlfriends order. Everyone had already finished their meals by the time someone even checked in on us and was alerted to the fact that we were charged for a dish that never actually made it to our table.
author: Dash Y.

description: Not a fan. My overall experience is...flavors were ok, but I've had better. My friend and I passed by Mandalay a couple of times, so thought I'd try it. First of all, they don't seat you until your entire party has arrived, which I think is fair. We tried a couple of items: tea leaf salad, mandalay beef, coconut curry shrimp, and coconut rice. Tea leaf salad had nice flavors, maybe too much peanuts. I wish they had put some leafy greens in the salad to balance the abundance of nuts in the dish. It felt like eating a dish of tea flavored trail mix. Maybe that's how it's suppose to be, but I prefer some iceburg or something. Anyway moving on. The Mandalay beef tasted like szechuan beef to me. For a signature dish, I was expecting  it to standout. But all I can think of was why it tasted like szechuan beef?  I would much prefer to go to my favorite Chinese restaurant for that. The curry shrimp was not memorable. The shrimp was overcooked. The shrimp portion was laughable. It was petty French portion, but unlike a French meal where you know you have 3-5 courses to follow, you only get your overcooked curry shrimp. Service was fine until towards the end of the meal. Four servers came within a span of 10 mins to ask if we were done. I understand that they want to turn over tables quickly, but we were not done eating. It made us feel rushed.  Overall, I've had better food elsewhere, and portions were small. I felt extremely unsatisfied after my meal.
author: Katzi H.

description:
My favorite Burmese restaurant in the city: the waits are not as crazy as the other places and the food has always been deliciously dependable.

My favorite (and therefore always ordered) items:
1.  Rainbow Salad: there are twenty ingredients in this thing, and together they make a divine dish.  I could eat this for a meal alone if it were just me.
2.  Mandalay Special Noodle:  normally I'm not a huge coconut fan, but it works in this dish.  The cooked noodles and the crunchy noodles complement each other in texture, and the chicken is always tender and nicely flavored.  
3.  Mango chicken:  the sauce on the chicken is so delicious.  The mango chunks aren't always the sweetest, but that's not always a bad thing given it's a savory dish.
4.  Dry pan-fried string beans with tofu: just get them.  Seriously.
5.  Also have tried the tea leaf salad, which is also good, but I still prefer the rainbow salad.  Will order if I want to change it up.

True, the portions do leave something to be desired, but I suppose it prevents me from eating too much to the point of bursting.
author: Can C.

description: This place is so much better than Burma Super Star.  My boyfriend and I wanted Burmese but the lines to get in were too long.  So we decided to go to Mandalay several blocks away because we've heard such good things about this place.  I'm so glad we decided to check it out despite a line of people waiting inside.  The wait wasn't so bad and we were seated in 15 minutes.  The Tea Leaf Salad was excellent and I loved their Special Noodles.  It's a mild coconut curry with chicken and flat noodles and topped with crispy thin noodles.  It was sooo good.  I had a party in my mouth with every bite I took.  Mandalay is now my go-to place!  But shhhhhh.  I don't need the lines to get as long as Burma Super Star.
author: Christine C.

description: You can't help but love this place. The staff is ultra -friendly. The food is great, but, be prepared for the bright yellow and green front. Green Bay Pscker fans would love it here. Try the tea leaf salad. You won't be disappointed.
author: John H.

description:
Delicious Burmese food! We had the Mandalay Special Noodles and the Burmese Style Curry. Both very flavorful and fragrant. I really loved the special noodles in particular. Lemon-y and coconut goodness and all those fried onions are perfect! I can't wait to come back for more!

Mandalay is also very open and although it gets crowded you are not squished in with everyone else. Burma Superstar is great but here you also get yummy food without feeling rushed.
author: Jaclyn N.

description:
Lemon Ginger Beer: 2 stars tasty but too sweet
Roti with curry dipping sauce (Badalada): 3.5 stars curry sauce good but Roti would have been better with whole wheat flour
Tea Leaf Salad: 4 stars fried garlic and peanuts provided a nice crunch
Mango Chicken: 3 stars tasty standard southeast Asian mango chicken
Black sticky rice with coconut ice cream: 4 stars sticky rice is always a treat but too much ice cream
author: Mary R.

description:
This place is great for food quality, authenticity, hospitality and atmosphere/location. Five STARS. Only reason I put 4 is due to their small space and inability to host larger groups over 6. Their tables are small and bench seating they try to make into long table seats for large groups but the tables are too narrow and we ended up with plates and silver wear on our laps to make room for the food. If you come here as a couple or small group YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED! If it's your birthday they will scoop you some coconut ice cream and throw on the birthday song. lol. So funny.

I am from Mayanmar, the Karen tribe (not Burmese tribe) but "Burmese food" is actually Mayanmar food and the 12 major tribes all eat similar diets that you may sample when you go to Mandalay. Mandalay is the oldest and first Mayanmar restaurant in the U.S. and they live up to their expectations of being the best by far in comparison to all other Mayanmar eateries.

Go with a small group Maximum 8, make a reservation and request the round table if you are a party of 6-8. Have fun and enjoy! When we go as a couple we usually end up paying around $50 with tip. Pretty good value for the price of the location and ingredients some of the dishes require.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
Went here last night with my mom (yes I still take my mom out and enjoy her company). It was my first time here and will definitely not be my last. Once inside their double doors the aromas hit you as you amble by other tables filled with colorful, mouthwatering dishes and elaborately decorated walls. It feels warm and intimate while being extravagantly ornamented. 

We were seated in the back next to a couple who had two tables filled with what seemed like everything on the menu. No joke and we figured they were reviewers, which they were. They were scouting locations for their latest show and Mandalay would be featured. Why? According to them - the amazing food, the gracious service (which is fantastic), and the decorations which feature Burmese jewelry, tapestries, and ornate paintings. Their picks:

-Mango Chicken
-Tea Leaf Salad ( Not so much a salad as a nut explosion) 
-Mandalay Special Noodles (which we had and was amazing)

Add to that, our dinner consisted of specials and classics: 

-Lychee Coconut Prawns (Lightly sweet and in a delicious coconut curry sauce)
-Shaking Duck (Amazing though not traditional, more fusion style)

Have the coconut infused rice and the Mandalay Cooler, a ginger and mint beer that is so refreshing and cooling paired with their spicier dishes.

Finish off with the Paluda, a rose flavored ice cream sundae filled with tapioca, jelly, and coconut strings. Amazing and flavorful way to end your meal, if you have room that is! 

They are the oldest Burmese restaurant in the country, 28 years and counting (according to the couple next to us), and it's no surprise that they have flourished this long as MANDALAY is an exceptional experience.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
Maybe worth a visit for the relative novelty, but overall a disappointment.

Tea Leaf Salad: Too heavy on lentils, sesame seeds, and peanuts and too light on tea leaves. Couple that with too little acidity and it tasted like eating a bag of corn nuts.

Balada: Oily pancake tasted like it had been sitting out for a while. Not good.

Mandalay Special Noodles: I enjoyed the flat noodles and the creamy coconut chicken, but the dish was too oily.

Rangoon Beef: Probably the highlight of the meal. Nice little cuts of beef in a spicy-sweet stir-fry sauce. Goes well with the coconut rice.

Perhaps the kitchen was having an off night, but I didn't think Mandalay was worth the wait.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Very good food and the nice interior, adds to a relaxed, laid back feeling.  Their bathrooms were clean and the sink area looked pretty fancy.  The servers here were pleasant and came by regularly to fill our glasses with water.  

Friend and I shared the Tea Leaf Salad and the Nan Gyi Dok and both dishes were excellent.  I heard from someone I know who is Burmese how the Tea Leaf Salad is a signature Burmese dish, so I really wanted to try that out and I'm happy that I did - I don't think I've eaten anything like it before, but I really liked it.  The Nan Gyi Dok was absolutely delicious!  I loved all the ingredients that made up those two and to have the server mix up everything in front of you was also nice!  This was my first time eating Burmese food and I'm glad I finally discovered how good it is!
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
I really want to give 3 1/2 stars!  :)    The slight lowering of my previous rating has to do with the service only.  The food is still 5 stars, the sauces full of flavor and sometimes rich; all flavors blending as one beautiful medley of deliciousness!  HA!  
ATE: ~  app. ~  BALADA :   Crispy pancakes with curry sauce were slightly crispy and nice and                         
                         soft....along with their rich, slightly chunky curry dipping sauce, heaven.  ****

entrees ~ TEA LEAF SALAD :  Oooh baby!  A MUST eat here.  They do it the 
             traditional way, which does not include lettuce. The flavor, rich, intense, delish!                                                                                                                                                                                                   The texture is just as fine, with several levels of crunchy, a dense and a light crunch.  Oh my. ***** (prepared at table)
             ~ BURMESE STYLE NOODLE :  I think this is what my friend ordered.  It 
                   looked amaaazing, and she said it was a party in her mouth. *****
              ~ BASIL "LAMB" :  This has lovely thin ginger strips which really accentuates
                   the sauce, which is rich and fab.  Unfortunately, I believe they made a mistake and       gave me beef, instead of the lamb I ordered; still delish.  ****

~~drinks~~ GINGER LEMONADE: Fabulous flavor, not too sweet, with an extra punch of
                        ginger. Comes decorated with fruit and an umbrella.****
                   FLOWER TEA? : Not sure of the name, can't find it on their online menu..
                       Gorgeous....it's one of those tea balls that slowly bloom in a wine glass. ****

So, it's really the service that has changed.  We were there fairly early, 5:45, and the place was about 2/3 full.  The hostess? (the older lady) spent a long time with the table next to us, yet hurried us a bit, not giving us all the same information.  There seems to be many more waitresses than before, all seemed not happy or sad to serve us...indifferent.  The number of waitresses also caused some confusion, when we asked for something we would then have to tell another waitress the same thing a couple of minutes later.  Sometimes, even with all these waitresses, my friend had to gently wave at someone to get their attention, which took a while.  Oddly enough, it also took a long time for someone to take our order.  There was one super sweet smiling young man who came to our table twice, he was the best, I wish he had been our waiter the entire time.  I think this is one aspect they need to change, as one does not like to feel rushed (especially when arriving so early!), or have to repeat the same thing several times, or get beef when ordering lamb, even though it was still delicious.  Their food is always amazing, yet if their new style of service continues, we will have to stick with Pagan in the future; which also has amazing food.  We'll see.
author: Delicious B.

description:
I was really, truly hoping that I could say this place was worth the wait. But, after a 45 minute wait, standing in the doorway having people walk into you to get through, I can't say that Mandalay was worth it.

I did everything right. I followed Yelp and got the most popular items.

- Tea Leaf salad - more like peanut salad. All I could taste was peanuts! The peanuts were definitely overpowering, and unfortunately claimed the dish in a not so good way. Yes, it was interesting and I'm glad I tried it, but way too many peanuts!

- Balada - definitely the star of the meal. A pancake like dish served with curry dipping sauce. So good! SO DAMN GOOD. But this was just the appetizer. And to say the appetizer is the best part of the meal, doesn't say much about what's coming.

- Mango chicken - surprisingly bland. It did not have much flavor for my liking. Thank goodness there were spices they put on the table beforehand. I slaughtered the mango chicken with the spices and this did improve the dish. However, it still was a disappointing dish.

At the end of the meal, we get our check and a "no rush, but there are people with reservations waiting." Hmm, really?! Well we waited for 45 minutes! That was a bit rude I thought.

Mandalay - not worth the wait and doesn't live up to the hype. Balada is great though!
author: Junel S.

description:
Finally, an authentic Burmese restaurant and one that is waaaay better than over-hyped Burma Superstar!  There's even a shrine to Buddha inside!  My bf and his family are Burmese and the fact that they instantly approved this place (and the fact that my bf discredits Burma Superstar) says something.  The bf's parentals did all the ordering and everything but the curry was so yummy and filling! 

Tea Leaf Salad:  They bring it out with all the ingredients separated on a plate and they then mix everything right in front of you.  I definitely liked the tea leaf salad here more than at Burma Superstar.  BUT I must say it is not the best I've ever had (Yamo's is better).  Still, it is worth trying here.

Nga Pe Dok (Burmese Style Fish Cake Salad):  This was my favorite salad.  It can be quite overwhelming to some though because of the heavy use of onions but I really enjoyed the mix of veggies with the dressing and fish cake.

Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup:  Another popular Burmese dish and damn good  (but it's not as good as my bf's mama's).  It was creamy and so flavorful.

Catfish Chowder:  Once again, not as good as my bf's mama's but it was, for restaurant's standards, very tasty and hearty.

Burmese Curry Lamb:  I wasn't a big fan of this dish because the lamb didn't taste like lamb.

Burmese Curry Prawn:  I did not like this dish.  I did not like this dish at all.  Mainly because I'm not a fan of herbal curry - I like mine with a dash of coconut and with less spices just because curry in itself is already very much full of spices. And it was a very small dish.

We had most of our dishes accompanied with Coconut Rice, which is my favorite rice ever!  I really enjoyed the coconut rice at Burma Superstar which, and I hate to admit this, was better than Mandalay's just because Mandalay's was a bit gooey.  But it had a very strong and refreshing coconut taste.  YUM!

Overall, very worthwhile experience and you don't have to wait a day and a half for a table.
author: Linh V.

description: Food is really good..it really is. Almost as good as Burma superstar over on clement street but their customer service is unacceptable. My boyfriend went crazy here because he was straight up disrespected and we waited for our food for almost an hour!!! Everyone who came after us got their dishes but we didn't. When he had asked where our dishes were she said hold on, walked to serve someone else their dish and walked all the way around to avoid my bf. When she came back out, he was furious lol. She didn't even know what to say, by the time the food came out we already had to leave so we cancelled our dishes. Probably won't be coming back here.  Terrible terrible service. Please get it together
author: Colette P.

description:
I don't understand why all-things Burmese is getting so much attention... even average restaurants (like this one) are stacked with people raving about their greatness.

Overall was okay...solid three stars.  Not really worth going out of the way for, but worth going if your nearby and if there's no wait.

The quality of the noodles is pretty good...but the Curry Beef fell a bit short...was nothing great.

The Parata Bread appetizer was good but it was the curry dipping sauce that made the dish.
author: Zoran L.

description: The food is exquisite. There's a reason why there's always a line here. Only an abnormal person with abnormal taste buds would not love the food here. The majority of human beings should love the food here.
author: Marcel S.

description:
I was disappointed with our dinner.  Tea leaf salad had way too many peanuts and not enough tea leaves.  It was lacking in flavor.  We've also had the tea leaf salad at Burma Superstar and think it's much better.   The flavors are more complicated.

My dish, #2 on the noodle menu, was greasy and lacking in flavor.  My friend ordered The Burmese Chicken Curry with potatoes and liked it.  We shared samosas and they were good.

The waiters were annoying by wanting to take away dishes before we were finished.  My friend was grabbing things off of the plate as they took them away.  The also took the sauce away before we were finished with out appetizer.

Won't likely be be back.
author: Cynthia R.

description:
Although we had reservation, we had to wait for everyone to show up to get a table. We were 11! how could we be there at the same time? It wasn't a rush hour, there was no line! Our table was empty all time while waiting for our friends. What a stupid rule!!!!!!
Also lady dealing with us was soooo rude!!!
author: Zel G.

description:
I would say my first review here would have been a 4 out of 5 stars...great food, good service, large portions!!

This was my second visit and I felt that although the service was " nice " it was ungenuine :( I had a male server tell me he would be helping me and didn't check on me at all until I had gotten my check and asked him to bring me water. He took our order and tried to get me and my friend to get drinks even though we said 5...yes five times that a water was fine. That sort of rubbed me the wrong way.

The noodle portions were small and then came out after I was 2/3rds done with my chicken :(

I may come back but definitely a let down for tonight. First visit was great and I couldn't wait to be back! Oh well, we shall see!


** Everyone that worked there were speaking to each other in chinese/mandarin and maybe that made me a bit sad because in my head I was thinking " oh another Burmese/Mandarin restaurant....that really is just a Mandarin restaurant ".. The mandalay chicken ( got the mango mandalay last time...which in my opinion is better than the mandalay but wasn't mind blowing ) was sort of like a sesame chicken/general chao/tsao ... I'm just so darn sad about my experience! I was so excited to find a new place :'(
author: Selina W.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in any city. Today, after waiting 5 years to return to this place, we had lunch, before even checking in to our hotel. Did not disappoint. Rainbow salad , green beens, mango chicken all A+. This place is a must. Same owner still serving the customers from 15 years ago when I lived nearby.
author: James M.

description: Tea leaf salad. It's been over a year since I ate there? I still think about the tea leaf salad. I miss it all the way from Seattle.
author: Daljit S.

description:
Lunch is the way to go if you want to come here. There is seriously no wait and you will have a better experience than trying to grab a table during dinnertime. (Even with reservations, it could take an extra 20-30 minute wait if everyone in your party has not showed up). Every time I come here though, I must order:

1. Balada - OH SHOOOO GOOD. I love the curry dipping sauce and the crispy softness of this dish. Perfect appetizer!
2. The rainbow salad - More like a noodle salad dish. Simply delicious and light! Compliments the next dish....
3. The Mandalay Special Noodles - THIS IS WHAT YOU MUST GET. The flavors kind of remind me of the SILVER PACKAGED MAMA NOODLES but I loveee that shit so this dish was heaven to me.

I also really like the hot tea. I wanted to take the package out of the tea pot to see what kind of brand it was but I didn't. Next time, I'll just ask :)

Overall, I hate the parking. I hate the wait at dinner time. But I LOVE THEIR FOOD!
author: Betty P.

description:
Wow!  I think I've been going to Mandalay for almost 20 years now.  I thought I should give them a review.  Well, what to say?  Thanks, for always being there, I guess.

My family and I have seen this restaurant transform from just a plain restaurant to one of the best restaurants in SF, in my opinion.  I am still crazy about their PAN FRIED STRING BEANS and MANDALAY PORK.  A lot of changes have occurred here since I first came, mostly decorative, but the staple that keeps this restaurant together is the quality in their food.

I hope there is another 20 years of me coming to Mandalay.  It's like growing up with a childhood friend.  As time passes by, you grow apart, and on the outside noticeable changes occur, but on the inside they are still that same friend you enjoyed and revel being around, that same friend you've known all your life.
author: Jules S.

description:
Meet the best alternative to Burma Super Star... without the crazy wait. The Mango Chicken is a must have. The Balada was also nice and filling. Brown rice was a little dry and the Burmese Iced Tea wasn't so great. Service was nice and friendly.

The next time we crave for Burmese - we know where we are headed!
author: Anwar H.

description:
First of all, the service here is so amazing. It's not a hit or miss, it's consistent good service. Can't be mad about that.

We ordered the:
Tea leaf salad
Balada
Basil prawns
Mandalay special dinner

All the dishes were good. You can't go wrong with the Balada, one of my favorites. Will be going back soon. Sangria wasn't bad either :)
author: Denise L.

description:
Still like my original order

Balada is great - like Chinese pancake

Tea duck was ok - like Peking duck

The fried string beans can be ordered with seafood - this is awesome 

I also got Mandalay lamb...which was like orange chicken crispy batter but with lamb - wouldn't order this again because the concept / texture was weird for me - reminded me of orange chicken
author: Julia L.

description:
I came here with my sisters on a cloudy Saturday evening. We were seated right away and greeted with warm smiles and open arms. Prior to arriving to the restaurant we had already decided what to order based off of previous yelp reviews. Haha! So it took a while for the waiter to get to our table, which was weird since the restaurant wasn't even half full and there were at least 6-7 servers.
   Balada- This is your typical Asian style pan fried pancake. It was savory and crispy and all around oily goodness. It came with a coconut curry dipping sauce that was a bit milder than what I'm used to. This is definitely a heavier appetizer dish.
  Tea leaf salad- The salad had a nice presentation and a generous amount of roasted tea leaf. However, the strong flavors from the nuts and tea leaf were a bit overwhelming since I'm accustomed to there being lettuce in tea leaf salad. The flavors competed instead of compliment each other. 
  The specialty Mandalay noodles- Noodles were drenched in a chicken curry sauce and topped with fried noodles( tasted like ramen). Haha! The dish was super heavy and is def. more than enough for 2-3 people. I would advise to share this since it gets tiring really fast. 
  Rainbow prawn- Let me start off by saying that these were not prawns and only had a meager amount in the dish! I was really disappointed in this dish since I was expecting big pink prawns! The dish was just a typical veggie stir fry with a pile of over cooked and burnt shrimp on top! Def. no no!!!
  Burmese style chicken curry- The chicken was dry and the curry lacked flavor! For goodness sake the potatoes were still hard and absorbed none of the curry "flavor". Definitely not worth it! 
  The drinks- Between the three of us, my sisters and I ordered a mango lassi, ginger lemonade and fresh young coconut juice. The drinks were def. the saving grace of the meal! This is rather disappointing since we expected a meal up to par with its competitor- Burma Superstar. Despite the hour and a half wait for Burma Superstar, I would much rather go there for an impeccable meal than to endure a mediocre one here!!
author: Celina C.

description:
Great tea leaf salad, mango salad too! The Samosa soup is spicy, good during cold weather.
Mango sticky rice is good for dessert!
author: Katie P.

description: We ordered food to go on Friday night and it was fantastic.  Super quick pickup time despite the restaurant being completely packed when I arrived to pick it up.  We had pumpkin chicken curry, coconut rice, and Burmese noodles.  All three things were really delicious.
author: Chris A.

description:
Mmmm...Burmese food. 
-Yamo's: hole-in-the-wall and oh-so good. (http://www.yelp.com/biz/yamo-san-francisco) 
-Burma Superstar: Haven't tried but heard its not worth the wait.

Mandalay~

Spacious and inviting. The decor adds character to this restaurant.

Satay skewer platter: 2 stars (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=YeWh8RTucz71Ise417MkCA) Skewers a bit dry and flavorless. The dipping sauce also lacked flavor.

Tea leaf salad: 5 stars (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=BQpKb9fP11vm_UfMKJAp-g) It's easy to see why they mix the salad at the table. The salad looks like crap post-mixing. We still hesitated to try even though we saw it mixed. Imagine if it was brought out like that, no one would've touched it. It was really good though! Crunchy, spicy, pungent with tea flavor. Different because the tea leaf is a paste, unlike Yamo's which is served dried.

Pan fried string beans: 4 stars (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=qCU2uF8nxbJF-ZrTgtkOqA) Right amount of spices. Right amount of crunchiness. Yummy!

Mango chicken: 4 stars (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=t0RwHcGaCt4cc5AiOFiQjg) Mangos were sweet and ripe. Chicken cooked perfectly. A surprisingly well done combination.

Curry beef: 5 stars (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=2ZhX3aGrr7F-6XHaDJR-9g) The beef is soooo tender. The curry had the right amount of kick, but didn't overpower the beef. Mmmmm...

Mandalay chicken: 3 stars (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=oM-Oexnxny9RRsIaUzZQdg) It tasted just like sweet and sour chicken. Not a big fan of sweet and sour stuff. But the chicken did have a nice crispy exterior.

Coconut rice: 5+ stars. Soooo goood! I believe it is cooked in coconut milk. The rice is soft and has a sweet taste. Very fragrant too! It works well with any dishes.

Although a bit pricey for the amount of food given, the food was enjoyable.
author: Marti L.

description:
My bf and I took a weekend trip to SF and we wanted to try this place out after reading the reviews, but really wished we went somewhere else. The wait was long and the food wasn't as good as what we had expected. 

The rainbow salad and the samusa soup were okay. It was a bit salty for my taste. The mango chicken was nothing special, it tasted like something you could get at Panda Express. 

One good thing was the Ginger-lemon beer, that was refreshing.
author: Carrie T.

description:
Dare I say it? I think I will. This place is as good as, if not better than, Burma Superstar.

There, I said it! 

I've been here twice in the last month, once for lunch and once for dinner.  The dishes are flavorful, the servers are friendly, and the decor is super fun!

I've loved everything I tried here!  Some highlights: 

+ The tea leaf salad is wonderful, with many different colors and flavors and textures mixed all together beautifully.  First they bring you the dish with all the ingredients separated, describe to you the different pieces, and mix it all up at your table.  I love that kind of tableside service, and it all tastes so good!  Very fresh, indeed.  Note: you can get it with or without lettuce.

+ Spicy okra prawns: WOW. Just, wow! The okra is crunchy, and the shrimp are plump and cooked very well. That spicy flavoring is AMAZING. It's just spicy enough to give the dish a kick, but not so much that it's uncomfortable. The okra is crunchy, but in a good way because it complements the softer shrimp. Do get this dish, as it is DELICIOUS.  I'm generally not a fan of shrimp or spicy foods, but this converted me!  

+ Mandalay special noodles: VERY coconuty, and hearty pieces of chicken. The cilantro was pretty strong too, but I liked that.  There was a pretty mild yellow curry, balanced with the sweetness and nuttiness of the coconut, and I think there was just a touch of spice somewhere in there.  Add some cilantro for that extra hint of freshness, and some fried noodles on top for some crispiness, and you've got yourself a dish that was, in my opinion, balanced in color, flavor and taste, and texture.  Do get this!

+ Nan gyi duk: Also very highly recommended!  These round spaghetti-like Burmese rice noodles have a very special texture that I'll describe as "bounce" in your mouth.  It's a combination of slippery and chewy, and feel firm, solid, and satisfying in texture when you bite down.  The coconut chicken is creamy and light, and the fried noodles are a nice touch.  There is a healthy amount of cilantro in this dish, which I love.  This dish is similar in taste to the Mandalay noodles, except the noodles are round and "bouncier" and has less of a coconut flavor than the former.  Delicious.

For most dishes that have many ingredients, the servers come and introduce the dish to you tableside, name all the ingredients, and then mix it up.  That is awesome.  The service is also quick, and dishes came out at a good pace.  If you come for dinner, they also give you a complementary sweet and tasty mango pudding after your meal.  Very cute.

I must also give another point for the decor - it looks like perpetual Christmas in there, with all those ornaments hanging from the ceiling! There are also fresh flowers on every table, a very nice touch.  When I came here early for lunch, we actually saw the owner (?) coming out and changing the flowers from the vases at the tables.  Fresh flowers.  Love it. 

Prices are decent too, ranging from $8-10 for most entrees, and $10 and up for seafood dishes.  When I came for dinner, we each got a young coconut juice (which comes in a real coconut!), an appetizer and two entrees, and the total after tax and tip and Healthy SF was $25/person.  When I came for lunch, we ordered two entrees and the total was $13/person total. 

Next time you're in the area, be sure to drop by.  Completely delicious.  The prices are decent, service is good, the food is fantastic, and best of all, unlike the more well-known Burma Superstar, you won't have to wait 45 minutes for a table!
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place is so underrated at 4 stars. I never had such great service and food in once place. My friend Cory told me that Mandalay is better than that other Burmese restaurant and I was pretty skeptical until I tried it for the first time.

We had the rainbow salad which was done perfectly. I ordered Basil Beef, Raul got the Sizzling lamb and Cory got her tofu green bean dish. I had a bit of everyone's food and paired with their HOMEMADE chili seasoning/sauce/oil concoction, I was so good to go. Well seasoned, well cut, and completely perfect. It felt like a mom and pop restaurant, yet adorned beautifully with artwork. 

The service is amazing. Never have I stepped into an Asian restaurant where I thought the service was amazing. I don't think I ever had my water ever go down for less than minute before it was refilled. We were constantly checked and even given complimentary dessert. The staff are friendly, kind and warm. I felt transported back to Southeast Asia. Ah, my people.

If you have to choose between that other burmese restaurant and mandalay, choose Mandalay. Great food, Great service at a competitive price. You really can't go wrong. I'd recommend this place before you head to the Cal Academy for Nightlife.
author: Roth E.

description: Came here for the first time for dinner last night. 3 stars for the food and service and 4 stars for the drinks. The gf and I shared the ginger salad and the nan gyi dok. Overall the food was decent, but not up to the standard set by Burma Superstar or Rangoon Ruby. On the other hand the non-alcoholic drinks were solid. I had the Burmese iced tea (pretty much the same as a thai iced tea) and the gf had the ginger lemonade. Both were presented well and tasted great.
author: Prashant S.

description: Everything from the appetizer to main course was delicious! Good flavors but portion size varies depending on order. I highly recommend the tea leaf salad, pumpkin curry, house special noodles, and basil eggplant. Hands down better tasting than Burma superstar! I also prefer the mango lassi here than at Indian restaurants. The wait, however, is loooong and service is slow due to the overwhelming crowd. Mandalay is a must try but be prepared to wait!
author: Goldie L.

description:
Let me first start with this: 5 star food. 0 star service. All of the previous comments about disappointing service are unfortunately accurate.

Wait to be seated:
First, we arrive and there is a line. Totally fine and there was a sign in sheet. There was minimal rhyme and reason to the sign in. I saw more than one party come in and add their name to the top of the list. No one was managing it. The lovely hostess wasn't calling names loud enough to be heard and I saw her ditch 4 parties that were standing in the waiting area. Eventually they caught on. She kept telling one party of two that they were up next. 25 minutes later they were still sitting there. Our wait was about an hour.

Ordering:
No issues actually. Our server was very nice.

Food:
We ordered an appetizer (Balada) and 2 soups (Hot and Sour/Samosa) plus our entrees (Fried rice/ Ginger beef with coconut rice).

25 minutes later, my boyfriend's soup arrived. 15 minutes later and after he was finished, our appetizer arrived. 10 minutes after that, my soup arrived.

We sit.

His fried rice arrived. We eventually decided that they forgot my entree and I actually forgot what I ordered. 1 hour and 10 minutes (I clocked it) after ordering, my entree arrived.  While we were waiting, we looked around. I saw one waitress bring the wrong food to 5 different tables. (It was so ridiculous it was comical). Two tables down from us, there was another couple; she was done with her food by the time his came out.

Now, that being said, when food came out it was piping hot. And unfortunately amazingly good. Best coconut rice I've ever had and it went beautifully with my ginger beef. My boyfriend said his chicken fried rice was the best he'd had.

The  two stars I did give them  were because the food was awesome. I can't discount that. (I would have split it 50/50 but I can't do 2.5 stars and I'm not about to round up for service that poor.) And from observation, reservations carry no weight, so don't bother.

The take away:
*DO NOT go to Mandalay if you're in a rush.
*DO NOT go to Mandalay if you're on a date in a new relationship (and make sure you really like who you're with because you'll be doing a lot of talking).
*DO NOT go to Mandalay if you have any plans after dinner. You WILL be late.
*DO NOT go to Mandalay if you have guilt feelings about not tipping after bad service.

*DO plan ahead.
*DO get take out (and plan accordingly such as to pick it up at least 20 minutes after they say it will be ready. I'm sure it re-heats well). Every single take out order we saw stood there waiting.
*DO adjust expectations. 

TO MANDALAY: You have to figure out how to run the house. Your food is great, but your service is horrific. If you're going to have a list, you have to have someone managing it. Also, if the kitchen is small, you need to find a way to accommodate the  number of patrons. Also, you can't, just can't taper the delivery of food to the table. People do not want to watch their friend/date/spouse eat while they just sit there. And to the poor waitress who couldn't get a table right to save her life, bless her little heart.
author: Brie P.

description:
I know Mandalay is the first Burmese restaurant in San Francisco . . . because they said so themselves in their business description up there on their Yelp page, but just because you're a trailblazer doesn't necessarily make you the best. It's not bad, but from my experience, Burma Superstar, a few blocks up on Clement, has taken Mandalay and refined it. Yamo in the Mission has unapologetically stripped it down to the basics being served up in a small and dive-y fast food eatery that whips up fresh and tasty Burmese favorites for far cheaper, and Burmese Kitchen in the Tenderloin has added a comfortable homestyle spin to it. It all works, unfortunately just a little better than Mandalay does.

What I do like about Mandalay, though, is that while there is a wait on weekends, it's still not ridiculously painful (ahem, Burma Superstar). They also have a nice authentic, festive vibe inside (that Yamo's is lacking). They're really nice, too -- on two occasions that I've been there, they offered complimentary glasses of wine and water to those waiting! The food is generally tasty: try the okra and shrimp dish -- super flavorful, and you can't go wrong with of course the tea leaf salad and any noodle dish. Albeit, it's all served in smaller portions than I'd like. 

Mandalay will always have major props in my book for being a pioneer, and for that reason and many more, I hope it continues to thrive because they truly deserve it.
author: Betty W.

description:
I came here with a group of 11 to celebrate a friend's birthday. The service was great considering our large group. Best of all, they didn't charge us cake fee or the mandatory 18% tip!

We got a bunch of appetizers to share and everyone just ate off each other's plates for the entrées. Their tea salad was amazing (so much fermented tea leaves! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=zfgiyneBAGKVWzrh5by1SA, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=4Z59NYw75DU9IbFxr07kWg) as was their balada (very crispy, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=CV0XwTcnds4tB_3z7K9Bgw) and chicken samusa (so flavourful I didn't bother with the dipping sauce, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=zWHLFXaQ02cxT9Pb4zDXyA, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=c_aa18rwyNfCZ3uoHeL9OA).

They also make one of the best fish chowder noodle soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=UUKCeH_DBoIzVxy_HP3s1g) I've ever had. It was incredibly flavourful--seasoned perfectly with loads of catfish. I was tempted to lick the bowl to get every last drop! Their pan-fry okra prawns were also delish with lots of ginger and garlic. The other dishes I tried weren't as great though--the rainbow chicken was just meh, the coconut chicken noodle soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IPpQnGDJVApDEM5A93txtw?select=izaI-lOY5OBKQsiLmJcERw) wasn't that flavourful, the rice noodle in the Mandalay special noodle was undercooked, and the Burmese curry lamb was really tough.
author: Steph L.

description:
I went here for lunch with a party of three, all vegetarian/pescatarian, and none of us having any experience with Burmese food. 

There are plenty of options for vegetarians and meat-eaters alike. We started off with fish cakes (chewy and delicious), as well as the fried onions (like a delicious Awesome Blossom, though a little unwieldy as the lump of onion pieces stuck together a bit). For main courses, my dad got the delicately sweet Broccoli Walnut Tofu, which was excellent. I had the special Mandalay noodles, which took a little longer to come out but were worth the wait.

Everything we had was amazing and I cannot wait to go back and work my way through the rest of the menu. Either we picked really well by chance, or there just aren't many bad options.

Also: don't skip out on ordering a beverage! The "Fresh Young Coconut Juice" is in fact served in the coconut with a spoon to scrape out the flesh, even though that isn't explicitly mentioned on the menu. The Ginger-mint lemonade is also an excellent choice.
author: Jacob M.

description: We have been coming here for years & did not realize that we had not reviewed this. Mandalay is one of our favorite restaurants in the world. We always get great food & personalized warm service. I would mention that it gets busy, as we found this holiday season, so call them for reservations. They are not on Open Table anymore. The vegetarian & vegan  options are incredible. We love the had balada, samusa soup, tea leaf salad, ginger salad, walnut broccoli tofu, Mandalay special noodle, & coconut rice. The tofu kebat, Singapore noodles, & basil spicy eggplant are okay. The desserts & drinks are also great. Parking can be tough in the area.
author: Mihir M.

description:
Long wait but they were kind enough to give us glasses of champagne while we waited. Def worth the food. Saw some folks mention that the portions weren't that large -- not sure what they ordered but we had wayyyyy too much food. We were pretty hungry and thought we could finish it all but didn't.
Tea Leaf Salad - yum
Balada - yum
Coconut rice - yum
Mandalay Noodle - yum
Mango Prawn - yum
Sauteed spinach  - yum
Cant remember which chicken lol but it was good.
GOod service. Food comes out quick.
Looking forward to my next trip to SF to eat there.
Also, I went to Burma SuperStar too which I also enjoyed immensely. 
I think both are great.
author: Farzin K.

description:
We came here after his cousin's graduation.  Though things were meant to be ordered and shared family style, we opted to order a couple things for ourselves since we weren't very hungry.

We both got a mango lassi, shared an order of the chicken samusas & mango salad.  We each stole a piece of roti from the table too.  The chicken samusas were big and served piping hot filled with curried chicken & potato.  The mango lassi was creamy and refreshing.  I didn't care for the mango salad much, it just seemed like a weird combination of ingredients.  The roti hit the spot, was a little more doughy then crispy, but still good.  

It was a packed Sunday night so service was spotty but still friendly.  This is the second time that I've tried Burmese food & I honestly don't think I care for it much, but I'd say that this restaurant is an okay option in the Richmond.
author: Cat C.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city! I bring all visitors here; they can't get over the friendly staff and delicious food. Serious neighborhood gem
author: Laura B.

description:
On more than one visit to Mandalay I have felt less like a guest and more like an intruder.  They push relentlessly to turn the table even when the place has not yet filled.  So the moment they remove one plate from the table the next is immediately plopped down.  There is no pacing to the meal, which turns into a race to finish you off and get you out.

As to the food, I started with tealeaf salad, which was completely overpowered by a too large dose of peanuts.  There was no subtlety to the dish.  Next samusa soup.  This was composed of two OK samusas that were crumbled into a spicy, but I thought, too thin broth.  Finally the highlight of my meal was a special of spicy rock cod and asparagus.  Yes, the aspargus were a bit underdone.  And true there were too many peppers on the plate.  But the fish seemed fresh and was not overdone.
author: David D.

description: I have a particular fondness for Mandalay because it was where my mom ate her first ever meal in the US, almost 30 years ago. (Been a loyal customer wayyyyy before Burmese cuisine blew up on Yelp #OG #notbandwagoning) I have been to both Mandalay and Burma Superstar many times, and here is my (overall) verdict: though I personally like the tea leaf salad better at BS, that place is similar in quality to Mandalay, despite the overwhelming number of Yelp reviews that BS has. Coconut rice, fish cake, mango salad, Birds Nest seafood prawns and Burmese stir fry string beans are seriously bomb at Mandalay. Plus the line is shorter. The fact that Mandalay has been in business wayyy longer than BS says something! The end.
author: Lena R.

description:
Love the food here. We tend to stick to the usuals and get the rainbow salad (so, so good) and the green beans with tofu. It's all top notch. The service is very friendly, if a little pushy (they must do serious training on how to get people to up-order..."are you sure you don't want a drink tonight?"). 

Honestly, I feel it's a little pricey for the portions, but it's so good I can't complain. The ambiance at Burma Superstar is better. We typically call ahead to reserve a spot in line, and by the time we arrive it's our turn to be seated. Parking is usually a pain in that area but even that can't get in the way of our affection for Mandalay.
author: Megan S.

description:
A friend brought a group of us here and we had a fantastic meal. I was told that this place is sometimes considered better (more authentic) than Burma Superstar, which is the famous Burmese restaurant in SF. This is a great place for anyone who wants to have a good meal with friends visiting from out of town. 

Must tries:
- Mandalay Special Noodle
- Tea Leaf Salad
- Coconut Rice
