Note: Burmese food is typically very rich, sometimes maybe too heavy. I would eat light foods during the day before a Burmese dinner. I've once had take out (salad, noodles) and wanted to have nothing but fruit juices and plain veggies after.
author: Jackie C.

description:
I've been here several times and each time I come, they don't disappoint. The food is delicious and the service (once seated) is great. What more can you ask for? You can make reservations, but make sure your entire party is present or else they will not seat you. The place is small and when you have a big group, it's confined. It's better to order family style, that way you can try out a little bit of everything because one plate of one dish can be too much. They offer vegetarian food as well, so it's a perfect place if you have someone who doesn't eat meat. Some recommended dishes to try include:

Tea Leaf Salad: Everyone raves about this salad, simply because it's 'AAAAMMAAZZINNGG. It's an acquired taste for some cause you can taste the true state of the natural leaves and beans.'

Mango Chicken: A MUST have! Chicken is tender and the warm mango with the sweet sauce is just delicious. Try it and you won't regret it

Coconut rice: the right amount of sweetness. 'Perfectly balanced and you don't get that artificial taste of some fake coconut.  It's just magic in your mouth (that's what she said)' haha

Walnut broccoli Tofu: the right amount of everything! walnuts are glazed!! Broccoli is tender and tofu is firm.

Mandalay Special Noodle: 'There are no words for this cause when you eat it .. there is no room for talking.'

The staff is extra helpful, especially if you're a first timer. If you try something and don't like it, they are more than willingly to take it back and offer you something else without hassling you.
author: Linda N.

description:
I've been coming here for years and at least a few times a month (twice Yelp rating them as a 5), but after today's experience they may have lost my business.

OVERALL: Food is always good, but looks like just b/c they're popular, they're paying less attention on caring for customers, even regulars. Skimpier food portions and worsening service.

1 - be prepared to wait. Don't bother w/ reservations as walk ins, especially of a larger # will be seated ahead of you. (Just for kicks, I wrote my name on walk in list and they called up to the name before us just as we got seated.) They'll even cram 4 folks into a table for 2. Their business model is becoming increasing turnover at the cost of patron experience.

The past 3 times, I've waited at least 30-40 min to get even an appetizer brought after ordering.

2 - don't lie about wait time - we were seated 30 mins late of reservation, but 3 times dismissively told by female mgr we were next (as other walk ins got seated before us). For the past few visits, I've overheard people repeatedly complain about being told they'll be seated in 10 minutes that turns into 30 min.  

3 - short staffing on a 3 day weekend? Don't seat people if you arent prepared. Staff were frantically running around and the usually calm servers we know we're even short tempered, rushed and got our orders wrong.

4 - when you make an error - apologize, correct it and maybe even make up for it? We got the wrong appetizer and it had to be sent back. All in all we waited 30 mins from time of order to get ANY food and had been starving for an HOUR bc they were late to seating us.

The table next to us also got their order botched and waited for 30 mins to get it right.

5 - rude manager when complained about errors - we asked that our appetizer be comped due to error and consequential wait. Instead of apologize, the female manager said "well you got the right appetizer eventually right? So no, we still have to charge you." She then also tells us that they don't take reservations for 2 at 8p onwards. Then why did your other manager take the reservation and has done so for years?!!

We even got charged for the appetizer brought in error on top of the right app.

6 - food has increasingly become saltier and more oily. Portion sizes, especially for seafood dishes have gotten skimpy - mainly vegetables w/ less than a handful of seafood.

We've been forgiving about service because they've been apologetic, corrected errors as they come and food has been good. But after today where it's clear my business and that of friends' isn't valued, we don't plan on being back... The sad part being individually, we bring out own friends and family here too.

They can keep the $9 for the appetizer because they lost at least $320/mo of business from both of us.
author: Jason N.

description:
Many people will compare this restaurant to Burma Superstar. Please. Don't.

Come to Mandalay for delicious food (Spicy Basil chicken and coconut rice please), great decor, a clean, spotless environment and friendly atmosphere. 

Mandalay is my favorite restaurant in the Richmond and 2nd favorite restaurant in the City. (The House being my first). My only gripe is that some of the chairs are older and poor quality, they really need to replace them.

Honestly, I'm selfish and originally didn't want to write a review for this place. The lines here are getting longer and longer.. but they already have 1100+ reviews. What's 1 more review from a regular customer that always leaves happy?

The next time you're in the Richmond, skip Burma Superstar, walk down to the next block and get an extremely satisfying and enjoyable meal at Mandalay.
author: Kevin C.

description: Great food and love the roti or balada. The decoration was ok but the service was great. I will try it again.
author: Jagan B.

description:
Why isn't Burmese food all the rage?  Listen up -- Burmese cuisine has flavors influenced by China, India & Thai (just some of my favorite cuisines).  Fusion done beautifully.

Mandalay was tasty, authentic, relatively cheap, spectacular service and super homey.  I felt as if I was dining at a friend's house.  The food didn't weigh me down.  A group of 6 split several items:

Tea Leaf Salad:  My favorite dish of the night.  Combination of crunchy peanuts, softened tea leaves and heat make for a killer salad (no there is no lettuce).  

Balada:  A softer and fluffier paratha.  A cross between a paratha and a poori maybe.  Divine.

Samosa Soup:  Sort of a hot and sour soup with bits of samosa and falafel.  Crunchy and sour. I'd order this over hot and sour soup any day.

Coconut rice:  I'm always a bit leery about ordering coconut rice b/c it always tastes bland.  I tasted the coconut and it led to a creamier rice dish.

Saffron rice:  Sort of their take on bryani (saffron, raisins, etc.).  I prefer the coconut rice.

Pumpkin Pork Soup:  All I can say is that I was a slutty vegetarian and I tried it.  I felt guilty, but damn, the pig melted in my mouth.  

Pan Fried Beans:  Even my veggie phobic husband devoured these.  Crunchy outside and soft inside.  Oh so flavorful.

Mango Chicken:  Everything was perfectly cooked.  My husband loved it.  It's not that this dish wasn't good, it just wasn't as flavorful.  Great for more reserved palates.

Mandalay Noodles:  I felt the same way about the noodles as I did about the mango chicken.
author: Ani P.

description:
Pretty good. I don't have Burmese food often, so I can't really make a comparison.

Very busy for dinner on a Friday night in that horrible rain, but only had to wait 5 minutes for a table for 2. Lucky timing I guess.

The staff were friendly and super attentive. The food came out very timely, and everything was very tasty.

Dry Pan Fried String Bean
Mango Chicken
Tea Leaf Salad
Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup)
Chicken Satay skewers

Burmese ice tea just tastes like a thai or viet ice tea with a kick.
author: Bonnie Y.

description:
Every so often you come to a restaurant that deserves high marks. This place is extremely overrated in many ways than one. I waited for over an hour for a table here on Saturday night. I must say that I nodded off a few times waiting for my table.  The amount of people who want to eat here is out of control. On most Friday and Saturday nights, you will have to wait over an hour to get a table. 

I waited over an hour and it wasn't pretty. When I sat down, the table just so happened to be near the waiting area in the front part of the restaurant. The amount of people waiting for a table swelled so much that soon I had some old man's ass in my food and face. I had to get up and tell him to move it the fuck down. The way the restaurant is set up is a problem but I won't go there because it's not really for me to say how these folks should set up their place of business. 

Getting to the food, I must say I was quite sleeping waiting for such a long time to get a table. The food was not bad, all in all it was decent, the experience waiting for a table is the most problematic of all. That in itself was a huge turn-off. Another thing is that Burmese food isn't new, it isn't unique in San Francisco as there are a few other Burmese places around. Burma Superstar which is awful is down the street. Even though tons of people flock to it like they're giving away free food or something. The tea salad is a joke btw.

I would opt to go to a different Burmese restaurant than wait over an hour at Mandalay. While the food is decent, the frustration is high and that my friends does not provide for an overall good experience no matter what.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
It's a real treat to discover such a colorful family restaurant that serves delicious food. Mandalay was only mildly busy the Monday evening we stopped by. On street parking was no problem.

The staff could not be nicer. It's clever that they have servers double check the full order with you before leaving the table. The food was fresh and colorful, plated with care. My shrimp dish was delicious, although I admit I added fresh hot pepper sauce to spice it up.  The tea leaf salad was so interesting--totally new to me and the balanda was good, but a bit greasy for my tastes. I really loved their stringbeans.
author: Lynn S.

description:
This place is freaking bomb.

Before I started eating, I was already pretty grumpy and hungry from the wait. I swear they forgot about my group! We were waiting for close to an hour!

But then the food came...and wow. This was the first time I had a legitimate vegetarian Burmese meal, and these dishes simply blew me away! Honestly, I didn't think the tea leaf salad was going to taste that great...it didn't look really delicious...but this was one of my favorites. My boyfriend was going crazy and couldn't stop raving about the ginger salad (which we also ordered).

I forgot the rest of the food we ordered up until the dessert. We ordered the coconut and sweet potato dish to finish everything off. Everyone at my table LOVED it, but this just wasn't for me. I have no doubt that it was good...the texture was just not for me.

What I noticed: the servers prepare the salads in front of you. You would think the reason why they squeeze the lemon over a fork would be to prevent the lemon seeds from falling into the salad. Yeah...I watched as the seeds went all up in our salad. Luckily for me, my boyfriend unfortunately ended up with all the lemon seeds. I laughed at him.
author: Sandra C.

description:
Wow, I was really impressed with the Burmese food here! 

We were headed to Burma Superstar but saw the long line and headed here instead. We were sat right away and ordered a bunch of food: a fettucine-type noodle dish, catfish soup, tea leaf salad and Samusa soup (yah, we crazy!).

We ate every last bite of everything. And, even though the noodles thing wasn't the thing we thought we were ordering (I thougt we were getting this glass noodle dish that looked really bomb), we were still delightfully surprised by it.

I thought this place was better than BS and so I give it my highest ratings, two Burma Bombs way exploded!

If you never had Burmese food, don't be afraid - it's kind of like Indian food had a baby with Thai food while visiting South China. i.e. Delicious!

The neighborhood is also fun to walk around in. It's kind of like the real chinatown with lots of cheap markets/produce and asian restaurants, a great fish pet shop and two small independent book stores.
author: Ryan S.

description: I still really don't know how to define Burmese cuisine after my first experience this past Friday night, but after dining, I know I want to seek this out in Chicago when I return home.  Tried a number of items, all of which were sans nuts (since I'm allergic to peanuts); between the beans, the meats, the samosas, and the items used to make my salad (I think I had more soy than nuts to compensate for the allergy), I was quite happy, quite full, and later, it felt like this was quite healthy and light, which I can always appreciate.  Others paid the bill before I even saw the menu so I can't speak to the value proposition, but from a taste perspective, I would be back if I still lived in SF.
author: Justin B.

description:
This is a grrreat restaurant for traditional Burmese. 

We're just back from Burma & even in Burma, we rarely found food this good. 

The Burmese salads are authentic, esp. the tea leaf salad. 

Not giving 5 stars, only because the Chinese-style & Indian-style dishes felt water-down & unexceptional.  BUT it turns out that's the same in Burma. 

Stick to the Burmese traditional dishes & you're in for a treat. (Better than Burma Superstar, in my humble opinion, because the food is too salty there.  But Burma Superstar's sister restaurant, B Star, is a superstar for non-traditional Burmese.)

Yum.  I'm jealous you're going!
author: W G.

description:
I ordered Mango Chicken with Coconut Rice, Ginger Lemonade, and their Tea Leaf Salad. All items taste amazinggg! 

Mango Chicken with Coconut Rice: the mango was sweet mixed with salty, super yummy!!! Chicken was a bit too salty on its own, but when mixed with the coconut rice, it was the perfect blend. 

Ginger Lemonade: taste exactly like a virgin mojito! ;) 

Tea Leaf Salad: I couldn't stop eating it. It was very unique. First time I had that kind of salad.
author: Michelle T.

description: Curry beef wasn't that great...a bit too salty and chewing the meat gave my jaws a workout! Loved their noodle though (can't recall the name but I think it was the first noodle item listed). Also had the sizzling rice soup...was meh. broth only was so-so and the stuff inside the soup (shrimp, mushroom, veggies, scallop) didn't taste that flavorful. Coconut rice was good but overpriced. Would come back but try other items.
author: Iris W.

description: Amazing food for vegetarians. I had balada,mango salad and vegetarian samusa soup. Everything was amazing! Topped it up with fried banana and coconut ice-cream. Just one star less for reservation issue. They had some mix up and we had to wait for 35-40 min to get a table in spite of reservation.
author: Chhavi S.

description:
Burmese food take 2!

After being referred and hearing much about Mandalay after my recent experience at Burma SuperStar, I had to try the 'other' Burmese restaurant in the city - Mandalay.  It also helped that Mandalay was featured on SF Gate's "Bargain Bites".

Arriving on a Wednesday evening, it was crowded, with only a party of two ahead of me.  The decor was much more pleasant to the eye and the atmosphere was much more serene...the kind of place you could take your time and enjoy a meal.

The head waitress made her way to me and asked if I had been helped yet since I had been sitting in the waiting area for quite some time.  I mentioned I was still waiting for a couple of friends.  She came back and asked if I wanted to wait at a table, which I definitely appreciated.  While waiting, I ran into celebguru c. who raved and raved about the Burmese bread that I HAD to get! 

It took us FOREVER to order as the male servers told us the waitress was coming.  And the female server telling us to hold on a bit.  It seems that there's only one person, ie the head waitress, that is allowed to take orders.  So, that was very frustrating already and we were starving.  (This didn't impress my friends a bit.)

We decided to start with the Teal Leaf Salad aka Lap Pat Dok ($7.50) which is "salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with Lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing."  I enjoyed the presentation of this salad as it was mixed together in front of us.  I particularly loved the green pepper because it added a zing to each bite.  I found this dish unique and enjoyed it quite a bit.  Unfortunately, my friend was turned off from the moment she saw it and was repelled as it reminded her of diarrhea!  It tasted and looked fine to me though!

Next came the Pan Fried Pompano Fish ($11.00).  The waitress deboned the fish in front of us and we helped ourselves.  The fish was tasty with minimal of bones.  I didn't particularly find this fish special, but my friends seem to have enjoyed it more.  

Next to arrive was their special Pumpkin Curry with chicken. It was presented within the pumpkin/squash and it was a good thing we decided to order a side of rice.  My friend really liked this dish, and I found it average though.  (Maybe it's because I just had Thai pumpkin curry last week.)

The infamous Burmese bread was soon to arrive with a dipping sauce ($3.00).  My friend immediately pointed out that it tasted like a Chinese Fried Green Onion Pancake, but without the green onions.  After a couple of bites, I had to admit she was right about that one.  It was tasty, especially with the sauce, but not as original as I hoped.  (Sorry celebguru c. - I guess you have to try the Chinese Fried Green Onion Pancake yourself so you can compare!)  

We also ordered the Nan Gyi Dok ($7.00), which was "Burmese rice noodle with spiced coconut chicken, split yellow pea, powder, and fried onion."  Once again, the waitress mixed this dish in front of us and I enjoyed the tang of this dish.  My friends thought it was alright, nothing particularly special for them.

We needed something sweet to close out our meal.  They did offer Mango with Sticky Rice, but we opted for something we never had before.  I forgot what it's called, but it had a dollop of vanilla ice cream, raisins, small tapioca balls, nuts, syrup, and jello.  The two different color (red and green) jellos reminded us of agar and those lychee things that come in little cups and some kid choked on it and now they no longer make it anymore.  It was sweet, and reminded me like I was eating a wet trail mix.  

At one point, our teapot needed to be refilled and it never came back.  When i asked the waitress for tea, she looked at me like I was an idiot.  She asked about "tea leaf" and I saw "tea...teapot" and she just didn't get it.  It took a little while for her to understand that someone had taken our teapot and never came back with it and now we wanted it.  So, that put us off a bit.

The meal cost us $57 and we ordered too much food.  We could have done without at least one dish as there was leftover fish and rice.  

I did enjoy the fact that I never felt rushed when I was eating.  We were the last ones there as we had lots to talk about and not once were we asked to hurry up with our order.  (I was the last one eating from my party though when they did ask if we wanted dessert..., so maybe that one point only.)  

We were interested in the beverages, but found them to be a bit overpriced.

Overall, I would give this place a solid 3.  If they took our order in a timely manner and if the girl didn't look like I was nuts when I asked her about the tea, I would feel a bit better about it.  I would definitely go back for the tea leaf salad and the noodle dish.  And yes, I would choose Mandalay over Burma SuperStar.
author: Teri C.

description:
Good place for Burmese food with decent wait but faster than Burma superstar. Flavorful dishes with helpful, friendly staff. definitely try the tea leaf salad. Rainbow salad has a light but well balanced vinaigrette dressing.

Notable items:
Samosa
Tea leaf salad
Rainbow salad 
Burmese style noodles (Kaw soi dok)
Mandalay special noodle
Rangoon beef
author: Tony Q.

description: Omg the best food ever!!! I got the mango chicken, prawn and string beans and their flat noodles with coconut milk! Let's just say my friend and I didn't say one word to each other, just kept stuffing our face, and practically licked the plates clean! If you're in SF and want Burmese food = a fusion of Indian, Chinese and Thai come to Mandalay!!
author: Meghna K.

description: One of my favorite local restaurants. Try the mango chicken and rangoon beef, yummo.
author: Michael G.

description:
My favorite restaurant in SF, hands down.

Highly recommend the Balada, Tea Leaf Salad, Kaw Soi Dok, and Curry Beef. After eating food this flavorful, it's hard to imagine eating something else.
author: Munaf A.

description:
Tea leaf salad. After having had this at Rangoon Ruby, I will not get this here again. 

But if you're looking for an app to share, get the rainbow salad, it's the best! 


Samusa soup. Very thick. Meh. 

Mandalay chicken. Fried chicken cube sautéed w garlic and chef hot sauce. 

Pan fry string bean. Yum I love my green beans from here! 

Nan gyi do. Burmese rice noodle w mild coconut chicken. Split yellow peas powder garlic shredded onion and house dressing. 

Burmese curry beef. Actually very most and flavorful. 

Plata bread. With curry sauce. Yum. My go to app every time is on the menu.
author: Judy N.

description:
A friend of mine took us here a while back, and it was my introduction to Burmese dining.  Since then, we've tried the ever so popular Burma Superstar to compare, and I'll say that I think this place is just as good and without the wait.  You can make reservations here, and the food is on point!  The tea leaf salad here is delicious, and the ginger tea lemonade is so refreshing!  Great service, fabulous food, all you need is great company to share it with!

TLDR: Fantastic Burmese food without needing to wait hours like its competitor(s).
author: Carol L.

description: I came here for years since Burma superstar renovated, raised prices, cut portions and made a big name in Burmese food. Mandalay has decent Burmese food, however  i noticed that the staff and owner are super friendly to Non Asians and offer non existence service to Asians. That is very sad given that SF is very diverse with Asians with different background. Don't expect any decent service if you look Asians, go elsewhere... Very sad
author: Ellen T.

description: Meh. Ok dishes, small portions and not great prices. Will probably not come back...  Had the chicken mango and the special noodles. Both small but nice. Too bad the price is not low.
author: Idan B.

description: The most exciting meal I've had in a while. Many of the textures and flavors were new. Think Chinese food on steroids. Get a ginger drink, get a "salad;"get the eggplant and get some meat!
author: Kevin M.

description:
Mandalay holds a special place in my heart and tummy. Whenever friends or family come visit me in SF, my first choice of restaurant to take them to is usually Mandalay.  Not once have I eaten a mediocre meal; everything has always been delicious!

My go-tos are:  

-balada with curry sauce
-tea leaf salad
-coconut chicken noodle soup
-Mandalay special noodle
-mango chicken accompanied by coconut rice
-mango lassi

Order the above when trying to impress out-of-towners and proceed to watch them gleefully savor each morsel while rolling their eyes in orgasmic bliss.  They'll love you even more.

Service can be a bit scattered and at times absent (it gets really busy) but the employees are usually friendly.  

Hands down, best Burmese food!
author: Abby D.

description:
Worst service, greedy.

Last Saturday, we had a reservation for 11 people at 6pm for a surprise bday party.  We hoped to get there a little early to be seated first before our birthday guest for the surprise.  When we arrived, the table was all ready, but the waitress would not seat us unless ALL of us we here.  I tried to explain nicely about our surprise bday, she would have none of it.  She took us to the the sign in the entrance that explains their not seating unless all of party was present, and pointed out the actual words for me to read.  I quickly understood her message.  We then waited, while our table was still reserved for us, she went on to seat other parties and of course had to ask our large party to move aside to make room for her work.  The surprise occured at the crowded hallway entrance.

We started ordering appetizers, the waiter kept telling us to order more, which we did.  Then when we ordered the entrées, he said the same, so we ordered an additional, after which, he said he's afraid that we didn't order enough, but really he's not trying to push anything on us...  I finally said no.
We ordered too much.  We had too much food.

The food was good.  We had some desserts.

The waitress brought us the bill.  We put some cash in the billfold.  She came back and said oh didn't you order the sweet potato dish?  We said no.  She grabbed our billfold, minus the cash, disappeared into the kitchen and came back out with a small dessert plate with sweet potato cake and tapioca, a candle in the middle, everyone sang happy birthday.  We tasted the cake, was a little strange.
 
Waitress now brings us the bill again, with the added sweet potato birthday dish charge that we did not order.

The food was decent, but unthoughtful service and lack of generosity will bite you and leave a bad taste in your mouth.
author: Loan T.

description:
Although expensive, I thoroughly enjoyed my meal here with friends last night! I went with the tea salad and the pea shoots, to compare with my recent experience with these dishes at Burma Superstar. While both were good, it was nice to not have wait at Mandalay, and the food came out quickly and was quite flavorful!

Also the rainbow prawns were really good!
author: Leilani W.

description:
The food has always been good here, and it's a great alternative to Burma Superstar, which is overhyped in my opinion.

However the service here is awful at best. I had a reservation for two, and walk-ins were getting seated ahead of us -- what's the point of making a reservation?

The servers had no shame in coming by our table THREE times to ask us if we were done and ready for the check. I understand it was busy on Saturday night, but it's very annoying to be rushed during dinner. It's even more annoying to have empty cups that they don't bother filling, yet they come around and ask if they can take plates away (which weren't even close to being cleared). 

I really want to like and support Mandalay, because I've been coming here for years. However, as they've grown popular they don't know how to manage the increased business, and service is lacking. I don't expect GOOD service from family owned Asian restaurants, but I don't appreciate RUDE service.
author: Rich L.

description: I had the ginger lemonade (if you like ginger, you'll love this) satay chicken, hot and sour soup, tea tree salad, 2 orders of mango chicken, and 3 orders of coconut rice. All this food was split between 6 people and it was the perfect amount. My favorite thing I had was the satay and the lemonade. I enjoyed this place but it was on the pricier side at $130.00 for the whole meal including tip. The establishment was pretty busy when we got there and even more busy by the time we left. The food came out quickly, but for the amount we paid we weren't expecting to feel like they were rushing us out. Overall, definitely worth a stop by sometime, just try to come before it gets crowded.
author: Caitlin V.

description:
The food here is great! I"d never had Burmese cuisine until eating here and now Mandalay is a regular stop every time I visit San Francisco.  

I highly recommend the following dishes (in no particular order):

- Tea Leaf Salad 
- Naked Eggplant
- Mandalay Special Noodle
- Balada
author: Rod M.

description: Burmese food is really good and it looks like it is getting more popular in the Bay Area. Mandalay is a solid option if you want to try Burmese food. The tea leaf salad was very good but spicy. The flat noodle chicken and coconut rice were awesome. The pork string bean was aiight.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I am usually not the type to try new foods because I'm too scared I'll waste my money on a place where I won't like the food.  My friends tooks me here because they swore I'd like the food..and I did! :)  It's very different and very new to me, but it was a great experience!

We ordered a couple of dishes: Fried squash appetizer, Tea leaf salad, fried eggplant (a special they do NOT have on the menu, but it was my FAVORITE), Pumpkin pork stew, & Pan fried prawn with string bean.  Everything was delicious and had lots of flavor.  My least favorite was the tea leaf salad (we ordered it sans lettuce) - I liked the variety of nuts and spices, but I don't think it's something to where I could finish the whole dish.  I was only able to eat 2 spoonfuls and was done with the dish.  My favorite was definitely the fried eggplant.  It has a crispy outside, yet soft inside and it was just PERFECT!  If you're an eggplant lover, you HAVE to order this dish.

The pumpkin pork stew was delicious too - I liked how they kept the stew in the pumpkin for presentation and it was nice and hot (thank goodness it wasn't lukewarm!)  It has nice huge chunks of pumpkin and pork and it definitely is the best when you mix it in with some white rice.  The prawns w/string beans was also good - we needed some veggies so the string beans was a nice addition to our meal.  We also ordered the fried squash because we were waiting for friend to join us.  It was the perfect amount to hold us off til we were able to order our main dishes - it wasn't too oily/greasy and the sweet/spicy sauce that came with the dish was great!  I'll definitely make another visit if I have foodie friends visiting with me - I know they'll have a great experience like I did!
author: Grace K.

description:
Not as good as it can be and overpriced for the shrimp plates. I ordered the curry shrimp and got a small plate with about five shrimps in a red curry sauce without rice or noodles, which had to be ordered separately and was charged $13 for that alone. Add the $2 something for the rice and it's a $15 dollar meal for a small dinner. 

I will say that their sweet potato dessert is worth a shot and for that alone i would go back for. Also, we had reservations for 6:45pm on a friday night and we still had to wait for a table as the place was packed.
author: Carolina S.

description: This was the first time I had Burmese food and I loved it! I was first worried it was going to be curry like and heavy, but I was pleasantly surprised. The service was great. The food was delicious. Our group ordered a dish from every section to share and it was all very filling. I def recommend the coconut rice as the meals come with a type of rice. Everything we had was delicious such as the eggplants dish, seafood with green beans, the Mongolian beef, their special Mandalay noodles. I am telling you that you can't go wrong here. It is an ethnic treat!
author: Golnaz P.

description:
I absolutely love coming here! It's a family favorite! 

I've tried many things on the menu and I'm never disappointed by their dishes. There's always a lot of flavor in the dishes. Yum. My favorites are the samusas and the burmese style noodles. They also have a lot of different types of drinks that they'll serve you while you're waiting.

I try to come here early to beat the rush because once it gets to about 7pm or so, there's almost always a wait. Sometimes you don't know how long you'd have to wait either. However, the service here is usually still pretty good. They'll make sure you have water and get you your drinks quickly. I don't think I've ever had to wait that long for the food either. It usually comes out one after another. Sometimes there's not enough room on the table for all the food because it comes out so quickly. 

The decor here is beautiful! The bathroom even looks really nice and is super clean!
author: Connie Y.

description:
I'm shocked by a few things... 
1. That it received a Michelin Recommendation 
2. That it's received just shy of 1000 reviews and is at 4-stars.
3. That it's still in business with Burma Superstar down the street

The service was great and the food didn't suck, it just wasn't amazing. I do understand that everything is relative and if I hadn't first been to Burma Superstar, this place would most likely be a 4.5 star place. I actually prefer Mandalay's Tea Leaf Salad better than BS's but only b/c BS uses lettuce and Mandalay doesn't. 

The service was good but again, not as good as BS and the servers at Mandalay were not as easy to communicate and navigate when eating gluten and dairy free. The waiter at BS was very knowledgeable about the ingredients and was able to make other suggestions and recommendations when our primary choice was not gluten free or dairy free. This was not the case at Mandalay. We felt like our menu choices were pretty limited at Mandalay and ened up getting 3 different curries but all 3 tasted identical! :( So yeah, it was kind of a disappointment. I think I'll go back to Mandalay and try some different dishes on a time when they're not as busy and try to get a different experience.
author: Johnson M.

description:
A nice dining experience

We had dinner at Mandalay. It was a Monday evening . The restaurant was very busy. Even though we had reservations, there was a short wait. However, it was not an excessive delay.

Overall, the service was very good. The server was friendly and informative. The support staff was very quick with bringing and removing dishes. The "at the table" preparation of the Tea Leaf Salad was a nice touch. The portions were definitely large enough to easily feed two with leftovers.

I will list but not detail each dish. Overall, I thought the food was very good and made from fresh ingredients. It was presented well. I do not think the food was spectacular though.

I selected Mixed Satay.
She selected the Tea Leaf Salad.
I selected the Burmese Curry with Lamb.
I selected the Burmese Flat bread with the curry.
She selected the Smoked Tea Duck
We selected the Basil Prawns.
We selected brown rice.
We shared it all.

Overall, I think the food was 3.5 to 4 stars and I think the service was 5 star. I did like the room. While it was basic there are nice touches with decorations. It does have a bit of an exotic feel. The table might be a tad to close to each other. I would give the overall ambiance 3.5 stars.

I would visit here again.
author: Mark D.

description:
I still love the food here.  However, I have to mention the service is lacking.  

Don't bother making reservations because even if you do they will still seat other parties ahead of you. I think it is because they are trying to accommodate the number of people in the party as opposed to who actually has been waiting the longest.  For example, if you have a reservation for a party of 2, they will seat a party of 4 without a reservation ahead of you if they have a table large enough for them, instead of having your party of only 2 sit at that table.  So, reservations, calling ahead, etc. means nothing. You really have to be a patient person to tolerate this without becoming furious. This becomes vary annoying, especially since it has happened to me EVERY TIME I have visited.

When you place your order make sure you are very clear.  They often make mistakes.  Although they were quick to correct it right away, it is still a pain in the butt, and embarassing to have to address it in front of a dinner date.  For example, you order a vegatarian dish, and they mistakenly bring it to you with meat. 

Overall, the ONLY problem with Mandalay is service.  So if you are a very patient and forgiving person, you will probably have no problems.  

The food is amazing as always.
author: Lizzie L.

description:
A friend of mine who grew up in the Inner Richmond recommended Mandalay for Burmese without the wait you would usually have at B Star.

We went together last week, and it was fantastic. A Burmese food virgin myself, I was immediately in love. The Balada (Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce) was absolutely delicious, and the Nan Gyi Dok (Burmese rice noodles with spiced coconut) was a prefect combination of sweet and savory. They also have a great, and inexpensive, beer selection. The servers were very friendly and attentive as well, always a plus!

I'll definitely be back as I just moved to the neighborhood. Thumbs up Mandalay! Yum!
author: Charlie D.

description: We had a Birthday Dinner there recently.  We had patronized this restaurant many times for birthday dinners.  I was surprised that the restaurant had charged us $15 cake fee for bringing our own birthday cake after having so many Birthday Dinners there.  Their food is not cheap and the portions are smaller than most restaurants. The guests were not happy to pay the extra fee.
author: Ron L.

description: I couldn't believe how delicious this food was! Never in my life have I tasted such flavors....It might be my new favorite restaurant in town. Bravo to this traditional style of cooking, its beyond description!!! The service was great, too. We went on a very busy night ( no reservation ), and they handled everyone with such care. I would highly recommend it !! Love!!
author: Soul Surfer S.

description: I was blown away by this place. Amazing food, service, very inviting ambiance for this price range.
author: Marina C.

description:
Let me start by saying that their food was good.  The atmosphere while the restaurant is nearly empty is good.  But our experience there was not, and it is a regular issue at Mandalay.  It took us 2.5 hours to be seated on Saturday.  It only took an hour and a half for our name to come up on the list.  We spent another hour talking to the hostess after that while later walk-ins were seated ahead of us.  The restaurant was a mess with about 20-30 crammed shoulder to shoulder blocking the entrance/exit... that condition lasted for the evening and a fire marshall would have shut them down.

Honestly, I want to see Mandalay managed better and then it would be wonderful.  In the interim, I would *wholeheartedly* recommend completely avoiding the place.

An additional good example is that we had a table next to us with multiple tablets playing multiple movies for children at full volume.  The restaurant did not consider this to be an issue.  I am not considering this when writing this review... it is just a supporting topic.
author: James R.

description: I came here with a large party for a USF graduation celebration dinner. All of the employees were very kind. It was quite a while ago, over a year, but I remember everything being delicious. I especially remember the tea leaf salad (amazing!!!) and the lychee sangria.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Yea, yea, it took me 2+ years to write this. I've been to Mandalay at least 10 times, and every time I sit down excited and starving, and walk away completely satisfied.

Not only is the food delicious, the service is fantastic, the entire experience is enjoyable. The head staff are always smiling from ear to ear to serve their customers. Food never takes long to come out, there is no such thing as a "bad dish" here. Prices are more than reasonable, most dishes are under $12

The must-haves on the menu:

Vegetarian Samosa - Crispy hot crust holding in chunks of potato and peas. Careful, these usually need a minute to cool down...and don't forget to slather that puppy up with the accompanying sauce.

Tea Leaf Salad - I can't get enough of this dish. Fried garlic flakes, toasted lentils, cherry tomatoes, tea leaf, lemon, peanuts, etc. I could eat this dish as my main entree any day of the week, it will definitely serve 3-4 people for appetizers.

Young Fresh Coconut - An entire coconut served with an umbrella, spoon and straw. You drink all the coconut water first, then go crazy scooping out the coconut meat. Absolutely nothing added to it. Delicious!

Aside from that, the Black Pepper Soup is phenomenal, brings powerful flavors of pepper but doesn't kick your butt. Mongolian Beef, Yellow Chicken Curry, and Fried Okra Prawn are my favorite entrees.

Tip: They usually don't take reservations for parties under 4 so if you're in a small group, you might have to put your name down on the list and wait for a little bit. 

Mandalay seriously knows Burmese cuisine. Hate to say it but Burma Superstar's got nothing on this place.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Love the tea Leaf salad from here! Service is always pretty good. Make reservations for dinner or lunch time though cause otherwise you'll be waiting for a table.
author: Xbbygirl X.

description:
Nary a day has passed in my nearly two years living in San Francisco that I haven't spent moments daydreaming about Mandalay. There are only a few lucky cities in the US that (according to Yelp) offer Burmese cuisine, and SF is one of them. There is no reason not to eat here at least once a week, unless you don't like delicious food or are on a fun-free diet.

Unlike some Burmese restaurants in SF, Mandalay takes online reservations for moderately sized groups and there is rarely a wait. I typically am able to walk in and be seated within a few minutes. The moment I sit down I start scanning the room for my favourite server, Raymond, who is rarely without a smile. 

A perfect order for a group of 3-4 people:

Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok): It's the assembled-on-the-spot salad that everyone familiar with Burmese cuisine knows and loves, and it's a banger. I've never had anything like it. Tea leaves, toasted lentil seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & lemon juice. 

Samusa Soup: This is a slightly spicy soup with beans (maybe chickpeas?), curry leaves, lentils, crunchy yellow shoots, cabbage, mint leaves and onions. Packs a nice punch before the main entrees come out and is easy to share. 

Mandalay Special Noodle with Tofu or Chicken: I dream about this entree - it's just that good. Burmese flat noodles similar to a fettucine, with mild coconut sauce, yellow peas, lime juice, cilantro, peanuts, fried onions and crispy shrimp.

Dry Pan Fried String Bean: I'm sure this is the least healthy item on the menu but it's the one I always insist on ordering. I just love green beans. These are pan fried with ginger, ground shrimp and chili sauce. A bit zesty and super crunchy. Requires followup with dental floss.

Sauteed Peashoots with Garlic: Hard to find this item on other menus so if my group can stomach the produce, it's usually on the list of items to order.

Coconut Rice: Get this one instead of plain rice to zest it up.

When the bill comes, you'll wonder if they forgot to charge you for some items. Pay it and make a note to come back when it's within reason to do so without people mistaking you for an employee. Yup, it's that good!
author: Kat F.

description:
The place is very well decorated and representative of the Burmese culture. 

I wanted to like this place and give them a good review, but I guess seeing people who sat after us get served first, and having to ask the waiter for the where abouts of our food twice after waiting 35-40 mins after ordering didn't make the evening as enjoyable as I imagined. I'm not sure if this influenced my judgment of the food but it sure didn't meet my expectations.

The bf and I shared a Ginger lemonade, which was pretty good.

We ordered their Mandalay Beef which was basically cooked in the same way as Orange Chicken from Panda Express but with a different flavor. So I wasn't impressed

We also ordered their Mandalay Noodles, the texture was interesting but the taste was meh.

Mango Chicken was the best dish of the night and it wasn't that special, probably  because it was cold by the time it got to our table.

Even thought their service is nice and somewhat attentive, it took quite a while for our food to arrive. I normally wouldn't complain about the wait if other tables that sat after us got their food first.
author: Oriel F.

description:
After hiking a Presidio trail, I was hungry and wanted something southeast Asian. I was kind of leaning toward Lime Tree in the Inner Sunset but the Husband likes trying new things so we Yelped Mandalay. 

There were only a handful of people at 12 PM on a Saturday afternoon so we were seated promptly. 

I love the balada. It's a Burmese pancake that comes with a tasty curry dipping sauce and it's so, so good. The pancake is about the width of a buttermilk pancake that's been perfectly cooked but the consistency is lighter and the pancake almost comes apart in sheets. It can taste a little doughy when you get to thicker parts but the curry sauce makes up for that.

Get coconut rice! The coconut is crispy and the rice has the perfect texture for beef rendang - light but not dry. I like how southeast Asian rice is between dry, almost hard Chinese rice and sticky, glutinous Korean rice. 

We also tried the sauteed green beans and they were good. Still snappy but a tad bit salty for my taste.

I was disappointed that the service took so long. It's possible that our food was late because the kitchen had only opened half an hour earlier but even getting water took 10-15 minutes. We finally got our appetizer 30 minutes after sitting down. If you're in a rush, this might not be the best place for you.
author: Christine P.

description:
I have been going to this place since the late 90s.  I have never had a bad dish at this place.  The service has alwasy been very good.  We were there on a Saturday early afternoon and it was packed (X-MAS Eve).  Fortunately, we (2) were seated in about 5 minutes since the small tables were turning over fast.  There was a large family of about 6 who were made to wait till a larger back table cleared.  No, joining the smaller tables together (on the left side).  However, we did have to wait a little be longer than usually for a server to show up and our dishes were running about 10 minutes late.  I attribute this to the crowds.

Items ordered:

*Samusa ( Vegetarian)
A mixture of grounded curried meat and potatoes.  They were hot and crispy.  The potato filling and spices were spot on.  No complaints here.

*Mandalay Special Noodle 
Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top.   I loved this dish.  Not to much cream and the noodles were cooked just right.  I did have one complaint, please take out the steams from the cilantro and chop the cilantro up in lieu of serving it in full leaf as well as reduce the amount of cilantro (I took about 30 leaves out).  Also, chop the other chewy green condiment in small pieces because the texture is a bit hard to macerate.  

*Burmese Style Curry Chicken
Burmese style yellow curry chicken with potatoes.  Excellent dish.  The chicken was tender and the curry was excellent.

*Thai Tea.   Perfect drink to temper the spaces of the main dishes.  It can substitute for a dessert drink.  

I will always go back to this place.  I love the low key vibe of the staff, the working costumes, and the festive decorations.  For a place the is small and crowded, it is early to talk to the person in front of you because the shadowboxed ceiling was constructed with hanging fabric panels (weighed with wooded poles)  that absorbed the noise.  This is a very friendly place to eat.  For those of you who have a large family, they have large family style family rounders  farther back  for comfortable dining. 

Driving/Bus:  Easy to get to via 1 California Bus.  Parking is always tight, but there is a small street side parking sectional across the street the can turn over relatively fast.  For the most part, best to drink around the hood to find street parking.
author: Vanilla C.

description:
I just picked up the fish chowder soup and it's made a world of difference for my cold.  Every food item I've had from here has been consistently delicious.  Another visit prior to this, the tea leaf salad made me forget about the conversation I was having with my date.  
I highly recommend.
author: travis c.

description:
This is a real nice place ... i get a family home feel here .. nice people around ..
I have been for dinner couple of times .. tried tea leaf, rainbow salad, mandalay noodles, samosa soup, tofu basil .. i am vegeterian and liked all stuff .. just find the place expensive but food is awesome .. i like the fact that is open till 9.30pm .. usually it get 9pm by the time i come back home and others are closed .. and we rush here for the dinner .. all satisfied when we come out ..
Also, everytime i see some sort of celebrations like birthday jingles .. kinda feels good they make you feel home sometimes .. nice hangout place :)
author: Deepak A.

description: I want to update that the service here, despite the crowds, the wait, etc, is top notch. They move quickly, and really care about their guests' experience. We will return!
author: Kim D.

description:
Warning: LONG wait time. We were seated pretty quickly, but our food took almost an hour to come! The restaurant was packed, certainly, but some other tables who came later got served first, not cool..
Our servers were always very nice though, and apologized for the wait.

Tea leaf salad - we actually had a version of this with lettuce somewhere else and preferred that, but apparently that's an Americanized version so I guess our tastebuds were polluted to begin with! Love the fried chickpeas and peanuts though, gives a crunch.

Black pepper soup - yummy vermicelli inside and pieces of fish and soft squash-like vege which I thought was bitter melon or something, but am not entirely sure. Pretty gd!

Burmese catfish curry - a bit on the salty side, pretty good still!

Burmese Style Noodle (Kaw Soi Dok) - far and away my favorite dish! Loved the combination of crunch (fried onion/garlic and cucumber) and citrusy dressing.

We also ordered coconut rice, which came in a flower-shaped bowl, really cute! It was very good, tender/fluffy/flavorful :)
author: Clarissa L.

description: We were raving about different Burmese dishes to our aunt and uncle who were visiting from India. They had never had Burmese food so we decided to take them to Mandalay based on the great reviews. Maybe we came on one of their "off days" because the food was not as great as other Burmese restaurants I've tried and the service was horrible. The server was very impatient with us and was rushing to get us out. It was a shame our aunt and uncle didn't have the same experience as we did when we first tried Burmese food. I definitely won't be coming back here again nor have I ever recommended this restaurant.
author: Poonam P.

description:
This is one of my all time favs.....Much better than the much more crowded and more costly Burmese Restaurant down the street with a 2 hour wait.  

Mango Shrimp...delicious, fresh, and light.

Tea leaf Salad.......Yummmmmm

Pumpkin Curry:  Better than any Thai Restaurant that I can remember.
author: Morgan C.

description: We LOVE Mandalay! The tea leaf salad was good and my friend was able to ask for shrimp on the side because she's allergic to shellfish. The coconut rice is the BEST option for rice. We think it's better than it's top competitor. The wait can be long, but the service is very fast and nice! We asked for extra water because we had a long day of being in the sun and they brought us pitchers and filled us up constantly!! Highly recommend!
author: Lauren S.

description:
FIVE starts for Mandalay!!  We came with a party of 20 for a birthday celebration.  The staff was super accommodating and we made it easy and ordered the pre-fix, Royal Dinner.  It was a ten course feast! 

This was the first time a lot of us had Burmese food and it was delicious!  Of course we had nothing to compare it to, except our preferred tastes.  There wasn't a dish we didn't like, and we enjoyed that the servers explained each entree.  Specifically the tea leaf salad! Its always a plus to have semi-demonstrations at the dinner table!

The standout dishes (in no particular order) were:
-Mango Chicken
-Tea Duck with Siopao Bread (well that's what we called it!)
-Spicy Shrimp & Scallops with Green Beans
-Spicy Fish
-Chicken Satay
-Mandalay Beef

For dessert we had "Happy Birthday" in Burmese playing in the background with fried bananas and ice cream :)

This place was sure popppin on a Friday night... at 10pm there were still people waiting to be seated!
author: Earlene C.

description: This place serves delicious food, no doubt about that. Yummy. Unfortunately the prices keep creeping up so I will not be able to eat there as often as before. It is with disappointment that I report the last few times we've eaten there, we've been charged for more rice than we ordered which is always a hassle to point out, not to mention makes the customer look petty. The last time we ate there, our food took an hour to arrive for a party of 3 with 4 dishes. It was Halloween and we were looking forward to doing some other things that we were not able to do. Eventually some wait staff came to explain that the gas had been shut off for a while so they were backed up. Still, it would have been nice if they offered a discount or a free dessert or something....
author: Moonbird G.

description:
Excellent food, if a tad overpriced for the portions. However, as my first experience with Burmese food, I could not ask for more. I highly recommend getting coconut rice with some sort of curry. Even if you don't like coconut as a flavor, trust me on this. It's really rich and creamy, but not overpowering--I personally dislike the taste of coconut but coconut rice pairs really well. 

The Mandalay special noodles were really tasty, and the mango chicken was good as well. The atmosphere is cool too--it's like eating in someone's dining room. And considering how much I've been missing Southeast Asia these past few weeks, this was the perfect comfort food.
author: Justin E.

description: Their Mandalay special noodles are the best everywhere. The ambiance is sparkly and relaxed. The broccoli  with walnuts is fabulous. The servers are attentive and friendly. The owner makes sure you feel welcome. If you like lychee- their sangria is fabulous.
author: Me M.

description:
Came in for dinner on a Saturday night with no reservation, we only waited a few minutes and the hostess offered us wine while we waited.  The food was spot on. I've only tried B Star (have not made it to Burma yet) but hands down preferred Mandalay over B Star.  Get the tea leaf salad, you can't leave without trying! 

Everything was so flavorful and filling. Loved!
author: Brianna M.

description:
Their Rainbow Salad is quite tasty. Notable ingredients were: fried peanuts, fried lentils, sunflower seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic, noodles, and orange rice.  After the salad was tossed, there was still an astounding retention of unique flavor identities as per most individual ingredients.  Wow, I felt really in-sync with this salad, great flavors.

The sizzling rice soup was hearty, and the perfect size for sharing. Delicious seafood stock, with bits of shrimp, carrot, bamboo, and snow peas.  I like to eat it by itself, but it is also tasty spooned over white Jasmine rice.

The Ginger Lemonade, although refreshing, is also very sweet.
author: Ty T.

description:
Hellya!  Loved the dinner here, we had to wait a while for the table, but it was well worth it.

Looking to go back soon, with a good group or for a special occasion.  

Top items:
Soups 
Seafood
Veggies 
Crazy sweet potato dessert
author: Chris M.

description: My boyfriend's family and I came here for dinner our first night in SanFran, it. Was. Amazing! Everything was so delicious, the atmosphere was eclectic and beautiful, much like San Francisco itself. Don't forget to try the muddled mint ginger beer drink(I forget it's menu name, delicious though.)
author: Rachel P.

description:
The only drawback about Mandaly is that it's so good and this makes it very popular.  If you don't mind the wait, the food is so bright, tasty and interesting.  

Their service is great and the food is so interesting.  It's a must for out of town guests for me.
author: Carrie B.

description: This place is amazing. Great ambiance! Food is superior to the other Burmese restaurants in the area. There tea salad is really good. Very nice staff. Come early if you don't want to wait. This is a much nicer place than the ones around the corner. Every dish we have had is great.
author: Ariel F.

description:
Not many deserve the rare 5-star rating... but MANDALAY DOES! 

I fantasize about their Tea Leaf Salad and Mango Chicken days and weeks after I dine here. Their Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup is also a must-try.

Mostly recently, we ordered the Mango Salad (delicious), Tea Leaf Salad (the best I've ever had), Mandalay Special Noodle (which was amazing), the Burmese Style Curry Chicken (great taste), and my favorite Mango Chicken. The Mango Chicken is cooked to a perfection - crispy outside with a tender center and the sweet mangos nicely complement the savory flavor. I love ordering a Sweet Young Coconut juice with an umbrella and straw (in the coconut!) to refresh my palate. 

Dessert was the fried bananas and sorbet - decent. 

The most memorable part of the meal was ordering Jasmine Tea. The tea arrived in clear wine glasses with a Jasmine flower in a tight ball inside. As time passed, the flower slowly opened up and revealed it's beautiful bright red center and released it's aromatic flavors! So cool.

The quality of their food is superb as well as their very efficient service. The owner woman is always there making sure everyone is seated right away.

I 100% recommend this place to everyone. The combination of flavors is surprising and always tasty.
author: Erin C.

description: Came here yesterday for a belated birthday dinner with a group of 9, after making a reservation. They were great with a big group, very attentive and there was so much food, it literally could not fit on the table! Every item was delicious and we got a mix of vegetarian and non-veg food. Special note to get the rainbow salad!! We are all definitely coming back :)
author: Reeti B.

description:
Absolutely delicious. First time having Burmese food and now I'm just constantly on the lookout. MUST Tries: Chicken Samusa, Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken with Coconut Rice and Mandalay Special Noodle. If you order that, I promise you'll have the most delicious experience. Also, ditto to the reviewer below me, Burmese Iced Tea = Thai Iced Tea. Both extremely sweet and tolerable at limited doses. 

There is a no photo policy, but based on the amount of photos on Yelp and the amount I took, it's not particularly enforced.
author: Joanna H.

description:
"Mandalay Superstar, that is what you are, 
Coming from afar, reaching for the stars, 
Run away with me, to another place,
We can rely on each other uh-huh,
From one corner to another uh-huh!"

If the wait is too long at Burma Superstar go to Mandalay. Food is just as good if not better, with no wait.
author: Jen Y.

description: Not the happiest person right now. The food was very disappointing .i got the basil pork for lunch. It wasn't what I expected, it was sour.
author: SF S.

description:
Went with Mom for lunch.  Love their Mandalay prawns noodles, shocking duck and spring rolls. 

Went there for my Mom's b- day. Love the noodles and spring rolls. The mango chicken, lychee coconut prawns and curry pork stew were good, but small portions. Also, the squash that holds the curry pork is not edible and you can't bring it home.  The papaya salad was good and not spicy  Be sure to check their specials for the day. I love their Mandalay noodles even a little more than traditional pad thai.
author: Nathalie C.

description: Very good coh swey. I'll be back to try the mohinga. I think I'm more of a fan of the Indian influenced Burmese food than the Chinese influenced.
author: Khalid N.

description:
The Balada appetizer is absolutely delicious and so is the curry dipping sauce that comes with it. You must start with it. Unfortunately, the last time I went, they were all out and it was only 7pm. I really think they should stock up even more to make it to the beginning of the dinner service. That really put a damper on things.

Also, I recommend the Rainbow Salad and the Mandalay Special Noodle. 

If you've been to Burma Superstar, you might be interested in the Tea Leaf Salad here. Its also very delicious, but be prepared that it does not comes with lettuce which makes it more potent in flavor, but also makes for a smaller dish. Very good, but I love the Rainbow Salad even more.

The service is ok, they are great at certain things like presenting the food and serving it to you. But sometimes it seems like they are just going through the motions and are missing that personal attention. They seem to run out of things and not quite know how to handle questions about the menu or any special requests. Everyone is pretty professional, but I never feel like they are there for me and its also often unclear who I should mainly be talking to about my order because so many different people come to the table.

Overall I really like this place, some of the food is unbelievably good and most is very good.
author: Dexter H.

description:
My boyfriend and I have started a new tradition of trying someplace new once a week.  We try to go to places outside of our neck of the woods (the South Bay), for a change of scenery.  After reading some reviews, we decided that we would try for call ahead seating, just in case.  It was a Sunday, so I didnt think it would be too bad, but I am impatient so would rather call ahead than wait when we got there. I called at 6pm as we headed out, and the lady who answered said they were very busy and she could put my name down if we were going to be there soon.  I told her we wouldnt be there for another hour, and she said "Okay no problem.  Just come in, no wait at 7pm."  I was already feeling like this was going to be bad.  Turns out, she was right. We got there a little after 7 and were seated immediately.

Service was really good, maybe too good (is that possible?).  3 people tried to take our drink order, and multiple people brought out our drinks/gave us refills on water. I ordered the tapioca with coconut milk, which was delicious  Something that we make at home on occasion, but it never tastes that good for some reason.  

As an appetizer we ordered the Palada. It came out pretty quickly and was hot and fresh.  The curry dipping sauce was extremely hot; my boyfriend burned his mouth because he was too gung-ho about eating.  I felt that the Palada was a bit thick and doughy for my liking, I prefer something thinner and flakier (like a Malay/Thai Roti). The flavor was good, but it was a bit greasy.  

For dinner we ordered the Walnut Prawns, Burmese Curry Beef, Spicy Naked Eggplant, Coconut rice and the Mandalay Special Noodles.  The walnut prawns were battered a little too heavily, and it was confusing that some of the prawns had tails on and some didnt.  It was like Russian Roulette, whether you got a tail or not! The Burmese curry beef had good flavor, and had ample meat.  It wasnt really spicy, but had a lot of spice flavor (if that makes sense...). The spicy naked eggplant was also heavily battered and was a bit chewy.  The sauce flavor was good, but I would have preferred less onions and bell peppers and more eggplant.  Also, the eggplant was cut into HUGE pieces, which made it a bit difficult to eat. Coconut rice is, well, coconut rice.  Nothing special here. The Mandalay special noodles were interesting.  I can only describe the flavor as a creamy, lemon-curry sauce.  Very light and refreshing in your mouth.  It came with crushed pea, cilantro, crunchy noodles, and chicken.  Maybe something else, but thats all I can remember.  The server presented it to us and then said she was going to mix it for us.  Score!!  It took her like 5 mins to mix it though, which was kind of awkward.  Are you supposed to watch her the whole time? We tried to have a conversation but felt like it was rude to talk in front of her, so we just stared awkwardly at her tossing the noodles. 

After dinner, we were contemplating dessert but ultimately decided not to get anything.  They gave us complementary Mango Pudding, which was light and mango-y.  I'm not a huge fan of mango, but I assume that it would taste pretty good to someone who likes it.  

Overall, we enjoyed the food and would come back if we were in the area.  I dont think that we would drive 45 mins specifically to eat here though.
author: Kristin K.

description:
I'm not sure why everyone is raving about the Tea Leaf Salad. It had a strange tangy flavor to it, and it had way too many peanuts. Maybe my taste buds are broken, but I did not care much for it. I also did not care much for the Mango and Coconut Rice dessert. The rice had more of a cake texture than I would've liked.

However, the Mandalay Special Noodle dish was pretty good. I liked the dried onion flavor and the coconut milk sauce. 

I give this place three stars because the service was good and they were very friendly. I would definitely come here again, but I think I would have to try something else other than the Tea Leaf Salad to alter my opinions about this place.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Loved the Tea Leaf Salad (it doesn't have lettuce like Burma Superstar's -- and frankly, I've had this authentically and we haven't put in lettuce).  Also ordered items that seemed available for the American palate like Mango Chicken and Rangoon Lamb -- neither of these really strike me as "Burmese" or maybe the Burmese folks I know never make this.  Nevertheless the Mango Chicken & Rangoon Lamb were delish.  Not saucy really.  Smell of lamb was covered up well so I guess that means the marinating was done well.  I'd definitely come back.

My gripe w/ Mandalay was the wait was terrible (granted it was a Friday night)... but the hostess kept saying that our table was getting up and we'd be seated right away though we weren't.  The false expectation kind of sucked - I'd just rather be told the honest wait even if it's long.  On top of that, they seated a 4 person party at a 2 person table.  Kind of tight.  I guess it's  better than not being seated at all.  However, even though the wait was long, the estimated wait time inaccurate, and the space cramped... I'd come back. 

Ginger cooler (has alcohol) and ginger lemonade were fresh and delicious.  It's a healthy $5+ for the drinks (even non alc) I think.
author: Alias A.

description:
FOOD/DRINK:
1.) Ginger lemonade - sooo good! Refreshing and sweet 
2.) Rainbow salad - refreshing
3.) Mango salad - refreshing
4.) Soup - the first one on the menu
5.) Mango chicken = this was alright
6.) Fish filet bean sauce = This was good!
7.) Combination noodles = I liked first bites, but afterwards it was just normal
8.) Coconut rice = Oh yum! amazing


SERVICE:
Good


ATMOSPHERE:
Casual, ornate, cluttery with random decoration... perhaps Burmese? But also.. old Christmas ornaments still hanging around haha.. O well food's good.
author: Angela L.

description: Me and my friends with their child went to the restaurant. We placed orders. Their food was partly on the table 15 minutes later. After watching them eat for 30 minutes I asked the waiter about my order. She had no idea what I was talking about. I left that place and went for some sushi on Balboa. By the way, my original order came 10 minutes after I left. Just in time for my friends to finish eating.
author: Leonid G.

description:
WOW - great, great food. Would have been 5 stars if the service hadn't been so slow and inconsistent. We were seated before three other parties sitting nearby, yet all three received their food before we did. Friendly staff, but not well-trained.

It was a very cold summer day in the City, so the Samusa Soup was a necessity. Wow - the rich, deep flavors just jump around on the tongue! Perfect for a cold, foggy summer afternoon in the City. Highly recommended.

Though I wanted the Tea Leaf Salad, my wife opted for the Burmese Style Noodle. I was absolutely shocked how good that first bite was! Again, the flavors just jump around on the palate. These are tastes you just don't find in other cuisines.

Finally, I had the ginger lemonade, and yes, the flavor was exquisite! I rarely get excited about lemonade, but this is a must, even on a cold day.

If you can be patient with very inconsistent service, this is a can't-miss.
author: Chris S.

description:
SO GOOD! My first ever experience having Burmese food was at Mandalay. I am now obsessed with Burmese food. The tea leaf salad was to die for, the balata was mouthwatering, and the fried eggplant was so yummy (I DON'T EVEN LIKE EGGPLANT). Oh, I almost forgot... The Mandalay Special Noodle was amazing as well. 

The service is great too. The waiters are very attentive and helpful when deciding what to order.
author: T C.

description:
This restaurant is soooooooo much yummier than the other Burmese place down the street.  Service is great.  The wait and parking is not so hellish.  

 I like the satay and lap pat dok ( tea salad) for starters.  The tea salad is different, with all the nuts and tea leaves.  The tea leaves used in the salad are not the usual tea leaves you drink.  It could be an acquired taste for some.

The ong no kaw soi (chicken coconut noodle soup) is AWESOME with a bit of lemon and cilantro!!  I have to have this everytime.  The samosa is decent.  The entrees are similar to chinese dishes.  The mango chicken is consistently good every time.  Mandalay noodles are flavorful.   Its not your typical chow fun.  

Dont forget to try some of the yummy coconut desserts!!
author: Kris H.

description:
Let me put this out there: I love my city. I think Atlanta has fantastic cuisine. I'm not one of those "everything is better in SF" types, but daaaaang. BURMESE FOOD. Who knew? I didn't.

And now I'm dying because it's my new favorite and it doesn't exist in my city.

I came in on a chilly Friday night with a merry crew of 5 and we were treated to a serious flavor party. Two in our group were regulars so we let them do the ordering and we kept it vegetarian. 

The pea shoots were divine, the green beans appropriately garlicked, the house noodles flavorful and hearty without being greasy. The samosa soup was the right amount of spicy: I'd happily order up a heaping bowl of it for my entire meal.

But honestly, the tea leaf salad stole the show. Nutty, spicy, leafy... delicious. It's a flavor I can't explain and, unfortunately, can't replicate. My only regret is finding this on my last night in SF, as otherwise I most certainly would have returned... likely the next day.

In addition to the delicious eats, our service was fantastic and gracious, they play "Happy Birthday" over the sound system multiple times a night, and they were happy to split credit cards with ease. 

Speaking of, the final tab for one of the best meals in recent memory? $100 for a crew of 5, including a round of beers. I'll be back.
author: Kathleen M.

description: This is my all-time favorite restaurant in San Francisco! I've been coming to eat here since we first moved to SF in 2008 and it is our go-to restaurant for anyone visiting from out of town. The balada bread is amazing, the mango chicken rocks, mandalay noodles are delicious and those are just some of our favorites. Sherry, the owner, is the nicest and always has a smiling face. I've held my graduation dinner here, numerous birthday dinners, and always getting take-out or eating in. It's gotten busier over the years which is great for them, but the wait usually isn't too bad if you have a reservation or go before the dinner rush.
author: Joy M.

description: Food was yummy but the service was lacking. We had reservations for 11 and got a table for 6. We wanted dessert but they  apparently 'ran out'. The ginger lemonade, samosas, sizzling prawns are all delicious. Liked the cocunut rice as well. It's too bad the service was not good:(
author: Zainab B.

description:
I never read a review of this place prior to coming here, so I didn't know it was so highly rated. My girlfriend and I actually stumbled upon this place when we got lost in the City and I really needed to stop somewhere to use the bathroom and fill my stomach. Lucky us then, since Mandalay turned out to be first rate.

I've never had Burmese food before, so I'm not going to pretend that I know anything about the cuisine. But what I can tell you is that the Mango Chicken and Mandalay Noodles are unreal flavor explosions (especially the Mandalay Noodles). Also, I'm all about mangoes, and if you are too, then this is the place for you.

The service was prompt and helpful also. If you are apprehensive in any way about trying Burmese food, I would describe the experience as refreshing and fun, so please, for your sake, don't be apprehensive. Give Mandalay a try, and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.
author: Tyrone V.

description:
If you go to this restaurant the one thing you should try is the Tea Leaf Salad...there's just one word to describe it: Incredible! My friend and i went to try it after my roommate and his boyfriend were raving about it and I couldn't believe how good it was - I've never tasted that mix of flavors before. We ordered it without some shrimp ingredient that was in it on account that we're both vegan/vegetarian.

Our other dish was the Broccoli Walnut Tofu which was also good, but it wasn't super unique. I think we were slightly disappointed by how many of the dishes had fish sauce so while they offer tofu in replacement of the meat most of the noodle dishes aren't and can't be made even vegetarian let alone vegan.

But it's totally worth the salad!
author: Micky W.

description:
Christmas in July or January or whenever! This restaurant feels so old school SF to me, and that's delightful. Not really stylish, but delightful.

I've had the Mandalay Special Noodle, Tea Leaf Salad, and Burmese sour vegetables. All were great! Friends also got some of the more Chinese-restaurant-seeming vegetable dishes (e.g. Walnut Broccoli Tofu) and those were also yummy, but also kind of sweet Chinese-American tasting to me.

But definitely ample enough vegetarian choices. The only negative is the wait can be a pain on the weekend.
author: Tom Z.

description:
If you're looking for true Burmese cuisine, this tastes closest to home cooking more than any other Burmese restaurant I've been to. How do I know what authentic Burmese cooking tastes like? My parents and grandparents were born there! I think my great grandparents came from China, but that's another story ;P

If you haven't tried it, the Balada is awesome! Save half of it to take home later and dip it in sugar! Better than pancakes :D

The only thing I don't recommend is the Burmese Iced Tea lol never heard of it before until here. Thai Iced Tea is better.

I will be coming here often. Portions are huge. One dish will serve 2-3 people. So bring lots of friends and family!
author: Timothy L.

description: Two stars for the food and service.  The service was pretty good but the wait was long, which is supposed to be a testament to the food, right?  But the food was disappointing.  The pumpkin curry was uneven like ground beef was put in there making a brown curry with oil or something.  It did not taste good either.  The only thing cool about that dish was that it came in a pumpkin, which makes for teeny portions.  The coconut rice was ok.  The Singaporean noodles are pad thai but with thin glass noodles, which were just ok.  The mango chicken was panda express-y (fried, lathered in sweet sauce) with soft square chunks of mango.  The Burmese Iced Tea is actually Thai tea, which you can't really mess up.  I would say that and the noodles were the best part of the meal, which is not saying much.
author: Chris L.

description: We went here after reading many stellar reviews.....after waiting over an hour we were expecting a delicious dinner.  We ordered the recommended salad which turned out to be mostly peanuts and not too terribly flavorful.  Had the pork stew with pumpkin, boring and again not much flavor.  Third dish was Rangoon Lamb, I do not think it was lamb but that was delicious.  Still not worth an hour wait.
author: Judy H.

description: Superb service, ambiance, excellent food, owners Kevin and his wife hosted us personally.  Can't say enough about Mandalay!
author: Roderick C.

description:
My wife recently turned me on to Mandalay. It caught me by surprise, nestled in Inner Richmond with it's delectable delights, affordable prices, and family-oriented atmosphere. The service was equally good and we didn't have to wait long compared to other Bermese restaurants I've experienced in San Francisco. 

Be sure to order: Balada, Satay Chicken, Chin Hin Yee, Tea Leaf Salad, Basil Spicy Pork, Smoked Tea Duck, Burmese Curry Beef, Pan Fry Okra Prawn, & Dry Pan Fried String Beans.

Damn, now I'm hungry for Mandalay again. Here I come!
author: Pascal G.

description:
I had the recent pleasure of trying Burmese cuisine.  With wonderful, knowledgeable company I knew I was in for a treat of the senses.  

We came here for an early evening dinner and already this medium sized restaurant was packed, even on a Sunday.  So either make reservations or be prepared to wait.  Later I would realize why this restaurant would be so packed with families and parties seeming to be celebrating.   Inside is brightly colored in vibrant hues.  Pleasantly decorated with tasteful paintings, the ambiance was colorful but without needing glasses for blinders.  All around I felt transported into a different culture and comfortable throughout dinner.

The staff was quite nice and happy to explain the dishes presented.  With smiles and cheerful manners, our waitresses were a great addition to the evening.  There was no wait and getting more water or extra items were easy.

The food was interesting and fun . . .  The rainbow salad was fresh, colorful and with a fish sauce that seemed a bit tangy.  While I cannot say I loved it, it was something new and fun to eat.  Additionally, we ordered a noodle dish I do not remember the name of, but it too was neat to try but not a feast for the palate.  Finally, we had a curry that was a tad spicy and oh so good.  I am a sucker for curries, so i was completely on board with the order.  Tender meat, fragrant aromas and tasty bites were in store with every mouth full.

Overall the experience was great and I would totally come back!

Good food.
Lovely decor.
Great staff.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
Mandalay is UNDERRATED! Mandalay is better than Burma Superstar!!! Mandalay is NOT always crowded! Mandalay will take walk-ins!!!!
Mandalay is that hotness of all hots! Love the food here. It's quiet, nice peaceful atmosphere. You'll even get great personable service from the owner and the hostesses. Love Mandalay.... Read my review for Burma and amend it to Mandalay. Take out the crowded and overrated parts from Burma and add the ambiance, the great atmosphere and service stuff to Mandalay... 

There you have it!
