My review for Mandalay!
author: Erik R.

description:
This place has really outstanding food - I enjoyed it more than the Burmese food I actually tried in Burma!

The tea leaf salad is not to be missed (although you should make sure to ask for peppers on the side in case not everyone in your party likes spicy food!), and the noodles were so good I ended up ordering a second plate.  Also try the sangria, which was delicious.  Overall, every dish our seven-person table ordered was well-received.

Service was friendly and helpful, and the food came out really quickly.  I understand this place can have a very long wait, but we came in on a Tuesday evening with a reservation and it wasn't that full at all.
author: Joëlle M.

description:
I came here the other week for father's day dinner. 

My dad had tried Mandalay and since we assumed Burma Superstar would be packed, we figured another Burmese restaurant would be a good choice.

We came around 5pm on Father's Day and the place was not. too packed.  But as soon as we were seated they had a line out the door!

First off, the only gripe I have with them is the seating. We had a party of five and they seated us at a table that at most restaurants would not seat any more than 4 people.

I saw them do this with other groups, a couple and their son were seated at a two person table. I understand that the place was small and that the wait was long, but it was a tight squeeze.

The food was delicious though. Their honey walnut shrimp was probably the best I've had. The shrimp/prawns were huge and it was a nice crisp coating with a sweet glaze.

My dad ordered the tofu eggplant dish and it was also great. So great in fact I only had time to nab one piece of tofu before he ate it all. My mom ordered the whole fried fish. At first my dad and sister were hesitant but in the end only the fishes spine remained. They got a nice crunchy texture on the outside and the inside of soft and flaky.

The other dish we ordered was the Mandalay chicken, which reminded me of a typical orange chicken from chinese restaurants, but not as sweet. Still I would definitely ordered it again. Oh can't forget the delicious coconut rice. Always a must with south asian cooking!

Overall the food was excellent. Aside for the seating crampedness, the place was great!
author: Karma B.

description: This place is deliciousssss. Came with some friends on a Sunday afternoon and th place was hopping (might have been a lot of people out because B2B?). Love the tea leaf salad (it's great with lettuce) and if I could, I would have the mandalay special noodle every day. Four stars because service was fairly slow. Nevertheless, I'll be back!
author: Amy ..

description: Basically on par with Burma Superstar in every way except there is a much shorter wait.
author: Brian M.

description: Rangoon Ruby and Burma Super Star have been food and service.
author: Monica R B.

description:
Lots of people are devoted to Burma Super Star, but for my money Madalay is the place to be. I first heard about it several years ago through the office grapevine, from a colleague who'd grown up in the Richmond and had been going there forever.

The atmosphere is much more casual than the rival restaurant around the corner, brightly lit and colorfully decorated, with strings of lights, walls covered in framed engravings, and a huge alter in the foyer.

There is so much here that's just unmissable. For an App, I'm devoted to the Balada. I think every culture has some version of savory fry bread. This is the Burmese one, and it is wonderful: deep fried and delicious, paired with a sweet and spicy curry dipping sauce. 

The Tea Leaf and Rainbow salads are both wonderful. The Tea Leaf is exactly what it sounds like, cold cooked tea leaves, with crispy fried garlic chips, lentils and nuts. The Rainbow boasts some 20 ingredients, tossed table-side with a certain showmanship, and drizzled with lemon juice and a house dressing with a fish-sauce base. Pepper pot soup is also a really interesting dish.

For main course, my go-tos are Mango chicken and Mandalay noodle, both so good I have to admit I've done very little exploring.

Overall, this place offers great quality food at a better-than-average price, and as an added bonus, you can usually get in the door in a timely manner.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
The service does seem to be a big challenge for the place. Be prepared to experience some frustration and handle it, since they seem understaffed. At one point last night there was not ONE plate in the entire, fully packed restaurant that had food on it. My guess is that there was a kitchen malfunction and/or there aren't enough people staffed. The host also served as our server and required about 10-15 minutes of waiting after sitting down before being acknowledged again. Drinks eventually came out, which were almost finished before any appetizer came out. Ironically, I was prompted twice by the host/server about having another drink. Having been there on a Tuesday night, I can't imagine what the weekends are like. 

Despite all that, the food is excellent and although busy, the place is conducive to a nice meal. The staff were friendly. The Mandalay noodle dish was quite tasty. The "naked" eggplant was also good, but seemed plain relative to the other dishes offered. Started with Balada - the "crispy" pancake that is more flaky than crispy. Still, it was very good, especially with the accompanying curry sauce. As a side note, the decor is quite kitschy yet endearing - neon palm tree, ornaments hanging from ceiling, geode water fountain.

I will be back!
author: Ben C.

description:
Oh Mingalaba, you have some serious competition here! Burma Superstar was closed in between lunch and dinner hours so this seemed like the next best choice nearby, but I am thrilled that we came here on a whim! Plus, I just can't stand waiting in long lines for a table when I'm deliriously hangry! Got seated right away and although the menu and ambiance strongly resembles Mingalaba, the fantastic flavors and lively decor at Mandalay felt a little more authentic. It is a bit pricier and the portions seem a bit smaller compared to Mingalaba, but I thoroughly enjoyed every dish we ordered. Can't exactly compare both restaurants as they are located in very different cities and I have been long loyal to Mingalaba, but Mandalay definitely warrants another visit when I am in Pacific Heights. I appreciate that they accept reservations, which is becoming uncommon these days especially at popular restaurants. Overall, all their dishes were prepared fantastically - impressive flavor and not dripping in oil. 

Here's the must-try list:

- Balada (aka paratha or roti) - I prefer their easy-to-eat version which is cut like pizza and much thicker and filling compared to other places that serve a thin pancake. Curry dipping sauce pares beautifully well.

- Ong No Kaw Soi (coconut chicken noodle soup) - I have tried many times to recreate this dish at home, but it is always better at the restaurant. Soup is not too thick. Generous serving of fresh cilantro. I would try the Moo Hin Nga (fish chowder) next time.

- Mandalay Special Noodle - A brilliant combintion of flavor and texture, every ingredient (mixed table side) marries perfectly together with a very mild hint of spiciness.

- Walnut Prawn - Devoured this tower of prawns in minutes.
author: Ellie D.

description:
Came here for late lunch on a Saturday and had no trouble getting a table for two. AND found free parking on the street. Bonus! It's in a lovely neighborhood, I believe Laurel Heights?

My standard for Burmese food is Burma Superstar because frankly I'm not an expert haha. I've tried 3 other Burmese restaurants and have not been as impressed.  I think Mandalay is on the same level as Burma Superstar when it comes to the food.

We started off with the tea leaf salad, which was prepared in front of us. I don't know but I think this version is even better than Burma Superstar's. Really really really yummy. We also had the fish cakes which were good, but can skip next time. For main courses, we shared 3. The samusa soup (which they separated into 2 bowls... convenient!) was on par with Burma Superstar's, but based on my memory alone Superstar may have the edge on this dish. The tofu kebat was absolutely delicious, really impressed me as I don't usually eat tofu. Then a noodle dish Nan Gyi Dok with chicken, also very good. 

The dishes are a bit tiny but maybe because it was lunch? Or that I just ran 12 miles before that.. hmm. Anyway, we'll be back many times to Mandalay. Cannot wait to try the other dishes which include other cuisines such as Chinese and Singaporean.
author: Vol T.

description:
My first Burmese food experience was a great one. 

It can get crowded, so go early or order to go, but the food is worth the wait. 

The Rainbow salad is very good and the 20 ingredients go well together, even though some of them may have gotten overpowered by other things on the plate.  4 stars

Fried squash was good, batter was light and airy and zucchini was cooked perfectly even if it wasn't drained well and so was a little overly greasy. 4 stars

The Singapore style noodles were so tasty and a great mix of vegetables, chicken, pork and shrimp. I don't know why, but I have a hard time finding this dish, so order it when I see it. 5 stars

The Pumpkin chicken stew was decent though not a lot of pumpkin flavor. I think it would have been better if the pumpkin it was served in was cooked so that you could have eaten it. 3 stars

Coconut rice was so good, nice rich flavor! 5 stars

Thai iced tea was great too. 5 stars

Only complaint is that I think they forgot about our order. Once seated, we immediately ordered everything (we had been waiting for about 30 minutes so had plenty of time to study the menu) but 45 minutes later we had received nothing. But then less than 5 minutes after I asked a server where our food was she magically brought out our appetizers, saying the kitchen was busy. Meanwhile the table behind us which was seated at the same time was paying their bill and leaving! WTF. 

Same thing with the manager when he asked how the meal was. I said it was good but it took a long time to be served. He said kitchen was busy, no apology and no comped apps or drinks.

5 stars for the food, 3 for the service.
author: Russ C.

description:
My first Burmese experience. It was delicious and at a reasonable price. 

Mandalay Mango Chicken $10.50 (2nd best)

Mandalay Special Noodle $9.00 (THIS IS A MUST ) -taste a little bit like Mama's Ramen the Spicy Kind coz of the Lime Leaves

Bird Nest Seafood Delight $12.50 (this is quite flavorable and awesome)

Burmese Curry Beef $11.95 (very tender meat)

Rangoon Smoked Tea Duck $14 (dude I ordered this, and it was a total FAIL LOLL!! I only blame myself) Duck was a bit dry, just didn't like the Smoke duck effect.. it comes w/ hoisin sauce like pekin duck. 

Surprise Sweet Potatoe Dessert on the house. It smells like Mac and Cheese but tastes chewy and a little sweet. hahahah The smell is a turn off to a dessert. 

Most of their Menu is Spicy. 

Burmese Iced Tea $3 is just like a regular Thai Tea

Sangria is allllllllright. Had better, but they had logons and lychee bits in there :D
author: Jenna L.

description:
This place is on point!

Whenever I enter Mandalay, I am amazed that it's always busy whenever I come in.

I order and love:

The coconut drink that has the little tapioca pearls, veggie Samusas, Balada (like a thick roti) that comes with a delicious curry dipping sauce, Tea leaf salad, Mandalay Chicken, Walnut Prawns.

Parking typically takes a few circles but is worth it.
author: Solitaire M.

description:
Love it.  Every dish I have had is yummy.
The staff are friendly and helpful, they actually seem to like their customers.
One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.
The food is better than Burma Superstar.
I will return again and again.
Have the balada, samusa soup, tea leaf salad and rainbow salad!
Take friends and share a bunch of dishes, or
treat yourself to a special feast.
Try to go during lunch so the wait for a table is shorter.
author: Sheila L.

description:
Skip the wait at Burma Superstar and go to Mandalay. You WILL have to wait, as it is getting increasingly popular. We eat here way too often. As in, they say "good to see you" when we walk in and they already know half of the stuff we order. We have had just about everything on the menu, and it is all fantastic.

You must try the tea leaf salad, the papaya salad, the Mandalay special noodle, the string beans with tofu, and the ginger beef. But seriously, everything else is also outstanding. 

These people are incredibly hard-working and gracious and always make us feel welcome. We always take our out-of-town guests and they have never been disappointed.
author: Caroline G.

description:
I love this place. I would recommend coming here for lunch, since this place is packed during dinner time. I've tried this place 3 times and so far, they have been consistent with their quality of food. 

Drinks: Burmese Ice Tea = Thai Ice Tea (I Don't taste the difference) 
My brother and his friend ordered the Ginger Lemonade (Worth Trying) 

Not a Fan of the Tea Leaf Salad, too nutty for my taste 

I order this every time! Rangoon Beef, Very Tender and Juicy served with bell peppers

Braised String beans, Nice and Crispy mixed with their special sauce 

Lamb Curry, Surprisingly, it was not gamy at all and neither was it chewy 

Singaporean Noodle, Nothing Special 

Overall, I loved the Rangoon Beef, String Beans, and Curry Lamb 

Did I mention, my last visit was during dinner time. They seated my party of 4 on a table for 2. Making a somewhat uncomfortable dinner, we held onto our plates making room for the entrees.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Fish soup - 5/5
Teal Leaf salad 5/5
chicken mango 3/5
string beans 4/5
ambience 4/5
beef mandalay 1/5
chicken skewers 2/5
samusa 4/5
service 3/5

i dont see the point of reservations because you will have to wait anyway. you will get a seat faster if you come in multiples of two

the tea leaf salad is worth the wait.
author: Joe C.

description: Wow, try the balada pancake bread, rainbow, salad, and mango chicken. This is my favorite restaurant of the year so far. Definitely get the rainbow salad and balada bread!
author: Myra H.

description:
I love Mandalay...

That was gonna be my entire review for a second there! Honestly what more can I say? If you like Thai, Chinese and/or Indian food then Burmese food should be right up there too. Its a perfect mix of those flavors which in turn, becomes its own unique flavor. Its hard to explain but I've yet to find a friend of mine who did not like this food!

This place gets packed if you go later! Its very popular and with good reason! I don't want to go into reviewing all the dishes simply because everything I've ever ordered here was top notch. 

They have a little bit of everything for everyone whether you are vegetarian or a meat eater. The perfect example for me of how excellent Mandalay is to me would have to be their tea leaf salad. I'm not big on eating greens nor do I claim to be the most adventurous eater, but I cleaned my plate when I had the tea leaf salad!

Its an amazing mixture of different flavors and its close to my fam's other favorite business in the area; Green Apple Book Store!!
author: Paul E.

description:
This review is for December 2012

Tea leaf salad = 3.5 stars
Coconut rice = 5 stars
Asparagus chicken (spicy) = 5 stars
Service = 5 stars
author: Peter Y.

description: this is one of our favorite places to eat for sure!  so many good dishes with wonderful flavors and the waitstaff is very nice.  our favorite dishes are the mandalay chicken salad, samosas, mandalay special noodles, any shrimp dish, coconut rice and the walnut broccoli chicken.  the space is big so you don't feel crowded but because this place is so good you could wait awhile for a table so get there early. we've been going here for at least 8 years and it always satisfies.  the owner, sherry, and her husband are usually there and it's nice to chat with them.
author: jennifer l.

description:
"When the lights go down in the city... and the sun shines on the bay... do I want to be there... in my city... [and eat dinner at Mandalay]." -Journey

When people say they're visiting San Francisco to experience the hidden culinary gems within the city limits, I always say they must try Mandalay.  It excites me to say, "Have you ever tried Burmese?  It will change your life."  

The biggest challenge you'll face with Mandalay is finding street parking, but trust me, it's worth it.  To minimize your wait, call ahead and place your name on the list.  I order the same thing every time I go to Mandalay, and that's because I always over order (secretly it's to have leftovers).  

These are my must haves--tea leaf salad, mango chicken, mandalay special noodles & seafood string beans.  All of them are the bees knees.  If you have room for dessert, or in my case, if you just stop eating because you want to take leftovers home, order the mango sticky rice.  Numscious!!!
author: Melanie T.

description:
Hubby & I had our (semi) annual Christmas Eve dinner at Mandalay this year.  Unfortunately, lots of other families had the same idea!  We had to wait about 30 minutes, which was pure torture when you are confined to a small waiting area watching everyone dine on delicious Burmese dishes & all you can do is sit there & drool.  We contemplated sabotaging the reservation list, but in the end we sat quietly & waited for our table.

I already knew what I wanted to order:  Tea leaf salad, samusas, & the Mandalay Special Noodle.  Hubby ordered the chicken satay & mango chicken.  The hands down faves of the night were the tea leaf salad (so fresh & crunchy!) & the noodle dish.  My Burmese friend from work turned me on to this noodle dish recently & I can't get enough of it.  It consists of noodles, chopped chicken, coconut milk, onions, & lime juice.  Delicious!

The topper was the little bowls of mango pudding that they serve you at the end of the meal.  I was stuffed, but I can never say no to mango pudding!  It was even topped with peppermint whipped cream.  Nice touch.

I can't wait four our Christmas Eve dinner next year!  Although I don't think I can wait that long for those yummy noodles.
author: Erin S.

description:
There is probably nothing I can say about this restaurant that hasn't already been said, but I went here last night after the wait at Burma Superstar was 1.5 + hours, and was not disappointed. This place was only a few blocks away, and was just as tasty, if not better, than Burma Superstar. 

Salads: We had Rainbow salad, and Tea Leaf Salad. Both were exceptional. 

We also had the Mango Chicken, the Pumpkin curry (it was a daily special) that was AMAZING, and the basil prawns w/ coconut rice. This was the right amount of food for our group (4 very hungry people). & we all left completely satisfied (w/ some leftovers too!)

Went on a Sunday night, and the wait was around 20 minutes. Not too bad! 

Will definitely come here again!
author: Kelsey K.

description:
My first experience here today was great! 

We ordered coconut rice, Special Noodles, Samusas, string beans with shrimp, mango salad, green papaya salad, fish cakes, and Rangoon fish filet, which were all absolutely delicious.  We also ordered Lamb Curry, which was alright, but it wasn't very tasty due to the fact that it didn't fit in with the other dishes. OH yeah, the Balada with curry was reaaaaaaaaaally good!! In my opinion, everyone who goes there should order that as their appetizer!

And the dessert was yummy!

Overall, the service was great and servers were very friendly.
author: Tina R.

description:
Avoid the long wait at Burma Superstar a few blocks away and get food that's just as good if not better at Mandalay (Mandalay's TeaLeaf Salad is definitely superior!)

Most of the food is really good. Mandalay Chicken and Tea Leaf Salad are particular favorites of mine.

The service is friendly but sometimes a little ... odd. Not sure what it is. Not a major deal, but it's the only reason I give this place four stars instead of five.
author: Mara S.

description: The fried eggplant appetizer was absolutely delicious! Food was genuine and atmosphere was pleasant. A nice experience, food could have been slightly more tasty...
author: Cheryl Y.

description:
This place was recommended to us by my friend a few weeks ago and we finally got to go last night! All I kept thinking afterwards was, "I can't believe I've never been here"! ...Yes, it was that good!

We had a short wait of about 10 minutes before a table for four was available. The wait staff was helpful but seemed overwhelmed... I guess it was unexpected but the place was quite packed for a Monday night and only 3-4 wait staff. After much laughs, recommendations and decisions over what appeared to be a very simple yet yummy menu, we decided to order a few dishes to share.

To start, my mom and her friend got the hot and sour soup while my friend and I got the sizzling rice soup (with chicken, scallops and shrimp) as well as vegetarian samosas. I'm not a fan of hot and sour soup so I didn't try it but my mom and her friend really enjoyed it with the restaurant's special spicy chili paste. The sizzling rice soup was just divine... they bring out the soup and the rice separately and mix it at your table so that you can see all the sizzle the rice makes once it touches the soup! The samosas filled with soft potatoes while the shell was nice and crispy... YUMMY!!

For our entries, we got their Mongolian lamb, basil leaf beef, chicken yellow curry, walnut prawns and the naked eggplant. EVERYTHING WAS GOOD!! The lamb was tender but ridiculously spicy, my least liked dish. The basil beef was extremely tender and tasteful, to me more flavorful then the Mongolian dish. The potatoes in the chicken curry were cooked all the way through, so soft that it made the curry thick but not heavy making the chicken dish very tender and flavorful! The walnut prawns was more on the sweet side but oh so very good! Crispy and sweet on the outside, soft and warm on the inside, with a piece of walnut it was just perfection. My favorite dish of the night was the naked eggplant! Basically, the eggplant is peeled before it is dipped in this amazing batter and fried to perfection... DELICIOUS!!

Of course, we all had an order of what my friend deemed was the best rice ever... cooked with cinnamon, saffron, peas, carrots and raisins. It seemed to complement almost ever dish perfectly, I really enjoyed it. I was so full, I couldn't think of desert even though that desert menu looked tempting. I guess because we ordered so much food, we were given a complementary dessert, four small pieces of sweet potato cake made with a bit of milk, cream of wheat and topped with poppy seeds. When I could finally breath and took a bite, it was quite good for something deemed dessert rather than an appetizer.

All in all, I loved this place and plan to come back soon!! It is a bit pricey but you are getting your money's worth in my opinion!
author: Ms. Hala A.

description:
Do not go to this restaurant with an indecisive group of people because, with all the delicious options the menu offers, you will never get your order in!

I noticed that there were some service issues from the moment we walked in. But they were very minor and everyone was seated in good time. 

My friends and I went to this restaurant for dinner last night at around 7:15 and the place was starting to get pretty full. We spent about 10 minutes looking through the menu and trying to decide what to get because everything looked so good! We ended up ordering:

Balada (Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce): Wimilar to a roti. Warm, flakey, and delicious sauce to go with. Definitely a good appetizer. 

Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup (Coconut noodle soup with chicken, onion, cilantro, and lemon): tangy, coconuty-y, and much better if you add some cilantro in! The waitress helped us divide this soup into 5 bowls without us even asking, which was nice.

Pumpkin Curry with Pork: I believe this was one of the specials of the day. Pumpkin curry with chunks of pumpkin and pork served inside a small pumpkin. The name made the dish sound better than we thought it would be. While it was good, I wouldn't consider it anything special. 

Mango Prawn: Tastes exactly as it sounds. Tangy sweetness of the mango with savory prawns. Tasted good but also wasn't a dish that stuck out to me.

Walnut Broccoli Tofu: Broccoli and tofu cooked with ginger sauce and served with honey walnuts. A very different flavor with the kick of ginger and mildly spicy. Pretty good, and the ginger taste really made it different from other vegetable dishes I've eaten.

Mandalay Special Noodle (Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut tofu, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top): I would consider this the best dish of the night. Not sure how to describe it, but I would definitely eat this again.

We also ordered three bowls of coconut rice on the side, which was very good! I'm going to teach myself how to make this one day...

We were also given dessert on the house: sweet potato cake of some sort. Sweet and a good way to end our meal!


Left the restaurant with happy hearts and stomachs!
author: Reanna T.

description: I had never had Burmese food before visiting Mandalay, so I have nothing to compare the meal to, but everything was delicious with interesting flavors. Standout dishes include the shrimp with walnuts and the Mandalay special noodles. If this is what all Burmese food tastes like, then I'm a fan!
author: MZ ..

description:
Hands down my favorite Asian restaurant in the city!  Love to go here and love taking friends and out of town guests here for a taste of Burma. 

The food is always excellent.  Everything is always very fresh and comes out as it is ready.  Sherry and her husband are great hosts and always remember their returning guests.  It can get very busy in the evening especially on the weekends,  but it is worth the wait!

Every time we go we just order an array of food for the table and share. Some of our favorite dishes include:  vegetarian samosas and balada for appetizers,  mandalay chicken, naked eggplant (best eggplant dish i think I have ever had),  pan fried string beans, mongolian prawns, and burmese style fried rice.

We have been going here for the past 5 years or so.  My only complaint is that it is not closer to my house!
author: Jax B.

description:
Mandalay never disappoints! 

The food is consistently great and the service is always friendly and exceptional. You must have the Tea Leaf Salad. The presentation is beautiful and the flavors are so interesting and unique. This is an impressive dish.

Every dish I've had is fantastic. Lamb curry is great and and mango prawns are to die for. But you cant ho wrong with whatever you order. This restaurant id great for groups and of course the more friends you have the more dishes you can order to share!

The restaurant is intimate and very welcoming and the service is really fabulous. The employees are do gracious and accommodating. They treat you as a guest in their home. 

Take a trip to The Richmond and enjoy a wonderful Burmese meal.
author: Denise S.

description:
Rainbow salad
Tea leaf salad
Mandalay special noodles
Mandalay dry friend string beans with tofu

I enjoyed all of the above dishes. We also ordered the balada (think roti prata) and some sliced chicken dish (I forgot the name).

If you have been to Burma Superstar then you know how good the food is there but I'd say given the insane wait, Mandalay is not a bad alternative for tasty Burmese food.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Burmese food has become absolutely my favorite kind of food of the year! I love their tea leaf salads and coconut chicken noodles. Wait isn't bad at all. I love their service. This restaurant is the first Burmese restaurant in SF back in the day. Burmese food is like Indian, Thai, and Chinese mixed together. Very easy on the palette.

The Burmese iced tea was very yummy too. It's like thai tea with coconut milk in it. Jus t don't drink too much of it before your meal. The wait here isn't as bad as Burma Superstar's. Which is another good one very close by.

I would return back here to eat in a heart beat because that's how amazing their food is!
author: Ann V.

description:
I've never had so much Burmese food before moving to SF, but man is it good. Mandalay definitely didn't disappoint and I was overall pretty happy with the quality of food.

However, their tea salad (which you pretty much always have to get at any Burmese restaurant) was kind of weird. It didn't include any lettuce, so it felt almost like just a nut filled tea leaf sauce.

Besides that though, the service was attentive, the food came out extremely quickly, and we only ended up spending $50 something for 5 ppl. Will definitely go back to try other dishes!
author: Jono L.

description: Mandalay is the restaurant I take out of town guests to when we're craving delectable food without the marked up SF prices. The more people the better, because family style lets us taste the rainbow of flavors. The balada is like crack - I've eaten that sauce with a spoon and am not even that embarrassed. The lamb, seafood, and noodle dishes are also highlights. I think this place is better than Burma Superstar, and easier to get a table. The only thing that would make this place better is slightly bigger portions. And a location closer to my apartment.
author: Jane Z.

description:
I've been here twice. Both visits have exceeded my expectations.

The last visit, was with my less than adventurous but always willing to please boyfriend. It takes a lot of coaxing to get him to try something totally new, but if the restaurant is a slam dunk, he'll be a return customer and recommend it to everyone.

His dialogue went a little something like this:
"I don't wanna eat salad with no lettuce in it!" 
"WTF, 40 minute wait??" 
"Can't we just go to Olive Garden??" 
*Sits down* 
*Grumbles*
*Silence* 
"This is effin good. Wow. I gotta take my parents here."

My favorite dishes are the smoked duck, balada, special noodles, and tea leaf salad. Everything at Mandalay is like something you've never tasted before, yet its so comforting and delicious. It's like wearing a snuggie on a cold winter day. :)
author: Stacy S.

description: Have passed by this place numerous times but finally got a chance to stop in. Boy was it worth it. The food was wonderful and so was the service. Most dishes came out within 5-10 mins. They did forget to bring out a dish we ordered but it was worth the wait. We ordered mostly vegetarian dishes and all were great. Spicy tofu with vegetables was delicious. I was so full that I didn't have room for dessert. Will definitely go back again and will save room for dessert.
author: Deepa W.

description: Mandalay has big shoes to fill. The shoes are those of Burma Superstar's. I have had tea leaf salad at many places and I did not like the famous "tea leaf salad" here. It is pricier than Yamo but cheaper than Burma Superstar. I also had the 'Mandalay Special Noodle' which was so-so as well, not what I had heard from my acquaintances. However, I really enjoyed the dish which I least expected to be nice, which was the Spicy Tofu with Vegetables, which by far was the star of the show.In a nutshell, I 'd rather spend my time and money to eat at Burma Superstar.
author: Ankit R.

description: 4 of us ate at Mandalay tonight and thought it fabulous. definitely get the tea leaf salad. Actually, get 2 orders of it.  It was incredibly wonderful.  All of the food was excellent. It's a very popular restaurant; so make reservations or plan to wait in line for a while.
author: Da H.

description:
This is a great option over Burma superstar! There is rarely much of a wait and the restaurant isn't as crowded/cramped. They take reservations which helps :) 

Certain dishes here are better than Superstar and others aren't quite as good. My friends seem to like tea leaf salad here more. 

The only downside is that they do not have as many vegetarian options for me.
author: Angela K.

description: I was excited to try this Burmese restaurant I'd never heard of but left bummed. We ordered tea salad, coconut tapioca drinks, coconut rice and the rice noodle dish with tofu. We told the waiter 3 times we were vegan but the dish tasted like fish sauce. The tea salad had no lettuce or cabbage so it was really heavy but the drink and rice were good. Also, when I tried to take a photo if the tea salad, the waitress said "no photos". Weird. The waiter was not helpful and nothing was comped for the mistake. Restaurants should know what vegan and vegetarian mean. We won't be going back. Bummer.
author: Josie L.

description:
One of the best spots for burmese food in SF!

I've been here 2-3 times in the past few years. Mainly because it's in the other side of the city in Richmond and parking is just horrible here. Besides that, its a can't miss!

Their milk tea here is like thai milk tea i'd say. My favorites are their fried rice and that entree number 1 or 2, i just know its noodles with all these things mixed together with their coconut chicken. So damn good! 

Their service = awesome. always open to give suggestions whenever I cant seem to decide. Lastly, i'd say minus one star though because last time i came, i ordered before the couple next to me and they got their food before me. for some reason, it just took extra long. that sucks, cuz i was starving that day!
author: Kenny L.

description:
They have great food, but WEIRD policies.  I have a friend who wanted to see the Tea Leaf Salad before it was mixed and the waitress would not allow us to take a picture of the food.  "No pictures, it's against policy".   Whatever.  All the Burmese restaurants I've been to serve Tea Leaf Salad.  It's not like it's a secret and they're the only ones to come up with such a thing.  So WEIRD and frankly turned me off.  Good food, but weird policies.   Hmmm. I wonder if Burma Superstar would allow me to take a pic?? In the meantime, my friend found a pic of said salad right here on Yelp.  Ugh.  Your Tea Leaf Salad is NOT a secret!  Get OVER yourselves!  

But yeah, the food is good, so they get 4 stars.  :P
author: Lori B.

description: Always spectacular food and wonderful service! Don't miss the Tea Leaf Salad, Rainbow Salad, and if they have it as a special, the Banana Flower Salad. The Mandalay Special Noodles and Bird Nest Seafood Delight are our favorite entrées. On the weekend, if you have a party of 4 or more, make reservation, it gets very busy!! Special thanks to waitresses Sherry and Joyce for always making dining at Mandalay a special treat!!
author: Cary R.

description:
YUM. I took the bf here for lunch and our stomachs were left happy :). I went to Mandalay ~2 years ago for my birthday dinner and it was nice. They even played "Happy birthday" for me in Burmese (?).  

AMBIANCE
Very serene. The tables are far enough to ensure intimacy and the decor is awesome. 

SERVICE
Pretty attentive. Nothing to complain about.

FOOD
We ordered the mango salad + walnut broccoli chicken lunch combination and a special of the day, lychee coconut prawns. They were all really flavorful. It was like a flavor party for my palate!

Mango salad: had mangoes (of course), cucumbers, cilantro, green and white onions. It was a tangy and sweet blend of tastes. If you've had papaya salad, the taste is sort of similar (but no spice!). Pretty refreshing.

Walnut broccoli chicken: I love walnuts! They were crisp and the broccoli + chicken were made fresh. The dish has a sweet and sour taste to it, with a little bit of spice.

Lychee coconut prawns: I know...lychee?! But I love trying different dishes so we decided to go for it. The dish is a bit small for the price I suppose ($12.50 or something like that) but it was yum. It was like a curry--the closest thing I can relate it to is Thai panang curry. The lychee was stuffed with shrimp (6 of them) and pineapple slices were sprinkled in between.  The lychee brought a sweet burst of flavor to the curry and shrimp. I really loved how the sweetness of the lychee (and pineapple) complemented the dish. The shrimp tasted slightly overcooked but it was still good.

I didn't try any of their drinks...but next time!

PARKING
Sucks.

I can't wait to come back to try more dishes! Too bad I don't live in SF...
author: Mads N.

description:
The mango chicken is delightful! Paired with the spicy chilis, it's a taste bud explosion in your mouth!

Young coconut!!

Definitely would come back here instead of waiting for Burma SuperStar.
author: Moraia W.

description:
The servers were so sweet here. The server even made a joke when he took our group photo. 
My first time dining here and I have nothing bad to say about the dishes. TEA LEAF salad and RAINBOW salad were so colorful and delicious!
The meat dishes and veggie dishes were also just as good. 
Gosh, I never say much about the rice but the coconut rice was cooked perfectly. The fragrance and its snow white color was good in itself.
I really enjoyed having Burmese cuisine here.
*Celebrate with a glass of red sangria. There is also lychee in it!
author: Oanh N.

description:
Since you are supposed to save your big milestone reviews for important places, I've been holding on to this one for a few months now. Review #100 goes to Mandalay, easily one of my favorite places in SF. There was a period when I was going out to the Richmond up to three times a week to eat here before I realized that I might have a problem and toned it down to once every couple of weeks. Oh please, like you haven't done that before. If there's anything worth a six hour bus ride out into the land of fog and Russians, it's Mandalay.

After so many visits, I pretty much have my order down: Tea leaf salad (this is key), pan fried green beans, and the Mandalay noodles. The samusa soup, mango chicken, and walnut broccoli are all excellent dishes as well, but it's hard to beat the core three elements above. Their dishes are great for family-style sharing, and the servers will let you add a half order of something to make sure there's enough to go around.

Service here is consistently great, especially Raymond, who seems to always be there. He reminds me of a Burmese Gilbert Gottfried but in a not weird way. He's never made a dish recommendation that wasn't spot on, and will make sure you leave well fed and happy. They take reservations, although even without one you can get in pretty quickly, especially compared to Burma Superstar.

So speaking of Burma Superstar, I think I've made it longer in my review without mentioning them than anyone else so far. I kind of feel bad for Mandalay because they are always described as "Burma Superstar without the wait." I feel like we should more accurately be saying "Burma Superstar is like Mandalay but with a ridiculous wait."
author: Mark A.

description:
I can only say good things about this restaurant? Why? Well, apparently, I came here for the first time in 2009 and didn't remember the name of the place, but I'd often reference how awesome the satay was and how much I enjoyed my experience here.

Well, after a day of wandering through the gardens in Golden Gate Park, our group wandered over here for food. We all split the vegetarian dishes and were thoroughly impressed with everything! It was all sooooooo very good. The dining experience here is great because even though the place is small, the experience is slow and enjoyable. You are brought your food dish by dish and have a chance to enjoy everything on your own time. This is good and bad. Good because you get to enjoy the company you bring, bad because you devour the early courses and end up too full for the later courses.

I think my favorite the second time around was the samosa soup and the balada...of man, the curry here is to die for. Yummy Yummy!!
author: Lily K.

description:
I was really disappointed with this place after hearing so many good things about it.  The first time we went we called in and placed our name on the list.  When we arrived it was packed with people and our name was nowhere on the list.  After waiting for 30 minutes with little movement we left and went somewhere else.  

Second time we went we were also on the list but had to wait about 20 minutes.  When we finally arrived at our table it took a long time for a waitress to take our order.  It then took a long time to get our food.  The people at the table next to us who came later got their food before us.  The food was ok.  But the service left a lot to be desired.  The décor is nice.
author: Karen B.

description:
For those of you who haven't discovered Burmese cuisine, I highly recommend Mandalay.  It's the better of the two Burmese spots in the area.  I've tried both and not to take away from you-know-who but I find Mandalay less trendy and more genuine.  The staff is so nice and hard working.  I mostly go for lunch but be prepared to wait a bit for dinner.  The food is awesome!
My favs are the samosas, walnut prawns, coconut rice and mandalay pork.  The desserts are yummy too.  Most seafood dishes come loaded with veggies and everything always tastes fresh and delicious.  Wash it down with a Burmese iced tea (same as Thai iced tea) and you're set.  The prices won't break you and street parking can be OK if you're willing to walk.
author: Pablo R.

description:
I'm not a Burmese food expert, but I do know when tastes and textures make me happy, and all the dishes we ordered for our family lunch today had me smiling from ear to ear. 

*Tea leaf salad -- apparently the only "traditional version" in the city sans romaine lettuce. Loved the crunch of the lentils and peanuts and the restraint with which the chef seasoned the dish. Mouth watering for me. 
*Rainbow salad -- very tasty though my least favorite of what we ordered today. More noodles than I expected but had great flavor.
*Moo hin nga -- the favorite soup for half of the fam. Lots of umami with a creamy and smooth broth texturized with the broken noodles and ground catfish. The freshness of the cilantro and lemon are perfect to balance out the richness of the soup.
*Samusa soup -- the fave of the other half of the table. Smaller serving than the Moo hin nga (so order two if this is the only soup order for a group of 4-5). Tasty. Spicy. Perfect. 
*Seafood with green beans -- delicious wok-tossed dish of scallops, squid, and shrimp with cut green beans in a semi-spicy shrimp paste sauce. Fantastic execution. All the seafood was cooked perfectly. 
*Rangoon lamb -- my absolute favorite dish of the day! Tender pieces of marinated lamb sautéed with tomato, onions, bell pepper, and chili topped with fresh cilantro. This dish hits the tongue as sweet, then follows with slight saltiness, then a finish of subtle spice. Perfect. Getting this every time. 
*Mandalay special noodle -- hubby's favorite dish. Toothsome noodles in a chicken curry sauce with a hint of lime and topped with crunchy noodles. It's a toss up between this and Mission Chinese's squid ink noodles for my favorite noodle dish in the city (including all pasta from SPQR). 

Final bill for a party of 5: just under $100. 

Excited to try the banana leaf salad, lamb curry, okra prawn, and Mandalay chicken salad. 

Added pro: they take reservations. Was craving Burma Superstar but didn't want to risk having to wait in the cold if there was a wait (cuz there's ALWAYS a wait). Found Mandalay on Yelp, called at 11:30am for a 12:30pm reso on President's day and was seated immediately when we got there at 12:28pm. LOVE! This is my new favorite restaurant.
author: Nini G.

description:
We don't get out this way much and when we do we often forget about this great place. First of all, service is ALWAYS excellent. The folks are friendly from initial greeting to saying multiple thank yous and goodbyes!! Service is very attentive, so if you even remotely glance at one of the servers, they will be over faster than you can say excuse me.

The food is pretty excellent as well. We almost always have the tea leaf salad, and yes, as noted from other reviewers, it does have a lot of peanuts - which we like. It's not much of a traditional salad per se and the tangy flavor is definitely not something most folks are used to but it's good none the less. We've never been here for dinner, so for our lunch entrees this time we ordered the Mandalay Noodle and Singapore Noodle dish. Both were very good. The Singapore noodle leans more towards a Pad Thai (orange color) tangy flavor rather than the usual yellow curry flavor of most Chinese styles. The Mandalay Noodle was saucey with a curry coconut flavor, with bits of diced chicken sprinkled with some fried noodled. The dish could have done without the fried noodle bit, but was still very tasty and flavorful. 

This is a great place and I will one day come and try it for dinner.
author: Jack D.

description: WOW this place is fantastic. Great food and reasonable prices. Huge selection, but everything we've tried has been delicious. Thanks Mandalay!
author: Zoe F.

description: Five stars. Great Burmese that (if my memory is correct) predated Burma Superstar in the neighborhood. Very friendly service, big dining room so it's usually busy but easy to get in, too. Affordable and satisfying.
author: Matt C.

description: Ate here right before going to Crissy Fields.  No line on a Saturday for lunch.   We had the duck... Delicious a must get.   The Special Noodles were great the sauce was perfect. Great service also.
author: Shabana J.

description: Most delicious food in the city. Have brought multiple people from out of town here and everyone loves it. The tea leaf salad is amazing. Strangely, the Singapore Noodle was also the best I've had anywhere. I say "strangely" because we were all skeptical of ordering something off that menu that you can get at any Asian restaurant and it's usually just average. There hasn't been a single thing I've tasted that I haven't loved.
author: B B.

description: Tea leaf salad. It's been 2 years since I ate there? I still think about the tea leaf salad. I miss it all the way from Colorado.
author: Merrilee T.

description:
Ahh this place... I didn't know more Burmese restaurants existed past Burma Superstar but this place seriously takes the cake. There wasn't a crazy wait, but that's not even the thing. What's great about this place is just the amazing, amazing food that they have. You just feel so comforted and happy. I am a fan of:

- Mandalay Special Noodle - almost like a salad but with noodles, loved the lime touch because it kept me eating more and more
- Ong No Kaw Soi (coconut chicken noodle soup) - hearty and warm

I had a few other things that were pretty good too (rainbow salad, duck, beef curry) but those 2 dishes above were the ones that sold me. Next time I go, I'll probably just eat a plate of my own special noodle and call it a meal.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I'm not sure if my tongue is suffering from the-need-of-over-spiced-food syndrome or is it just that Mandalay is too careful about how much they 'spiced' up their dishes. I have to admit that the dishes served here are remarkable. As tasty as it can be, the catfish chowder is the right choice to start my evening meal. It's my first time trying out the Burmese chowder, and when I thought it could be as thick as a clam chowder, it's of lighter weight, more brothy than creamy. Served with cilantro and lemon on the side and an ample amount of chili. 

Unlike Burma Superstar (I hate comparing restaurants, but here I go), Mandalay lacks that punch of ingredients put into their curry. We ordered the seafood curry with shrimps. The bowl that came in, sits on a big dinner plate adorned with some boiled broccoli, sliced tomatoes and cucumbers. Size of bowl is smaller than our bowl of saffron rice. Despite that, they are pretty generous with the shrimps...countable maybe..8? not bad. 

Then, here's a funny part of the dinner. I want some Burmese salad, and my girl wants some Burmese samosas. So we did a treaty-the Burmese Samosa Salad. Waiter made it clear that it'll come with 2 pieces of samosas, chopped up and tossed in the salad. Mandalay's manager passed by, overheard our waiter and corrected him that it's actually FOUR samosas not TWO. Wellll, sounds perfect. Salad came in some while later and there was the obvious 2 triangular pieces of samosas on the bed of salad and some cucumber fritters. Where's the other two? Supposed to be four isn't it? We thought maybe the other two got chopped up much smaller and disappeared into the salad. We digged em up, but in vain.

"Excuse me, there's only two samosas here, didn't the manager just said we'll get four?"

nervous giggles "yea! I know she must've misunderstood it, but I'm sure I said two and I'm sure It'll only come in two. I always see the salad comes with only two samosa. Maybe she's not sure. I'm sure.. yea sorry. so sorry. But you get only two samosas" more giggles.

OKAY then. 

Service is 5*. I love how friendly and attentive everybody is over at Mandalay. The manager's great, always come around the tables and customers and make sure that everyone's doing okay. Servers are really polite and efficient. 

Place is busy, but tables aren't squeezed so we won't bump into one another. Overall, I like this place. Maybe I haven't hit the bull's eyes with my food. I should try ordering other items and we'll see...
author: Rika P.

description: I had the Mango Chicken: tender, slightly crispy, and very flavorful -- excellent. The coconut rice makes for a good accompaniment.
author: Paul L.

description:
I was really disappointed b/c the yelp reviews for this place were really good.  But then I came here and it felt so overrated.

Maybe the good reviews all came from the er... non-Asian race b/c frankly, I've had better.

We ate the samusa - typical, though a tad salty.

The lychee shrimp was $14 for 5 shrimps and a few pieces of canned lychee and pineapple.  The portions were really small like when they plate food on Top Chef for just Padma to sample.  

The Mandalay noodles were luke warm temperature and small.  A little too sweet for my taste.

Everything tasted so sweet - and not in the good way.

FYI - Burmese iced tea is NOT "thai ice tea but better." It's just thai iced tea.

Price was not bad.  2 apps, 2 entrees, 2 non-alcoholic drinks came out to $50.
author: Tina L.

description:
I was excited to try this place after seeing the review on Check Please Bay Area.  For those who want to try this place because of the TV show, I would say skip it.  This place is not worth it,and ought to be called Mandalame!
The food is okay but the service is horrible - long waits for tables, and even longer waits for food.  

We made reservations for 6:30 pm, and we didn't get seated until 7 pm even with the reservations.  So my question is this: why bother having a reservation system if you are not going to honor it?

Once we were seated, we had to wait a long time for the menus, an even longer time for our order to be taken, and even longer for the food to appear.  Other people who were seated later than us received their food first.  Food pacing was slow - there was a 20 minute gap between the time the appetizer came out and the actual meal.  The last dish appeared 30 minutes after everything else.  Once we got our food, the waiters than rushed us to leave - collecting dinner plates even before everyone in the party was done eating! our water glasses were not refilled at all, even though they were empty half way through the meal.   it was really hard to get their attention and I think that maybe the extra publicity they received from Check Please has really hurt their service levels.  i did notice that the "regulars" got better service and even received wine while they were waiting for their table.  

Portions here are incredibly small and given the poor service and the small portions this place just isn't worth the visit - spend your hard earned dollars elsewhere and have a better experience.  You pay just as much as the "regulars" for your dinner so there's no point in feeling like a second class citizen while you are having your meal. 

Here's a breakdown on the food; keep in mind that all the portions are super small so you might want to eat first before coming!:

Balada - excellent sauce but the pancake itself was too greasy.
burmese style curry chicken - too salty, and more potatoes than chicken.This dish should have been called burmese style curry potatoes.
Crispy chicken - no complaints
Mandalay special noodles - tasty homemade noodles.
walnut brocolli tofu dish -  Good flavor but too much corn starch and the sauce was too goopy.

I am off to try burma superstar on my quest for superior burmese food and service.
author: Bebe W.

description:
We get the tea leaf salad and Mandalay special chicken noodles every time. I prefer their tea leaf salad over Burma Superstar's, against everyone's popular belief. While Burma does have some great flavors, their wait is dreadful and Mandalay is comparable on some of the dishes with little to no wait, so we go there almost every other weekend.

And the mango lassi is SO fantastic!!!!
author: Carrie B.

description:
I came here after my graduation 2 years ago and I revisited today with some friends. It may look awkward and not very appetizing on the outside. But hey, don't judge a book by it's cover! The decorations inside are really cool and pretty. The dishes are extrememly sophisticated. Even the bathroom is neat, clean, and has nice decorations.

The service was without a doubt, amazing! We ordered the hot and sour soup, the waitress helped serve the soup into little bowls. We also ordered the Mango Chicken which was extrememly tasty! The walnut prawn plate and coconut rice are both very good. But the Cin Man Jaw wasn't so good. 

Lunch specials are only on Mon-Fri. 
It's about $10-$15 per person. I would recommend family style so you can taste a bit of everything. 

Damn, burmese food is good. But after we left to get desert, we realized that we forgot to give tip to the awesome waitresses. I still feel really bad about it. Next time, I'll definitely leave extra tip!!

I also really want to try the Tea Leaf Salad next time!
author: Kelly H.

description: Solid Burmese food in a cute location. I still prefer the tea leaf salad and noodles at Burma Superstar. Not a bad option if you don't want to deal with lines.
author: Pearl L.

description:
went here because the wait for burma superstar was too long, but I think I actually like mandalay better.

Tea leaf salad is awesome and their samusa soup is AMAZING! So many textures and flavors, this stuff is awesome!
author: Caroline D.

description:
Been hear a few times and unfortunately (for me) it looks like Mandalay is gaining its own popularity instead of just the Burma Superstar leftovers. 

I actually prefer the tea leaf salad here to Burma and they have a fun offering of specialty drinks (though pricey). The food is very tasty and always on my list to take visitors when they are in town.

Minus one star for not understanding the meaning of a reservations and the lack of a functioning seating system.
author: Raina B.

description:
A friend took me here for a birthday dinner, and what a treat! Burma Superstar gets all the buzz, but honestly, I think it's just the love of Burmese cuisine. 

We had the tea leaf salad (because you kind of have to), the samosa soup (a hot and sour-ish vegetable soup with bits of samosa), and a duck dish...ooooh, the duck! It came with a lovely presentation: a tower with kamboucha pumpkin on the bottom, wilted spinach in the middle, and oh-so-crispy duck on top, surrounded by a moat of a light mango sauce. Over coconut rice, you're looking at a remarkable dinner indeed.

The place was hopping and service was a little disjointed, but always friendly, and water glasses always full! I work nearby and will definitely be getting some take-out once in a while.
author: Jen D.

description: Good food but way too expensive. Plus they get/encourage you to order more than you really need. The bill really adds up.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Definitely a good place to try new things.

To be honest, I have never heard of restaurants that are Burmese Food specific, let alone heard of Burmese Food, but this was a good first time trying the cuisine.

When my family and I arrived, it was pretty busy around late dinner time, so we had quite a wait for a party of 4. The restaurant decor reminded me of any usual asian restaurant.

For our order, we went for the [Sorry I don't remember the exact name] group package dinner that serves dishes according to the number in your party. There were 4 of us, so we had an appetizer, chicken skewers, beef and vegetables, soup, fish, and some other vegetable dish. The wait for our food actually took a while after we received our drinks (not a large beer menu for you beer drinkers out there)

The appetizer is a salad of mixed nuts (Let's all be grown-ups for a second lol) and other things, a dish that our waitress says is one of the most popular for the restaurant. I'm a very picky eater so it took a while to try it, but when I did it was actually pretty good. I would definitely recommend it for anyone's visit. If you call soup an appetizer, I'll list that here too. I've never had a soup before like the one they served. It was a chicken noodle soup. Coconut milk was a very prominent flavor, but I hear that coconut milk is a staple in Burmese cooking. It was very chunky, it was a good thing. I've never been a fan of coconut "anything", but this is a good exception.

Then comes the main course, in this situation, courses. I found the Mandalay Beef pretty good, the sauce that it was served in was very good. The BBQ chicken, I found to be just okay though, I did not find anything special about it. I didn't really get to the fish, nor the vegetables. Even though it was meant for four people, it was definitely more than enough, probably even for five.

So for first time going for Burmese food, I had an overall good meal. The visit supplied me with a lot of firsts. It can however be a little pricey, especially for the party servings, 20+/person. Anyone should try it!
author: Robert O.

description:
great place, great food
gets crowded as people realized it's as good if not better than burma superstar and bstar with more seating.
author: El T.

description:
Great place for a family dinner!!! Quick friendly service and all sorts of foodie deliciousness !!!

BASIL PRAWN
prawns were a bit small, but still tasty with the basil sauce

FISH FILET W/BLACK BEAN SAUCE
chunks of breaded fish w/an intense black bean sauce and mixed veggies

ASPARAGUS SPICY CHICKEN
makes your pee smell, but totally worth it!

BURMESE STYLE NOODLE (KAW SOI DOK)
egg noodles w/fried onion, fried garlic chips, cucumber slices & grounded split beans. my favorite dish!!

SPICY TOFU W/VEGETABLES
can't go wrong with big pieces of fried tofu!

DRY PAN FRIED STRING BEAN W/TOFU
strings beans, ginger in a chili sauce
author: Tien T.

description: Fantastic service, food, drinks!  We arrived late, around 8:30pm, but were seated within 5 minutes. Our order was taken and the delish foid arrived right away! We lived the tea leaf salad!!
author: Audrey M.

description: Absolutely delicious! We literally just left and I couldn't wait to leave a review. We ordered the Burmese ice tea (A), coconut milk with tapioca (too sweet for me, but husband loved it), tea leaf salad (unique and delicious), string beans with shrimp, calamari and scallops (mouthwatering-- i would lick the plate), and noodles with shrimp, chicken, veggies, and egg (vert good). Would definitely come back.
author: Julia T.

description: By far one of my favorite hot and sour soup spots in the city. Filled with shrimp, pork, mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and tofu you can't go wrong! Came out to $10 bucks but money is no option when it comes to suppressing my cold and sore throat. Definitely will be back to try the rest of the menu!
author: Nick L.

description: Lovely Burmese dishes. Rainbow salad with 20 ingredients was fantastic. We had the noodle dish #3 from the menu and it was superb. The mango prawns were not my fav as the mango was not super flavorful and soft but everything else was delicious. I will definitely go again and will recommend to friends. It is not a fancy restaurant but clean and very friendly.
author: lmej p.

description: This place is super authentic.  They make you feel like you're in Burma.  I now know what it's like to live in Burma and want nothing more than potable water.  The service he just sucks.  They don't fill your water unless you ask.  Then it takes five minutes.  Once it took over a half hour after being seated for them to bring our table water.  The food is also pretty slow to come out.  I have been here four or five times and despite the service I will keep coming back because the food is absolutely amazing .  The Tea Leaf Salad is a must.  Pretty much everything I have had has been incredible.  I would have not hesitated giving five stars if not for the service.  I would recommend this place to anyone.  Definitely check this place out.  When you eventuality get your food you wont regret it.  It's worth the wait.
author: Isaac S.

description:
We had our first bad service experience in this place last night. It's too bad that one server's behavior affects everyone's reputation in this business. I love eating here, but if attitude is also in the menu, then I'll have to pass. If mixing our tea leaf salad takes too much effort and makes one bitter, then please let us mix it ourselves. We only want good food and positive vibes on our table.

Really the best!
Try the tea leaf salad and the fish chowder soup, you can't go wrong starting with those. Drink the ginger lemonade.  LOVE this place. Warning, there's always a line, so be prepared to wait.
author: Jonsey B.

description:
I have never been to Burma Superstar, and after trying Mandalay I probably never will. 

The food here was delicious. We had a group of 5, all ordered our own dishes and shared them. The portions could probably be enough for 2 people as we had a lot of leftovers. Every single dish we had was delicious, and there's no use having me describe it all, you simply must go and try it yourself.

We came on a Saturday evening. Even with a reservation made we had to wait about 15 minutes to sit. The lady running the front was kind enough to take our order as we waited for a table, which definitely sped up service. Someone else complained about being rushed. We weren't at all. In fact, I must say the service was excellent. We were checked on multiple times, our water glasses were never even close to being empty and there were waiters constantly walking by if you needed to get someone. They really do try to make good use of their space to get as many people in as possible. 

The drinks here are yummy as well. 

Will be going back.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
TLDR:
- Hilariously overhyped.
- Very boring food. Burmese food is supposed to be full of striking flavors from SW China, Thailand, and neighboring countries. Pathetic homage.
- Overpriced, over-salted.
- Tasteless tea leaf salad that features crushed nuts over tea leaves. Where's the rich fermented flavor?
- Waitstaff too chill for their popularity.
- Wait was long. Food wait even longer.
author: Christopher L.

description: Amazing ginger salad. Started going here in the mid-1980's. Just went back a couple of weeks ago. Still amazing!
author: Partho G.

description: This is a nice alternative to B Star/Burma Superstar. The wait isn't as long and you're still getting your burmese fix. I don't find their food AS fresh as B*Star but they do make killer green beans, which keeps me coming back!
author: Maggie F.

description:
Went here on a Fri night, made reservations just earlier that day for a party of 3.  GLAD i did so... because they are a surely busy!  

Ordered a few things, Samosas, Mandalay noodles, Rangoon three ingredients, and pumpkin duck. 

Food was excellent quality, the portions were on the small side.  I could have probably ordered another dish and shared it among the three of us simply because I just wasnt that full.  

Service was as expected for an asian restaurant, but i never really go to Asian restaurants for service.  It's almost expected to not have service, and if they can refill your water without having to ask twice, that's a A for me!  

One weird thing, Server didnt allow us to take photos of the food.  No photos of the food to an asian group of friends is like bringing a kid to a candy store and not allowing them to eat it.  Just saying....

Overall, would try it again.  Want to try different stuff, and probably would order a little more just to satisfy my palette.
author: Barb B.

description:
Why take a trip to Burma for the good food when you can enjoy that at Mandalay!  An establishment which has been around in S.F. for many years, this place is really worth a try!  Mandalay has a casual atmosphere and is good for groups since it has a large dining area that can accommodate big parties.

Some of their tasty dishes include:

*  Lap Pat Dok (Tea Leaf Salad) -  Their signature dish.  A delicious, pungent combination of Burmese tea leaves toasted with lentil seeds, ground shrimp, fried garlic chips, peanuts, sesame seeds, green peppers, and a special dressing which is all prepared by the server right in front of your eyes!  A wonderful salad!

*  Balada -  A Burmese pancake which is pan fried with a crispy outer layer, accompanied by a delicious curry dipping sauce.  Not too greasy.  One of my favorites!

*  Rainbow Chicken -  Tender pieces of pan fried chicken breast with slices of fresh, sweet mangoes, pineapples, and an assortment of vegetables.  Yum!

*  Pan Fry Okra Prawns - Good-sized pan fried prawns sauteed with okra in a ginger and garlic spicy sauce.

*  Mandalay Beef -  Tender slices of lean beef sauteed in a tasty garlic hot sauce.

*  Mandalay Dry Pan Fried String Beans -  String beans dry fried and sauteed with spicy seasonings.

*  Basil Spicy Eggplant -  A great vegetable dish with tender, juicy pieces of eggplant sauteed in a spicy sauce. 

*  Own Ta Mein (Coconut Rice) -  A must!  The coconut flakes provide a very subtle but flavorful addition to your rice and melds well with all the various Burmese dishes.

The service is relaxed but well paced.  Parking can be a little tough so please allow time or take public transportation as the restaurant is conveniently located on California St. at 6th Avenue.  Prices are reasonable with most dishes, excluding seafood choices, about $10 or less.  Enjoy!  You'll have an amazing meal!
author: Karen L.

description:
The food is out of this world amazing. Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup) is the best soup I have EVER consumed. The Balada was flaky and fresh, loved the curry dipping sauce. The Rangoon Beef was (of course) delicious too. Very happy food coma.

Minus one star for VERY confusing service. No consistency there, but I gotta say I prefer this place over Burma Superstar! Quite a long wait so don't come here with someone you can't talk stand being around for a long time.
author: Briana F.

description:
Mandalay feels a bit like a Burmese version of TGI Fridays.  They've got drinks with umbrellas, they sing happy birthday to birthday diners with a pre-recorded background track on the speakers, and the menu has helpful little pictures of each dish.

That all said, the food is pretty good.  We had the ginger salad, the papusa salad, and the Mandalay Special Noodles.  The ginger salad was nice, though ultimately not as good as you find at Nan Yang in Rockridge (full disclosure: I've been going to Nan Yang since I was a kid when it used to be in Oakland Chinatown, so I have strong and undoubtedly biased memories of the food).  The pupusa salad was a waste of time -- it just didn't work on any level.  The Mandalay noodles were really nice and are clearly the "no-brainer" dish you're supposed to order every time you go.

We finished it all off with fried bananas and ice cream.  If I had known it was going to be strawberry ice cream rather than coconut, I never would have bothered.  Still, dessert is dessert, and I'll eat it without too much complaining.
author: Laurence W.

description:
The best sampling of Burmese cuisine I've had to date. The Mandalay Special Noodles are so good you'll be telling everyone at your table, like how they do in the Cheez-It commercials, "get your own box," but in this case it would be "plate." Seriously, this dish is so good you'll find it difficult to share and you'll want to eat it all on your own. The balada (roti) and curry dipping sauce is also some of the best roti I've had and they don't skimp on the portions. Salads: the rainbow salad is very good and the tea leaf salad is also a winner but will have your jaws sore when you've finished from all the chomping and crunching on all of the nuts and seeds. The pumpkin curry with chicken is quite delicious. Moo hin nga soup is a tasty option if you are looking for a relatively light starter to your meal.

The service here is always great, friendly and super polite.
author: Erich D.

description: First time I've tried Burmese food.  I didn't really know what to expect, but it is very thai influenced.  The rainbow salad was surprisingly good, even though I'm not a salad person.  Coconut rice is really delicious and the mandalay noodles were my favorite.  Beef curry was not bad as well (very tender beef).
author: Wes Y.

description: The ambiance was SO nice. I really appreciated the time spent decorating the place-- it really gave it character. The staff was very friendly and WOW the Mandalay Special Noodle was delicious. I've been to Burma Superstar three times and this is SO much better. The ingredients were delicious and the presentation was great. Will definitely be returning and this is my new favorite Burmese location!
author: Lissette L.

description:
I been wanting to try this place for awhile and finally found a good night to check it out. Food was split between 3 girls.

Balada - kinda like roti canai. light bread  with a yummy yellow curry sauce
Samosa salad- not bad! Never had samosa like that;interesting.
Rainbow Salad- this dish seems to be a popular one here and it did not disappoint.
 Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup) - delicious!

So much more dishes I want to try! Will definitely come back for more. One thing to note: our table was too close to the one on my right which means we can heard the whole convo going on on that table and probably the same to them.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Wow greatest experience in food and staff in a long time!!!

Staff was super knowledgeable on GLUTEN FREE eating! Soups were amazing and so was the rest of gluten free options! TRY EVERYTHING! 'Nuff said! :)
author: Dat P.

description: We where here for dinner this place was packed..... Really good food and great service. Recommend that you will call for reservations other wise you will wait in a long line. Once again because food is great.... I will be back soon.
author: Boris M.

description:
Who would've thought to try Burmese food?  It's not as well-known or popular as many other Asian cuisines, but I'm always up for something new and different!  I've been here a few times now and every time, we must order the Tofu and Eggplant and a noodle dish (wish I could remember the name).  If you ask for a rec, that's probably the one they'll advise you to order.  After the 150+ times the tea leaf salad was mentioned in these YELP reviews, I had no choice but to give it a try!  I was very much looking forward to this dish, as I am quite unfamiliar with it and was excited to try something new.  Sadly, I can't rave about it as others have.  I don't know if it was the taste or the way it was prepared, but this dish did not suit my palette well at all.  Actually, of my 5 friends and I, NO ONE enjoyed the dish.  Was it poorly made that day or we just don't know how to savor the taste? HM.  

Of the few times I've been here, there were birthday celebrations and the restaurant played "Happy Birthday" in Mandarin.  Zhu ni shengri kuaile!  Curiously, I asked the owner if she was Chinese- turns out she's half Chinese and half Burmese.  Ah, this explains why most of the dishes have Chinese influence, with a touch of Burma... excuse me, Myanmar now.
author: Mindy D.

description:
I love Mandalay! I've been here twice, the first time for dinner with friends a little over a year ago, and then again today for late lunch with my dad. 
Both times Mandalay did not disappoint. I also noticed that they gave the interior a nice little face lift. The first time, two friends and I shared the chicken samosas for appetizer, and a la carte orders of mango chicken and the Mandalay special noodles. (the noodles were especially great!!!) Today, my dad and I walked in around 1:45pm, got seated immediately and were delighted to see their lunch specials! Dad got the rockcod with blackbean sauce and after much debate, I ordered their honey walnut prawns. I don't think I've ever had honey walnut prawns as an individual lunch order. ... OMG! Sooooo gooooood!!! I thought it was a really nice touch that their lunch specials aren't your traditional "over rice" entrees. Their presentation is awesome! They come as little a la carte plates that you can definitely share with the table. I was especially excited to receive my prawns arranged in a little mound, all nice and glazed with honey mayo sauce and sprinkled with walnuts and those crispy, crunchy noodle-like things they use to garnish fish sometimes. !!! Perfection! I'll post a pic. Dude...the prawns were huge! like tempura size man... 
And everything I've ever had here was SO FRESH. It's literally reFRESHing to dine here. The rock cod was melt-in-your-mouth awesome, and the honey walnut prawns here were probably the best i've ever had. I even ate the walnuts. I never do that. ! 

You get so full at the end, but you never feel disgustingly full... if you know what I mean. lol... 
It's a nice, nice feeling. ahhhhh.... I'm already thinking of what to get when I go back. 

Oh yeah, and I also like that the glass of water has a lemon slice in it. OOOoohh yeah. ...it's the little things.
author: MB M.

description: Good, Tea Leaf Salad, Papaya Salad and Mango Salad are amazing. Chicken Lettuce Cups are always delicious too. Clean and always brilliant friendly service. If you have to wait (never more than 15 minutes) then it's highly worth it!
author: Jalpa P.

description: Been going here for years, it's a family favorite. It's one of my favorite restaurants in town. Try the tea leaf or green mango salad, special noodle, DELICIOUS!
author: Elie L.

description:
Although I am 24, I'm really behind on the times and the youthful vernacular of my generation.

Today while perusing a million yelp reviews (I'm sick in bed :( ), I finally asked myself:  "What the f**k does 'nom nom' mean?"  Due to my super-honed inductive reasoning, I concluded that it had something to do with food.  And not just any food, super-amazing, tantalizing food.  Slap some s**t on me and call me Sherlock.

Always a fact checker, a visit to urban dictionary confirmed my educated guess.  As I was laying amongst a sea of wadded tissues and Netflix, my mind did some wandering, it settled on a very recent dinner at Mandalay.  

PheNOMenal. 

The tea leaf salad. Order it. Mix it. Eat it. Say nom nom. Repeat until done. Coconut chicken, do the same. Those noodles are perfect: slick, tender, with the perfect amount of coconut in the dish. Actually, I love coconut; so add some coconut rice and prepare for some nom[squared] expletives to come out of your mouth. I can't wait to come back, now that I know how to express my satisfaction.
author: Joanna M.

description:
I have had good Burmese before and having a four star rating on Yelp IN San Francisco, I had high expectations.  General consensus: This is a much hyped and over-rated place.   Some highlights:

The service was great.  Friendly, helpful staff and there was a mad group of folks waiting for tables and hostess even brought out complimentary wine for everyone waiting inside.  How cool and high-class is that?   9 out 10 for service.  I have to take away a point for some slight delay and repeating a request for a drink to the table.  

The food was just simply average.   This is where Mandalay looses big time.  We had the Samosas and Tea Leaf Salad for starters.   The Samosas were okay but the ones at Burma Superstar are much more flavorful and the hot sauce there is better as well.  

The Tea Leaf Salad was interesting.  I have had the Rainbow Salad at Burma Superstar and I LOVE that.  I figured I would try something different here.  It tasted interesting.  I would most likely compare it to Burmese flavored granola.   Seriously.  The pan roasted garlic retained a horrid burnt taste in the salad that pretty much destroyed any appreciation of this interesting dish.  

For the mains, we had the Rangoon beef and the Mandalay chicken.  Both were okay.  The Mandalay chicken tasted like any Orange or General Tso's chicken you would order at a decent to good Chinese fast food place.  Except for here it is WAY overpriced.  

The saffron rice was a bit sweet and had an intense cinnamon flavor.  Are they buying cheap imitation saffron or the real shit? 

Burma Superstar rocks this place and I would never come back here again unless I was with a group of friends that were adamant on going.   Burma superstar has better food, better ingredients, a better chef, better presentation......  Hands down, that is the winner.  

 Hope I didn't rock the boat with all you Mandalay fans out there.  World-traveled and I have high standards for food quality and general experience. Thanks for reading.
author: Ross B.

description: This is our go-to spot when we want to show out-of-towners what SF can do in terms of dining in the Richmond District. Way way better than the over-hyped Burma Super Star (and less of a wait).
author: chris e.

description: Came here for my birthday with my husband. We thought that it would be amazing from all of the reviews. We have never tried Burmese before so we were very excited. We ordered their special tea, the tea salad, mandalay noodles and the Singapore noodles. My husband said everything was okay, but I did not like the tea salad or the Singapore noodles at all. I am not a finicky eater so we were both surprised. I am the one that's adventurous and is always dragging him to try new things. This was the first time I was truly disappointed. The tea salad has the fermented tea leaves but I did not expect it to taste so wrong. It was very oily and left a bitter taste in your mouth. I do not understand why so many people rave about this dish. My house noodles were alright. Overall, we decided that these Burmese dishes tasted like wannabe Thai dishes. But nowhere nearly as good as Thai. Maybe I just had an off night and my taste buds were messed up? That's never happened before... We will Burmese food a try again sometime in the future.
author: A W.

description:
