I've been coming to Mandalay for years. The food here is consistently good. Portions are extremely generous, and the prices aren't too bad.

Last time I was here, it was extremely crowded. I hadn't been here in a while and was disappointed when I saw that the lemon chicken was no longer on the menu. Instead, I ordered the walnut shrimp and white rice, which was good. It was a lot of food, so much I almost got a headache. My friend ordered the tea leaf salad and saffron rice. The service could've been better. They seemed overwhelmed at the amount of people, but our food came fast. We decided to order dessert: fried bananas with coconut ice cream. As this is one of my favorite desserts, I've had my fair share of different interpretations. There was too much batter on the bananas, and the batter itself wasn't very good to begin with. However, the coconut ice cream made up for it. 

Best Burmese place in the city, hands down. The location isn't convenient for me at all, but I will go out of my way to eat here.
author: Nastasia G.

description:
I never knew Burmese food is this good before I've been to this little restaurant in SF.
Mandalay Noodle was so great that we finished the whole dish within like 10 min.
Mango salad was great too.

Sad that I can visit there again only when I go to SF.

If you are in the Bay area, it is a must go place!!
author: Hyeran L.

description:
Food 5 stars. Service 1 star. Overall 2.5 stars.
first, foods are pretty good. Very close to authentic Burmese food. But the portion is very small for the price u pay. We paid $21 for 1.5 size Yangon beef, but it is even smaller than the size of regular size Chinese dishes. The dishes doesn't include rice. The regular rice is $2.5 and coconut rice is $3.5. Overall the food are expensive.
For the services, we waited 15 min to get water. They never refill the water even after we told them to. The two out of three dishes take 30mins after ordered to get serve and another 30min to get the third item. We finished the first two dishes and it took forever to get the final one. Very slow. Good food.
author: Wai C.

description:
I'm not expert in Burmese food but this place is definitely not what I imagine of a four star 1000+review restaurant.

The tea leaf salad here is very short on green (by that I mean none), which really robbed it of the texture and taste contrast it needs and making it very one dimensional. The coconut soup was serviceable. The lamb in the curry was dry and bland. Service was slow but friendly. The decor was a little dated but not in a good way.

I feel bad saying this but just wait longer in the line for the other place down the street.
author: Eddie W.

description:
I'm not gonna lie. I came here for two reasons:

1) The wait at Burma Superstar was an hour
2) A Burmese co-worker said it was good

I guess #2 should have been enough. Either way, I'm glad we came here. It was good. The service was very friendly, the place is vibrantly decorated and very inviting, and there was no wait. 

The menu is quite varied, so it took us awhile to figure out what to order, but I was pretty satisfied with everything we ordered. 

- Balada: It's a variation of fried green-onion pancakes and roti. It's a crispy/chewy pancake that comes with a curry dipping sauce. It was pretty good, but not amazing. It was not quite crispy enough, and a little too thick. It also wasn't like roti, pulling apart into several layers. 

- Mandalay special noodles: Flat rice noodles with coconut chicken and vegetables. It was kind of like pad thai. 

- Pan Fry Okra Prawn: This was one of the better dishes. Okra's usually not high on my list of things to eat, but here it's sauteed, so the consistency is very different from the okra you'd find on something like gumbo, where it's been boiled to hell. The okra in this dish was still slightly crunchy, bright green, and very good. Only downside was that there weren't very many prawns. The flavor was good though. 

- Rangoon Beef: Sliced and stir-fried beef with vegetables. Beef was very tender. I liked it. 

- Coconut rice: I'm a sucker for coconut milk and rice. This is basically steamed rice with a hint of coconut milk, sprinkled with fried coconut flakes on top. Maybe a shade dry. 

Overall a good Burmese restaurant. Portions were not large, but we still had some leftovers.
author: Saunders C.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the city.  And in the words of Forrest Gump, "that's all I have to say, about that."
author: Victoria G.

description: The food is terrific. And, the staff is excellent. The tables are really close together so prepare to get intimate with your neighbors. If you're not up for that, they do take out. Parking is always an issue; leave the car at home if you can.
author: REN S.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Here the reasons why:
- First and foremost, never have to wait in line (unlike Burma Superstar) since they have so much room.
- Ginger lemonade is awesome, must have.
- Yummy salads, including the colorful Tea leaf salad. 
- Excellent service, love the family who runs this place. 
- Oohh and they give you free mini desserts :)
author: Kanwal A.

description:
The food at this restaurant is delicious! I ordered the papaya salad, green beans with soft tofu (spicy and yummy) and the Burmese style noodle (Kaw soi dok). 
The flavors and spices are unique and I'm so satisfied when I'm done with my meal! 
The service is excellent and servers are polite and accommodating. I recommend this place for a Burmese or mandarin cuisine experience.
author: BJ S.

description:
ordered 
Chicken satay
curry duck with pumpkin
curry noodle 

food are ok. but I was looking for more authentic burmese food not fushion.
author: Rina C.

description:
If you're craving some Burmese food, have no fear, because Mandalay is here!

Well, it's been around for a while, declaring itself on Yelp to be the First Burmese Restaurant in SF, but it's a great option to keep in mind besides Burma Super Star and Burma Tea Leaf.

My friend and I stopped by this afternoon after checking out Burma Tea Leaf (which oddly enough, was not open to business at 1 PM - we stepped in and the guys in the back said they weren't, despite the posted hours on the door that suggested that they definitely should be. Bummer.) and Halu (which was only open for dinner). Two strikes, and only one more chance before my lunch mood was dampened. Luckily, my friend thought of Mandalay, a place she has frequented often, and we walked over for my first experience.

Am I glad we came! The moment I stepped in, I noticed the lovely decor of the place. Beautiful traditional ornaments and artwork of various bright hues hung on the walls and ceilings. Nice to look at during pauses in the meal, and they added to the dining experience. The place was fairly full the entire time we were there, from 1:30 till almost 3, and I could tell why once I had my first sip of the Coconut Milk Tapioca. I hadn't tried a bite of food yet, and I was already hooked. Creamy, with coconut jelly and yummy sago balls, that drink filled me up in the best way possible.

The Ginger Salad and the Mandalay Special Noodle were recommended by my friend, and I'm so glad she suggested them, because they were absolutely delicious. So many tasty and unique flavors, and somehow they all blended together in a tantalizing way. The pickled ginger added a nice spiciness, and despite the quantity, it wasn't as overwhelming as I'd expected, melding perfectly with the other ingredients. And those noodles? They were homemade and looked and tasted way better than they looked - and let me tell you, they already looked very appealing. I definitely appreciated the tanginess of the lime juice, and the texture of the fried thin noodle was a great accent to the flat noodles. The flavors also reminded me of my fav Burmese dish, Nan Gyi Dok. Both plates were visually and literally tasty :}

Service was great; our plates were cleared within minutes and our water was refilled a couple times. They were polite and checked in with us often as well.

Only complaints - maybe I'm just being petty? - were the table size and the amount of chicken in the noodles. I thought there wasn't enough poultry for my taste; one piece for every few bites is not cutting it, especially if the pieces are tiny. Also, the dishes and drinks did not fit comfortably on the table. It was just a bit cramped; one more dish, and nothing would have fit. Luckily, my friend and I weren't voracious, and were stuffed by the salad and noodles.

Mandalay and Burma Super Star are now sitting pretty close in my book! Next time I am considering BSS for a meal, I might just check out Mandalay instead, especially because there is no wait :)

Thanks for the introduction to this lovely establishment, N.L.!
author: Tina Y.

description:
Burma Superstar is BS, and if you go there I will laugh at you. 

The food is always good here. If it's crowded it definitely takes a little bit longer to be seated, but I've never waited more than 20 or 25 minutes. Went today and it was a little more crowded than usual but we were still in and out in about an hour, and even with a crowd the food was wonderful.
author: Rachael L.

description: My favorite Burmese restaurant in SF. My favorite dishes are the Rainbow Salad and Mandalay Special Noodles. The food is fresh and I love how the waiter / waitresses mix some of the dishes in front of you (entertainment value!). The people are so friendly and not pretentious (unlike what you get a neighboring Burma Superstar). Definitely give this place a try. Yummy!
author: Karen H.

description: Price is really reasonable. The flavors are amazing. We had the papaya salad, samosas, mango salad, beef curry, teal leaf salad, eggplant, and black sesame rice & ice cream. Sooooo good!!!
author: Niona W.

description:
saturday night, came around 6, found parking around the block. got seated pretty quickly. definitely come early, when we left there was a lot of ppl.

seatings are a bit cramped....pretty much they squeeze as many ppl as possible.

we ordered

tea leaf salad- now that I know what to expect, it wasn't bad...a little more oily compared to other ones i've had.
catfish soup- has noodles in it, very hearty and feels like a home cooked soup..not bad
mandalay noodles- good also, mild in flavor, like a very light curry. tiny pieces of chicken
mango chicken- pretty good, most flavor out of everything.
coconut rice- nice aroma

overall I liked it and better than what i remember of burma? maybe since i didn't expect too much.
most flavors consist of coconut and lemon/lime flavors.. think i prefer thai food!

service was nice, but since table so small, they tried to take away our food before we were done...so made it awkward at times....nice that they mix and tell you ingredients in front of you.
author: Christine M.

description: Must try :Samosa, tofu kebat. The taste was perfect! I'm amazed why Thai food is so popular. For me, I'm a fan of Burmese now!!!
author: Pratiksha S.

description: Portion sizes are VERY SMALL! But food was Very Delicious! They need to make the portions almost double for it to match the high prices here.
author: Moein J.

description: Place has a cool setting. Polite and speedy service. I ordered a soup called "ong nokaw soi." Really flavorful. Also ordered  a drink called "mango lassi." The taste was bomb. Hit this spot up asap!
author: Randy L.

description:
Since Yellow Pa Taut in SoMa closed a while ago, I've been looking for a new Burmese restaurant to fit the bill. Burma Superstar is too much fuss for not much gain (read my review), so I was really excited when a few friends recommended Mandalay. It's a trek from SoMa, but it's worth it each time.

My most recent visit here was with family visiting from out of town. It was up to me to order, since my family had never had Burmese food before. We went a little buckwild.

Samosas: Vegetarian and chicken. Crispy, tons of filling, all-around delicious.
Tea Leaf Salad: For anyone who's never had it before, this is a must-order. You've got to try it at least once. I was unimpressed with the Tea Leaf Salad at Burma Superstar, which resembled Corn Nuts, but here, it was more flavorful and not nearly as salty.
Moo Hin Nga Soup: This fish chowder with noodle soup is great with lemon and cilantro. You can't see the catfish because it's all ground up, but it imparts a great flavor which is not overly fishy.
Burmese Curry Beef: Tender and flavorful.
Basil Spicy Eggplant: Full of basil flavor, and great spice. One of my favorite eggplant preparations.
Mandalay Special Noodle: This is another must-have. This was easily my favorite thing on the menu. Two kinds of noodles with a delicious sauce. I could easily eat this all day.
Combination Fried Rice: Ordered for my poor allergic little brother, but I couldn't keep my spoon out of it. Another well flavored dish.
Falooda: A very filling, coconut-y dessert that should be shared, not eaten by one person!

The food was delicious by all counts, but the service really sealed the deal. As soon as we mentioned my little brother's allergies (peanuts, fish sauce, really anything with seafood) they mentioned whether anything they brought out had any of that stuff in it, without us even asking. In most restaurants, we just order him a dish for himself, make sure there's nothing he's allergic to in it and we order our own dishes, but here, we didn't have to. They made it so easy to share nearly our entire meal with him. Also, we ordered falooda to share for the eight of us, since we really only wanted a few bites each, but they made sure to bring out enough bowls and spoons so everyone could eat comfortably. 

The portions aren't huge, and the dishes aren't cheap, so you may end up having to pay a little more than usual. But for the delicious food and impeccable service, I consider it well worth it!
author: Angeline P.

description: If I could eat here every day I would. We have been going here for over 15 years and we always visit when back in SF. It's usually packed but quick, staff is incredibly friendly. My favs are the tea leaf salad, Mandalay special noodle, all their curries and the palata. Can't go wrong here!!!
author: Jim F.

description: You absolutely have. not. lived. until you've eaten at this restaurant. I take everyone I know here, whether it be my dad who's afraid to try new cuisine or my best friend who's been eating Burmese food for years. Mandalay not only has the coziest, coolest atmosphere (dimly lit, ornate paintings, colorful pillows - wait, am I in Asia?), but it also has the best food ever. I'm talking about the Tea Leaf Salad, coconut rice, Balada, coconut chicken soup (I get it for my boyfriend every time he's sick), and of course, the Signature House Noodles. That's a very short list of my favorites, but seriously, everything here is nothing short of the most delicious food you've ever put into your mouth. Try it. It's better than Burma Superstar (sorry, not sorry!). You won't regret it if you're into this kind of food. P.S. there's usually a line, so either plan for some extra waiting time or call ahead to put your name on the list! They do take out too.
author: Sophie R.

description: Beef curry was good we also ordered the mango chicken the visitor in samosa I recommend all three. The service was good they kept checking to make sure our drinks were full.
author: Adam W.

description:
Ever had one of those days where you get home in the evening from work and you're just wiped?  You can't think about making dinner, and you're sick of your uninspiring whole-foods assembly-line dinner choices (if I see Mac-n-Cheese one more night, I'm going to...).

Well, then, El Jeffe, get yourself out of the funk and head over to Mandalay, where we start off with a delicious tea-leaf salad (freshly assembled at your table), and then a tasty veggie hot-and-sour soup (excellent), maybe some mango chicken, the spicy tofu veggie, the saffron rice (pampoi), all good!

 It's just a run of delicious food, with a chill cozy ambiance, swift service, and friendly staff.  They seem to arrive just-in-time with the next dish, almost synch'd to you finishing up the last dish.  

Now, go back to your whole-foods assembly-line salad, and think about dinner!
author: Mark K.

description:
Mandalay is the first choice when we want to have Burmese cuisine with friends.  Today my family came from out of town to visit including a few of my little nieces and nephew so what better place to share than Mandalay.  The food was spectacular as usual everything was great except for the SERVICE.  We walked in only to received the cold shoulder from the female owner because perhaps we were with children.  I noticed she checked up on all the other tables around us but somehow managed to skip our table.  

We were all done with our meal and the kids wanted fried bananas and ice cream.  I asked the waiter to see the dessert menu and he was very nice to flip it to the dessert page and pointed to me in which i ordered.  However, another wait staff came out with our check and fortune cookies and said oh we don't have anymore fried bananas but sounded really unsure of herself.  She left to go check with the lady owner and came back with a more definitive answer that they don't while the waiter was already on his way to the kitchen to put the order I had placed with him.  Something is fishy here, sounds like they were trying to rush us out!  Well we decided to cancel our dessert order and paid.  The Kids were plenty disappointed.  Shame on you Mandalay and I really liked you guys too!  Tsk tsk tsk!

MAndalay may not be ideal for small families with children, go at your own risk!
author: Justin L.

description:
The service was actually pretty decent.  We came here at 7pm on a Saturday with a reservation for 4, so we got seated almost right away.  (Otherwise, the wait from what I saw was kinda ridiculous.)

Every dish I ordered was delicious, and in my opinion, rated 4-5 out of 5!  Here's what I ordered:

Balada (Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce)
---- Pancake was not *that* crispy.  The sauce had a peanuty taste to it

Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok) Salad prepared with imported Burmese tea leaves, toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing
---- Very good, unique.

Mango Salad Picked mango slices, cucumber, green pepper, onion & dressing
---- Not as spicy as I thought it would be

Mandalay Chicken Fried chicken cubes stir fried with garlic and chef's delicious hot sauce
---- Tender.  Spicy.  Looks like the Mango Chicken but without the mango (we eyeballed what our neighboring table ordered).

Dry Pan Fried String Bean (Pan fried string beans, ginger, chili sauce and grounded shrimp)
---- Spicy.  Definitely heavy on the grounded shrimp paste which I enjoyed.

We ordered a bottle of their shiraz wine, which I enjoyed.  Also got complimentary dessert (4 rectangles of spongy orange cake)!  The check came pretty quickly to our table, and payment processing was also very prompt.

5 stars for an overall enjoyable experience!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I frequently order take out from both Mandalay and Burma Superstar and am constantly comparing them.  I like both restaurants very much but have recently decided that I like Burma better.  Both restaurants serve many of the same dishes (curries, the famous tea leaf salad) but also have dishes unique to their restaurant.  While my preference is Burma, others may like Mandalay.  It comes down to what will better tantalize your taste buds.

Mandalay's food tends to be sweet.  They seem to use a lot of coconut milk and basil.  The curries are more watery/thin (not in a bad way).  Their hot sauce is better than Burma's though.  Because it's HOMEMADE!  It has a pungency that reminds me of fermented shrimp and garlic (maybe that's exactly what it is...)  My favorite dishes:  Burmese style curry, pea sprouts with garlic, balada (buttery flaky pancakes with curry dipping sauce)

Burma's food has stronger flavor and is very garlicky.  Their dishes are more savory than sweet.  The curries are thick.  But their hot sauce is nothing special (just the chili garlic hot sauce that you get from Asian markets).  My favorite dishes:  Garlic chili shrimp, eggplant with garlic sauce, Burmese style catfish curry.

I prefer Mandalay's pumpkin pork curry over Burma's.  I prefer Burma's eggplant dish over Mandalay's.  But the tea leaf salad tastes exactly the same to me from both restaurants.

Both restaurants are ALWAYS busy no matter the day of the week.  Parking will always be difficult to find in this area.  

In the end Burma wins by a margin.

(I am going recycle this same review for Burma, hehe.)
author: Justine L.

description: You can call to make a reservation. So i would do that in order to avoid the wait. It's a shorter wait then Burma Star but still. .... Why wait to be seated when you don't have to?
author: Nikki M.

description: I think Burmese food is growing on me. This place was comparable to Burma Superstar in terms of the food (both delicious!), but it was much easier to get a table at Mandalay! (read: they actually take reservations). Tea leaf salad was interesting --- very salty, but I liked it. We also had a noodle dish and I think the Mandalay beef. Overall solid. I look forward to trying more of the dishes!
author: Laurent L.

description: Maybe I'm not a fan of Burmese food or maybe I just ordered the wrong dish, but I wasn't super impressed. I liked the tea leaf salad in concept, though there was too much garlic for my taste. The beef dish I got was also not exactly to my taste. The staff was extremely nice and efficient though, so plus one star for that.
author: Rowena L.

description:
House noodles, green papaya salad, curry chicken and the special pancakes (one of the appetizers) are the way to go. Don't forget to drink fresh young coconut.

Went there last week with a group of four and the bill was comically affordable. Kind of felt sad.

Love it!
author: Bulent K.

description: Came into Mandalay for lunch and enjoyed the atmosphere and decor.  The service was pretty good as well; however, I wasn't the biggest fan of the tea leaf salad.  I felt it was missing something, probably greens, I don't think they had salad leaves on the plate at all.  The mango chicken was very good as well as the coconut rice.  We also had a lamb dish which was not so enjoyable.  Overall, a decent meal, but would order other dishes if I came back in the future.
author: Janelle C.

description:
Solid. 

Good Food. Nice people. Reasonable prices. Awesome lunch specials.

Go there. Burma is good. But I think this place is better.
author: C. S.

description: Best Burmese in town, great food and very attentive service. It gets crowded Thu-Sat in the evenings, but what that is good doesn't.
author: Guillermo L.

description:
I do NOT love the TEA LEAF SALAD. really good flavor in the first bite, but after that it's like eating a bowl of greasy peanuts with a spoon and my jaw was exhausted from all the chewing. Prefer Burma's which is a little lighter and fresher tasting.  

The BALADA is like a hot, buttery, crispy, croissant with super flavorful curry dipping sauce.  SO GOOD. 

Beef Burmese Curry: yum! accompanying coconut rice seemed a little dense. Beef a teeny bit firm and dry, but sauce was nice an buttery and flavorful.  

Service: good.  Note that the "sign up sheet" by the door might not actually reflect the wait. Wednesday around 8:30 we were 5th on the list, but then we were seated immediately when the host found us.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
This is a pleasantly run, VERY busy local business. The #1 salad is amazing, a taste and texture experience unlike another I've had to date.
The entrees were very good too. Definitely get a reservation or you could be waiting awhile.
As far as southeast asian cuisine, this is some of the best I've sampled.
author: Matt Y.

description:
I've been to a few Burmese joints in the Bay Area and I think one is easily my favorite. (YES, I have been to Burma Superstar, so stop that thought).  The service is nice and accommodating and their food is delicious.

The Mandalay Special Noodles are to die for. They were creamy, yet light...flavorful, yet delicate... bright, yet subdued. Those noodles spoke to every one of my senses and told them "These aren't the droids you're looking for"... These noodles had the "force"!

The tea leaf salad was pretty awesome too. The fermented tea leaves weren't as pungent as the other tea leaf salads I've tried, but for my palate that's a good thing- it allowed the other flavors  to come through... the fried crispy garlic, the jalapenos, and the shrimp powder. Not quite on the same Jedi scale as the special noodles, but still highly recommended.

And the Balada... What's not to like about this crispy and chewy bread? One general problem with balada (or other similar breads) that I have at other restaurants is... the rather small portions always leave me hanging like Luke in a Wampa cave. I always end up wanting more. Here, I thought the portion was very generous and actually had some to take home. Also, where the curry dipping sauce that comes with balada often seems like a watered down afterthought at other restaurants, this was a very creamy and thick sauce that I really could've stood on its own.

For reasonably priced, delicious Burmese food that'll make you want to yub nub, check out Mandalay!
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
4.5 stars - I'm embarrassed to say, I didn't think Burmese food had much going for it in terms of uniqueness until I went to Mandalay. I expected something similar to Thai or Vietnamese food. Alas, the experience I had was phenomenal and my taste buds were dancing.

The restaurant was still bustling and there was quite a wait when we got there a little past 8. Like most restaurants in San Francisco, expect to be sitting elbow to elbow with your neighbor. It's cozy. 
The food:
- tea leaf salad - others who have posted reviews also seem to love it. The majority of the "salad" (called that because all the ingredients are mixed together) consists of of peanuts, ground shrimp, lentil seeds, lime, of course the tea leaves, and a variety of other spices that make the dish quite flavorful and nutty. It's crunchy and you want to just have it by the spoonful.
- Nan Gyi Dok - it sounds Korean, but is actually a noodle dish with chicken with spices that had a kick. I love spicy noodles and this one hit the spot in terms of its spiciness level, texture, and quantity.
Mango chicken - this dish made me want to try their other entrees. Cubes of fresh sweet mango coupled with lightly battered chicken, yum. Great with the coconuty rice they serve. Tropical party in your mouth!

The service was attentive enough, but several times they brought the incorrect order to us and the tables around us - could use some process improvement in that regard.

I would come back here to try other dishes - namely some of the mouth-watering entrees with that delicious coconut rice. On a weekend be prepared to wait during dinner hours, and budget time for parking if you're driving, for sure. It is Richmond, after all.
author: Brandy A.

description: This is my favorite Burmese restaurant in the area. I typically don't order vegetarian dishes, but Mandalay Eggplant is one of my favorites here. Other Favorites are coconut soup, Rangoon beef, and tea leaf salad.
author: Zhenya K.

description: We ordered 2 dishes - Pork Pumpkin Curry and Broccoli Chicken dish and with a bowl of coconut rice! It was very tasty and it was worth every penny! Oh yeah try their Sangria, you will like it too! :)
author: Michelle H.

description: Great food top notch service. We came here on Saturday night after we were told that it would be an hour wait at Burma Superstar at 6PM. We were not disappointed at all. The host (could be the owner) was so accommodating. There were a few groups in front of us but she managed quickly to get everyone seated less than 5 mins. We were in a hurry to go to a show so we ordered the food 5 mins after we looked at the menu. We ordered tea leaf salad, mango chicken $12 and beef curry ($15). We waited for 15 mins then the salad came. We thought the food was gonna be long so we told the host that we were in a hurry.She then went back to check on the food for us and the food came out right away. The waitresses were very nice and attentive. Our water glasses were always filled. The food was delicious especially the salad. I would definitely come back again mainly for the service and ,of course, the food.
author: Kitty D.

description: Loved the tea salad and green papaya salad. Really enjoyed Mandalay green beans and tofu, lamb curry, pumpkin chicken curry and lamb basil. If you haven't had Burmese food, this is the place for you!
author: Michael N.

description: We love this place.. Let it be a party of 3 or a party of 10, they know how to accommodate very well and according to the reservation time. The servers and owners are constantly checking in to see how the food is and the service.. Everything is yummy in the menu and fresh!!
author: Das M.

description:
Came here on a tuesday night and luckily we made reservations. Family dinner for 8 and overall the night was just okay. We started out with the ginger lime beers and ginger lemonades. I thought the ginger beer tasted better than the lemonade because the lemonade is too sweet, or perhaps I just like booze in general. 

Food on the other hand, took FOREVER to come out. I mean how hard is it to deep fry a bunch of stuff. The balada and samosa should be the easiest thing to pop out of the kitchen but it took so long that when the food got to our table, it wasn't pipping hot. I dont know if they dont have enough cooks or what, but the food coming out was really slow. The taste of the food was delicious, a bit heavier in flavoring for my taste but because food took so long to come out, i was pretty much full. But i'm not sure if i'm full from eating slowly or just full from the heavy flavoring.  

We of course ordered the tea leaf salad. Because there was so many of us, we ordered 1 1/2 orders, but it didn't seem like it was much bigger than the regular size. Most of the noodles taste the same with the coconut and peanut and cilantro. Curry wasn't spicy or that flavorful.  

On a tuesday night it took us 2 hours to eat, just imagine how long the weekend would take. I had to ask them to fill my water about 5 times until someone came to my table. Service is definitely not the best.
author: Anita W.

description: The food is delicious here but the service is a bit slow. There doesn't seem to be enough wait staff and the kitchen seems slow.  But the food is worth it if you are not in a hurry!
author: Karen W.

description:
Been here twice.  The first time, the place was still small, then when I came back in 2009, the place got huge.  Now I can't do a comparison between Burma Superstar and this place since it's been a while.  Although, this place is always a default everytime Burma Superstar has super long lines and we don't feel like waiting. 
Location-- can't really complain because it is San Francisco.  Just keep driving around and you'll eventually find parking.  If you dn't wanna go through that then take the bus.  
Service- good service, but nothing that stands out.  Got seated right away.  
Food- I'm no expert of burmese food, but I like it.  Bursting with flavors with all the herbs they use.  Last time I went, my friends and I ordered our own dish and my noodles were good.  I still wanna go back to try the rest of the food  
Price- reasonable.
author: Claire J.

description:
I would give this place negative (-) stars if I could.

Someone recommended Mandalay as an alternative to Burma Superstar, because it's less crowded and there aren't lines of people waiting to dine.  

I came in after 5pm when there were very few people in the restaurant and let the manager Kevin know that I'm vegan -- no shrimp, no fish sauce, no milk/dairy, no eggs, and on and on.  He had a waitress take my order.  I told her the same, thing, listing out all the ingredients I couldn't eat.  I emphasized the vegan thing, asking her to make sure with the kitchen.  

After my order came out, I asked her again if everything was vegan.  She took the bag back to the kitchen for a moment to confirm, and came back out saying YES.

After the long drive home, I picked up the bag and found it leaking, the boxes about to fall out the sauce-soaked soggy bottom.  The bag wasn't well-packed, and the box of string beans had slipped down and leaked everywhere.

She was super, super nice. BUT, she and the kitchen miscommunicated, my Mandalay noodle dish was NOT vegan.  It tasted funny, and I later called Kevin confirmed with the restaurant that they put FISH SAUCE in it!   

After ALL the effort I went through to make sure the restaurant understood my order, I was not a happy camper.  Still, the waitress was so nice.

Calling, and having Kevin tell me to call back later as he was super busy.  Then calling again, having him quickly--and to me quite insincerely--apologize, then HANG UP on me, wasn't cool.

Mandalay should have done a MUCH BETTER job of training their staff.  They've been here for almost 30 years and seriously, they should know better if they want to operate in San Francisco.  

Oh yeah, and they promised to refund me the noodle dish (like that makes up for it), which I have YET to see reflected in my credit card statement.

VERY DISAPPOINTED
author: Ten G.

description:
This is the sister restaurant to Mingalaba in Burlingame. I was wanting to try Burma Superstar but when I saw the line outside, I decided to check out Mandalay.

Fortunately, my mate and I was able to snag a table as soon as we walked it without a wait. It's a much bigger restaurant compared to Mingalaba. It has the traditional decor like it's sister restaurant and the staff are super friendly and fast.

They seem to serve the more "authentic" Burmese dishes here compared to Mingalaba. Everything we ordered was delish and we were happy to have our Tea Leaf Salad cravings fulfilled.
author: Soozie H.

description:
One of my close friends/coworker's birthday was today. We heard many good things about Mandalay and thought it would be cute and fun to try a new restaurant out for his birthday. Let me just say, we made a great choice!

What we ordered:

Tea Leaf Salad - (YUMMY!) Loved the mixture of nuts inside. It was a crunchy and delicious salad!

Mandalay Special Noodles - (YUMMY!) Light curry coconutty sauce with noodles. Reminded me of a vietnamese dish my parents make called Banh Tam Bi which is one of my absolute favorite entrees of all time. *drool*

Sautéed Seafood and Green Beans - (YUMMYYY!) Very flavorful!

Mango Salad - (Good) Thinly sliced crunchy unripe mango with a tangy dressing

The service was very friendly and attentive. Our water cups were never empty and teapot was promptly refilled. They even come to your table and toss your salad in front of you.

We also brought a birthday cake and when it was time to bring it out, they played the birthday song throughout the entire restaurant for my friend. That was really sweet! :)
author: Marilyn L.

description:
Spacious Burmese Restaurant in the Richmond District with no wait.  My dad was dying to try Mandalay after seeing it on Check Please, Bay Area.  So instead of our regular dim sum family outing, we decided to venture out.

We ordered:
Satay chicken: chicken breast on skewers.  It was pretty dry.  The only ones in our party that liked it were my kiddie niece and nephew who 1) only eat chicken and 2) love anything on skewers.  Pass.

Somusas with chicken:  Perfectly fried with a generous portion of filling.  Everyone enjoyed these.

Somusa soup:  Basically a standard Burmese soup tomato base with fried somusas in it.  They have two kinds: spicy and mild.  We ordered both since there were 8 in our party.  The spicy isn't even spicy.  Good, but nothing to write home about.

Tea leaf salad:  Tasty!  The dish comes out with all the ingredients separated, and the server explains which ingredient is which before mixing it in front of you.  This salad is on par with the infamous Tea leaf salad at Burma Superstar two blocks down.  

Mandalay chicken salad:  Tasty as well!  Same as the tea leaf salad in that it's mixed in front of you.  Sweet and crunchy and a very different taste and texture than the tea leaf salad. 

Mandalay special noodles:  Yum!  These noodles had just the right amount of crunch, curry and chewiness.  Again, these noodles were on par with Burma Superstar.

Tea duck: Ew. No likey.  This is served like Chinese Peking Duck with the buns, the plum sauce and green onion.  The buns were hard and dry and the duck was dry and not meaty at all.  The taste of the duck was almost bitter.  Yuck. 

Burmese curry lamb: Rich and flavorful.  The lamb was very tender and the potatoes were infused with curry flavor.  Decent.

Mango chicken:  Deep fried pieces of chicken tossed with fresh pieces of mango and onion.  Pretty good, but not very authentic.  It's kind the equivalent of a Chinese Orange Chicken.  

Ice cream/Tapioca dessert:  Tasty, but melted way too fast.  It had chunks of colored gelatin in it, which was nice and chewy.  Good, but not mind blowing by far.

The service was attentive and I liked that they explained the ingredients and dishes because this was a 1st time Burmese cuisine experience for most of the fams.

All in all, the food here is good, but not awesome.  Plus points for no wait. Portions are pretty small too.  I would go back for the samusas, tea leaf salad, mandalay chicken salad and mandalay special noodles.  I'd skip the rest and save a decent amount of coin.
author: Sandee L.

description:
I went today for lunch with my mom after she had been ranting about this place for a while. I ordered the pancake and the walnut prawn and they were both delicious! Service was also great and very fast.

One thing you ABSOLUTELY MUST TRY is the Ginger Lemonade! It's basically a MOJITO with no alcohol! Absolutely delicious!!! 

I will definitely be back
author: NC B.

description: Go here when you want to be transported to the land of Heavenly  Flavor. Order the ginger lemonade. It is tall and quenching and important.
author: Alex O.

description:
Reviewing takeout only.
We haven't been back to this restaurant since the days when it was a hole in the wall. They've updated the facility such that I didn't even recognize it from the inside.  The outside looks about the same.  The owner told me they've been doing remodeling over time, slowly.  It's very nicely decorated now and looks nothing like it used to.  Near the front door is a Buddah worship altar, lots of large fresh fruits on plates for dear Buddah to eat. 

We took home: veg samusa, chicken samusa and the rainbow salad.  Each dish was about $9.  Jr. Yelper liked the chicken samusa better than the vegt ones but I liked both.  4 small pieces per order came with a container of spicy dipping sauce, chopped parsley/onion and a sm. serving of sweet cucumber salad.  I'd order these again.

The rainbow salad was suppose to have 20 ingredients, I couldn't tell.  I've never had this dish before and it was full of vegts, tofu, nuts and lots of noodles.  Not sure I'd order this one again, should've tried their tea leaf salad instead to compare to Burma Super Star's. 

I'd consider coming back to the restaurant to dine-in and try some of their other dishes.  The owner told me they were featured on TV, Bay Area Check Please, so they've been very busy.  No reservations.  MC and Visa.
author: Ry T.

description:
Mandalay is a San Francisco GEM. 

Every time I come here, I walk away a happy woman. There is usually a line out the door for Burma Superstar, but don't be fooled; Mandalay is the real star. From the moment you walk in, you are greeted with warmth. The ambiance is homey and comfortable, and makes you feel at peace. The waitresses are attentive, quick and kind. But let's get to the more important aspect; the food. Talk about flavor!!

I have my favorite dishes, but I am always dying to go back because this is the type of restaurant where EVERYTHING you order is going to be delicious! 

The fried green beans are to die for. They toss it with garlic chips & it's packed with an explosion of flavor that leaves you scraping the plate for more. These are a must order. 

The beef curry is tender and moist, the potatoes are cooked to perfection and the curry sauce has just the right kick of spice. 

Don't forget to order a side of coconut rice, the contrast of the sweet and sticky will compliment almost any dish you order. 

Solid 5 star restaurant with decent prices and impeccable customer service. Come to Mandalay if you like full flavor, straight to the point authentic Burmese dishes. You will not be disappointed.
author: Tiana P.

description:
Ong No Kaw Soi soup. Mmmm. I'd definitely go back just for the soup! It was by far my most favorite thing I had that night.

So between a friend and I, we ordered quite a bit, but thank god my friend was able to eat a large portion of it. The mango salad was good, it's like a twist off of a green papaya salad. It's worth trying. 

Then as entrees, we ordered the mango mandalay chicken, which I liked, and the basil beef. The basil beef was overly salty. But the coconut rice definitely mellowed out the saltiness. 

Mandalay is good. Much much better than burma superstar!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
This place is getting more and more popular every year. I remember stumbling into this place from searching on Yelp. Why were we searching on Yelp is because Burma Superstar was packed and we didn't want to go far since we found a good parking spot.

Thankfully, it was a great stumble as the food was just as good if not better for certain dishes.

Some dishes that stood out was, the coconut soup(lemons on the side to make it as sour as you like), mango chicken, and the coconut rice.

Food Highlight: Coconut Soup with extra lemons on the side
author: Rich L.

description:
Mandalay food and service was outstanding on a recent visit there. Long lines after HSB at Golden Gate but they moved customers through quickly without anyone being pushed out.
Hot and Sour Soup, tea leaf salad, coconut rice, samosa and other dishes were fragrant and delicious.
author: Marilyn B.

description:
GF and I went here on a Sunday night. We called ahead to get on a list to be seated. We waited about Five minutes (this was our back up when we called and found Burma star would be over an hour). 

The balada appetizer was delicious. It was a crispy pancake thing (like they serve at Indian places) with great veggies and flavoring.  Next, we shared two entres:  The Madalay Special Noodles (excellent texture, flavoring, and variety of ingredients).  The duck we both thought was pretty good, but not as good as the prior two items.

For dessert, we had the Tapioca ice cream with (coconut?) shavings and nuts.  This was excellent we thought.

They have a reasonable selection of beer (we had Singhas I believe).

Brumese food (at least here, which was definitely a fusion place) tastes like a mixture of Indian and Thai.
author: Charles S.

description:
It's hard to talk about this place without acknowledging Burma Superstar around the corner, but really, they are separate entities with distinctly separate vibes. All things considered, however, Mandalay wins. Packed on a Saturday night, they still offered everyone waiting for a table complimentary wine. 

Samosas, Mandalay noodles, and rainbow chicken were excellent. The honey broccoli tofu was plate-licking worthy. The coconut rice was swoon-inducing. 

Worth a foggy little trip!
author: Melissa G.

description:
Had no expectations going into this place, but I am sold on their Kaw Soi Dok noodles, my absolute favorite noodles of all Burmese food. I honestly don't even know if I like Burmese food, but I equate Burmese food almost solely on these noodles haha (minus the tea salad, I just never got into it, after multiple tries).

The noodles are springy; it's light and refreshing, got a nice tangy, savory dressing, balanced by the sprinkling of cilantro. I like the fact that this place has fried diced potatoes in it, because some places don't! Ooo and the fried garlic really polishes the dish off.

Good to know I can always get it here, I shall be back! Coming home, I did find out it made the list for SFWeekly's must eat...which I totally agree with.

Also tried their Singapore noodles there, which was also good, a little different curry powder from the standard at most Chinese restos. 

Their ginger lemonade is a little too sweet for me.
author: Ly T.

description:
The food is so good and the owners actually work and monitor the restaurant. Also they make dishes off the menu for me. If I want a pumpkin tofu curry they will make it or if I would like to add eggplant to a dish they will do it. I mean talk about amazing! 

Also the food is very reasonably priced. I can get a dish and brown rice for under $12. Not many places in SF do that and if they do they are not as good as Mandalay.

I have taken my family and friends to this restaurant and they love it. I enjoy the atmosphere, always fresh flowers and the kindest staff. 

I am a regular at this place. If you have not tried it you definitely should, but dinner time be prepared to wait as the line is out the door!
author: mehjabeen k.

description:
It was extra loud and the wait was extra long because of graduation but the employees were on top of it. It took longer to get drinks, food out but they never forgot. I was happy with the appetizers (balada, samosas), I thought the tea leaf salad could have used some lettuce (and on that dish Burma Superstar is better), the Mandalay house special noodle was awesome! Very limey, cliantroy, coconuty and the noodles were...chewy. 
It was more of a let down once we got the main dishes - Mandalay beef was battered and deep fried beef; overcooked for the most part (therefore chewy and stringy) and covered in a sweet spicy sauce. It was tasty but it was a big reminder that they are ultimately catering to western tastes. The Mandalay mango chicken had good flavor but that was also deep fried but without batter so it was left in a pool of its own grease. 
The ginger lemon beer was tasty but very light on any alcohol (was there any?) and it might have been too bubbly on an empty stomach.
author: Rena J.

description:
I mainly like to go to Burmese restaurants for their coconut noodles or in Burmese, it's "oh-no-kow-sway". So this place has a decent tasting one. However, I do have to admit the tea leaf salad from here is pretty good.

Unfortunately, I personally do think everything is overpriced for what you are getting here, especially in terms of the quantity of the amount of food you get. But, hey, try the tea leaf salad, it's worth the taste, but not price.

  Oh, and I would definitely recommend this place over Burma Superstar, that place is definitely overrated and overpriced as well. And totally not worth the long wait in line.
author: Pudgy G.

description: This place is SO good...seriously. So much better than Burma Superstar, in my opinion. It's always packed but they get you in and out fairly quickly, so you never have to wait too long.  My fiancé and I typically split the Mandalay beef, mango chicken, string beans, and chow mein. It's way too much food for 2 people, but it makes for great leftovers. We live in Cow Hollow but always drive across the city when we get a craving for Asian food. Do yourself a favor and try this place! Our favorite hole in the wall. :)
author: Jillian P.

description:
Food = 5 stars.  The Tea leaf salad is just nuts, oil and deliciousness...so if you are anti fat, dont get this... otherwise, so good. The satay was a bit dry.  The seafood stirfry was really really good, light and full of crisp veggies in a light sauce.

Ambiance = 4 stars (it is strangely decorated, in a good way, sort of funny with the xmas light palm tree and the ornaments hanging from ceiling)

Service = 2 stars. SLOOOOOWWWWW service. we ordered right away, then sat there for 20 minutes waiting for appetizers and I had to ask for them after which they came out right away, obvious they were just sitting there.

I would come back here and give them another try, the food was great.
author: Nilu r.

description: I came here for a family dinner and all 7 of us left wanting more.  The food is great.  The  rainbow salad keeps me coming back.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Sadly my favorite Burmese restaurant has gotten popular & now the wait time is outrageous. :-(
I found this place when I was living in the city a year ago. My husband & I actually wanted to try out Burma Superstar but the wait was about 3 hrs so we walked around & found this lil place. It was great & we continued to go since. Back when we were living in SF we never had to wait to eat here... it was never THAT busy & we were always able to take out as well. So yummy!
Fast fwd to last weekend..... this place is SUPER BUSY. We hadn't been there in over a yr since we moved to the east bay... and we figured we'd check the place out since we were in the neighborhood. The lobby was packed! We didnt get seated til 1.5hrs later!! From waiting to be seated to paying for our meal... took us 3.5hrs total. It was worth it... this place is GREAT... but I dont think I'll be waiting that long again =(
author: Viv D.

description:
We go to this place for any occasion - regular lunch or a special dinner with friends and family. The interior is gorgeous, all those fresh fruits and flowers tell you - the place is well taken care of!!! Clean, beautiful, authentic! 

Their food is an experience worth drawing for a few extra miles! San Francisco provides a variety of similar cuisine options and working in the business district I've been spoiled. But this one is a hidden gem! I love a lot of dishes - green papaya salad, coconut soup, hot-n-sour soup, variety of curries, flower teas, special bread, you name it.         

You can't beat their lunch special! However for the dinner they do get a bit pricy. 

All in all - highly recommend going as a couple, with kids, or with friends! Everybody will be accommodated.
author: Elena K.

description: Mandalay was tasty and the staff was very friendly. Besides the fact that they don't want you to take pictures of the food, the food was still good. Some of my family and friends and I were in SF for the day, so my sister insisted on Mandalay. It's Burmese food so it's kind of a blend of Indian, Chinese and kind of Mediterranean. It's pretty much a fusion of flavors. We started off with the tea leaf salad which does not resemble a typical salad at all. It consisted of Burmese tea leafs, lentils, grounded shrimp, fried garlic, sesame seeds, peanuts and dressing. I highly recommend this dish because it something unique and I'm sure you will never find a dish like this at any other Burmese restaurant. All in all it was a nutty yet earthy dish. We then had the Burmese style curry with white rice. This dish reminded me of the Indian Dahl / curry dishes that my dad makes. It was a thicker curry and tasted pretty good. Nothing too mind blowing but not bad. We then had the Mandalay special noodle, which was refreshing. If you want a vegetable dish I suggest the Mandalay eggplant. It was crispy and hearty and oh so yummy. All in all the food was good. So if you're in need of Burmese cuisine Mandalay is the place to play!!!
author: Reena R.

description: What can I say, it's one of my favorites.  It really gets crowded after 7:30 pm with people hanging out of the sidewalk outside the front door because there is no more room inside.  Walk in and write your name on the list - attached to a wall on your left.  My personal favorites include Burmese Hot and Sour soup and Rangoon Lamb. If you like noodles try Mandalay Noodles.
author: Vadim N.

description:
This place is pretty tasty. I like it a lot and compared to Burmasuperstar's ridiculous wait, I like it even more. You can make reservations here too! 

I had the basil lamb and it was really good. Tried the curry chicken and the cod with yellow bean sauce too and it was strangely reminiscent of chinese food you can buy on clement street for a few bucks. 

Overall, I liked it. They seated the three of us at a two person table because they were so busy but wanted to honor the order of the wait list. Dampered the vibe, but squeezing so closely together for dinner. 

I'll check it out again though. =)
author: Jeannie L.

description: Long wait, but the food is good. The walnut prawns come in a strange looking tower, but they taste good. Not as refined as some of the other burmese places in the area, but it serves nice homey food.
author: Anna J.

description: On par with Burma Superstar, it is really good Burmese food with a relaxed atmosphere and reasonable prices.
author: John B.

description: Wow! The food here was amazing.  The staff was super nice and friendly. We started out with Tea leaf salad which was one of the best things I ever ate.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Geo S.

description:
In the ongoing debate of Burma Superstar vs. Mandalay, I have to throw my lot in with the Mandalay crowd. The food is always great, but there are a few things that you just have to accept as fact when coming to Mandalay:

- You have to order the tea leaf salad. I honestly feel like they should just bring this to every table without even asking.

- You have to order the coconut rice. Again, don't even give people the chance to not order it.

- This place is always busy. You won't have to wait as long as Burma Superstar, but expect to wait at least a little bit for a table.

- It's best to call in ahead of time to put your name on the list. I'm not sure exactly how much it helps, but I've never had to wait longer than half an hour and that was with a big group.

- Don't really expect to have a single person be your server for the meal. They kind of operate with an everybody does everything structure.

On the whole, I love this place and highly recommend it to anybody looking for some Asian food that isn't quite Thai and isn't quite Chinese.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
In the last 5 years in living in this city, I've left a grand total of two yelp reviews (one scathing, one lukewarm). I'm happy to leave my first ever 5 star review for Mandalay! 

This place is superb, and service is perfection -- waiters and waitresses work hard; owner is patrolling the restaurant like it's her job (bc it is...!)

Eff Burma Super Star and it's one hour wait. 
Food at Mandalay is super tasty, and they have a pickup option, which is great bc I'm a lazy fuck who doesn't like to cook during the two days out of the week when I don't get food at my overfunded startup gig. 

Very few people know what it takes to run a good restaurant, but I can say that the operations of this place is outstanding, and it shows in food. Highly recommend it
author: food y.

description:
This is the best Burmese restaurant I have been to!

All the salads here are very colorful and appetizing. I'd have to say my favorite is the Rainbow Salad though.

As for their appetizers, I really like the Balada (curry dip pancake) and samosas!

And last but not least, pretty much all the meats and seafood that I've tried so far are good - Rangoon, Mango, Rainbow, and Mandalay style!
author: Julie H.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant so far in SF. Granted, I only moved here a few months ago, but really, it's special.

The best way I can think to describe Burmese food to anyone who hasn't yet tried it is that it's like a culinary mashup involving Vietnamese freshness, Indian depth, and predominantly Thai ingredients. I hadn't tried Burmese food until I moved to this city, but I'm completely enamored with it now and I've been to three places so far and like Mandalay the most.

I usually get the Mandalay special noodles, which are wide noodles in a coconut lime leaf sauce with garlic chips, dried shrimp, cilantro, chicken, and other goodness. Each dish here has over a dozen ingredients so it's tough to try memorizing them! 

Other great dishes I've tried here include the lamb curry, the naan-like bread that's buttery like croissants (very special!), the famous tea-leaf salad which isn't like a salad you've ever tried, and a spicy lychee nut mango salad appetizer that was on special one day.. really, I don't think it's possible to order anything here that isn't good.

The service is excellent. The waitstaff mix the salads and noodles for you at your table, explaining what everything is with the utmost patience and grace. We've always been impressed by the service.

The great thing about this place, too, is that it's never too crowded like some of the other places nearby. The one time (out of I'd say 5 times I've been there) that it was crowded, they were still on their game and gracious hosts. Everyone waiting was treated to free wine. Awesome.

So yes, I highly recommend this place. It's one of the best things ever.
author: Sherah S.

description:
No chance that this place is better than Burma Superstar

Yes, the servers ram it in your face that Mandalay was the first Burmese restaurant to reach SF, but their duration of experience aint got nothin' compared to Burma Superstar. I'm not saying that Mandalay isn't a nice restaurant to check out (hence the solid 3 stars). There really wasn't anything necessarily bad about it. On the other hand, I went here for Burmese, and instead got mandalay chicken, aka the equivalent of panda express's orange chicken with a thai sweet chili sauce that you can find in a bottle at an asian supermarket (I'm pretty sure even Trader Joe's has these sauces on their shelves too) 

Our dishes:
- Chicken satay appetizer: had an initial kick of curry taste, but was followed by an overcooked dryness and a bland peanut sauce
- Coconut rice: good, but not as coconut-ey has Burma Superstar's
- Mandalay chicken (see above)
- The girly got a burmese iced tea, which was like any thai iced tea, but this one wasn't as overly sweet as you may find in other restaurants that overdo the sweet condensed milk

The only reason you should choose Mandalay over Burma Superstar is that the wait might not be as long since it's a bigger restaurant and you might be into the suuuppperr ghetto menu (prices pen-written and taped on) and tacky decorations.
author: Ronald T.

description:
the skinny:

nice people - they respected special requests & attentive
nice atmosphere - relaxing, 
tasty food - Burmese is a nice switch
Because it's not on Clement, if you go a bit early you can avoid the excessive hippy crowds you see at Burma Superstar
author: Chris G.

description: I was visiting a good friend of mine in SF (from So Cal) and happened to mention that I love Thai food.  So we ended up here.  Lo and behold, we run into others we went to high school with (mind you over 15 years ago in San Diego) at this restaurant!  Either we all fall into a specific demographic of folks that love this kind of stuff... or this place is that good all ended up here.  Well believe it, it's that good.  And something different.  Our party had the tea leaf salad (herbacious and yummy- could have used extra lemon), coconut rice, basil chicken (spicy!), and asparagus chicken.  The basil chicken and coconut rice were the best.  Would love to come back when I'm in town again!
author: Connie W.

description:
I'm a bit hesitant to even review with such high salutations because I don't want this place becoming even more popular than it's already become. I'd much rather see hoards of people waiting outside Burma Superstar while I get seated quickly and eat a delicious meal at Mandalay. Staff is super friendly. On some crowded nights, they  provide free wine while you wait. Even though the white wine has the quality of nail polish remover, it's at least a thoughtful gesture most other places don't provide. 

Food recommendations are endless. A must have is the Burmese Yellow Chicken Curry. The texture of the chicken and potatoes are perfect, while the sauce is what Yellow Curry should always taste like. Not a large portion but keep in mind these are actually how big portions should be. This is isn't Chile's or TGIF people! Paired with the coconut rice, you'll definitely go home happy. The tea leaf salad is outstanding. They prepare the 9(?) ingredient dish in front of you. Just be careful of the lemon squirt at the end. I caught the acerbic juices in the eye once.......

Last several times, I've ordered the Samusas - a move I'm sticking with and highly recommend. The prawns in the prawn dishes are massive and flavorful. Most people I've shared the Walnut Prawn dish with are on one side of the fence or the other as it's unique sweet glaze provide a  "hate-it-or-love-it" response. A more conservative solid prawn choice is the Basil Prawn or Pan Fry Prawn with String Bean. I'm not a huge fan of coconut, but people rave over the coconut water served in a giant coconut. 

The complimentary dessert looks like a gelatinous french fry. Tastes better than it looks. Pretty much the only item I don't like is a lemony noodle dish (my apologies for not remembering the name). The menu is quite large so one dish out of a several dozen is more than acceptable. Not everything can be perfect - keep in mind, even Heidi Klum has bad cuticles.


To sum up: it's a fantastic Burmese option even amongst the several quality Burmese choices in the area. The pricing is appropriate and it's nearly impossible to go home unhappy. But please don't let this review sway you into coming to Mandalay if you're a new-bie. I don't like waiting for good quality food.
author: Alex O.

description:
My man introduced me to Mandalay. Thanks to him, all of you who are reading my review will be spared of the infamous wait at the famous Burma Superstar. A short walk away from the Superstar, Mandalay is like raw undiscovered talent. No hype, no crowds, no joke. Their food is incredible. 
 
I recommend getting the tea leaf salad. It is super fresh with a nice kick of spicy. The catfish curry, with the perfect balance of crispiness and sauciness, is heavenly. The mango shrimp, although simple, will send your taste buds to a tropical island and back. All this great food without the headache and annoyance of having to wait.

My man may not be the best cook out there, but he brings me take-out from Mandalay...and for that he is my Superstar!!!
author: Sue L.

description:
My reactions to the food I ordered:

Pan Fry Okra Prawn - "OMG."
Rangoon Beef - "WOW."
Coconut Rice - " (speechless) "
Ginger Salad - "...Interesting..." (not really my cup of tea but worth a try)

Will definitely come back again to try the rest of the menu.
author: Sarath S.

description:
Do we really need 348 reviews of Mandalay?  I say yes, only because I want to break 400 reviews sometime!

After rave reviews of the Balada, I had to try it.  Give me dough, and say it's fried, and I am there!  It's served with a Curry dipping sauce, (maybe?), and I liked it equally dipped in the hot sauce that they put on your table.

Then we had the Tea Leaf Salad, and while it does not seem like a salad, and there's not much greens in it, but was very good!  I tried to get all the jalapeno slices, but my friend tried a slice.  That's all I will say about that!  It's nice that the server will show what everything is, and mix it for you at your table.  I liked this very much, since it's so different.  An actual Nut Salad!

We also had the Manadlay Noodles, vegetarian.  The noodles were almost creamy, and full of flavor.  This too was tossed table side.

I wanted some protein, and tried the Mandalay Beef, and it was just OK.  I wanted it spicier.  For some reason, I totally forgot about the hot sauce.  I suppose I wanted to try it as it is served.   We also had the Dry Fried String Beans and they were very good too.  Don't miss the Coconut Rice!  It's an interesting flavor combination.

For me, it's an easy bus ride, and I will be back!
author: Michael M.

description: Love their food! You have to try the tea leaf salad for sure! Their noodle dishes are very good as well as the duck & pumpkin curry! Tasty ginger lemonade. Service is just ok but they are extremely friendly and you go there for the food! My to go to for burmese food!
author: Caroline C.

description:
EDIT 12/08/07:  Psst!  I think I've found heaven (it's in the balada!).

-------------------

I had been to Mandalay once before and didn't think much of it.  My first impression was that they were a step above the hyped up Burma Superstar.  In comparison, there was little wait, if any.  There can only be so much to add for a business that already has 227 reviews, but recent return visits have impressed me enough that I must share and add my own praise.

Lately, I've been a slave to the walnut broccoli tofu and coconut rice combination.  Like Remy's experience with combining foods in Ratatouille, it's like a flavor explosion in your mouth; the melding of flavors with the sauce and the rice are right on.   

Dining in or dining out, the service has always been hospitable.  Mandalay's a great choice to satisfy both meat and non-meat eaters, and a comparable option for when you don't want to bother waiting to eat at "that other" Burmese restaurant.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMandalay.

So I live closer to Burma Superstar, but I've never even bothered to attempt its horrendous wait. Instead I walk a couple blocks further to Mandalay, where the seating is ample and quick and the food is GOOD.

I always leave this place in a CCC (complete carb coma), which I suppose is another reason why the slightly further distance is an advantage (allows me to walk it out walk it out now walk it out walk it out...)

Everything I've had here is good. Unlike the more common genres of Asian cuisine, I've learned here that Burmese flavors tend to have a spicier, tangier kick to 'em, which I adore. The 2 items that have become mainstays for me here would be 

1. Balada: very similar to the roti/rotee. Served with a curry-like sauce. Greasy and HEAVENLY scrumptious in your mouth.

2. Nan Gyo Dok noodles. All their noodles are pretty good, but the NGD ones are the best, in my opinion. The Singapore noodles remind me much of Flipino pancit noodles, and the Mandalay noodles are a fatter version of NGD. But NGD consists of the perfect sized linguini-like noodles, mixed together with a whole bunch of delicious surprises that capture the essence of that unique Burmese zest I mentioned earlier.

Oh, and it's kind of like Christmas in here, too. All the ornaments, gourds, and wreath-like foliage and lights hanging everywhere only enhance the inevitable end result of dining here, which mimics a large, delicious Christmas meal:

Mmm...

CCC...

zzz....
author: Kate V.

description:
We decided to head up to the city to grab dinner with some friends, and they suggested this place. It's Burmese food, so I was excited to try a whole bunch of new plates there since I don't get Burmese food very often. We got a bunch of stuff and shared, family-style. It was crowded in there, and it was rainy that night, but man was it worth it. Everything was super good, and the atmosphere was very comfortable. Nice, but still comfortable. Loved it.

We had lots of stuff: Balada - Crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce, Samusa - mixture of grounded curried meat & potatoes, Ong No Kaw Soi - Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup (soooo good!), Mango Chicken, Mandalay Special Noodle, Coconut Rice, Burmese Curry Beef, Bird's Nest Seafood, and Sweet Potato Dessert. '

I will definitely be back for more. The only thing that was a little sad for me is that a lot of the food was spicy (of course - it's Burmese food) and I am lame and cannot handle the heat. Awesome flavor still though - it's worth the burning pain to try it all :)
author: Jenna L.

description: Slightly overpriced but this place has good service and a great variety of food as well as flavors. Try the house noodle special.
author: Danielle O.

description:
So, I was under the impression that one goes to Burma Superstar for the best burmese food in sf.  But I was wrong.  

The food here is way better and the service, way nicer. 

The tea leaf salad was amazing, the venue cute and large.  

The samosa soup was really good, I only wish that they portion was larger....

Can't wait to go back
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
The 2 star rating is for the service. I ate there last night and their timing could not be more off!

But first, to be clear, the food was fine. It is really flavourful, salty and tangy and garlicky. If you like Thai, Indian, and Vietnamese cuisine, then you'll do just fine here. If you prefer foods on the more mellow side, then Mandalay might not be the place for you.

Last night, I ordered the ginger salad, white rice, roti appetizer (bread with dipping sauce), and string beans with tofu. I do prefer the tea leaf salad vs. ginger salad, but both are good.

The waitress clarified and asked, "Is the ginger salad your entree?" I answered, "Yes, with the rice please." I was expecting to get the roti appetizer first. Nope, out came the ginger salad ....no rice. I waited 15 minutes. No one noticed I wasn't eating the salad. So, my mom asked for rice for me. Thanks mom!

I was still waiting for the roti appetizer. 30 minutes into the meal, it still didn't come. I went ahead and started with the salad. Then we asked the wait staff to check in on our food. Finally, my mom's entree comes. They seemed annoyed that we kept asking for the roti...finally, 40 minutes after we put in our order...the appetizer comes.

Moral of the story: don't order an appetizer unless you want it for dessert.

Worse than sending our food out in an untimely manner? The waitress asked to clear our table before I even finished eating! I was chewing my food and she asks, "Are you all finished?" I couldn't answer with my mouth full, so she watched me eat while waiting for an answer. She cleared a few dishes. And then every minute, she came back to clear a few more though we weren't finished with the meal. I don't know what the rush was. Usually they are 125% full, last night, they were maybe 75% full.

They need to work on their service here! I would only come back for take out, or to order only one dish. I can't bring a guest or children here unless they improve their timing.
author: Ato Z.

description: I had my birthday dinner here this year. The service Is amazing. The waitress was so kind and patient with us regardless of the drunk, belligerent fools at my table. And the food is AMAZING! Keep it up!
author: M. J.

description: The spicy eggplant, beef curry, mango salad, special noodles(first time I've tasted anything like this), coconut rice, and mango chicken were great. We shared these plates with 5 people. Service was fast and friendly.
author: Curtis Y.

description:
I have always wondered about this restaurant.  I am not sure when the first time I ever saw this place or wanted to try it out but it was awhile ago.

What kept me from going there?  Parking.  I had no desire to look for parking on California St or in the upper Richmand Dist.  

I ate there this evening because friends made reservations.  "Okay..."  I figured that I woud get there 30min early to look for parking.

The food was excellent.  A little pricy but not outrageous.  $95 "out the door"  for the four of us which included three fancy tropical fruit concoctions.  

Would I go there again?  Yes, I would.  Especially if I get parking directly in front of the restaurant like I did this evening.  Go figure...?
author: Miguel C.

description: I had the samusa soup, which was very beany in texture, was seasoned somewhat spicy. The pumpkin pork stew was quite good and was also spicy. The portion was not hefty at all; rather skimpy (frown). Attentive service from the servers and the price was reasonable.
author: Derek N.

description: Nice people great food.  Wait isn't ridiculous like the other Burmese place in town. I would go here over the other place any time.
author: M C.

description:
After eating at the trendy Burma Superstar, I was weary about trying any more places like it.  But after hearing Burmese people recommend Mandalay, I decided to give it a shot and would say that I'm fairly satisfied.

Service is great here!  A week in advance, I made a reservation for ten people on a Saturday night.  We got there fifteen minutes before our designated time and a table was already ready for us.  I even got to order all the food before our entire party showed up to decrease the lag time and they had no problem with that.  Even though this is a Burmese/Mandarin restaurant, I didn't expect it to have so many Chinese dishes.  The menu is pretty evenly split between the two types.  The appetizers & soup that we ordered is definitely Burmese though.  For rice, you can get steam, brown or coconut rice... one order can serve two people.  I recommend the coconut!

Samusa (curried chicken & potatoes wrapped in skin & deep fried) - Better than Burma Superstar's by far.  Perfectly crisp outside & seasoned inside.  Comes with 5 pieces, pickled vegetables & some hot sauce (I think it's Thai sriracha.... I have a bottle at home).  You can also get this vegetarian.

Balada (Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce) - I've eaten this all my life and this place makes it good.  I wonder if they actually make their own balada or get it from someone.  The curry was mediocre though... a little chunky and I wasn't even sure what was in it that made it that way.

Rainbow Salad (Salad prepared with eight ingredients served with house special dressing) - Only 8 ingredients?  When Burma Superstar has 22?  Just kidding, I don't even like Burma Superstar.  This dish is refreshing to eat... you can definitely taste the lemongrass. I still recommend the Tea Leaf Salad since that's the most popular Burmese salad.

Moo Hin Nga (Catfish chowder with rice noodles, ground catfish, onions, and cilantro) - Very good!  Tasted like there was some time and effort put into it since this dish normally takes a while cook.  It's the pho/ramen/kimchichigae of Burma.  If you haven't had this soup before, it's on the heavier side so it can be treated as another entree instead of an appetizer.

Rangoon Beef (Marinated beef sauted with tomato, onions and green chili) - Now this is more of a Chinese tasting dish.  Good but nothing special.

Mango Chicken (Pan Fry chicken sauted with fresh mango, onions and green chili) - Sweet and tasty.  They put a lot of mango pieces in it.

Pumpkin Chicken Curry - Served in a little green pumpkin.  I wasn't particularly impressed but some others enjoyed it.  It's not a thick curry but it goes well with the coconut rice.

Dry Pan String Bean (Pan fried string beans, ginger and chili sauce) - This is actually a very simple dish to make.  If I knew what it was, I wouldn't have ordered it because we make it all the time at home.  I would recommend ordering something else unless you're in the mood for string beans or something simple.

Mandalay Noodle (Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow pea powder, lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top) - It actually tasted very similar to the Rainbow Salad.  It's a cold dish and they mix it at your table but they don't explain what the ingredients are to you like they do at Burma Superstar.  
 
Ginger Tea Lemonade - It tastes weird at first but after you mix it and let it sit for a while, it's quite delicious.  Presentation is nice... it's served in a tall glass.

Between Mandalay & Burma Superstar, it's definitely Mandalay for me.  The wait is shorter & it's less crowded inside.  I like the intimate feel & decor... they have Burmese artifacts and photos around the restaurant.  Also, the food tastes more authentic & less commercialized.
author: Shannon L.

description:
We had dinner at Mandalay Burmese & Mandarin Cuisine where they had the Tea Leaf Salad which was so different and soooo surprisingly good.  They got the Mandalay Beef, which I took and bite and thought was really tasty, crispy, sweet and sour.  They said the Roasted Tea Duck was the best, really good, moist.  I had a bit of the Coconut Rice, which was moist and tasted nice.  My dining mates had the Mandalay Ginger Lemonade, good, but sweet.  I had the Coconut juice, that was so refreshing and just like the packaged stuff, but obviously much more fresh, right out of the coconut.   I also had the Pauldon dessert which was good and tasted like a Vietnamese 3 bean dessert.  

I was pretty impressed.  The service was great, food surprised me.  I'm now looking for a Burmese restaurant here in Houston!

For photos, http://sooandthecity.blogspot.com/2011/11/soo-kim-greenwood-king-properties_12.html
author: Soo K.

description:
Burmese food is damn tasty. A mixture of Chinese, Thai, and Indian flavors all wrapped up into one tasty cuisine... and luckily, Mandalay does not disappoint. 

While Burma Super Star will always be my favorite because of the heavenly samosa soup,  I am not a fan of the 45 minute waits for a table. At Mandalay, you can make reservations and generally get a table with ease. Along with their solidly yummy food, the price is reasonable, the decor is cute (with some quirky eclectic touches that just add to the character), and the service is prompt and friendly.

 I highly recommend this place. Also, they serve tthe yummy tea leaf salad now!
author: Kimi W.

description:
Yesssss!  A super yummy, super cheap, super laid back, super friendly, super awesome restaurant in SF!!

Coconut drink: served right from the coconut.  On a plate.  With a straw.  And a cute umbrella.  Am I in the islands, or am I in the city?  Oh, right.  City!  (Darn...)

Tea leaf salad: mmm.  So many flavors and textures all blended together!  It's cute how they mix it for you right at the table.  I loved all of the crunch.  Highly flavorful and very healthy.  Makes you feel good.  Hedonists, come and get yo tea leaf salad!

Shrimp with okra: spicy!  But in a tangy, Asian way.  Lots of garlic.  Okra still a little crunchy... yet very satisfying.  Red bell pepper slides and strips of carrot to complement. 

Mandalay noodle: coconutty.  Yes, that was the coconut chicken talking (you can request tofu if you'd prefer) and it spoke very loudly.  Fortunately it was pleasantly balanced with a bit of spice and a pleasant base of yellow curry.  The fried noodles on top added a nice crunch.

Mango pudding: cute!  We didn't even ask for this, but out it came anyways.  The servers were adorable... and helpful.

Total: $25/person after tax/tip/Healthy SF
author: Lindsay M.

description: We came here today with a friend who is Burmese and she says most of the things we ordered were very authentic Burmese taste, even though she says the menu looks like Burmese fusion.  I especially liked the Pa Na Jong, which is a mixture of dried shrimps, shallots, dry fried fish bits, garlic, and chili.  It is crunchy and tasted awesome mixed in with the coconut steamed rice. The curry chicken (very bland) and tomato soup (tasted like minestrone) was underwhelming for me. Rainbow salad and tea leaf salad were as good as BurmaSuper.
author: James W.

description:
Incredible, wonderful, delicious.  The best Burmese food I have ever had.

Mandalay has the feel of an old-school Asian restaurant.  The servers are slightly formal, while helpful.
