We had a tofu appetizer, the honey walnut broccoli, and some coconut noodles.  We had to stop ourselves from licking our plates.

I like Burma Superstar, and I have a special place in my heart for Yamo.  But Mandalay is my new favorite for Burmese food in San Francisco.
author: Tara M.

description: My co worker recommended this place to me and I visited twice last week. The staff were very friendly and attentive. My favorite dishes were the Mandalay Beef and Mango Chicken. There's a little bit of wait but it's well worth it. Just know the second time I went two additional friends and they will put you in a table of two, meaning someone sit in a chair and the other two will sit on the booth. If you are sitting on the booth side, you'll get to know your neighbors well. Again, I didn't mind it too much and the food was delicious!
author: Kimberly K.

description: I love this spot so much when I die I want my friends to bring my casket to the restaurant, use it as a table and order the Mandalay Chicken. Can't wait to go back! Also the service was great!!!
author: Dylan B.

description:
I came here with my girl Les... She made reservations, but we arrived early.

The lady in the front seated us right away.  Hmmm, are we the only Asians besides the servers??? YIKES!

We ordered fish chowder, samosa salad (did I spell that right? LOL), and beef curry.  Lots of food, but lots of waiting??? We had to wait so long for our food, while everyone who came after us were inhaling their food! (minus one star)

The service seemed tied up... I can tell the servers paid attention to certain tables. But the food was great.  My favorite was the salad, thanks to Les who made the choice.  My number one pet peeve is rushing me.  And I could tell the place was getting busy, but the servers did not rush me at all! Cant wait to come back for more!
author: Cel A.

description:
Burma Superstar + reservations (even on OpenTable) = Mandalay!

I still like a few dishes at Superstar better, but boy is it nice to be able to eat a good samusa soup (extra spicy please) and not have to deal with a parking nightmare followed by 30 minutes of waiting on the street for a table.
author: Mike G.

description: Mandalay is a hidden gem located in the Richmond district. The place can get crowded during prime time and especially during Friday/Saturday nights. Mandalay is the place to go if you don't want to deal with the crazy lines at the Burma Superstar nearby. The ambiance is a tacky in a kinda cool way. Place is packed and tables are cramped together, but it's all ok because the food is always good. I always like to try something new each time I'm there, but always seem to order one of their noodle dishes.
author: Rick T.

description:
Pretty good Burmese/Mandarin food. Just as good as Burma Superstar but without the hype or wait. 

Got take out here last week. We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Mandalay Noodles, Veg. Hot and Sour soup, mango prawns, and coconut rice. The tea leaf salad was a disappointment to me. Compared to the salad at Burma Superstar, this one was different. Only 3 shreds of lettuce with a bunch of nuts and sesame seeds...it was quite different. Not even a salad. Just tea leaf and nuts. The hot and sour soup was the best dish of the night. Not too spicy and not to sour. The mango prawns came in second. The mangoes were so good and sweet. Not mushy and didn't affect the prawns that were lightly dipped in batter. The coconut was VERY good. So fragrant and fresh. 

I would def suggest this place. Especially if you want a different Burmese restaurant. Decor is simple and elegant. Very spacious, not so packed like BB is. You can take your time here and don't have to feel rushed.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: First time here in about three years and what a difference ... for the worse. The prices have gone up the portions gave gone down. There were five in our party four adults and a 6 year old. We had two appetizers and four main dishes to eat family style and the bill with tip came to $99! We came at 5:45 on a Friday and were told only two desserts were available ... how can you not have any bananas for the fried bananas?? Three years ago you could walk in and get a table no problem now you need a reservation. As the two nearby Burmese placed are always busy the overflow now goes to Mandalay and it doesn't seem like they can handle it, and  response they have decreased their portion sizes and raised prices. Food was okay but no longer outstanding ... sad reflection of the times I guess.
author: Chas D.

description:
Wow. 

After my lunch hour here, I was convinced that Burmese food is pretty tasty and delicious. We had ordered the Tea Leaf Salad with lettuce, Mandalay Chicken, Prawns with Fried Okra and the fried rice. This was my first time here and loved it. The service was friendly and helpful. We didn't have to wait for a table; we walked right in and was seated right away. We had a few beers to go with our meal and it was perfect. The food coma was definitely worth it!
author: Mika D.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  Love it.  Food is great.
author: Carol W.

description:
I actually think this place is better than Burma Superstar. Maybe because it didn't have all the hype to live up to, or the wait, but regardless the food spoke for itself. Good, authentic, service is friendly, and the ambiance is nice. 

Tea leaf salad, apparently can be served in the traditional style or in the American way (with lettuce). We tried it traditional, and it's not like a salad at all, more like a savory granola with the crunch of peanuts and garlic. Very tasty.

Mandalay's special noodles where interesting, burmese flat noodles similar to skinny chow fun in a yellow curry sauce. I didn't feel like the dish had enough noodles on the plate, they were slippy to eat, the curry sauce didn't seem to stick to them well. I scooped all the remaining curry sauce onto my coconut rice though and it worked, perfect!

We also ordered ragoon beef, mandalay chicken, and the sizzling rice soup. Sizzling rice soup was good but ordinary. The meat dishes were very good, good seasoning and a decent amount of spice.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Screw you, hour and a half wait at Burma Superstar.  Mandalay will seat you in 20.  On a Saturday night.  BOOYA.

Ok enough now.  

Mandalay is super on par with Burma in terms of the true Burmese dishes.  Their special Mandalay noodles are so so delicious.  Didn't have the tea leaf salad but it looked awesome.  You may want to get a little bit more info about the dishes before ordering-- the Mandalay beef, which we thought would be more "Burmese" is kind of like really good Chinese take-out sweet and sour pork (but with beef).  The string beans and tofu is also a more Cantonese style dish.  Not that they aren't tasty, they just didn't seem super Burmese.  Next time we'll ask the server.  Who, did I mention, was probably the nicest little asian lady I've ever met.  She offered us a drink the second we walked in and made sure to give us updates on the status of our table.  Absolutely lovely.  

Also got complimentary custard/jello-y mango dessert which was Deelish.  Can't wait to go back and then drive down Clement St. and laugh at everyone at Burma (which, I will admit is also excellent, just overhyped).
author: Kristin P.

description:
Held my 1st graduation dinner here on a Saturday night. Made reservations via opentable for a party of 11 at 7. We were running late, so I called in, and they said they would be able to accommodate us at 7:30

When we got there, it was packed! I kept asking about our table, and they said soon soon. There weren't any empty tables, so obviously there was no room for us. 10 minutes passed, and the boy tried to flag down a server, and she kinda just walked passed him and said "I'll take care of you." Maybe after 20 minutes of waiting we were finally seated. 

Food was pretty good! I really enjoyed the veggie samosas, the chicken coconut noodles, and the tea leaf salad. I don't know if I like their tea leaf salad the most, but it is very close to Burma Superstar's. The mango prawns were pretty good (mango very ripe!), but I do like Burma Superstar's mango tofu better. As for dessert...most of my family thought they were just okay...though mango sticky rice was pretty bomb. I say take a trip to Genki's if you're not full yet. I do like the fresh coconut water!!!

Food is good. Most of my fam had never had Burmese before, but now they love it. Service was pretty slow and inattentive...it took forever to get our order out. And they made me wait for my table that I reserved... parking is a biotch, so beware!
author: Katrina L.

description:
Waited over an hour with a reservation on a Friday night.  We had a few stragglers in our party though and they won't seat you til everyone's there so try not to lose your reservation.  This place is extremely popular especially for how out in the boonies of SF it is.  The restaurant isn't that big so the entrance was packed with people waiting for a table.  Food was very good though and well worth the wait. 

Vegetarian samusas - yum

Tea leaf salad - yum, colorful salad of pickled tea leaves, sesame seeds, peanuts, and fried garlic.  you can ask them to add shredded lettuce which we did for added salad-like freshness.  

Green beans - beans were cooked through but still bright green and crunchy, flavorful, not too oily.  

Coconut rice - rice cooked in coconut milk, very fragrant, a must try, goes great with savory dishes.  they have brown rice too.  

The #1 noodles were OK.  Friends liked the meat dishes.  Sangria looked good but was busy drinking Singha beer.
author: Janet C.

description:
Burma Superstar gets all the props for being a good Burmese restaurant, but Mandalay can give it a run for its money. Sure, Mandalay lacks Burma's cult following and revered status, but it's food is pretty good. Burma's food is slightly better, but you're also paying a premium and get smaller portions. Thus, from a value perspective, Mandalay is the way to go. Plus, the restaurant is bigger and easier to find a table. And, who doesn't love neon palm trees and christmas ornaments hanging from the rafters year round?

My husband loves the mandalay beef. I am particularly fond of the coconut noodle dish (I think it's bun tay kawser but don't quote me on that) and coconut rice. Yum!
author: Laralynne B.

description: Seriously, stupid good. I want this right now... and the sangria was great too, for how cheap it was :)
author: Stefani O.

description: Horrible experience -- will not be going back. Four of us had a reservation for 6:30pm. The host lady never checked in with us nor with anyone else standing in the crowd of people near the door. After 10 minutes we mentioned to her that we had a reservation. She dismissed us, saying we were late for our reservation, but then she said the next table would be ours. Another 15 minutes later, she seated a different group of four. My friend and I are 27 and 37 weeks pregnant, and the host lady didn't notice, care or blink about her treatment of us while we stood waiting for over half an hour. We finally left and went to Troya where the service was outstanding. Go there instead.
author: Molly P.

description:
I never tried Burmese food in my life, so I decided to come and try it when I was in the neighborhood.  Hearing that the wait could be quite long, we decided to call and reserve a table of 4 at 7:15.  When arriving, we saw that even with reservations, we would have to wait about 45 minutes.  

After the wait, we were seated and ordered the balada, chin hin yee (Burmese Hot and Sour soup), Mandalay special noodle, Tea Smoked Duck, and the ice cream and tapioca dessert. 

Ultimately the night went like this:
- 45 minutes pass and we complain to the waiter where are food is and then he brings out the soup.  I always thought that restaurants had a giant pot of soup and just pour it in to save some time.  Oh well.  It tasted sort of like Tom Yum soup in my opinion.
- 20 minutes pass, balada comes.  By itseft, meh, but with the curry sauce, it was pretty decent.
- 25 more minutes til the Mandalay Special Noodle came.  The waitress stirred all the stuff together at the table.  It was very inconsistent throughout.  Some of the bites had sauce, while others tasted just like lemons.  The noodles reminded me of linguine pasta.
-15 more minutes, the singapore syle noodles came.  I actually really like this dish.  I thought it was kind of ironic liking a dish with the name Singapore in it at a Burmese restaurant.
-15 more minutes and the duck and dessert came.  I don't understand why they would serve both at the same time.  the duck was pretty tasty, where as the dessert was way too sweet. 

In the end, we spent basically two hours and the food wasn't even that good.  Will not come back.
author: Alan N.

description: Busy place so expect to wait...but it's definitely worth it. Great soups and have a variety of choices for any palettes.
author: Dima S.

description:
Burmese food without all the wait and crowds at those other Burmese places. 

We had the Burmese pancake thing (Balada) with curry sauce for an appetizer. It was really good. A flaky, roti type pancake with a nice curry dipping sauce. For my entree I had the special noodles. I saw the noodles on Check Please and I knew I had to order them. Rice noodles, curry chicken, cilantro, lemon and some other unique ingredients mixed table side. I was pleased with the service and how they prepare certain things table side. I especially loved their consideration when squeezing lemon. They used a napkin to hold the lemon, as to not touch it with their bare hands. Very hygienic!

Overall I'm pleased with Mandalay. It's not a scene like some other places and the food is great. I'll definitely be back, especially for those special noodles.
author: Joshua C.

description:
I like the Mandalay Special Noodles, Mango Chicken, fried spring rolls, coconut rice, coconut chicken soup.  The green papaya salad and tea leaf salad are very fresh and tasty.  Good lunch specials during the weekdays, reasonable.

The owers are very nice and friendly.  They keep the places very clean and nice fresh beautiful flowers.  very good services.
author: Lulu H.

description:
First off, Mandalay is BETTER THAN BURMA SUPERSTAR!

I love their tea leaf salad. It definitely has a lot of interesting flavors and it's super addictive. They have peanuts, sesame, fried garlic clips and fermented tea leaves. I like it better than Burma Superstar's tea leaf salad because there isn't any lettuce and it really high lights the tea leaves. They present their dish with all the individual components before mixing it all together table side. 

I also love the Mandalay Special Noodles. It tastes like a southeast version of Fettucini Alfredo. It's fat noodles with a creamy, coconuty sauce. Really good.

I know it can get pretty crowded at dinner time, so it's a good idea to make a reservation. I usually go at lunch and there's usually no wait. The servers are really nice and the owner is there every day, serving and speaking with customers.
author: Melissa P.

description:
We were quickly seated for 6 on our reservation since the restaurant isnt filled yet.  At this time, the server/manager is still very attentive.  In the next 20minutes, tables slowly started filling up.  Space is tight, for all of us being in our petite asian nature, we are already seated arm to arm.

We ordered quickly seeing so many new tables being seated.  The table came quickly but not altogether.  There are about 5 mins apart for each dish coming out.  Even for the burmese pancake, the same item for 2 orders, there was a wait.  

Food is not as good as burma on clement.  Overuse of the dried fried garlic on most dishes.  The tea leaf salad is nothing but peanuts, fried garlic, and a mish-mash of other things, but the flavor blended but is not tasty.  It is just overcome with garlic. 

Servers started getting much busier and their service was lacking.  Even when spilling over 2 glasses of water on the table and running onto our pants and seats, the server or manager did not sincerely apologize.  Our whole table had to try to get out of our already tight seats so water would run down on us from the table.  I knew this was an accident, but they could've been more sincere and apologetic.  I hardly think I heard the server say anything.  We cleaned up ourselves and just ordered her to bring us more napkins/towels, etc.  Apparently she/they do not know how to handle situations like this.

The food overall was below par.  Again, too much garlic, too salty.  Doesnt bring out the flavor of the food itself too much.  

Thai Tea - too sweet
Tea Leaf Salad - NO! Too dry / fried garlicy.  Go home and mix all your herb spices together and throw in some nuts, that's how it'll taste.
Curry Lamb - too gammy
String Beans - bit oversalted but texture is good
Pancake - texture is good but dipping sauce is bland (no much peanut or curry flavor)
Home-make chili (dipping sauce) - we call this a NOT HOT chili sauce
Flat noodle - good on first taste, lemony, as it gets cold, gets pasty
Sizzling beef - chinese style stiry fry with chestnuts, bell pepper, snappeas on hotplate
Mango Salad - this is good
Prawn seafood - this is good, made with asparagus big prawns.

Lines started forming so server rushed us away by quickly removing all our plates and brought the bill.
author: Ju D.

description: Not a fan of Burmese food since Burma Superstar, but loved the dishes here. Service is wonderful too. Authentic and intimate atmosphere to catch up with close friends.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Yelp says this place is good for groups but I highly refute that. Our party of 16 were cramped in the space they gave us. The waiter was very impatient with us and a bit on the rude side. The food we ordered (and we pretty much ordered 50% of the menu) were small in portion and not good or flavorful. The coconut milk tapioca and mango lassi was decent. 

I would definitely NOT recommend this restaurant for the food or the ambience. I'm not sure what Burmese food really is but I can say that I wasn't impressed in the least.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Where have I been?  This is truly excellent Burmese food.  I wish I lived closer so I could come here more often.  I'm hooked on the tea leaf salad and the Mandalay special noodles.  Seriously, I would want just the special noodles as my meal, but there are so many other scrumptious sounding dishes on the menu that beckon for me to try them!  The baladas are a great way to start off the meal.  Other notables:  mango chicken, lychee prawns and rangoon beef.
author: Thi D.

description:
You can't go wrong here, even if you tried. Everything on the menu is so Yumm! A group of friends and I came here on the 4th of July before heading out to watch the fireworks. No reservations, yet that did not stop them from seating seven people right away. The food was amazing and their blossom tea was gorgeous and delicious.

I highly recommend this place. :)
author: Narina A.

description:
Good spot -- the service was persistent and friendly, and the food was yum. The decor (including a neon palm tree and a foundation geode) cracked me up.

+ Rainbow Salad
+ Spicy Green Beans
+ Burmese Pancakes (sweeter more coconuty flavor)

Affordable prices and delicious flavors. fun!
author: Sarah T.

description:
Hm, first visit = awesome. Second visit = OK. 

+ pretty authentic stuff - they don't put cabbage in the tea leaf salad b/c Burmese people don't do that either...
+ palatha is actually thick and flakey 
+ never a wait (would choose this over Burma Superstar any day)

- you can pass on the coconut noodle soup. my mom makes it better.
- prices are high for the portions you get, probably b/c they can get away with it, but still nobody should pay high prices for Burmese food!

I'll go back, but I'll try other Burmese spots before doing so.
author: Tammy T.

description:
must order:
tea leaf salad
pumpkin curry
mandalay noodles (this dish was golden! so flavorful, i really want to take home a bottle of whatever sauce the chef cooked this in)

pass over:
egg rolls
author: Jen C.

description: This place is awesome!  Great food and a very friendly staff.  I've been coming here for a few years now and everything I have eaten is wonderful.  My favorites are...Tea Leaf Salad, Rainbow Salad, Mandalay Special Noodle, Mango  Chicken,  Walnut Shrimp, Spicy Green Beans and Pumpkin Stew. Oh and don't forget the coconut rice.
author: Darren K.

description:
Came here with the family -- which included two young children -- on Christmas.. They were slammed and overwhelmed with all the people waiting to dine. We were a party of 6, and waited over 20 minutes to be seated all the while, they kept seating smaller tables until one of the bigger tables in the back cleared. They made no apologies for the wait. Nor did they try to push smaller tables together so that they could seat us more quickly.

The service was SLOW but once the food came, it was all really delicious! The Rainbow Salad was great as were the Coconut Prawns with Lychee.
author: N W.

description:
Better than Burma Superstar, but Mandalay still cannot hold a candle to Mingalaba in Burlingame.

I love me some Burmese food, but wait times are so ridiculous.  There is such a large crowd in the front of the restaurant that it doesn't even matter if you've made a reservation, they just do not have the capacity to seat you.  Add that to the four large (8+ people) groups present the Saturday night we went, and you may be waiting for an hour and a half.

During which I played Diner Dash on my iphone.  I got expert.

However, service was impressive for such harried employees.  I was given a glass of wine on the house because of the long wait, and the wait staff would check up on you when they could.  Of course, due to the sheer volume of diners everything was slower than it could have been.

The food itself was good, but not anything that was worth a 90-minute wait.  It also didn't help that we compared each dish with its Mingalaba counterpart.
author: Cathy Y.

description: Great service and space! The food was good, but nothing really inspired me to write something elaborate. We had the eggplant strips, the tea leaf salad, mandalay mango chicken, the chicken curry, the mandalay beef, and the sui gi mok ($90 after tips). The dish I enjoyed the most was the tea leaf salad. All the others were kind of familiar and ordinary. Noticeable differences from Chinese dishes are there, but I find them similar. Don't get me wrong though, they still tasted good but I didn't find them inspiring. The sui gi mok was interesting by the way. It was a warm little cake that was pretty damn buttery LOL. All in all, Mandalay is one of those restaurants you can always come back to and know you'll leave with a solid meal. I really enjoyed the nice and attentive service, which I paid attention to harder because I read a review with someone saying they had shitty service. I'd recommend Mandalay under the circumstances that there is no wait, or if you're just craving some Asian flavors.
author: Holly P.

description:
Went to Mandalay for the first time today for lunch. I had the Rangoon Beef. I have a huge appetite, so I was still a bit hungry after I got done with my dish. The lunch plates are a little on the small side, but I didn't have time to order more. 

The flavor was good, though, and the price was right. And the service was really fast and friendly. I love Burma Superstar, but sometimes it's just not possible to endure the typical 45-90 minute wait to get a table. Mandalay seems to be an excellent alternative since the food appears to be very comparable. And at only a fraction of the time it takes to be seated while being only a little more than a block away, why wouldn't you give them a shot?

I'll definitely be going back. Once I've tried more of the menu I'll update my review. From my limited experience, though, I'd recommend Mandalay in a heartbeat.
author: Don W.

description:
Like several of the other reviews state, this place is just as good as Burma Superstar, if not better.

The service went above and beyond for our excited but indecisive group of 8 ladies. They never once looked annoyed even though some other diners were. I would highly recommend the Balada appetizer, which is a crispy Burmese pancake with curry dipping sauce. The tea leaf and rainbow salads were much like Burma Superstar's and just as good. For entrees, I really enjoyed the Mandalay Special Noodle. Incredible flavors and how can you go wrong with noodles? I don't quite remember what else we had, but all was good. Most of the names of dishes are self-explanatory (i.e. basil chicken, lamb curry). Just go with your gut.

Nice staff, delicious food, great prices and zero line. I'll definitely be coming here over their more well-known competitor.
author: Jasmyn M.

description: My husband and I have been here several times and we never get bored of the tea leaf salad. A house speciality and it's one of the best salads I have had till date. A must try for all peanut lovers. anything on the menu is good and they have a good collection of mocktails too :)
author: Aparna K.

description:
after eating at other burmese restaurants like little yangon in daly city and burmese superstar just down the street, i wanted to see what's mandalay is all about. yelpers have been raving about how amazing it is so i just had to give this place a shot. 

i was with a large group- a rather hungry large group so we ordered at least half the menu and shared family style. the one thing i could eat forever is probably the balada and rangoon spicy fish... seriously i could live on those two dishes alone. the line is much better than superstar's and the food more authentic so thanks mandalay. you earned a good solid a-ok from me!
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
Rich and greasy food; good service; cheap prices!!!

I have not eaten here for months because the grease and garlic-flavored shrimp paste used in many dishes gave me gastrointestinal adverse effects.  However, for the rest of you with a strong stomach, I recommend Mandalay over Burma Superstar.

Recommend:
-Balada: fluffy pancake served with a small cup of chicken curry
-Sambusa: their version of samosa
-Pork stew served in the squash
-Noodle dishes
-Curry dishes
-String bean stir fry: greasy, with a lot of the garlic flavored shrimp paste 
-Tea leaf salad: sometimes the fried soybeans are hard/old
etc.

Beware: they messed up my friend's credit card billing several times: charging her for someone else's meal.  Despite being innocent mistakes, they showed the distracted and careless cashier - owners.  Luckily that did not happen to me.  So pay cash to support this family-owned business and prevent credit card discrepancies.
author: G D.

description: Absolutely love Burmese food and this is a convenient location if you're parking. It gets 4 instead of 5 stars because I had ordered a meal to-go and they didn't remove the shrimp from the meal as requested (I'm vegetarian). Other than that though this is a good second-option to Burma Superstar (soft spot in my heart for that restaurant) and has more space for sitting inside.
author: Lily C.

description: This place is top-notch. Me and my dinner date had the okra prawns (STUPID good) Mandalay noodles and tea leaf salad. Oh and the ginger lemonade is super addicting! Can't wait to come back.
author: Althea D.

description:
This place was arrritee....

Hot: Great interior
SUPER CLEAN BATHROOMS from what I heard from my bro, dad, and uncle
Mandalay noodles: yum!  They had coconut and curry flavors on these flat rice noodles...delish!
Rainbow Chicken: Loved all the different fruits mixed in with the chicken

Not so hot:
The hot and sour soup: eh, all i can remember was that it was thick
Portions: SUPER TINY!  
Service: gave us the wrong dish, forgot our hot and sour soup (that came free with the lunch menu), and took a long time to give us our check
author: Kristen T.

description:
They have great service (really, they do!) The wait staff is attentive, friendly, and really helpful about your orders.  

Their food is always great on presentation, quality and flavor.  They even explain to you about how something is mixed together (They have this special noodle dish, where it's semi-cold and they mix it up at your table, with all of the different seasonings.)

They have a great assortment of americanized fare (mandalay chicken), or the authentic (mango salad), and many of their dishes are spicy, if you're into that.  They have a great assortment of meat choices, seafood dishes, and vegetarian delights.  

I just love this place!  Parking is a pain, because of the area it is in.  But the effort is worth it!
author: Fannie S.

description:
Ah this was a tough review for me because service was good but I wasn't that impressed with the food.  I really wanted authentic Burmese food because I've only had it at my friend's house and was dying for more.  The appetizers and soup that my friends and I ordered were reminiscent of authentic Burmese, but the rest of the dishes were very Chinese.  A little too oily for my taste and the spices in the food weren't that memorable.

We ordered one coconut rice and one order of brown rice.  I love that they have the brown rice option!  I thought the coconut rice would be like sticky rice, but I think it's just white rice cooked with coconut milk.  The texture/consistency is just like white rice but with a hint of coconut taste.

Service was excellent.  Our table for 10 was all setup and ready for us in the back when we got there.  The head manager quickly got a waitress over to us as soon as we said we were ready to order and our first dishes arrived within 15 minutes.
author: Angela C.

description:
Had a lovely meal here with my wife and two friends.

The green tea salad was wonderful - one of my preferred renditions of this glorious dish. The rainbow salad replete with noodles and lots of tasty crunchy items was also decent. The beef curry with platha was great as was the curry coconut soup. Want to go back for the shrimp wonton soup. The dry fried green beans were excellent. Coconut rice was also good. Got a little freebie dessert - some hot and some cool - coconut milk confections. Nice touch. 

The service was friendly and knowledgeable.
author: Marco M.

description: I find this place to be completely overrated. At first the food tastes good but then after it is finished you feel heavy and greasy. I also didn't find the customer service to be very good. I know they get really busy but they were not very accommodating because we had two toddlers with us. It's a pretty open space and they should be more welcoming. It's not like the kids were screaming and crying, all we were asking for was a booster seat and a big enough table. There is better Burmese food in the city.
author: D G.

description: had the coconut chicken soup, reminded me of tom kha gai with noodles added but wasn't anything to write home about
author: Robert B.

description:
1. They asked us if we wanted rice like 4 times.  We didn't.
2. My tofu with broccoli and walnuts was so sweet, delicious, and perfect.
3. The service was on and off, but they definitely rocked at filling up my water.
4. They gave us sweet squash-like free desserts.
5. Samosas and chicken satay were great appetizers.
6. The decor is kind of festive, sparkly, and amazing.
7. Came at 6:30 for 3 and waited 10 min.
author: Julia D.

description:
Like Burma Superstar but better. Oh ya~ 

Must eats: balada, fish chowder, Mandalay special noodles.  
Must try: Burmese fried rice is very unique and unlike any other fried rice.
author: Wakako U.

description:
One of our family favourites. The people here are so nice they take really good care of their customers.

Faves:
-Papaya Salad - not sickly sweet just enough tart
-Okra Prawns - big up all the people from the tropics who love their okra
-Sizzling Beef
-Belada

Once when we waited in those god-awful lines for ages, and then got seated with a baby in a super cramped space they were thoughtful enough to  comp our dessert- Sweet potato pie something not sure but it was super yummy

Please make a reservation - the lines here are killer
author: Bee O.

description:
I don't feel it super necessary to write a huge review on this. Alls I have to say is everything is delish! I'd recommended the chicken satay skewers, the mango salad and the thing that has changed my life. It wasn't until recently that I became a fan of the coconut. I've had it in almost every form, raw cooked, toasted, I've drank the milk, used the cream and live off the water. All of this and I had never had one just cracked open with a straw stuck in it. Life changing. I want to put together a church of latter day coconuts to spread the joys of this versatile satisfying fruit. The fresh water inside and the jelly like scraping to be had form the inner walls. coconut, I heart you.

Very well priced and the noise level is under control. the only drawback to coming to this are of the city is the parking situation. Oh well. I can deal with it.
author: Alia D.

description: It was ok. The service was good.  The tea leaf salad was not my cup of tea, I suppose. It was overwhelmingly fishy.  Even when I think about it now, I shudder a bit. I got their stew that was made inside a pumpkin. I guess it was ok? Everything had some flavor or spice that was pungent...I couldn't really handle it. I've had Burmese food before. Maybe this was too authentic for me?
author: M N.

description:
Burmese food is so good and should be very very popular. My friends have been telling me to go here instead of Burma Superstar. At first I scoffed; Burma Superstar is so good. Boy, was I wrong!

This place was maybe even better than BSS. Tasty as Hell - more authentic, cheaper, amazingly nice service.

It felt comfortable. The flavors and textures were complex. The food was high in fiber, but low in oil. Lots of fresh veggies.

I had the ginger lemonade, samusa soup, tea leaf salad, pumpkin chicken, and coconut rice. Everything was spot on. The portions looked small but were truly very filling.

GO!!!!!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Summary based on 1 lunch:
--to get a reasonable selection I stayed away from the lunch specials and ordered tea leaf salad and samusa soup, planning to take what I couldn't eat home
--tea leaf salad was pretty good
--samusa soup was pretty good, too.  Maybe not as good as Burma Superstar/Oakland
--average service
--no waiting on my visit
--ok prices, somewhat higher than Burma Kitchen
--ok parking
--restroom way better than average for an Asian restaurant

Ok if in the area and there isn't much of a wait.
author: Rich H.

description:
Went there today for the first time and was pleased with the dishes we ordered. We went in during lunch hour rush and it was quite clear they had my table mixed up with the dishes of the neighboring tables. It could have just been a fluke in their otherwise great service, but what matters most when I review a restaurant is THE FOOD! 

The Eggplant was delicious, probably some of the best I've had. It was caramelized, sweet, smoky, and juicy. I also had the Mandalay Pork which was delicious and even the Burmese style milk tea was a bit more refreshing than Thai tea. 

Our neighbors' mango chicken looked awesome, and overall it seemed that though a few people had to wait a little longer for their dishes- everyone was happy. 

If you're looking for something tasty and unique, Burmese food here is definitely a possible route in your food explorations.
author: Jilleen l.

description:
I really don't understand why you would bother trying to go to Burma Superstar when you could come here instead. The inside is actually clean, the staff is very friendly, and it doesn't feel like you are sitting on top of other people--all of which are the case at Burma Superstar. It's also slightly cheaper!

That being said, the food was also better than Burma's. We ordered the 12 ingredient salad, which was vegetarian, and it was awesome! I think it may have even had more than 12 ingredients but it was just a lot of fun and everything in it tasted delicious. It even had little potatoes in it (I love potatoes). We also had the Broccoli Walnut Tofu. It was a little bit spicy, and the walnuts were a delicious touch. A lot of times, tofu in dishes like this can be very spongy and taste too fried, but it was warm and soft inside--very good! We also got the coconut rice, yum!

Another convenience is this place is probably really easy to park at since it is off the beaten path of the richmond area. I walked here, but I could see driving if you lived farther.
author: Jessica K.

description:
I have been going to Mandalay since early 1990- and have seen it go up- down- and now its been wonderful since the new management took over.  The atmosphere- food- music- alters- energy- love-
Sherri is amazing.  I love her and her family.  Brother sisters everyone.
ok- samusa; -papaya salad;- mandalay noodles;- dry string beans;- coconut rice;- thai iced tea or flower blossom tea (I forgot what its called)
Order that- go between 3-6- enjoy yourself.
At nights- this place is super busy and the tables are tight.  You get into others conversations- and I really dont like that- and the noise.
So I go between 3-5 or after 930 and enjoy myself.
Thank you Mandalay.  My favorite restaurant in SF.
author: Jack E.

description:
OK I rarely give out 5 stars, but this place is well-deserving of all five.  Let's first discuss the food.

I am new to Burmese cuisine, so I can by no means comment on authenticity.  However, I know what I like, and this food is absolutely amazing. First of all, you must start with the tea leaf salad. Unlike Burma Superstar, they do NOT put lettuce in their tea leaf salad. As a result, Mandalay's tea leaf salad is actually better--and probably more authentic! For entrees, we ordered the mandalay special noodle with tofu--I COULD DIE! and rainbow shrimp--YUM!  Both were winners. I should also say that I've been here with a group of 8 before, and we got lots of dishes which we shared family style, and everything I tasted was phenomenal.  One particular stand-out was a lamb dish which came with Burmese bread.  Let me just say, that bread was so buttery and delish, I'm surprised it doesn't come with more dishes. 

Next, the service was top-notch.  There were at least 10 people working the dining room making sure water glasses were filled, hot tea was replenished, used dishes were cleared, etc. They all worked together so cohesively to make sure all guests' needs were met. Right on, Mandalay staff!

In conclusion, Burma Superstar is good, but this little gem is better. They don't need to claim to be a "Superstar" restaurant--the food and service speak for itself!
author: Emille L.

description:
Food was delicious! Order the special noodles, fish ball curry, tea leaf salad. Don't order the tea leaf smoked duck-- too dry and all bones. From a food perspective- no complaints!

However, from a service perspective, I had to knock down my review by two stars because here's what happened:
1. They forgot about us at the start-- we had to ask about or salad after waiting 20 minutes.
2. They didn't have tapioca ready for our drink so they urged us to cancel the drink vs. offer us to wait and ask whether that was okay. We told them we were okay waiting... But then they forgot about us again! So we cancelled the drink 1 hour after ordering it.
3. Then they screwed up our curry. They gave us shrimp curry vs. fish ball curry. Btw- the curry was forgotten as well we had to remind them we were still waiting for dish.
4. After the curry, we got the check and they accidentally split the bill 3 way vs. 4 way
5. Overall slow service-- understand it could have been a busy day but still... Multiple errors aren't excusable. Neighboring tables finished before us even though they got there after us

Too bad the food was pretty good otherwise I could just cross this off my list of places to go. I'd go back if I were craving Burmese. But only for that.
author: Steph W.

description: Hands down my favorite restaurant in this city. Excellent atmosphere, food, and service. Cant go wrong with any dish on the menu. A regular spot for me and my roomate.
author: Sara S.

description: I love the palata here - super flaky.  We've come here with people who are new to Burmese food, as well as those who are Burmese foodies.  Never disappointed!  Get the beef curry and tea leaf salad.
author: suzanne l.

description:
Regular on the take-out list after long work days. Saw it on Check Please Bay Area & have noticed it more and more crowded in the past couple months. Great for families & parents in town. 

Favorites include:
-shrimp wonton soup (simple, meaty shrimp wontons in a light but soothing broth with spinach leaves)
-rainbow salad (reminiscent of the one at Burma Superstar)
-mandalay chicken (fried chicken cubes smothered in a thick sauce surrounded by oranges...just chicken, nothing else)
-basil spicy chicken or prawn (lots of basil & bell pepper strips so must be in the mood for it)
-walnut broccoli chicken (pretty straightforward but not in a thick sauce)
-walnut prawn (thick battered prawns, but could do without the cream sauce)

Recently noticed the following items on the restaurant menus but not on the take out menus as I was waiting for an order:
-salt/pepper prawns (fried & shell on)
-mushu shrimp 
-lychee coconut prawns (prawns with coconut chicken, pineapples, & lychees)
-shaking duck (with spinach & pumpkin in a tropical sauce)
-shredded chicken & garlic (with black mushrooms & veggies in a hot sauce)
author: Annie K.

description:
The Burmese food at Mandalay is delicious and fresh! The restaurant features a variety of savory and sweet dishes and is a great place for dinner with friends/family, especially if you aren't familiar with traditional Burmese cuisine. The place itself is not that big so table space is limited so many people waiting for tables have to stand close to one another by the entrance. The restaurant has a nice atmosphere with plenty of ornaments and decorations and it's not incredibly loud so you're still able to talk to your friends/family at the dinner table.

The waiters are very friendly and often described many of the dishes we ordered upon arriving at the table. What was also pretty neat was that many of the dishes are actually prepared at the table, ensuring the crispiness of some of the dishes' ingredients. For the Rainbow Salad, Tea Leaf Salad, and the Mandalay Special Noodles that we ordered, all the ingredients are displayed on the dish before the waiter mixes and prepares it for you. I would definitely recommend the Rainbow Salad, Tea Leaf salad, Mandalay Special Noodles, and the Dry String Beans! Each dish was very flavorful and it was pretty cool seeing the waiter prepare the dishes after explaining each ingredient to us and mixing it all in together to bring out the full flavor of the dishes. The noodles were especially delicious - the flat noodles were cooked in a curry broth with coconut chicken and a range of spices and then topped with fried noodles! Delicious. I would also recommend getting the Balada - crispy doughy pancake-like pastries that one tops with a curry sauce. Great for sharing and starting off the meal.

All in all, delicious food and a great atmosphere for group gatherings. I'd definitely suggest making a reservation as the place was consistently busy throughout the entire night. Only downside of this place in my opinion is the wait time - we made a reservation for 7 PM and still had to wait upon arriving for another 30 minutes or so. Aside from that minor disappointment, I'll probably plan on coming back eventually especially when I'm craving Burmese food.
author: Cheston W.

description:
I was excited to try this restaurant after seeing it on Check Please!, and while I thought it was good I didn't think the quality and taste of the food compared to Mingalaba in Burlingame (which I just found out is a sister restaurant by reading other reviews). Warning: I compared every dish to Mingalaba, which I like better.

Luckily we made 6:00 early reservations because within 10 minutes there were 10+ people waiting to be seated.  Make a reservation!

On to the food:

-Tea Lead Salad: it was okay but not as good as I've had this at other Burmese restaurants
- Balada: not as crispy as I woul've liked but the curry dipping sauce was so good that I would definitely get this appetizer again!
- Dry fried green beans: cooked perfectly but not as tasty as the version at Mingalaba
- Rangoon Beef: there wasn't much beef and the pieces that I ate were a bit overcooked and dry for my liking.  Similar to Mingalaba's version but not as good
- Mandalay Special Noodles: I really wanted to like these but the flavors were a bit muted for my liking. I had to douse everything with hot sauce to give it extra flavor.  I would not order this again

Service:
- Started off great because the restaurant wasn't crowded.  Then the service went downhill as the place got packed.  My dad had seen a dessert on the menu he wanted to try but we didn't get offered dessert.  Instead, we were quickly given the bill which clearly indicated they wanted us to leave!

Overall, this place was good but I wouldn't come back unless I had a reservation.  And, I would go to Mingalaba over this restaurant any day!
author: Marisa G.

description: I have been going there for years.  However, I had lunch there today and can't believe how much they have increased their prices.  There weren't prices on the menu so I didn't know until they brought the bill.  They have just lost a long time customer - it looked a lot emptier than it has on past visits so I wouldn't be surprised if other people have decided the same thing.  Burma Superstar is better - worth waiting in line for - Mandalay is not!
author: Leyla C.

description: The tea leaf salad lives up to the hype. Great spot for vegetarians. Almost any meat dish can be made veg. Staff is really friendly and helpful. Even though it was really busy, we didn't have to wait long for a table and our food. Highly
author: Kris C.

description:
my dad's side of the family is from burma. so it's quiet hard to impress me in terms of burmese food bc i have tasted better and more authentic foods at home. for example, ppl rave about burma star. i would not go there even if there isnt a wait. it was sub par. 

this place on the other hand, blew me away. 

we were here on a tues night and EVERYTHING WAS VERY YUMMY! everything was full of flavor and literally perfect to us. my friend kept saying, "this is one of the best tasting meals i've had in a really long time." 

the service was super. 
the food came out in a timely manner.
they always came around to fill our waters.
the manager (?) asked if everything was going well. 
they very quickly take away our empty plates. 
we were there for a while after we've paid and never once did i felt rushed out there. 
i even saw one waitress help a group move their drinks bc that group didnt like where they sat. then saw her move them again bc i guess the 2nd table was not ideal either to them either lol

at the end there were complimentary sweet potato jello (?) dessert. very yummy also. needless to say we all walked out there a happy and full camper :D

if you're wondering, we got the following (please see pics): 

1. Ginger Salad 8.50 - Toasted with lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing, prepared with pickled ginger - i dont like ginger but this salad was SO good. the ginger was not over powering at all.
2. Vegetarian Samusa Soup 8.50 - Soup made of bean base, curry leaf, broken samusa, lentil, crunchy yellow bean, cabbage, onion and mint leaf. - tastes just like samusa as a soup lol
3. Okra with veg and tofu (cant find this on their menu, we asked the waiter what he recommends)
4. Mandalay Special Noodle (with Tofu) 8.95 - Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut sauce, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top. - you HAVE TO ORDER THIS. you'll thank me later.
5. Coconut rice - tastes like they cooked it in coconut milk :)
author: Eliza C.

description:
Craving noodles and opting not to satisfy this with our usual Chinese or Thai tendency, we searched around for an alternative. It was this odd search criteria which led us to Mandalay.

Hearing the great Yelp reviews, we ventured to this place to see if it lived up to the hubbub. Much to our delight, not only did it... but exceeded it. In total, we ordered three things off the menu. We satisfied our noodle craving with the Mandalay special noodles,which were a show stopper. As an odd twist, they actually made the dish in front of us. They brought out the noodles, fried tofu, greens, sauce, powder and lemons. They then proceeded to mix and prepare them. It ended up being excellent, one of the best noodle dishes we have had. 

The other entree was a Basil chicken, which was also delicious. We rounded out the order with a nice sample of steamed rice.

Overall, this place was awesome. Perfect experience and meal, which lead us to start to plan for our return voyage.
author: Sami R.

description:
Don't hate me, I like this place a lot more than Burma Superstar.  And it's bigger, less cramped, and more bang for your buck!!

I loved their Kau Soi.  It's seriously so well-flavored that it beats B Star's Kau Soi too.  

Their Burmese beef curry was hardly a curry, but more like a stew.  So if my friend and I didn't expect curry, then this would have been an amazing dish.  Very well flavored and the meat was SO tender.  I loved how tender the meat was.  Like wow.  It came with a choice of rice or the Burmese pancake.  We tried the pancake and it's sort of like Chinese Scallion pancake without the scallion.  I liked it a lot and it paired well with the sauce from the beef.  Beware of the oil though... it's panfried so the oil definitely stays on the pancake.

Their samosas are hella good.  Expensive, but by far the best tasting I've ever had.  Their mango lassi is also good... Yeah I pretty much love this place.  And the proprietor was hella on top of things, coming to ask us about our food and taking away our dishes if the wait staff was with someone else.
author: Anna T.

description:
I loved this place,

I was in San Francisco in the spring with friends for a training camp/vacation and this restaurant was recommended by a member of our group.  I have to admit I'd never had Burmese food before and that caused m to be a little apprehensive but once we were seated and the first dish arrived any questions I may have had were erased.

The service was quick and courteous, everyone from the hostess to the waiters and the busboys were very helpful. Not being familiar with Burmese food I had a few questions and  our waiter answered all my questions clearly and patiently. 

Once our order had been placed the waiter brought our food out in the perfect order with an explanation of what the dish was and why it was being served in this order. Even though we were a group of 8, I always felt like there was something new on the table to try. There was never a time during the meal that we didn't have something to share.

The food was very good and the quality were excellent, the kitchen looked clean and well maintained ( took a peak when going to wash room) I'd love to list the dishes we ordered but unfortunately I waited too long to write this review and I've forgotten the names. But I can say that everything was good and the staff made excellent suggestions.

I'll be back on my next trip to S.F.
author: J.F. H.

description:
First and foremost I'm not big with burmese food ever since I went to burma super star (I'm probably one of the only people that didn't enjoy that restaurant). I went here over the weekend with my family and we got one of those huge set menu family dinners. My sister and I are allergic to seafood, so they kindly made substitutions for us. I really enjoyed their food and could barely get up from the food coma. So food was a A.
Service was ok. Everyone is nice, but like pretty much every asian restaurant they can be a little pushy, so just tell them what you want directly.
author: Kristin S.

description:
Love the artwork and the ambiance in here. Its thoughtfully decorated and a great place to go with a big group. There were 12 of us, so we sat near the back and totally forgot about the other patrons in the restaurant (we were having a blast and we were LOUD) Be sure to bring your appetite (I've marked the dishes below with a "YUM" of sorts for the ones I highly recommend)

We ordered the following (all of which I highly recommend)
Chicken Samusa
Vegetable Samusa
Balada (DOUBLE YUM)
Rainbow Salad
Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup)
Pumpkin Pork Stew with Sour Mango
Mango Prawn (SUPER YUM)
Rangoon Spicy Fish (LOTS OF YUM)
Pan Fried String Bean
Burmese Style Noodles
Coconut Rice
Smoked Tea Duck

The only thing we had that I didn't really like was the samusa soup. There's plenty of other great things, I'd stay away from samusa soup. 

Bon Appetit!
author: Analisa S.

description:
tea duck.  Tea Duck.  TEA DUCK!!!  Yes, tea duck.  Rich fatty tea duck with hoisin sauce and those doughy things.  Tea duck.

The yellow curry something soup with egg in it (came with the royal dinner) - orgasmic.

Beef Mandalay.  Like a fattier tastier version of sweet and sour something. Beef f'ing Mandalay.  It wasn't as good as the duck so I'm only saying its name twice.

Rainbow salad: super simple but it all blends together...  the whole is much greater than the sum of its parts.  Be sure to include the chili powder.  It won't kill you.  The rainbow salad was all "say my name biznatch" and I'm all "I already spent all my street cred on the tea duck" and it's all "whatznever" and I'm all "OK, Rainbow Salad."  Actually Kim made me get this.  She's all smart and shiznit.

One of the shrimp things: great.  The other shrimp thing: not so great.
author: Aaron M.

description: While I've never had Burmese before, one dinner here has sold me on the amazingness of the cuisine.  The tea leaf salad and the vegetable noodle dish I got both arrived with ingredients beautifully arranged in neat piles.  The server then mixes the piles together at your table, meaning fresh, crisp ingredients are freshly combined!  The combinations of flavors in their dishes is a must-try.  I am definitely excited to come back here for more!  Also, the staff are incredibly nice and friendly.
author: Ling W.

description:
A-1 food.
Big menu, everything's delicious!

Weekend evenings can be crowded.  Be sure to arrive early, even if you have a reservation.

The service is friendly, but sometimes a little less-than-attentive, even when it's not busy.
author: Ken B.

description:
Oh No! I just finished this post and realised they charged us for a dish we did not order - $10.50 for a Mango Chicken.

This was the very first time I tried Burmese food, and was told that this place serves actual authentic dishes. I enjoyed every dish and it was not cheap but worth every penny spent.

We tried:
Tea Leaf Salad - great

Fish Chowder - The chowder was a little fishy - Not a dish for everyone. The rice noodles were a little too soft.

Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup - Great! Sweet savoury broth with silky egg noodles

Rangon Beef - Great! Sweet, salty and a little spicy sauce.

Pumpkin Curry Chicken - Not bad. The curry was very creamy, sweet, salty with a little kick to it. The chicken was tender white meat. 

Mandalay Eggplant - Excellent! It was very crispy on the outside with well cooked soft eggplant in the centre. Lightly tossed in a rich sweet salty sauce

Mandalay Special Noodle - Amazing! Crunchy noodles, silky rice noodles in a creamy coconut curry sauce

Mango Sticky Rice - Not bad

Fried Banana Ice cream - Not bad


Service was great w a few bumps along the way. Drinks took over 15 minutes to get to us, then the food came in a steady stream after that. Guy who took our order was patient with answering questions and making suggestions. Every dish was fully described when placed at the table.

Make a point to make a reservation because without one, wait could take up to an hour!
author: Edda O.

description: Fabulous!  My first visit to a Burmese restaurant, I really enjoyed it.  The interior is kitschy and the service a bit disorganized, but the staff are so genuine and helpful, they really want you to like the food.  Tea leaf salad is awesome, earthy and nutty.  Samusas were fresh and crispy.  Had the duck with pumpkin, it was well done and quite filling.  I'd definitely come back.  It wasn't crowded at noon but filled quickly by 1pm.
author: Rebecca H.

description: I have never had the privilege to taste burmese food before so I figured its now or never. Sadly I was slightly disappointed in our menu choices....if I remember correctly I would say half was mediocre. To be on the bright side decor was beautiful!
author: Zaynaf S.

description: Always serves great food.  Haven't had a bad meal yet.  Really one of the good ones in SF that are consistent with service and food.
author: s t.

description:
This place sucks!!! 
Worst  Customer Service !!!
Rude Staff!!!
Be prepared to starve if you go here..
If you have kids...this place is no no.... The lady will try to squeeze you in table of two.
thinking that kids need less space.

I will pay some one extra cents for not going there.
author: Annoynms A.

description:
It took me two times to finally dig this place as much as everyone else, and I'm happy to be on the bandwagon.  From this point forward, I will no longer waste my time freezing my a$$ off in line at Burma Superstar.  

Awesome for vegetarians. I highly recommend:

* Banaha
* Vegetarian Burmese Hot and Sour
* Spicy basil tofu (OMG OMG OMG!)
author: Maulie D.

description: The people here are so nice I feel bad for even thinking of writing a bad review. My favorite was the tea salad and chicken mango. Nuff said. Try it for yourself. In my opinion, this place is better than B Star...it's too bad it's not located on clement.
author: Logan N.

description:
I am on a perpetual search for ong no kau soi since 1) Mingala Village on 7th street closed, 2) I stopped dating someone w/ a mom that made a delicious ong no kau soi.

So this review is purely for that... 

The consistency of the soup was not thick enough. There was not enough fried onion bits. There was very little chicken in the soup. The noodles tasted slightly like spaghetti. However, it still partially satisfied my craving.

I also had a young coconut w/ my meal, but since that really doesn't pass through the hands of any chef I won't like that sway my rating. :)
author: Dee Y.

description:
One of my all time favorite restaurants!!

Great service - LOVE the owner ChoCho.
Also as a Burmese - I know Mandalay is authentic, and the food is great.
Have been here a ton of time, and I recommend Tea Leaf Salad,  Coconut stew, Their noodles, Padatha ( the bread with penut sauce is so yummy ) I can go on and on :)

Get the fresh coconut milk too!!
author: ThuZ W.

description:
Pretty damn freakin' delicious!  

And so pleasantly surprised by the wonderful dining experience i had here.

The green tea salad and the tea with the flower that blooms in the glass are a must!
author: Jessica W.

description:
DA GIT GOT BOMB SHIMMY!

YES SUURRR!  This place is awesome. The service is great, they will even server you drinks as you wait, unlike some other burmese places that make you wait sometimes hours for a seat, usually in the cold.

The food was for asian fair above average considering price and service.  Did the food blow my mind, not like POLENG did, but after eating at Burma I realized what I fool I had been for going to Burma twice. The atmosphere is great, with space between tables to actually let the belt out post meal and lay like a sack of potatoes as the fatness takes over.

The rainbow chicken awesome, the sizzling rice soup....super bomb for a cold, the curry chicken--YESS!  The salad was really good, really the only thing I thought was OK was the decor.  Coconut drink was actually coconut with a straw, reminded me of fun times in the Phil's.  The rice was super good too.

Foodies....who are looking for an excellent price to flavor ratio this places wins.  Foodies who don't like waiting in lines...because lines are soo passee...this place rocks the socks!
author: Spanky M.

description:
Not quite 4 stars, maybe like 3.75, but close enough. 

Friend brought us here on Memorial Day before heading over to a Blues festival, even though I was hoping for a (non Asian)seafood place of some sort, I enjoyed the food here a lot. 

We got Ginger Salad, Fried Tofu, Dry Pan Fried String Beans, Mandalay Eggplant, Burmese styled Curry with Catfish, Mandalay Noodle and coconut rice on the side. Out of all the dishes I like the catfish and noodles the best. Both were super flavorful, especially the noodles, couldn't figure out what spices they used (other than coconut...) , but it was yummy!

The string bean and eggplant was decent, taste exactly like how these dishes taste at a Chinese place. Ginger salad was a big "MEH".. it was pretty much like eating raw ginger. Fried tofu was good, rightfully so like all fried foods should be!

For drinks we got Mango Lassi and a coconut tapioca drink the name I forgot... the lassi is very much the same as the ones we get from Indian places, the coconut drink tasted good but was heavy, a meal by itself.

The waitress gave us complimentary orange dessert cake thingy, those were delicious. 

Oh, btw, parking was a pain in the @ss.
author: Angie H.

description:
I couldn't believe that I never wrote a review on Mandalay.  This is my mistake!! This place is INCREDIBLE!! I have been going here for YEARS, before they got onto Zagat, before they got popular.  This is one of my favorite restaurants in the Bay Area.  This place and its rich flavors never fail me.  Every dish is excellent, but here are some of my favorites:

1. ginger salad
2. mandalay chicken, or beef, or pork
3. pan fried string beans
3. mango chicken
4. #2 of the noodle dish (forgot the name)
5. mango sticky rice

But believe me, you can try anything on the menu and love it!!
author: Jannie Q.

description:
I haven't had Burmese food in years, and this place reminds me of how amazing it is!!! A group of us (5 total) came here on a Sunday night around 8, and there were 11 parties ahead of us waiting to be seated. We had tried to call earlier to make reservations, but they said they were not taking any. Probably because it was so busy.  We waited about 40 minutes for our table.  By the time they seated us, we were starving.  Everything on the menu looked delicious, so we ended ordering a bunch of dishes to share. I recommend doing this to get the most variety of dishes.  

For appetizers we ordered the Green Papaya Salad, Samusa Soup, and Balada.  I loved the papaya salad, especially the grounded shrimps in it.  I was a little hesitant about the samusa soup, but it is definitely worth trying if you like spicy food. The curry dipping sauce for the balada, which is like a crispy pancake, had a strong ginger taste, but I liked it.

For the main course we ordered Rangoon Spicy Prawns, Basil Beef, Curry Chicken, Burmese Style Noodles, and Combination Fried Rice.  Everything tasted so good.  My favorite dish was the spicy prawns.  The 5 of us couldn't finish all the food, so we ended up packing a good amount. After all that food we had no room for dessert. I'll definitely be back here to to eat.
author: Priya J.

description:
I've been trying to get into Burma Superstar for a while when a friend recommended this place.  The food was pretty good and the service was friendly and prompt.  About the food, the best things that we had we
Tea leaf salad - Good, but not as good as Burma Superstar
Mandalay beef - Best thing we ate here
Mandalay special noodle - Different, but tasty
author: Shen J.

description: It was a very popular place, waited for an hour before getting seated. But it was worth a try. We got the tea leaf salad, not your typical salad, I highly recommend it.  The mango chicken was good too, although I prefer the mango to be more soft. The ice cream dessert is a must try,  kind of on a sweet side. overall if you are a first timer, give this place a try. Side note, it's terribly difficult to find parking.
author: Kathy S.

description:
fried rice was great.
mango chicken had ripe mango so a little sweet for my taste. tofu curry with veggies was loved by everyone at the table. Highlight is their Jasmine Tea which opens up inside the water!
author: M J.

description: Skip Burmese Superstar for this gem. We had wanted to go to Burmese Superstar. But, the line was outrageous! So, we walked over to Mandalay and, while we did wait about 45 minutes, the staff were very accommodating. They gave us complimentary wine and were very attentive to us as we waited. When we sat down and ordered, we were taken aback by how amazing each dish was. We got the bread and curry appetizer which I HIGHLY recommend. I go the curry chicken which was amazing. My friend got the mango chicken was was SO good! Again, the staff were so kind to us. I would recommend Mandalay in a heartbeat.
author: Michael W.

description: This place was phenomenal!  Incredible food, great prices, world-class service, and cool ambiance.  The owner/manager/head server was terrific -- she went out of her way to accommodate our gluten-sensitive and otherwise rather picky party.  I can't wait for next time!
author: Liz O.

description:
The service was great here and so was the food.  Rainbow salad is so good, and so is the coconut chicken soup- if you are lucky you might get some egg in it.  We had the curry beef and it tasted like Singaporean Beef Rendang- but lighter.  It was tasty.  I want to go back someday for sure!

yummy!
author: Lisa M.

description: An opportunity for me to dine in the Sunset doesn't happen often. So I was happy to head to Mandalay today. There were eight of us, vegetarian and non, which provided an excellent chance to try lots of things.  Pretty much everything we tried was delicious. The real standouts for me were the Samusa soup (chock full of beans, onoons, and pieces of fried samusa), the mango prawns (tender mango, juicy prawns, garlic, and hot pepper slices), and the tea leaf salad. Prepared table-side. The salad is chock full of simple yet incredibly tasty things. I especially liked the crispy garlic pieces. If I thought I could pull it off, I would be trying to grow tea leaves in my backyard. The service was friendly and efficient without making us feel rushed and they seem to handle groups really well. I can't wait for another excuse to head that way so I can try more tasty things.
author: Nicole M.

description:
The tea leaf salad is so good, fresh and flavorful.  I love the little fried bits of garlic in there.  Other highlights were the Jia San Hinga (Black Pepper Soup) and the Mandalay Special Noodle.  The coconut rice and the Burmese Tea are bananas. 

Fun place to take a group of friends. Our party of 6 was one of many large tables celebrating.

Better than Burma Superstar (but don't spread the word...I don't want to wait 2 hours for a table).
author: Amanda R.

description: A most memorable meal and I will probably come back to San Francisco for many reasons but this is one of them.  The staff cannot be lovelier. The tea leaf salad is amazing! I love the savory crunch with some heat and spice. do not miss the balada. i'm not a big bread person, but this was fantastic. it's similar to naan but better, with a curry, peanutty sauce that is just right. The noodles were a nice touch and the lamb with coconut rice delicious. The bottle of Zinfandel recommended was spot on and then the bill. $105 for three if us! A good meal all the way around!! I highly recommend a stop here while in SFO.
author: judy b.

description:
Honestly one of my favorite places in SF.. Make sure to try the tea leaf salad, samosa salad, and the mandalay special noodle! Absolutely phenomenal. Love the platha bread with the curry dip too. 

But last night? Ugh. We went there kinda late, and they were taking trash out..through the dining room and right by our table. FOURTEEN (14) loads of it! Unbelievable. My date said it best: "the next thing is they're going to start dragging out the carcasses of the animals they slaughtered today"... Honestly guys at least you should have seated us in a different corner of the restaurant. 

So despite many, many times of phenomenal food.. I will dock a star just for being unhygienic.
author: Rob G.

description:
Mandalay remains one of my favorite restaurants in the City.  Friendly and welcoming service, a warm and pleasant atmosphere and terrific food with some really unusual flavors make this a winner for me.  I'll use last night's dinner as an example...

We showed up for an early dinner after roaming around Ft. Point and the Presidio.  We were greeted warmly and seated right away.  Our Singha beers came while we were still looking over the menu.  

We started out with my all time favorite, ginger salad (although, with no lettuce, taco bell wouldn't say it is "technically" a salad...yes, i do need to watch less tv).   I think it's much better than the tea leaf salad.

Then we had two specials -- a delicious stir fried lamb dish, with red bell peppers, tomatoes and onions; sorry, can't remember the name.  Then an amazing pumpkin pork curry with sour mango; delicious, with a very unusual flavor.  rich and flavorful not too spicy.  If you ever see it on the specials board, get it.  The coconut rice was perfect with both dishes.  Definitely go for the coconut rice -- creamy, aromatic, and a great side dish with pretty much anything here.

To finish, we couldn't decide between two items (the first two on the desert list; sorry, can't remember the names, but aletheia has a picture of them here ), so the waitress suggested half and half! so we got a mix of these little jello cocunut sticks, and these little orange somewhat cakey (and warm!) sticks.  The white coconut ones were so so, the orange ones were yummy! wish i knew what they were called.

I just wish people would keep flocking to Burma SS and leave this place for the rest of us....
author: John R.

description: My teacher introduced the class to this Burmese restaurant.  A lot of classmates had trouble with the spices.  It is VERY flavorful with heat!  I enjoyed their mango chicken.  We had green beans and tofu, this one was very spicy, the tofu tasted great (if I didn't know better I would have thought that it was teriyaki meat).  The other dish we tried was a beef with mixed vegetable dish, a lot of bell peppers and tomatoes.  I really enjoy bell peppers, so they pretty much had me at hello.  Everything was good nothing really knocked me off my socks though.  I gave a three because there were a few bites throughout the meal where I only tasted a strong spice that hadn't been mixed in quite enough.  It was definitely an A-OK meal for me.  I wouldn't mind eating there again, but I probably won't seek it out.
author: Trix T.

description:
Thumbs up!

When I came here, I though to myself: "GREAT THIS IS WHERE THE REJECTS FROM BURMA SUPERSTAR GOES". 

After being seated and helped by the waiter my perception changed! The atmosphere was actually nice and the food wasn't bad at all. Not knowing what to order, the waiter was patient and gave us great recommendations. LOVE THE COCONUT RICE! 

Overall: food was good and it wasn't crowded!!!!
author: Mai W.

description:
The question is: Burma SuperStar, Mandalay or B Star?  They're all in the same neighborhood, they're all Burmese, and they're all pretty good.  

According to our server, Mandalay is the original Burmese restaurant in the Richmond district, is family owned and operated, and "Doesn't use MSG."  Hmmmmm. These were her comments when I asked about why Burma SuperStar and Mandalay serve very similar dishes.  I did a little research, and Mandalay has more authentic Burmese dishes than Burma SuperStar.  And my favorite dish, Nan Gyi Dok, I have decided is better at Mandalay after having it both places. Although I have friends that swear they like Mandalay better, I'm still undecided. I do like how the interior and scene of Mandalay seems more authentic  than the other restaurants and yet I am also still a fan of Burma SuperStar, because some of Mandalay's dishes (like some of the breaded chicken dishes) remind me a little too much of cheap take out chinese.  But all and all, it was pretty darn good.  And, the portions are bigger and cheaper than Burma Super Star.  

Try the Nan Gyi Dok and the green papaya salad, and do research beforehand online about what Burmese dishes you want to try, instead of falling prey to their large menu, which has many ok Chinese dishes that aren't worth ordering.
author: Erica L.

description:
Finally came here when a friend said she was coming up to SF and wanted to get some dinner. I am so pleased to have chosen this place which happily took my reservation for 7:00pm at noon. 

As we came in just in time for our reservation, we were seated at a table closest to the door. The lady asked if we didn't mind and said we could use their little floor heater... (how nice).. Upon asking if we can wait until something inside opens up, a table just left. This place was packed the day before Thanksgiving!

So we ordered the Veggie Samosas to start off with and those things are so damn good. Just the smell... I can identify a Samosa from a mile away.. It was elegantly plated with some sliced and pickled cucumbers with an assortment of veggies on the side. 

Next came the Spicy Basil Chicken. Good choice. It was seasoned nicely and the coconut rice complemented it. 

Lastly, we ordered the Curry Goat. Unfortunately, I didn't like this dish that much. I am a big fan of Goat meat, but theirs was a little tough. If it was more tenderized, I would order it again, but it was nothing special and was overshadowed by the Basil Chicken.
author: Jason C.

description: This is the worst managed restaurant I have ever been to. We made reservations for a special birthday celebration two weeks in advance. We had to change the reservation time by 1/2 hour to accommodate out of town relatives so we called to change the time in the morning. We called again to confirm and were told they could accommodate our party. When we got there the hostess was extremely rude and told us, "You are late; we gave your reservation away!" We saw on her seating chart they never changed the reservation! To make matters worse she didn't do anything to try and accommodate us. She ruined my brother's birthday celebration and turned my 100 year grandmother away into the cold. I was shocked to see how dirty the restaurant is and how run down it is. It is poorly managed and has a rude hostess. If you let a party of 11 walk away and ruin a birthday celebration, your business has terrible customer service. I have frequented many wonderful Asian restaurants and this is not one of them. This is the type of place that gives Asian restaurants a bad name - rude, dirty and questionable cuisine! I will never come here again and as a fellow Foodie will never recommend it to anyone. We happily ate at King's Thai Cuisine #2 down the street that warmly accommodated our party and has much better food!
author: Natalia B.

description: It's...ok.  I'm not sure what the fuss is about.  I hardly notice it's Burmese -- just seems like all the other meh Chinese restaurants around.  Certainly nothing to go out of your way for, and nowhere near as good as Burma SS.
author: Brian C.

description:
Went here because someone told me that they found a better place that Burma Superstar. Maybe they were having an off day, but I really don't think it is. Nothing special about the food, smaller portions, not that cheap.

Only cool thing was the pumpkin curry served in a pumpkin? I dunno. Everyone else seems to love it, so maybe I have to try it again.
author: Sirina K.

description:
I love this place because it's just as good as Burma Superstar, if not better, but it's not constantly packed.

I used to live on 7th Ave b/w Clement and California. I ate at Burma Superstar once and was over it. Not worth the wait. Then I discovered wonderful Mandalay. Ahhhhh, delicious food and no huge wait. I hope it remains a bit of a secret....

My favorites here are the chicken samusas, which used to be just okay and are now much better for some reason, the Mandalay Special Noodle (which I order without lime leaves due to their hard-to-chew texture), walnut broccoli chicken, saffron rice, and the mango prawns. Mmmmm. Everything is soooooooo delicious. I usually call ahead and order to go, unless I'm in the mood to sit down, in which case there may be a small wait during peak hours, but nothing compared to that other hipster haven a street over....
author: Lizzy R.

description: Such a wonderful place! I had never tried Burmese before, and all of the staff were very helpful in recommending dishes and drinks to try. The mango chicken with coconut rice is amazing, as is the tea leaf salad. We arrived on a Sunday night with no reservations and although it was busy, we were seated in under 10 minutes. Service throughout the night was very fast, too.
author: Angela F.

description: Love me some Mandalay! Discovered this little gem as we went strolling through California street and Burmese food has never been the same! The wait can be a little agitating on weekends, but well worth it. Amazing tea leaf salad and various curries! Love discovering our new favorites on their menu
author: Karina A.

description: Pretty decent food. Not as good as the other Burmese restaurant in the neighborhood but if it was in an area by itself, I'd find myself going here quite a bit.
author: Sasha K.

description:
Love love love this place! Ever since they were featured in "Check Please Bay Area", business just took off (thank God!). 

It's always busy. You need to know that you will wait. They don't take reservations; however, you can write your name down and they can call you when your table is ready if you wanna grab a drink at a bar on Clement street. 

The Duck is DELICIOUS (very fatty, but that's what makes it good).
Curry chicken is one of my favorites! 
Tea leaf salad is a must have! 

It's a family owned business, so that's always bonus points (for me) 

Oh yeah, I forgot. This place is 10 times better than Burma Superstar which is overrated and overpriced.

Enjoy Mandalay!
author: J. C.

description:
If the wait is more than 1 hour, say that it is an hour or more.  Don't say it's a 20 mins wait!!!!!!!!!!  If you said it's an hour wait we won't be waiting, cold, hungry, and angry!!!

Lesson is: they don't care about the service and the wait.  They just want our money!

We got free appetizer and she said sorry tho, so plus 1 star. *happier now that i'm full*


Good food btw, highly recommend the chicken coconut soup and mango chicken.
author: Immanuel L.

description: Cute, bustling restaurant with fantastic Burmese food. My favorite green papaya salad, ever.
author: Cec D.

description: I finally tried this place after years of Burma Super Star.
