Comparing this place to Burma SS is like comparing a really quirky, authentic neighborhood restaurant to a busy, trendy (more american) Burmese restaurant. Actually, it is exactly that. I like Mandalay a lot for what it is - really unique, authentic Burmese food.  The decor/aesthetic in the place is a clash of tasteful Asian elegance meets 365 days of Christmas, plus one electric palm tree. Pretty awesome in a "what is going on in here!?" sort of way. It's worth a try for sure.
author: Robynne W.

description: The food here is FANTASTIC! Traditional Burmese food, great prices, great services. Get there early, it gets crowded!
author: Pedro C.

description: I've been going to this place for the past 10 years.  I always get the same thing- tea leaf salad and samosa soup.  They're consistently great.  It has become a little on the pricey side but I don't mind because the service, ambiance and food are great.
author: Swati K.

description: Love that Mandalay special noodle! We usually get it with chicken and enjoy it every time. Especially with some of that homemade hot sauce mixed in. Lots of delicious affordable options on the menu and great for quickly getting a table or grabbing take-out.
author: Erik F.

description:
Dinner here was decent but didn't wow me. Don't really have any complaints but can't think of any reason I would be dying to go back.

The ice cream dessert was pretty interesting, would recommend trying it if you're looking for something fun.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Mandalay I AM DISAPPOINT.

Based on good reviews and recommendations from friends, I went to Mandalay a few weeks ago for a Friday night dinner with a friend.  Even without considering how busy the place was the service was extremely attentive (bordering on aggressive), the food was very good.

Based on that, I went back with two coworkers for lunch this past Friday.  Blech.  We started with chicken samosas and each ordered a "lunch special".  Despite being mostly empty, the samosas took thirty(!!) minutes to arrive.  The coworkers loved them, but they were *greasy*.  If I were looking for Chinese influenced samosas I'd go for the golden triangles at Marnee Thai.

Two of the specials were a plate + soup of the day, one was two plates.  First our rice came out, about five minutes before the first two plates came.  So, you know, we got to sit around and stare at a pot of rice that was doing nothing other than growing cold.

Eventually, the third plate came out... and finally my plate, the mango chicken, came out.  The chicken bits were so salty you could feel the salt on the chicken.  Disgusting.  

After we ate as much of our food as we could, we inquired about the soup that was supposed to accompany the "lunch specials".  Neither the soup nor the excuses were noteworthy.  The fortune cookies were, however, notable for being burnt.

Man.  I'm  firm believer that a restaurant should focus on what they can do well.  Well... Mandalay can't do lunch.  I will not risk bringing someone here again.  The service is way too spotty to risk it... and thankfully now I'm that guy who nobody will listen to for lunch recommendations.  Thanks Mandalay!
author: Alex Z.

description: After going to Burma Superstar, we wanted to try this place. Friends had come from out of town and so we took them here. The wait staff was very helpful and nice, five stars for that. I wasn't impressed by any of the dishes, but maybe I'm biased because Burma Superstar was SO GOOD. Our out-of-town friends seemed to enjoy everything, but it just didn't hit the spot for us. I don't think I'll be back.
author: Julie W.

description:
I made a reservation here on a Friday night for my birthday dinner. I called about 2 weeks in advance and made a reservation for 13 people. "No problem," they said. Awesome.

First, the good news: The food is as amazing and wonderful as everyone says it is. Tea Leaf Salad is a must, as is the pumpkin pork curry with coconut rice and the eggplant dish. Every dish the server collected was totally clean, we loved it all! The restaurant itself is very cozy and has a hokey, old time-y feeling about it (Christmas lights, leafy plants, drinks with umbrellas in them, etc).

Our server was very friendly and helpful in providing recommendations for a larger party, as if he were used to this sort of thing. They were very prompt in filling up our water glasses and picking up finished plates. Lovely, lovely.

The unfortunate terribly bad news: Apparently it doesn't make a difference whether or not you make a reservation, even for 13 PEOPLE! The restaurant was totally full when I arrived and they would not seat us until the entire party was there, even though I knew 2 people were going to be 30 minutes late. My party filled up the entire entryway, making it incredibly awkward and uncomfortable for other people to wait for their tables too. I don't know why they called to confirm the reservation the day before, even if all 13 of us had been there on time, there would have been NO table available for us anyway! We weren't seated until 45 minutes after the reservation time, well after my late friends arrived. If that wasn't bad enough, the hostess was very frowny, curt and unfriendly, reminding me of the Michael Scott quote: "This is an environment of welcoming and you should just get the hell out of here!" 
We were squeezed into a small table and, although we were able to add one on, she sighed and pouted like we were ruining her life. Did I mention I made a reservation two weeks in advance??
Therefore, minus one really BIG, FAT star for the rough start. I was stressed out when we sat down, but after the drinks came out and I spoke with the friendly server, I started to feel a little better. The food was really it's saving grace, I will definitely be back to try some more dishes!

Moral of the Story: Do not expect your reservation to count for anything, even if you have a large party. Arrive early on a busy night or prepare to get comfortable in the waiting area.
author: Liz M.

description:
I believe I ventured out here after seeing this place featured on TV.  I knew that this place would be packed and everyone in the cramped waiting area, who I assumed were regulars, lamented over the fact that this place was much more crowded than usual.  
Much of the food was average.  The food that we received in a timely manner was dry (odd) and my entree was forgotten.  I assumed it was sitting out in the window for a VERY long time because the outside was completely cold.  I almost sent it back but the inside was still warm so if they had re-heated it the inside would dry out :( .

The manager (or owner?) was walking around the crowded restaurant chatting it up with the larger dining parties.  This seems like a friendly gesture of a professional staff.  However, this individual did not walk over the tables for two where many of us were ignored and did not receive our entrees in a timely manner.  Maybe it's because we all had angry expressions on our faces but the service was pretty bad and I was quite ready to complain.

Anyway,   the main let down was the fact that the food was not very good.  Perhaps this place is popular for its Burmese flavors but why get balada here if there's a better version at another Thai or Singaporean restaurant?  The same goes for the duck and catfish curry.  Both dishes have far superior equivalents at Chinese and Thai restaurants.
author: Amber R.

description:
A happy accident, our intended place for lunch is closed on Saturday and Sunday (!!!) so we decided to head out to Mandalay to give Burmese a try.  We were not at all disappointed.

We shared all dishes family style and this is what we had:

Balada - the bread with the curry dipping sauce, OMG, craving it now.
Samusa - Very good, not greasy at all and a nice sauce to dip them in, too.  The pickled veggies were a real plus for me.
Rainbow Salad - a party on the plate and in your mouth.  It looked like 15-20 ingredients, tossed tableside and filled with crunch and flavor.
Mango Chicken - delicious with fresh mango.  I want to try the Mandalay Chicken next time for an added kick of spice
Coconut rice - delicious, light coconut flavor and the fried onions on top really made this.
Pan-Fried Prawn with Green Beans - This dish was really delicious, too.  I sound like a broken record, but there was nothing we ate that was not delicious.
Mandalay Special Noodle - Another tossed at the table dish that was a party in your mouth.  Creamy, coconut curry-ish taste, props for the kaffir lime leaves in the dish.  

We also shared the fried banana dessert and the ice cream was incredibly good!  There is another dessert with tapioca, ice cream and little jello shots we need to try.

The service was leisurely, the food delicious, they did not rush us out at all.  This was nice considering the place filled up after we got there with very steady clientele.  The noise level was low and the place still felt peaceful and nice even though the staff was hopping.  Also had the most gorgeous arrangement of orchids on our table.

Absolutely will be going back, the party décor of the place goes well with the party of flavor in your mouth.  A family run place that should be on everyone's list.  A welcoming haven out in the Richmond.  I only wish I'd found this place years ago!
author: Donna H.

description:
The food here was delicious. A must visit if you're a vegetarian. The tea lead salad was my favorite dish of all, fresh and satisfying. 

Long wait before you can get seated, which was a but annoying (we had a reservation at 8, weren't seated until 830)
author: Poonum K.

description:
This is the place to go for great Burmese food. I have to qualify that statement to say I have never been to Burma, or whatever the Generals are calling it this week, so I can't verify the authenticity.

The Ginger Salad is worth a trip by itself.

If you like waiting in line and eating on top of the people at the table next to yours, go to Superstar. Otherwise, walk one more block to California Street and sit right down. 

Other than the improvement in the food, you won't notice the difference. 

Vinnie says check it out.
author: Statin Island V.

description:
After visiting this place again a few times I like it more. I love their sangria and ginger cooler drinks. You must try both!

As for the dishes it taste good. Great tea leave salad, vegetable dish, winter melon soup. 

I really dislike the tables and how close you are to other diners. I feel like there is no privacy. The decor is nice and the waitstaff is friendly and attentive.
Also there is usually no wait, and if there is one it is not that long. 

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
author: Chatree T.

description: I like this restaurant a lot . I recommend the chicken coconut soup, mango salad, ragoo beef, fruit punch (#10) on the drink menu, coconut rice, asparagus chicken, and fish filet
author: E M.

description:
I recommend trying the Samusa soup and Balada. The soup was very tasty and Balada is like a paratha which came along with a curry sauce. I also tried the vegetarian noodles and liked it very much.

Everyone in the group like whatever they ordered.

Long wait, so plan in advance.
author: Akta A.

description:
As far as comparing this place to Burma Superstar down the street, I rate it one star less for taste. Mandalay has many similar items on the menu like the tea leaf salad and samusas which taste just as great but the other items like the lamb and beef lack that "pizazz." The food is a little more greasy but the meat and veggies are very fresh. The flavors are just slightly more mellow and I prefer the robustness of Burma. 

The atmosphere is much better for groups because there is no long wait and the tables are much bigger with room around them- not like Burma where you kick elbows with your neighbor. 

I  have no problem going here on a regular basis where as I have to save up just to treat myself to Burma. I recommend this as a cheaper and more comfortable place to experience Burmese food.

Try the house special noodles, the basil beef, and the green beans. Skip the banana fried ice cream and walk down to Genki crepes instead.
author: M K.

description: First time trying out Burmese food and this place is awesome!  I dont think you can go wrong with whatever you order on the menu.  Get the ginger lemonade!  It rocks.  The tea salad is very popular.  Too bad I was only vacationing in SF, if not I'd go back there again.
author: Asha V.

description:
I came to this restaurant with my friends for a birthday celebration. I even recommended this restaurant for my friend to come for her birthday.  I saw this restaurant first featured on Checks Please!

I was taking one picture of the food and the waiter came up to me and said no pictures of the food. I thought that was kind of rude because I see all the reviews and pictures of their food on Yelp. Why was it that I can't take one picture?

As for the food and drinks:

Ginger Lemonade: Too much lemon, too tart

Combo Satay: Beef was chewy and chicken was dry.

Balada: It was okay, had better.

Chicken Samosas: A little dry and sauce was a bit too spicy.

Mandalay Special Noodles: Too much Lemon which overpowered the whole dish. (They should have asked if the customer wanted lemon before squeezing all of it on the noodles)

Ong No Kaw Soi: Two of the people in our group got this dish, they liked it.

Pan Fry Okra Prawn: One of the people from our group liked this.

Ambiance: I was not too impressed with the tacky decor and this place is very small. I would not recommend for a big party.

I would not come back to this restaurant due to this first experience there.
author: Irene L.

description:
This might be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.

I know, I know. That's saying a lot. But everyone has a favorite. And this one might be mine.

I've been coming here since I was a kid, but it is only now, as a full grown vegan, that I truly appreciate the greatness of this place. First of all, the service is impeccable. They are attentive without being officious, and always find a way to accommodate your requests. As a vegan, this is huge. HUGE.

Example: in my non-vegan childhood, I used to order the sizzling rice soup here, which isn't vegan (it's made with a meat broth). Now, I order the hot and sour soup, vegetarian (they have two varieties) with no egg and a side of sizzling rice. Do they always bring me exactly that? Yes. Do they ever give me a funny look? Never. 

A ton of their tastiest dishes have vegetarian (vegan) alternatives. All you have to do is ask. My favorites are the mango salad (no dried shrimp) and the pan friend string beans (no dried shrimp). 

If you don't order dessert, they almost always bring you a mini-dessert on the house. They are nice beyond nice, but again, without being in your face about it, and the food is SO FRACKING GOOD that I will often go way out of my way to get it. 

Mandalay: You are everything I could ever want in a restaurant. I can't wait to spend the rest of my life with you. Will you be mine?
author: Devin F.

description: My boyfriend and I were craving some hot soup to-go on a cold evening. The coconut chicken noodle soup hit the spot! The soup was as delicious as it smelled on the car ride home. If my regular Burmese spot is ever closed again, I'll be back for this dish.
author: Kathleen T.

description: It's a great place for a vegetarian. I am always able to get most entrees without fish sauce. My favorite dishes are the: Dry Pan Fried String Bean with Tofu, Mandalay Special Noodle with Tofu and Singapore Style Noodle with Vegetables (you have to ask for the veggies). You must get the coconut rice, it's out of this world. This is coming from someone who isn't a fan of anything else with coconut.
author: Lisi G.

description: This place is not as trendy looking as the burmese restaurant down the street, but the food is just as good.  Living in the neighborhood, I always call in a takeout order and avoid the lines.  I can then satisfy my craving for special noodles whenever I want it. Mmmm.
author: Heidy S.

description: I am a fan of the Mango Salad! I've never had it before and it was so good. I had the chicken broccoli and while my friend is a big fan, I felt that the chicken was a bit dry, though the sauce was great and the broccoli nicely cooked.
author: Vicki T.

description: There is definitely a wait on a Friday, Saturday night. But the serves is really good, and the food is great!
author: Luke V.

description:
Excellent Burmese food. My fiance and I were brought here for a work dinner by his boss, a Burmese lady, and she ordered everything for us. SOOO much better than the terribly overrated Burma Superstar. The Tea Leaf Salad is different and far superior. I can't remember everything we had because we got so many dishes. Some outstanding ones I could remember are the Fish Chowder and the Mandalay Special Noodle.

Great for groups and definitely somewhere I'd take visiting guests for something different.
author: Lisa K.

description: This is definitely one of my top 5 places to visit in San Francisco whenever we come here. The food is fantastic here and service is very nice. You may have to make a reservation if you are coming around peak times on Friday. Even if you don't make a reservation it is well worth the wait. The place has been here for many years. We found out about it from our friends who used to come here 10 years ago and when we went together it was every bit as great as they have remembered. We have come back many times every since.
author: Greg S.

description:
We waited an hour, but it was worth the wait! Loved the beautiful salad mixed at our table, Mandalay house made special noodles, and delectable yellow curry chicken.

I can hardly wait to come back with friends!
author: SF F.

description:
Mandalay beats Burma Superstar on every level. 

Food is delicious and authentic (for example, tea leaf salad is not mixed with lettuce here). 

Service is friendly and attentive. 

Decor is quasi-Christmasy all year round with the ornaments hanging from the ceiling, but I like it. 

I do wish they took reservations though.
author: Robin C.

description:
Well goldang!

I got home from work tonight, pretty well famished from only having ingested a half dozen strawberries, and a couple of cups of coffee all day. Asked the roommate what he was getting into for dinner, and he wasn't quite in the mood to eat yet. So, I decided to utilize ol' Yelp to track down a new spot to eat at whilst he did whatever he needed to do to to get his appetite  up and running. 

As I searched for cheap restaurants that were in either the Inner or Outer 'hood, up popped the Mandalay. 

Burmese you say? I've never had it! 

(and So I read on...)

Consistently good reviews, a few dishes being repeatedly mentioned...affordable..close to home...BINGO! 

Lemme just say, I was not expecting the dinner to be THAT good. 

Apparently the roommate had already tried this spot on a date a year or so ago, and when we got there, he said he remembered it being good. *woohoo!*  I made sure to read the specials on the menu board to see if anything caught my eye. When I 1st moved to the Bay Area, I read an article from some food reviewer who mentioned trying specials when you can, as they're often a unique creation the chef normally doesn't prepare. Tonight I see "Pumpkin Curry Pork Stew" on the specials....you had me at "pork".

Now, I have had some pumpkin curries before, and I already love them - but man oh man - this stuff was a complete foodgasm. The pork was so juicy and tender, and complemented the pumpkin so well...you don't even KNOW!  *drool*. I also noticed they had a saffron & cinnamon rice (called "Tom Poi" I think), and I thought it sounded like it would sit under the curry pretty well...it was out of this world combined. In fact, I think I might have to lobby to have that particular combo put on the menu permanently, just so I can eat it once a week. Yes indeedy folks - THAT good. 

The Samusas (a Mandarin style Samosa), and what I tasted of my roomie's Rainbow Prawn dish (prawns w/ pineapple, red bell pepper, onion in a light and tangy sauce) were all really spot on as well. Veggies cooked to perfection ,flavors not muddled - and the prices were really reasonable.  

The staff was super courteous and friendly as well...total win on all points, especially for (me) trying the place for the 1st time. I will, DEFINITELY be back. The menu is big enough to let your palette roam a bit. 

Two thumbs up.
author: Marco M.

description:
Ate here with a group of 6 people, our reservation was at 8pm on a Friday night and this place was packed wall to wall. 
The only other place I could compare this place to is Mingalaba in Burlingame as I have not been to Burma Superstar.  Anyways, here is what we ordered:
1. Appetizers: Samusas and Baladas   
These were good, but while eating them I distinctly remembered that they were not as good as Mingalaba.  Tasty, but a little on the heavy side.
2. Salad: Tea Leaf Salad
This was just OK compared to Mingalaba.  It seemed like the garlic was overbearing.  
3. Hot and Sour soup
This was actually pretty good.  Good consistency and lots of ingredients with flavor.
4. Basil Beef
If I'm remembering the right dish, I think this was pretty good too.  I thought the beef was cooked right and had good flavor.
5. Burmese Style Curry Chicken
This was just OK, pretty mild from what I remember.  I ordered this just to see what kind of flavor they would have.  Also, the chicken pieces seemed a little over cooked. 
6. Mandalay Eggplant
I enjoyed this dish, and eggplant is one of the vegetables I actually do not like. The eggplant had lots of flavor and was actually a little sweet. It wasn't over cooked either.
7. Sauteed Peashoot with Garlic
I enjoyed this dish a lot. Good flavor and good consistency.
8. Mandalay Special Noodle
This was a dish that they mix at your table just like the Tea Leaf Salad. I liked this a lot.  I like the crunchy noodles mixed with the soft noodles. Good dish!
9. Coconut rice
I really don't like coconut but I enjoyed their coconut rice a lot, and ate it with almost every other dish!  Impressive.
10. Coconut ice cream with Strawberry cookie stick thingys
This was just OK (I didn't enjoy it as much as the rice) but the Strawberry cookie wafer was pretty good.

The portions are fairly small here, which is why we ordered this much food.  The six of us finished all of the food, four guys and two girls.   
Parking is decent, we found parking down the block fairly easily. 
Reservations are a must here unless you want to wait a really long time.  I think my group waited 15 to 20 mins with reservations.  Recommended, but try out Mingalaba first in Burlingame. =)
author: Dean S.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!

Because I'm a human I naturally want to compare things. When I came here I was forced to ask myself the question: where does Burma Superstar fit into all of this Mandalay wonder? I thought it was the best, that the Tea Leaf Salad was supposed to have lettuce in it, that the wait came with the quality... but I'm not so sure anymore.

For starters, the Mandalay staff is so incredibly friendly and I've never waited more than five minutes for a table! How can it be? 

The food is just so high quality, so so so scrumptious. Unfortunately, I've only had a few dishes here so I can't offer an all-encompassing review on the food vs. burma sstar, but with the dishes I have tried I'd say Mandalay surpasses burma sstar with everything except the coconut rice. The chicken samusas..... I could die eating them. They are so incredibly flavorful and juicy. I could probably just order a bunch of them and have that for dinner. The tea leaf salad comes without lettuce which apparently is how the dish is traditionally made, and i like it better this way! More of the good stuff. The rainbow chicken is also delicious. 

I don't know if I could ever write off Burma Superstar, especially since I live in Oakland and there's one on my side, but sadly, no Mandalay. That being said, I do think Mandalay has the edge here, especially with the lack of waiting time.
author: Allie M.

description: Amazing! My favorites are the tea leaf salad and the noodles with the coconut chicken.
author: Erin W.

description: This place is beautiful a total hidden city gem! Anything you order here is fantastic and fresh the restaurant is beautifully decorated, very aesthetically pleasing and even some of the servers are dressed in colorful traditional garments. Love to bring people and show them this very cool place.
author: V L.

description: service is good vibe is great. yet americanzied in that its a lot of fry and sugar.
author: Shuting Z.

description: My boyfriend just said "Best Burmese food we've gotten" and I agree. We got the Mandalay noodles, and it was AMAZING. The beef curry was awesome and so was the coconut rice and the tea leaf salad. We'll be back. One of the best restaurants in SF. The people that work there seem extremely nice.
author: Rose M.

description:
I remember when Mandalay used to be the place you'd go for Burmese when you didn't want to wait in the line at Burma SuperStar. Well, now there's a line out the door at Mandalay, too, so I guess Burmese is trending up. 

The staff at Mandalay are super nice, and their platha (flaky fried layered doughy goodness) is really yummy. Other than that, i have to say that I prefer the food at that OTHER Burmese spot a lot more. Sorry, but it's true.
author: Vandana M.

description:
I brought my friend here because we appreciate good food and we're picky. For efficiency, I got a reservation ahead of time on Open Table. We arrived 30 Minutes early and they happily seated us, so for those of you that are frustrated just make a reservation. The food is good that why you're waiting!

It's been years since we've connected Mandalay...I've missed you my friend. I was hoping the food was as lovely as I remembered and you did not dissapoint. What I remember: genuinely nice wait staff that are so polite and always smiling, the CATFISH CHOWDER with noodles served with cilantro and lemon (hands down the best Fish Chowder of all the Burmese restaurants), Samusa Salad (Not greasy, so the person frying them knows how to do it right, beef curry stew with cocounut rice ( nice and tender). The portion sizes are just right so you don't feel like a lardass afterwards.

The main thing that has changed about this place is that it is 3 times more packed than it used to be, so consistency in there service has been lost. My friend and I waited 30 minutes for our food, she pointed out that other tables that came after us got their food first, they brought us fishcake salad and not samusa at first, so I can only imagine the chaos they have to keep up with in the kitchen.
author: Leslie L.

description:
My friend, Anelya S., eats here at least once a week, sometimes three times a week. I tried Mandalay for the first time during my GDC visit and if they shipped food to Pennsylvania, my eating dilemmas would be solved forever.

Everything I had here was tasty, the service was warm and friendly; No wait for a table on a Thursday night and affordable bottles of wine. I tried fried squash sticks (my attempt at eating healthy), balada, special noodles, basil beef and coconut milk rice. The noodles were the star of our dinner - very fresh and flavorful. And we got free dessert! Even if we couldn't fit it in our stomachs...
author: Tatyana K.

description: The lamb curry and mandalay chicken were probably one of their best dishes and the basil eggplant was yum. The food was pricey but I had better experience with thai food at a cheaper price. This place is over hyped by people who don't know what kind of food this should taste like. I don't know whats so good about the hype here and the food isn't super. I don't recommend this place unless you got extra cash to spend.
author: Chris L.

description:
So, I wanted to go to Burma Superstar but my hungry Greek didn't want to wait and found this on Yelp two blocks away. Very glad he did!

Tea leaf salad is different from what I had before. Love the presentation and the abundance of roasted garlic chips. The samusas were fried perfectly and the sauce had a nice kick, although to be honest I tasted more potato than chicken. We stepped out of our comfort zone to try the catfish chowder (moo hin nga), and I'm so glad we did! It had a nice heat, and though the broth is light the soup is hearty and they mix up the texture with hardboiled egg and....something crunchy. As a lover of bright, sharp flavors I was enthused that it was served with cilantro and lemon. After all that we were a little too full for the mango chicken and coconut rice, but it was delicious. I would have preferred it to be spiced throughout instead of tossing in green chiles at the last minute, but perhaps that isn't traditional.

We were seated right before the big dinner rush, but even so our service was a bit disorganized. It took them a while to take our order and we waited so long for the mango chicken we thought they had forgotten to put it in. However they were very pleasant and I would definitely go back.
author: Maria A.

description: It was pretty good. The duck was excellent, nothing else really stood out for me though to be honest. Very great service .Get there early it gets packed, but ya the tea duck, DE-LIC-IOUS
author: Lauren V.

description:
Good food with good friends and a special someone I thought was special, turns out I was very wrong.

Except for the company, the place was great and I'll be back, hopefully with someone who really cares.
author: Sam I.

description: It has been 20 years since I have been here - nothing has changed (which is great)!  The food was still delicious and there was no compromising on portion size or quality of ingredients.  We ordered the tea leaf salad, mandalay special noodle, string beans and pea sprouts.  We also had a few appetizers since there were 7 in our party and we were hungry.  Everything was delicious and the servers were very attentive refilling our water glasses frequently.  We will be back....and not wait 20 years before our next visit.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Everytime I go to SF, I always go at least once to Mandalay. Great service, roomy, not too noisy-- unlike that other more famous Burmese place.
  This was the first restaurant I ever ate at in SF, back in 1989 and it has only gotten better over the years.
The ginger and tea leaf salads are great!
author: Rick F.

description:
It was my first time trying Burmese food and I loved it! I really wanted to try Burma Superstar, but I didn't want to wait for a ridiculously long time, so we decided to go to Mandalay instead. They don't really take reservations for after 6pm, but they do put you on a priority list, so do call in before. We still had to wait a little bit for a table when we arrived, but we spent that time looking over the menu and sipping on our drinks (the hostess will take your drink order while you wait). I tried the Ginger Beer Cooler. I know a ginger and beer combination sounds kind of weird but it was surprisingly good! It was really refreshing. 

When we were seated, we already knew what we wanted to order so we ordered right away because we were starving. We ordered the samusas, tea leaf salad, Mandalay beef, shrimp with green beans, coconut rice, Mandalay special noodles. Everything was soooo good...except the tea leaf salad. Everyone seems to be raving about the tea leaf salad, but everyone that I had dinner with liked the tea leaf salad the least. 

This is definitely a good place to go when you are craving Asian food, but want to try something other than the usual Chinese/Thai/Vietnamese food. I would say that my first time having Burmese food was a success!
author: Patricia L.

description: We once waited in line for 2 hours at Burma Superstar and left grumpy and disappointed.  Then we were introduced to Mandalay.  Sometimes there's a crowd, but most times you feel like it's the best kept secret in the City.  The tea leaf salad is incredible.  Usually end up with pumpkin curry, or Singapore noodles, or both.  The food is always amazing.  The staff is attentive and friendly.  Consistently some of the best food in the city.
author: Lucas M.

description: Amazing  food .. amazing service ... best burmese food around.
author: Abhishek C.

description:
We had an atrociously long wait at Saturday night for 2 people around 7. I don't think we were seated until after an hour even though the hostess told me the wait would be around 20-30 minutes. Since we weren't starving, I was determined to wait it out. But seriously, the waiting area was like a crowded subway compartment..ugh. 

Anyway onto the food. We started with the chicken samusas, which were delicious! The presentation is also very nice and make the samusas look uber plump and appetizing. Comes with 4 and I would recommend eating only one because eating 2 like I did will ruin your appetite..

..especially if you also order the balada appetizer. It's like the Burmese version of roti canai and I love it! The curry is not very spicy but has a sweet and unique taste to it. The flatbread is not so hot that your skin burns if contact lasts more than a few seconds. It's also not overly greasy which I appreciate. Yum yum but again should probably shared among 3+ people.

Because I was really interested in the coconut rice we got a complementary dish, Catfish Curry. My only issue with the catfish is its bones, but what can you do. The quality of the fish is good and I enjoyed Burmese curry more than I thought I would! It's also not very spicy, and goes with the coconut rice very well. The coconut rice is addicting...you can eat it by itself and be happy...

And we also got an order of the pan dry fried string beans which was quite good. The flavor is really strong though so it would be most enjoyable to eat with rice or some kind of bland starch. 

I would have given Mandalay 3 stars, but the exemplary customer service we received has earned it another star in my heart. We had wanted the remainder of our balada to take home, but when we were leaving, the waitress apologetically informed us that they must have accidentally thrown it out. No worries, we said, and we walked off into the blistery night.

A few minutes later, we hear rapid footsteps running after us, turn around, and lo and behold, a waitress is flagging us down with our doggie bag! She ran almost an entire block and across an intersection (in a skirt!) just to give us our balada. This unnecessarily kind act has inspired in me a lot of tender feelings for the Mandalay staff.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Made reservations 2 days in advance for my mom's birthday. This place comes highly recommended by a few friends and had a lot of good reviews on Yelp. I came in with high hopes and really wanted to like this place. 

1. My sister arrived before the rest of the family. She checked in with the hostess; told her we have reservations. She was not seated nor updated about the reservations situation. I arrive and proceeded to tell a server that I have reservations. The server asked for my name and walked off. I had no idea what was going on because no one told us anything. No ''Ok, your table will be ready soon." or "Let me check on your table for you."
2. We were finally seated. We were asked if we wanted water. Instead we asked for tea for everyone. We were charged $1 per person for tea. 
3. A man came to introduce himself and told us about the restaurant. Gave us a few moments to look over the menu. When we were ready, we flagged him down and gave him our choices. He said that the soup would not be enough for the 5 of us and suggested we added a half order. We declined. He again gave us a recommendation of a dish we ordered. The rock cod to be made rangoon style. He asked about rice and we said 2 orders was fine. 
4. The man lied about the soup. It was MORE than enough for 5ppl. Actually three people were able to get 2nds. 

Off to the food...
* bbq skewers: we were not asked if we wanted beef or chicken. we really wanted beef but instead, we were given chicken.
* balada: it was not bad but not memorable. the pancake was a little chewier than I would like. The curry dipping sauce did not taste like curry, not even a hint.
* Jia San Hinga (Black Pepper Soup): Oh man...this soup is no joke. It was definitely very peppery. Thats all it was. Pepper. 
* Shaking Duck: this dish was NOT worth it AT ALL. a whopping $16 for 2 pcs of thinly sliced duck per person. 
* Rangoon Rock Cod: this is by far the best dish. The cod was fried but the ratio of batter and fish was just right.
* Burmese Style Noodle (Kaw Soi Dok): not a fan. was supposed to be spicy but not at all.
* Walnut Broccoli Tofu: another good dish. i loved the sauce and broccoli was cooked perfectly. again, not spicy. 

Cons:
* my sister found pieces of plastic in one of the dishes. 
* you know when you run out of tea in the teapot, you removed the lid to let them know you need more tea? well, for some reason...this restaurant does not understand that sign. we had to flag them down several times for tea.
* they would take away dishes when we weren't even done with them yet. we had to tell them twice to leave it. 
* the dishes came out super slow and when it did finally leave the kitchen, it was cold or lukewarm

Ugh, this was a horrible dinner experience. AND I walked away $100 poorer. So not worth it. Such a disappointment.
author: Serena F.

description:
I sure am glad i somehow managed to convince my coworkers we should go here for lunch yesterday as a farewell to two of our comrades.  I'd been here before and really enjoyed it, so now I can report that whether you go with 3 people or 13 people, the quality is not compromised.

first of all, both times i noticed the service was incredibly attentive and friendly.  I drink a lot of water with my meals and when I'm with a huge group, waiters often neglect timely refills because of the huge crowd of items on the table, but Mandalay never let me go thirsty yesterday.  The food comes out pretty quickly and the servers always describe what you're getting if it has a ton of ingredients.  

In terms of the actual food, I've never gotten a dish I didn't like, so I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong.  The mango salad is delicious.  The curries, noodles, and stir-fries are exactly what you'd expect from a quality establishment.  The portions are also relatively sizable (we shared 7 entrees among 13 of us, following 3 sets of appetizers and yet we all left full, and when 3 of us shared 3 entrees we had lunch for the next day).

This is good, quality Burmese food in a nice environment with a helpful staff.  Why wait in line for an hour elsewhere when you can come enjoy the deliciousness that is Mandalay?
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Does anyone else find the waiter annoying?  I found him to be fake and patronizing and I didn't feel like he was consistent with all tables.

I've been here twice and have no desire to come back.
author: Miss Bonnie B.

description:
Mandalay has been my "asian fix" go-to place since 1992. It went through up's and down's and (I believe, but could be wrong) few changes of ownerships. I really like what they have done with it in the most recent years - from food to decor to service.

 If you stop by on any given week night - place would be packed. For that very reason I rarely eat-in, and usually take-out. They do not deliver, which is fine by me, since it gives me a reason to walk my dog and baby for 20 blocks each way. 

Here are some things I have ordered in the past:

Satay Chicken / Beef - just ok. Chicken can be a bit dry, and I usually like beef better.

Samusa (with Chicken or Vegetarian) - is tasty. I don't care much for the hot sauce they serve it with.

Balada - is more chewy than flaky, but still good. Dipping sauce has too much curry for my taste.

Hot and Sour Soup (Chinese version) - is my favorite. I usually substitute pork for shrimp. It is not too hot and not too sour, just right.

Shrimp Wonton Soup - is a must try. It is a light broth with chopped shrimp filled wontons.

Basil Beef - I can eat every day. Perfectly spiced, bathing in a rich sauce, tender pieces of beef, basil leaves, shredded carrots and bell peppers. It also comes with onions, but I order mine without.

Walnut Prawn - is one of the best around. Whole large prawns lightly battered. You barely taste batter - just the fleshy prawn covered in sweet dressing.

Sizzling Seafood - medley of sea critters in a light sauce with carrots, mushrooms and bell peppers. Also very flavorful. In a restaurant it is served on an iron plate, literally sizzling.

Basil Spicy Eggplant  - similar to basil beef - also very good, if you like moist, slightly mushy eggplant. If you like a drier variety, try Mandalay Eggplant.

Mandalay Special Noodle - I was not impressed with. Maybe when ordering in the restaurant it would have tasted different, but as a to go dish it was lacking definition. Just a pasta noodles with curry sauce poured over it.

Singapore Style Noodle  - has a better flavor, thinner noodles, but a bit too dry. Again, maybe this is a to-go thing.

Overall, whatever you order, you will not be disappointed.
author: Katya L.

description:
Tea leaf salad
Samusa soup
Mandalay Special Noodle (wow)

bam. 5 stars.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Everything is really good here, and this is coming from someone who's used to eating Burmese food (my parents are Chinese from Burma). 

One of the drawbacks to this meal was that the portions were small, but I don't know if that was because the waitress saw it was 3 small girls or that it's usually like that. I'll observe the next time I go there and see if anything changes. 

Our group ordered samosa soup, la pet dok (tea leaf salad) and oh no kau swe (noodles). The samosa soup was spicy and sour, and had bite-size pieces of samosas (or something similar to it). There was enough for 3 bowls, coincidentally. 

The tea leaf salad was way smaller than I expected. When I went to Burma Superstar, the salad was way bigger -- but that could have been because I got VIP access. Either way, there was enough to share for the 3 of us, but only for a handful. The salad I had at Burma Superstar had more lettuce in the salad than tea leaves, but I really liked that the tea leaf salad here at Mandalay only had tea leaves, which is exactly how I usually eat it. 

As for the noodle "salad", the meal came served in a weirdly shaped bowl that made it seem like there was less noodles than there actually was. The noodles weren't mixed well, and a lot of the meat and tofu sank to the bottom as we were splitting the noodles. Other than that, the noodles were good, flavorful and went down smoothly. Again, I just wish the portions were a bit larger, but it was filling. 

The only other drawback was that the wait time for the food was a little long, and the waitress (or owner) tried to remember our orders but messed up not once, but twice. At first, me and my friends marveled at how she could have taken the orders without a pad of paper, but we realized her futile attempt after getting two random orders of food we had never ordered. Our server must have thought we were being forgetful, because she became annoyed after the second mix-up. 

If I come back here again, I'd like to try the Burmese ice tea (I never knew there was a Burmese ice tea) and some of the desserts. However, the meal was enough for a light lunch, but not worth the price.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Originally we were supposed to go the Burma Superstar, which I heard was really good! So we picked up one of our good friends but she told us that B Star would be a really long time, so she suggested this place! At first I was kinda disappointed but it turned out that I really liked it here. First off we got the vegetarian samusas which were oh-so-gooood. The presentation was fantastic. (I'm such a sucker for presentation). Next there was the combination chowmein thing that my sister had ordered. She said it was pretty good. Next the walnut prawns came in a funky looking plate/bowl thing. It was kind of salty but still fairly tasty. 
OHMYGOD. One thing that I LOVED LOVED LOVED was their coconut rice. i usually HATE coconut but this bowl of rice was DELICIOUS! I kept eating it and eating it! It's sweet yet edible. It feels kind of like butter in your mouth...except it's rice. 
Next came the spicy tofu with vegetables. I really liked this dish! It was spicy but had the perfect amount of flavor! It was quite wonderful and a great combo with the rice!
For desert we were treated to fried bananas! They were so yummy and the presentation (again) was amazing! We also got this jello thing which was eh... It was ... "foreign" and different. I wasn't into it so much. But then again, I don't really like jello in the first place. Overall, I do recommend people to come here if they're willing to try something new or if the line is waaay too long at B Star.
author: Susie N.

description:
I thought that the food was pretty good. I definetely liked the chicken satay, fried banana and coconut ice cream. If it was based on food alone this place would get 4 stars. 

For me what realyl brought it down to 3 stars is the slow service. Upon walking in my guest and I were greeter by a friendly gentleman who I am assuming is the owner of the restaurant- I could tell just by the way he was dressed. What really ticked me off is our waiter who was sort of curt and unfriendly. He looked like he did not want to be there seriving us. Not once did he smile or show any friendly character. When he repeated our order he had a loud and unpleasant tone of voice. Not once were we checked up on or asked how our food turned out. Instead when we started eating he took off for about 45 minutes. A professional way of taking a break if you were already assisting someone would be to say, "I am actually going to be heading out, but one of our other waitresses will be happy to assist you. Is there anything else I can get for you?" But no, he just took off. 

The other waitresses were rather very very firnedly, but the service was incredible slow. For exmaple I had to ask for peanut sauce twice, and I had to ask for a diet coke twice. The lady owner of the restuarant was very firendly though and was easy to flag down. 

Maybe I will be back and give this place another shot but I really feel like their service needs to improve. The food was just okay, not the best ive had. Its very similar to Thai.
author: Emily G.

description: I had the mandaly special noodles and they were delicious! The Young coconut water was really flavorful and slightly sweet- soo yummy, worth the $4 once in a while. I think this place if much better than Burma Superstar.
author: Layla L.

description:
I had a friend in town from Belgium and she really wanted to try this place. So, being a responsible adult, I called for reservations. 

ringring ringring ringring ringring ringring ringring 

friendly voice "Hello?" 

"Hi, I would like to make a reservation?" 

"OK" 

silence 

"Um....do you have a reservation for tomorrow, Friday night?" 

"Yes" 

silence 

"Can we come at 8pm?" 

"Sure" 

silence 

"Would you like my name or phone number?" 

"OK" 

"Mitsi 777-7777" 

silence 

"Um, so, we have a reservation tomorrow at 8pm?" 

friendly voice "Yes, tomorrow, byebye!" 

click. 

My friend and I arrived at 7:45 pm and spoke with the hostess. 

"Hi! We have a reservation at 8pm" 

"Yes! Mitsi for 2? Have a seat." 

As we waited we watched 48 different parties put their name on the waiting list and immediately get seated before us. 

At 8:10 I asked the hostess "Do you know how much longer the wait will be?" 

"Oh right away." 

We were seated 10 minutes later. The food was very good, especially the tea leaf salad. 

Moral of the story, never make reservations at Mandalay. Just show up, put your name on the list and you will be seated almost instantly.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
This is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  We visit at least once every couple of weeks, and it has never disappointed.  One special thing to note about Mandalay:  THIS PLACE IS SPOTLESS!  I have never seen a cleaner restaurant in my life.  The tables, silverware, and glassware always sparkle with pulchritude.  

The restaurant is family-run and the service is always so attentive and nice.  And most importantly, the food is out of this world!  I am obsessed with the Ginger Salad, which is light, fresh, and abundantly flavorful.  We also frequently order the Fish Chowder Soup and Tofu with Broccoli and Walnuts.  There are many other fantastic dishes at Mandalay, you really can't go wrong.  For a delicious and refreshing non-alcoholic beverage, try the Ginger Lemonade.  Everything at Mandalay is yummy, yummy, yummy!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants of all time, why are there not more Burmese restaurants in the world. Order the balada, ong no naw soi (coconut chicken noodle soup and the BEST dish on the menu, mandalay special noodle. Family style dining is the best way to do it.

Fun atmosphere, Christmas ornaments hang from the ceiling year round. The waiters are super nice and efficient.
author: Lynn B.

description: It's a neighborhood go to place. We've been several times and find the "Rainbow" dishes to be our favorites - salad, prawn, chicken. The pumpkin pork stew is also not to be missed.  A fresh coconut drink in the shell is a wonderful accompaniment.
author: Angela B.

description:
The atmosphere definitely isn't as exciting as BSS, but then there's no wait either, so it all evens out.  And the food!   Oh, the food.  Just as delicious as it's competition down the street, and have I mentioned already that I didn't have to wait two hours to eat it?   Amazing.   

The Burmese beef curry with potatoes was my favorite.   It's more like a dry curry similar to Malaysian beef rendang, rather than a typical coconut milk based curry .  My only complaint was that I wish the portion could've been larger since there were only a couple of chunks of beef in the dish.  Also very good was the tea leaf salad and the Mandalay noodles.  

The staff was so friendly and polite, and it was a little sad that we were one of only a handful of customers on that particular Saturday night.  I hope their business has picked up since.
author: Joanne G.

description:
I only live a block away from this place so it's one of my favorites for take out but it's always packed for dinner and the little restaurant is great.   It's very nice and cozy inside and the food is very fresh and with a healthy flair.  It's not too much sauce and the meat, fish or vegetables are always great quality. 

Now the natural thing is to compare this place to the famous Burma on Clement and I have to say, this place is just as good, and you don't have to wait for over an hour after which point you're just famished.  

Recently I got take out here and brought back to my place with my date, we opened a bottle of wine and had a great dinner, it was really good and very inexpensive.  He's new to SF so all the places are new to him but he loved this one, and he's a foodie like me.
author: Inga W.

description:
5 stars for the Spicy Prawn with Okra! It taste HEAVENLY.
I crave for it every day!!


everything else gets a 3.5 stars to 4 stars. 
Service is great too. it doesn't get too crowded but crowded enough that it's popular which is good because it means it'll stay in business.
author: Xiu L.

description:
We made a point to stop for lunch after museums.
A Wed crowd still a bit of a wait after 1 but so worth it.
Friendly, welcoming and efficient. 
And I had to lick the plates before I let them leave.
What more can you ask?
author: Karen S.

description:
This is the third time I've gone here and I must say that I like the service and atmosphere here better than Burma Superstar. You can avoid the craziness of Burma Superstar and still get very good Burmese food. 

We came on a Friday night around 9PM and only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table. Once seated we ordered: 

Tea Leaf Salad: we got the traditional style and it was yum. there were a lot of different flavors and textures. 

Chicken Samusas: I always order this with the tea leaf salad. It's pretty good. 

Tea Leaf Duck: This was not something I ordered before and it was pretty good. It came with some steamed buns. I made duck sandwiches with the buns and dipped it in the sauce provided. I'd have to have this one again when I go back. 

Coconut Rice: Sooooooooooo good and coco-nutty! 

Mango pudding: compliments of the house. It was refreshing. 

The servers were very attentive without being overbearing. Our water glasses were never empty. 

Can't wait to go back again when I am in the mood for Burmese food!!
author: Thang H.

description:
I am here with my team, I liked the Singapore noodles. 
wooow, its spicy and after a long time I had a very good taste of noodles.
I would try some other dishes next time I visit.
author: Sricharan M.

description:
**Review just based on service**

Horrible service! We made reservations for 730 and waited an hour to never get seated. The hostess seated everyone who came after us and didn't have reservations. We were so hungry we called Bagan down the block and were offered a table so we left.
author: Tina Y.

description:
The food and the service was not bad but I was expecting more considering the wait (this was also despite calling in to reserve).

Good:  Moo Hin Nga (Fish Chowder)  The flavors were not all that unique but I loved the variety of texture in the soup.

Okay:  Rainbow Salad, Nan Gyi Dok (Rice noodle with coconut chicken).  These were fairly similar, lots of ingredients mixed together.

Meh:  Mandalay Beef--hardly different then the preparation of general chicken dishes from Chinese restaurants, fried pieces slathered in sweet sauce.

Compared to Burma Superstar I think the food at Superstar is a little better and unique, but at least Mandalay has a more tolerable wait time and is not as overrun by hipsters.
author: Christine C.

description:
Burma Superstar outshines BY FAR.
The coconut rice here is totally wrong. It was more like fried rice and was oily. Obviously not cooked in the rice cooker properly. 
The Green Papaya salad was to die. Everything else. Meh.
author: A. H.

description:
Froggy Style:Date Night 2 was held here.  We rolled in about 10 deep and luckily made a reservation cause it filled up pretty quick.  parking was a little hard (that's what she said) but we lucked out and someone around the corner had just left as we were turning the corner.

the staff was great and very attentive without being too attentive.  i was asking our waiter about the restaurant and apparently they are the first Burmese restaurant in SF.  We started out with Chicken Satay and Samosas which were very good.  I had a Burmese Lemonade which was lemonade with chopped cilantro...it was very tart and had a distinct flavor...like they had added sour power to the lemonade.  really good.

we had about 10 entrees and we all sampled a little bit of all of them.  ones that really stood out to me were the prawns curry and the dry fried green beans.  everything was really good.  why the missing star? the only problem with the food was the size of the portions.  i felt as if they were really, really small portions.  we paid an average of about $10/ entree but i felt as if we got only $6 worth.  i really wish they had given us more.  don't get it twisted though - the missing star has nothing to do with the quality, flavor, or freshness of the food - it was superb...i just felt as if the portions were too small.
author: Ray R.

description:
I enjoyed Mandalay and will go back.  Upon entering, the somewhat silly decor threw me off a bit - but the incredibly friendly service and quality food is worth it.  

Two of us shared a green papaya salad, the curry beef with an interesting type of bread (similar to naan but much greasier, yum.), vegetable potstickers (fresh, steamed), pan fried string beans with seafood (including prawns, octopus, scallops) and the ginger lemonade (a bit sweet for me).  All of the food was good.

Thanks Mandalay!
author: Mara C.

description: I've been pleasantly surprised every time I've eaten here. Aaron is very nice, attentive and helpful. Take good care of us.
author: Mei Su H.

description:
We are a big fan of this place and by far my favorite Burmese restaurant in the city. The rainbow salad, Fried Pampano, and burmese fish curry with coconut rice- awesome. The dishes are mild to moderately spicy. The dishes all in all are really flavorful and well presented.

Kudos also to the service- prompt and friendly despite the place being jam packed on the weekends.

The decor though is a bit tacky- they have some christmas/holidays ornaments hanging from the ceiling!!! But then who cares if the food  is good!
My recommendations- rainbow salad

tea salad
mango salad
Rangoon three ingredients
Basil spicy eggplant

and of course- The Jasmine Tea!
author: Dee N.

description: Wonderful!!! I used to come here quite often when I was younger and my recent experiences have still been sensational! The ambience is great, the service is great, and the food....mmmmmmmm. Dishes that are a must to order: mango chicken, papaya salad and the tea leaf salad. The tea leaf salad is why this place is 5 stars for me. I have never had a salad quite like this one and it's flavorful and texturally satisfying. They even have a waiter/waitress that comes and explains what is in the salad and mixes it for you. I have not had everything on the menu, so I cannot attest for all the food. However, you must try Mandalay for an exceptional Burmese food experience!
author: Lauren D.

description:
This is the best Burmese restaurant in the city. Others are overrated and do not seem authentic like the ones a few blocks away. The service is very friendly although it can get very crowded during dinner times. Make reservations in advance for a big party.

I've been to Mandalay a number of times and the food has been consistently wonderful and appetizing. I love their Mandalay Chicken, Moo Hin Nga (fish chowder) soup and the best Tea Leaf Salad for its taste and texture. Pan fried string beans with prawns and Mongolian lamb shouldn't be missed either.
author: Alan L.

description: san francisco saturday chills...evening crowds outside and inside...just waiting...waiting for a table...inching towards the indoor chairs...a lengthy wait...time unknown...typically not a fan of burmese and superstar cooking...mandalay was about to change that...beers and water before ordering...warming up with a catfish stew to start...soothing warmth, but dull taste....next, taking tea salad, and palada with curry dip...not really a salad, but a mix of fried and grains...crunchy, flavorful and grainy...new experience in good taste and good texture...palada just a simple pancake dish flavored by mild curry dip...little rice requested to lather on lamb curry...finding good and simple....a mango beef little sweet, little tangy, little salty and little goodness...mix of such strong tastes...making for a complex mix of flavors...trying the mandalay special noodles too...tasty mix of seasoning, herbs, garlic and onions...finishing with standard asian string beans...finding many dishes garlic heavy...little heartburn at the end, but worth it...only $twenty-two per person quite filling dinner...
author: Hen A.

description:
Amazing Burmsese food! I have been to Burma Superstar, B-Star, Rangoon Ruby in Palo Alto and Mingalaba in Burlingame but this place is my favorite! There can be a wait at times, but I usually go at 7:45pm and am seated pretty quickly. Good for families, though can be a little loud. The ambiance is nice, nicely decorated but not too fancy to feel like you have to dress up. 

Recommended things (in addition to tea leaf salad and any of the noodles):
1) Dry Pan Fried String Bean - the sauce is so good! and beans perfectly cooked and slightly crispy
2) Sizzling Rice Soup with Shrimp, Chicken & Scallop - light broth, seafood flavorful, and the sizzling rice is interesting and adds a nice crunch!
author: Gary S.

description:
Apparently I had been here before years ago, but I don't really recall that first time.  I doubt that I will forget my second visit any time soon.

Craving some spicy cuisine on a cold, winter night (on the eve of what is supposed to be SF's first snow day in years ... we'll see), we found ourselves at Mandalay for some hearty Burmese cuisine.

The restaurant is decorated in festive and somewhat kitschy decor, with hanging ornaments and paintings.

The tea leaf salad, while comprising simple fresh ingredients (fermented tea leaves, lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts, chopped lettuce & dressing) was delicious.  Love the different crunchy textures and the way they prepare it table-side.

The vegetarian samosa soup was also delicious.  One order serves two small bowls (although you will wish there was more).  Rich and creamy with lentils and beans, the broth contained broken pieces of yummy samosas.

The Rangoon beef (marinated beef with spices sauteed with tomato, green & red peppers, onions and green chili) was also a great dish that was reminiscent of more northeast Asian cuisine.  It balanced well with a side of coconut rice.

Finally, the Mandalay special noodle (Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas powder lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top) was good but perhaps a bit overhyped compared to the other dishes.  Liked the contrast of the crispy, thin noodles with the flat noodles but the dish was a bit too creamy.

Still, compared to the hectic feel of nearby Burma Superstar, it's nice to have a more calm, alternative that serves comparable Burmese cuisine in terms of presentation and quality.
author: F. P.

description:
If you are looking for good Chinese food this is not your restaurant. If I had to rate it only on Chinese food I would give it 3/5. If you're looking for good Burmese or more south east asian, this place is great.

I used to live by the pan handle in San Francisco. It was a short trip to both Mandalay and Burma Superstar. The novelty of Burma Superstar was nice with their coconut's and other touristy complements, but I found the quality of food and shorter wait of Mandalay to better fit my tastes. Why wait an hour plus for food, when you can have the same quality and similar items for a 15 minute wait at it's busy times.

I think on every visit we have ordered the Balada (flat bread with great curry dipping sauce), Moo Hin Nga (Fish chowder soup,) and the "Dry Pan Fried String Bean."

Sometimes we get the Tea Leaf salad or Rainbow Salad, my wife loves the Green Papaya Salad, but we don't always get it. 

I don't really think the Mango Chicken is that great and many of the other mains are only so-so which is why I only gave this place 4 stars.

Overall I love the starters, soups, and curries and go back to this place almost every time I visit SF.
author: Chris I.

description:
I prefer Mandalay to Burma Superstar - except the Tea Leaf Salad, who is kind of heavy here because only nuts and seeds, little vegetables - their Samosa soup is better, the Mandalay noodles are special and, generally, for my taste their menus is better and more variety...
So OK with me if people want to stand hours in line at Burma Superstar, I go one block up and there is less crowd, less noise and the food is better, at least for my palate...
author: VIORICA C.

description: This place satisfies my burmese food cravings with the usual selections. Docking one star off for consistency - a perfectly good mo hing ga can be followed by a bland version in the next visit.
author: Sarah L.

description: We went on a Burmese food binge last weekend. This was our first stop. Balada - so good and totally hits the spot. Tea Leaf Salad - too many peanuts. Mango Chicken - ate the whole thing - lots of fresh mango. Special Noodles - again, delicious and flavorful. Out of the other Burmese spots, this was by far the best in terms of quality, service AND price.
author: Es F.

description: The original Burmese restaurant, my parents have been coming here for over 20 years. The tea salad is one of my mother's favorites.  If you love Burmese food you have to check this place out.
author: Tina B.

description: To get my five stars, Mandalay only needs one dish: the fermented tea leaf salad. The spiciness, the nuttiness, and that fermented tea leaf taste - which I can't really describe with any other words, because it's so different from anything I've ever tasted. This is a salad that inspired me to scour the internet for sources of ingredients - it turns out fermented tea leaves are not easy to find. Oh well, I guess I can't make it at home, I'll have to come back!
author: Nicholas R.

description:
Mandalay has been my go-to place for excellent Burmese food for over 10 years, and the food is just superb. The owner is Burmese, and I can truthfully say the food is authentic; my mom is from Burma, speaks Burmese, and knows her Burmese foods. 

Mandalay's got it all; from Ong-no-kow-swe (coconut chicken soup) to boo-thee-jaw (fried squash). They aren't missing a single essential Burmese dish. They also have an array of yummy appetizers and desserts.

On top of having awesome food, the prices are awesome. If you go to Mandalay, I suggest you go in a group of some kind because the dishes are serves family style. I had my sweet 16 at Mandalay with about 20 of my friends, and I ended up paying about $300, including the cake. For the best birthday party I've ever had, $300 for such a huge group was a small price to pay.

Good, authentic food; great service; and reasonable prices. What's not to love?
author: Natalie L.

description: Honestly has to be one of my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I frequently order the Mango Chicken, Chicken Skewers, Samusas, Tea Leaf Salad, and of course the Mandalay Special Noodle. The service here is fantastic. Their milk tea ((the Burmese iced tea) is that for which I would die. The owner/manager is the most kind woman and knows what my friend and I like to order when we come. Can't beat this Burmese place!!
author: Austin P.

description: Mandalay consistently serves good food, I have been here numerous times and have always enjoyed trying different dishes. My favorites are still the Mandalay Special Noodle and Samusa.
author: Tim T.

description:
Best example of authentic Burmese cuisine in the city of San Francisco!

Being raised by a Burmese father, I, of course, can identify a wonderfully prepared Burmese dish, and each one that I've had, at Mandalay, has reminded me of home. The best start to default to is the tea leaf salad.  There are a variety of flavors going on in it, nutty, fishy, garlicky, chili peppery, etc....  It really opens the taste buds and prepares them for anything you throw their way, later in the meal.  Another of my personal favorite starters is the fried squash.  It's type of summer squash, which is cut into strips, battered lightly and fried, accompanied with a savory sauce that can be drizzled over the top of each piece.  Mmmm, mmm, mmm, they're so hot and crisp, yum!  Ready to move to entree items?  Mohinga, a catfish noodle soup, is so comforting.  The catfish and ions are reduced to a point where they almost fuse together.  Of their curries (they have beef, lamb, chicken, and okra), the lamb is my favorite.  It's tender, and absorbs the flavors of the curry like a sponge.  I recommend ordering a bowl of coconut rice, if ordering any of the curries.  Mandalay's coconut rice earns its name!  The coconut flavor is very present, and it has a sticky texture to it, which makes me sometimes just want to eat it by itself.  When I go to Mandalay, I usually order so many items, that I am rarely able to handle dessert, but the couple of times that I was able to save room for it, I've had the mango and sticky rice, and the sticky rice, which are served in a shallow bath of sweetened coconut milk.  

The proprietor and all of her staff are wonderfully attentative and willing to explain anything on the menu, which you may have questions about.  Mandalay does get crowded, so my strategy is to arrive before I'm experiencing absolute starvation, to avoid getting cranky during the wait.  Once the wait is over, it always seems worth while, at the end of dinner, when I'm walking out the door!
author: Damon Z.

description:
Finally came here with friends last night and was instantly struck by the warm environment and welcome from the host. I can see why our friends are such big fans of this place!

If you like Burmese/Mandarin food (or at least the American version), do yourself a favor...skip Burma Superstar (cause I still can't understand why all the rave reviews??) and hit up this place, less than 10 blocks away! The food is made with LOVE...seriously, and it's actually brought out to you as courses (I'm a huge fan of that). If that isn't enough, the quality of the ingredients is immeasurable. All of this for very affordable prices!

Hugely recommended!! You don' t have to wait to eat here either!
author: nina B.

description:
So, we had to wait for a table. It was Saturday night. Totally worth it.

The food here is stellar. The service is amazing. The flavors and textures are out of this world!

Try the lamb curry! It's so good!
author: Aliya J.

description:
LOVED this place!!!! 

Better than Burma Superstar (Yes, better. There I said it!!! )

No SUPER, SUPER Looooonnnnggggg wait

Excellent, friendly service

FABOULOUS food!!!

house special noodles=heaven
samosa soup=heaven
rainbow prawns=heaven, and LOTS of fresh prawns
rainbow salad=heaven
tea leaf salad=heaven
  you get the picture....

***cheaper too***

methinks I will eat here all the time!!!
author: Nicole L.

description:
THIS PLACE IS WAAAYYY BETTER THAN BURMA SUPERSTAR.

There is actually taste in the samusa and moh hinga, unlike B-star. And the wait is not as long. 

The service here is wonderful, I ordered the moh hinga for myself, and the waiter was so kind to give me a small size one at half the price, so I could eat other stuff.
author: Alicia W.

description:
WONDERFUL alternative to Burma, however I would actually give Mandalay a few more points in regard to presentation and service.  They really make you feel attended to and well informed.  When they bring a dish out, they let you know all the ingredients (as they are presented on a plate separately) then is mixed at your table.  The jasmine tea is a full flower that is put in a clear wine glass and blossoms in front of you.  

The taste rivals Burma.  I had the tea leaf salad, garlic okra and shrimp, mandalay noodle special, fried onion blossom with special dipping sauce, and coconut rice.  I would have all of them again, except the onion.  I could do without it.  My favorite out of those dishes was the okra and shrimp.  It had great flavor, texture, and balance.  They also don't skimp on the big, plump shrimp.  

I would have ranked this as 4.5, but the mango and sticky rice was semi-upsetting.  Everything that was brought out made me say MMM and I was expecting an equal if not above standard finish.  I was disappointed.  My favorite asian dessert is stick rice & mango.  Rice didn't have the sweet coconut cream hint and the mango wasn't ripe and was too crispy.
author: Deanna A.

description:
I had my birthday dinner here about 1.5 months ago, and the BF and I visited this place prior because it's open late.

Burmese food is awesome ^_^ and this is the original Burmese restaurant in SF. 

Fried eggplant & squash was the best.   I'm pretty sure I ordered way too much food the first time coming here, but hey we were starving.  The second time was just right.  The service is very attentive and pretty good. 

The only gripe that I have is that the flavors of the mango chicken didn't really blend but other than that everything else was tasty and filled me up =].

I highly recommend the Ginger Lemon drink--it's soo good, you'll want seconds.
author: Natalie G.

description:
So, I've been eating at Burma Superstar and B-Star for years and then I moved into the Inner Richmond and noticed that there are actually 4 Burmese restaurants here.  I tried Mandalay last week and then I went to Burma Superstar again tonight (Superbowl Sunday = no wait.)  I feel like I can now say with confidence that I prefer Mandalay- the flavors had a certain explosiveness that really does it for me.  

I had the tea leaf salad, the chicken satay, and the Mandalay special noodle dish.  The tea leaf salad was nicely balanced and didn't have lettuce which made the rest of the flavors more intense.  The chicken satay was probably the best I've ever had- scrumptious with pickled veggies and a side of peanut sauce.  The Mandalay noodle dish (we had it with tofu), was wonderful and must have contained a lot of lemongrass.  The noodles had a nice mix of textures and tastes and I have never seen or tasted anything quite like this dish.  
The decor is bright and colorful in Mandalay, which I enjoy.  The dishes are also in bold colors.  The bathroom is nice.  All of these things make a difference to me- I can appreciate some bright and shiny in my dining experience.  I also overheard patrons casually chatting it up with the managers (possibly the owners) about the recent upward trend in business and concluded that Mandalay has a loyal following.  I am not surprised, in fact, I will be coming back myself.

*oh yeah- I almost forgot the best part: the fortune in my fortune cookie told me that I need to be eating dessert at least 3 times a week.
author: Erika W.

description:
I love this place. The food is always delicious and the service is so friendly. Don't miss the tea salad, and definitely try the pea shoots!
I suggest you either make a reservation or arrive knowing that you might have to wait a bit. Despite long lines, the wait tends to be reasonable.
author: D Z.

description: Amazing food and speed! Must try the tea leaf salad (we did vegetarian and it was amazing). Then as a group of 3 we tried: Tofu Special Noodles, Coconut Rice, and Basil Eggplant & Tofu. To drink we tried the Mango Lassi which was great; we also tried the Burmese Iced Tea which was okay but very sweet. Granted it was our first time trying this tea all together. Overall: MUST GO!
author: Dorian S.

description: We made a reservation in advance, but for 7 o'clock on a Saturday night, so we ended up waiting for about 30 minutes. However, the hostess (who I'm assuming is also the owner) must have seen how hungry (and cranky) we were and she offered for us to order before we sat down to cut down on the waiting time which was AWESOME. Then we got to the table and ordered the jasmine art tea. WOW. It's a flower in a glass and it's delicious. Insta-opportunities. Every dish we ordered was amazing, rich and delicate at the same time. HIGHLY recommend the rainbow dishes.
author: Elena T.

description:
Dear Mandalay,

Yum!  I am resisting the urge to compare/contrast you with Burma Superstar, because it seems patently unnecessary.  Can there only be one Burmese place in the neighborhood?  Clearly not, and Burmese food is certainly delicious enough in my book to merit alternatives.

Your food is a mix of what seem to me closer to Chinese dishes, and the Burmese dishes I recognize based on your recommendations as well as my experiences at Burma Superstar, which I tried first.  My favorite dish so far is the Walnut Broccoli with Tofu, in a wonderful sweet sauce with honey-coated walnuts.  Yum.  I also enjoyed your tea leaf salad (always a winner) and your Burmese lamb curry.  Your Mandalay Chicken was tasty, but I think I'd order something else next time, as it very closely resembles sweet-and-sour chicken and I would rather enjoy your more specialized offerings.

On top of your lovely, well-prepared food, your space and atmosphere are friendly and the service is attentive.  I tried you on a Tuesday with one friend, and ended up taking another out-of-town friend to you the following Saturday.  Both visits were a delight, and I'll soon be back.

Tea-leafily, 
Erin
author: Erin M.

description:
I had lunch here yesterday. Delicious food!! Great for vegetarians too!
The staff is warm and friendly. I have had Burmese food in other restaurants and found the flavors and presentation much better at Mandalay.
author: Lila L.

description: food is great, service is very friendly, but wait is way too long. only party over 5 can reserve, that's a disappointment to me.
author: Paiyu G.

description:
I can't get the Balada bread out of my head.  I am actually imagining eating that warm, tasty dough this very second.  Crap, Mandalay, what have you done to me?!

Here is my break down using Serge's Patent-Pending-Pending F-technique:

* FAST: No waiting in line for an hour to an over-rated over-hyped restaurant *cough cough*.
* FRIENDLY:  Ghandi would feel at home here.
* FILLING: Don't order too much, the portions are quite large.
* FOOD: They have it here, which is good because it's a restaurant.
* F..um.. PARKING:  Mostly a residential area, so no trouble there.
author: Serge S.

description: Awesome - Better than Burmese Superstar IMHO because it is lighter.  We had the coconut rice (delicious) - great coconut flavor and NOT sweet at all.  The Mandalay Noodles are a must!!  Everyone raves about the tea salad - I am not as into nuts salad but everyone in my party loved it.  We got the prawn and okra was super awesome.  I cook a lot of okra and I don't know how they did it - it was not mushy and it was not fibrous - that is actually quite hard to do.  Excellent flavors.  Waitresses were attentive - they do have fast turnover so I don't think you are expected to lounge for hours.  There is a slight wait if you arrive after 6pm - we got there at 5:45 and NO WAIT - I really got tired of the minimum 45 min wait at Burmese Superstar so I have not gone back there in ages.  This is a must do if you love Burmese cuisine.
author: Booboo S.

description:
Food here is quite good, but a bit pricey.  Went there for dinner last nite.  For appetizers we has the samosas and fried onions. Both were quite good.  For main courses had the Coconut Tiger shrimp which was also good, but the portion was tiny, just 4 shimps and I think around 15 bucks.  Too expensive.

The only thing I didn't like was there "sangria", if you could call it that.  It didn't taste like much more than wine with a few fruits tossed in as they made it.

Overall good, but a too expensive
author: Raul G.

description:
Love Love Love this place! I was craving Burmese food the other day and my boyfriend took me here. The food was delicious. We ordered "boo thee kyaw" (deep fried squash), "A Mea Tha Hyn" (beef curry), "ba la tha" (fried flat bread), "La Pet" (dried tea leaf mix) and jasmine rice. My boyfriend and I were so full after stuffing our faces with this goodness. The "boo thee kyaw" was fried to perfection! And the dipping sauce was so yummy. 
Not only was the food delicious but the staff was so friendly. I was so pleased that the owner/manager knew how to speak Burmese. Its nice to know that there are authentic Burmese people running this restaurant. Also, throughout the dinner I spoke to them in Burmese and they were kind enough to give us free desert! 
Mandalay is such a great restaurant. I'm definitely going back!
