author: sharie w.

description:
Our party of 5 was seated immediately right after 5pm on a Sunday evening. We were asked if we had reservations (we did not) -- and the restaurant began to fill up VERY quickly.

Good, tasty food. Clean bathrooms! I'd come back if I didn't have to wait. Not sure quite how authentic the food is however -- not very experienced with Burmese food and I suspect they might cater to American tastes instead of delivering authentic food.
author: Eric C.

description: Always yummy! Great service from friendly, lovely people. I'm gonna keep this review simple: I LOVE this place & every friend I have recommended it to has as well. The tea leaf salad is a must, as is the Samosa soup. And I am never disappointed when I get something new off the menu. Definitely worth going out to the avenues.
author: nancy s.

description:
I had a feeling the rainbow chicken (pan fried chicken, mango, pineapple and veggies) was going to be good, but I had no idea it was going to be this good. Each ingredient was simply bursting with flavor, and I was very, very impressed by the generous and balanced quantity of meat, fruit and veggies.

I now understand why when I walked in the people in front of me said unprovoked "you'll love it". This is food you want to rave to people about. Or yelp five stars.
author: Jason B.

description: This is one incredibly tasty menu. Nice people and the food is truly amazing.
author: Hieu D.

description: Very good, well prepared food. Like everybody else, we loved the tea leaf salad. The menu was deceptive about the so-called half a duck (the breast portion was missing). Because it is so popular they definitely are set up for turning over the tables. Not a place to go for a leisurely meal.
author: FromScratch M.

description: This is one of my favourite restaurants in San Francisco. Just as good as Burma Superstar without the overwhelming crowds. The food is amazing and I've always had prompt and attentive service. Just like everyone suggests, the Tea Leaf Salad is amazing but so is just about anything I've tried (including the catfish soup which I was sort of skeptical of initially).
author: Sean H.

description: Really enjoyed dinner here a couple of nights ago. We started off with the tea leaf salad which was prepared in front of us and very flavorful and delicious mix of ingredients. Then moved onto hot and sour soup which was also great, and then the highlight was the mango chicken which was fantastic. The food here has so much flavor and the service was very friendly. Not to mention the excellent value ( $35 for 2 stuffed adults).
author: Christy D.

description:
The food was amazing. Tea leaf salad, curry beef, some kind of pan fried fish and the fish stew - all fantastic. 
The service was stellar, couldn't be better and the price was right.
Loved it.
author: AMY J.

description:
I ate here quite a while ago out of spontaneity to try out this famous Burmese restaurant.

For appetizer, I ordered balada, which was a crispy pancake with curry sauce. I thought the curry sauce was good, but the pancake wasn't anything out of the ordinary.

As for my meal, I ordered the Burmese style noodles. Interesting taste to the egg noodles. 

Pretty satisfying meal! Probably more suitable for meat eaters.
author: Tina C.

description:
The food here is as Burmese and authentic as it gets! And this comes from someone who grew up in a family of Burmese folks. I'm not going to itemized what I've eaten at Mandalay. Basically ALL is superb! 

However, the few must haves are:
Balada (crispy pancake), Samusa (triangular crispy curry filling treats), Lap Pat Dok (tealeaf salad),  Moo Hing Nga (Catfish Chowder Noodle Soup) and Kaw Soi Dok (Tossed Cold Noodle Salad).

The customer service is delightful and the prices are decent. 

Will come back again if I'm deprived of Burmese food from my family.
author: Dee T.

description:
Awesome lunch and the dishes were cooked just right, not over done which is so often the case in these types of restaurants and all was very tasty.

Fresh flowers all around the place, nice people, attentive staff. It was my first time, was there for lunch and it was surprisingly welcoming and good.
author: J.J. N.

description:
The food-
We went here for Christmas in lieu of cooking for just the two of us. We made reservations- were not sure that they would be needed ( but it never hurts to be prepared)                        
We ordered the flower tea- what else to order on a chilly drizzly day. I have had better flower tea at a tea house in Boulder, Co but for a restaurant it was good.
I had the banana flower salad, could not place all the flavors in the salad, it was a little muddy, but I did appreciate the artful presentation of the plate.
We ordered the fried eggplant strips- listed as stripes on the menu. They were overly breaded and scant amount of eggplant. Percentage of breading to eggplant 75/25. Which means that after a few minutes they were greasy looking long lumps. The pickles served as the center for the eggplant were exceptional and we held onto those as the waiter took away the greasy long lumps.
R ordered the beef curry and I ordered the Special Noodles. it is the noodles that gives the restaurant the rating it got, they were very good, flavorful with clean flavors and a good balance of ingredients. R said his beef curry was good, not exceptional. We decided to bring it home for it to be kibble helper for the dogs( which they enjoyed thoroughly)
To finish our meal we ordered a dessert that was made up of ice cream tapioca pearls, hard jello, and various fruits (the name escapes me) It was okay, verging ont he sweet side and definitely did not need the jello. 

The service:
As others here have noted the service is real the killer here. We were seated and waited for over 8 minutes ( yes, I counted) until someone came to see if we would like anything. Our food came out very slowly, more slowly than I would have expected for the number of people int he restaurant.
The table beside us was asked four separate times if they would like something other than water to drink, 2x by the same person.
When the time came to get the check one of the owners brought us two other tables bills with credit cards inside. More unsavory people would have had a field day with that, we did not. Also not sure why he left two of them on the table.

Overall
We will go again, try some other dishes and see (hope) that service improves.
author: Gmarie H.

description:
Yummm.  Don't bother with Burma Superstar!  Mandalay has no wait, really friendly staff, and reeeeeeally good food.  The owners have given my friends and I free dessert on two separate occasions.  It's the sort of place where you're happy to give them your money.  

Do yourself a favor and try the chicken samosas!
author: Allison D.

description:
Tea leaf salad was great.  Will try the Papaya Salad next time. 
Good presentation and easier to get a table tahn Superstar.
Good drinks
author: Ray Y.

description: The most fabulous Burmese food we have ever had. Great atmosphere, attentive wait staff dressed in native garb. The tea leaf salad was to die for! We will visit this restaurant every time we are in San Francisco.
author: Steve C.

description: Value for the money, make sure you order the home made noodles and Balada.
author: Bulent K.

description: This place is run by a sleaze ball. Originally we wanted to eat at burma superstar, and then upon realizing that the wait was long called this place and was told we would get our table in minutes.  Walked ten minutes here with three elderly people and waited 50 minutes before we got fed up. The supposed table that was ours hadn't even finished dinner and were having desserts AND were celebrating a bday during that whole time we had to wait. I confronted the asshole manager who couldn't even look me in the eye when I asked him why he told me to come now and that a table was available in minutes. Ironically the table opened up for us at burma so we bounced. Do not ever come here. Seriously F this place.
author: Tien-Yeo H.

description:
This is a wonderful place!!!
Good ambiance,great customer service,GREAT FOOD!!!
Sherry is always very nice ,warm and caring.
You have to try their flat bread with sauce,eggplants,Mongolian beef and ,for sure,papaya salad. Believe it or not-Monday evening -5/13- was packed until the very end-it was my b/day,so if I wouldn't made reservation in advance-we wouldn't be able to get in.
And they are consistent in everything-food,service,accommodations.
Thank you a million,Marianna Marenitch and guests.
Caramella Skin Couture Spa
author: Marianna M.

description:
Fantastic Burmese food and great value. The tea leaf salad (traditional style) was really interesting with garlic chips, lentils, and a little heat.  Our favorite dish was a noodle dish with amazing coconut milk sauce and chicken (I think it was called a Mandalay special).  Basil beef also quite good.  

We seemed to hit Tues night rush hour and waited a little bit, but they kindly took our orders while we waited so the food was pretty quick.  It's a pretty large space and not too bad to walk-in. Ended up around $25 each including beers.
author: Aki N.

description:
Great food! I'd come here to avoid the wait at Burma Superstar. Service, however, is definitely not as efficient.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
I was very attracted by the good reviews on yelp, and I made a reservation.

I talked to 3 of our servers, and none of them were Burmese--hmm, interesting.
1. Tea leaf salad--I was glad we added lettuce, otherwise, I would be feeling eating nuts with sesame oil.
2. Beef and chicken satay--The chicken was outstanding.
3. Mango chicken--Not good.  The chicken was dry, and mango wasn't sweet at all.
4. Mandalay special noodle--Very small portion, and the flavor was just okay.  Not really sure if the fried noodle on the top was necessary though.  

Overall, the portion was pretty small, and I didn't really like the food.
author: Elena L.

description:
I went to Mandalay with a group of friends, so I was fortunate to be able to sample several different items.  Every single one of them was delicious.  The one that stands out most in my memory is the Rainbow Salad.

I'm definitely going to be back.  The only tough part will be deciding what to order if I don't go with a group!

Oh, the only negative is that we had to wait in line a little while.  This place is popular!  Allow a little bit of time if you go on a weekend night.
author: Colleen J.

description:
The food here was good, but not great compared to all the other Burmese cuisine I've had. Truthfully, I'm not sure why this place has such high reviews. 

Three of us went to Mandalay on a Saturday night. We got here around 7ish and got seated at 8:30ish. Durning the time of the wait, the hostess (who I think is also the owner) gave out free wine for waiting. When the lobby got crowded, she offered 20% discount to those that were willing to wait outside in the cold. Which I think is GREAT customer service! She acknowledges the long wait and find ways to make sure we stayed! (p.s. later on I realized she kept telling people 30 min wait time, which was more like 2 hours. There was a party that made reservations and they still had to wait about an hour when they got there.) 

15 mins after we were seated, they took our order. Getting water was actually hard... I had to ask three times just to get water. Lucky for us, we ordered Burmese iced tea (same as Thai iced tea) to subside our thirst.

This is what we ordered and the timeline of how our food came.

Waiter took our order...
*20min wait*
* Balata dish came out -appetizer dish (loved this dish! There was some sort of fishiness to the curry that made it much more interesting in taste.)
*15min wait*
* chicken and beef skewers -appetizer dish (very dry, my friend said his beef was dry and the chicken was good. I said the opposite.... at the end two out of three of us decided the beef was the better choice.)
*15min wait*
* Samosas (chicken) - appetizer dish (really good! but I am biased, I love samosas!)
*10min wait* 
* fried squash sticks ( I disliked this dish because it had way too much batter... You couldn't even see or taste the squash)
*10 min later* the host asks if we got our entrees yet and we all said no and he said he would check up on it
*10-15mins later* 
We got two out of three of our entrees. 
Ragoon beef - dish was good
Curry chicken - pretty good, chicken was pretty juicy and the curry was tasty 
*10mins later* our last dish finally came
Mandalay special noodle - it was good, but I was not a fan of the lime stems and it tasted a bit salty.

Overall, the food here is NOT worth the wait. Maybe I will take my friend's advice and come here on a weekday, maybe then I can enjoy the meal as a whole and not wait every 15-20 mins for my dish. If you have an event to go to after dinner (on a weekend), this is NOT the right restaurant for you!!
author: Erica T.

description: Our table had tea leaf salad, green beans, mango chicken, Mandalay special noodle w/tofu, Burmese curry beef, tapioca coconut milk--LOVED Everything!
author: Laura C.

description:
I gotta tell you...I'm Burmese and the TASTE of our culture is A LOT CLOSER AT THIS PLACE...than BURMA SUPERSTAR.  I'm not really hating on Burma Superstar but I do think the food THERE is more Americanized and I can taste that the key spice ingredients being taken out in some dishes so it DOES NOT taste AS AUTHENTIC. 

Also, if you haven't noticed...almost everyone that dines at Burma Superstar are mostly Caucasians/Americans.

I also love the fact that they have my FAVORITE dessert drink mix called "Paluda" here.  For you Asian dessert drinkers out there--its similar to drinks like Halo Halo and the Vietnamese 3 tapioca jelly mix drinks.  It's just AWESOME!

However, my friend liked the green tea leaf salad better at Burma Superstar though because it had lettuce added to the mix of nuts so it added a different texture in taste.  

But all in all, I definitely WOULD COME BACK HERE more than I plan to ever go to Burma Superstar if you want to know the comparison between the 2 restaurants.
author: Wendy T.

description:
I never knew this place existed until my half-Burmese friend took me here. It's delicious. Probably my favorite Burmese place I've tried thus far! 

When we arrived, there was a ten minute wait, but they seated us promptly! We ordered:
-Moo Hin Nga (Fish Chowder)
-Chicken Samusa (pretty good; the dipping sauce is delicious . . . don't expect much chicken!
-Mandalay Beef (very tasty and filling)
-Dry Pan Fried String Bean (very good)

The price range is reasonable . . . although I don't know how much our bill came out to since he paid for us. Ha. Minus one for not being very attentive and taking a while to bring the bill.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I have been on quite the Burmese kick lately, and it's no wonder why! My Burmese education started a mere 7 months ago when I was introduced to Burma Superstar. Since then, I have been experiencing non stop cravings for sauteed veggies in chili sauce, rainbow & tea leaf salads, and sticky rice with cinnamon.

The endless amounts of vegetarian options that I still want to try include spicy eggplant and pea shoots with garlic. The menu is insatiably long and more than ample for moods that include chicken, lamb, beef, seafood and  veggie cravings. 

Service was very nice and informative and complementary dessert was served. 

Tip: *Try the Sangria and the Lemon Ginger Beer. Great cocktails for $4.50!
author: Theresa T.

description: My favorite Burmese restaurant in the City, hands down!!!! The quality and taste of the food is above and beyond! My favorites are the samusas, mango salad, coconut rice and walnut broccoli chicken. The service is also on point - very warm and attentive.
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
If you like moo hing nga (fish chowder soup with rice noodle) this is the place. I think they are the best so far that I'd tried in bay area, so much better than Burma Star.

Tried the tea leaf salad as highly recommended by other yelpers but I think it's just ok...actually I think I prefer the Rainbow salad. We like the coconut curry chicken noodle & Balada. As for the drinks the Ginger lemonade is good choice, it has a good flavor of basil. At the end they are always generous to give you free desserts & omg @@ the mango pudding & the sweet potato desserts are HEAVEN!!! We left happy with the food & their services are very good, everyone is so cheerful :)
author: Michelin f.

description: Okay. Super busy, waited 45 minutes for just okay food i'm afraid.  Service was good but took ages for drinks to come out (starters arrived before they did).
author: Harriet P.

description:
I remember the food being decent but I'm sure they'd get more attention from would-be customers if they let us use their bathroom. I've been here before with a party of 4 before, but when I walked by today in a desperate need for their bathroom, they turned me away. 

Me: Sorry, would it be okay if I used your restroom? 
Server: Um, no not really. 

Ugh. It's not like I'm going to mess it up. I dressed clean cut and came in with a smile. I'm not some teenager or bumb and I asked politely - not like I pranced up in there like I owned the place.  I don't know what the big deal is. This was 3:00pm so it was completely empty. Not like customers were waiting to use the restroom. Gosh. That single staff person that turned me away isn't going to change my rating b/c I'm hoping it's just him.
author: Brian Q.

description: Far better than Burma Superstar, and nowhere near the wait. The food is delicious and the service is impeccable, and the quirky decor is part of its charm. It's worth the trip out to the boondocks! Don't miss the famous Tea Leaf Salad and the Special Ginger Lemonade.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
Solid 4 stars! Arrived during lunch hour on a Friday and was seated right away.  My friend and I ordered the tea leaf salad to share, along with individual lunch specials.  The waitress was very helpful when we couldn't decide between several dishes.

The tea leaf salad (one of my favorite dishes) was absolutely delicious - moist, flavorful and mixed table side.  I ordered the rainbow chicken with saffron rice for my entree while my friend had the basil seafood with coconut rice.  Both were excellent choices.  

I highly recommend Mandalay and prefer it over Burma Superstar on any day.
author: M G.

description:
Absolutely amazing.  Usually we always go to my favorite restaurant in the Bay Area.. Spices II.  This time Anelya convinced me to try something different.  Have been eyeing the yelp reviews of this Burmese restaurant and the more-crowded version on Clement St for a while.  From the reviews, it sounded "eh okay" -- nothing I would be crazy about.  The tea leaf salad particularly surprised me as a favorite for many people.. can it really be that good?

Oh yeah baby, it's really that good. I'll keep it brief, because Anelya covered all the fine points in her review (and surprisingly she didn't like the tea leaf salad).  I'm IN LOVE with their tea leaf salad.  I can't get it out of my head.  I crave it.  I want some right now.  Going crazy just thinking about that crunchy, spicy taste.
author: Allan G.

description:
I love Burma SuperStar but sometimes I don't want to wait in line and deal with Food Network scenesters.  Whenever this mood strikes me I head to Mandalay, put my name down on the clipboard and get seated in a very timely fashion.  
Now on to the food!  The tea leaf salad is very comparable to Burma and I think their curry is too.  If you want a more chill atmosphere and value your time I'd say Mandalay is a noteworthy spot to eat Burmese food.
author: Sarah C.

description: Before coming to Mandalay, I didn't really know what Burmese food was.  Anyway, all I have to say is RAINBOW salad.  JUST ORDER IT! :)
author: Lauren C.

description:
My first time trying Burmese food and I couldn't be happier. Mandalay knocks it out of the park in every facet. Great food and great service. I haven't eaten Thai food in weeks because I keep coming back here. 

It does get crowded at times but it is worth the hype. Food and drinks are fairly priced while making use of quality ingredients.
author: Alex L.

description:
When you think Burmese... people think of Burma Superstar or B-Star, owned by the same people, and a long wait.  But if you don't want to wait, a good alternative is Mandalay.

Spicy somosa soup is a must
Roti - not the same as you get in an Indonesian restaurant.  This one is more like a pancake
Egg plant was good
Brown rice you can't mess up and if you did you should get out of the kitchen
Sangria was good, but the wait staff didn't know what was in it

The decor was nice, well lite, and was an easy place to talk.  The waitstaff was attentive and friendly.
author: Po L.

description:
Guys, Burma Superstar is overrated.

We stopped in here on a whim one evening after deciding against the barren sushi restaurant a block over. Despite the relatively spacious -- not to mention beautifully decorated interior -- we had to wait 15 minutes or so; the place was poppin', and with good reason. 

We ordered the samusa soup and the spicy tofu with vegetables. The samusas were crispy yet tender and full of tasty veggies, and the broth was delicately spiced and plentiful. The spicy tofu left some to be desired; it had neither much sauce nor many vegetables, and it was not as spicy as we had hoped it would be. But the addition of a little hot sauce kicked it up to a much more delicious level, and the tofu itself was prepared perfectly.

My only complaint? A couple of kids running around, throwing noodles all over the place, leaving tiny shoes in the aisle, and generally being annoying. But that's not Mandalay's fault. I felt sorry when the waitstaff was cleaning up after them.

Anyway, Mandalay will now always be my first choice above Burma Superstar or B-Star or whatever other satellite restaurants they have. It's just as good if not better, and it's far cheaper.

UPON MY RETURN: I'll order the tea leaf salad and some sangria. It was a mistake to go without those.
author: Sarah S.

description:
OMG So good!

Yeah, okay, there is going to be a wait... maybe even a long wait... maybe even if you have reservations, you're going to have to wait a bit. But the wait is worth it!

The food is great and the service is very good for how busy they are. This was our first time at Mandalay and we had no idea about the wait situation, so by the time we were seated we were starving and on the verge of putting on the cranky-pants. We were all zoning out on the menu when my friend said, "Let's just get the meal". So we got the meal for four. None of the dishes were all that exotic, but they were damn good. We ate all of it... even the deep fried banana at the end.

We will be back. We will have reservations. And I think we will be trying at least one of everything on the menu! Yum!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Good flavors, efficient and friendly service, and gets crowded.  

Came here for a weekday lunch. Although we arrived prior to their posted opening time, their neon sign was lit, the doors were open, and the young waitress happily received us and seated us.  Eventually, the lunch crowd came and it's definitely a popular place to dine.  One lunch group member ate here before and recommended this place, so we decided to try it all together.  The satay beef skewer appetizer came with some spicy, pickled cucumbers and a watery, but surprisingly delicious peanut sauce. Never had peanut sauce quite like it.  Most people liked the skewers, although one of them seemed a bit chewy.

The mongolian beef entree seemed a tad small, but was cooked just right. The Mandalay special noodle with chicken was unlike any other noodle dish from a SE Asian restaurant we've ever had. Definitely will re-order this the next time we eat here.  Apparently this place experiences the same long wait lines for dinner as Burma Superstar over on Clement.  Next time will be sure to try their version of the rainbow salad and other dishes.
author: Ye W.

description:
This was my first Burmese food experience and I was elated to have it at Mandalay.  My dining companion is well versed in Burmese food so I left the ordering to her with the exception of insisting on the Walnut Prawns because I am just one of those mayonnaise loving Asians.  

She ordered the Rainbow salad, Moo Hin Nga Soup, Mandalay Chicken, and the coconut rice.  I couldn't believe the amount of food we consumed...it seemed like dinner would never end.  The salad was a wonderful melange of textures and flavors, the soup was thick and rich, and the chicken was delightful.  

All in all this place was great and I would recommend it to anyone looking to try Burmese food for the first time.
author: Shari d.

description: Amazing Burmese food at reasonable prices!!! We love this place. Every time we have someone visit us in San Francisco, we take them here!!
author: Brittany F.

description: Came here with my family for my sister's birthday & all I gotta' say: "Mandalay is WAY better than Burma Super Star".
author: N A.

description: The tea leaf salad and samosa soup, without a doubt, rank among the most delicious things to grace my palate in SF.  Far superior to neighboring burmese places. I feel transported to Southeast Asia every time I go here.
author: Andy B.

description:
Mmm there's something yummy about their noodles that makes me keep coming back here.  Many of their dishes are solid and won't leave you disappointed.  Some of my favorites are: 

Papaya Salad
Hot & Sour Soup - Burmese style
Mandalay Chicken w/Mango
Rangoon Beef
House Special Noodles
Coconut Rice

Service is typically attentive without being intrusive.  Tables do get a little crowded when the restaurant is full, but manageable to hold a conversation (although you might hear some gossip from next table over).  If you come in a group larger than 4, you might have to wait for the small tables to clear so they can be combined.  On a busy day, write down your name out front; The wait isn't as bad as Burma Superstar and I think the food is better anyways.  

Food: 4/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Value: 4/5
author: King L.

description:
Had high expectations b/c people were comparing it to Burma Superstar...but Burma is DEFINITELY BETTER. The tea leaf salad was interesting, and I can see why people recommend it. However, that's where the pros of this restaurant end. First of all, while we were trying to take a picture of the salad, our waitress rudely said, "Actually, you can't take pictures of our food." 0_0 WHAT?? People ALWAYS do that at restaurants!! SECONDLY, while my friend was putting a spoonful of the mango chicken on her plate, she saw that the STICKER was still on the green BELL PEPPER!! LOL pretty hilarious for us, but NOT so appetizing!! We told the waiter and he took it back and gave us more mango chicken....

So to sum it up: DON'T GO HERE, STICK TO BURMA SUPERSTAR!!
author: Diane G.

description:
Mandalay has food that meets expectations; Not excellent, but good. For anyone who has tried Burma Superstar, Mandalay can be described as Burma Superstar / 2. It's about half the price and half the excitement.

VERY IMPRESSED: My first observation is how well the staff cleans the tables after each customer. They actually use a cleaning agent. Very impressive as certain un-named low-class restaurants in the area, use customer's left over tea and dirty napkins to clean the tables after each use.

The waitstaff is very friendly. They are professional and efficient in operation. The waitress who took our order didn't have the need to write anything down and she made no mistakes.  WOW... I would forget everything!

The food has flavor and good texture. I must point out that we placed an order for cocoanut rice ($2.00 a person) and I would not recommend this item. Perhaps it was a one-time fluke, but the rice appeared under cooked. It was hard to chew and had too much cream with very little cocoanut flavor.

My only other complaint is that the restaurant is a bit cramped. They try to accommodate as many guests as possible. I prefer my space. When I want to be near strangers, I take Muni.

Overall, I enjoyed the restaurant and I would recommend people try it out while in the area.
author: Nathan E.

description: I love this restaurant!! For the price, it doesn't get better then this!  Everything is delicious, if you haven't tried it....you have to go!
author: Liz A.

description: Ambiance was nice.  Burmese Tea Leaf salad was delicious.  We ordered the pancakes which was delish.  The Mandalay chicken was a good dish. Wonderful flavors.  I'm glad we got there early since there were plenty of people waiting for our table.
author: j. l.

description: Totally awesome! Great atmosphere, great food. Great place for a date night. Only complaint was that it's very crowded. Then again, it's very crowded for a reason... Highly recommend
author: Tim B.

description: Awesome! Great food and equally good service! We had the Tea Leaf Salad and the Singapore Noodles, both of them were brought to our tables and then mixed in front of us, which was a delight to watch!
author: V K.

description:
" Have you been here before?" Yes! Many times. Now let's break this down quickly for all of you with ADD.

Who are they? Oldest Burmese restaurant in SF. 

Service: Friendly and... let's say relax. Water and food won't come out super quickly, but you won't be punching your date unless you're hypoglycemic 

Price: Very reasonable.  Most dishes run about $8-$10. 

Portion: We always have leftovers. 

Interior/ Seating: My back is almost always to a wall. No real seats out in the middle of the restaurant. Important for those of us who only like to get shot in the back when in the bedroom. 

FOOD

Appetizers 
A) Samosa soup. 1 order serves 2 people. Just get it and stop complaining that it's not cold enough for soup. 

B) Rainbow salad-the mix of flavors are, how you say...YUMMM

C) Tea leaf Salad: Now I like this, but sometimes it's too crunchy for me and gets stuck in my teeth. But addicting.

Main Dishes:
Chicken
1) Mandalay Chicken -Kind of like an orange chicken, but better. 
2) Mango Chicken-I don't like sweet dishes, but this one seems to hit the right spot. Not too sweet. 

Seafood
1) Pan fried w/ String bean-Pretty good. 
2) Rangoon 3 ingredient: Not full of flavor, but decent. 
3) Pan fry okra prawn: Not so much. The okra was woody. 

Noodles
Nan Gyi Dok-Although I prefer this without the chicken. They mix this on your plate too! 

Vegetarian 
Eggplant and Dry friend sting beans. Both yummy when in season. 

Deserts: 
They often give us a little something free, but we really like saving 6% of our stomach space for a crepe at Genki
author: Kat M.

description:
The food was delicious. Everything was great. I highly recommend the tea leaf salad, rainbow salad and mango chicken. The sweet potato like desert was great too. I highly recommend this restaurant. I plan to come often.

I thought the service was top notch.
author: John-Mark I.

description:
My server, Vicky, was hands down one of the nicest and most attentive servers I have EVER had since I've lived in San Francisco. I went to Mandalay with 7 girlfriends and I think we were probably quite a handful. Vicky was so sweet and patient with us and very helpful with the menu!!

We ate everything family style and I don't think there was a single dish that anyone did not like. For appetizers we had samusas (chicken & vegetarian), dumplings (pork & vegetarian), the rainbow salad and the bread with a curry dipping sauce. All were incredible! Be careful though, because the rainbow salad has sliced jalepeno. 

For dinner we share multiple entrees. The mandalay special noodles were a big hit. The curry beef and lamb dish we ordered were great, but my favorite was the pumpkin curry with prawns. We had a couple others that I can't remember.

The restaurant is very clean and parking was pretty easy. 

Corkage fee was $8/bottle (we brought 4) and the overall tab for a TON of food including 4 desserts was $29/person with a 20%+ tip. SUPER reasonable and excellent quality food. I will go back many many times!!
author: Kandace K.

description: Good food.  Had the tea leaf salad (hope you like peanuts!), veggie samosa soup (sooo yummy!), and sizzling prawns (too bland).  I will def be back for that soup!  FYI...the place was packed by 6p on a Saturday.
author: Janelle F.

description:
I recently planned a birthday dinner for my aunt's big 50th, and decided on something other than the typical Asian cuisines.  My experience at Mandalay was very nice.  I made a reservation for 6:00pm on a Wednesday, and they happily accomodated me.  I was actually quite surprised at how many tables were filled during this time and already eating by the time of our arrival at 6.  

Once arriving , the very friendly staff greeted and assisted us with our birthday cake and balloon that we had.  They were very attentive and made sure everything was going well...water and tea was constantly being refilled, and cleared our tables as we finished eat dish. This was definitely great because we ordered quite a bit, and it can definitely get quite cluttered.  So I was very pleased with the service here at Mandalay.  

Food was also quite good.  We started off our meal with the Samosa and the Fish salad.  Salad was a bit spicy and refreshing at the same time.  Samosa had great flavor and the sauce on the side added to it.  

For entree's we had:

* Burmese Curry Beef with their flat bread - Flavor of curry was great, nice and spicy, but the beef seemed to be a bit tough to chew as the chucks of beef were cut in large cubes.  The flat bread was great for dipping the curry; reminds me of Green Onion Pancakes with out the green onion of course.  
* Mango Chicken - Yummy, wasn't overly pan fried, batter was just right.  I wish they put a bit more mango flavor and more mangos though.
* Spicy Tofu w/ Veggies - Yummy, but had the exact flavor of General Tso's chicken it seemed.  
* Mandalay Special Noodle - Way too sour for my taste for noodles.  It seemed to almost be a better dish cold.  I don't prefer a sour hot noodle dish.  

We ordered the Safron rice and Coconut rice to compliment our meal.  Safron rice was way "Chinese Fried Rice" to me without soy sauce flavor.  Coconut rice smelled delish when he came out, but the flavor was nothing special.  Definitely smelled better than tasted.  

After our meal, it was cake time, and to our surprise Mandalay plays throughout the whole restaurant "Happy Birthday" in Burmese and in English.  It was sooo cute!  My aunt was extremely embarassed.  So if you want to embarass someone fo their birthday, definitely bring them here so that the whole dining room can sing happy birthday.

Overall, I enjoyed my experience here at Mandalay very much.  Food was pretty flavorful, and service was very accomodating.
author: Cass J.

description: My favorite weekend late afternoon lunch set at Mandalay includes: veggie samusa, rainbow prawns, the Kaw Soi Dok noodles, veggie samusa, and Phaluda for dessert.
author: Eloy T.

description:
Fate led me to this very restaurant.

It happened when I took a cab to Burma Superstar. After chatting up with the driver, he gave me two bits of advice: eat at Mandalay and don't sleep around. Duly noted.

So a few weeks later, I was exploring the Richmond and poked my head into the Boudin Bakery, to which then a baker gave a friend and I each a loaf of sourdough bread.

With that bread we skipped around California Street, poking our noses in the different eateries until we fell upon Mandalay. Quickly I remembered the cab driver's advice and we went in.

Inside, there were many parties waiting for a table, a half hour wait at least. As we sat down, munching on our sourdough breads to appease our grumbling tummys, I noticed a woman eyeing the bread.

"Would you like some?" I asked.

"Yes!" she replied. Apparently she had been waiting for sometime too.

After grabbing enough to temporarily withstand her hunger, the waiter showed her party to their table. Since a few of her friends couldn't make it, she insisted that my friend and I join her group for dinner.

So we did. We had the walnut prawns and utterly delightful tea salad (which I hope to recreate at home.)  We had nice conversations with strangers turned friends and glad I followed the signs that took me to Mandalay.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Why go to Burma Superstar when this is in the neighborhood?  We showed up at Burma Superstar at 5:30 PM on a rainy Sunday with a group of six, and were told that the wait was 1.5 hours long. We were actively encouraged to go to a "sister" restaurant a few blocks down but was more Vietnamese than Burmese (then what's the point?)

Fortunately one of the folks in our group knew about Mandalay, so we walked over, were promptly seated, and had a delicious meal!  Good green papaya salad, tasty beef curry, a very tasty Paluda desert that reminded me of its namesake (falooda) from India and a very friendly waitstaff.  $100 for a group of six.  The next time I need a Burmese fix, I'm coming to California Street, not Clement!
author: Vikram K.

description:
The food:

Sizzling Rice Soup - Clean tasting but nothing over whelmingly special.
Mango Salad - wonderful flavors.  One of my favorites.  The mixture of flavors is so unique and special.
Papaya Salad - almost as good as the Mango salad but not quite.
Mango chicken - there's a reason everyone gets this.  Simple but wonderful.
Mongolian beef - tender chicken, wonderful flavor.
Green Beans with mixed seafood - the sauce is terrific and the scallops, shrimp and calamari is perfectly cooked.

The only negative thing I can say about this restaurant is that they charge $1/person for tea!  The food more than makes up for it!
author: Julia K.

description: One fun waiter. Delicious sangria. That's Bout it though! The tea leaf salad was mediocre at best and the food was overpriced and sub par.
author: Christina D.

description:
Out with the new, in with the old!
I'm completely sold on Mandalay, the oldest Burmese restaurant in SF. Mandalay is like Burma Superstar's older sloppier-dressed, but wiser sibling-- that's a little cheaper, too. 

Aside from Mandalay being a bit faster to get a table than Burma SS, I think the food is AMAZING. It's where I would take anyone from out of town. 

Not to be missed are:
-the tea leaf salad (don't let the word "fermented" deter you, it really is fantastic)
-vegetarian samusa soup (sooo yummy)
-Mandalay Special Noodles (think lemon grass, kafir lime, coconut, fried garlic, and creamy noodles)
-anything with mango (tofu, shrimp, etc.)

The staff is also very friendly and willing to answer any questions about the menu. 
I also see the owners every time I go in, which I like. 

The decor isn't flashy, but it is fun and gives you something to talk about-- there are always Christmas ornaments hanging from the ceiling, and a big shrine in the front entrance to Buddha next to a fake palm tree.

Love this place!!
author: annie s.

description: Visiting a friend and she took us to eat here tonight. It was FANTASTIC!  We had the tea leaf salad, naked eggplant, basil chicken, and Mandalay special noodles. I'm always iffy with chicken - I hate getting fatty pieces or nasties in my chicken, but all the chicken we had was perfect. Don't try to call for a reservation for a small group though, they'll tell you it's easy to seat you and you'll wait about 45 minutes. But it's totally worth it, promise!
author: Karina F.

description: I fell in love with Burmese food because of this place. (I've been to Burma Superstar which is way overrated in my opinion.) Mandalay is spacious and in the afternoons is nice and quiet. (Unlike the closet sized Burma Superstar where you feel like it's a race to finish your food because there's always a line of people waiting outside.) Mandalay has amazing food. I don't know what there's not to love about it. Plus it's super vegetarian friendly. I love meat but I don't believe in eating meat every single day for every meal. It's nice to have something delicious without having meat be the best part of the dish. Also the environment is really interesting to be in. There's so many little eclectic decorations everywhere. I think it's a pretty special place and there's not that many Burmese places out there.
author: Margarita B.

description:
I've been on a Burmese food rampage of late and the most recent one is Mandalay. 

Coming here on a random weeknight has its perks - no aggravated (mostly Asian) drivers or double-parking idiots on Clement, the meters are no longer in effect (I just got a parking ticket 2 minutes after the meter expired and I am still bitter, but that's another story) and the walk between Clement St and Mandalay is actually a quick and pleasant one.

The best thing about this place is that it DOES take reservation, unlike Mingalaba (http://www.yelp.com/biz/mingalaba-burlingame#hrid:GH62J8iNWl6FfzO_qbsvwg), Yamo or neighboring Burma Superstar.  And sometimes, all I want is just to walk in, chow, and walk out (after paying, of course). 

As far as the dishes are concerned, they are pretty good.  Not the lip-smacking earth-shattering zomg-i-want-more kind that I had at Mingalaba, but they were tasty nonetheless.  Presentation-wise, it's definitely better, cleaner and way more organized than hole-in-the-wall Yamo with lower risk of falling victim to some random drive-by shooting whilst tucking into your tea leaf salad.

The menu is pretty standard - for those of you who haven't had Burmese food before, it's a combination of Chinese and Indian, similar (but not quite the same as) Thai, best eaten family-style.

We had the tea leaf salad (a must - especially when the server with the lilting accent brought it out and started explaining each one of the ingredients!), rainbow salad with 3 different kinds of rice and egg noodles, ong no kaw soi (coconut chicken noodle soup) and samusa soup (for the vegetarian in our group), and of course the coconut rice, pumpkin curry (pork), stir-fried string beans (not unlike those found in a Chinese restaurant), and the Mandalay eggplant. 

On Mandalay eggplant, we decided to order it since it bears the name of the restaurant (so the assumption is that it's a house special).  It's so delicious that it made me wonder why eating an eggplant never occurred to me before!
author: Ange L.

description: As mentioned above, the Rainbow Chicken is fantastic, the special noodle is special, love the coconut rice and saffron rice.  Great food without the wait.  We have been several times and have always been happy.
author: Nettie A.

description: My mom and I went here after a visit to the Legion of Honor. It was a beautiful day- cold, clear- and we drove through the Presidio and then down California to get here. The sun was setting and lights were going on in apartment windows. Mandalay was so appealing. The bright yellow entry and neon open sign didn't prepare me for the light-up imitation cactus or all the beautiful baubles that waited for us inside. We got there at 5 and grabbed a table easily, but just half an hour later it was packed. I ordered the balada, mango salad, and chicken curry with potatoes. It was very difficult not to eat all the balada- which the menu calls a "crispy pancake" and is the most delectable fried thing imaginable- and order more. The mango salad had onion and nuts and something else (what is the crunchy part? ) and was overall very light and fresh. The waitstaff was friendly and kind. The woman next to us said she goes to Mandalay every week, I think, and was equally sweet. If you are very hungry after a wonderful day in the city, or even if you are only a little hungry after a horrible day, I would recommend this.
author: Isabel L.

description:
When it comes to Burmese food Madalay is #1!!!
The food is awesome and the staffs great!
Definitely try the Mango Chicken w/coconut rice
author: Rich P.

description:
I actually like this place BETTER (yes better) than Burma Superstar! We had a reservation at 745 and was seated right when the four of us arrived. 

Four of us ordered a tea leaf salad, vegetarian hot n sour soup, some pancake style appetizer, vegetarian dumplings, basil chicken, sizzling shrimp, a tofu entree, a bottle of wine, 4 beers, and a jasmine tea.  The bill was only $125.  In my opinion, that's pretty cheap for all that food.  My favorite was the basil chicken. So flavorful and pretty spicy.  

The service is good, the ambiance is interesting, and the food was great. Overall better than Burma.  The only item we ordered that I actually thought was better at Burma was the tea leaf salad.
author: Jenny W.

description:
It's true, it's better than that other more popular Burmese restaurant on Clement street.

While the tea leaf salad was more minimalist and focused, I didn't find it to be any better than the one at BStar, nor the lamb curry.

However, the banana blossom salad, which was the special that day; holy s--t. The perfect combination of sweet and savory, in some secret dressing that will not be disclosed.

Mandalay FTW.
author: Mark A.

description:
Three of us went to Mandalay for my first experience with Burmese cuisine.  If this restaurant is representative, then I'm a fan.

All our selections were vegetarian, and I'm happy to say they had a variety of choices from the ginger salad, mixed at the table to the noodle dish also mixed for us.

The servers were all very nice and quite attentive without being intrusive. And the price was very reasonable, considering the fine quality of the food and the service.

I will definitely make another visit to this restaurant.
author: Stephen S.

description: Food is good but the atmosphere could use a little work. Get the tea leaf salad.
author: Peggy N.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco - amazing food, super friendly owners/staff - lucky to have this one in the neighborhood!
author: Jon N.

description:
Happened upon Mandalay at lunch today and was pleasantly surprised. I had only the rainbow chicken from the luncheon menu, but it was excellent. Really nice staff, too.
Wish they delivered.
author: Just R.

description:
Mandalay has single-handedly gotten me hooked on Burmese food. Combining the best flavors of both East Asian and South Asian Cuisine, it has quickly become one of my favorite restaurants in the city. As a Burmese restaurant, it outshines Burma Superstar (its more popular, more highly-regarded sister restaurant) and Yellow Pa Taut (its lesser known, less delicious South of Market rival).

As a starter, the Tea Leaf Salad is incredible. The seemingly-odd fusion of tea leaves, lentil seeds, grounded shrimps, fried garlic, green pepper, sesame seeds, peanuts & dressing works surprisingly well. The flavors blend harmoniously in your mouth while the extra zing provided by the pepper and garlic are an added bonus that will make you crave more.

The Mandalay Chicken was also a winner--spicy, not too oily and very delicious. As were the Rainbow Prawns--well-seasoned and combined with a tasty trio of mangoes, pineapples, and veggies. Our group also enjoyed the Mandalay Special Noodle--a great noodle dish that was packed with flavor and complimented our meal well.

The standout dish, however, was the Burmese Curry Beef. The best curry I've ever tasted, hands down. Not only was the beef super tender, juicy and delicious, its taste was the perfect mix of sweetness and saltiness. It also came with a yummy side of potatoes. Overall, the Curry Beef is a must-order and tastes great with the coconut rice.

I will definitely remember Mandalay as the restaurant that single-handedly made me fall in love with Burmese food. In addition to the delicious cuisine (unlike anything I've ever tried before), service was great and the wait was much shorter than it is at Burma Superstar. The only downside is the fact that portions are rather small (order 1 more dish than the size of your party, trust me).

I can't wait until I come back to try more!
author: Joseph F.

description:
Wow, I really have loved Mandalay the two times I have had food at this fine establishment.  Consistently good food at a very reasonable price (fairly typical for the Richmond).

The menu is extensive, and if I were to guess there is not a flop on the menu to speak of.  The appetizer I had was great (a delicious pancake) and so were both the Kaw Soi Dok and the Mandalay Dry Pan Fried String Beans.

This would probably be a 4 star review, except that they gave a free dessert to a first-time-Burmese-cuisine-consuming family.  That was also very good.

Check this place out!
author: Sam D.

description:
This place is both a "hell yea!" and an "ummm, what is that?" type of place. The waiters did a good job trying to tell us what is in each dish, but we still came out with some mystery dishes. 

The "hell yeah!" dishes were the fried eggplant appetizer and the coconut chicken noodles. Both were amazing. I couldn't stop eating them which was bad because I wasn't the one at our table to order the noodles, I probably ate half of that dish too, whoops!

The "ummm, what is that?" dishes were the tea leaf salad and the caky fruit desert. The salad was good... as a tip of the tongue taster. Maybe I would have liked it more if there wasn't shrimp flavor in it. It was pretty strange though. It was definitely fun to watch everyone try it for the first time. The dessert (featured in one of the picks) was a caky type fruit bar. It was kind of floury and hardly sweet. I wasn't a fan of it. 

There were some plain old, good, dependable dishes too. They weren't outrageously excellent or bad; just good. Those dishes were the mango prawn and the smoked tea duck. Actually the tea duck was pretty good, but should be shared, there's too much fatty meat and bun for one person.
author: Shanna H.

description:
After a long meeting at work, all I wanted to do was EAT. It was around 7:30pm on a Thursday night and almost every table at Mandalay was full but we didn't have to wait longer than a minute. I loved the atmosphere. It was bright and colorful with Burmese decor and ornements hanging above our heads. The service was great too! I just couldn't believe when our bill came. It was around $50 yet we had no leftovers which meant I didn't have a lunch the next day! Sucks for me. Here was the dinner:
 
Special Ginger Lemonade - I HATE ginger and I dislike lemonade. So why did I try this? Yelp of course! And I don't want to box myself in! This drink is very sweet and refreshing. It almost has a carbonated taste and just a slight pucker of lemon. I couldn't taste ginger at all. YAY! 

Rainbow Salad - I really wanted the Tea Leaf Salad but again, I ventured out to try something new. The difference between Rainbow and Tea Leaf Salad is that Rainbow is mainly noodle based. It has three different kinds of noodles, tomatoes, cucumber, cilantro, tofu, potatoes, fried onion and garlic, saffron rice, cabbage and dressing. It sounds like a towering plate of food but it's actually on the small side (especially for $9). I liked it but I was still craving that nutty, crunchy, amazing Tea Leaf Salad! 

Black Pepper Soup - This soup was prepared with vegetables, squash, vermicelli, and rock cod filet. I know this is probably a big duh but the soup was VERY peppery. I thought the combination of everything went well together except for the overwhelming pepper taste/sensation. But that's just my preference. 

Burmese Style Noodle - Made with egg noodles touted with fried onion, fried garlic chips, cucumber slices, grounded split beans and dressing. We totally didn't notice that this dish had a "chili pepper" next to it (indicating spicy). Boo! I really liked the egg noodles though. It had great flavor and it really stood out from so many other egg noodles I've encountered. This is another noodle dish on the small side. 

*Burmese Style Curry Catfish Steak* - This entree made my dinner and MY NIGHT! It has some of the tastiest catfish I've ever put in my mouth. The meat was so savory sweet, tender, and HUGE. Unlike the noodle dishes, they gave us generous portions of catfish in a delicious chunky curry. 

Coconut Rice - This was a great compliment to the curry. The rice was perfectly infused with creamy undertones of coconut. Yummmm!

Sui Yin Aid - This is a chilled dessert soup made with coconut milk, tapioca, and agar. The red tinted glass that it came in made us think we ordered jello! The HORROR!  I really enjoy the agar it came with and to me, it tasted like a cross between lychee and jelly. The coconut milk was sweet and not thick at all. The tapiocas are the small clear kind which worked well with this dessert. Didn't love it but I'm glad I tried it. 

Due to the smaller portions we left satisfying full, not STUFFED-I-can't-walk full like you expect at most Asian restaurants. Which is better??
author: Julia T.

description:
In recent trips to SE Asia, i've not gone to Burma as one must pay beaucoup $ straight to a horribly corrupt govt just to travel there. Having lunched today at Mandalay, i'm thinking that the FOOD ROCKS and i may need to cough up the dough and go see the country as an anthropologic and gastronomical trip. Key point: This was a delicious meal.

We had the Rainbow salad and i loved the texture diversity and esp the tofu and garlic bits... My date was keen on trying the Banana Blossom special which was artistically presented but we both found a little sweet-- it was primarily a fruit salad... and we were looking for savory. We also had the sweet and sour soup w/ prawn. Good as well.. I'll be back to try more entrees.. what's the naked eggplant all about??! Stomach was at capacity by this point.

The service was sweet, though there was an oversight on my companion's peanut allergy, but he saw the dreaded things before biting in and reminded them. They took it right away and brought a whole new dish as they should.. ( all's well that ends.. without anaphylaxis..). 

And so it is, Rachel meet Burma.. Nice, nice to meet you. Oh an p.s-- word on the street is this beats Burma Superstar right outta the water and we waited not even a moment..
author: Rachel S.

description:
I've been to the Mandalay a couple times with friends. The food was very good both times and the restaurant has a pleasant atmosphere.  They have a variety of tasty salads (e.g. tea leaf salad, papaya salad, chicken salad", which are all excellent.  The main dishes are excellent as well.  I've had the soup (sizzling rice) once, and it was ok, but not as flavorful as I expected.

Both times the wait at dinnertime was very long... worst yet, the staff indicated a 15-20 minute wait but it was actually an hour.  On our most recent visit we actually went to check out another place while we waited, but ended up returning for the nicer atmosphere at Mandalay & tolerated the long wait.

They are so busy that you have to wait for a menu even once you've been seated. Also on both visits they messed up our orders, delivering the wrong items to our table... Then they took them back off our table and gave them to the correct party.

Also the people waiting in line are crowded up in the entry area (and overflowing out onto the sidewalk), standing there watching the diners like vultures... It feels a little weird like you should be hurrying.

Again, the food is very good, so you have to decide if it's worth the drawbacks.  I heard Mandalay has been featured on "Check Please", which probably accounts for the large crowds.
author: Bill H.

description:
Taste like Asian to me. When you have influences from India, China, and Thailand, you are more likely to taste curry, spicy, and nutty favors.

The thing is, I'm Asian so eating Burmese food is mildly pleasant.  The only thing I'd like was the papaya salad and the sesame seeds / nuts plate appetizers. Those were some of the items I'd like, totally different and unexpected. The Rainbow Chicken, soup, beef, and noodle dishes were decent. I have had similar flavors before. 

The surprising dish was both the saffron rice and coconut rice, the saffron rice was not flavorful but the coconut rice was delicious. It actually inspired me to start cooking rice at home. But....you're Chinese, shouldn't you be eating rice daily. Umm....NO! I never cook rice.  

The noodle dish was my least favorite. It looks like fettuccine and it had grass in it. The flavor was disgusting. 

I wouldn't come here unless someone has a birthday party I have to attend. And I wouldn't take someone plate while eating or rush someone to leave because there is a long wait. I think that's a horrible way to end someones dinner party.
author: Stanley K.

description:
I would give it 5 stars if it wasn't for the service. Maybe it was just because it was a busy night, their service was a bit slow and they brought out our dishes about 15 minutes apart. They are nice though and were very patient when half of our reserved group (6 total) was late. 
I had their Nan Gyi Dok noodle dish. It was very delicious, worth the money. When they brought my dish out, it was not mixed. As the waitress put the dish down, she explained went over the ingredients allowing us to pick something out to leave out. The Burmese iced tea was delicious, like thai iced to but slightly different. Again, the food was delicious and the price was good. The service was ok. I plan to go back to try some of the other dishes that looked delicious. I recommend this place.
author: Alex E.

description: Mandalay, I award you 5 stars for two reasons: 1) your delicious food which is every bit comparable to Burma Superstar and 2) you didn't have a redonkulous wait like Burma Superstar.  We ordered the tea leaf salad, a curry dish, and the special noodles.  All were very tasty and satisfying.  If you want Burmese but don't want to wait 2 hours for dinner, come here instead!
author: Brian A.

description:
We come to Mandalay quite often for lunch and dinner. Our party size various as well - starting with 2 people to as large as 10-12. Across the board my experience here have been great! I would have to list the whole many pretty much to describe what is good. My personal favorites are - papaya salad,walnut shrimps and green beans

Pros:
- great service
- consistent quality 

Cons:
- parking can be tricky 
- have to wait for a table on Friday or Saturday night
author: Natasha J.

description: Well to start, the food was mediocre at best. Not to mention the forgettable service. They're boss has a short fuse and it reflects with negative energy throughout the restaurant. You could go here and pay $20 for an nontraditional rendition of Burmese food or you could walk a block down to clement and get some dim sum for a 1/4 of the price. I don't know, you tell me.
author: Zack T.

description:
I was last here 20 or 25 years ago.  My youngest brother introduced us to it and it has glowed in my memory since.  We haven't been back since, mostly because it seemed like such a long trek across SF to get here from the East Bay.  Rinky and I have been talking about a lunch w/ Marian G. and Mandalay was suggested.  I was delighted.  We discussed BART and bus and the more I thought about it the more hassle it seemed, so I offered to drive.  I do BART, but a crosstown bus in the rain is just too much for my spoiled self.  When I looked at the map to figure out the route, I realized we had been doing it all wrong.  From where we live it's easiest to go over the Golden Gate Bridge.  It's even closer and easier than going to the de Young.  Damn!  We could have gone here for dinner lots!

So, it's yesterday.  There is a beautiful break in the very welcome rain.  We drive over to California Street and find a parking spot right in that block.  We walk into the restaurant, which looks just as I remember it, full of light, carved wood dividers giving tables a little privacy.  We were greeted by Marian, who is beautiful and gracious.  It's such a pleasure to meet in person someone you've known and admired only online.  We looked at the menu of lunch specials.  Rinky and Marian had an idea of what they each wanted and we were so busy talking that I really didn't give myself enough time to develop an idea of what I wanted and quickly chose the first thing that called me, the mango chicken.  I love fresh mango.  The waitress suggested the combination plate w/ samosas and I agreed.  In retrospect I realize that my research was inadequate.  I should have read more reviews just before to get an idea of what others liked.  My ancient memory was simply insufficient.  We decided to split the renowned green tea salad and that was an interesting contrast of tastes and textures.  I liked it, a lot.  My dishes were not appealing.  The chicken was a bit overdone and there was nothing special about it.  The samosas were curried potato and chicken.  Again, nothing special.  The tastes I had of Rinky's broccoli, walnuts and tofu sang in my mouth.  Excellent.  Marian's fish looked gorgeous and she liked it.  I didn't taste it because I had so much food.  Fortunately Rinky helped me w/ the chicken and the samosas.  Had I chosen better the food would have been as stellar as the company.  As it is, it's 3 stars for my meal but the extra star is for Rinky's and for my past visit.  Not to mention probable future ones!
author: Toni M.

description:
i had been waiting a while to try this spot out, i do like me some burmese food. i've been to burma superstar, and burmese kitchen, but hadn't experienced mandalay just yet.

the waiter came by and said "special burmese diet coke" when delivering our diet coke. i think he's so used to saying "special burmese ____" that he skipped over the thai iced tea and said it before the wrong beverage. kinda funny.

the samosa soup is ridiculously delicious.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Delicious! And no sesame! Yay me! 

Whenever my mom comes to town I like to take her to weird and new foods she's never had. After pedicures at Salon Belle Linda, this was a great spot to grab some dinner. Tonight was the second time I've taken her here so she wasn't as nervous. There were 3 of us and 3 dishes suited us perfectly. All pleasantly stuffed while still being able to walk out of there. 

Mandalay Special Noodle - refreshing, delicious, mixed table side which is fun to watch. I like to eat this last because it leaves you with a pleasant, light, citrusy flavor in your mouth. 

Yellow Curry - Very good, comes with chicken and potatoes. Not spicy at all, but still holds a lot of flavor. 

Mango Prawns - Absolutely to die for! The prawns were sooo tasty. I think I'll be ordering one for myself next time I come here. 

They also have some fun nonalcoholic drinks which is nice when the mom is town. I had the Burmese iced tea but almost opted for the ginger lemonade. 

If you're ever in the mood for good food, come before 6pm and you should get seated pretty quickly. If there is a wait, it's well worth it.
author: Ali R.

description:
WOW! Yup! That what you will say when you exit this restaurant after your elegant meal! My family and I dine in during my dad's birthday and we have a great time! Food was excellent, service was great, and the presentation was exceptional.

5 stars for service
5 stars for quality of food
5 stars for presentation

Highly recommended! Give it a try and you will be WOW!
author: Harry L.

description:
Came here with a group of people.  Made reservations for 8 but they only had a table for 7 set up so we had to wait for a few minutes.  Why set up a smaller table?  hmm don't know.  But the table was very small for a large group.  In any case, the place is cute and it was packed with people even at 6:30 in the evening.  

We ordered lots of food - 2 portions for everything.  But the portions are very small.  Double portions of prawns is like - 9 or so prawns.  Basically, this is not the place where you pig out, unless you order more. The food quality I though was good and tasted good, except for being pretty greasy.  You can actually see the oil on the plate.  And they clearly use lots of butter and cream in the food.  

Overall, the food is tasty but not sure if I'd come back just due to the price to portion ratio and the unhealthy aspect to the food.  Ended up costing 31/pp which is not cheap for this type of place.
author: Frida C.

description:
This place was delicious.  I'm glad I trusted my travel-mates and allowed them to choose Burmese and Mandalay, in particular.  I had a Burmese iced tea (which tasted exactly like Thai iced tea) and we ordered chicken satay and veggie potstickers to start.  They were decent.  We also ordered Ong No Kaw Soi (coconut noodle soup) and Chin Hin Yee (Burmese Hot & Sour Soup), which were excellent.  

Then, they brought out the entrees: beef curry, sizzling shrimp and Mandalay beef with coconut rice and balada.  So much deliciousness!  I was regretting the appetizers because I didn't have enough room to keep eating the Mandalay beef.  I don't know how they get it that way, but it was so crunchy, never soggy, never greasy, topped off with a delicious savory sauce.  It paired wonderfully with the coconut rice.  And the balada?  Yes!  You want this.  I have a love of all savory pancakes and this is certainly no exception.  Crispy on the outside, slightly chewy on the inside.  Soooo good.

Sadly, we didn't have room for dessert.  This place was easily the best meal was had in SF.
author: Jenn E.

description: My friend and I tried Mandalay the other day after seeing it on "Check Please Bay Area".  The food was good, especially loved the Rainbow Salad which has about 8 different ingredients that they mix together right at your table, yum!!  Also had the Yellow Chicken Curry which was good and the Basil Pork which my friend thought was too sweet.  I thought it was o.k. but it was a bit sweet.  I would definitely go back and recommend this place!  Parking can be a bit difficult in this neighborhood.
author: Dave C.

description: After seein this place on Check Please Bay Area we had to try it out! Sure enough this place was amazing. The decor, service and food. Absolutely nothing I could say bad accept for maybe parking.
author: Eric P.

description:
Ordered dinner to-go the other night.  I had the tea leaf salad and the Mandalay Special Noodle dish.  When you order these dishes to-go, they separate the sauces in containers from the noodles and salad so everything will stay fresh until you want to eat it.

The tea leaf salad was not as good as Yellow Pa Taut's salad.

The Mandalay Noodle was really good.  It consists of "Burmese fat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas, powder lime juice, onion, and fried thin noodle on the top."  The chicken was soaked with the coconut sauce which I can basically drink.
author: Danny P.

description:
Mandalay is a San Francisco gem. Rainbow Salad and Tea Leaf Salad were excellent. Mandalay beef, Singapore Style Noodles, tea smoked duck and coconut rice were also quite good. For dessert, we'd really wanted to try the "palata" with tapioca or the mango sticky rice, but there were all out. :-(   The dessert we had with coconut milk and gelatin wasn't good. :-(  (that's why only 4 stars)
Next time I will order the flowering, green tea like the lady at the table next to us...it was so pretty.
Parking was easy. Dinner for 2 was $80.
author: Deeb A.

description:
Ok, I'm not going to say get into any details about the food because I think that's been well covered by all the other reviews. Its fantastic, plain and simple. I would give it 5 stars except for the one caveat explained further below. The tea leaf or ginger salads are a must--if you haven't have Burmese food this is dish you've probably never experienced or would ever think possible. Don't pass these up! In addition to the ginger salad, we  ordered the Balada(like a Roti),basil shrimp and Rangoon Lamb(I love that they serve lamb on the menu). All were amazingly flavorful and the three of us left very happy campers. 

But then the MSG kicked in.

 I'm making an assumption that they use MSG as I didn't ask, but judging from the way we all felt afterwards, I'm 99% certain that they use it quite generously. I'm particularly sensitive to MSG and passed out for an unintended hour long nap shortly thereafter. I should have asked, but now I know better. Believe it or not, most Asian restaurants still use MSG--just ask and you'll be amazed. 

But it was so delicious that I won't even think twice about not going back. I'll simply request dishes without MSG or plan for a nap afterwards. It really was that delicious. 

Never been to Burma Superstar because I refuse to wait in lines, but I can't imagine it could be better than this place.
author: kevin b.

description: BEST Burmese restaurant in SF! My usuals consist of the hot and sour soup, mango chicken, mandalay chicken salad, and last but not least the Mandalay Special noodle ftw!!!! My mouth is watering thinking about the Mandalay special noodle right now....I wanna go back!
author: Diane L.

description:
We love this place, and were lucky enough to have our rehearsal dinner here.  Mandalay became one of our favorite restaurants because of their great (and eclectic food) and their even better service.  Come here a few times and the owner will know your name, and a few of your favorite dishes.  Be sure to check out the Mandalay Noodles (the dish that hooked us), Banana Blossom Salad (not on the menu but very refreshing), and the rainbow fish.

Lastly, they did a fantastic job handling our 45 person rehearsal dinner.  Very flexible, since we were about 45 minutes late, they were very patient with us and let us take our time.
author: Grant E.

description:
Wow!! everything was amazing! 
Tea Leaf Salad
Mango Salad
Eggplant Basil
Okra and egg curry
Mandalay Chicken
Get em all! They totally hit the spot
author: S R.

description:
So my friends have been going to this place a lot and speaking so very highly of their Mandalay (coconut & curry sauce) Noodles, so I finally had to try them.  It was a saturday and the place was packed, but luckily we had a table reserved. 

Food: 
To be fair now, I must say their portions were small for the mango chicken (too little chicken), mango salad, whereas the basil beef and mongolian beef pretty much did not impress me compared to the sautéed beef I could get from a to-go Chinese food place, and was not anything special that I can say was "soooo good".  I've been eating at a lot of different Asian food establishments that have much more exquisitely tasting food, larger portions and more reasonable prices, if you ask me.  Oh, and might I mention that this place also leaves you drinking a lot of water due to the salt content of their food. But the one thing I did like was the Mandalay Noodles, maybe because this one was not so oily as everything else and didn't contain mango that did not taste much like mango.

Service:
I will have to agree with those who said first 10 minutes was good, but then where did the waiting staff all go? It was hard waiving someone down to get a box, or a fork (yes, they forgot a fork for me!). Yes I also do understand that you're busy, but when the drinks you ask for comes 20 mins after your food gets there, it kind of defeats the purpose of ordering them first. With the exception of asking multiple times if we wanted more water towards the end of our meal, I think the staff might have come around once to ask if everything was okay. But I guess they were nice.

All in all, I'd say there's better places that doesn't take me an hour commute to get across the bay and into the city to just dine there. Verdict: 3.45 Stars overall & 5 for the noodles!
author: Valentina W.

description:
This is a combination Burmese and Mandarin restaurant that my sister suggested we go to for a birthday dinner. I have been back a few times and it is consistently good.

I love their vegetable samusas which is like the Indian samosa but with an eggroll crisp wrapper crust which is lighter,crisper and better than the Indian's pastry-like thicker crust. Their satay chicken was also a good appetizer and Balada was similar to the East Indian/Pakistani prota(roti) which was good(a bit oily though). 

I wasn't crazy about the tea leaf salad-it is an acquired taste-although my mom and sister love it. It wasn't visually appealing to me at all and gritty tea leaves did not appeal to me either. I like to drink tea not eat it. The Mandalay chicken salad and green papaya salad was good.

I like the coconut rice(light) esp with the Rangoon beef or Burmese curry beef. The Mandalay Beef which is fried is on the sweet side-this one I think is better to order than the Mandalay chicken. I also liked the Basil chicken dish and I had them add eggplant with the bell peppers which really made it better as the eggplant melted in your mouth(I love basil dishes).

The Mandalay special noodle was light and a nice mixture. The Singapore style noodle was rice like bean thread/cellophane kind of noodles with curry-this was okay(almost like a pancit). Their chow mein is comparable to  other Chinese restaurant's chow mein.

Since I go to many Chinese restaurants,I choose to order Burmese style here and skip the more traditional Chinese fare usually. The ginger lemonade is refreshing and the kids love their coconut type of drink with tapioca pearls. The sweet potato cakes were light and airy,and were okay-not one I would order(they gave it to us). But I do want to try their fried banana next time-that sounds good.

The service is very friendly and on top of things even though they are busy whenever I go there. At lunch and dinner, even on what I would think would be slow days like on Monday or slow times like at 5pm,they were packed! I enjoyed this little gem of a place-and easy parking even every time(which is important to me when I go to SF and have a suv to park!).
author: EllenMarie S.

description: Very good food, portions are big enough to share. The rice and tea are a bit more expensive than in other restaurants, I must be use to the rice being included with the meal.
author: Krystal A.

description:
This is the first place I tried Burmese food, overall it was a great food and great experience.

I've eaten hear twice and loved it both times. The salad there is good, i forgot what it's called but they bring it to your table and mix it for you, with flare too. Of course the mandalay chickens real good, basil garlic anything is good. The servers there are really nice and courteous. Even the owner, I believe helped served us when the servers were backed up, that kind of relationship with your customer is rare.

TWO THUMBS UP!
author: Tam T.

description: My first time having Burmese this place was good very comfy and cute as well as a friendly staff.  I've also realized I prefer Thai :)  I had the pumpkin Curry though it was good I felt like it was less sweet than when I have had it at Thai restaurants, My friends vegetarian dish was very good though.  Definitely recommend though was great restaurant.
author: Nirea S.

description:
The staffs are always friendly and courteous, 
no matter how crowded they are.

I absolutely LOVE their rainbow chicken, 12 ingredient salad, and coconut rice! 

Most of the dishes that I had there were pretty good : )
I would recommend it to my friends in a heartbeat!
author: Sunny S.

description:
After trekking it all the way out to the Richmond for what we thought was going to be a delicious Cambodian meal, we found out out destination had closed two month earlier, so we instantly whipped out yelp to find something nearby that we'd enjoy. After much arguing over not much of anything, we settled on Burmese food and headed over to burma superstar. But wait, this review is about Mandalay. BS had about a 1.5 hour wait, and we were not about to stand in billowing fog for that long on an empty stomach, so we walked the three blocks over to Mandalay, which  will happily inform you that they were the first Burmese restaurant in the city. We were seated within 10 minutes and were please with the number of vegetarian options and delicious drinks.

I ordered the coconut tapioca drink to start with, which in retrospect, may not have been the greatest idea. If was definitely delicious, beyond delicious even... but should have come with a warning label **dessert. 

We'd heard their tea leaf salad was divine, but ended up getting the veggie version of the ginger salad, which was great if you like ginger, and I mean really like ginger. I ate 75% of mine before succumbing. Along with the salad we also had the onion pancake appetizer with it;s magic and delicious sauce. There is nothing better than a god onion pancake with delicious sauce. 

For main course the four of us ordered three dishes, the tofu with broccoli and walnuts, Mandalay noodle w/ tofu, and some spicy tofu. It was the perfect amount for the four of us, my favorite was definitely the tofu with broccoli and walnuts, my leave favorite was probably the noodle, but only because I was already full when it arrived, and it again had more ginger in it than I'm accustomed to ingesting. all in all though, it was a very successful meal, I would definitely come back again.

The only thing I would like to see change about this place is their Happy Birthday ritual. There were three of them in the course of our dinner, and they just blast the music for it, and it becomes annoying the third time around.
author: Allyson S.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to this place after wanting to try something new and we had already been to Burma SuperStar.

The atmosphere was very welcoming and good ambiance.  The waiters service was very attentive, almost too much.  But they were very nice.

Food was phenominal.  They had the perfect mix between burmese and mandarin.  Mango beef was delicious.  Try the fried banana with ice cream dessert.
author: Eric R.

description:
5 stars for Mandalay! 

So, the bff of my BF invited us to dinner in SF. We told him we love hole-in-the-wall places, and he surprised us with a trip to Mandalay on California Street. The BF and I had never tried Burmese, nor would we have thought of going to such a restaurant of some sort. Needless to say, we were blown away by the food. 

From the outside, Mandalay looks like one of those dirty restaurants where the grout looks like some kind of moldy black. Not this one. Upon walking in, it is brightly lit inside from the big front window that welcomes passersby. As you make a quick left, you suddenly realize just how popular this restaurant really is...the floor was packed. Every table was full. It looked as if one table was having dinner with the table to the right and left of them.  The authentic decor of the restaurant was such an inviting feeling and gave me an excited feeling that I could not wait to try the food. 

Upon sitting down, you are quickly greeted by your server, or at least one of them. Ordering water and after looking through the menu, we ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, the Coconut Chicken Soup, the Mango Chicken, and the Mandalay Special Noodle along with brown rice and saffron rice. 

The Tea Leaf Salad looks..interesting. As one of your servers lays the plate on the table, you look at it wondering "How do I eat this?" The server politely names each of the ingredients, asks if you'd like the lemon squeezed onto the salad, and tosses all the ingredients together.
