The salad, consisting of ingredients such as peanuts, roasted garlic, green tea leaves, and chickpea among others, is amazingly delicious. You could taste every ingredient in every bite you take, and the spritz of lemon was perfect with the salad. 

The Coconut Chicken Soup was even better than the salad. Who would have thought that lemon spritzed in a coconut soup with cilantro would be out-of-this-world delicious. I wish I could thoroughly explain the deliciousness of this dish, but you just have to try it yourself. On a scale of 1 to 10, I give the soup a 20. Oh, how it was unforgettable. 

Onto the Mango Chicken and the Mandalay Special Noodle dishes. Both dishes were delicious, but not quite up to par with either the soup or salad. The Mango Chicken is exactly what it is..mango and chicken stir-fried together with a sweet sauce with a little bit of tang. The Mandalay Special Noodle was a nice dish. Having the same taste as the Coconut Soup mixed in with the chow-fun like noodles, which I absolutely love, it was a nice noodle dish. 

All in all, our visit to Mandalay will never be forgotten. I can't wait to come back and have the soup and salad again. Absolutely delicious.
author: Clarissa C.

description: I love this place. I always order the Mandalay Special Noodles and they are delicious! The waitstaff is generally very friendly. I only had one awkward encounter in which a member of the the staff told me I couldn't add broccoli to my order, (which I have done dozens of times before without any trouble). Eventually, I was able order with success, but not without a lengthy conversation with him. Other than that one weird experience, I have had many delicious meals here and would and have come back many times.
author: Mimi N.

description:
If you don't read the rest of my review just read this part:

Sat down with a group of 9 so we all planned to share and order the following:

Samusa (with Chicken or Vegetarian) [made in 4's]
Tea Leaf Salad (Lap Pat Dok)
Mandalay Special Noodle 
Combination Fried Rice
Rainbow Chicken
Burmese Style Curry Chicken
& Prawns (i think it was the garlic ones)
+ got complimentary sweet potato dessert on the house

&GOT CHARGED DOUBLE FOR DISHES. 

Not cool! We didnt know that our waiter was multiplying twice for every dish we ordered simply because we wanted to share.  Other than the fiasco at the end, it was such a great first experience with Burmese food.

Service was really up to par at the beginning till the waiter asked if we were ready to order and then walked away to forget about us for a good 15minutes till we flagged him down again. 

Some of the group members ordered the Burmese Iced Tea (reminds me of Thai Tea, but just ask for Burmese Iced Tea). Also, tried their Ginger Tea Lemonade which is surprisingly refreshing!

Would order the Special Noodles again in a heartbeat. Everything was really GOOD. Hopefully the servings are up to par because when they "doubled" the dishes, it honestly looked like one serving.
author: Anne T.

description:
Sumptuous, expertly prepared Burmese food, served by gracious ladies in elegant national dress, flowing sweetly across a dining room which is - nearly always - busy but not rushed.  

Upon entering... a big golden Buddha greets you, surrounded with orchids and candles - oh yes ,and a slightly Hollywood lighted "palm tree" that manages to look pretty, not cheesy.  

It's a lovely room with good lighting, nicely spaced tables with good chairs.  There is pretty decor everywhere and usually a smile on the face of your server.  Right away you think "relaaaaaaaaaaaaaaax."  :)  Ok, now I'm ready to eat!

I've been a fan of Mandalay since childhood - driving clear across town as soon as I got my license for their sticky coconut rice, curries and samosas.  Oh heaven... Nothing has changed, except that now I work close by and can come more often.

I've only twice tried Burma Superstar on Clement - the erstwhile rival.  Superstar food was good, but the "dining experience" as such was insanely rushed - I felt like I was cramming aboard some train leaving town in a hurry (escaping a war torn country maybe...).   Lots of clamoring - lots of people squeezed into a tight space, trying hard to look cool about waiting an hour for the crammed table.  Why on earth would a sane person tolerate that when the other choice, the quieter choice, is so close by and so good?

Flash back to Mandalay.  Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh.  Some more tea?  A bowl of the best Southeast Asian fish soup in existence?  Cold beer?  Noodles, lovely.  And samosas crispy enough to cry over.  

Nothing out of place or rushed.  Details matter here.  And I've never seen a scowl on the face of any one of those lovely women, or the patrons they serve.

Geez, I wonder if wearing a sarong actually MAKES you nicer???  I nod in quiet thanks to Buddha on my way out the door...  His favor is shining on Mandalay.
author: Juliana C.

description: Exotic & lip smacking food .. Great ambience ... Tea leaf salad is just super delicious!!
author: Rinkon P.

description: So I have been to both Bstar and Burma Superstar and I can't say which of these is better! I think that Mandalay is the more "authentic" Burmese restaurant of the 3 of them. The food was really good. we had the curry chicken and the #2 on the noddle page. I highly recommend the noddles there. As we sat down I was drooling of everyone else noddles too! Its family style so be prepared to share. They don't have a full bar but they do have wine/beer (reasonably priced). The staff was nice and I would def recommend going to a friend! (actually I already did!)
author: Quel H.

description: Way better and authentic than Burma Superstar. Burma is fine but Mandalay is way better. The House Noodles are to die for!
author: Ang P.

description:
I LOOOOOVED this place!

Five of my friends and myself walked in on a Sunday night and only had to wait about five minutes before being seated. While we were waiting the hostess was very sweet and also offered us menus to browse through. 

When we were seated we were offered drinks right away and they suggested some of the house specials like their iced tea or their ginger lemonade. The lemonade was so good, nice and refreshing. the iced teas were just like Thai iced teas (which I also love). 

This being my first time eating Burmese food I was a little overwhelmed by the menu but we ordered chicken samosas to share as well as some pot stickers since we were all starving. The samosas were tasty- especially the dipping sauce that came with them! The pot stickers were mediocre but they were made with the thicker dough that I'm not crazy about which is why. 

We then all ordered and I had the pineapple and mango chicken with veggies (not sure what the exact name was) but oh my gosh it was SO good! I wish there had been more pineapple actually because surprisingly it was so good with chicken, something I hadn't expected.  I also had a side of coconut rice (which I really need to figure out how to make because I'm totally obsessed with it!) and I was going to share a hot and sour soup with my friend but when it came out it was much smaller than we expected so I just had a few bites. It's definitely the best hot and sour soup I've had in the city- can't really explain what it was but it was so, sooo good! Glad I know now where to go for some comfort soup. 

Besides the great food the service here was excellent. The staff was friendly and attentive without being overbearing, the atmosphere was amazing as well. We didn't feel cramped and the restaurant is beautiful on the inside. 

Overall this is probably one of my favorite places in my neighborhood and I can't wait to go back and try more- especially the chicken noodle soup!
author: Suzanne D.

description:
A great place for Burmese food. We came here for dinner on a Friday night with very little trouble finding parking (might have been luck). The wait in line was tolerable, although had we arrived 30 minutes later we would have been waiting a lot longer as the crowd started growing. 

We ordered the Samosa appetizer, which was ok but not the best. We then shared the Lychee Prawns (a special on the menu) and the Mongolian Beef. Not really a fan of the Lychee Prawns, but the beef was exceptional with great flavor. Absolutely loved it. Service was good, except towards the end of the dinner service when it got a lot busier. 

Overall, I would highly recommend this place over the "other" Burmese restaurant a few blocks down.

The Good: Great food, great value
The Bad: Depending on what time you arrive, the wait can be long
author: Yan W.

description: For vegetarians, tastiest dish so far is the tofu and string beans-make sure to stress vegetarian/no shrimp paste.  So yummy! A must try for all!
author: Lucky P.

description:
I had never tried Burmese food in the past, but Mandalay was a great introduction to the tasty Burmese cuisine.

I'll start off by saying that the place has a lovely look to it, it was clean and nicely decorated, and the staff was helpful and friendly.

My friend and I shared the chicken samusa appetizer, the spicy curry beef with the Balada (crispy pancake), and the Mango chicken with saffron rice.

Both of us really enjoyed the samusas, they were 4 little fried pockets of chicken and potatoes, and they tasted great with the two different hot sauces that we were provided.

(sidenote:I loooove hot sauce, and if you do, this place doesnt dissapoint.)

First dish we recieved was the curry beef with the crispy pancake. The beef was good, not amazing. It could have used a bit more flavor. I enjoyed it more with some of the hot sauce on it, it became a lot tastier. On the other hand, the crispy pancake was AMAZING. It complemented everything so well. If you dine here you gotta ask for it, you're going to love it.

The mango chicken was very tasty, had a nice crispiness to it, and it had just the right hint of spice in the form of some small green peppers amid all the chicken and mangoes, which created a nice sweet and spicy combination. As for the saffron rice, I personally disliked it. My friend said he was okay with it. I just didnt find much flavor to it, it had a very dull, pepper-like quality to it, lacking something to brighten it  up. I did just mix it with the wonderful hot sauce and then it was good :)

We mostly put the chicken or the beef on top of the crispy pancake and added hot sauce and rice or potatoes on top of it and ate the food like that. It was all very delicious, and very filing.

Also, the prices were pretty decent. We bot came out full at about 25 each. Not too bad.
author: Ricardo A.

description: Incredible. One of my top 5 favorite restaurants. I don't know where you can get food that tastes anything like what they have to offer. Try the rainbow salad and the Mandalay special noodle with chicken. If you like lassi's, their mango lassi cannot be beat. Sometimes you may have to wait in line to get in, but it is worth the wait. Reasonable prices, too!
author: Conrad S.

description: Food here was pretty good. The service and staff were friendly. The line isn't as long as Burma superstar which is a great thing. Everyone has to definitely try this place out.
author: Anthony V.

description:
One of my all time favorite places to eat!! Though I haven't tried a lot of the food here, I HIGHLY recommend the Mandalay Special Noodles (I get them with chicken), which is tied for first place (along with the Pad Woon Sen from Silver Spoon) for my favorite dish EVER. My friends and family that I've brought here have always enjoyed each and every dish they've gotten.
The service here is extremely friendly, knowledgable, and usually fast, though if you come in the evening on a weekend, be prepared for at least a half hour wait for a table, because the place is always PACKED.
It's pretty hard to find parking at night here, so I usually order my food to-go, so I can double park and run in and get it, or take the bus.
author: Erika B.

description: The food at this restaurant is fantastic!  The prices are right, the service is wonderful and friendly.  Sometimes you may have to wait to get seated at prime times but it is absolutely worth the wait.  Delicious!!!
author: Mr And Mrs Helene And Tyrone D.

description:
can't get into Burma?  come here...  just as good and i actually like the tea leaf salad better here.  blasphemy you say?  well kiss my ass....ITS BETTER!

staff is super nice....
author: Colin L.

description:
Oh, Mandalay. My love for you is unending, my devotion unswerving. 

As much as I hate to reveal this neighborhood secret to the silly people waiting in a two-hour line at Burma Superstar, I just have to give this family-run restaurant the accolades it so richly deserves. 

The service here is friendly if a little slow at times. The food is very good across the board with spots of perfection here and there. The samosas and tea leaf salad are absolutely delicious. Unlike at Burma Superstar, the tea leaf salad doesn't include lettuce, just all of the good stuff and no unnecessary filler. Yum. The Mandalay beef is incredible, and the coconut rice... oh the coconut rice... I could live off of that rice, and I'm not much of a rice person in general. Also try the ginger lemonade. Sweet and very refreshing.
author: Lindsey H.

description: SOOOOOOOOOO good. Run don't walk to order the tea leaf salad and mango chicken with coconut rice. super hungry writing this. Mango chicken with jalapenos. are you kidding me? Why would you go to Burma Super Star? Good portions, easy to get in. Gets busy around 7pm though. Fast service. dessert is good too. yum. :)
author: Bing B.

description: I would definitely come here again. And its way better than Burma SuperStar. The decor is really overwhelming and transports you somewhere exotic, it was super crowded when we went but we got a table within 15 minutes. THe menu is full of interesting things. We ordered a smoked tea-leaf duck dish that was very suprising in its stacked almost french-style presentation. THe duck was really good, but our dish was maybe a little too sweet with the mango sauce and pumpkin puree, but it was still a vey exciting meal. THe menu is so endless, you could have many memorable meals here.
author: Adam G.

description:
As I type, I am in a very happy food coma from tonight's meal at Mandalay. I had my first foray into Burmese food about three months ago at Burma Superstar, just a few blocks away from Mandalay. It was great, but when a friend found out that I liked it, she insisted that I had to try Mandalay because it was better food without the hours of waiting that you get at Burma Superstar. She was so right...

Although just a block off Clement Street, the restaurant is located in a pretty quiet area and I think you have to know about this place to go there or be very fortunate to stumble upon it, which might explain why Burma Superstar gets more attention (location, location, location). We arrived around 8:45 PM on a Tuesday and the place was about a third of the way full; the servers were genuinely friendly and attentive during our entire meal. When our server found out it was our first time there, he dove into a spiel about how this is the first Burmese restaurant in S.F., established in 1984. He continued on, in the same breath, about all the different drink options they have and explained the menu. It was comical and reminded me of a Mexican place I went to in LA where the waiters recite the menu to you and say the exact same script over and over every time. 

My friend and I split the Burmese fried pancake with curry sauce to start with, which was like fried naan and extremely delicious, albeit a bit oily (but I'm not a fried food fan so take that comment with a grain of salt). The Mandalay Special Noodle dish I got was even better; they mix the egg noodles in front of you with chicken coconut curry, fresh squeezed lemon, cilantro, fried onions, etc. which adds a nice touch to the meal. 

Too full for dessert, we got the check and escaped with a very tiny bill: $24 (not including tip) for an appetizer and two entrees. On our way out the door, my friend turned to me and asked if I liked Mandalay or Burma Superstar better. Food wise, I couldn't really say, because I loved both and had enough time between to not be able to compare. My friend said that although she preferred the spices of Burma Superstar better, Mandalay's food was less oily and she preferred the lack of a wait at Mandalay. I agree and to further that, want to put out there - why wait hours for Burma Superstar or B-Star when you could go here?
author: Kara A.

description:
I'm going to let you in on a little secret... You don't have to wait hours and brave long lines to get good Burmese food in EssEff. Mandalay is better than Burma Superstar. 

While their styles are a little different, you'll have a much better dining experience at Mandalay. More parking. Rarely the lines you see at Burma. Bigger dining room = more tables = less crowded = better service = you don't feel like you're rushed because there are 372 other people waiting to get in = a better dining experience. So what if you trade off a little bit of better tasting food for dining in comfort? It's still good. Totally worth it! 

Last time I was able to make friends with the 4 year old cutie at the table next to ours, trade toddler experiences with her parents, and enjoy a lovely meal with friends. 

That my friends, is not possible at Burma.
author: Kevo M.

description:
I didn't know what to expect from this very nice restaurant as I've never been to a Burmese restaurant. I have to say the food and service was really good. We ordered the prix fixe dinner which was only about $20 each for two and the food just kept on coming and coming. I don't usually go for the dessert but it was included and I was blown away by it. Fried banana fritter and ice cream really topped off the meal I really liked the Tea Leaf salad and the Mandalay Beef but really all of the dishes were great. 

We had been on a bike ride earlier and didn't want to leave our bikes on the car rack outside so the owner allowed us to bring our bikes inside and store them behind the waiting chairs next to the podium at the front of the house. A very nice gesture indeed. 

Highly recommended.
author: Daniel D.

description:
mmm I love this place.... I want to go back!  The first time I checked this place out was bout 3 years ago.  The waitresses never seem to write down my order but they get it right every time! (How do they do that????)

The food is always amazing. My favorite is the pumpkin curry.  

They are always super friendly and I say more than half the time they give me dessert on the house! 

I can not rave enough bout this place.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Delicious, delicious, delicious.

I got here with the roving hoard of wasted Yelper's and it was as if Wolverine, the Tasmanian Devil, and a coked-up squad of Viking berzerkers smashed into a Shaolin Temple of psychic Tai-chi masters who could seriously cook.

Within 10 minutes our madness had been seated, calmed down, given drinks, and settled in - an act of madness-bleeding I haven't seen since my stay in the booby hatch back in the 90's.

Our two tables babbled their incoherent orders.

"blah blah tea bamboo bok ting please!"
"ginger flap flok tampingo over here"
"bowls of chewed gum flamingos for everyone, thanks"
"want chicken. want chicken.  want chicken. bokbok chicken."

Thankfully we had John T (?) with us at our table, and he ordered for everyone.

Every single dish that came my first thought was, "awww I'm not going to like that..." and my second thought, post first-bite, was, "I'm not sure if my pants have fallen off again or not, but this sure feels like sex to me."

Delicious, delicious, delicious.
author: Matt H.

description: We got there a our 5:30 and got seated right away. An hour later it was filled. I don't have a lot of experience with Burmese food but everything was good.  We had samusas, mango salad, a special spicy fish dish and Burmese fried rice. Next time I will try the tea leaf salad and noodles. Lots of Burmese people here.
author: Bob R.

description: I really like this place! The honey coconut walnut shrimp is delicous. I have tried many items on the menu, and most have been really delicious with variety of tastes. Definetly will come back.
author: Sepas K.

description:
Do you ever have those moments when you really, truly consider that food is better than sex?

If not better than sex, at least equally as good as...

Do you?

I have those moments often.  As in: a lot.  I have those moments a lot.

This might have something to do with the fact that I have food far more often than I have mind blowing sex these days.

Don't pity me.  It's fine.  Me and my grrl Rosie can take care of those needs just fine.  Just fine.

BUT I DIGRESS.

Food.  Better than sex.  Often.

Last night... oh, geeze... it was mind blowing... last night I had me some really good, hot, mouth watering... Burmese food.

Delicacy after delicacy - they just kept coming.... Tea leaf salad... Coconut chicken soup... Samosas... Those were just foreplay for the main courses... Walnut prawns in my mouth... Mandalay chicken... Pea shoots... So tasty, so hot... so... so... aaahhhhhh....

I'm sorry, I'm blushing just thinking of it.

I have to say that this might be the first time that I have ever given a restaurant five stars solely on the basis of how orgasmic the food was.

Yelpers, have no doubt that I will be coming back to Mandalay... coming again and again and again and again...

Mmmmm...
author: Kate R.

description: This was the first time I tried burmese food and I have to say Im a fan! I didnt really know what to expect but the flavors and different types of food they offer was pretty fab! If you are looking to try a new place or try a new type of food, Mandalay is the place to come!
author: Natasha I.

description:
One of the great things about living in my neighborhood is that I can walk 20 minutes in any direction from my house and fulfill pretty much all my needs. Burger? Bar Johnny. Cocktail? Rye.Tranny hooker? Larkin Street after midnight (so I've heard) It takes a lot to get me to leave my little bubble - hell, I considered dating a girl in Emeryville to be a long distance relationship. The food at Mandalay? Worth the trek.

An order of Samusa and Balada started the meal off right. Next came the Pumpkin Curry served in a hollowed out pumpkin. Cute and tasty!
My favorite dish of the night was the Mandalay Special Noodle which arrived at the table looking like a mini salad bar until our waitress whipped it all together to form one big pile of love. Wash the whole meal down with a couple of Singhas and I was a very happy boy.

Service was uber-friendly and we were even presented with free dessert. And in case you haven't found this review FUC worthy yet, here's a good reason to mark this review useful: unlike Burma Superstar, Mandalay accepts reservations. 

Oh Mandalay, you are like the Friend with Benefits that I've lacked for so long...please don't tell Nob Hill that I'm cheating on her.
author: phil h.

description:
I stopped in here because I was hungry and didn't want to put my name on the long ass wait list at Burma Superstar. Although we were seated immediately it took a while for someone to come around and take our order. Our two appetizers dribbled out at different times then we had to wait for twenty minutes for our entree to come. Meanwhile we had to watch as the three tables that came in after us all got their food in rapid succession. Believe me, the irony of coming here to avoid the wait at Burma Superstar was not lost on me.

When our entree came out (the Burmese Special noodles) it had like five ingredients in it. Whaaaa??? Did I mention that I was hungry? Now I consider myself to be a fairly levelheaded person but if you fuck with my food when I'm hungry, you sir, are an asshole. Sure it was pretty good but not I'd-wait-twenty-minutes-while-I watch-everybody-else-get-their-shit-then-when-it-finally-arrives-it's-CRAZY-FUCKING-SIMPLE-good.

It's times like these that I should have listened to the little voice in my head. Yeah, little voice, you were right again, I SHOULD have gotten a fucking burrito.
author: Josua P.

description:
Yummy Burmese food at a friendly price, friendly service, really interesting tea leaf salad and Mandalay Special Noodles, definitely a cuisine to experience. The roti, more of an Indian dish I believe, was delicious too.
We were comped one dessert that we would not have dared to order, some kind of paste (sorry forgot the name), but we would order it next time, smart of them!
author: Frederic P.

description:
Burma Superstar, I am dumping you. Yes, thats right. You and I are through. Why, you ask? Well, let me tell you! 

You have changed as you have become more popular. For some time now you have left me sitting in a bar for hours on end, right across the street from your house no less, waiting for you to call. You then have the nerve to make yourself seem like a hero for giving me that "special" call that you will let me see you. 

Then, once I arrive, you rush me through an hour of your precious time and kick me to the curb so you can see someone else, who is entering before I have even left. 

To top it off (and I don't care if this offends you because it is the truth) you are too small. Yes, thats right, I said it. Oh, and you are not that attractive either. 

I don't know how to say this, but I have found someone new. Don't get me wrong. We had some good times together and I will hold on to those memories. You helped me through a time when I needed good Burmese food and I will always be grateful for that.

I think I just forgot over the years what it was like to be treated better until I met Mandalay. Mandalay is MUCH bigger, doesn't make me wait around, is more stylish and tastes better. So, yes, I am leaving you for Mandalay. 

Sorry.......well, not really.
author: Drue C.

description:
Went again last week with a friend and it was just as good as the first time. That saffron rice is something to get agro over. If they did it with brown rice it would kick ass.

We had the walnut broccoli and the intoxicatingly delicious mango salad again. I'm so glad they actually make things spicy here! This time we ordered desert - a totally sublime, completely southeast asian fruity blend floating in coconut milk with tapioca, like a rich ice cold fruit soup. They really went over the top by putting a blob of ice cream in it!
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
What a find! We intended to do Burma Super Star but were discouraged by the 2-hr wait. Somebody in line mentioned this place so decided to take a chance. 

We got all the staples, including the Mango Chicken which is  pan-fried chicken sauteed with fresh mango, onions, and green chili.

I highly recommend the coconut rice, Mango Chicken
and Rangoon Beef!!

After finishing a great meal, we headed home on  the 1 bus. Half way home I get a call from Berma telling us our table was ready. They called two hours too late.
author: johanna a.

description:
Buuuuuurrrrrmmmeeeessseeee!!!! Man, I love this Yelp thang! First it was Thai,  a little Ethiopian, then Vietnamese, true Chinese and all the other ESE of the world...now Burmese? One of my fav Yelpers (I'd tell you her name but she has a stalker and I don't want YOU stalker to know we are friends because I wish a motha F**Ka would stalk me) decided that instead of  PHO (pronounced FO like Fo'sho...jk unless you are Black because we get away with saying whatever the F*** we want... right nephew?) she wanted to introduce my taste buds to Burmese! OOOOoohhh no, not chopsticks again!

For starters, she orders the tea leaf salad and catfish soup... ok Jamal pick a dish. How do I top that? I don't know what to order but I know you can't go wrong with Chicken! Hmmmm... so I don't look too retarded in front of the waiter I order the Rangoon Chicken (looking like I know what I'm doing... but don't) sounds good and it's not made with curry, so that should be fine. I know that pick was a winner, since they were sold out! Next, green beans with pork... sooooouuuullllll foooood in Burmese? Holler! My stalking-magnet-friend ordered coconut rice, to which she  cussed me out for adding lemon to the rice. What? They didn't have bbq sauce!
All I know is you best have an appetite when eating with Stalkaholic because she will keep feeding you and feeding you and feeding you. The food was so good I gave the waitress two thumbs up. *Shaking head* yes, that's the white in me. ;0)

The highlight of my night was when Bella (oops) traded in her chopsticks for a fork to eat her rice with!  Brrahahahahaha... "Usually the rice is in a bowl"  Shhuuutt it!!  Bruce Lee doesn't make excuses... Bruce Lee doesn't need a bowl to eat his rice with. Bruce Lee just adds Wa-------- you know how it goes!
author: Jamal G.

description: Everything here is amazing!!! Mandalay chicken, Rangoon Beef, Burmese Lamb Curry and Mango Prawns...I'm stuffed!!!
author: Meli B.

description:
9:35: The waitress emerges from the back to announce that we should very quickly order anything else we want, as the kitchen closes at 9:30.  I glance at her, then at my watch, then back at her again with one eyebrow cocked.  She slips me a knowing smile.  I knew we chose the right place to eat.

The service is impeccable at Mandalay.  The staff treats you like honored guests at their restaurant

It's a perfect mate to the phenomenal Burmese food they cook up.

I've had both delivery and dine in experiences with Mandalay now.  Even the mere thought of leftover Tea Leaf Salad makes my mouth water as I write this review.  Each and every dish I have ever sampled delighted me.

Simply scrumptious.
author: Christopher K.

description:
(Part 2 of 2 - Inner Richmond Burmese Eats)

My original review of Mandalay started with about 4 paragraphs of slamming Burma Superstar & their ridiculous wait times. I felt it was better directed as a review of their establishment entirely. 

So, let's talk Mandalay!

I have visited Mandalay on a number of occasions, and they have yet to dissapoint me. My first experience was with my girlfriend at the time, and we both felt like we were part of some secret club that not only knew there was another Burmese spot a few blocks from the so-called 'Star', but also because we now knew that a real Tea Leaf Salad doesn't come with lettuce--at all.

The restaurant itself is bigger, and you will rarely wait for a table. Last night my dinner plans were at 7pm, my dining companions arrived at 6:45 & immediately got a table. How cool is that?!? I arrived at 5 until 7pm, and their 'better than Burma Superstar' tea leaf salad had just arrived. There was tea waiting for me on the table, and water was served soon thereafter.

The servers at this restaurant are totally down-to-earth, don't have some weird sense of entitlement to rush you through your meal because 'they can'. The staff at Mandalay understands dining & that people like to enjoy themselves and savor the flavors of their meal. 

After our salad, they allowed us to chat for a few minutes & then were back at the table to take our dinner order.

---

We had:

Kaw Soi Dok -- Egg noodles touted with fried onion, fried garlic chips, cucumber slices, grounded split beans and chef's delicious dressing.

Mandalay Beef - Fried beef slices sauted with garlic and chef's delicious hot sauce

Mandalay Special - (I've sworn off not to tell anyone what it is, you'll have to check it out yourself) It's suuuuuper yummy, probably their standout dish.

We finished at the oldest Burmese joint in SF sharing a Green Tea Ice Cream--perfect way to end a nice dinner.

---

Mandalay hits a HOMERUN-- it's the classic Hank Aaron to the Barry Bonds superstar hype.
author: matt m.

description:
I can't believe I haven't yelped this place...although I noticed some of my yelp friends have given this place less than 3 stars, I've been here a few times and really enjoyed myself.  The food is reasonably priced and there is a pretty decent selection of food on the menu.  There are vegetarian options for those that don't do meat but not too much in regard to vegan fare.  I've been there enough times to say that I actually enjoy the food and the service.  

If I recall correctly, we definitely had the samusas and Nan Gyi Dok, which is a Burmese rice noodle with spiced coconut chicken, split yellow pea, powder, and fried onion dish.  Deelish!  Seriously, it's a great alternative if Burma Star is just too much of a headache and it's on a side of California Street that's nice and quiet.  Definitely pay this place a visit.  The times I've been, again, I was delighted by the service and the food!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
I realize I'm the umpteenth Yelper to let the cat out of the bag, but I gotta give Mandalay props. The food was orgasmicallly good, and that's not just my drunk palate talking. 

First, they treated us like kings. Any other establishment that saw an army of 20 drunk Yelpers (is there any other kind?) headed toward its premises, would have immediately shut the lights, locked its doors, and pretended to be closed. Mandalay hospitably opened its doors, its kitchen, and its heart to us. They fed us plate after heaping plate of Burmese (or Myanmar-ese?) delectibles including Rainbow Salad, Samosas, Walnut Chicken, Manna-from-Heaven Soup, and Lemon Chicken. We may as well have been Donald Trump at the Ritz-Carlton for the courtesy and customer service they showed us -- cooking up a gourmet feast, spoon-feeding us, pouring us more sake shots that we obviously didn't need. God, I love enablers.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
Excellent Burmese food with a shorter wait than Burma Superstar and while being even cheaper than B.Star. We usually head to B.Star to avoid the hullabaloo at Burma Superstar, but had been meaning to give Mandalay a try for a while now. It was a very pleasant surprise. 

We had the chicken samusas to start. They were quite good, I particularly enjoyed the dipping sauce. It tasted something like a light mild hot sauce. For our main course, I had the Mandalay Special Noodle and my girlfriend had the Thai-style eggplant dish (I forget the name). Her dish was good, but nothing terribly special. My noodles, however, were quite excellent with lots of interesting flavors and a nice mix of crunchy and noodley. I had intended to take some home, but I ended up eating the entire plate.
author: Michael H.

description:
So.

Effing.

DELICIOUS!

I tried a few dishes... Rainbow Salad, a soup whose name I cannot for the life of me recall, the Rainbow Chicken, and the Okra Prawns... beautifully blended flavors, delicious fresh ingredients, and overall atmosphere would normally result in a four-star review... HOWEVER, Mandalay DEFINITELY deserves that oh-so-special fifth star for making OKRA appealing...

... and for accommodating a VERY large group of Yelpers (of which I was not a part) at nearly closing time.
author: Elle Q.

description:
Mandalay is simply one of my favorite restaurant in San Francisco! 

All the dishes are excellent (particularly the cat fish soup and the Mandalay noodles), the owners are super nice and you don't have to wait for ever to get a table. Check it out!
author: Isabelle G.

description:
Hands down. 5 stars. Ask any of our regular crew where we're likely to stumble, a dozen or so deep, after an early evening start at 540 Club and we're likely to slur, "Mandalaaaay". These gracious, charming folks have accommodated our belligerent band of party people on a moment's notice time and time again, and always with a smile. They have helped us celebrate special occasions, such as birthdays, and always with style and poise. They let us bring in 3 dozen cupcakes for Kate K's birthday and kept them in their own refrigerator without charging us. That ROCKS.

Fortunately for us, we have Amir A, a 5-star human navigation tool when it comes to the fine art of selecting Burmese for 12-20 hungry drunks with appetites for destruction. His tool is so refined, it functions perfectly even when altered by excessive alcohol consumption. Some of my favorite choices include Tea leaf salad, samusas (yes, samUsas), Pumpkin curry with chicken (served IN a hollowed pumpkin), and chicken satay. Other things my associates appear to enjoy include crispy whole chicken, string beans with tofu, and the Special Noodles. Also, there is a prawn dish crusted with coconut and walnuts that looks so good I'm almost willing to endure anaphlactic shock to taste one bite of that allergic-reaction inducing goodness.

There can be a long wait on weekend nights, not sure about weekdays. Make a reservation if you have a large group and whatever you do, try to refrain from walking in yelling, "My bajingo's on fire"!!!!!!!!!
author: Autumn K.

description:
I have never been to Burma Superstar. (I heard that shriek, Kristina!) Yes, yes, I know what you're all thinking, What kind of Yelper does she think she is?! A place with 4 stars based on 508 reviews, I know that I've been missing out. I've heard how fabulous the food is there but when I can't make reservations for a place and I know there's going to be a long ass wait, I just can't bring myself to going there. Sorry!

So I can't compare Mandalay to Burma Superstar, but from what I experienced, Mandalay was really really good. I got our party of 4 reservations quite easily. We were seated right away and served promptly. The servers were all very friendly and patiently pointed out all the ingredients in our dishes before mixing them up at our table. It was all very interesting and extremely delicious. I had yellow pea powder for the first time. Yes, it doesn't sound very appetizing, but it was definitely a key ingredient in making the salad and noodle dish so flavorful. 

We had the balada, rainbow salad, tea leaf salad, shredded chicken with garlic, Mandalay noodles (Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken), and dry fried string beans with tofu. All the dishes were delicious and the amount of food was perfect for 4 petite ladies. 

I really enjoyed my first Burmese dining experience, even though it wasn't at Burma Superstar. I was very pleased with everything about Mandalay, especially that we didn't have to wait for anything. Mandalay gets 4 super stars from me!
author: Connie C.

description:
Um, so this is review #263 for Mandalay...let's get this out of the way: No, you don't have to wait 3 hours for a table like at Burma Superstar. Yes, it is a satisfying place to experience Burmese cuisine. But the bottom line is that the flavors and textures don't pop out to me as much as at BS. It stops just short of being great authentic, homecooked quality (more Yamo's thing) and doesn't quite make it to the sophistication of BS.

The nitty gritty (+ my little anecdote):

Tea Leaf Salad: judging from my experiences at Burma Superstar, Mandalay, and Yamo and trying a store-bought tea leaf salad mix I'd say this version is probably the most boring but more authentic than BS. It's probably my least favorite out of all of them. Overall, the flavors are not as bright as at BS. The tea leaves are not as pungent, you should definitely ask for some lemon, and it doesn't come with lettuce. Not to say that the salad is bad, but...BS wins on this one.

Many of the other dishes similarly lack the explosion of flavors that I have come to love at BS...Curry chicken, Catfish chowder, Mandalay Special Noodles...good, but lack that X factor. 

What makes Mandalay's menu standout is what is most arguably their most authentic dish, the Burmese style sour vegetables. This exchange with the waiter solidified their authenticity:

Steph: We'll have the Burmese style sour vegetables. Are they really authentic? What does it taste like? 

Waiter: Uh...[has look of concern on his face and points to menu] how about the walnut prawns?

Steph: No, we want to try the Burmese style sour vegetables.

Waiter: People like the mango chicken.

Steph: Why does it seem like you don't want us to order the sour vegetables?

Waiter: Because some people don't like the fermented taste.

Steph: [in a defiant voice]] We DEFINITELY want the Burmese sour vegetables!

Don't EVER tell me that I wouldn't like the taste of something because I swear I will stop at nothing to prove you wrong. Well, maybe not babies or bittermelon.
author: Steph P.

description:
Another Burma Superstar vs Mandalay review:

I like both, but I think they're geared for different crowds. Burma Superstar is small and intimate dining in a beautifully appointed room. Its careful presentation and moderate portions appeal to foodies. It's good for a date or impressing out-of-town folks. It's popular with good-looking young people who dress fashionably.

Mandalay is more casual and can better accomodate large groups. Food is great, but doesn't match the elegant touches of Burma Superstar. However, Mandalay has quicker and better service, bigger portions for sharing, bigger menu selection, room to move, and they deliver. It's good for a night out with friends. It's popular with neighborhood folks and families who are dressed down.

My personal preference is for a comfortable neighborhood joint. Burma Superstar may have better food, but Mandalay is the better restaurant.
author: Stacy J.

description: The mango chicken was great.  I am not sure if we were given plain rice instead of coconut rice but it did not taste like coconut rice( and we were told it was).  Service was fast and friendly.  If you enjoy burmese food this place is definitely worth trying.
author: Fara P.

description:
Mmmmm Burmese food is so damn good.

My friend and I eat here regularly and the dishes we order are SO tasty that we always get the same thing.

We start with the balada bread (I hope the spelling is correct on this).  This is a fried, flaky, doughy flat bread that is served with a sauce that resembles peanut sauce, but it is almost like a curry (but not). It is hard to describe but it is fantastic.  

I could make a meal of the bread alone. But beware that it is really filling.

We like the String beans, the Mango chicken and coconut rice.  The string beans are perfectly cooked: still firm and served crusted with spices and salt.  The mango chicken we had last night was exceptional (probably because mangos are in season now), the mango of course being sweet and tender and the chicken nicely browned and all of it slightly spicy. I like to pour a bit of the chili oil on everything to kick the heat up as well.

Top it all off with a Tsingtao and you will be in full belly heaven.  All for $21 bucks or so, including tip.  

Once you start with this food it is difficult to stop, but typically we have leftovers for a least one person.
author: Alice S.

description:
Some like it hot, I like things HOT and SPICY! Mandalay brings tears to my eyes and this is my go to place when I visit SF.

It's always packed but well worth the wait.  The service is quick and friendly, the food is delish and when I'm not feeling that fiery, the Pumpkin Curry Chicken hits the spot. 

I think this is the best Burmese cuisine in San Francisco!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
blah blah burma superstar blah blah so good yeah whatever. Mandalay managed to seat fifteen drunk yelpers and serve them awesome burmese food when they walked in a few minutes before the kitchen closed. Had we gone to BS we'd still be standing outside two days later waiting for a table.

I recommend, um, everything. Maybe not the rainbow salad, which was decent, but was the only decent dish in a sea of excellent ones. Oh, and the samosas were just slightly oilier than I would have liked but only slightly. I really have to dig deep to find something to criticize.

So whenever someone suggests the other burmese place you can steer them towards Mandalay and end up looking like you know all the dining secrets of this town and you'll score a lot of favors.
author: matthew r.

description:
My cousin had been here once before and recommended it so our 2 families came here on a Saturday evening. We didn't have a reservation so we had to wait a little. They ended up pushing 2 tables together that would have comfortably sat 6-7 people for the 9 of us (we were squished!)

Food:
1. Tea Leaf Salad ($9) - it comes out with all of the ingredients separated, then the server explained what everything was before mixing it together. It was interesting and pretty good (quick note: it has jalapeños in it)
2. Mango Salad ($8.50) - everyone's favorite salad out of the 2 we tried. Def try it!
3. Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup) ($8.50) - the noodle itself is similar to pho noodle, the coconut soup was refreshing and light. 
4. Moo Hin Nga (Fish Chowder) ($9) - this was only so-so. It uses the vermicelli noodle. I would get the coconut soup over this. 
5. Balada ($5.95) - a pancake-like appetizer with a curry dipping sauce (kinda like Thai food's peanut sauce). Pretty good, we all really liked it (the pancakes are similar to the Chinese's pancakes with green onion and no sauce)
6. Mandalay Chicken ($9.50) - this is basically like orange chicken. It's pretty good but I would skip it and try something else. 
7. Mandalay Special Noodle ($9) - this has a thicket wider noodle mixed with coconut chicken. It was several of ours favorite dish of the night, a must try!
8. Coconut Rice ($2) - if you get a choice, I would choose this over the steamed rice.  It's a dry rice (not wet like some other restaurant's coconut rices). 

Service:
We had multiple servers throughout the night. They were all friendly, explained each dish as they were brought out and tried to recommend menu items (although the guy ended up just reading off the menu, which was not helpful). Service was pretty quick though because the restaurant was full, they would forget to bring our certain things we ask for sometimes.
author: Cindy H.

description:
I had limited time to get dinner before going to see The Warlords at the Castro.  I had been talking to someone about Mandalay the day before so it was like a self-fulfilling prophecy to end up here.  Within 15 minutes of arrival, I was seated and ordering.  I'm glad I got there when I did though because a lot of people showed up right after me.  

I tried the rainbow salad, shrimp with okra and the tea duck.  Everything was delicious.  I must go back and try more things on the menu.
author: Seong P.

description:
Like many people who eventually end up at Mandalay, we were headed over to Burma Super Star but when we got there, the line was too long and parking was ridiculous. Now I don't know if I'll ever go over to BS because Mandalay is just easier. The food is really good and the service is friendly, attentive, and helpful.

Bottom line, Mandalay is the place to be, especially if you don't want to deal with BS.
author: Arnold G.

description: I love it, love it, love it! Always delicious, always consistent, always polite. The place is packed for a reason. People wait at the door with patience knowing they will get an excellent meal for a reasonable price. The wait staff is excellent. Order anything on the menu and you'll be happy. Just go!
author: Bada B.

description:
I love Burmese food. I just realized that today. In the pantheon of Asian cuisines Burmese is kinda low on my radar screen, but I'm gonna change that.

Burmese is like a nice cross of Thai and Indian, which are two of the best tastes going, so I could a hybrid of the two be anything but awesome?

On top of that they gave me a cup of Hot and Sour soup, which qas probably better than any Chinese hot and sour I've ever head.

Eat more Burmese. You'll be a better person for it.
author: Jason R.

description:
YESSS!!! There is hope, my friends, when the wait at Burma SuperStar is 2.5 hours long and your stomach is roaring for a tea leaf salad.

That hope has a name -- Mandalay. And its green awning and the warm glow of its somewhat oddly-bedecked interior (Christmas ornaments? Really?) are only two blocks away.

And guess what else? Their tea leaf salad is BETTER than Burma's. I know, I know... It seems sacrilegious to say it. I'm as big of a Burma fan as anyone. But I'm not kidding -- it's better. There's no lettuce in it. The waitress at Mandalay explained that a traditional tea leaf salad doesn't have lettuce in it (like it does at Burma SuperStar). At Mandalay, they make theirs the old school way -- lots more of all the other crunchy goodies, plus way more fermented tea leaves. Oh boy oh boy...

Otherwise, I'd say the food was totally on par with Burma. But the real tipping point is that now that you're in the know, you can WALK RIGHT IN to Mandalay and have as delicious a Burmese meal as you would have had at the SuperStar's house (plus a better tea leaf salad!), while all those other clowns wait in line in the fog and wet for 2.5 hours.

Suckas!!!
author: Lisa T.

description: This is only my second time having Burmese food...first time at Burma Star. I just let my friends order and they did not disappoint. Service was great, especially the food.
author: Dan P.

description: Food is delicious and service is good. The balada appetizer is my favorite. Price is great too. But it gets crowded so if you don't like waiting try to get there before 7:30pm.
author: Kamila M.

description:
Great food, but be prepared for some service speed bumps. Even though I called ahead and made reservations, we still waited to be seated for about half an hour in the crowded entrance. The hostess offered us a glass of wine on the house to make up for it, although actually getting the wine was like pulling teeth. 

We politely reminded her and then she brought put our glasses for us... filled with water! Ok, second try -- after fighting to flag her down she informed us they are out of the wine!? When we finally got seated we asked that women as to whether it's still possible to get the wine that was offered to us on the house -- at this point it was becoming a bit of a joke to my dinner companion and I. She said she'd need to confirm with the hostess that the offer was made. We never saw that woman who sat us again. 

Just for the heck of it we later asked our waitress and shockenly the mystery wine finally came. I will admit that the friendliness of the second waitress we had almost erased our odd wine experience.  And the food was amazing.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Mango salad- $ reasonable
Coconut rice-$ reasonable
Walnut Sauce-$ reasonable

Not having to wait another hour to get seated at Burma Superstar= PRICELESS

The food was fantastic.  Everyone was nice.  The restaurant was busy but also peaceful.  Unlike Burma Superstar Mandalay actually values their client's time.
author: R M.

description:
Yay!  I'm a fan.  And that's not just me copying the words that appear when you roll over the 4th star - it's the truth.  And to be honest, I toggled between Yay! and Woohoo! a few times.

We were in the neighborhood and hungry right around early-bird-special time, that is, just past 6pm.  We're late eaters, so that almost qualifies as a late lunch for us.  We thought that surely we would be the only ones at Mandalay - Monday night, cold weather, dining at a time suited for the elderly and little kids - well, nope, we were wrong.  The place was packed.  I think we got the last table before the line started forming.

I liked the decor right away.  Christmas ornaments hanging from the ceiling, real flowers on every table (and beautiful arrangements), wonderful tapestries.  It all spoke of warmth and pride and welcoming.  

The food was EXCELLENT.  We ordered enough for a small army, since it was our first time there, with the intent of taking some home.  I like Burma Superstar, so I didn't order what I usually get there - instead, we tried whatever sounded different.

Mandalay Chicken Salad - thinly shredded, light, refreshing with plenty of fresh cilantro and sesame seeds.   Delicious!

Samusas - pretty good, looked like little birthday hats on the plate, heavy on the potatoes, light on the chicken.  Spicy dipping sauce was nice.

Balada - crispy onion pancake with curry dipping sauce - DIVINE!  The pancake is dense and satisfying, and the sauce is sooooo good.  Totally vegetarian, too.  I took 2 wedges home for breakfast.  Breakfast may occur at midnight tonight, mind you.

Mandalay Mango Chicken - very good, tender chicken, slightly kicking sauce.  Nice spices.

Mandalay Beef - very good, similar to the Mandalay chicken.  A little heavier, but not overwhelmingly so.

Mandalay Special Noodle - TERRIFIC dish.  Broad soft noodles mixed with thin crunchy noodles, chicken, lots of lemongrass and ginger and cilantro - and a coconut broth.  I could not stop eating these noodles.  Not heavy at all, but totally satisfying.  Can also get with tofu.  Mixed tableside.

Service was very efficient and friendly.  

Mandalay is a wonderful place, one that I know that I will visit often.  I'd even skip lunch in favor of an early dinner here.  While we were eating, I kept naming people that I wanted to bring there - friends, family, friends AND family - it's that good.  Also open for lunch with reasonable prices for specials.

**Extra Credit:  see if you can find the typo on the dessert part of the menu - hint, it mentions "puppy seeds".  Awww!  Who wants to grow a puppy? I do!  I do!**
author: Liz S.

description:
This is a great place. Instead of going to the B word restaurant, I decided to FINALLY get over to Mandalay for a try. If you overlook the really funny electric palm tree at the entrance, it has a spacious and tastefully decorated decor with plenty of room for several tables/people. The menu, despite a few typos (does every Asian restaurant have them?) the menu was easy to follow and offered several familiar eats.

We started with the tea leaf salad...come on, you have to see if it's as good as the competitor's salad we all know and love. This version doesn't come with lettuce so make sure you ask for it. The salad was excellent and I could have eaten another one. Next was the coconut broth chicken soup. Seriously, this soup was so good I could have eaten that as a meal alone. Awesome! Next came the sizzling beef with peppers and onion with coconut rice and the spicy chicken with saffron rice. Both entrees were great but I would lean toward the coconut rice over the saffron but that is based on my taste buds alone.

Our server was the biggest sweetheart ever and I hope that everyone gets the same treatment we did. I'm quite sure of it. She probably makes more more money than a surgeon in tips alone she's so nice!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of Burmese food, but this place is much better than Burma Super Star. Very attentive staff, good samosas and ginger salad.
The Young coconut drink is sooo good ! I liked the vibe and decor of this restaurant. HARD to park!!!
author: Pez B.

description: I had no idea Mandalay even existed due to my lack of time in the inner richmond. It was a weeknight around 8 so we were seated right away. I'm glad I went with someone who's been before because I had no idea what to order. ;-)  We had the tea leaf salad with no peanuts (I'm allergic) which was awesome. I've never had anything like it in Thai or Chinese food, its definitely Burmese. For our entrees we had a half tea duck - one of my favorite things in the world and curry beef. Both were good & I would order them again!
author: Sara P.

description:
I had heard great things about Mandalay from fellow yelper, Teri C., and I finally was able to try it! 

We arrived on a Friday night, around 730pm, 4 diners. The restaurant was crowded, and we didn't have reservations but we were seated immediately. The wait staff was very nice and the waitress memorized all of our orders, which I was impressed with because I can't even remember what I did yesterday. We ordered, let me see if I can remember...The Balada(crispy pancake with a curry sauce) and the tea leaf salad to start. As entrees we ordered basil beef, sizzling prawn, and walnut broccoli tofu and Mandalay noodles.

All the dishes were VERY flavorful and tasted very fresh. We also ordered coconut rice with our entrees and the sweetness really complimented the savory and spicy flavors of the food. I LOVED the walnut broccoli tofu. The walnuts tasted candied, the broccoli was fresh and not mushy and the tofu was fried and yummy! The Mandalay noodles tasted like an Asian version of fettuccine alfredo. I didn't eat the meat/fish dishes, because I am a vegetarian. But my fellow diners appeared to really enjoy the meat dishes! 

We were also given complimentary desserts: a coconut jello like dessert and a sweet potato jello like dessert. The sweet potato dessert was tasty, not too sweet. I wasn't a fan of the coconut jello. But it was very nice of the wait staff to give us free desserts! 

Overall, a very nice dining experience. I really like the Burmese food here over Burma  Superstar. I thought the food here tasted much more flavorful and of course, there was no hour long wait!
author: Caroline C.

description:
"Welcome to the Mandalay," our waiter bellowed as he handed us our menus.  Starting with waitstaff and the menus, a lot has changed at the Mandalay in the last year and a half.  When I was last here, there was one meek server handling all three occupied tables, an now there is a bustling crew.  The new menus are cushioned, which I like, and there is a map of Myanmar/Burma on the back, so we have a better idea of why the food tastes like a sublime mix of Chinese, Thai, Southeast Asian and Indian. 

This time there was also a 10 minute wait for a two-top, which was fine compared to the hour and a half to 2-hour wait quoted around the corner at Burma Superstar.  I think people are catching on that the food at Mandalay is just as good, but the wait is exponentially shorter and you get a lot more elbow room.

The food is still sublime and the desserts, which are either new, or were just not noticed by me in the past are fun, exotic and tasty.  They've picked up on the joys of the table-side preparation employed by Burma Superstar too, which make a meal so much more fun.  Check out Dessert #1, the Sui Gi Mok, which according to the menu, is sprinkled with PUPPY SEEDS.  

I've always loved this place, but I feared for it's survival, so I am thrilled to see Mandalay so successful!
author: Quinn S.

description:
I came here with a friend and I'd been wanting to try this place ever since I tried the food at their sister restaurant in Burlingame. My favorite was the samusa, although we didn't have any this time around. Instead we ordered the pancake appetizer, which was SO GOOD, but if you're planning on eating more later, you should order something smaller because the pancake is big and pretty filling. It was cut into 6 large pieces; I only had 2 and I had trouble finding room in my tummy for my Special Noodle main dish (And I'm usually a big eater). The Noodles were pretty good too, but it's understandable if some people don't like the sauce--it's just different.

We went at a good time (around 6pm), because 10-20 minutes after we sat down, the place was packed and the waiting line was out the door.
author: Kym M.

description:
It was their Tea Leaf Salad that will forever be the first time food gave me a visible emotional reaction.  Eating that salad was a life changing, palette transforming experience for me.  I have never had food make me so happy, so joyous, so incredibly relaxed.  

While my friends were upset at how long it took for the food to come, I was somewhere else -- on cloud nine with the mango salad and then the tea leaf salad. 

   Unreal, folks.  Unreal.
author: Johnny A.

description:
I remain a fan of Mandalay and will eat here many more times, but I don't think it deserves 5 stars anymore.  This is sad for me since it's one of my favorite restaurants in the Richmond.  Maybe it's because they have become increasingly busy and popular of the years or maybe my palette has matured; either way the quality seems to be suffering a bit.  I'm starting to think thier samusas are smaller and come from a frozen package.  I'm fairly certain I can get samusas of the same, if not better, quality from Trader Joe's.  Mandalay doesn't deliver anymore either. Boo.

Anyway, I will come back for the soups without a doubt, but for real quality Burmese I may actually go to (I can't believe I'm saying this) Burma *I'm holding my breath I swear* Superstar. There! I said it! Their food is better.  But I still hate waiting an eternity for my food and after my take out experience I'm nervous. (I still have some pride to swallow before I'm a full-blown fan though.)

Also, Mandalay's ambiance is still better.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
So I finally got sick of the wait at Burma Superstar and cane here.  It looked promising, not too long of a wait, good prices, they offered us a drink while we waited.  I was feeling good.  The food selection is a bit different than Burma, but like I said, good selection, good prices.

Then came the 45 minute wait....
then my entree came, followed by 20 minutes before my friend's entree came, and 10 minutes before my other friend's entree came

If the kitchen is behind, I can understand that, but to bring out three people's entrees over the course of 45 minutes? 

I was forced to chose between alienating my starving friends and eating in front of them, or waiting while my dish got cold.  It sucked- then, there was no explanation or even acknowledgment that we had waited over an hour from ordering to getting all the food.

My food (veggie/tofu noodles) was AMAZING- seriously, like nothing I've ever had before.  I cant speak for my friends meat dishes, as I'm a veggie and deep-fried pork just doesn't appeal to me.

Bottom Line:

Come here during the week, by yourself and I'm sure the service is better...the food is definitely 4.5 stars :-)
author: Ali M.

description:
I hate admitting that this was my backup after finding out the wait list for Burma Superstar was 30 parties deep because Mandalay deserves better than being labeled "the Burma Superstar backup."  It is an awesome little restaurant in its own right with great food, friendly service and awesome American pop music translated into Burmese/Cantonese running in the background.

Screw Burma Superstar and go to Mandalay as your first choice.

And regardless of what you order, get the coconut rice... mmmm!
author: Derek B.

description:
"Nature has placed mankind under the government of two sovereign masters, pain and pleasure" --- Jeremy Bentham, British philosopher.

We think with our rational mind, but when it comes to action, we are motivated by pain and pleasure. I like Burmese cuisine and my rational mind leads me to the door of Burma Superstar. However, every time I have tried coming here, I see a huge line.

Now I am a firm believer in immediate gratification and hence, the pleasure of delicious food turns into the pain of waiting and, like every other time, I walk 2 blocks to California street to Mandalay, my backup place for Burmese cuisine. Now if I were a masochist, or a sadist with a masochist in tow, I would have stayed back but that is a whole different review altogether.

Don't get me wrong, if Mandalay was'nt pretty good, there would'nt have been a 5 minutes wait on a Tuesday evening. Bumping into Teri C, who was one of the fun people I met at the infamous Halloween party of Danny H, provided extra gratification.

I dip my Burmese bread(paratha) into the Lamb curry and feel the gratitude of gratification. Past memories of Tea salads, Satays(skewers), mango chicken/beef make my taste glands secrete even more. Finally, the ever  friendly waitress, warms up to me with the lure of desserts.

"To dessert or not to dessert, that is the question"..I turn out to be more decisive than Hamlet and say a firm NO even though, I can feel the tingling sensation of the fried bananas with coconut icecream  salivating my tongue and I leave for home  satisfied even more so since the dining experience at Mandalay did not burn a hole in my wallet.
author: Kaustav C.

description: This place is delicious! I have tried a lot of the dishes here but my absolute favorite is the Mandalay Special Noodles. I eat here as often as possible when I come to this side of SF. The location is in the Inner Richmond District off California St. The parking is OK depending what time of the day it is so always give yourself extra time. The people working here are so friendly and the customers too. The decor is fun! traditional Burmese Art meets sprinklings of Christmas left up. ... love it! There is usually only one waiter/waitress working and one person hosting/working the register so there can be a bit of a wait to order your food after you are seated. It definitely helps to know what you want BEFORE you are seated that way you can tell your server what you want and they can get it to the kitchen earlier for you. Once you place your order the food comes pretty fast. This is only if it is busy though, otherwise they provide very attentive service and the food is always fantastic no matter how busy it gets. Will always keep coming back!
author: Ashley T.

description:
Since my last review, I've been back at least half a dozen times. And in that time, there have been significant changes.

Burma Super Star's fame has really been a double edged sword for Mandalay. On one hand, BSS's enormous popularity and proximity has made Mandalay a huge financial success. On the other hand, they haven't handled that success very well at all.

The quality of most dishes has gone down. Serving sizes, always on the slim side, have gotten even smaller. Prices, of course, have risen. And now there are even lines.

Where's the bang for the buck? Not here. If someone else knows a good Burmese spot in the city -- please don't review it! Let us discover it on our own -- for all our sakes.

Funny, but true -- my friend whom I introduced to Yelp uses Yelp all the time, but she refuses to make an account and write reviews. Why? She doesn't want people going to her secret spots, making them popular. Why give out her hair stylist if it makes it impossible for her to get an appointment, right? Popularity has made, and ruined, good small neighborhood spots like Mandalay.

Dearest Mandalay, everyone I've introduced to your moo hing nga adores it still. But when we're paying shy of $200 for dinner for my family and they're still hungry, I have to leave, scratching my head and wondering if I should ever come back. For around half the price, I can go a few blocks away to China First, get mountains of fresh crab, lobster, fish, prawns, shellfish, and leave with leftovers.

My next visit? Maybe it'll just be me and some moo hing nga...
author: Perci N.

description:
Came here tonight with an old friend after we attempted to go to the Supastar but were thwarted by the longarsewaitlist.  

The first thing you notice about Mandalay is that is soooo much more less congested than the Supastar and don't have to savour your rainbow salad or other Burmese goodness while sitting on the lap of the couple next to you. The layout is spacious and well decorated.  The service was very attentive, the portions generous, the curries sumptuous and the desserts exquisite.  I'll definitely be back. fast!!!
author: I. O.

description:
If you come here, you must try the tea leaf salad! The server brings the plate of tea leaves, lentils, sesame seeds, peanuts, roasted garlic and chile peppers and after explaining what is what, mixes it all together for you at the table. The flavors are intense and I don't think I could have eaten the whole salad myself. But do share it with someone!

I came by in the afternoon after the lunch rush and was promptly seated. My water glass was refilled twice without asking and I can't say how much that warmed the cockles of my cold, cold heart. Oftentimes at restaurants the server simply disappears after the food is served. Not the case here at Mandalay! 

So if you're interested in Burmese food (and don't want to wait for two hours somewhere else...), give Mandalay a try! Great service, tasty food and inexpensive to boot.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
This place is a great when you want to try something new but familiar. I mean Burmese cuisine is like fresh and lighter Thai food (to me). So the dishes sound and look like what I know but when I taste it it's new and oh so good. 

My favorite thing is the Mandalay Special Noodle dish (#3). I love how they mix it all up at your table and tell what all the little ingredients are.
I have also had the pot stickers, satay, Burmese iced tea, some chicken dish, some other noodle dish - all good. One time I tried a dessert, it was in stick form, bright orange, gummy and grainy - it was super strange but oddly addictive. 

Also, most of the restaurants in this stretch on Cali are not open for lunch but Mandalay is - always a hit. I saw someone order this quesadilla looking thing that I can't wait to try next time.

My biggest complaint is that service is very slow here no matter how busy they are - come on Mandalay come back and check on me every once in a while!  

FYI- Take Out is VERY fast!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
I am not even kidding you...you can order a dang coconut and drink out of it and then eat the meat. I was in such sweet coco-heaven. 

I went with a group and we ordered ALL the salads and they were  ALL fantastic.  

Super affordable, too!
author: Kristen Y.

description:
To all the bad food people who think they know stuff...please don't go here and ruin it.  Staay awaaaaay! Glitteratti and other hipsters -go to the light.

For those that are kind and wonderful, who love authentic Burmese food, okay.  You can stay.

I've enjoyed every single dish I have ever ordered here.  They sized me up in one go, and then told me "I'll bring you a plate of spicy chili paste"  -HAHAHHAHA.  After my own heart.  And it was the amazing and complicated kind.  It was NOT Sriracha dressed up.  It was some serious paste that someone labored over.  Even more complicated in the  making, than Vietnamese fish sauce.

The La Phat Dok here ROXXX!  I love their proportions and that they don't get stingy with ingredients...unlike other Burmese places I've gone to.

Khao Shwe Tok?  Yes!

Even their green beans are great!

Here are the downsides:

My friend and I first got seated near the door.  It was a cold winter and whenever other people came in, I felt a great gust of wind on my back.  Bad.  I had to ask to be re-seated elsewhere in the restaurant.  But this just speaks to their good customer service.

Parking.  Uh, what parking?  Sadly, I don't live anywhere near this gem of a restaurant...so I must go get a car in order to get here.

Mom and Pop decor.  eh.  It can go either way.  It usually tells me they focus more on the food, so I suppose that's a good thing.  Oddly, good food for me usually doesn't have good ambiance.

My friend could not eat most of the food I ordered.  He had to have a lot of water with his food.  Well, for me, that wasn't really bad.  Maybe that was a plus...because that keeps folks with that kind of stomach away.  

You know...the kind that doesn't really like AUTHENTIC FOOD that's made the proper way that isn't watered down to fit into someone else's palate...the spicy, pungent, real kind of food that makes a scenester's eye's water -only to reveal they don't know what they are doing and don't have the experience to back it up either.  Don't be frontin'!

Can't stand the heat?  Don't eat with me.  LOL.
author: angel a.

description:
Yay!!!  I am NOT a bitch!  I just gave a restaurant five stars!  Six words, yo:  Sizzling Rice Soup & Tea Smoked Duck....ummmm, ummmm, ummmm.

I went into Mandalay a little furtively...fellow yelper James Tiberius S. has been scrutinizing my every restaurant move, chastising me for being frivolous and eating out so much.  He thinks I should invest my monies and plan for the future.  Snort.  Little does he know, I already gots that sh*t handled.  The plan is to marry rich...

Dude, I hate to be a hater but Burma Superstar sucks hard.  I have stood in line a couple of times to give it a chance but besides the sangria and the beer cooler, I was not impressed with a single item and I tried about ten things on the menu.  In fact, it sucks so hard that I thought I didn't like Burmese food.

But then my sick friend dragged me to Mandalay and I went kicking and screaming because if I was going to violate my financially savvy boy's sound advice, I at least wanted to eat something I liked.

Hello, new money pit!  Sick friend wanted soup, and most of the soups have shrimp which I'm allergic to, so we asked for the sizzling rice soup without shrimp.  The waiter was super nice and said it could be done.  The soup came out in a little tureen wafting a cloud of steam floating over a well seasoned, chunky brothy soup.  It had firm little chunks of chicken, tender scallops (scallops!), peas, and other vegetables swimming all around.  The menu said (I think) that it also contains fish but I didn't spot any and frankly think it would be overkill.  But check this out...the sizzling rice are these patties of puffed rice (rice crispy look alike thingies) that get tossed into the piping hot soup, sizzle, and dissolve!  The rice absorbs all the lovely flavor of the soup and fills you up.  Wonderful soup to get over a nasty cold or flu.

The second item we ordered was a fluke.  I just wanted to be ornery and order something that sounded wierd.  So I ordered a half order of the tea smoked duck.  You guys, everyone at some point in their life, needs to stop by Mandalay and try the tea smoked duck.  Perfectly crispy skin, with deep tea notes throughout the meat and skin.  The duck itself was moist and thick and I felt my arteries thicken with the duck fat that I allowed myself to leave on my morsels. 

Sheesh, now I can't stop thinking about it.  Oh, btw, it comes with these little buns that are kinda like the dim sum barbeque pork buns but smaller and without any filling.  It also comes with plum sauce and strips of green onions so you can make little sandwiches.  But its so rich that it seems like a waste to mask the greasy ducky goodness with the bun, although the green onion and plum sauce (mixed with a little chile sauce for me!) provides a nice contrast.  Its the Burmese equivalent of homestyle southern fried chicken, y'all...oooooh, go when you're hungover!!!!

The reason they get five stars is because although it was late (we got there at 9:48 on a week night) and there was a big party at the same time, our waitress was so attentive, noticing when our greedy paws got too greasy from the duck and bringing extra napkins without being asked and without revealing the disgust I am sure she felt at our lack of table manners.  

Long story short, this spot is three blocks away from Burma Superstar, never crowded, better food and way better service.
author: A S.

description: The food is AMAZING here! I came here on a Friday evening with my friends and had a wonderful time dining here. I love the atmosphere, the place is clean and even though it was a busy night, the workers all managed to come around and make sure things were alright - with that said service is fantastic! For appetizers I ordered the Tea Leaf Salad and had the Pan Fried Okra and Shrimp for the main course with Coconut Rice on the side. This place is awesome, I would totally recommend this place.
author: Clementine D.

description: Good Burmese food in the Richmond, with great service. I'd recommend the fried onion appetizer and the beef with okra with coconut rice. The Mandalay special noodles are tasty too, and mixed right in front of you. Everything here has really strong flavors, but they're pretty balanced and not overwhelming. I'd have to say the flavors are a little more delicate at Burma Superstar, but overall the food at Mandalay is fresh and satisfying.
author: Meesh N.

description:
I recently found out that I'm related to Burmese Royalty and when I came here it sure felt like it. The servers are really friendly and they are almost always on top of everything.

So apparently burmese traditionally  get their food all at one time, so when my uncle asked (in burmese, which is really cool) they delivered. Salad, Soup, rice, meat... all came out at once and we devoured it all. I also got the coconut milk drink... it's all good here, I can't remember the names of any of the dishes that we ordered, i usually leave that to my aunt and uncle do all the ordering... but i will tell you that this place is worth it, and is mighty good. Yum!
author: Richard T.

description:
Having been to Burma Superstar up the street many times (and having waited 45 minutes to an hour for a table there), we decided to give Mandalay a try. I am from out of town and always try to hit up Burma S. when I am in SF and consider it one the best places to eat in the city. That said, I think Mandalay will be our new must go place for future trips. 

The food is equally good to Burma S. and there was no waiting. NONE. Also, the restaurant was laid out in a way that gave each table plenty of elbow room which gives it extra points in my book. 

Based on the server's suggestions, we ordered mango chicken and the Mandalay Noodles. The noodles were OUT OF THIS WORLD, CRAZY GOOD. Also the rainbow salad was different but on par with the one over at Burma S. Try the ginger beer cocktail - really refreshing. 

We walked in at 3:20 on a Saturday, apparently 10 minutes before they were supposed to close and stop lunch service. I expected for them to rush our meal but they were extremely friendly, patient, and knowledgeable about the menu. At the end of our meal, the manager sent us free mango rice pudding which was amazing. 

They were 3 of us and we walked out extremely full for a bill of about $65 (that's drinks, appetizers and 3 mains). Great value for the money, highly recommended. A+++
author: Crystal J.

description:
Oh..my..god. How did I go this long without knowing the joys of Burmese food!? I wish I could give this place more stars. 

The service was awesome and the food was...oh...my..god. 

Burmese food is a mixture of Chinese, Thai, and Indian. 

The Chinese and the Thai are apparent. My only true encounter with the Indian aspect came after my meal was over if you catch my drift. I was ripped up but I could barely care..it was that good. 

The meal broken down:

Balada - A fried pancake of insane happiness. A sort of flakey biscuit (but not at all) comprised of crepes. This is served with a curry sauce that is heavy with galangal and lemongrass. A bit of chili sauce? AMAZING

The Mandalay Chicken - Fried chicken in an amazing sauce. It's like the best orange chicken ever but..not quite orange. Order it.

The Rainbow chicken - Happy nuggets of chicken nestled in bell pepper, pineapple, mango, and such. Yum. 

Coconut Rice - HOW DID I NEVER TRY YOU BEFORE!? 

Saffron Rice - Perfumed with bay leaves and cinnamon and other assorted magic. Then there are raisins and..mmmmm

Mixed Vegetables with Tofu - The tofu is PERFECT. There is more tofu than vegetables but yeah..no complaints. Silky magic tofu with a slightly fried exterior with a magical sauce? Hell..yes. 

Mandalay Noodles - Thai Fettuccini Alfredo..ish. Very good..particularly mixed in with the Saffron Rice.
