I wish I could have kept eating. I really really do. It was one of those meals where it was so good that you know whatever you order you will love but you almost want to order the exact same thing so you can try to relive that experience.
author: Natalie G.

description: This is some really good Burmese food we have here! Came in on January 1st for lunch so it was expectedly crowded but the wait time was around 20 mins which is not bad at all. The food was delicious! Got the fish with asparagus, Rangoon chicken, flat egg noodles. Everything was really really good. I like this place a little better than Burma Superstar because the food is comparable and it is easier to get a table here. I'll have to try this on a busy weekend evening to confirm this though. Definitely worth checking out!
author: Mustansir M.

description:
three words my friends: Lap Pat Dok

ok, make it 5....Mandalay Noodle

Scrumdilicious!
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Wow.  Burma Superstar was my first foray into Burmese food and I was very  underwhelmed by the whole experience...that being said, Mandalay has totally turned things around for me.  Burmese food is delicious!  

I came on Saturday night at 6:30 with a group of 7.  I made reservations earlier that day and when we arrived the restaurant was pretty empty.  It filled up fast though and by the time we left there was a long line to be seated, so if you do have time to plan ahead I would recommend reservations.

We opted to eat family style and everyone chose a dish.  We had:  Burmese Curry Chicken, Mango Mandalay Chicken, Walnut Broccoli, Mandalay Special Noodles, Hot and Sour Soup and Coconut Rice.  Everything was delicious, the real stand out for me though was the Mango chicken.  The small pieces of chicken were tender and the addition of the spicy sauce and the sautéed mango chunks were perfect.  I wasn't too sure initially about the Walnut Broccoli, but it turned out to be a good combo and my sweet tooth enjoyed the tangy yet slightly sweet sauce.  

I am a big fan of curry, but the Burmese style curry didn't really do much for me, it was good, but not something I'd get again.  Also you really need to spend the extra money and get the Coconut Rice, it is AMAZING!  The coconut flavor is not overwhelming and adds a nice little kick to otherwise bland white rice.  

Everything is really reasonable priced too, I think we all ended up throwing down $13 for a delicious and satisfying meal...come here!
author: Katherine C.

description: Sometimes it's a bit crowded because it is so good! I love their tea leaf salad. Their food is authentic. They are friendly. Love this place!
author: Travis N.

description:
I had never eaten Burmese food before trying this place.  I have already been back here three times.
The food here is really good. While it seems to be getting a longer line every time I go, it is still worth it (or you can order by phone and pick it up--no line!)
My favorites:
Balada -- the menu describes it as a pancake, but it seems to be layers of filo dough which have been lightly fried.  Whatever it is, it's delicious!
Walnut Broccoi Chicken -- the menu does a good enough job of selling this item: "boneless chicken and steamed broccoli glazed over with honey kissed walnuts" (just writing this makes me want to go back so I can order it again.)
Coconut Rice -- no matter what you order get a side of coconut rice.  It wonderfully compliments every dish I have tried there.
Overall: I have yet to try something even mediocre here.
author: Greg J.

description: I make sure to come here every time I am in San Francisco and I have managed to get my family hooked as well.  The Tea Leaf Salad (minus lettuce of course) is to die for and no matter which entree I've tried, they have all been delicious.  It's a little off the beaten path but that's part of what makes it awesome.  Last time I was there, my friend and I nearly needed to walk back to our hotel with our pants unbuttoned.  We had ordered a quite few things to try and planned to take most of it to go but couldn't stop ourselves. Anyway, bottom line...I can't rave enough about this place.  You just have to try it.
author: Alison R.

description: This restaurant is spectacular!  The owners, Shari and Kevin, are very courteous and friendly.  They treat customers equally and with great service.  The food is awesome!  Mango Chicken, Chicken samosa, Rainbow Salad, Chicken Skewers, Palada, Lamb Curry, Pea Shoots, Combo Fried Rice, Mandalay Beef and so much more!  These are our favorite dishes.  Get there early because parking is sparse and the place fills up fast.  Highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Jerry H.

description:
Your days of glory have gone.

This is nostalgia: bittersweet, leaving me with more desires, and a heavy stomach that can't digest.

Your lamb curry has less flavor and more oil.  Your baratha (roti pratha) is still good, but your tea leaf salad lacks the kick it used to have.  Plus, you're always packed now.  

Why do you hurt me so?  I just can't stomach your food anymore.  But knowing that, I still go back, hoping for those days where I would leave your establishment so satisfied.

Momma always said, "You can't relive the past."
author: Tangerine L.

description: Mandalay is a delicious Richmond neighborhood gem.  I had never eaten Burmese food prior to coming here, and I left a fan.  They have delicious curry, rice, noodle, & soup dishes (and much more).  My favorite appetizer is the tea leaf salad.  This restaurant is fairly big, always busy, and has friendly attentive service.
author: Lauren P.

description:
So since I've written my Burma SuperStar review and pleaded for an explanation of Burmese food, no one's stepped up to the explanatory plate.  I'm still waiting . . . .

I actually came to Mandalay before I had even heard of Burma SuperStar.  The first time someone took me to Burma SuperStar, I assumed we were coming to Mandalay, as they're geographically close to each other.  (Wouldn't it be cool if there were a Burmese part of the Inner Richmond?)  It's got a completely different vibe from its more popular counterpart.  Mandalay can get crowded, yes, but you never feel rushed by the service or the people waiting at the door.  This relaxed feeling makes everything OK.

The food itself is delicious.  I've never had anything bad here.  The service is also good.
author: John S.

description:
Forget Burma Superstar! This place is just as good.  
Comparisons:
1. 10 minute wait in a fairly spacious waiting area vs. a two hour wait in out in the fog.
2. Mandalay, big tables and cozy booths vs. sitting asses to elbows at BS. 
3. Let the conversation flow freely at Mandalay. You'll probably have to strain your ears to eavesdrop on the table conversation next to you, vs. leaning into your bowl of pumpkin shrimp and yelling, "What was that you said?" at BS.
4. Yummy traditional Burmese food vs. yummy traditional Burmese food.

I'm putting in my order for the Curry Vegetables right now!
Yes they deliver! Take that BS!

Enjoy!
author: Aria M.

description: I'm lucky enough to live only five blocks from this amazing restaurant, and have been there dozens of times. Not only is it delicious, but not at all overpriced. Their tea leaf salad is so addictive - I keep coming back to get my fix! The staff is so welcoming and helpful, they make you feel like family. I cannot recommend Mandalay enough - we have turned many friends onto this place with similar results. Cannot wait to go back!
author: Andrea N.

description:
The food is great.  
Simple with fresh ingredients and authentic as far as I can tell.  The Rainbow chicken is fantastic.  We also had the Mandalay noodle which is a homemade noodle with curry sauce.  mmmm.
The service isn't the quickest but that's because they're actually making food back there.
author: Lisa G.

description:
I was considering giving this place a 5, but the wait was much longer than expected.  Anyways, I decided to eat at this place because Burma Superstar had a hour and a half wait time.  My friends and I were hungry so we called up Mandalay since it was right around the corner and I didn't feel like B Star.  

Put in a reservation of 6pm for 5 people.  We didn't get seated until 6:40.  Of course that isn't as bad a wait as Burma but it was still quite a wait and the food came out slowly.  

On to the food portion of the review:  Started off with the Tea Leaf Salad.  It was a great, flavor-packed starter that warmed everyone for what was to come.  If you haven't tried a Tea Leaf Salad yet, you definitely should!  Burmese Curry Beef tasted great also, but there were only 5 pieces of beef.  The Mandalay Chicken had a nice hint of spice in the dish but wasn't a standout.  We rounded off the night with Rainbow Prawn, Mandalay Special Noodle and Coconut Rice.  The Noodles may have been my favorite dish of the night.  The dish sounded a little much but everything mixed well together and it just tasted right.  Good job on the food!

After seeing everyone elses review it does seem like their business is booming and need to work on managing the amount of people they can expect.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Y'know, I don't think that Burma Superstar is overrated. However, I do hate the long wait.  Usually if you go early enough to Burma Superstar, there's no line. Not so this past Labor Day.  We showed up at 5:00, and already at least 30 people were in line.  So we turned around and headed over to Mandalay. I still like the Tea Leaf Salad and the Special (Superstar) Noodles better at BS + Mandalay doesn't have Samusa Soup. But what Mandalay does have is an amazing Samusa Salad and the Tofu with Broccoli and Walnuts dish that is so good. The atmosphere is very comfortable, staff helpful and attentive, and they often bring out a free desert. The food isn't quite as zippy as BS, but it's still a destination restaurant for me.

Update 10/27/06:
I've become obsessed with Mandalay.  Burma Super-who? We've been eating at Mandalay at least once a week lately.  Now we've discovered  so many favorite-must-have dishes that it's very difficult to order.  Our staple dish is the Burmese Style Noodle (Kaw Soi Dok) which--though milder than the Burma Superstar version--is freakin' fantastic.  Aside from the aforementioned must-have dishes, Samusa Salad and Tofu with Broccoli and Walnuts, we recently branched out to try:

Naked Eggplant (a special not on the menu, but you can ask for it anytime)--melt-in-your-mouth chunks of peeled fried eggplant in a slightly sweet sauce with onion (and bell peppers if you want 'em)

Tofu Pumpkin Curry--very rich--almost as good as the Pumpkin Curry at Silver Spoon but with more vegies.

Balada with curry dipping sauce--deep-fried goodness. It's especially good with the chili sauce that they bring to the table.  I dream about that chili sauce.  I'd spread it on toast in the morning if I could.

It's a good thing I don't eat meat or seafood--I'd never be able to make up my mind.  As it is, Mandalay has a great selection for vegetarians. I just got back from there, and I want to go back.  Just thinking about it made me add another star.
author: Wan T.

description:
I love the food here.  I love the rainbow salad especially, and it has actually caused me to crave it enough to cross Market on a weekday.  Burma Superstar is too crowded and too rushed, while this place is busy yet more laid back.  

Sure, the service could be improved (I was told that I ordered and wanted a green tea salad, when I didn't, and then was charged for that, plus the rainbow salad that I really wanted), but that adds to the charm.  

Also, they play the Burmese version of Pink's "Get this Party Started," so I don't understand why people aren't lining up to go here.
author: Kim S.

description: I went again to this place ... and it wasn't as good. Not sure why. Their Rainbow salad wasn't yummy -- only their tea leaf salad was good.
author: Antara B.

description:
Very good. I like sweet plates and so I was thoroughly satisfied with the lemon chicken and my coconut rice. I also tried the walnut chicken and that was nummy too. Good service as well! I'll definitely go back.

You can also spread your arms without smacking someone (it's roomy.)
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Let me start by saying i didn't start eating Burmese food until i started eating here a few months ago...

Having said that...this is a solid solid restaurant...

The other Burmese place near by (Superstar) is always packed with people waiting outside and their menu is at some points, double the price of this place.  While i cannot compare the two, i will say, that Superstar MUST serve amazing food in order to feel justified into paying their prices, because the amazing flavors and reasonable prices of Mandalay make me never want to go anywhere else (and pay more) for burmese food again.  The food here is just so perfectly seasoned, each entree with its own distinct flavors and uniqueness...you cannot go wrong with almost anything you order here.  For something different, try the tea salad or the mango chicken.

Oh and another plus, lots of seating :-)

I will say too, that while this place certainly has very good food, the service leaves something to be desired...hence their 4 stars...prob closer to 3 1/2.  Servers were in plain view and easy to see however, it was very difficult to get them to your table for most things.  Im sure its a hit or miss thing, and most nights are better then others, so i wouldn't make too much of a big deal about it.  

People who love Burmese food and especially people who usually frequent Burma Superstar, should definitely check out this place.  I would highly recommend it to anyone!  For the very reasonable prices and especially the lack of crowdedness (word?) lol, this place is a must when ur in the mood for Burmese food.
author: Mark R.

description:
I've been going to Mandalay for about two years now.  Yes, it's become popular.  Arrive before 6:30 or after 8:30 if you don't want to wait for a table.

Dishes here are always light, exotic, and amazing.  You can't go wrong with the Mango Chicken, Coconut rice, and special Mandalay noodles.  Certain dishes they will mix at your table so you have a better idea all the ingredients that are going into it, like the Mandalay special noodles or the tea leaf salad (which is less of a salad, more of a nut mixture).

Frequently, we've dined later in the evening and dessert was complimentary at that time.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I agree with Mr Curtis!!! I don't know what the deal is with not-so-super-star on Clement- Golden Mandalay is the place to go! It's one of our local favorites and the staff is always friendly, food is fresh with a huge menu! Of course we're guilty of ordering the Rainbow salad, mango chicken, samoas and coconut rice almost all the time- if we can fit it, we'll also get the fried banana dessert with ice cream (oh yum...) 
Reasonably priced, nice ambience, quiet, easy access (ok fine, I live a few blocks away so I guess parking is REALLY easy for me) and a great deal overall. If you're in a hurry, just call in your order and pick up or have it ordered- they're usually more than happy to deliver!

We hosted ~60 out of town guests here for dinner after a city-trolley tour through SF (wine and beer on board, of course...) We took over most of the back of the restaurant and it was a total blast!!!
author: M'ia K.

description: I came here after they remodeled (sorry this review is a bit old). The Ginger Lemonade was SO ginger-y but delicious and so refreshing. As for the food it was a bit overpriced, I had the mango chicken however which was pretty good.
author: A C.

description:
I love Asian dishes but there comes a time that you have to realize that not all Asian cuisine is for you.   That is how I felt about Burmese food.  
We ordered;
Fish Chowder - tasted ok, nothing great
Tea Leaf Salad - I had to try it because everyone talked about it.  This was interesting, but not something that I would do again.
Samosa- This was oil soaked and very disappointing. The dipping sauce was a little weird - I would say sweet and sour with a squirt of siracha sauce?

I've been eating pretty healthy and there has been only a few things that made me feel bogged down like this - a burrito from a taco truck on International and this place.  I think it might too rich and fatty and my body is trying to reject it as I've been burping for the past 6 hours.

I had to try everything and realized that I'm over Burmese food.

stinky robot
author: StinkyTofu S.

description: Great food, great customer service!! The servers here make sure you are enjoying their food.. We tried some dishes on their recommendations and loved them. I am especially fond of their fish cakes, lamb rangoon, balada and the mandalay special noodle.. All their dishes have a nice and distinct flavour..
author: Chandrika G.

description:
Created a new Burmese food fan. 

Great service.  

Fresh ingredients with exquisite taste

Fantastic arrangement
author: Mike O.

description:
A TEA LEAF SALAD may be the only way to get me to the Richmond... and Mandalay serves an extremely delish one. I'm not going to compare to Burma Super Star b/c I think the more Burmese restaurants the better! Go to both! In fact, let's just go to Burma!!!

You won't have to wait at Mandalay! it's much less crowded in there, they serve cherries and bendable straws in their water, and Christmas ornaments dangle from the ceiling!! But ya, I'm not comparing...

The Walnut Broccoli Tofu is indeed honey kissed as they say. and yes - TEA LEAF SALAD. I've decided I'm just going to EAT tea from now on.. drinking is so overrated.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Chicken dishes had tiny pieces of breaded chicken. Not great.
Basil chicken didn't contain much basil, either.

Green beans were ok. Mongolian beef was good.

Samusa soup was fantastic.

Green papaya salad was also awesome.
author: L B.

description:
So I was here on a Wednesday night and it took us 20 minutes to get a table for 2.  On a Wednesday?!  For a second I thought I was at Burma Superstar but without the long line floating out the door.

But I must say this place is WAY better than Burma Superstar.  The seating arrangement is certainly much more comfortable and you don't feel like you walked into a food sauna.  

The Rainbow Salad was especially healthy and tasty.  The salad was prepared with eight ingredients served with house special dressing.  Overall the salad had a light and refreshing taste to it.

My friend had eaten here a few days back and wanted to reorder the Mandalay Special Noodles.  And we did.  Nothing too special for me and it is not a dish that is special in Burma (Myanmar).  It is only "special" at this restaurant.  Basically it's like garlic noodles but without the garlic and with dices of chicken, which I didn't taste until the end of the dish.  A more accurate description of it is: Burmese flat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow pea powder, lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top.  Needless to say, it does sound "special."

We also had the Rangoon Beef based on the recommendation of "Ashley M."  She had said that the beef was so soft that if you blew on it, it'd fall apart (almost).  We'll based on that I had to try it and low and behold the beef was nice and tender.  So I have to say that Ashley M.'s enthusiastic review was 110% accurate!  FYI, Rangood Beef is marinated beef sauteed with tomato, onions and green chili.

I also had a fresh coconut drink.  

I'd come here again for the salad and the rangoon beef.
author: Alan T.

description:
LOVE this place! Food is always top-notch, staff is always friendly. Here's a secret...If you don't order dessert, they'll give you some anyway. I love the dessert. It's coconut and sweet potato gelatin sticks--that sounds way gross, but believe me, its delish.

We always order the same thing:
Start w/ tea leaf salad  (the chicken coconut soup is also delicious, but then I'm too full for dinner)
Mango chicken is amazing, all white meat cubes with very fresh pieces of mango and onion.
Curried prawns are the best, non-fishy, freshest shrimp dish I've ever had. It's not a typical "curry." You just have to try it!
Order entrees w/ coconut rice...mmmmmm

I testify, this place SPANKS Burmastar. ;)
author: cali c.

description: Love love love this place!! The tea leaf salad is down right addicting, the spicy asparagus chicken, and basil beef are my favorites!  Great Burmese food, good service, and not nearly as croded as Burma Super Star.
author: Hope S.

description: The ONLY reason I didn't lick my plate clean was because I knew I'd be coming back -- soon! We got in without a wait on a Sunday evening and had a fantastic dinner. The samusa soup was an addicting combination of spicy and savory. The pumpkin curry was tasty and beautifully served in a squash. And the Mandalay noodles had us scratching our heads to figure out just why the flavors all went so well together. Everything that came out of the kitchen to the tables around us looked and smelled great!!
author: Jessica R.

description:
I was happily pleased when I went to Mandalay last night. The food was amazing and the service was wonderful as well.

The coconut rice mixed with the ginger lamb and fried battered squash sticks was a great mixture of tastes and smells.

The Mandalay noodles had a taste that just made me happy. 

I woke up this morning and polished off the leftovers, and they are still great!

I can't wait to go back.
author: Mark H.

description: Simply amazing! We got the Mandalay noodles, Mongolian beef and mushu shrimp. We couldn't decide which dish we liked better because they were all flavorful and unique. This place goes to the top of my favorite restaurant list in San Francisco!
author: Karin Z.

description:
What a surprise.  After reading the glowing reviews of Mandalay, last night we went there sure that the meal would be very good if not better.  Alas, life does throw some curves and our meal was one of them.  Four of us ordered tea leaf salad, mango salad, satay chicken-beef, Mandalay prawns, Mandalay beef and a noodle dish.  The mango salad and the noodle dish were quite good.  This is where the good news ends.

The tea leaf salad by comparison to that I've had in 2 other Burmese restaurants was lackluster with nuts being the predominant taste.  The satay chicken-beef was a few skewers each with a fairly tasteless stick of ground chicken and beef mixture accompanied by a bland dipping sauce.  We each ate one of these and left the rest. The Mandalay beef was simply bad - like over fried pieces of beef in a not appealing red sauce.  We left most of it on the serving platter.  The Mandalay prawns were 6 medium size shrimp in a tomato based sauce and that is what it tasted like.  I don't think anyone would willingly ruin decent shrimp with such an unappetizing sauce.

The opinions above were pretty much shared by all 4 of us.  I wonder what went wrong.  The restaurant was crowded and perhaps the kitchen was overloaded.  Maybe the chef had a night off.  Maybe I will return to give the restaurant another chance - maybe not..
author: Jed A.

description:
How did I grow up in the Richmond District and miss out on Mandalay?  All this time I believed that the only good Burmese restaurant in the lower avenues was the insanely over-hyped Burma Superstar, when I could have been enjoying my samosas at place where you can be seated almost instantaneously.  

The salads (crunchy lentils, peanuts, ginger, some kind of seed all mixed together), pumpkin curry (with tofu or chicken), green beans and samosas were divine, and the complimentary dessert (one looked like taro and the other was coconut) was sooo good.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Emma K.

description: Been coming here before it got busy.  Our friend's mom turned us into Samusa addicts and this is the only place that makes a close enough version to give us our fix.  Everywhere else only has vegetarian versions.  Love the Chicken Samusas, Mandalay Chicken, Rangoon Beef, Fish Chowder Soup, and Mandalay Noodles.  Only wish that the portions didn't keep diminishing as the prices keep rising.  Just discovered their fair lunch combos:  Soup and Rangoon Beef for $8/9 or Mandalay Chicken and Samusas for $11.50-Perfect.
author: Tony And Candace T.

description:
The food is GREAT with only a couple of exceptions, and the decor really pretty and exotic, but service/seating is problematic... which is why I knocked off a star.

I've eaten here 3 times, and I definitely recommend coming here during off hours since waits can be horrible even with reservations.  Twice, we had to wait 30 & 45 minutes past our reservation time... once for a party of 3, the other for a party of 8.  Having worked at restaurants before, I could tell that they really just didn't manage seating well (tables could have been put together)... and it didn't seem like there was much concern or planning. They didn't go out of their way to apologize, estimate seating time, or acknowledge they even remembered we were there waiting... thus, forcing me as the organizer, to keep reminding them we were there (which I hate to do... who needs that job?)

Some favorites include:
green tea salad (a bit more sour than other's I've tasted)
cinnamon & coconut rice
samosas
long green bean dish

I prefer this place to Nearby Burma Star.  Parking is a little easier on this much quieter street.
author: Terry B.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF is hands-down Burma Superstar. I thought that it had the best Burmese cuisine I've ever tasted.... until now. After eating at Mandalay, I wonder why everybody raves about Burma Superstar, while nobody talks about Mandalay?

PROS:
(1) Much shorter wait than Burma Superstar. Call ahead for reservations. If you don't, you should expect to wait about 45 minutes to an hour during peak hours. (Still better than Burma Superstar, though)

(2) Food was fantastic. My favorite was the crispy eggplant cubes. Damn I never though eggplant could be so well-made. I also loved the mango chicken and walnut shrimp as well. Quite possibly better than BS's.

(3) Service was incredible. Our waitress was this peppy young lady who seemed like she was overdosing on some happy pills. I love how they don't rush you, even though there's a crapload of people waiting (I guess this is bad for those who are waiting). I hate how at Burma Superstar they take away your plate when you still have food on it and they do it all fast & ninja-like so you're like: "But... but... but... wait..."

The One & Only CON:

Now two main reasons why I go to Burma Superstar is because of their Ginger Beer and their Rainbow Salad. After Mandalay, those are the two sole reasons why I would stick with Burma Superstar. Mandalay's ginger beer was like 90% sugar water and 5% beer and 5% ginger. It was way too sweet and I'd be surprised if it had any beer in it. We actually had to order an extra bottle of Tsingtao just to pour into it so that we could at least feel like we're drinking alcohol instead of Kool-Aid. And yeah, the Rainbow Salad at Burma Superstar is much better than at Mandalay.

All in all, I'd definitely come back to Mandalay -- unless I want ginger beer or Rainbow Salad. In that case (which is always), I'd stick w/ Burma Superstar.
author: Roy C.

description:
I'll add my vote to the group of "It's as yummy as Burma Superstar, but without the bitter bitter taste of a 2 hour wait stuck in the back of your mouth" reviews. Personally, I think this place could be just as popular as Burma Superstar if they simply used a name that wasn't so generic.

I recommend the Mandalay chicken (which are just chicken nuggets in a sauce made of pure deliciousness) and the mango prawns. The tea leaf salad is... interesting... I could see where people would love it or hate it. (My wife loves it -- I think it tastes a little too fishy.) Service has always been friendly and quick when I've been there, and they deliver, too!
author: Todd K.

description:
Shhh, it's Richmond's little secret against the Burma Superstar wait.  The restaurant is big and never filled (probably until the word gets out via Yelp, anyways).

Our dinner consisted of:
chicken lettuce cups
tea leaf salad
coconut chicken noodle soup
mandalay beef
fried string beans
burmese style noodles

All were very, very good!  It was difficult to walk back to the car afterwards.  We all felt like a blimp, but in a good way.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I was driven to finally try Mandalay after reading Ed M's review of this place.  I'm half chinese, does that make me privy to the chinkvine, Ed?  I dunno.  What I do know is that I've been hearing about  Mandalay for the past year or so, and it totally lived up to what I've heard.

Thanks so much to everyone who suggested the tea leaf salad (interesting and flavorful), the coconut rice,  and the walnut broccoli dishes (we chose chicken.)

I also ordered the house lemonade which came in a huge glass and was delicious.  One small detail which I loved is that all the drinks came with colorful bendy straws!  Including the water!  Yay!   I'll definitely be back to try more dishes.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
A week before trying this restaurant, I went to B* star but found it overrated and too fusion for my taste buds.  

For authentic Burmese food, I would highly recommend this place.  I came here twice, the first time, I phoned in a reservation 20 minutes prior to my arrival and was seated right away.  I feel in love with the Mandalay Special Noodle and instantly ate it all.  I knew I had to come back.  

So two weeks later, I came with a group of 10 but we were seat at a small round table.  It was pretty tight for 10 but luckily, the table next to us left and we got to separate into two tables.  Once again, I ordered the Mandalay Special Noodle along with Samusa, Curry Chicken, Mandalay Beef.  I brought along my Burmese friend and he even admit the place tasted really good.  It reminded him of his Mom's home cooking.  

Overall, everything was great, the waitress was really nice and humorous.  She was patient with us and repeated our order to make sure she didn't miss anything.  Two thumbs up!
author: wane a.

description:
Ate here for lunch on Monday, and it was tastee: fresh meat and veggies, sauce was good, rice was perfect.

$8 for Mango chicken, soup, rice and tea.  Good service, nice ambiance, and relaxing.  

It gets crowded at noon, so if you want a guaranteed seat - go at 11:30.

I'll be back.
author: Audra E.

description: I would give this restaurant 4 stars, but the food was incredibly slow so they lost a star. We ordered the tea leaf salad to share as an app and it took probably like 25 minutes before it was served. The salad itself was great, though.  20 minutes after we were done with the salad, our entrees came out- we got the Mandalay beef and the string beans with seafood. The timing would've been fine for a crowded dinner hour, but it was lunch on Sunday and the restaurant wasn't even full. I'd come back for the food, but I really hope the service is better next time.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I'm beginning to sense that people are catching onto this place b/c the last time I came here there was about a 15-20 min. wait to get a table (it was a weeknight too). The Burma Superstar customers are finally catching on to this little gem.

Everything that I've had here was excellent. You must love garlic to eat here b/c most of the dishes have large quantities of it. It's no problem for me... at least my bf and I both end up stinking for the rest of the night; we get desensitized by our own stank. :)  I recommend getting the Tea Leaf Salad, Mandalay Special Noodles, Lemongrass Seafood Soup, and the Mango Prawns. Mmmm! It makes me drool just to think about it. The service here is very attentive and friendly. The prices are reasonable. What's not to love about this place?

Oh... to add to the cool factor of this restaurant...  while I was waiting in line I was glancing around, people watching to kill some time. A freak out moment came over me when I realized John Waters standing next to my bf trying to get a table as well.
author: Athena E.

description:
Had the Orka Prawns pan fried in garlic ginger spicy sauce here yesterday and it was surprising good.  I've only had Orka maybe once or twice and it is definitely not something that I can cook on my own.  It was so good in fact that we had to order a second.  This menu is a nice change from what is offered at most other places in the neighborhood.

Apparently the table next to us was having a birthday because halfway through our dinner, they started blaring a "Happy Birthday" song over the speakers, then all the waitresses came out and presented her with a huge ice cream sundae.  Kinda corny but kinda cute also.  :)
author: Judy K.

description:
Came here with a group of friends and had a great time and the food was delicious! The server, Vicky was extremely patient with us and gave us great recommendations. 

For appetizers we had samusas (chicken & vegetarian), dumplings (pork & vegetarian), the rainbow salad and THE MOST DELICIOUS bread with a curry dipping sauce.  The mandalay noodles were my favorite entree.

The xmas ornaments hanging from the ceiling were very festive, hilarious and random. 

Oh and did I mention we ate a ton of food with 8 people and the bill came out to $29 pp including a 20% tip???!!!! yeah!

If you are in the mood for Burmese, this is where its at! I will be returning very soon :)
author: Veronica P.

description:
We're in love with this place.  They are so nice, and the food is delicious.  Have taken many friends here, and all have loved it.

Recommend: Brocolli Walnut Chicken, Coconut Rice, any of the salads.
author: Chris Q.

description: Pricey and most of the dishes lack a true Burmese taste. Believe me I am a Burmese. Born and raised there. But still not bad. Burmese don't put coconut milk in curry. That's Thai style.
author: Pan P.

description:
I went to Burma Superstar and Mandalay in recent weeks, and while both are excellent, I would choose Mandalay over BS for the following reasons:

-No or shorter wait (we were seated on a Friday night immediately even without reservations; at BS, we went on a Monday night and still had a 20 minute wait despite calling ahead and putting our names on the list. Some girls who were waiting when we were seated were still waiting when we finished our meal.)

-Bigger space: you're not crammed together and eating within a foot of the next table. At BS, they crammed 3 of us around a table for 2 that was tilted.

-Beautiful decor: both places were decorated but Mandalay's was nicer in my opinion

-Food: both offered excellent dishes. The one thing Mandalay beat BS on was the fried bread (balada). Manaday's was a large layered pancake with a yummy curry sauce. I could've eaten the whole thing by myself. BS had a small piece that crumbled when you tried to tear or cut it and no sauce. We had the Rainbow Salad, Rangoon Beef, Samusas, Homemade Noodles with Chicken and Fish Filet with black bean sauce, plus the Balada and a bowl of coconut rice. Everything was excellent. The dessert choices looked good but we were too full. Bill came out to $17 a person.

-Service: polite and friendly at both places. BS was a little slower.
author: Wen T.

description: Went with HD and SS on a Friday night after 540 Club.  Packed with people.  Servers have really pleasant attitudes.  Crispy pancake and smoked tea duck were both excellent - very similar to the Chinese versions.  Other dishes were pretty standard fare.
author: Eric C.

description: I am a food lover and love Burmese food but this is less than average: cold food, little flavor, low quality meat. Not to mention a 45 mns wait to get served. Even the wine is really not that good. I strongly recommend Burma Supertar or B-Star, in the same neighborhood.
author: Steph S.

description:
The meat (fish) eaters in the party went into fits of ecstasy over the prawn in basil sauce.   Personally I prefer the tea leaf salad and samusas at Burma Super Star.

This is however a comparatively spacious, chill and friendly alternative not two blocks away if Burma proves to be too much.   And probably more authentic.
author: kellan e.

description:
Good food, fresh, clean. Good ingredients. Chicken dishes are good, the chicken is tender not rubbery and nasty like some other places.
flavors are good. Gooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooood is the word for this place at this time. Basil Chicken, mango chix all good. the coconut dessert is creamy and so nice in your mouth.
okay that the mood for now, yum yum good.
author: SForiginal T.

description:
While this place is a little pricey for the amount, what isn't in SF? That being said, when my Aunts took me and my mom here the first time, we were sold. We left it up to them to order their usual dishes, and seeing how they knew the owners, we trusted that we were in good hands.

The food was good, a little salty, but still good. The coconut rice was delicious, just enough sweetness but still savory. I love the samosas...by FAR my favorite dish of all the ones I've tried from here (we went back a couple times and showed other family members). I also like their burmese iced tea, its similar to thai tea except not as sweet and i think they might use evaporated milk instead of half&half.

I think what really sold me was how cute this place is. The decor is great and gives a nice vibe, almost like you're on vacation for the time being. The middle row of tables are really cute for dates. It's almost cubicle-like, but in a good way, you feel like you're in a private little nook. 

Going with people that know the owner was a big plus, we ended up getting free goodies with our meal. I will definitely be going back to this place whenever I'm in SF
author: Shelly A.

description: Definitely my favorite Burmese restaurant in the city (better than Burma Superstar).  Really delicious food, great service, and prices/portions have Burma Superstar beat for sure!  If you've never had Burmese food, this is the perfect place to try it out, so delicious and tasty. This used to be the closest restaurant to my apartment so I've had it quite a few times :) consistently delish!
author: Emily M.

description: The food here is very good, I personally like the walnut tofu, and they also have pretty unique ginger lemonades. The tea leaf salad is good and you can ask for meat powder on the side to make any of the salads vegetarian. It's not the best for a college budget it's not super overpriced, though I definitely wouldn't classify it as cheap. The service is usually pretty good but you should plan on spending some time waiting because during dinner time it gets really crowded.
author: Ashley A.

description:
Arrived at this place with my hubby on Monday evening to celebrate our anniversary.
Decor is very lovely and romantic with a lot of fresh flowers .
 We ordered Rainbow Salad ,Basil Beef  , Rainbow Prawn , Walnut Prawn and Saffron Rice . All food tastes fresh and delicious.
Love it very much! Will come back next time for sure.
author: Liana L.

description: Tried all the recommended dishes that everyone on here said to try. Also, got a few choices from our server's recommendations list. Every dish was good. It was probably like my 3rd time eating Burmese food. I enjoyed this experience way better compared to my dining experience at Burma Superstar. No waiting for 20-30 mins for a table and its not super cramped inside. Its pretty spacious. I will come again if ever my gf craves for this food.
author: Jeff C.

description: Went on a Saturday night with a group of 5 and loved it. Some of the best vegetarian dishes I have ever had. The broccoli with walnuts was awesome! They were pros at getting people in and out quickly and managing the long line of people waiting. The waiter also made some great suggestions.
author: S O.

description:
Exotic.  Enticing. Boisterous.

Mandalay is the true "Superstar" of Burma!  The wait is half as long, the place is twice as big, the interior is beautifully decorated, and the servers - well, the servers are perhaps too excited to be there, but it's not a bad thing.

Went with group of 7 for Krys S. new job celebration! (hooray!) and got a sampling of everything.  My pepper soup was deliciously calming: lots of black peppery spice, but not too much to upset my capricious tummy.  The broth was soothingly clean and the glass noodles and seaweed added a nice depth.

Coconut rice is leaps and bounds more flavorful than Burma Superstar's.
Tea leaf salad packs more punch than BS's.
Ginger lemonade is sexy and snappy.
Complimentary warm sweet potato cakes are divine! 
(Tea leaf duck looked a little dry, accompanying buns were a little flavorless)

$$110 for party of 7?  Sounds like a deal to me!

Know Before You Go:
1. Call ahead to put your name on the wait list on busy nights!
author: Jane L.

description:
Let me try to write a review of Mandalay without mentioning Burma Superstar.

Mandalay Bay is basically a cheaper, less classier version of Burma Super...ah fuck.

I visited the place with 3 of my friends last night and we ordered various dishes (as opposed to ordering the same dish 5 times)

The waiter brought out the 10 ingredient tea leaf salad and mixed it in front of our eyes, as if to show that they didn't hide any broken glass or hand grenades. I hate to see the lawsuit that forced that rule.

The basil beef was done well and tasty, as well as the walnut noodles, the tofu and the sizzling shrimp.  they even offered us some free desserts. Hmmm coconut and squash.  Two great taste that go together. Well not really. Maybe if you were a chimpanzee living in Burma....
author: Huyness D.

description:
All the food we ordered were good and my fav is the tea leaf salad! I forgot the version at Burma Superstar but Mandalay's version is definitely tasty. The servers will introduce all ingredients before mixing each dish at the table. Attentive and quick service.

Thank goodness our lovely friend made reservations since the place was full at 7:30pm. As Helen Y pointed out, I could eat here again minus the outrageously long lines at Burma Superstar.
author: Yan M.

description:
underpromise.  overdeliver.  this should be the golden rule when restaurants disclose to you the wait time before you get fed.

for example, mandalay should have said 1 hour instead of 15 minutes, when we asked how long the wait was for our group of 4.  it was 45 minutes.  i mean, we probably would have waited anyway, since it was cold and rainy and we still wanted burmese food.

get:
roti prata with curry dipping sauce
samusas
pumpkin curry with prawns
tea leaf salad (a must must)

pass:  curry chicken noodle special.  blah.
author: Josie M.

description:
I've been here twice.  The first time my friend took me here around 8:45 pm on a weekday night -- only a few tables were occupied when we entered.  The second time was with my husband on a Saturday night....very long wait and we were late for our movie.  Even when we were seated it took forever to get our dishes....

My point it...avoid coming here during peak times...just like Burma Superstar (although not as a long of a wait)

Ok...the food...is excellent.

I recommend the Mandalay Noodles (I've only had the chicken) my favorite dish!! They mix all the ingredients at your table and I would describe the flavor as creamy -- almost thai -- with a kick of citrus, cilantro, and even nuts.  The noodles look like linguini...interesting.

The Mango chicken is also really really good!!!

I don't remember what else I ate...but these 2 are the most memorable!  I'll be back!
author: Sheila S.

description: I've never had Burmese food before eating at Mandalay. A lot of it is a fusion of Chinese and Thai and other southeast Asian foods. Some of the more distinctive dishes, such as their tea leaf salad, have their ingredients separated on a dish, explained and then mixed in front of you. The food here in general is pretty good, the atmosphere nice and fun. The wait can be long and a bit slow. For people especially used to Chinese and Thai food, it might be more fun to order the less ordinary dishes, 'cuz they're more different and unique. A pretty good place.
author: Dave Y.

description:
I love that this restaurant is right around the corner AND doesn't keep you waiting for hours and hours....I also like the warm, comfortable atmosphere on foggy nights.  We like to take out of towners here especially if they've never had Burmese food.

I especially recommend their appetizers and salads such as the rainbow salad and mango salad.  Mmmm, mango salad.  Also, fried bananas with ice cream.

However, minus one star because once I went with a friend who is shrimp-allergic and very clearly requested that her noodles not be made with shrimp powder or dried shrimp.  She sent it back, but not before taking a few bites and realizing their mistake.  You can't make those kinds of mistakes, Mandalay.  At least you should have comped her dinner.
author: Laura T.

description:
A stone's throw from Burma Superstar is Mandalay Bay, where we weren't given a 1hr estimate for a table.  We did end up waiting for about 30 minutes, even though we were told 5, but I can forgive that given the way it turned out.

Every dish we ordered was good-to-excellent.  I don't think you can go wrong.  The Burmese iced tea was flavorful but not too sweet.  The chicken samusa was fried just enough -- crispy and light -- and had a good flavor.  Our other appetizer was the tea leaf salad, which came out served on a plate with all of the components separate.  Our waiter enumerated them and mixed them all together in front of us.  It was strange, but delicious.  The tofu-curry rice noodles (I forget the Burmese name...) was served in a similar way, on a large platter with extra seasoning and ingredients arrayed around the edges.  Our server mixed them all together and helpfully explained what everything was.  

We also ordered curry chicken, which was consistent and well-made, some preparation of sliced beef, which was excellent, walnut tofu with broccoli (mmm... candied walnut), szchezuan-style green beans with prawn, and coconut rice.

For dessert, we had some burmese sweet-potato cake and tapioca with paluda syrup with ice cream.  The paluda (falooda) was great.  I wasn't so much a fan of the sweet-potato gel-cake thingy.

So, the food was good, the staff was helpful, and their recommendations were great.  The coolest thing about this place was the music they were playing.  Burmese covers of english soft-rock classics are the most insidiously awesome songs to play in the background.  You hear them, you recognize them, but then you realize they're in Burmese and that you've been the target of careful mind-control all night.  Our server told us they got the CD in Burma, and they didn't expect to see it in the US.  Boo.  I want to get that music.  Yes, it was that cool.  Maybe if I go back there and bring some blank CD-Rs...
author: Jay M.

description:
So....I'm still definitely in a food coma from my dinner today at Mandalay but I had to sit down at the computer and rave about what an AMAZING dinner I just ate.  My friend Chris and I had the: 

1.  Mandalay special noodles
2.  Mandalay  Mango Chicken
3.  Mandalay Beef
4.  Coconut rice

...and it was all sooooooooo good, especially the noodles.  I really liked how the waitress explained to us the ingredients and then slowly mixed them all together at the table....but the end I was totally salivating.  

At the end the owner (?) thanked us for coming, brought us dessert on the house and asked us where we heard about the restaurant (omg thank you YELP!).  

Though parking was a pain (as it typically is in that neighborhood), we only waited 10 minutes at 8pm on a Saturday night.  I really think that the food and quality of service really surpassed BurmaSuperstar (especially the lack of wait).  This place is definitely one of my new favorites and I will be back!!!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Service was great, the food was great, I'll be back.  I love that the service is always great and I don't have to battle lines of people wanting to eat trendy burmese food like at Burma Superstar.

The tea salad, not spectacular, but I can see how some might love it.  It just seems like a small amount of food for the $8 entry fee, and not special enough to justify.

The Samusa salad was surpisingly good, chopped up samusa with some veggies and a sweet sauce on top.

The samusa soup was quite good, 95% as flavorful as the Burma Superstar but more hearty and I'd definitely order it again, filling and a better value than the salad for the same price.  Adding a touch of lemon to the dish makes it closer to the slightly tangying flavor of Burma Superstar.

The Balada was excellent, it was just the right blend of crispy and chewy and although the dipping sauce wasn't the best I've ever had, the spicy chili sauce they give you at the table more than made up for any deficit in flavor.  A great value at $5.  That and the soup is most of the way towards filling two people up.  

We also ordered the Mandalay chicken, which was unfortunately a letdown, especially surprising considering I love orange chicken and general tso/chao/cho/chow/etc   But while the meat was quality white meat the flavor just wasn't up to snuff, even compared to good lowly dollar Chinese food joints.

The rainbow chicken was good, lightly fried, with sweet pinapple.  Not as rich as your traditional sweet and sour sauce, very lightly done.  

The string bean dish was great, tasty and fresh.

The saffron rice was tasty, and I'd try that again.

All in all the service was great, the atmosphere was far more relaxed than at Burma Superstar where I always feel crowded and rushed.

I will try to go back here for lunch specials as a way to explore the menu further without breaking the bank
author: Stephen H.

description:
Mandalay is the city's superstar for Burmese food. 

Samusa Salad: Cut-up samosas with salad. Best when first served. But texture freaks beware, the crispy samosas become soggy after awhile.

Jia San Hinga (Bean thread noodle soup): Tasty yet strong pepper-flavored soup. The fish has a nice hint of wine. 

Tea-smoked Duck: Similar to Chinese-style Peking duck with mini baos, hoisin, green onions but just no crispy skin. Smokey flavor is niiiiice. 

Mango Chicken: Scrumptious lil' chicken nugs with mango chunks and slightly caramelized onions. 

Coconut Rice: Solid. Best I've had to date. 

-NCM
author: Chiu Man N.

description: We came to Mandalay because Burma Superstar had 1.5 hr wait, and it turned out that it was even better! There's a great vibe, the service was fantastic, and the food was sooo delicious. I coconut chicken noodle soup is one of the best things I have ever eaten.
author: Kate G.

description:
Having only had a cupcake for lunch, my bff and I were starving when we arrived at 5:30 today. I was amazed at how many diners there were already (must be all the Yelp reviews!). We ordered half the menu...Saffron rice, tea smoked duck, Samusas, tea leaf salad, dry fried string beans, and noodles along with the soup. A lot of food for 2? Okay, so we rolled outta there. 
The duck was disappointing, too fatty. I guess I'm spoiled. Only place to get duck is Great China in Berkeley. Enough duck 101. The tea leaf salad is nothing like I've had before. Bff really enjoyed. I polished off the Samusas. Saving the best for last the noodles...WOW...you get hit with so many different flavors and textures in this one dish. Little pieces of potato, fried tofu, cucumber, cilantro, onions, and garlic....not to mention all those other ingredients I can't quite make out. String beans and rice were incredible too. After all this, we managed to share the Mango ice-cream for dessert. Kinda bummed that they didn't have the Mango pudding that Jan Z. had the night before. Get the Ginger tea...so refreshing.
The servers are very attentive here, always asking how your meal is. Only thing was, not sure what happened to leftovers from the little Mantau buns from the duck and the rest of the string beans. Did YOU get it? I want it back....hahaha!
author: Arlene C.

description:
Actually 3 1/2 stars. Food tasted great, but unfortunately service took a looong minute. 

Really not a bad place for your better than usual fix for Asian food. This place seem to have mixed Burmese, Chinese and Thai food all in one menu. Big plus for location off the Clement street, so finding parking seems to be less of a madness.

Picks:
- Coconut Rice
- Burmese Lamb Curry
- Burmese Bread (I am sure it has an authentic name, but that's what was on the menu)
author: Misha K.

description:
If I hadn't built Mandalay up in my head from the great yelp reviews and from talking with friends, and had just stumbled upon it, I'm sure I would have been awed.  Unfortunately, because I hyped it up, I was a little disappointed.  

The ambiance is nice - high ceilings; lots of space between tables.  The service is amazing.  

The chicken satay was delicious  - a generous 6 large skewers and wonderful peanut dipping sauce.  

The tea leaf salad was very good - I feel like it wasn't as good as I remembered from Burma, but I haven't been to Burma in a while and I can't be sure about that.

The dried sauteed string beans were excellent - appropriately spicy and flavored.  Cooked, but no over cooked - they didn't lose their crunch and were not soggy.

The kong pao chicken was terrible.  It wasn't spicy, there were hoards of mushrooms in it, not many peanuts, tons of non-spicy peppers...    But, I am not deducting a star for that because, I was the idiot who ordered kong pao chicken at a Burmese restaurant... Still, part of me feels like if you don't know how to make something, it shouldn't be on your menu.

Given everything, I will definitely go back.  I'll definitely get the chicken satay and string beans again.  Especially given the very reasonable prices, great service, and great ambiance.
author: Cara C.

description:
This is Burma Superstar counterpart with the exact same menu, two blocks away on California, and have no wait. 

Why haven't all those people who stand in line for over an  hour at Burma Superstar just walk over here and grub? It's kind of a best kept secret, beecause the food is really good. Burmese food reminds me of Thai and a little bit of Vietnamese/Chinese? Good southeast asian food... 

Try the tea leaf salad - it's nutty, savory, and has a really fresh crunch to it. I didn't know fermented tea leaves can be so good. 

Pumpkin curry is definitely different from the normal yellow curry you can get anywhere else. I also had the beef curry and the chicken curry. I don't know why tried so many kinds of curry from there, but they were all good. Pumpkin one trumps everything else. 

The portions are kind of on the small side, mid range price (9-15 bucks) and is probably good to go with a couple of people so that you can share dishes.
author: Miss Pigg y.
The Puppydawg ..

description:
I was told by a coworker to go here because the line at Burma Super Star is always so damn long. 

What a great f'ing recommendation.  We ordered the rainbow salad - YUM.  We ordered the broccoli/walnut - oh my god.  I don't know anyone else who can make broccoli and walnuts taste so great.  I was so pleasantly pleased with the food - we ordered a few other dishes and everything was good, but standouts were the two listed above. 

Bonuses - tons of parking on the nearby streets AND the 1-line goes right by the restaurant!
author: Bhumika K.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  

I absolutely LOVE the tea leaf salad here...its absolutely perfect!  I crave it so often that I used to constantly harass the owner into telling me where I could buy the leaves to make the salad myself.  She would always try to convince me that she travels to Burma to get it from relatives (which I absolutely did not believe --sometimes just to shut me up she would give me some to take home for later)...so after searching and searching, I finally found where to get it locally...and I can finally make it myself (and without flying to Burma)

My second favorite dish is something called "Naked Eggplant" which is not on the menu (just ask for it) and then have them add shrimp.  its wonderful!  Very tender and delicate dish.  The only dish I didn't like was some sort of sour vegetable dish. 

Anyway, the owner is a really sweet woman and I am always so impressed that she takes our order without a pen and paper and never misses a beat.  I love this place and come here as often as I can.

It is MUCH better than Burma Super Star, which I believe is very overrated.
author: Krista K.

description: Wonderful tea leaf salad to start, followed by pan fried string beans, Mandalay noodles, mango chicken, and curry lamb.  We love Mandalay!
author: Gino R.

description: Came here last Friday after a swearing in ceremony at USF.  My niece called and they sat a group of nine immediately which was kind of alarming.  Really on a Friday night?  Well it seems like we got lucky and beat the dinner rush.  Server was nice, gave a little run down on Burmese food.  Food was great...LOVED the papaya  and the fish cake salads.  Couldn't tell you what else we ordered, but it was delish, free dessert also.  Minus one star, it took forever and four reminders for the check.  Would definitely come back here.
author: Marsh-Silog P.

description:
This is my favorite Burmese joint. When I have a craving for Moo Hin Nga or Fish Chowder soup and can't get my hands on some homemade version, I come here. I usually stick to that and the Green Papaya Salad.

Other dishes I tried that were okay:
- Nan Gyi Dok / Burmese rice noodle with spiced coconut chicken, split yellow pea, powder, and fried onion (salad version of below, which is better)
- Ong No Kaw Soi / Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup with onion, cilantro, and lemon
- Satay Beef Skewers 

I agree that the servers need to communicate to each other more and stop keep going to the same table asking the same question. They asked us at least 5 times if we wanted dessert. The wait is a lot longer than it used to be but still beats Burma Super Star.
author: Katie K.

description:
ok, I will agree with the other 4 and 5 star reviews that the food is good.  I especially liked the coconut noodle soup and cat fish soup.  Very tastey.  HOWEVER, you need to be aware that you get very little noodles.  That was a major disappointment for me and that's where they fell short a star.  The entree dishes weren't outstanding, they were ok.  The tea leaf salad was also on the small side.

I've eaten at other Burmese places and Mandalay's portions are on the smaller side.
author: Will I A m.

description:
I'm writing this review, mostly to disagree with my brother.  That's what siblings do, don't they?

While I do agree with his point about waiting, (our party wasn't seated until a full hour after our reservation time), I really did enjoy my first Burmese food experience.

Fortunately, we had a large group, and got to order a number of dishes.  Some of the items we tried:

1. Tea Leaf Salad - by the name, I expected it to be bitter.  But it was actually good, and garlicy.  I didn't even mind the peanuts in the salad.  I'm not normally a fruit-or-nuts-in-food, kind of gal.

2. Pan Fry Okra Prawn - this was the best dish we ordered.  The okra wasn't soggy and the prawns were tasty.

3. Pumpkin Curry Chicken - the sqaush flavor was subtle, and made the dish feel earthy and comforting.

4. Mandalay Chicken - sadly, this was a disappointment, compared to the other items we ordered.  I learned that "Mandalay" pretty much means fried and then covered in sauce.  This dish reminded me of something from Panda Express.

Overall, I'd definitely come back.  And even moreso, I am curious to try its nemesis Burma Superstar.
author: Chanelle W.

description:
I just called them, and they say they are not delivering anymore :(

Yelp won't let me post without putting a rating, so I put 3 stars (an estimate of the other ratings and my disappointment). That's not the rating though. 

I just wanted to let everyone know they're not delivering bc it's a bummer when you get all psyched up and they say "no, sorry". Not sure if it's permanent or temporary, if you have any news, pls post it.
author: Amy T.

description:
think annie.....entering daddy warbucks' mansion...

I THINK IM GONNA LIKE IT HERE...
author: coffeecake j.

description: My friend and I ordered three things:  tea leaf salad, pea shoots and beef curry.  All were super yummy.  I liked the festive ambiance and the food.  I didn't like the pressure we got from staff to hurry up and eat , especially since no one was waiting for a table.  In this case, their efficiency felt smothering.  Same thing happened with the bill.   In the end it is about the food for me, so I'll definitely be back.
author: Andrea S.

description: This was my first foray into Burmese cuisine and I can't wait to go back again! The interiors are crammed with a collection of art and crafts that hark back to Burma. Our hostess was very gracious and solicitous, reminding me of the 5 star service I used to receive in Thailand. The food was excellent, as many other Yelpers can attest to. Try it all! I don't think I had anything that was not delicious. The only drawback to coming here, due to their continued popularity, is the wait and the parking. It took me over 30 minutes to snag a parking spot around the neighborhood, about 5 blocks away. Then when I hiked back to the restaurant, my companions had just been seated. That is the only thing that would make me hesitate going back there again. But the tea leaf salad would make me forget all that in a heartbeat!
author: Eric T.

description: Very good restaurant. Quick service, friendly staff and good food. Mango Chicken and Mandalay Eggplant (I believe that was the name). Were very good. The eggplant was huge chunks...moist on the inside crunchy on the outside.
author: Trang P.

description:
Woweee! 
This place never disappoints!  Here are my staples:
Green tea salad. Mmm to the toasted garlic in it
Coconut rice.  It tastes as good as it smells
Mango chicken or shrimp. To die for !
Mandalay special noodle: Do not miss this dish
Basil spicy eggplant.  oh gawd yummmm!

I want to try more, but I can't help but order the same above food every time. My next plan is to go with a group so I can order the above items and more!

This is my favorite Burmese spot.

The good: Service and Food, and cute decorations
The bad: Can be noisy, deserts are ok.
author: Suzy M.

description:
I'm not sure I agree with the assessment that this place is better than Burma Superstar or B Star.  While the service was a little more friendly than Burma Superstar and the wait wasn't nearly as long (5 minutes here), the quality of food here isn't as good as Burma Superstar.  I'm not sure if it's more authentic or what, but it just didn't compare.

We had the Ginger Salad which was ginger and a bunch of peanuts and fried garlic.  Didn't blow us away.  The tea leaf salad doesn't have any lettuce (like Burma Superstar's).  

We also ordered a tofu/veggie dish, and while serving we discovered a piece of PORK in our dish.  Um, yuck.

The Mandalay noodles had tofu, coconut sauce and fried garlic.  Mediocre.

I was also disappointed they didn't have Samusa soup on their menu.  Turns out, it was a special, but we didn't notice the special menu until we were leaving, nor did the server bother to tell us other dishes were available.

Worth a try, but probably won't go back here.
author: mazzy r.

description:
Drool. I'm still thinking about the Mandalay House Special Noodle (w/ chicken). So good. Also ordered the spicy basil eggplant, but when we said medium spicy, it actually came out mild... so minor bummer, but it was still really fresh and nothing a little chili sauce couldn't fix. They also ran out of brown rice, but gave us coconut rice instead. Very subtle flavors, but good.

I. want. more.

Saturday night at 8:30 and didn't have to wait more than 15 minutes for a table. Not bad considering it was packed from table to table.

Cheesy decor yes, but excellent service and food.

Can't wait to try the other items on the menu!
author: Jeanne C.

description: By far the BEST burmese food in town. Much much much better quality meals than the other burmese restaurants that are raved about.
author: A T.

description: Great place to eat lunch.... Samusas were soo good
author: Cara L.

description: The food is delicious (and the tea leaf salad is classic), but for the price I'd expect larger portions. I ordered a shrimp dish that only came with 3 shrimp! Very nice servers though!
author: Emma B.

description:
What a pleasant suprise!!  This place has opened up the space (knocked out a wall that used to make this place look cramped), and generally jazzed up the flavors.  The Rangoon Beef and the Mongolian Chicken were very good, the Palata mediocre.

Service was strained- two poor servers were covering the whole place so food arrived painfully slowly.
author: S H.

description:
Honestly - I'm about to start singing Abba's "Winner Takes It All"... you'll see why in a minute.

Yes! Thanks to the other great yelp reviews, I tried this place for take-out today. YUM!! 

I'm so happy I could sing - except my mouth is full of savory tea leaf salad - right now at this very moment!!

I can't say if the food is equal to or better than B Superstar (the two hour wait at that place prevents me from going), but I have a hunch it might even be better. And the atmosphere is decidedly more relaxed. 

I got the tea leaf salad and the brocolli walnut chicken. 

They were playing BURMESE versions of ABBA songs when I went in to pick up my food, and it sounded just like Abba except in Burmese! The decor and vibe is excellent, and service was very warm and friendly. I love this place.
author: Kent W.

description:
I am not familiar with Burmese food. I tried Burmese super star.. it wasn't that superb for me. 
Mandalay was surprisingly good, the Mandalay house special noodles and orka prawn were excellent. I will definitely go back to eat that again. This place is perfect for casual dinner with friends. yummm... i am drooling just thinking about it.
author: Ervinna L.

description:
So, it was a warm Friday night, and the husband and I wanted to try some place new for dinner...one where we can walk to and enjoy the balmy evening. So we walked from 21st Ave and Clement to California and 6th Ave where we found Mandalay Restaurant. Yes, we've had burmese before (at that "other" burmese restaurant) but we wanted to try a new place. We are so glad we did!

First, we were a little put off as there was a huge line of people. But that must be a good sign of a good restaurant, right? Luckily, the wait wasn't too bad (maybe 20 minutes?), and we were able to look at the menu until they called out our name.

For an appetizer, we ordered the Fried Squash and Eggplant combo. I was really surprised at the amount of pieces we were given. It could have fed a group of 6 easily! The sauce was a beautiful mixture of sweet and spicy.

For our main entree, we ordered the Walnut Broccoli Chicken, whose sauce was perfect to pour over our steamed rice. The honey kissed walnuts definitely made the dish. 

But the Mandalay Special Noodles was by far the best  of everything we ordered. When the server came to our table, she explained what each of the ingredients were before she mixed them all together right in front of us. The lemon-ey, velvet-ey coconut sauce lightly coated the flat noodles, chicken, fried onion and crunchy chow mein noodles. We couldn't stop saying, "mmmm...uhhhhh...mmmmm...yummmm". 

And just when we thought we couldn't eat any more, the server came back with some mango pudding. WOW. it was like a mango flavored custard/flan. So flavorful yet not too sweet.

We absolutely enjoyed our meal and will definitely come back again and again and again.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Update 2:
Singapore style noodles!! MMM! I went back here and absolutely loved the Singapore style noodles and the paratha with curry! I can't save enough about this place. I've never been to Burma Superstar, but I think this is the go-to-spot for Burmese food. Mmm. 
Although the service could've been better. It wasn't that packed and I had to ask for napkins to 3 different wait staff to finally get some.  The owner looked stressed out too. Good thing the food is bomb though.
author: James C.

description: We really enjoyed this restaurant. The lamb curry was fantastic and the chicken mango was first rate. The rainbow salad was delicious too. This salad wasn't the tea leaf salad one would experience at Burma Superstar but still worth the price. Very attentive service and a free mango dessert. This was a great alternative to Burma SS and cheaper without the wait. Check it out-it's a great place for Burmese!
author: david w.

description:
They've earned the extra 5 star point!  Here's why, my party of 3 had called ahead to put our names down on the "list".  When we got there, we still had to wait at least 30-45 mins after being skipped a couple times.  BUT they made up for it with complimentry wine and desert.  Can't go wrong there. 
I'm surprised I haven't yelped about it already.  For bday celebrations, it's good to keep the party no more than 4-6.  This place does not have too much room to accomodate larger parties.  The portions of the food are good for 4.  I realized that after comming here for my bday with 12+ people.  As for comparing it to Burma Superstar like everyone says, I believe this place has more flavors.  

**Get there early or else you'd be competing for a parking space! Spent at least 30 mins! Longest ever in SF!
author: Christi S.

description:
Calgon... take me away?  Here is a little slice of Burma right off California street.

Need a break from the hole in the wall a little too authentic Clement street for something you can sit and enjoy?  Fear not, this is your place.

I haven't had a bad meal here, and after 4-5 trips in I'm a believer that they  can do no wrong.  Personal favorites are the Tealeaf salad, Mandalay chicken, walnut broccoli chicken and rainbow chicken.  One item we found a bit boooorrring was the Sizzling soup.  The chicken satay  was just average too.

While they offer a fairly quick pick up, the restaurant is worth a dine-in experience.  If you are lucky the server will bring you a nice complimentary fruit dessert.

Stop reading these reviews, 150 people hold power, so make your reservation or start walking to Mandalay now.
author: Dave E.

description:
Ahhh...the taste of Burma singeing my brain and tongue...today was such a kicker my stomach is still wallowing in all it's full splendor...I may cry tears of curry for days.

My group of 10 was ready and armed with moolah to chow down. First off, absolutely beautiful table decor and lovely interiors. I love the tiny floating red and white heart petals floating in the serenity lotus bowl. I also love the vase full of flowers. Nice touch!

The Burmese Ice tea and the lemonade were presented in really tall glasses. My tapioca coconut milk was soothing and juicy.
The Tea leaf salad was succulent with garlic, spices and crunchy lentil seeds...tangy salty sour...it was a mouthful of interesting! You know we love vegetarian egg rolls when we ordered it 3x in a row. Wow, the presentation was exceptionally cute..in a giant glass cup with the dipping sauce in the center. We had to slap down Steve for trying to be a food hoarder..nuh-uh..we don't play that in foodie land...it's all sharing at this table. 

Mandalay Beef (Fried beef slices sauteed with garlic and chef's delicious hot sauce)...spicy and juicy beef was delicious. And I thought we were doing just Burmese...who the heck ordered Mongolian Beef? (glances at Steve again..sigh..) but it was really good too. Mango Chicken, Mango Prawn, Rainbow Chicken...dang we had so much mango, I can feel it coming out of the pores...all of them were so good, we had to dig into second rounds. Fish Fillets with Black Bean Sauce was light and delicately flavored. Pan Fried Prawns with String Beans...a wonderful mixture of seasoned salty, peppery, spicy goodness.

I got the Nan Gyi Dok (Burmese rice noodle with spiced coconut chicken, split yellow pea, powder, and fried onion)..I thought the coconut could be stronger, but otherwise, it was delicious. The Singapore Style Noodles had the thin vermicelli noodles with shrimp pieces was spiced just right. We had kids at the table so we had to do the Combination Fried Rice (the chicken chunks were plentiful as opposed to other places that usually skimp) and coconut rice (wow! a new way to chew my carbs).

The service was wonderful and prompt. I have to give them kudos because they cleared our table efficiently and they also gave us complimentary agar agar & taro topping jello for the whole gang. YAY!! Free Food too!!

One mention, the music in this place is hella funny...I've never heard of ACDC done quite in that style of techno before.

Parking is challenging but do-able. Best to travel towards Lake street to search for possibilities.
author: Pauline L.

description:
My wife and I went here for dinner on Nov. 21, 2010.  The food was ABSOLUTELY UNBELIEVABLE!!!  It was so incredibly flavorful, delicious, fresh and authentic.  We regularly eat Thai and Malaysian food back home (Vancouver, BC Canada) but this restaurant comes in top notch.  Mandalay was definitely the highlight of our trip, and we HIGHLY recommend the restaurant, food and the service.  The service was so good we had 3 or 4 people waiting on us and checking up on us the whole time we were there!  The cost of our dinner was very reasonable too.

We had, and recommend, the following:

- Coconut soup
- lamb curry
- seafood green beans 
- mango lassi drink

My wife and I will be dreaming about how good the food was here for years to come.
author: Stuart E.

description:
Mandalay!  Woot! (Technically a real word now).  It's walking distance for me.  The food is not too expensive and always good.  I've at least liked everything I've tried.  I love the fish chowder.  It makes me happy.  I like it when I'm happy.  

Romeo met Juliet.  Menelaus brought war to Troy because of Helen. Leonardo di Caprio died on some boat for Kate Winslet.  Joanie loved Chachi.  And then there is Mandalay fish chowder....

I may be exaggerating...a little.  But not much.  

Tea leaf salad is also good.  Yeah.  You know you love it.

Unfortunately, you can't discuss this place without reference to Burma Superstar. You have two Burmese restaurants (of equal quality IMHO) which are three blocks away.   However, if you want to eat at Burma Superstar, you get to wait for hours on end next to the WaMu ATM machine and hope your companion is an excellent conversationalist.  (Fingers crossed!)  Otherwise, it might get awkward.  And no one likes awkward.
author: Aron L.

description: Best place we  have ate all year!  Food is delicious, service is very pleasant, food comes out a little slow because they are always busy but it is well worth the wait!   Balada  and the Dry pan fried string beans are must have items! We can't wait to go back and try more dishes.
author: Shelley D.

description:
I decided give Mandalay a shot after a few of my friends have gone here.  I wanted to know if it was just as good as Burma Superstar.  The restaurant itself is more spacious than Burma and so there wasn't a huge line when we walked in.  We got seated immediately.  The decor is cute, but I still think Burma is more cozy.  

To compare to the quality of Burma, we had to try their tea leaf salad, and their curry noodles (Nan Gyi Dok (Available with Tofu)
Burmese rice noodle with spiced coconut chicken, split yellow pea, powder, and fried onion).  I wanted to compare their Mango beef or chicken, but they declined my order because mangos weren't really ripe and in season!  That totally blew.  I didn't know what else I wanted... =P  So we got their Mandalay chicken instead.

Tea leaf salad:  no lettuce = more tea leaves!  It was REALLLLLY GOOD.  I don't know what I prefer, lettuce or no lettuce.  I think this tea leaf salad without the lettuce is probably more authentic.  I think I prefer without the lettuce.  You get so much more flavor.

Curry chicken noodles:  The only difference is that they don't give you egg in it, which isn't a big deal.  It was really tasty, but to be honest, I can't tell which one I like better either.  I guess that just means they are comparable and equivalent!

Mandalay Chicken: The chicken here was kind of over cooked in my opinion and a little dry.  The mango would have added great flavor to it 

Overall, the service is great.  The food is comparable to Burma, and I would definitely come back here again.  get the coconut rice!! it's so good!
author: Diane L.

description:
Now that I have moved to the neighborhood, I find myself just a hop, skip, and a throw away from all of that yummy, authentic Burmese food. The nice little ladies who run this place are too nice; they're not a good enough deterrent to stop me from coming here on that frequent occasion in which I want something spicy. They give me their "House special sauce" in little containers to take home with me, to put on my rice, vegetables, waffles, cereal and I just can't resist the charm. At this rate, I'm glad they don't deliver, because it means I'll be forced to leave my house in order to eat this. I think that is key, in order not to get too fat to be able to fit through one's own front door. Right? How does that happen? If anyone knows, I'd really like your insight, because it is a potential threat in my future, which I would rather not have to deal with.

In any case, really friendly and generous service, perfect portion sizing (i.e., nothing excessive), and wonderful, melt-in-your-mouth goodness. Authentic and spicy, just how I like it.
author: Anna S.

description:
The WILSEW* used to live nearby in Presidio Heights back in our courtin' days, so I've made a solid, thalidomide-baby's handful** of visits to this establishment. The first time was real early on in those courtin days, on a Sunday evening in August after Opera in the Park, and a walk back to her place where we unpacked the picnic basket and, uh, rearranged the furniture in her apartment for a few hours, working up quite an appetite. The conversation went something like this: 

Me: Oooh--how 'bout Burma Superstar?
WILSEW: Oh--Burmese, yeah, that sounds great. But let's go to Mandalay instead. It's right down the street. 
Me: Oh...okay. [Pause that was one part mopey, two parts wondering if this was perhaps vestigial princessery, and 1-2 dashes of petulance about not getting my ex*act* way.] What's wrong with Burma Superstar? 
WILSEW: Oh, Burma Superstar's always crowded and there's a line, and you have to wait outside...and it's just--Mandalay's just as good, and we're not going to have to wait, and it won't be crowded, and we'll be happier and not hungry sooner. Doesn't that make a lot of sense? 
Me: Yeah, I guess so. Okay; let's go to Mandalay.

And so began my relationship with Mandalay/this new reality of not getting my way at all times, in every way. On both counts I've been pleasantly surprised by my enjoyment.
