Though I'm sure you're more interested in the interpersonal relationship dynamics between WILSEW and myself, I'll limit my review (to the extent that it can still be considered limited) to just what I've eaten at Mandalay (all visits). In no particular order, the following items are enough, in themselves, to bring me back: tea leaf salad (perfect combination of tangy and spicy and salady, basically low-level internecine culinary warfare in your mouth), ginger salad (ibid.), green papaya salad (though I admit I'm wicked easy when it comes to green papaya salad); samusa (meat--WILSEW's insistence--which melted and swarmed my palate); samusa soup (almost a sweet nuttiness to it that made it impossible for me not to love, though somehow WILSEW found a way not to like it).

It also bears mentioning that the service is pretty spot-on: nice/polite, efficient, and attentive without being bothersome. A little like if your aunt had a house in the town where you went to prep school and you stopped in every once in a while for non-institutional food that was not just non-institutional, and not just really really really good, but also delivered to you with the kind of affection you can't get from the in loco parentis set-up down the road, but also not too up in your business or grill. The tea salad just gets set down in front of you, and it's so good.



*Ed. Note: For all you readers new to this Series, WILSEW is an acronym for "woman I live/sleep/engage with."
 
**Too soon? No, of course not; that was like 50 years ago, dude.
author: T U.

description:
I was just here again last night and I have to say:  I still love this place!!!

We had the Mandalay Special Noodles (omg, try this!  The combination of all the flavors is excellent!), the smoked tea duck (some parts were a little crispier than I like, but it was still super good), and the mango prawns - also yummy!

The wait staff was very courteous and the food, as always, was amazingly good.

I want to eat there every day!!!
author: Vicky M.

description:
I've been to Mandalay SEVERAL times. Every time I go, I am never dissapointed. 

I strongly reccomend the mango, mandalay or rainbow chicken. Their saffron rice is also to die for, so that is a must when ordering. Another great thing there is their mango lemonade (or some sort of lemonade).

The wait staff there is all really nice (or at least the ones that I have had serve us) and I rarely wait long for the food. 

Another tip is this place is great to go to after you've had a mani-pedi at Salon Bella Linda down the block...
author: Zoeboe D.

description:
SOOOOOOO much better than that OTHER restaurant a few blocks away whose initials are, coincidentally, B.S.  My fiance and I discovered this gem while circling the neighborhood after realizing that we just didn't want to wait 2 hours to eat at the other place!!!

The wait isn't nearly as long, and even if you have to wait, they have extra space for you to stand inside so you're not freezing your ass off outside.  Last time we were there, a lady walked around passing out glasses of complimentary red wine to the patrons who were waiting and apologized for the wait.  And when you sit down, this extra space (it's 3-4 times the size of B.S.) in the restaurant allows for a couple of things that, again, the OTHER place can't:

1) The people still waiting aren't breathing down your neck to hurry up and eat before they pass out from hunger.  Actually, at B.S. they don't have a choice - the place is so damn tiny that they're practically sitting in your lap.

2) The servers aren't staring at you or getting ready to swoop down onto your table like the Tasmanian Devil the second you finish that last bit of tea leaf salad, so that you can hurry up and move the line along.

The food is comparable and in fact, some dishes are better than at B.S.  The staff is also way more friendly, smile more, and generally have a happier vibe.  At B.S., I always feel stressed out (and I hardly ever get stressed out!) and who wants to feel that way when you're out to lunch or dinner with friends?

Whenever someone mentions B.S., I point them in the direction of Mandalay instead.
author: Lee H.

description: Amazing. Purely amazing. And in my opinion, better than Burma Super Star. The tea leaf salad and Mandalay beef are my favorites. And the Tapioca dessert with agar agar, yum! I brought my whole family here, and although the service was slow (since it was packed) it was a huge hit amongst all 12 of us.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I finally made it down the street to check out Mandalay.  It was decent all around I'd say, and I'll probably go back.  The fishcakes appetizer (Nga Pe Jaw) was little disappointing because they were bland, and they looked and tasted like reheated frozen fish sticks (but, I will say that the table next to us ordered pot stickers, which looked awesome. hmmm.. come to think of it, I don't think I've ever had bad pot stickers ever in my life, so maybe it's no big deal?...but I digress...)

I tried the Mango Chicken- really good!  What struck me, though, is that it didn't really taste like chicken.. in fact, I kept thinking it was tofu (but it really was chicken, so don't worry)!  I wish they included a few more peppers (i.e. heat), though, which played well on the sweetness of the mango, and the saltiness of the chicken.  All around, a classic dish, and a must try.  Good portion, too!

The service was great, I thought.  The place is very ornate, and seemingly popular.  Go check it out!
author: M S.

description: We love the food and people at Mandalay! We don't go as often as we used to, but they still remember us---even if we are taking take-out--and give us a friendly smile. We usually start with  the ginger salad,  and then move on to mango chicken, and spicy basil chicken--with occasional substitutes of prawns. We are not "foodies" in any sense of the word: we are too ordinary. However, we have found the quality of the food and service consistent and high whenever we have gone there
author: Carol O.

description: I went here a few months ago with my hubby for the first time after hearing that it was better than Burma Super Star (which is like really overly hyper in my opinion not to mention too crowded most of the time) So we gave this place a try and though the food was pretty decent and I enjoyed it, the portions seemed rather on the small side for the price you end up paying, and we didn't get very full off it and had to eat somewhere else less than an hour later. I haven't tried the other Burmese place yet, but may end up doing so soon just so I can compare the two.
author: Petra S.

description:
pros: great food, great prices, great service
cons: parking, some of the more chinese items were not good

have to try: tea leaf salad and mandalay special noodle
author: Noah P.

description:
decided to try this spot out, based on a friend's yelp review. i've never had burmese food before, but i figured it was probably delicious. we actually went RIGHT when they were opening for dinner. the owners and staff are incredibly nice! 5 stars for service, 5 for cleanliness/atmosphere.

we had the catfish chowder. so, this soup is incredible. basically, i gave this restaurant 5 stars for this dish alone! you add some cilantro and squeeze lemon juice in there, maybe mix in a little spicy chili sauce - mmmmmm. so savory and spicy! 

we had the balada, which is like a fried pancake, which comes with this chunky curry sauce. it was super tasty, but very greasy. but still. it tasted really good.

and by this time, we were stuffed, but managed to try a little of the curry beef with coconut rice. SO GOOD! perfect amount of spicyness for me, and the coconut rice was so fragrant and sweet. 

and best of all? we got dessert on the house - coconut pudding/jello and sweet something cake. i dunno what it all was, but it was the perfect ending to a delicious meal.
author: Aletheia W.

description:
Okay, so this is admittedly my first adventure into Burmese food, but I cannot imagine a better one! We were seated right away, and upon finally deciding what to eat, our order was up in a rather prompt manner. We ordered an array of food, and no, I won't specify how many there were of us, but we ordered more than enough, I'll say that. 

Let's break it down now:
Chili oil on the table before the food even arrived, insanely good Balada (fried multi-layered pancake magic with curry sauce), Mandalay Chicken (fried chicken to die for, that may actually kill you anyway, in a good way, in a good heart-clogging way), yummy Rainbow Chicken, amaaaazing Coconut Rice, great Saffron Rice, a yummy almost "alfredo" style fettuccine dish (but Thai flavors), and their mixed veg with tofu...oh...mah...gah! They fry their tofu so delicious styles, I'm drooling, right now. 

We really couldn't finish even a single dish, it was so plentiful. I loved the flavors, the preparation, everything was hot, the service was sublime, water and hot tea at my disposal, I ate so much I was nearly sick. It was a very, very good night.
author: Shannon F.

description: After revisiting Mandalay, I was glad to try their Yellow Chicken Curry...Juicy and moist chicken pieces in an amazing Yellow Curry Sauce!  Order it.  You'll thank me...
author: Jennifer L.

description: My first experience with Burmese food, and it was excellent!  There was a bit of a wait on Saturday night, but the service was prompt and the food very good.  Two of us had noodle dishes and one the curry.  The coconut chicken soup was amazing, and plenty to share.
author: Sarah W.

description:
3 stars means it's not bad. Like good food. And really it was a pleasant meal. We were overwhelmed by all the options and tasty sounding choices so we opted for the Meal for 2 for $18.95 each which consisted of a soup, appetizer (Tea Leaf Salad), Mandalay Chicken (but we substituted Mango Chicken), Pan fried string beans, and includes rice and dessert.

We started with the Tea Leaf Salad. Not exactly what I expected. It came to us decontructed, the peanuts, separate from the tea leaves, from the fried garlic, tomatoes, chili, dried shrimp, sesame seeds. It is distinct in flavor contributed mainly I think to the shrimp and garlic. Admittedly fishy in flavor. Probably not my favorite but worth trying.

We substituted the Black Pepper Soup with the Coconut Chicken Soup. As my friend described it - tastes like a Thai Tom Yum soup. To which I added except for the Coconut Milk, the hard boiled egg, cilantro and others. Honestly though, the soup is great! Like a light thinned coconut curry.

Then we were served the Mango Chicken and the String Beans. Both were good though nothing to shout about. We did have Coconut Rice for a little extra. I just like the extra flavor. Fragrant.

Dessert was a shared fried banana with ice cream. 

So a fairly traditional Burmese meal in a quiet part of the city. Friendly service with a smile.
author: Cindy W.

description: My family has been coming to Mandalay for over a decade.  The food is delicious, consistent, reasonably priced, presented nicely and clean/fresh.  The service is also consistent - the owners and the servers visibly work hard to conscientiously accommodate the customers who are clearly number one in their eyes.  Mandalay is so dependable - great food, excellent service.  Parking is a little tough but those who know "it's worth it" would be willing navigate around this issue.  Mandalay is one of our family favorites.
author: Chris D.

description:
I dined here because of yelp. It had so many great reviews, that I had to give it a try. (Plus, there's no way I'd be patient enough to wait for Burma Superstar.) Once again, yelp did not let me down.

Burma, if you didn't know, is near China, Thailand and India, and appropriately, its cuisine blends these three countries' well-known flavors. There were Thai dishes on the menu (Satay), Indian dishes (Samosas), and Chinese dishes (Won Ton Soup), but this restaurant wasn't just a hodge-podge one-stop Asian restaurant, but a tasty adventure in Southeast Asia.

Although the Chicken Satay was on the dry side, the Shrimp Won Ton soup and Combo Fried Rice was flavorful and rich. The Nan Gyi Dok rice noodle dish combined unique flavors of coconut, onions and pea powder that surprised the palate while the Rainbow Prawns mixed sweet fruit with savory shrimp. And another thing worth noting... anything that said Hot & Spicy, was not.

To finish, I highly recommend opting away from the "safe" fried bananas and choosing the dessert with tapioca, milk and ice cream. It was deliciously different and well worth the risk. Overall, a very solid Asian restaurant experience, despite the lack of Asians dining there.
author: eileen b.

description:
I'm not one to stand in interminable lines a la BSS, so I was really excited to try Mandalay after driving by and then reading  its Yelps.   

We had a 7:45 reservation on a Saturday night and were seated about 15 minutes after that. The spacious interior and gracious service are definite pluses. 

We started with the very tasty Tea Leaf Salad, a must if you will be dining here. The Burmese Hot and Sour soup was ok, and the Prawns and Okra mightily outshone our second entree, the Burmese Curry Beef. It was WAY too salty for us, and would have taken this review down to 3 stars, but I did notice on the menu that you can ask to make dishes less or more spicy and/or salty when ordering. 

So Mandalay deserves a return visit, probably with my mom when she comes to town, and we will ask for less salt and more spice, and try some other dishes!
author: Priya S.

description:
Burmese cuisine is a whole new world to me.  After eating here and BStar, I think I'm hooked. The tea leaf salad scared me a bit -  what came to the table looked a lot like barf - but the more I ate, the more I liked. It's the fried garlic chips that did it. It could have actually BEEN barf, and if said barf contained fried garlic chips, I would have tasted it. 

The entrees are wonderfully fresh, and the lunch specials are on the cheap. I'm happy to have it close by for work lunches, and I think it will be worth the drive for a future dinner.
author: Beth T.

description:
I've been here twice now, and the food is fantastic.  I haven't had anything that I didn't like.  I have tried:

1. The balada (a thin flatbread served with curry; known as roti in some other cultures):  absolutely delicious 
2-3. their famous green tea salad and ginger salads (nutty mix of a variety of nuts, lentils, seeds, and steamed green tea leaves or julianned ginger: both very good and also great when mixed together.  
4. Their spicy samusa soup is basically a tomato-based broth soup with chunks of samosa in it.... very flavorful, a bit salty. 
5. Coconut chicken noodle soup... light coconut based soup with amazing flavor.  yum.
5. Mandalay Special Noodle: very similar to the coconut chicken noodle soup in taste but more noodles.
6. Nan Gyi Dok Noodles: really really good... even better than the Mandalay Special noodle.
7. Palada dessert: a mix of dried fruits and random jellies in a coconut milk liquid plus a scoop of vanilla ice cream.  Good, but not amazing for my sweet tooth.

Very reasonably priced... the cost came out to $20/person (no alcohol) for dinner.
author: Grace M.

description: I took my boyfriend and his family here for mother's day. It was really packed! We made reservations but still had to wait a good 15-20 minutes or so. The hostess was going to seat us at this really small table but said it might be too small so we can wait for another table which we agreed.. A few minutes later she ended up seating us at the small table that we didn't want to sit at anyways.. We had to request to move to a different table since it barely fitted the 4 of us.. it was like a table for two. At least we were able to order our food while waiting for a bigger table.. After we moved tables our food came out. We ordered the mandalay beef, the pumpkin curry chicken, the burmese fried rice, and the mandalay special noodles. The mandaly beef was pretty good but it tasted just like something from a chinese restaurant. The pumpkin curry chicken had good flavors but the chicken was a little too dry.. the burmese fried rice was pretty good, but my favorite was the mandalay special noodles. Great flavors! Although my experience here wasn't that great.. didn't really like the service or waiters much, but I might go back to try some other stuff.
author: Nancy T.

description:
I'm not sure I'll be able to add any towering insights to the 513 reviews Mandalay already has to its merit, but damn me if this wasn't one of the best meals I've had in a long time, and I'd be remiss if I didn't Yelp it.

On our way to the restaurant, our inner-Richmond insider warned us that this wasn't the more famous of the two Burmese restaurants in the area, but showing up on a Saturday at 8 with four people and without a reservation, we didn't have more than a 15-minute wait, which was just enough time to sip through the beer offered to tide us over. An okay trade for fame points in my book.

Now, this was the first Burmese food I've had (described as as mixture of Indian and Chinese by someone in the know, which wasn't entirely accurate to our meal, but that could have been an accident of ordering), so I can't say how it stacks against other offerings, but everything we had was a delightful mix of sweet, spicy, nutty, and floral that was light on the palate in a way that Indian (which always seems to have too many middle notes) and Chinese (a decided bass) usually miss. My only complaint was that the fried garlic and onion in the Kaw Soi Dok was maybe a bit smokey (read: burnt) for the dish, but even that, I could see how somebody else might have liked. The other dishes we ordered -- pepper soup, mango chicken, and broccoli-walnut tofu -- were all amazing, with the broccoli-walnut dish as my winner for the night.

Perhaps the most surprising thing about the meal was how cheap it was. Not $5 street-food cheap, sure, but nobody at the table broke the $15 mark, which included beers for two of us. Now I'm sad I don't live in San Francisco, and have absolutely no idea where to get Burmese food in the Boston area. Franchise, plz?
author: Ben K.

description: This bright yellow gem of a place has been calling my name since I moved to the area 6 months ago.  FINALLY got to try it the other weekend, I may now be addicted.  The mandalay noodles are bomb, I order mine with tofu and it is perfect.  I also love how they point out each ingredient and mix it at the table.   I tried a beef curry dish as well that was delicious and the balada. The menu describes it as a crispy pancake, our was doughy, but good nonetheless.  And the curry dipping sauce was sooooo good!  I want to try everything on the menu but I dont know if I will be able to draw myself away from the mandalay noodles.  Ooooh and try the thai iced tea, seriously the best I've ever had.
author: Ciara D.

description:
I am never going to Burma Superstar again.  At this point, I have no idea why I even went in the first place.  This place was so much better, it was unbelievable.  

First of all, the restaurant is very large.  We walked in and were seated immediately.  We ordered three items: the tea leaf salad, the samusas (ok, they were just smaller samosas), and the tofu with walnuts and broccoli and coconut rice.  The first two items were great.  The tofu with the walnuts and broccoli was literally amazing with its sweet sauce.  We ate the entire meal and left with a stuffed happiness.  Overall it came to about $36 including tip.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Veggie-Friendly!!!

This was my special Burmese Place.  Not anymore.  Now I have to wait for a table sometimes.  Ahhh, the word has spread.  Yes, forgot the two hour wait at Burma Super Star.  I love the Mandalay Special Noodle (I want it all to myself) and the Basil Spicy Eggplant.  Adventurous?  Get the Chin Mong Law.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Love this restaurant . . . every meal there has been great. If you want a heart attack, try the mandalay chicken. But everything else is ridiculously good and super reasonable. 

The staff is almost too nice!!
author: Bowen P.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco! I know I've only been here for a little more than a year, but Mandalay is bar none the best place to eat I've found. The courteous staff, eclectic music selections, and of course, delicious food make this a best in class type of place.

I'll go ahead and say it... Mandalay kicks Burma Superstar's butt! While Mandalay does get busy and you have to wait at times, they are smart enough to take care of you by giving everyone glasses of wine while they wait. Also, they care about and understand the experience of enjoying a meal. Burma Superstar makes you pre-order and rushes you out the door in order to feed the hordes of starving patrons that stare in through the windows at you, while Mandalay will keep you happy while you wait and let you take as long as you need to enjoy your meal.

I have never had a dish I didn't like and delight in the thought of eating my leftovers the next day for lunch or dinner. I recommend their signature tea leaf salad as an appetizer, their ginger lemonade as a drink, coconut rice with your main, which I love so many of... but, I would suggest any Rainbow, Rangoon, or walnut and broccoli dish. To finish it off, mango and sticky rice is light and delectable. 

Ok, enough, enough... just go try it and find out for yourself!!
author: Bay M.

description:
This place is pretty small and quite colorful. The outdoor is painted yellow and green and the inside gives off a cozy vibe. The Christmas like ornaments hanging from the ceiling and a light up palm tree all year-round seems a little odd, but the food is delicious.

I'd never had Burmese food, but it was quite familiar. It is a combination of Thai and Indian. As an appetizer I had the vegetarian samosa which was great! I then ordered the Basil Chicken and coconut rice both very good. Service was a little slow, but I would highly recommend it. 

The next time I'm in San Francisco I will definitely have to stop by again.
author: Wendy L.

description: A great alternative to Burma Superstar. So if you're not in the mood for a wait, walk a block or 2 North to Mandalay. Different experience, similar flavor.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Because I hate to wait for *anything*, I am always searching for  decent affordable places without crowds. 

Mandalay delivers:  relaxing and pleasant atmosphere and great service!  Parking in this inner Richmond location is pretty good most of the time which is also key.

 and the food is tasty and fresh...

Try the Ginger Salad!!

See you there :)
author: Sue U.

description:
I love...no really, I really really really love!

We were waiting for nearly an hour in front of Burma Superstar. And as I'm watching people who came way after us get seated one by one, I'm beginning to wonder if they're ever gonna seat us...EVER. "Ever" never came, because when my pal went to inquire within, they said, "oh maybe another 30 minutes." There's no way this shivering and completely famished girl is gonna wait another minute to place her order for some luscious noodles. The hostess is very apologetic and asks if we'd like to try their sister restaurant up the street (which I hear is NOT good), to which I said, "Ya know...it would be a nice gesture to warn your guests if the wait will be longer, instead of waiting till I ASK you an HOUR later." Turns out that people can call in ahead to get their name on the list, which is sooo stupid because we asked about that earlier in the evening over the phone, and some dummy told us otherwise. 

So then one of my other gal pals blurts out, "Why don't we go to Mandalay on California and 6th? They have better food and that's where Mom (who's Burmese) likes to go all of the time." I'm thinking, GIRL...you tell me now??? But I didn't waste time, because by now, I'm ready to eat the bench I've been warming. 

Two blocks later, we land the only table in the full house at Mandalay. This place does not disappoint. Friendly service greets us and we place orders for tasty drinks, including some tall, fruity concoction and Sangria (I know...out of place in a Burmese eatery, but still yum). 

So my gal pal with the Burmese mommy orders, and OMG...it's all amazing! Here's what we got:

Samusa (crispy, triangular appetizers) with chicken

Fried Squash (battered with a tasty dipping sauce)

Tea Leaf Salad that actually contains mostly tea leaves. Yuuuuppp...Burma Superstar packs their's with lettuce which isn't the way it should be served. HA! No wonder I didn't much care for it. Mandalay's version is far superior.

Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup) - mmmm, just like Burmese moms' make (I guess...I wouldn't know)

Moo Hin Nga (Fish Chowder) - with a squeeze of lemon...wowsers. Unexpectedly tasty.

Basil Beef - sauteed beef with shreds of ginger and fresh basil. It's as good as it sounds.

And here is the dish that I could not get enough of...KAW SOI DOK. YES! You HAVE to get this. It's egg noodles with fried onion, garlic chips, cucumber slices, split beans and some lip-smackin' dressing of I don't know what, but who cares, sort of thing. 

I was a little pissy about the whole seating situation at Burma Superstar, but that has nothing to do with me giving this place a stellar review. Thank you BS for not seating me, so that I could try some place new. I've got a new favorite in Burmese that's mmmmm mmmmm good!
author: Virg Y.

description:
Although I had never heard of this place before and I would have never gone to it had I not run into a friend of mine nearby that night & 'the other place on Clement St' was an over 1hr 1/2 wait.... Mandalay is definitely worth checking out!

The service was fantastic and they actually gave us a drink on the house because the wait was so long.  And while they were originally offering house wine as the free beverage...we actually ordered 2 Kirin beers (thinking we would pay for it) and they were on the house!  it was a nice touch and we were pleasantly surprised.

We waited about an hour and of course by then we were starving and I must say that the Special Mandalay Noodle dish (with the coconut chicken) was smack-tabulous!   It was very very good.

We were hoping to try something very "Burmese" and tried out the "Tea salad."  While it was very cool to have our server come and explain the ingredients and then mix it together...I think the dried shrimp part threw me and gave it a little bit of a weird flavor.

But again, we were starving and at this point, anything tasted good!

The only disappointment was the Burmese curry with beef.  We ordered the 'bread' with it instead of rice and this 'bread' was very much like filo-type nan-ish bread...light, crispy, and tasty.

The disappointment was in the beef... it was a little too tough for me and I think the sauce alone couldn't carry it off by itself.

I actually dipped the bread in the sauce and added in a little bit of the homemade looking seratcha sauce thing... it was so fresh and very good!

The thing that topped off the night though was the mango pudding they brought out, again on the house!
They were really spoiling us and I never even told them I like to write reviews on Yelp!

All in all, the people were awesome and very hospitable.

I really like the atmosphere...between the worship table with overflowing fruit and tea drinks displayed for their buddha, to the lit-up Palm tree, to the karaoke machine-led birthday songs, it really made for a memorable evening with my honey.
author: Ahnee M.

description: Scrumptious food, especially liked the coconut chicken soup and the fried eggplant. Props for good service on a crowded Valentine's night.
author: Antonio B.

description:
I'm usually a fan, Mandalay really rubbed me the wrong way this time.  

Our server started out with a cheesy spiel about Mandalay (the city and the restaurant) and then 2 people's dishes came out after everyone else had finished.  The saddest part was that they took my tea leaf roasted duck back to the kitchen to box it up (since my meal was one of the 2 that came out late) and they took so long to box it up that I forgot about it and left the restaurant without it. (:()  

I'll take a little bit of the blame, since I should have remembered, but we took the time to eat dessert, pay the bill and open/read each person's fortune cookie fortune and they STILL hadn't returned my duck.  It wasn't very good anyways, so I didn't miss it, but it was poor on their end.  You better step up your game the next time I visit you, Mandalay.
author: Krystle S.

description:
Our favorite restaurant for the price, hands-down. 

They serve lovely, spicy, fresh, no-nonsense/no-frills Burmese food. The coconut-chicken soup is to die for. So's the mango chicken, especially if the mango is just a little under-ripe, so it's firm and tart instead of soft and sweet. You can request that your dishes be made mild, spicy, or very spicy.
author: Elle B.

description:
Don't faint, but I've never heard of Burma Superstar.  It's always been about Mandalay.

I've been about 12 times in three years and, everytime I go, I swoon over the likes of rainbow chicken, basil prawns, mongolian beef (that my colleague swears is the best he's ever had, ever), chicken samosas, and on and on!  

And the servers are attentive and nice.  They become a little too attentive if you try to linger over your tea, but that's the only downer in an otherwise fabulous dining experience.

I was just there last night (4/2/07) and prices have gone up since I was last there.  The pretty significant jump will make me think twice before going back as soon as I would have otherwise...but I know I'll be back!
author: Vanessa C.

description:
This place is awesome. We started going here recently as we were getting annoyed by the parking/waiting situation at Burma Superstar. The food here isnt as good as it is over at Burma (but somewhat close), but the seating/service is MUCH better.

If you want good food, great service, and a nice atmosphere, come to Mandalay. If you want outstanding food, long waits, crowded tables and marginal service (or want to impress a date and get some truly amazing food), go to Burma Superstar down the street instead.

Personally we eat here about 80% of the time and save Burma Superstar for special occasions.
author: Peter d.

description:
i came here for dinner it was pretty good. But the service was kind of slow. We finished our appetizers before the rest of the food came. I would recommend this place, their food tastes extremely fresh =)

below is what we ordered that i loved 
mango salad
chicken and beef satae
fried shredded onions
mango prawns
coconut rice
garlic string beans
author: Sandy l.

description:
Ok so it's no Burma Superstar but it is a close second!! I mean really who can beat Burma Superstar but I will for sure return. The staff was nice and the wait was warm compared to being outside in the cold waiting for a glimmer of hope to be called in....we ordered lots and lots of food!! 

I loved the Walnut-Broccoli Chicken and the Roasted Duck.....OMG that was soo good! Their Samusa's left a lot to be desired not as much flavor as Burma Superstar and their coconut f rice was not as good as the folks across the street...the flavor seemed off.  I would for sure go back for the duck and the service as well as that chicken dish...oh and the platha which goes by a different name here...all in all I cannot complain it was good food at decent prices...
author: T H.

description:
This is a nice place for lunch on the weekend.  I like most of the items on the menu and the food is presented very well.  The waiters are friendly and I like the ambiance especially if I need to relax.

My only gripe: sometimes they can be slow in delivering drinks/appetizers and the bill.  Last time, we had to wait for 20-30 mins for the bill ...
author: Prabu D.

description:
Went to Mandalay last weekend and was very impressed.  We've had some Burmese food on the Peninsula so we were able to compare.

We both ordered fancy drinks: a young coconut with a straw in it, and a ginger drink.  The coconut was just right.  It even had a spoon for carving out the meat.  For an appetizer, we ordered a special banana blossom salad.  It was very sweet and a nice departure from the usual tea leaf salad.  For dinner, we ordered the Mandalay Special Noodle and the Pan Fry Seafood (calamari, scallop, and prawn).  We asked for extra spicy but did not exactly get our wish.  The noodle dish was incredibly flavorful as was the seafood dish.  They managed to get all the seafood cooked right and paired very well with the string beans.  We also ordered a side of saffron-raisin rice.  It was nice but did not really go with the meal (probably our fault).  Finished very full and very happy.

We will definitely be going back to try some more of their cuisine.
author: Mike T.

description:
The food here can be a little greasy and sweet. I think it leans a little more toward the Chinese end of the Burmese spectrum. That doesn't mean it isn't good. Their Tea Leaf salad is excellent - maybe even better than BS. The Balada, which is like a flaky pancake thing with a curry dipping sauce, is delicious.

People often compare/contrast to Burma Superstar, which is understandable seeing as how they are only a few blocks from each other, but their menus are really quite different. I'm guilty of walking over to Mandalay a few times when the wait at BS was just too unbearable. Mandalay is certainly a more relaxed experience.
author: Zac H.

description: One of the Best Burmese restaurant in the area. The line is not super crazy either.
author: Kate J.

description: I love burmese food.  The mango chicken and the mango prawns are a must.  I always get seated right away and the service has always been good.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Way better than Burma Superstar. Love the food there and great service. 
For Salad: tea leaf salad , rainbow salad and Green papaya salad is sooo good. My favorite dish is Pan Fry Okra Prawn.
author: christy l.

description:
Love Burma Superstar but hate the wait?  Mandalay is the place!!!!!

I don't even have to think twice about giving this place 5 stars.  We've been going for a couple of years now - we celebrate birthdays and special occasions.  My 9-year old loves it - and he hates everything!  

Tea leaf salad is hugely popular (not for me but my companions double the order!!!), the Mandalay special noodles are delish and the coconut soup TO DIE FOR.  

Shrimp and okra - awesome.  Chicken and mango?  GREAT.  

Tapioca drink - unbelievable.  Coconut rice is delish and a dish unto itself (well, for rice lovers like me!)

You can't go wrong - although we never really order the "chinese-y" food sort of things.  So can't speak to it.  

Love love love Mandalay!!!!!!!!
author: amy b.

description:
I come from Miami where there is no such thing as a burmese restaurant. When I discovered this restaurant, I fell in love.

The flavors are so unique. mmmm.. i dream about you Mandalay
author: Alicia V.

description:
Our first night in our new apartment and we stumble upon this gem right around the corner.  YUM.

Of course, first things first: Wine.  Limited selection, kickass prices.  Sold.

Food.  Sizzling rice soup. Prawns, scallops, chicken.  Plenty for two people.  For EIGHT dollars.  SOLD.

Fried Squash sticks.  ok, i was starving, and i heart 'fried.'  Next time i'll pass.

Sizzling prawns served, well, sizzling.  YUM.  perfectly cooked, good amount.  SOLD.

Mandalay special noodles.  Mixed tableside to order.  Very different.  I like, boyfriend not so much.  SOLD.  (he can write his own review)

Green Beans with, well, stuff i can't remember.  Delicious.  SOLD.  

Combination fried rice.  generous helpings of prawns, chicken, egg...  wait for it.... SOLD.

We're already planning our next visit...
author: Alison R.

description:
Really tasty food, full of flavor! I am not familiar with Burmese food, but this tasted great to me! Kind of a small place and the bathroom was not that great, but that was really the only downside. Also, the waitresses were very sweet, but it felt like they were pushing us to order more. It was hard to tell if they were sincere or just trying to get us to buy more, but the quantities of food they recommended were about right, so I guess it was good they pushed! 

We ordered the Mango Chicken because of the recommendations on here and it was really good. I also like the noodles, but I forget what they were called! Ask the waitress to recommend their best noodle dish b/c that's what it was. Also really good was the mango sticky rice for dessert. Yum! Service was very quick and food came out fast.

Why only 4 stars? I'm not really subtracting a star for anything, it just didn't jump out as 5 stars as good at is was. Five stars is something special and this place was great, but just not that special something that gets 5 stars to me.
author: Laura B.

description: Simply the best Burmese food in the City.
author: Arthur A.

description: We recently came here with a party of 14 and pretty much ordered everything.  All the dishes were yummy and the tea leaf salad is probably better than Burma Superstar's.
author: Josie N.

description:
The food at this place is great that I don't want to share it.  I love the pumpkin and the special noodles.  I also found out that they take reservations over the phone to hold your place on the wait list.  I thoroughly enjoyed every dish and didn't feel thirsty like I did when I went to Burma Super Star, which I didn't even bother to yelp about.
One bad thing is that parking is pretty bad in the area, so plan to drive around the block a few times.
author: H G.

description:
I love this restaurant!  For my bday a few weeks ago, Sherry worked patiently with me to accomodate me & 20 of my closest friends.  Despite how we took up half of the restaurant on a Friday night, she & her staff didn't pressure us or make us feel like we were in the way.  They were fantastic.  The food was sensational.  Even though I didn't eat much that night, I went back a few days later & we ordered the mango chicken, tea salad, spicy green beans & everything was delicious.  I prefer Mandalay over Burma Star b/c I like how there is ROOM to walk inside Mandalay & I don't like waiting very long for anything, let alone FOOD when I'm hungry.

*************

Went  back for dinner last night with a party of six - again, fantastic service and great tasting food. (7/8/07)
author: Christie X.

description:
This was my first time eating Burmese food so I don't know if it was authentic but I do know that I loved everything we ordered. I went with Gabrielle T, Angela C, and Shannon L. Please read Shannon L's review if you want to know the perspective of someone who grew up eating Burmese food.

My favorite dishes were the Samusa, Balada and Moo Hin Nga.
author: Jenn S.

description: No joke, this place is amazing. And like every other review on Mandalay, you must try the Tea Leaf Salad.
author: Renee B.

description:
The comparisons to Burma SuperStar (BSS) are inevitable. They both serve Burmese food, they're within spitting distance of each other, and they're both very highly reviewed on Yelp. Let me break it down:

The food here is very good. The coconut chicken noodle soup and the Mandalay special noodles were exemplary. I also ordered the catfish steak with curry, which I thought was a little dry, and the Rainbow Chicken, which wasn't anything to write home about. BSS has the edge here, if only because their catfish steak was absolutely heavenly.

Of course, food is only part of the equation. If you consider that we would've had to wait an hour and a half for a table at BSS compared to roughly fifteen minutes for a table here... 

Also, I was pleasantly surprised by their attention to service. Case in point: the manager would frequently make the rounds at the waiting area, making sure that everyone there was taken care of and kept informed. We were also offered complimentary glasses of wine, which was a very nice touch.

If the quality of the food is your *absolute* sole consideration, BSS is your place of choice. But factor in everything else (wait time, service), and I think Mandalay is the clear winner.
author: Horace K.

description: Great food and without the wait of Burma Superstar.  I loved the tea leaf salad, and the lemon ginger beer was amazing.  Definitely coming back!
author: Joseph W.

description:
Yummy. I'm a regular here, and my favorite dishes are: chicken salad, dry pan fried string beans, and the okra & prawns. Oh, and the ginger lemonade!

The staff is always friendly and attentive. We usually don't have to wait long if at all to get seated. I admit Burma Star is good too, but I wouldn't wait hours in the cold to get seated. Mandalay is the way to go!
author: lisa m.

description:
Three words, my friends: Tea Leaf Salad. 

Although the other mix-at-the-table salads on other tables looked equally yummy, the tea leaf salad was divine. We also had the coconut rice (wow!) with the special coconut-mango prawns (or something like that) and the roasted duck. The prawns were good, but seemed to be sized more as an appetizer than a main dish. The rice is also not quite 2 servings. The half duck, though, was perfectly prepared (although I usually prefer it off the bone) and came with dumplings and a plum-type sauce. As good as everything was, I'll probably try something new next time since everything looked so great!

The service was also fabulous. The servers do the same schpeel to every table, describing the history of the place and what Burmese food is like, blah, blah. It was good, but it's the food that will keep me coming back. 

Personally, I don't think there is any food in the world that is good enough to wait 2 hours for. Screw Burma Superstar--Mandalay is where I'll head to when I want quality, authentic Burmese with great service!
author: Amy B.

description: Everything was great but the price.  Worth it, just want a cheaper alternative.
author: reza n.

description:
burma superstar gets all the glory... and the lines. 
mandalay is just as yummy-- arguably yummier-- and without the wait.
it's also not as hip, but you won't care when you wrap your lips around the special noodles. also amazing: tea leaf salad (get it burmese style) and fish chowder.
author: Brett W.

description: Great restaurant! Excellent food! Ordered Mongolian beef, Walnut Prawn, Hot and Sour Soup, Shrimp Wonton Soup... loved it all! Parking is a problem, plan to spend some time on looking for the spot.
author: Igor K.

description:
I had high hopes of this place replacing B Star because I'm tired of the wait there but I was sorely disappointed. There WAS a wait at Mandalay but the servers were pretty friendly explaining why another party was being taken ahead of us (different number of people in their party).

The food wasn't very good and the ambiance leaves a bit to be desired. Admittedly they are Chinese/Burmese but I still would rather eat Burmese at a Burmese restaurant.
author: JaM W.

description:
I came in a plain blank slate.

I came out a full satisfied happy belly.

Where is Burma anyway? Well, for all I know, we ordered so much that I know that it's NOW all in my happy belly. We picked random...first the tea leaf salad, which was really interesting at first, and gradually more and more captivating, a mix of textures, accented by fried garlic and lentils, and the lemon...not good looking after the nice servers mix it, but definitely worth trying!
Then, it was the turn of my top food of the night: mango chicken - nice, flavorful chunky mango with tender chicken - a combo I've never imagined before - and so yummy, especially when paired with their coconut white rice!
Close to capacity, but eyes still starved for deliciousness, we feasted on their Mandalay special noodles, special as in an awesome pile of mixed flavors, plus a nice order of soft, chunks, of yummy Burmese curry beef and roti!!!

Bottom line, I will definitely go back and order up another storm, perhaps not come in a bigger group than 4 people as it can get crowded... and not worry that it will hurt my wallet. I mean, we had all that, plus their version of thai ice tea and a beer-like cocktail, plus complimentary mango puddings and fortune cookies, all for $60 and we had a lot of leftover to take home!

that means, pure goodness is waiting for me in the fridge
author: Paolo D.

description:
We drive about 1.5 hours from home for the pleasure of dining at Mandalay.  A number of members in my party were vegetarian.  We ordered items on the menu (that had meat) meatless.  
The appetizers: Fried squash sticks, Balada (a bit like the Indian paratta) are just out of the world.  
Samusa soup: excellent choice that you will not regret.
Ordered Mango salad  (if you are veggie, you can ask for the same without shrimp and not a whiff of fishy odor).  Oh my!! Just incredible.
Mandalay special noodle with tofu and Nan Gyi Dok with Tofu.  Mixed it on our table.  Prefer the former noodle but both are good.
Order mango shrimp and was blown away by the taste and freshness.

Some words of caution:
a) Place is very crowded.  Be prepared to wait a while if you go late (after 11;45am) for lunch.
b) Menus are not written down.  every time they forget something.  But no matter, we always overdo, hence actually grateful that they forgot an item or two.

Very friendly service, but extremely busy restaurant.  You want really good service, be there when they open the restaurant.
author: Robert R.

description:
We ended up here on Saturday night because we wanted to go to Burma Superstar but there was a two hour wait and we were going to be seated around 10pm (when the close). 

So of course, used Yelp to look up restaurants close on the nifty iPhone (oo...me love iPhone). Anyways, Mandalay came up. 

We ordered the basil chicken, noodle special, beef rangoon, and one of their prawn dishes. Everything was super good, the food was served hot. The service was a little slow, but we didn't mind because we were talking and drinking lots of cold sake. 

Overall, yummy. And the fact there was no wait on a Saturday night definitely added an extra star. 

Funny enough, my friend asked for a Thain ice tea because she saw the table next to us (of 10 people) drinking them, and the waiter told us they ran out of thai ice tea. But it worked out, we had cold sake instead!
author: Radha S.

description:
Vegetarian and vegan friendly. Pretty good atmosphere and service is always really nice and friendly. We don't visit Mandalay too often but the owners always remember us.

We almost always split the hot & sour soup (no egg upon request).. add a little vinegar and it's just amazing. Veggie egg rolls, spring rolls, and samosas are pretty good, too. We recently tried the Burmese special noodles for the first time and it's now our favorite thing on their menu.
author: gibronandsahar K.

description:
OK, I have been holding my tongue for a couple of years, but I have to say this now.

If Mandalay is any good, it's because they've stolen Burma Superstar's recipes. Yes they have! If you only knew what I know about what the owners have been doing. They come into the restaurant under pretense of wanting to eat there, when they are actually stealing recipes. They even copy the menu, typos and all. A couple of Mandalay's staff actually asked for jobs with Burma Superstar, so what does that tell you?

Some of the items that they copy are items that have been created by Burma Superstar management. They don't even exist in Burmese cuisine!

I know many of you won't believe me, but I've witnessed this for two years and it really pisses me off that people say that some of the items THAT BURMA SUPERSTAR CREATED are better at Mandalay.
author: AJ S.

description: So I'll start with a disclaimer that my rating might not be entirely fair since my boyfriend and I ended up here for my birthday dinner only after being told that Burma Superstar and B Star each had a 2 hour wait.  The restaurant was super crowded and while the decor was nice it definitely felt like they crammed too many tables in the room.  My boyfriend got the lamb curry and I had some sort of noodle dish.  The curry sauce was good but the lamb was pretty tough and didn't even compare to the unbelievable curry I've had at B Star.  The noodle dish I had was weird.  I won't call it bad because I'm sure it was made well for what it was but I didn't particularly like it. The third star on this review was won by the tea leaf salad which I did think was pretty awesome.  However, overall it was disappointing.
author: Heather D.

description:
Great food for decent prices and a few steps above Burma Superstar around the corner.  

Missing one star because our to go orders have been getting consistently smaller - noticeably less chicken fried rice the last three take outs.  Started off getting six potstickers, two times ago only five, and the last time only four.  Same price though.  

Best thing on the menu?  Walnut Broccoli Chicken.
author: Brian H.

description:
i love this place!

its so good if you haven't had burmese food before you'll wonder what the difference is...and you won't really care.

you'll come back and order something again.  

if you don't know what to order?  ask the server and they'll suggest something you'll like..or just use the menu and see the pictures and you'll decide that you want to try more than one dish.

i've taken my friends here just so they can try it...they always want to go back here to eat.  we don't always because they want me to pay but sometimes when i'm in the mood i'll take a new friend to it if they haven't eaten here before.

the owner is my friends ex girlfriend and i'm ashamed because we always used to get one free dish of their garlic string beans...so i stopped going for a long long time and came back and they don't recognize me so its okay.  

okay, one thing i WILL NOT EAT THERE...the satay beef or anything.  satay is for people who don't know what they want and this will make you wonder why you ever ordered it.  DO NOT ORDER THE SATAY ANYTHING!
author: Bing D.

description: I've been here a handful of times now, they have real good green beans with prawns! Today I went for dinner and it was expensive! For the price I paid I would expect a larger portion. I suggest go for lunch not dinner! The food is very tasty! The singapore noodles were very flavorful, papaya salad was good, samosas were good. All very tasty including the free chewy sweet potato desert. Can they please make the portion size a bit larger and I will be very happy!
author: Karen T.

description:
I went here with a couple of vegetarians, so the options were limited, but here's the skinny:
 
- Samusas were crisp and piquant.
- Garlic salad was not very complex -- just a lot of oil and peanuts.
- Burmese hot and sour soup left the most to be desired. 
- Walnut broccoli tofu was excellent.
- Sauteed spinach with garlic was simple, albeit underseasoned.
- Flat-noodled dish with yellow pea powder and coconut milk was the best of the lot.

The above thoroughly fed a party of four for about $22/person.

Bear in mind that, whether by design or not, the dishes here arrive in staggered fashion; this is a refreshing way to eat family-style Asian food.

Service was fine: our reservation was honored, "Hot & Spicy" dishes were made mild as per our request; and there was no pressure to turn the table. 

Finally, since everybody seems to care: I'm no expert in Burmese cuisine, but Mandalay seemed a very adequate replacement for Burma Superstar, with the key advantage that it takes reservations.
author: Chusha T.

description: You could really spoil yourself with authentic Burmese Cuisine from Mandalay. Just the aroma is enough to have your taste buds tingle. The dishes are 'oh' so explosive with flavor! Combined with great presentation and atmosphere I guarantee you'll be back.
author: Charlene K.

description: I've eaten here once, it was recommended to me by my aunt who generally has very good tastes. And she was right! This food was delicious, I had the coconut chicken noodle soup and it was the best chicken soup I've ever tasted. I would definitely go here again and try to bring as many friends as I can when I do. If I remember correctly they also have a variety of vegan and vegetarian options as well.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Mmmmm.

My friend and I came here for a much needed catch-up session over dinner. My oh my, it was divine.

We started out with the vegetable samosas- I prefer their version much more to Indian samosas; they melted in my mouth and the dipping sauce was perfectly spicy.

For our entrees, we shared the Mandalay Beef and Mandalay Special Noodle. I highly recommend both. The Mandalay Beef was perfectly fried  and crispy, in a sauce of sweetness with a hint of mango. The Noodles were Burmese fat noodles, with curry chicken, yellow peas, lemon juice, onions, and fried onions; I love how our server mixed up the ingredients in front of us, carefully explaining what each one was. The flavors of this dish blended well together- not spicy, just interesting flavors. 

We also ordered a small side of coconut rice; perfectly cooked with just a hint or two of coconuts, topped with delicately fried onions.

I highly recommend Mandalay (over Burma Superstar, indeed); it was a lovely meal and I look forward to my next one there.
author: Laura D.

description:
Omg this place is awesome!  I've been to Burma Superstar and loved it, but saw the reviews of Mandalay on Yelp and checked it out. Like everyone said we would, we got seated quickly and the food was as yummy if not better than Burma Superstar. Plus slightly cheaper. We had:

-- Samosa Soup - It's not on the menu but they had it as a special. Broth is so flavorful and slightly spicy. 
-- Rangoon Beef  
-- Mango Mandalay Beef - Their #1 popular item for a reason.

Don't forget the coconut rice!
author: Melissa C.

description:
This has become my neighborhood go-to when it comes to MOST-EXCELLENT Burmese food. "Yes, I have been to B.S.S. on Clement" and "Yes it is really good." But Mandalay picks up where that other place leaves off. 
Mandalay always always has a table available, even on a moment's notice. They also have high-chairs, which is really only important to a select few of you out there, (but it's very IMPORTANT)
Did I mention gracious and friendly too? I am telling you, this place is great! 
Be sure to start off with the the Green Tea Leaf salad with all of its amazing flavors.
author: Travis W.

description:
Best Feature: the Appetizers.

My friends and I went here because my Bay Area friend said that Yelp gave it good marks.  You guys were right - Mandalay rocks!

For those of you who don't know, Burmese food is like Chinese food with potatos.  How can you go wrong!?  Try to get the authentic appetizers because those were the best parts.  I can't remember the name but it's like a wedge that you dip in a brown sauce.

As for the surroundings, when you walk in you realize that you are amidst many interracial couples.  In fact, I daresay this is the best spot to take your asian girlfriend if you are a 40 year old white guy.  This made me chuckle a little.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I had lunch with 2 other people.

I ordered the coconut with tapioca drink and it was way tasty. (it had shreds of coconut jelly in it as well as the small white tapioca). One of my friends ordered the ginger lemonade (she said it might need more ginger) but it was tasty, kinda sweet. and my other friend ordered the Burmese Iced tea (i like Thai iced tea better).

The staff was friendly and attentive.

We got the rainbow salad for an appetizer (3 different types of noodles (so good!)), pumpkin chicken curry, and shanghai style noodles. All the dishes were tasty, but i kinda wished they had more bang to them.

The chicken curry was ok, the chicken was good, but i wished there was more curry spices to it. but then again, maybe they're catering to the "doesn't eat spicy" crowd, which is understandable.

and then, the Shanghai style noodes were different from what i thought, but still good. the noodles were thin and stir fried up with some shrimp, egg, and maybe pork? it was tasty. but tastier with chili sauce.

I asked for hot sauce, and they brought out a small cup of it and it was good! it even had little black beans in it.

I was full.
author: N C.

description:
Last night was my second time at Mandalay. While the food is good it's not mind-blowing, and the service makes me unable to give it anything above 3 stars for now.

So before you get wrapped up in the Mandalay love fest and comparisons with Burma Superstar, just hear me out:

Ambiance: 4 stars - clean, spacious, definitely less claustrophobic and better lighting than Burma Superstar

Food: The food is alright.  It's tasty, but I leave feeling very thirsty.  The food is flavorful...but not from fresh ingredients!  I think that the flavors come from salt and an overcompensation of garlic.  
- Walnut Broccoli Tofu: this is a great dish for vegetarians.  it may sound a bit odd, but the tofu and broccoli goes well with this sweet and tangy walnut sauce.  Try it.
- Tea Leaf Salad: you can get it w/ lettuce or without (I prefer with just so that it's not too salty, but to each their own).  The salad was good, but the tea leaves were really coarse...I don't remember it being that way at Burma Superstar.  Moreover, there were waaaay too may nuts to other ingredients ratio.  I think I counted 3 half slices of grape tomatoes and with each bite you get a mouthful of peanuts and soy nuts.  
- Mandalay String Beans: this was pretty good, not too greasy, but the fried garlic was a bit overpowering. 
- Coconut Rice: very delicious, not too coconuty.  Try it!
- Jasmine Flower Art Tea: for $4 I don't know if it's really worth it.  Plus, I know they're trying to be all artsy, but tea should not be served in a wine glass...I'm just saying.

Service: Service is great at the beginning, but there were definitely moments when I was looking to get my water refilled and couldn't find a server.  We also had to wait forever to flag someone down to take the money.  
- Sidenote: This isn't a huge deal, but it left me with a bitter taste in my mouth.  During the course of dinner, I overheard that the Caucasian table next to us (and saw with my own eyes!!) received COMPLIMENTARY mango mousse (?) desserts.  I later saw that 2 tables down (another (coincidentally (?) Caucasian) table received the same dessert.  Fast forward and when we get our bill we got 2 cheap, stale-tasting fortune cookies.  I noticed that the other 2 tables of Asian patrons received the same...I don't like differential treatment.  Meh!
author: Alvina W.

description: I've been meaning to try Mandalay for years but in the meantime have hit up Burma Superstar many times. I think my preference is for Burma, although I liked Mandalay very much. I like the Mandalay cooler better than Burma's but I prefer Burma's tea leaf salad to Mandalay's. Pancakes totally delicious at both. We also had  the mango chicken and the okra shrimp, both of which were quite tasty.
author: m t.

description:
Just had dinner here last night for the first time. It was great! Everything was tasty. I had heard of this place from friends before and when someone again suggested going here, I thought "why not?"

The exterior is not much to look at, an unfortunate choice of yellow and green paint. What is it with Asians and cheap paint? (Hey, just so y'all know I'm Chinese, so I know.) The dining room is kitschy in a "nice older relative's home" way (there are xmas ornaments hanging from the ceiling). The dining room is large and has a fairly high ceiling. Service is courteous and well paced. They serve their ice water with a maraschino cherry in the glass. Cute. 

We ordered several appetizers and 4 entrees for 5 people. They were:

Green Papaya salad (the fried onions gave it an interesting spin)
A pancake like thing seved with a coconut curry sauce
fried squash
Singapore style noodles
Sizzling beef platter
Rainbow Prawns
Mango Chicken

It was all very tasty. I don't like cooked fruit. Hate it really. I don't like pies because of it. But here, the fruit became just an accent to the dishes. I didn't focus on the "hot fruit" issue at all. Which is saying a lot, people.

The only reason I gave Mandalay 4 stars instead of 5, was of the fact that we ordered another entree, rock cod filets, but it never showed up. Which is just as well, we were all very full and were considering on cancelling it. It turned out the waitress had overlooked it. She apologized profusely. It worked out fine but if we were a hungry group, I think a couple of people would've been grumbling.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I never had Burmese food, but went here for dinner last night with two foodie friends. It was awesome. I loved it and would definitely come here again. The service was impeccable and super helpful since I tend to ask for suggestions. We started off with the Papaya Salad and then moved onto the Catfish Chowder.  The papaya salad was refreshing and crunchy. The catfish chowder was thick and I would not recommend it. It's a little strange. 

Next, we had the rangoon beef, pan fry prawn with string beans, and nan gyi dok. I love the string beans and prawn. It was super tasty. It was not too salty or sweet. Definitely recommends it !!! The noodles were lemony, sweet, and clean to eat. Oh my goodness, the best was the dessert! You gotta order the dessert. Forgot the name and cannot locate it on the online menu. It is pink with vanilla ice cream and tapioca. Yummy. Is so good, I would lick the cup if I was alone in my apartment. =)
author: Sophie C.

description:
Ong Noh Kaw Soi aka Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup.

There are many good dishes here, but I wasn't able to try them all.  By far, this dish stood out.  I had homemade coconut chicken noodle soup last year, and I had a craving for some.  Seems like a lot of fed-up customers from Burma SS come on over here... and not to insinuate that Mandalay is just a back-up or crappier.  Mandalay definitely holds its own.

ANYWAYS, the service is awesome, there wasn't a wait on the weekday, all the dishes sounds fab, and I would definitely go back (ok, yes, that was a run-on and grammatically incorrect sentence, but whateva).

Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm, I want some now =D
author: Michelle W.

description:
Hands-down best rice in the city!

Saffron rice = delicious
Coconut rice = incredible

Mandalay also had the best vegetarian dishes I've had in a long time.  Not much to look at, but the food is awesome, and it's surprisingly affordable.  No pretention, just good food.  Definite recommend.
author: Chris R.

description:
So when my date and I tried to get a table at Burma Superstar last night and were informed that the wait time was 90 minutes, we decided to try this place out. Oh my, it was delish: we had the tea leaf salad, the samosas, and the curry prawns and mongolian beef. Mmmmm.

The waitstaff was so nice. We even forgot to bring our leftovers with us, and the waitress called after us when we were halfway down the block. Now that's service.
author: Cleo B.

description:
Why is there all this tacky-plasticky-should-be-in-the-back-yard-of-someone-in-ft.-lauderdale shit next to all this meditative looking Buddha gear? Oh that's just so thai. I guess.

So yeah, I loved the outfits and the genuine looking smiles too. Oh, and I waited 5 minutes for a table. 

Tea leafs great. But kindly lay off the oil in... everything! Maybe if I just hadn't tried your superior over on Clement I could have given you 4 stars.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
My first experience with burmese food was at Burma SuperStar.  I had heard about Mandalay, but didn't believe that it would compare.

After dining at Mandalay, I would say that the food is very close, but I would go for Mandalay better.  First, you do not have to wait 2 hours just to have a meal.  Second, We were seated immediately with no reservations.  Third, The food was VERY good.  Last, it cost less than Burma Super Star.

We ordered about 7-8 items and I couldn't even tell you which ones they were, but whatever you select you won't go wrong.  

It was a friend's birthday so they sing happy birthday, but it was tape recorded so it was kind of cheesy, but it was cute.  

The desserts are also delicious.
author: R M.

description:
The food was awesome.  A passerby suggested we order their Burmese specialties and we were delighted we did.  

-Mandalay Beef - yummy!
-tea-leaf salad - unique and very good.
-Burmese hot and sour soup - The best soup i've had in forever - don't skip the soup!!
-string beans - yummy, but I left the stringbeans out overnight and we didn't get to eat them - if you happen to have any spare REFRIGERATED leftovers, please send them my way and get me out of the dog house!

We'd give em 5 stars, but the wait and service were slow... most likely we suspect because it was Jan 1.
author: Carlos W.

description:
I am going with 3 stars since I haven't been to the 'defacto' Burma Superstar.  
We started off with the coconut-chicken soup which was excellent. The only non-veg entree I tried was the Burmese curry lamb which was average, however the non-veg dishes were excellent.  I highly recommend the sauteed Peashoot with garlic and the spicy tofu with vegetables.  We finished the meal with the local desserts which were delicious, athough after my coconut drink and my coconut soup I was done with the coconuts!
author: Kiran G.

description: Amazing food. Don't bother with Burma superstar, this is better, easier to get in, more seating and easier parking
author: Liz S.

description:
Yummm,- who knew such great, subtle, balanced flavors could happily share real-estate on the same plate?  This was my first experience with Burmese food, but surely not my last.  

We went for lunch and had the whole place to ourselves.  The staff was kind and attentive.  The interior was warm and interesting, a perfectly comfortable place to eat.

Everything they brought to the table was excellent, black pepper soup, okra, Burmese style noodles and (especially) the two different styles of rice.  (Coconut rice and cehffron rice). 

The portions are generous and prices are reasonable (especially their lunch specials, which offer two flavors for under 10 bucks).

This place definitely scores big marks!
author: Essa C.

description:
Yumness. That's the keyword for Mandalay.  This restaurant sits a bit off the beaten- to- death path from Burma Superstar (two blocks away on Clement).  This Saturday evening, there was a clusterf&*k of takeout patrons and dine-in patrons glomming up the foyer, but the more-than-in-control hostess sorted folks out quickly and efficiently.  She was also quick with menus and drink orders, so the wait was a non-issue. Pllus the housemate and I got to ogle some very cute geek boys at a nearby table.

Anyway, on to the food.  As you might expect from a country conquered by other countries over the centuries, the cuisine is a blend of conquering and conquered.  Indian, Chinese and Thai dishes are synchretized into Burmese dishes through subtle tweaking of ingredients.  For example, our starter dish,  vegetable samosas, arrived at the table shortly after being seated.  The Burmese version of this Indian dish uses a lighter dough for the pastry and is formed longer, thinner than the plump, dimple-doughed Indian ancestor.  Mandalay serves it with a side of lightly picked cucumbers/carrots and a sweet red sauce. The samosas were crisp, hot and yummy. (see my theme).  Our second dish was a diner fave, green papaya salad.  The shredded slices of papaya didn't have the lime bite of it's Thai cousin, but rather radiated a quiet, spice heat that never overpowered. It also benefited from the heavy handed use of roasted peanuts and garlic.  

The two main dishes, ginger lamb and basil chicken, paired nicely with each other. The lamb was tender and gingery (hence the name, I suspect). Same for the basil chicken. The Thai/Asian basil in the chicken dish complemented the garlicky/gingery lamb.  The restaurant serves brown rice on request, so we also got to feel even more virtuous about our pan-asian pig out.

I've never tried any of the desserts listed on the menu, so if anyone else has info on that, please weigh in.

All in all, Mandalay is easier to take than Burma Superstar, and I find the food and service to be much better.  With mas cervezas and mutliple dishes, we still got out the place for less than $30 each (not counting tip).  Delish and a value, what's not to like?
author: philip c.

description:
Dreaded my dining experience (getting a table, receiving my food, clientle), but the dishes i ordered redeemed this two star review.

Apparently making a reservation the night before isn't any better than walking in and signing your name on the notepad posted on the wall. Waiting 30mins for a table was understandable since i went on a busy Saturday night. But what annoyed me was the hosts didn't have a clue as to who was next for a table. I would assume the names that aren't crossed out and closest to the top of the list would be next in line. Is it that difficult?

Anyways, after being seated for a few mins, the waitier took my order (I already pre-selected the dishes during my 30min wait). Soon after service fell off sharp. In the time it took to prepare my warm Rainbow Salad (40mins) tables that were seated after me got their entire dinner delivered. Speaking of salad, the server MOLESTED the 12 ingredients like ppl do with ice cream at Cold Stone, "stop molesting my ice cream/ salad!"

This place is such a yuppie magnet. Yuck! And the decor... it's questionable: electric palm tree, dusty ceiling/ furniture, flimsy folding table, etc.

Despite all the above, the food was very flavorful, refreshing, and well put together. Most dishes labeled "rainbow {enter dish name here}" were pretty good. However, portions were small. 

By the way, this is my first experience tasting Burmese cuisine. What does Burma Superstar has to offer? Hope it doesn't disappoint.
author: BrYan W.

description:
First off this is a great restaurant, no frills yet great service and excellent food.  
I came here on my B-day and was treated to a marvelous dinner.  My Lady ordered a personal champagne and also requested a B-day acknowledgement.  They played and sang a B-day song and gave me some ice cream.  Still excellent service.  We got the check (not itemized) paid, and left.  Well...today my Lady looks at the receipt and was charged $15 for a glass of house champagne, and to add a little to it they charged $6 for the B-day ice cream.  I have been a waiter and I have patronized restaurants for a few decades and I have never heard of charging for a B-day dessert.  
The food is excellent, service is good, but beware of the hidden bombs.  I would recommend this as a place to eat, just know that costs may be hidden and assumed.
author: Dawud H.

description: Love this place and find it's much, much better than some of the other Burmese in the area.  The decor is definitely kitschy, but the waitstaff is pleasant and efficient.  Most important, the food is more than worth the sometimes long wait.  The tea leaf salad is a must, as are the mango prawns, the Mandalay noodles, and the Burmese curry with lamb.  Every time I go I mean to try some of the specials listed on the board outside, but the regular items are so fantastic that I rarely stray from them.  Every time I go, though, I like to try at least one new thing, including from the dessert menu, and I've never been disappointed.
author: John H.

description:
no likie :(  I went here for my friend's birthday and i was truly disappointed by the portion size.

The food was great, very tasty.  But i have a big issue with the portion size.  We had 7 people in the party and we each ordered a dish-- family style.  But by the time the dish got to the last person, there was hardly anything left!

wtf, who skimped on the serving size?!

No one was being greedy and took half the dish either, it just wasnt enough to go around.... I think i'll think twice before coming here again, especially if it's a large table
author: kate y.

description:
Yummmm.. I love Burmese food. This is my to go place.

It is your typical family restaurant, no a long wait, and service is pretty decent. 

I have say the food here is as good as Superstar, but simplier. 

Decor is simple, but seating are spacious, not a date place.
author: Alice C.

description:
Mandalay rocks!  Whether you're craving Burmese food or you've never tried it before, you won't go wrong at Mandalay.  My partner and I ate here every single week when we lived in SF.  We don't even look at the menu - your must eats include Mango Chicken, Spicy Green Beans (off the hook), Naked eggplant (this dish is so tasty that even eggplant haters will love this eggplant) , and Secret Shrimp.  Some of these items (Nekka eggplant and Secret Shrimp) don't appear on the menu and if a waiter looks confused, just ask for Sherry and tell them Ernie and Hays sent you.  Sherry and Kevin are amazing people, will tell you all about life in Burma.  Really nice people, really great food, quality is always consistent.  You'll be back!  Enjoy and tell Kevin and Sherry we say hi from Austin!

P.S.  Tea leaf salad is also amazing
author: Erndog R.

description:
Went to Mandalay last night (party of 3 people) they would not give us reservations at 7PM, so we booked it on Open Table, and were somehow able to get in. Got there at 7 PM- the waiting area was PACKED and actually sat at our table at 7:30ish..... Now, nobody came to check on us, give us plates or napkins, or a menu for at least 15 minutes. At that point, we had to ask for a 3rd time. I know that they were busy, but they did not even seem to notice. Sangria was tasty... when it FINALLY got there.... Samosas were good- but took almost 45 minutes to simply get our App'zrs. By that time, we were so damn hungry, we almost weren't hungry anymore... Finally, the nice lady owner person came by to take our order (by memory)- she noticed no one was helping us... All in all, we were there for about 3 LONG HOURS because they took so long to get us our meal...
I have been to this restaurant many times, and the experience keeps going down hill. THOUGH we love RAYMOND the waiter who is always smiling, but he was unfortunately NOT our waiter last night.
I would give this place more stars but our experience keeps getting worse.
author: nikky d.

description:
We were in the neighborhood for my son's basketball practice and decided to go for dinner.  Powered up the iPhone Yelp app and Mandalay popped up.  Read the reviews and decided to give it a shot.  Glad we did, really enjoyed the food! 

Food was very fresh...they were packed mid week dinner time.  Service was a bit slow but over all our experience was very good and we will return again!
author: Daddy F.

description:
My Top 3 in San Francisco!! 

Mandalay is must for any occasion! I love this restaurant! We go at least once a month. These are my favorite dishes: 

Tea Leaf Salad 
Coconut Chicken Soup 
Curry Beef 
Mango Chicken 
Naked Eggplant (MY FAVORITE) 
Kai Soi Dok noodles 

And for dessert- palooda (which is similar to a halo-halo)
author: Jennie L.

description: Best Chinamen food I've ever had. Delicious Mandalay chicken!!!!
author: Le L.

description:
I feel so bad for all those people that only get their Burmese at Burma Superstar, spending a ton of money, waiting in line for forever, eating averagely tasty foods. 
Actually....
I like...
I dont feel bad for them. I'm glad they arent taking up space in my beloved Mandalay. 
I have so many good things to say about Mandalay its overwhelming....especially because I have not tried a single entree. 
I have had like...almost every single salad and every single one is absolutely delicious. I especially like the tea leaf, of course, as well as the ginger, and the mango, and well....all of them really.
Ahh the samusa soup....so freaking good. I always order it. Also...if you want to share, they will bring it out in individual little bowls. 
The apps are good too. Especially the Balada...its like this amazing baked thing with an awesome sauce and I could probably eat just Balada all day long. 
You must also try the ginger brew drink which is minty and tasty
author: Yuliya R.

description:
I had never had Burmese food previously and as it turns out, Mandalay was an excellent choice for the first experience. We started with Balada and delicious Coconut soup.  The Walnut Prawns were oddly sweet and delicious and the Mango Prawns were done to perfection.  The Mandalay Noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow pea powder, lime juice, onion and fried thin noodle on the top was mixed fresh at the table. The service was very responsive and the price is affordable.

I love this place!!
author: Charles B.

description: This is our absolute favorite restaurant in the Bay Area! The coconut chicken soup, house special noodle, and tea leaf salad are staples - but every single item on the menu is delicious. Mandalay over Burma Superstar any day. Super authentic.
author: Aaron W.

description: I haven't been back here for a while so I'm just reviewing past-several years.  Everyone I've ever taken to Mandalay LOVES it and continues to harp about going back.  Their tea salad is excellent and a nice different taste.  Everything else we've ever had has been tasty and fresh.  And if they had delivery, I'd be eating from there a whole lot more.
author: Kai T.

description:
I had high hopes for this place - perhaps the lesser hyped, but just as good twin sister of Burma Super Star up on Clement. The food is good - especially the tea salad.. but either we came in at the wrong time or the service was just SLOW. It took ridiculously long (around 1 hour) to get our salad out, and the soup (first one on the menu- excellent) and mandalay beef (way too fried: avoid it) came out verrrry slowly, well after we were done with the dishes prior. 

Friendly service, just slow. Also, we were 2nd on the list but it took 40 minutes to seat us. Bad timing? Maybe. I'll stick with Burma Super Star though - they are a bit better at getting you your food while you're still hungry.
author: Anika K.

description:
This place is solid - food's good and the service too. A little speedier than Burma Star and there's less of a wait -- I think we went right in. I seem to remember that the food came out acceptably fast , which is something I can't say about Burma Star. One caution: we asked te staff to bring us a traditional Burmese dessert, and they did. It was kinda rubbery -- not bad, just really different from anything any of us expected.

It's walking distance from Burma Star, so if you need an alternate, it's a good choice.
author: Karsten P.

description:
Like others, we came here one night not wanting to wait in line at Burma.  I had heard many good things about Mandalay and I was definitely glad we gave it a try.  I tried the veggie pot stickers, spicy tofu with vegetables, Nan Gyi Dok, coconut rice, and some warm semolina cakes for dessert.  Everything was pretty tasty.  The noodle dish (Nan Gyi Dok) had a really interesting and unique flavor. It was unlike anything I've ever had, but it was quite delicious.
