The atmosphere is a bit odd.  Thankfully it is more roomy than Burma, but it seemed Christmasy in June.  There were ornaments hanging from the ceiling.  Paired with some faux greenery, the ornaments made it look even more like Christmas.  Christmas or not, we will definitely be back to try more dishes.
author: Squirrel L.

description:
Forget "that other" Burmese restaurant around the corner, this is the place to go. This place has become a staple night out for my boyfriend and me. Friendly and attentive staff and delicious food.

I almost always start with samosas and a tea leaf salad. The special noodles are amazing, as is the Mandalay Chicken.

Unlike a similar (but also good) restaurant down the street, there is no ridiculously long wait and you can actually have some elbow room while you eat!

5 Stars!
author: Kate Y.

description:
Some things here are really special.  The tea-smoked duck was definitely the best I've had.  The coconut rice was also excellent, and the sizzling rice soup was good.

One thing you have to get is the "young coconut water drink" which is a young coconut with the top chopped off, along with a spoon so you can eat the pulp afterward.  It's $3.25, which isn't much of a markup from the grocery store.

Other people in my group had the multi-course special, and were very happy with all of it, especially the rainbow salad and some sort of green curry soup.

I saw a PF Chang's comparison on one review, and to respond I'd say that I like PF Chang's, but this is a different type of place.  The dishes here are a bit more unusual, and some of them, like the tea-smoked duck, are really special.

I'll be back.
author: Bill C.

description:
Parking was a PITA.  

Some of the food was pretty tasty - we ordered the special dinner course, substituted for the Ong No Kau Soi coconut chicken soup since the soup that comes with the dinner special has seafood which I cannot eat.  That was pretty funny since I asked the waitress if the black pepper soup had seafood and she said no, and I read the menu and it said it had rock cod filet.  The coco chicken soup ended up fantastic.  We also had the tea leaf salad and found it to be very tasty, as it is at Burma Superstar.  

We also had the string beans as well as the Mandalay chicken.  I don't even like string beans, but my girlfriend does so I wanted to get that.  It was actually super tasty, had some fried garlic chips in it, but was a tad on the salty side.  Maybe I don't appreciate Mandalay chicken, but from what I gather it tasted slightly better than Panda Express orange chicken with a little less batter.  I only ate a little bit - if I eat too much of this stuff it gives me a sore throat since it's so oily.

2x while were sitting at the table after our stuff was boxed up, 2x different people came and asked if we wanted desserts.  Our "special dinner" comes with dessert, so I found that interesting.  Later on they brought out a fried banana with vanilla ice cream.  Meh.  

I thought the server was kind of slow - there was no wait when we showed up, but the waitress never really came back for us.  The girls and the guy bussing the tables were really quick, but they couldn't take our order or things like that.

This review might be biased since I have been eating at Burma Superstar for years, but oh well.
author: Dong T.

description:
My old boss took me here a couple times as well as the "other" Burmese place on Clement (my first time eating Burmese food) and I've been back to Mandalay many times since.

My absolute faves are the soups:

- Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup)
- Moo Hin Nga (Fish Chowder)

I've tried and like the other dishes as well: Samosas, Tea Leaf Salad (first time i had it, it was a bit weird, but you have to at least try it), Mandalay Chicken, and Mango Chicken. Never any complaints here. Flavorful and delicious.

The service is friendly and attentive. I wish it was closer to my work so I can indulge more often, but I always make it a point to hit up this spot when I'm in the area.
author: Carolyn J.

description:
Saturday night, table for 3 - No wait!

The food: Tea leaf salad, balada, tea-infused duck, coconut rice, and mango shrimp. The drinks: Burmese iced tea, ginger lemonade, tapioca coconut milk. ALL GOOD!

Our group was full and happy with everything. Service was on point and the ambiance was casual and chill. 

The damage: only $55 for three people with drinks, cheers to that!

Looking forward to going again :)
author: Jen P.

description:
Yes, like many folks here, we chose Mandalay as an alternative to the always packed Burma Superstar.  We called ahead on a Friday night just in case, and were able to secure a table easily.

We arrived, were seated promptly, and were serviced expeditiously.  

We were told that no photos were allowed.  

We inquired, and were later informed by the manager that it was because the restaurant feared "others" would "copy our dishes."

As for the food - not too memorable.  
Tea Salad - nicely sour with interesting texture; the peanuts short of overwhelmed everything else.
Pea Sprouts - great - perfectly cooked, crisp-tender and garlicky.  
Lamb Curry - ok; nothing special.
Mandalay Special Noodle - also one of the better dishes; fairly tasty but also nothing special.
Portions - small
Service - wonderrful, warm

All in all a decent and average meal, but I'd rather go to Burma and brave the wait next time I'm near Clement.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Just okay. 

The tea leaf salad has soggy tea leaves.
author: Judy L.

description:
The food is good. That being said, we will not patronize Mandalay again. This review is for their take-out service. Twice in a row, we have been given the wrong food. The first time, upon returning home (after waiting around 15 minutes longer than they said our order would be ready) and before we  unpacked our food, they called us at home and told us they had given us someone else's order. They do not deliver, and told us we needed to bring it back to the restaurant and pick up our order. So another 1/2 hour round trip. When I arrived, I was given a perfunctory apology and offered a soda (?!) as compensation. That's it. No adjustment on the check, nothing. 
A couple of weeks later we decided to give them another chance. When I picked up the food, I asked them to review my order, nicely explaining what happened last time. They recited it correctly, but when we got home, we discovered one dish was again wrong (a chicken dish instead of the noodle dish we ordered). Once again, had to drive back. No offer to do anything for our inconvenience. Mistakes happen, but this is above and beyond, and worse, they don't seem to care.
author: Diane R.

description:
Sort of a hidden Burmese gem, especially given its close proximity to the perhaps overrated and definitely overpopular Burma Superstar.

I was pretty pleased with my experience here. The mango chicken was delectable. It's a nice and quiet location that has a little bit of exoticism in its decor but doesn't go over the top.
author: Bernie L.

description:
So this is my third trip to Mandalay and my first for a date since I broke up with the West Virginian Amazon (WVA). So I'll rate the food first...


Tea Leaf Salad - An orgasm with peanuts... which really should count as two orgasms.

Mongolian Chicken - Very good and spicy without leaving you unable to speak due to tongue burn. Being able to speak during a date can be useful.  

Black Pepper Soup - Came alongside the chicken but was actually a very good counterpoint to the Kaw Soi Dok. Not actually all that peppery, but probably the best use of cucumbers I've seen in a long time. 

Kaw Soi Dok- my choice... very delicious, and much more subtle than the chicken... a little bit of sweetness dovetails nicely into the savory flavor of the garlic and onion. 

Dessert - Mango slices on sticky rice - delicious diabetes-inducing dessert. The rice wasn't too mushy and had a nice texture with it, so they get points for a good execution of a dessert with a low degree of difficulty...

I called in my reservation the day before, strolled right in and grabbed a table, no wait, no hassle. The service was absolutely fabulous and attentive - if i could give them nine stars I would. Mandalay drops a five star performance as expected...
 
As for the date herself... um... yeah we'll just say Mandalay's food was the highlight of the evening by far and leave it at that....
author: Mani F.

description:
It's time for Burma Superstar to give up its superstar to Mandalay. Mandalay is better in terms of quality and service. There is no huge wait time and they do take reservations. Staff are friendly and dining room is spacious, nicely decorated (even though it may seem like Christmas all year with ornaments hanging from ceiling, but it certainly adds an Asian touch). 

Everyone here seems to raves about the Tea Leaf Salad. I think it's so-so, just something crunchy and out of the ordinary. But I guess I like the simple things, like Mango Prawns,mmm delish, with coconut rice/saffron rice and cinnamon. Would love to go back and try more dishes.
author: Jeanette W.

description:
I am never quite sure if I like Burmese food or not. But I like Mandalay. There were three of us and two of us just had 3 drinks each at 83 Proof on 1st Street and Mission, and we were hungry since it was about 830 pm. Served family-style, we shared the tea leaf salad, (tea leaf, peanuts, crunchy lentils, sesame, and other things) that was very interesting and pretty good. No veggies aside from the tea leaf, and I think this always keeps me awake! 

We also ordered the moh hing nga (catfish chowder with lentils) which was hearty and served with fresh cilantro and lemon wedges. But I didn't see any catfish. Where's the fish? They also give you the option of having rice noodles in the soup. We ordered the soup as described in the menu (with no noodles), but then when we asked if it's usually served with noodles, the waitress said that she usually has the soup with noodles. I'm now confused. If you usually serve it with noodles, why doesn't the menu say noodles in the description of the dish? If you don't say that noodles become an addition. Are you trying to make a buck out of not giving us the real stuff!!!?? Anyway, aside from that, the soup was pretty good and i really liked the fresh cilantro in the soup. 

We also shared meat potstickers, the Burmese style curry with chicken, Rangoon Style Beef and coconut rice. The curry chicken was cooked with young potatoes with a coconut-based curry and really good and saucy. This isn't a spicy curry, so if you like, add some of the chili they bring to the table a the beginning of the meal. I totally recommend this curry. Rangoon Style Beef was basically tomato beef. Good, but not terrific. I don't think I would order this again. I don't like ordering Asian dishes that I can make at home. And the coconut rice was really good. 

Ok I like Mandalay because you don't have to wait, the service is very very good, it's comfortable but intimate and I like their chicken curry.
author: Betty L.

description:
At first I thought it foolish and futile for this other Burmese restaurant to exist so proximally to Burma Superstar, but I have since realized that its ability to survive is dependent on myriad factors (some of which other Yelpers have discussed as well). 

1. Short wait time - as many have experienced, the wait at BS is HORRENDOUS. Even on a Tuesday night. At 9:30 pm. At this place, our party of 5 was able to saunter in at quarter past 7 on a Tuesday evening and be seated promptly. 

2. Spaciousness - at BS, you'd be lucky not to have your eye poked out by your dining companion. At Mandalay, there is room for you to do the funky chicken in your seat if you so desire. 

3. Home-style cooking - the dishes here possess subtler flavors akin to what the bf enjoys at family dinners. While BS has a lot of BING BANG BOOM!, Mandalay is quiet comfort food. 

4. The Price is Right - Mandalay is about 25% cheaper than BS, with similarly sized dishes. 

While Burma Superstar may be the better place for impressing out-of-towners, this place is perfect for a simply scrumptious dinner.
author: Lillian L.

description: To start off I am not a huge fan of chinese cuisine. Mandalay serves chinese/ burmese cuisine. It's quite a nice place. The design inside resembles more the chinese restaurant. But it is clean and they have fresh flowers on each table, which is very pleasant. We came here for lunch with my sister and left quite satisfied. The food was good and I quite enjoyed it. Do not remember exactly what we ate, but it was good. I guess I will revisit, if I'll happen to be in the neighborhood.
author: Yuliya B.

description:
Came here last night with a friend and we arrived just before the huge crowds (yay!)  This place gets a lot of business and it is not hard to see why.  The food was amazing...  We ordered a tea leaf salad which was very well presented and mixed at our table, chicken satays, a noodle dish and some curry chicken.  All of it was wonderful and we ate way too much.  We had to walk around for about 2 hours to help digest all the great food we ate.

This is the oldest Burmese restaurant in San Francisco and the whole place has so much character.  I love the flowers in cute little vases hanging from the drop ceiling and the paintings on the walls are pleasant to look at, the restaurant has charm.

The staff are very quick at taking your order and bringing the dishes to you table and everyone was very friendly.  I am not sure if this is a great place for groups - probably not a group larger than 6 people as I only saw a few large rounds.  But it is perfect for having dinner with someone whose company you really enjoy.
author: Kristine K.

description: We get Mandalay catered thru our work caterer about once a month. The food arrives hot and varied in selection and it's always BOMB. I've still never been into the restaurant, but I will go sometime soon! I do wish the menu was posted online tho....
author: Devi G.

description: Love this place.  Rarely a wait.  The samusas are delicious.  Love the Mandalay noodles.  Excellent Mongolian Beef.  Extra bonus when they "sing" happy birthday to someone... added entertainment.
author: Lili L.

description: Why oh why haven't I tried this place earlier? Damn you Burma superstar for tricking me with your long lines and hype. This place will kick Burma superstar in a drag out fight any day of the week. And I will be happily waiting on the sidelines cheering them on. You must try the tea leaf salad and pumpkin curry. Trust me. You'll thank me later.
author: Sophia C.

description: Great food and service in a warm environment. Made my husband and I's Best of the Bay list. Try the tea leaf salad.
author: Wren C.

description:
Wow the restaurant was packed!  Our reservation was set for 7:30, but we didn't get seated till 8:15.  Then they crammed 6 of us into a 4 seater table!  We requested to get moved to a bigger table.  Luckily a group at a larger circular table finished dining, and we were able to switch tables after another 15 minutes.

The food was pretty good.  We all left feeling very full and satisfied.  The most interesting dish of the night was the Tea Leaf Salad.  Definitely try it.    My favorite dish afterwards was probably the Singapore Style noodle.  It tastes like a twist on the Pad Thai...with very thin noodles.  

Appetizers:
*Balada   (Similar to a Roti.  Served with a very mild curry sauce)
*Fried Squash   (Very simple taste.  Dipping sauce is light/mild)
*Tea Leaf Salad   (Fragrant.  Crunchy.  Nice texture)

Main Dishes:  
*Pan fried Okra with tofu*  (It was oooo-kay.  Nothing mind blowing)  
*Mandalay Chicken   (Reminds me of Panda Express chicken)
*Singapore Style Noodle   (Tasty.  Flavorful.  Chewy noodles)
*Mandalay Special Noodle w tofu   (Pretty good.  Slightly oily) 
*Smoked Tea Duck   (Think Peking duck)
*Basil Prawns   (Not particularly memorable)
*Coconut Rice   (Fragrant.  Light.  Yummy)

All of that for $98.  Not bad.


(Parking can be difficult to find)
author: Jenny K.

description:
+ Wonderful food! 
- Long waiting time even after reserving a table.
author: Lalith M.

description:
Well, I've been disappointed again.  I have been here before with no joy but after reading all the great Yelp reviews I decided to give it a second try hoping to have a great meal with my two friends, one visiting from out of Wisconsin where they supposedly don't even have "Burmese" food.  We had driven by Burma Superstar with their huge wait line so next up was Mandaly.  When we finally arrived without reservation at 8:45pm on a Saturday night, the 12 ppl in line ahead of us helped me set aside my first bad visit as just a fluke.  OK, rambling, so let's talk briefly about the food.

Again, it was quite late (~9:30pm), almost closing time, when we were seated.  We ordered light, pretty basic dishes: the "Pot Sickers" were good; the "Pan Fry Prawn with String Bean (hot & spicy)" was OK - the string beans being the better part of the dish; the "Mandalay Chicken (hot & spicy)" tasted more like not so Sweet and Sour Chicken; the "Burmese Curry Beef (hot & spicy) with potato" was rather bland curry; and "Coccunut Rice" which was well, white rice - hard to screw that up.  None of the dishes were hot or spicy, though I do realize I may not have asked for a more desirable degree of heat.

To summarize, none of the dishes had any pop.  Prices were competitve and the staff was very friendly but the food was so-so.  Though my friends were not as critical/disappointed, I left with the feeling that I would never crave any dish at Mandaly and probly won't go back, sparing them my dreaded third strike.
author: Keith S.

description:
When a friend and I were looking for a new restaurant to try, I was excited to find this place with good reviews and endless comparison to Burma Superstar.   AND you can make reservations.  Awesome!

Got there right at 7 on a Monday night, greeted by a friendly waitress.  I told her my friend was coming soon and I would just wait for her before we get seated. 

---Oh are you waiting for a woman?
---Um, yeah....
---Yeah, she came and then she left. 

What?  What was she trying to say?  I got stood up by my friend?  Turns out, my friend just left to get something from her car and DID come back. 

Anyway, we ordered everything recommended by yelpers: Mango Chicken, Tea leaf Salad, and the Special Noodles.  The Mango chicken was good but a bit too sweet for my taste.  Tea leaf salad is just as good as Burma Superstar's, I thought.  Although I have friends who swear by tea leaf salad from BS and nowhere else.   My favorite was definitely the Special Noodles.  It has a very light coconut curry taste and the chicken pieces were so tender and flavorful!  I would definitely come back just for the noodles. 

The service was very efficient and friendly.  Water always refilled.  I see how the ceiling decoration looks a bit Christmas-ornaments-gone-wrong, but overall, cozy and comfortable atmosphere.  

The birthday songs that they play are a bit too much.  One version in Chinese, another in English.  And then onto the next birthday table and press re-play all over again.
author: Candice B.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMMM-Mandalay.

I liked you before I knew you because your name reminds me of a Seinfeld reference. But now, I must declare my LOVE!

Your special noodles and tea salad are nothing short of magical. I don't like to wait, but you made it worth our while. And the servers are so nice!
author: G Z.

description:
So, first of all, this is not like Burma Superstar. And that's not a bad thing. Note - the place is a Burmese & Manadrin restaurant. That means the food has some dishes that lean more toward your Chinese fare.

Everything we had was tasty: Tea Leaf Salad ($8.5) - it does not have lettuce like the one at Superstar. Sorry to keep comparing the two, but they are different.

Smoked Tea Duck ($18 for half) - oh so yummy, Mandaly Beef ($10.25) - I thought it was going to be spicy but it was sweet and TASTY, Pan Fry Prawn with String Bean ($12) - a little spicy and so delish and the Mandalay Special Noodle ($8) - thicker noodle with a yellow pea powder that gave it a distinct taste. Subtle, maybe a little sweet, sort of buttery even. It was just good and something I have never had before.

There was no line like at, you know where, and it's decorated in.....it's just highly decorated. My whitey hubby loved the decoration, I thought, hmmm, maybe a bit much. Whatever - the food is good and we got free dessert. I don't know what it was but it was a warm, non-sticky mochi-ish, mustard color, coconut milikish tasting treat. I was stuffed, but I downed my piece and my hubby's. Our friends loved it too.
author: Wendy B.

description:
We went here on a Saturday evening with co-workers, the place was packed but we got a table pretty easily plus we had  a stroller with a 5-month old.

We had the Coconut chicken soup, reminds me of curry or squash soup, kinda fancy looking but forgettable. The tea leaf salad was blah - - Burma Superstar still rocks!  Seafood Birds Nest had a couple of seafood plus vegetables (I can count the scallops and the shrimp)and a lot of honey walnuts, the taste nah! The Basil eggplant was not that tasty, it was sweet and ordinary - where's the basil, how come I never tasted it?

Service was ok, we had to ask the lady server 5 times for extra napkins.

The verdict:  Nope.  I'm not a fan. I might as well request my Burmese co-worker to cook Burmese dishes for me, her cooking is waaay better than Mandalay!
author: kyra d.

description:
I really love Mandalay - we consistently get good dishes, soups and appetizers.  I'm hung up on ordering the Rainbow Chicken, it is so delicious - a fantastic blend of veggies and mango and pineapple - MMMmmm!  We  haven't actually dined in yet - just pick up every time, probably cuz they're so close to our apartment.  But the interior is cute - a little homey you could say.  And they usually seem to have a full house, but I've never seen a line.  A good sign that the food is good, but that you won't have to wait!

I can't wait to go back as I definitely want to taste lots more of their dishes.  Tip: They don't deliver, but they do take credit cards.

Update:  We finally dined "in" this Saturday night and the service was spot on.  Great job, very attentive!
author: Tracey E.

description:
I used to love this place. The last time I went (last year), I was a bit disappointed though. Maybe it was just an off night. I will try again when I move back home to the Bay Area later this year.

The moohinga (fish chowder) is fantastic and very comforting. Lots of crispy fried fish bits in their add just the right texture. Their lapat doc (tea leaf salad) is pretty excellent as well. Actually, all of their salads are worth trying. And definitely order the coconut rice. You can have white rice anywhere, so don't even think of ordering it here.

The ginger lamb and mango chicken are simple stir fried dishes worth trying. Same goes with the peashoots and green beans. My girlfriend and I used to order just enough food so that I'd have enough coconut rice, mango chicken, and a bit of veg left over for the following day's lunch.

I  tried the tea smoked duck the last time I went, and it was so-so. Oh, and their samusas are pretty good too.
author: J K.

description:
Mandalay was a REALLY good value and had some very tasty dishes.  However, mine wasn't among them (lamb curry...very bland) and that's really the reason I'm not giving a higher rating.  My tablemate had mango prawns which were fantastic.

The desserts, though, were also quite bland.  But you probably aren't coming to a Burmese place for dessert.

This was good Burmese food, but it wasn't great.  Maybe I caught them on a bad night.
author: Jon M.

description:
Ive been in love with this place since my first visit in june 2005. Some my girlfriends and i get together and come to mandalay and do lunch. The service to me was nice we didn't wait to long for our food. 
Some dishes we like to order are the coconut rice, chicken satay, mango prawns and rainbow chicken also there ginger lemonade is really refreshing.
author: kimiko l.

description:
So good!  We didn't want to wait for a table at Burma Superstar, and my cousin swore this place was just as good, so we decided to give it a whirl on our visit to SF.  This place was the first Burmese restaurant in SF, opening in 1984. 

We started off with the tea leaf salad which we asked to be mixed with lettuce so it wasn't so strong and balada, a crispy paratha like bread served with curry dipping sauce.  Both were delicious and we were super hungry since we were eating at 10 pm EST.

We decided to split 4 dishes amongst the 4 of us (we also had a friend join), we got a special of prawns with pumpkin.  There were too few prawns and the pumpkin could have been cooked a little more, but the sauce was delicious.  The chicken with mango was good, with slightly crispy chicken and perfectly ripe mango.  The beef curry was delicious and you could tell it was cooked over a long period of time.  The Basil Spicy Eggplant could not compete with Burma Superstar's delicious eggplant that I remembered from 5 years ago, nor could the coconut rice which tasted too weakly of coconut.  I'd definitely be back to avoid the Burma Superstar craze, but I missed not going there.

The service was very friendly and attentive and told us a nice little history of the restaurant.
author: Lindsay E.

description: Food was good, however, if I'm not seated comfortably, then I'm not a happy camper.  This was my third time to be jammed into smaller tables trying to accommodate larger groups.  Moreso, if you don't have the table availability, then don't offer reservations!  Its misleading.  To add to the discomfort was the slow service for a weekday.
author: Coni B.

description:
Appetizer Samusas: eh, ok

Tofu with vegetables: well cooked - I ate the whole thing

Mandalay beef: eh -  the sauce was overpowering, and it had nothing to do with the garlic (cuz for me, you can never be overpowering with garlic.. there was something else in that sauce that NEEDED rice in order to lessen its potency)

Coconut rice: best I've had

Dishes here are hit and miss

I'm undecided if I will come back here or not
author: suz s.

description:
Delicious, well priced, not as crowded as Burma Superstar. 

Things to remember: 
Ginger Lemonade
Mandalay Noodles
Eggplant special (dont remember name) 
Sizzling Beef

Inside decor is a little cheesy, but the food and service makes up for it. (although the service does suffer quite a bit when it gets hectic in there, however everyone is very accomodating and nice)

Need to return to try more dishes!
author: H g.

description:
This place truly is better than Burma Super Star.  Last night we were going to wait 1.5 hours so we could eat at Burma at 10pm...at 9:30pm we got fed up and tried out Mandalay for the first time.  

Mandalay is amazing.  I loved their Mandalay Special noodles and the tea leaf salad.  You must try this place!
author: Lauren L.

description: Portions are to small.  But their rainbow salad looked amazing.  My friends who ordered the tea salad did not like that there were no cabbage included.
author: C t.

description:
AWESOME!!!!!!!!!  Love this place.  Take all my out of town guests here.

It's the not hip Burma Superstar with better more authentic food.  It's sparking clean albeit very strange decor.  The staff is SOOOO sweet and love to serve you.  

Great prices.  Tea life salad to dream about for days!!
author: Judah C.

description:
Yum Yum Yum!

Walnut prawns...BANGING.

In fact, everything was really delicious...can't find anything wrong with the place. Just as good as burmasuperstar as far as i'm concerned.
author: Dayna E.

description: Mandalay is so much better than Burma Superstar.
author: City Guy A.

description:
Best Burmese food in SF! Blows Burma Superstar out of the water!  Best part is, I can walk to Mandalay in 5 minutes from my apartment. 
I would give Mandalay 5 stars, but we had to wait 15 minutes before anybody even visited our table/brought us water, and waited 40 minutes for our food after ordering. They brought our coconut rice about 25 minutes before any of our other dishes, so by the time our food came, the rice was cold.  We got there at 5, and didn't leave until 6:30. But, in Mandalay's defense, they were extremely busy (surprisingly busy for 5 pm) and seemed unprepared and understaffed.
Now on to the good stuff... the FOOD! Holy cow. The Mandalay noodles were to die for.  It was one of my favorite noodle dishes ever. We got the vegetarian samosa soup, which tasted as if they smashed up samosas into a curry broth, and it was perfect. We also got the curried prawns, and the homemade coconut ice cream. The food was all incredible.
If we hadn't waited so long for our food, I would give this place 5 stars. I can't wait to try Mandalay on a weeknight, when it's sure to be less crowded. I am very excited to have found a new favorite neighborhood spot. 

Next time you want Burmese food, you must venture out to Mandalay!!!
author: megan s.

description: Wow, the Basil Lamb has to be one of the top dishes I have experienced in the city.  Add to that the Tea Leaf Salad, some coconut rice and I am a happy camper.  The service is always attentive and proficient.  The food always makes me want to keep coming back for more.
author: S L.

description:
+ very good food
+ excellent service
+ reasonably priced
+ they serve yummy tea, while you wait for take-out
author: Tulip F.

description:
This place is good.  I ended up here by accident, after getting totally depressed about the lines at Burma Super Star.  I didn't go in with great expectations because it didn't seem logical to me that 2/3 blocks away another Burmese restaurant could be so quiet.  But anyways, was not disappointed and now I keep coming back.
The service has always been cheerful and efficient when I've been there but it lacks that hectic vibe that I always get at Super Star.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
Food : **** (4)
Staff : **** (4)
Decor : **** (4)

When the decor's good, you expect the service to be good. And you don't mind sitting down and waiting then, while you're sipping on some tea. Honestly, I didn't come here for the food, but was pleasantly surprised with it.

"ai"
author: Anand I.

description:
Fried squash and tea leaf salad were good. Mandalay chicken was palatable. Curry catfish was, well, chock full of bones. And inedible.

Took half an hour for them to refill a drink after having one ordered; she literally brought a new $4 drink after our food had been packed up. Service was retarded. I'd give it one star except the tea leaf salad was soooo good and ginger beer mixed with lemonade was tasty.

Still, spent $50 sampling the menu and, well, it wasn't all that.
author: Cate F.

description:
Three words: Tea Leaf Salad! 

When I go we always get  this salad, it's so satisfying. I've had the mango chicken (spicy), the basil beef (delicious) and the walnut prawns (my absolute favorite). Top it off with friendly staff and the occasional free desert of mango sorbet. 

Good date place.
author: M O.

description:
There seems to be this Mandalay vs. Burma Superstar review battle going on out there.Here's what I think about Mandalay.

Pros
1. No waiting! I walked with my bf with no reservation on a Thursday night and we were seated immediately.
2. Fast and friendly staff.
3. Great selection of food. There were so many things on the menu to choose from it was really hard to decide.
4.We got out food fairly quickly.
5. It's a spacious restaurant. Burma is loud, cramp and crowded.

Cons
These aren't so much cons but comparisons to BurmaSS
We ordered:

-Rainbow salad-2.5 stars out of 5. It just didn't taste fresh and there weren't as many ingredients as Burma. It was good but not awesome.

-Hot and Sour Soup-3.5 stars out of 5. The soup was great. Hearty, fully of flavor, spicy enough and good portions. However, it wasn't super special. Better than most Chinese restaurants H&S soup which are usually watered down but still it was not special.

-Spicy Tofu with Vegetables- 2 stars out of 5. It was really bland and not that spicy. It was also luke warm.As if  someone else ordered it, sent it back and then we ordered it and they sent it back out. 

Mandalay Noodle-  4 out of 5 stars. This was my favorite dish of the meal. It was full of flavor, a little crunchy and the chicken and lemongrass was a really touch.

Overall Mandalay is good. It's a nicer more relaxing atmosphere with decent food. If you are starving skip BurmaSS and eat here. But if you don't mind the wait then BurmaSS is a better choice.
author: alexandria a.

description:
Started off with coconut chicken soup.  I was skeptical.  YUM!  Tried the balada but I wasn't a huge fan, and I completely disliked the dipping sauce since I'm not a curry fan.  

My entree was walnut prawns and they were to die for.  It was like having dinner and dessert at the same time.  I also ordered a plate of veggies for the table.  

Went there on a recommendation.  Definitely worth the drive over to The Richmond.
author: Carol B.

description:
Lets quickly compare Mandalay with P.F. Chang's in Emeryville:
On a Friday night, you can end up waiting a good half an hour for a table at either of these establishments.  The difference -- you know that P.F. Changs is going to be good, but you might have some uncertainty about Mandalay.  That is exactly what I was feeling - uncertainly.

When my gf and I finally got our table at Mandalay, it took no time for us to get our order placed and for the plates to get to our table. Our order consisted of these dishes:

Chicken Satay:
Dry, pitifully small, little over lukewarm, bland-tasting (in flavor and texture).  The frozen chichen yakitori from Costco is 1000x better.  The peanut sauce that came with it looked like baby vomit, and didn't taste much better.  Best of Thai's satay BLOWS THEM OUT THE WATER.

The Prawn and Walnut:
Cold, soggy, and waaay overly mayonnaise'd.  The walnuts tasted old, as if the nut's natural oils were going rancid.  They used a nice plate, but who cares?  P.F. Chang's Melon and Walnut Prawns BLOWS THEM OUT THE WATER.

The Mandalay Beef:
This was the better of the three dishes that we ordered; it was served hot, sugary, a little spicy, and vaguely crispy with heavy orange/citrus influence.  It was simple and edible, but nothing anywhere near writing home about.  P.F. Chang's Orange beef BLOWS THEM OUT THE WATER.

To recap, I would have rather eaten at P.F. Chang's than at Mandalay.  I was woefully underwhelmed by the quality of the food, and the grueling wait. 

My recomendation:  Take you lady out to a nice dinner at P.F.'s instead. Classy and consistant.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Forget Burma Superstar. Seriously, just cross it out -- you get better food at Mandalay without the overhype and without the ridiculous line. 

I do so love this place, we decided it was tacky on the outside (seriously. it may also be a little tacky on the inside, but whatever) but we should just try it ... and it was fab! 

We had the tea leaf salad - it has peanuts, tea leaves, kaffir lime leaves, sesame seeds and like 5 other little ingredients. They come to your table, mix it all up for you into this little pile of yumminess. It is fragrant, so many different textures and very fun to eat.

We then had the Burmese bread that looks like Roti, it is a little thicker but super crispy and excellent.

We paired this with the chicken curry, which was very yummy, though not as stellar as....

The special Burmese noodles!! -- their homemade noodles with a little chicken curry and some other surprises on top. You mix it all together, it's a little of a luke warm noodle, but it's SO delicious. 

The service is also superb, the ladies are very into you enjoying everything you eat and mixing things at your table for you. I like that. 

It's good value, not expensive at all, so definitely try it out, it is interesting food, and I am going back soon to try all the other dishes that looked amazing.
author: Subie C.

description:
Rainbow Salad...

That's all you need to know.

But honestly,  I heard about this place much like many others as an alternative to Burma Superstar without the 2 hour wait.  

Service was great, my water glass never went empty!  We even got free tea!  Perhaps that's part of the deal...

Anyway, delicious sumosa no matter how you spell it.

My friend got the pumpkin curry with tofu and I almost stole it from him.

Check it out!
author: Kristina K.

description:
I had never tried Burmese food before. 

I learned about Mandalay from Yelp, after refusing to even try to go to BS- turned off by the thought of waiting for hours.

So, Mandalay was soooo damn good. No need to even try BS now.

This food is great.  

Mango Chicken - amazing, white meat chicken with mango pieces  
    cooked perfectly - so succulent and tasty. 
Mandalay noodles - This is prepared at your table and finished with 
    lemon juice to give it the ultimate fresh taste.
Mandalay salad - unlike any salad I've ever had and worth a try. It has 
    peanuts, garlic, tea leaves and some other ingredients. Again - it is 
    prepared at your table. I loved it!
Mandalay chicken - just ok. extremely sweet. kinda boring. wouldn't order 
    again. 

Everything we ordered tasted  incredibly fresh and tasty. The ambiance is nice, the service is warm and lovely. Overall, great restaurant. I can't wait to go back.

Avoid going here on a weekend night after 7pm - there will be a huge crowd waiting and the waitors/hosts are really disorganized (even with a reservation) - so it's a real hassle getting a table.
author: Chili B.

description:
This is the best Burmese place I have ever been to! It's a million times better than Burma Superstar - which is entirely too commercial and not authentic. 

pro's: tea leaf salad (to die for), mango chicken, all around delicious cuisine, friendly staff, typically short wait times

con's: In bumblefuck (who really goes out to the Richmond?)

Just plain funny: If you happen to be there when it's someone's birthday, they dim the lights and play this funny/Burmese version of "Happy Birthday" over the loud-speaker and the wait staff all claps and sings. It's truly entertaining.
author: Sadia J.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 92

I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place!

One of my favorite restaurants ever!!! I just went to lunch there for the umpteenth time and it's sooooo good. Lots of perfectly portioned, low fat food that is served quickly in a cute spot in the Richmond.

Some of my favorites: Rainbow Salad (old style, though i don't know the what the difference is between that and new style), Mango Chicken, and green beans!!!

Their desserts are pretty nice too. And they're great for lunch and dinner. And I have taken a couple people there who are not big Asian food fans. But after one meal there, they're hooked!!!
author: Kristina C.

description: Delicious, starting with the savory aromas that greeted me when I walked in the door.  Similar to Chinese and Thai food, but completely original.  My friends and I had a lamb special, Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup), Hot and Sour Soup, Chicken Lettuce Cups, Mandalay Special Noodle (exotic, not like Pad Thai as I expected) basil prawns, coconut rice and spicy string beans.  All excellent.  the atmosphere is very pleasant.  Relaxed.  Our server brought us a complimentary dessert, a sweet potatoe dish.  Everyone liked the place.  The photo reminded me of the flower tea I had.  Beauty in a glass.
author: Stacey D.

description:
After reading the reviews on this place, a buddy and I were excited to check it out.  We went in on a weekday afternoon so I can't comment on any long wait times, we were seated immediately.  

The staff was more than helpful when it came to making recommendations so we felt we were in good hands.  The chicken samusas were spot on, crispy on the outside, inside had great texture and flavor.

There were lots of comments on the Tea Leaf Salad so of course we had to give it a try.  It was definitely an unexpected experience, and for what it was, tasty, but there was nothing about it that grabbed me and made me want to order it again.

The soup was excellent, spicy, tangy but with a hint of sweetness.  It was obvious that all the ingredients were fresh and worked well together.  Thumbs up.  The curried lamb was tender and moist and the Mandalay Special Noodles were creamy with a nice crunchiness from the fried onions.  

All in all it was a good experience but I'd be a little wary about a long wait, might not be quite worth it.
author: Mike I.

description:
Mandalay is fantastic! After being Burma Superstar groupies for six years, my boyfriend and I checked this place out the other night because we had heard great things. There was a bit of a wait, but dear me was it worth it. 

The staff was accommodating and friendly and the food was out of this world. We started off by ordering a pitcher of ginger beer (which the waitress said would get us two glasses each, but ended up being about 3.5) and it was wonderful. Then we moved on to the food. Being fans of Burma's tea leaf salad, we thought we would mix it up and try the ginger salad, which was fantastic. We also got the lemon chicken and Mandalay beef with coconut rice and ended up scarfing it all down in about ten minutes because it was so delicious. I usually hate ordering beef at Thai/Burmese/Chinese places because I always find it a bit tough and chewy, so I wasn't very excited when my boyfriend insisted on doing it, but in the end, I was thrilled. The Mandalay beef was the best thing we ate all night. The sauce was delicious and the meat was cooked to perfection. It was melt-in-your-mouth awesomeness, Burmese style. 

I think the waitress may have overheard us saying it was our new favorite SF date spot, because soon after, she brought us complimentary mango pudding desserts, which were also delicious. Neither of us like pudding, but we both practically licked the bowls. 

I would absolutely recommend Mandalay to anyone interested good Burmese food...or just good food in general. It was fantastic.
author: Jessica H.

description: I hate to compare, but the food at Mandalay is not as great as Burma Superstar, but still good food.  The burmese iced tea was delicious, it tastes similar to Thai iced tea.  The tea leaf salad was not as good as Burma Superstar, nor was the flat noodles. The coconut rice was just ok, and the dessert was blah.  I would come here again if I didn't want to wait in line for Burma Superstar.
author: H. A.

description:
i love this place but have ordered the same thing the two times i've eaten here- hopefully you can try it and be more adventurous! 

i am amazed at how busy it was, there was always a huge crowd waiting to get in in the lobby. be prepared to wait, but the hostess (is she the owner?) makes it better by greeting you and offering you your drinks while you wait.
author: Michelle M.

description:
For the price range, this restaurant is fantastic. 

The food really flavorful and great for sharing. We had the lamb curry with the Mandalay bread (the bread was REALLY good, the curry okay), the sweet and sour soup (enough for 3 as a starter and delicious), and the Mandalay special noodles (also yumm). 

I can't say enough about the service. 

The decor is really warm and inviting. 

The whole experience just made me happy inside.
author: Maia S.

description: My first Burmese food experience. Split lots of dishes among 8 people. My favorites tended to be the salads and noodle dishes with lots of vegetables, peanuts, cilantro, etc. Loved the Rainbow Salad! Wasn't as excited about the beef, duck or shrimp dishes. They were very good, but they didn't stand out like the salads or noodles. Cute place, and great service!
author: Alison S.

description: We arrived here at 5:10PM.  Not busy, seated quickly.   The server came and took our drink order in about 10 minutes.  After about 15 minutes, we ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Coconut Rice, Ribs, and Mandalay Special Noodles.  The latter two were the suggestion of the server.  They did not come.  We finally inquired after 45 minutes to another staff person (owner, boss, ?) and they brought out in 5 minutes.  Lukewarm.  Probably is good food but they might consider managing their service better.
author: Chip S.

description:
This is my favorite Burmese restaurant.  Their menu is innovative, dishes authentic and well priced.  Their tea leaf salad is excellent as are most of their dishes.  However, I do like the samosa soup at Burma superstar better but that were it ends.  The ambiance at Mandalay Restaurant is warm and friendly,the decor is lovely too.  
Nancy A.
author: Nancy A.

description:
It's awesome! The food has good flavor, freshness, and diversity of choices.

The front of the building looks like a facade of a traveling Asian circus. Very yellow and green. Of course I would go back any day.
author: Andrea F.

description: Really great Burmese food!!! Love this place. Atmosphere is clean and welcoming.  Parking is a bear but well worth the effort once you start to eat a wonderful meal.
author: Kendra T.

description:
try as they may, my birthday dinner here was extremely disappointing and almost put a damper on my entire weekend. the food is good but they just can't handle large parties over 10 and i would recommend anyone to steer clear away, even if they do accept your reservation beforehand... i mean seriously, what's the point in accepting a reservation for 14 when you're going to make them wait for almost an hour anyway AND almost shirk you on the amount of food for a set dinner?

the two stars are for the hilarious birthday dessert and musical accompaniment at the end of the night though, and judging from the glowing reviews everyone else gave, i was probably just at the wrong place at the wrong time. go back on another night when it's less busy.
author: Andrey C.

description:
I went here with 6 friends for a friend's birthday, and was surprised with the food.  From the outside, it's not very impressive, and I have to admit, I was somewhat skeptical...especially after seeing the decor.  The light up palm tree and Christmas ornaments were...interesting...  But, the food was wonderful!  I can't remember the names of anything we had, but can say that the eggplant dish was great, the tofu was cooked to perfection, the coconut rice was to die for, and the portions were perfect for the quality and the price. 

I'd definitely go back for seconds.
author: Dudley F.

description:
I truly enjoyed my ginger salad, pleasantly surprised by it's balanced flavor.  I also loved the Chicken Curry soup.  The rest of the dishes were pretty good too.

I went back to try the tea leaf salad, and was slightly disappointed.  I did not realy like the after taste on my teeth.  Still, a good restaurant that I will visit again.
author: Mindy C.

description:
Awesome Burmese food!  My brother and I had the balada, the ginger salad, the burmese hot and sour soup, and the basil tofu dish.  The first two were absolutely excellent, the third was pretty good, and the last was standard.  I also tried the ginger lemonade which was quite good, but would have been better in warmer weather.  The service was very good, with the one wrong recommendation to order the last dish (my brother and I suspected 3 would be enough, but she wrongly disagreed and suggested we get a fourth).

Overall, excellent place and I'd definitely put it on my list of places to go to in the Richmond.
author: William C.

description:
Good Burmese food, DIFFERENT and good. When you've eaten a lot of different types of Asian food you'll see all the same flavors uniquely combined for each region. They have a salad there that does not seem like a salad. It's got 6 different things like peanuts and garlic, in which you mix up and eat. Each flavor is strong but tasty.

We had beef, Mandalay chicken, and their fish soup that was great. Service is real pleasant and they are price just right. If you want to try something very rare....try this place out.
author: Chantie G.

description:
I don't recall any Burmese restos in Chicago, so this was our first time .... Husband and I were up in the 'hood with an hr for lunch and as Burma Superstar sounds like wait purgatory, we opted for Mandalay.

Even at mid-week lunchtime, the place had quite a few customers. Nice ambiance, nice lighting and decor. Ordered more food than we knew what to do with and everything we tried was quite tasty. And the Singha! Any place that serves Singha is ok in my book. 

Also, this place also has the most awesome and plentiful Buddha shrine I've seen in any restaurant ever. Gorgeous.
author: Tracy K.

description:
Looks ghetto on the outside, but really really nice interior. I was real impressed right when I came in with my girlfriend who heard this place from one of her friends.

Can't say much about their service and food because it was all real good. Any dish with those spicy logos next to it and I'm enticed to attempt it.. I think it was Garlic Chicken or something? My girlfriend ordered a sweeter dish that had mangoes and chicken and both were good. Whenever a place offers coconut rice, I can't refuse it and so I suggest that to you as well.

They serve dessert here too but we were too full to order.
author: JJ C.

description:
Mandalay is one of those restaurants that I didn't intend on going to, but now I know to be a superior alternative. (Namely to Burma Superstar or even B-Star) 
Sadly, I am one of those people who judges others by what they eat. If we eat Thai and the first thing you want is Pad Thai or if you consider Panda Express authentic 'Chinese' food-you are on my dumbass list. Thank goodness my best friend a) went to culinary school b) doesn't give a shit about what I think and c) has incredible taste. She took me here after we had a hard time getting into the overcrowded BS. We were seated immediately by the courteous, if slightly, too attentive waitstaff. 

Rainbow Salad
Salad prepared with eight ingredients served with house special dressing: tofu, noodles, tomato, ginger powder, chopped herbs, bean sprouts, crispy fried garlic, diced potatoes, green papaya and a delicious tamarind dressing among other things. This was an amazing dish; sweet, sour; crunchy, savory, soft, springy. The server brought it out with each element presented separately on the plate and then mixed it in front of us. The idea is that you're supposed to understand how all these different elements mix into a sublimely yummy mix. Duly yummy.  

Samusa (with Chicken or Vegetarian)
A mixture of grounded curried meat and potatoes
You can rarely go wrong with fried products. There were A LOT of samusas! I think maybe, 5? Even for two women with moderate appetites they were a lot. We still managed to finish them. Curried, hot and crispy. 

Burmese Style Noodle (Kaw Soi Dok)
Egg noodles topped with fried onion, fried garlic chips, cucumber slices, grounded split beans and chef's delicious dressing; sort of the same as the Rainbow salad. Still really good, but overshadowed by the former. 

Mango Chicken
Pan fry chicken sauteed with fresh mango, onions, and green chili
This was my only regret of the meal. It just didn't compare with the rest of dinner; but I think if ordered on its own- it would be good. Juicy chunks of mango paired with wok fried chicken is always a good safe bet. 

I want to go back to try the Balada with curry sauce. The two of us were stuffed! Delicious and authentic.
author: Alexis W.

description:
Burmese cuisine seems to be all the rage lately- and for good reason- it's delicious.  So, I ventured out (I usually go to Burma Superstar), and tried Mandalay.  I was not disappointed.  

First of all, the servers are really nice and polite.  The place itself is pretty clean, and nice.  So we shared the Mango salad, which was refreshing, and delicious.  It was sweet, but not too sweet.  Very well done.  We also had the samosas (with chicken), which were quite tasty.  I have to say, I like the ones at Burma Superstar better though.  We also had one of then noodle dishes (#3 on the menu).  Great flavors- noodles (2 types) mixed with garlic, lemongrass, cilantro, lime.  The thing that resounded here is the flavors.  Everything tasted really fresh and healthy.  I left feeling satisfied, but not too full.  

I definitely will be back.  They can make a lot of their dishes Vegetarian, which is great.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I lived in SF for 4 years and everytime someone came to visit me, I would bring them here.  The tea leaf salad is the best.  The okra (ladyfingers) was good too.  There's quite a few other dishes there that are very yummy.  Top it off with quick and polite service, and they've got a winning receipe.  

Needless to say when I went back to visit SF in July, it was on my must-eat list.  Still good.
author: Tim C.

description: The food was good but the wait was NOT! Everyone in our party was done eating and that's when I finally get my Walnut Prawns. Like really? Does it take like an hour and a half to make it? Um, okay sure. They need to work faster or something 'cause I was HUNGRY! and they did not deliver with that.
author: Jessica R.

description:
this meal was fantastic and totally reasonably priced.

we started off with the mango salad, which was really sweet and tart and interesting. 
the samosa soup was really comforting, with falafel-ish chunks and samosa pieces in it, as well as garbanzo beans and onions in there.  
we also had this burmese pancake thing that was a lot like indian roti bread with a curry sauce.  the sauce was really good, and the bread was fantastic, like roti with soft grilled onions in it. 
finally we got the mandalay noodles with tofu instead of chicken.  it was totally amazing.  i loved the dish.  they brought out noodles with tofu and curry sauce and little piles of different things all around it, and then they mixed it table side.  it was really beautiful and delicious.  the coconut curry + cilantro has a rich, fresh taste to it.

the ginger lemonade was good, but really sweet.  i think if it was less sweet and had rum/vodka it would make a fantastic cocktail.

these are foods i know i'll crave.  especially the noodles.  i can't wait to go back.
author: Roxy R.

description:
Ah such flavor! Try the mandalay chicken or better yet the mango prawns. Mmmm. I can still taste them! The special noodles were interesting and very good as well. Well I've been going to this place a long time, and each time I go back it seems to get better. And the service is friendly and attentive even when the place is crowded, which it almost always is!

UPDATE Sep 2010: Just got back from a visit to Mandalay (the real one), Yangon and Bagan. Throughout all my travels I found NO food which bears ANY resemblance to the "Mandalay Chicken" and other delicacies served at the Mandalay Restaurant. So, as much as I hate to admit it, apparently this food is not at all authentic of Burmese cooking, perhaps it is Chinese food?
author: Marc K.

description: The Bulada appetizer was the most sensational dish we had. We tried the smoked tea duck since so many people raved about but was not thrilled. Overcooked duck and not a fan of the plum sauce. The special noodle dish was delightful even though I'm not a fan of coconut milk, sooo nice. We weren't really huge fans of the samosa soup though. But the service, deco, feeling was so wonderful!
author: Christina V.

description:
Oh, man.  This place is a block away from my sweetie's place, and we went in there because he said they had some pretty good vegetarian options.  We ordered a noodle dish, the name of which I forget, but they mix all sorts of goodies into it at the table.  We also got the walnut broccoli and the coconut rice.  Lunch was eaten in silence, both our faces plastered with the "delicious" expression that can never be faked, but can only be seen when an individual is eating food that's truly sublime.

Service was... well, it was kinda slow.  We got the noodles first, and it took much longer for the rest of the food to arrive.  However, the Christmas decor was cute and the tables were all full, so I'm guessing we're not the only ones who think the place is great.  

Thankful for small blessings, we believed that the one-block walk in the rain a reasonable enough price to pay for such tasty noms.
author: L. M.

description:
i heart Burmese food!!! 

think it's impossible to screw up coconut rice? it's possible, trust me. but at Mandalay it was perfectly cooked. nice and fluffy and all kinds of coconutty. 

i've definitely had better palada but when the rest of the food is so good it's a trade off i'm willing to take. my chinese friend who's mom grew up in Burma eats her palada with sugar as a dessert and i've adopted this habit. you should too. it's delectable! 

i desperately await tasting their basil lemonade and hope not to be disappointed.
author: Regina C.

description: I would give this restaurant 5 stars but, we had to wait for 2 hours (we didn't have a reservation) and the woman in charge of the waiting list seemed to let her friends and people she knew in first even though they came in way after us. Points for giving us free wine while we waited though. The service was normal, nothing special but the food, THE FOOD. One word: delicious. It was four of us and we all shared. I got the rainbow salad and it was flavorful and had different kinds of noodles, yummy! I also had the asparagus spicy chicken and it was phenomenal. The spicy sauce that they use was finger licking good. My friend got the smoked tea duck which was succulent and a large portion that came with four buns! We also had the mandalay chicken which was really good and coconut rice. They even give you a side dish of their hot chili sauce and if you like anything spicy like I do, you will love this. I thought Burma Superstar was the best burmese restaurant in the city, but Mandalay is definitely on the same level as Burma! Will definitely be coming back but with reservations!!
author: Jennifer J.

description: My first Burmese restaurant! It was pretty good, the service was friendly and we didn't have to wait tooo long for the food (except for my friend's smoked duck). I ordered the Nan Gyi Dok, which I have no idea how to pronounce. I love any kind of Asian noodles, this was pretty interesting. The waitress mixed the noodles in front of us, which I thought was pretty good service. I tried my friends dishes and they were pretty good too, except one of my friends hates coconut milk and they have it in almost every dish haha. Anyway, I liked the overall atmosphere of this place. I tried my friend's Burmese Iced Tea and it was very similar to Thai Iced Tea, except not as sweet. In the end they gave us a dessert on the house, some sweet potato concoction that my friend so graciously coined as "weird mac and cheese", but I enjoyed it!
author: Tina F.

description: This place must have the biggest Buddhist altar of any restaurant in SF. That alone makes it worth going to. There's also a reclining gold buddha in a glass case in the back of the restaurant. Our server told us that Mandalay was the first Burmese restaurant in the U.S. (and still going strong judging by the crowd waiting outside on weekend nights). As for the food, we ate simply that day, shared a seafood soup and a veggie tofu dish. Both were good enough to make me want to go back and try other things. I had jasmine flower tea. The tea "ball" opens up into a flower shape in your glass as it steeps. My friend had a very gingery lemonade, sweet and strong. The homemade coconut ice cream was delicious. Burma Superstar has a modern, urban, hip feeling. This place is old school and feels a little dated, but still charming.
author: Artemis K.

description:
i come here for lunch quite a bit. of course, i order off of the Lunch special menu which is a good price. i love their prawns and green beans the most but their tea leaf salad is super salty most times. 

2 less stars, slow when its lunch time and expensive for ala carte menu
author: Elly G.

description: Rarely have I eaten in a place where each dish that hit the table was so astoundingly delicious. We were a large group of 9 people. We ordered the Royal Dinner (6 or 7 courses for less than $20/person) to make it easy. These must be their signature dishes, because they all unique and well-balanced, from beef, lamb, chicken, and shrimp. Of particular note were the coconut soup and the tea-smoked duck. Simply sublime, The portions seem small, but trust me, it was enough for all of us. I was uncomfortably full the rest of the night, but that is not unusual for me. Knock down 1 star for the long wait if you don't have reservations.
author: Jay D.

description: Have been coming here for over a decade. So yummy. Especially love the tea leaf and rainbow salads, the green beans, and the mango chicken. Try to come during the week or early on weekends. The kitchen gets slammed at prime weekend times and the food isn't quite as good then. Would be nice if they had a few more dessert options and if the service were less spotty, but all in all very, very tasty.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Don't let my 4 stars fool you (I'm a tough one to please), I loved Mandalay.   The food was lovely and the atmosphere relaxed.  It is a pleasure to walk in, be seated right away, and be treated to first class service all night (for a pretty inexpensive meal).  

We started with the vegetarian samosas, which were a fried delight.  Then, we had the tea leaf salad (something that everyone new to burmese food must try).  For main courses we had the ginger lamb and chicken curry with coconut rice.  Once you go coconut rice, I swear, you'll never go back.  We topped off the meal with mango and sticky rice.  Everything was scrumptious.  

I echo the sentiments of the other folks that I couldn't bring myself to wait another 2 hours to eat at Burma Superstar while this place is just a few blocks away, although I regret that Mandalay lives in the shadow of its more popular cousin.  I have great hopes that many more people will come to appreciate Mandalay as I have (but not too many, as I'd hate to have to wait for a table).
author: Emily S.

description:
I have enjoyed their Tea Leaf Salad, Burmese Hot & Sour Soup, and Walnut Prawns. I've been here numerous times. I like it much better than Burma Superstar because of the atmosphere and not feeling rushed.

On a recent evening, my friends and I enjoyed the ambience & the warm welcome we received from the owners & staff. Only downside was that there was a bunch of young babies that were crying on both sides of us. I don't have kids, but it would be nice if parents would either try harder to calm their children down or walk outside for a bit to try and stop the constant crying. I know this is a touchy subject, but it would be nice to enjoy a wonderful dinner without the added noise.  Some crying is fine, but when it goes over 5-10mins, something should be done.
author: M M.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. I LOVE THIS PLACE, I LOOOOOOOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!!!!!

Can you tell this is my favorite restaurant?

I've been coming here since the age of 6, that makes it 16 years a loyal customer.  

The chicken satay is to die for.  It is always consistent and served quickly. The atmosphere is amazing. 

This is a rare gem in San Francisco, I suggest to anyone to check it out. You can have dinner for two under $30 and leave with the greatest smile on your face. 

Thank you Mandalay, I will return soon! :)
author: Tori E.

description:
Was blown away by the service and the food here. The best Hot and Sour soup, which is all you need, but then the tea leaf salad is delicious too. Lamb curry...yum. We orders way too much food, and leave me alone in a room with that coconut rice...

would love it if they delivered...or do they?
author: Gwenn G.

description:
I love this place.  I like the food WAY better than Burma Superstar, and you don't have to wait outside in the fog for two hours just to get seated.  You can even make reservations!  They have a fairly extensive menu, from which we choose somewhat randomly every time we go, and we have never been disappointed in a dish.  

This past visit we brought my in-laws who were visiting from out of town.  My mother-in-law loved the Rainbow salad so much she tried to memorize what all twelve of the ingredients were so she could try to re-create it at home.  I was also impressed by the balada, the sweet walnut tofu, and the hot and sour soup.

We told them it was my sister-in-law's birthday when we ordered dessert, even though it wasn't.  Sparklers in your ice cream and "Happy Birthday" in Burmese piped through the overhead sound system?  How could I resist?
author: Lauren F.

description: Im a regular here and i would not know what to do if they closed shop. The service here is wonderful, they always remember exactly what i want without me needing to say everytime. I absolutely LOVE the tea leaf salad! hold the peanuts with extra garlic chips please! the vegetarian sumosas hits the spot when im craving for comfort food and the mandalay special noodles are delish! my tummys just rumbling thinking about it!
author: maggie w.

description: Already been said. This is good Burmese food. In fact, its better than Pagan, and Little Star.  Not to mention the people who work there are really, really nice. When I need my tea leaf salad fix, Mandalay is there to exceed my expectations.
author: david c.

description:
2.5 stars, really - but I gave Burma super star 4*s, and there is more than one star separating these two places for sure.

We decided to try another Burmese place (not superstar) and Mandalay had such a good yelp rating, we thought we would give it a shot.

I wanted to love this place, but we just didn't.  The food seemed greasy and not a ton of flavor; we walked out with the same feeling we get from eating average Chinese food - with that coating on your mouth and strangely full but not really.

Ambiance - average.  Service - was great for the first 10 minutes, then we couldn't get water and later the check for 15 minutes after we were clearly done and trying to make eye contact.

Big plus - was very reasonably priced and the food was decent.
author: michael d.

description:
Wow, first time eating Burmese cuisine.  I must say it was delicious.  The owner and staff at Mandalay are amazing.  The presentation of the food from the tea leaf salad (a must have) to the coconut juice is great.

They made great menu suggestions and the flow of the food and presentation was perfect.

Highly recommended and I will be going back very, very soon.  Yum!
author: L W.

description: Food was tasty and the experience was great. We will gladly return every time we have the chance.
author: Sorin F.

description: LOVED their rainbow salad and noodle special.  Yum. The ingredients are fresh and you can taste all the flavors as they mellow together...mouth watering good.
author: Mel P.

description: As a big fan of Burma Superstar, but only rarely wanting to brave the long wait, I tried Mandalay just around the corner. Their food is delicious, with the tea leaf salad as the definite front runner and their seafood dishes taking a close second. The interior has a great ambiance and the service is impeccable. They also have a wonderful tea selection, including blooming jasmine. I'm not sure how Burma Superstar shot to fame over Mandalay, but Mandalay is very yummy and you never have the 2 hour wait in a crammed little entryway that you'll encounter only a couple blocks away.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
We had a great dinner last night at Mandalay! All the dishes were fresh, tasty, and served piping hot. I ordered a flowering jasmine green tea. This was really a unique drink with the bud of a jasmine flower floating in hot water, presented in a wine glass. The only thing I did not care for was the complimentary sweat potato desert. Overall, the price was reasonable for the quality and the portions. 
Another table of diners were celebrating a birthday. So at one point, over the sound system, Happy Birthday tunes merrily sang out....it was funny to be in a Burmese restaurant with an American birthday sing-a -long. But it beats all of the staff circling the table and singing off key. This added to the fun of a night out.
author: jennifer c.

description: Came here after reading so many good reviews over this place. I walked in hungry and excited, but walked out disappointed. I felt like we wasted our money here. What I had either lacked flavor or had an eerie taste to it. Their rice crisp soup was very bland and barely had anything in it except for a few baby carrots and veggies in the broth. We had their rainbow salad, which is a salad with eight different ingredients in a house dressing. I've had a tea leaf salad elsewhere before which had a similiar concept as the rainbow tea salad and it was fantastic, so I figured this one would be interesting to try. Boy was I wrong. It had a very strange taste and left an after taste in my mouth I didn't like. Other dishes we had weren't anything special at all. I don't this place is as good as what others say it is or maybe we just ordered the wrong items on the menu.
author: Staci G.

description:
Dropped by because we saw the line, and figured, if everyone's lining up, it must be good!  Fellow San Franciscans, you've failed me, because after waiting for almost an hour, and chatting with a lady who finished dining and happily told us that we can't go wrong with any of the food here, we entered with some high expectations, which ended up being entirely unmet.

The tea salad was the only dish I really enjoyed.  The fish cakes were just so-so, and seemed rather pricey at $8.  I expected something "authentically burmese" with the Mandaly chicken, but what we got was surprisingly similar to Panda Express orange chicken.  The Rangoon beef dish was an uninspired stir fry.

The "special", called "Shaking Duck", was a complete failure.  I few slices of cold and poorly cut duck (it was supposedly boneless, but had bone chips here and there), on top of a pile of cold cooked spinach that literally tasted dank, atop some cold pumpkin, in a pool of overly sweet mango syrup.  The whole pile looked and tasted like an amateurish attempt at horrible fusion cuisine.

It might have been bearable if this meal was $20 a person with a drink, but at closer to $30, it wasn't a good deal.  I also might have given another star, if the staff wasn't so busy taking out the trash, to take our bill so we could be on our merry way.
author: D X.

description: I love this place. The restaurant is roomy so you are not packed on top of each other and the Burmese food is delicious. Very friendly staff and will offer tea and wine while you are waiting if it is a long wait. You cannot go wrong with any of the food on the menu. Love the tea leaf salad and mango chicken (can't remember the traditional name).  Ask the server for suggestions too. :-)
author: Bill O.

description:
Went here last week after being told there was a 1 1/2 hr wait at Burma SuperStar. The place was quite full but the service was very good, the owner was very friendly and even apologetic for the 5 minute wait. 

samosa soup was exceptional - it's basically like cut up samosas, lentil vada's in the soup and they were still crisp and not soggy as you would expect.

The tea leaf salad was different but good, the waitress took the time to explain all the ingredients because it was out first time tasting that.
The balada bread is very similar to the south indian porotta, but the dipping sauce is not very spicy.The coconut rice with the fried onion was great and went well with Mandalay chicken with mango, we had leftovers and the chicken still tasted crisp the next day. Mandalay noodle with coconut chicken was our least favorite,  we didn't expect it to be cold. Overall a great place to experience good burmese food especially if you are new to it.
author: S N.

description: Delicious, affordable, unique. Gave us a complimentary dessert. Happy times. Go.
author: Brad W.

description:
stellar: mango salad

OK (but "other" restaurants to it better): tea leaf salad.  

major bummer was the small portions for the price.  both salads were quite small.

I ordered the mixed vegetables...they were disgusting.  in a gooey gluey clear broth that had no flavor.  

The walnut chicken was tasty.  My boyfriend and I agreed it tasted like americanized chinese food though...not a bad thing if you like that taste!

Overall, things were alright.  I had a better experience here about 6 months ago, with the walnut shrimp and other items.  For now, I will stick with Larkin Express for a tea leaf salad
author: caitlin c.

description: Nothing great for vegetarians. Because they didn't wow me, I don't plan on driving across town to go back.
author: Shal J.

description:
We either had terrible entree selection, a very off night for the kitchen, or both.

The samosas (chicken) were fine, but at $8 for a samosa appetizer, I'm expecting something inventive. This was the highlight (relatively speaking) of the meal.

We split the Burmese Curry Beef and a noodle dish (preserved vegetables and prawns? - though we substituted tofu for the prawns).

The Burmese curry beef was quite fine, if a bit dry, and short on sauce.

Our first reaction to the noodle dish? It was tiny! After a bite each, we didn't mind. Nothing was going right with this entree - overcooked noodles and totally confusing flavors (not complex... confusing).

This wasn't a bad place, per-se. This is a bad neighborhood, however,  to be slinging mediocre asian food at the $20/pp price point - there's no shortage of truly great places to eat (both at the price and below) within just a few blocks.
author: r g.

description:
Mandalay is the first restaurant I ate at a few years ago when I moved to San Francisco and have been hooked ever since.  I don't even mind the wait so much...the tea leaf salad is so much better than at that other Burmese place.  They have been able to accommodate a large group with advance notice.  The desserts are kinda bad (except last night they gave us some kind of fried banana thing that was quite good)...but the fortune cookies always have the wackiest fortunes...

love it.
author: Laura F.

description: Amazing. Period. Visit this restaurant. It is the original Burmese restaurant in SF and it still delivers. Great selection, great service, can't wait to return and try the rest of the menu.
author: C G.

description:
I showed up 15 minutes before my reservation, they happene to have an open table and seated me right away. 

The food is yummy but a little pricey for the portion, I am not a big fan of their tea leaf salad but it's worth trying if you have never had before, it's very unique. special noodle is the best!
author: Jie Y.

description:
Previous I gave the rainbow chicken a 5 star, today it will only be 3 stars. They gave me mango chicken, charged me for rainbow chicken. No big deal, just 4-6 pieces of pineapple missing. Also, the dish was swimming in oil.

The tea leaf salad was interestingly tasty, very crunchy. 4 stars
The basil chicken had a nice aroma and lots of veggies. 3.5 stars
Corn soup, plain but nice and hot. 3.5 stars
Service was good. 4 stars
author: A Z.

description:
its 3.5 stars for me. some things like the samusa soup were really good whilst others were mediocre. also, seemed like the menu was catering more to the mandarin food lovers than burmese with the mixed menu. made me really miss this place called Mandalay Cafe in Wallingford, Seattle that shut down a couple years ago :(

parking was a nightmare, btw!
author: A. B.

description:
We had made reservations in advance (for those of you who have waited at Burma Superstar). The restaurant was full but not pakced and there was no waiting. 

Service was good and they helped us with menu selections and portions and were very patient with all our requests (we were a large group). 

The hot and sour soup was ok but I loved the tea leaf salad.

We tried a variety of chicken dishes and veggies and they were all good. 

Will definitely be back here!
author: P From CA C.

description: I ordered the hot and sour soup, which was good, but a bit too much corn starch for me.  Just as a textural thing, it makes the soup too glutonous, and not at all pleasurable.  It tasted goos though, so 3 stars.
author: Phil J.

description:
The food, as many reviews discuss, is very good. A solid 4-star place with very reasonable prices. 

The verdict is two stars due to the waiting. We had to wait 30 minutes for a table. Not the end of the world, especially when they serve you drinks while you wait. However, once seated, it took over 40 minutes for our food to arrive. Parties seated after us were well in to their meals and I finally got the server's attention to ask about our food and then it became pretty clear he forgot to place the order. As a rainbow salad is mixed table side, it shouldn't take 40 mins for that to come out. 

Main courses didn't appear for some additional time after. Really frustrating and disappointing experience when you are starving.
author: Kay T.

description: I haven't eaten anything here that I haven't liked yet. Except the drinks. why don't i like burmese teas and drinks? maybe i would have liked the sangria, but they ran out by the time we ordered.  =(
author: Giggly C.

description: This place is 1 trillion times better than Burma ghetto Superstar balls.  Burma Superstar sucks.  Don't go there unless you want to help keep the crowds of Mandalay.  The papaya salad, vegetarian "samusa", and mandalay cooler were my appetizers.  They spell their samosas with a "u".  Its weird.  The mandalay cooler is a mixture of beer and lemonade or something.  Its was weird.  The papaya salad was good and possibly better than Bodega Bistro.  The mango and chicken dish was good.  The fish curry stew was freakin awesome.  This was probably the best dish we ate.  Their palat (Burmese bread) with curry was really good.  The catfish curry was really good.  The sizzling beef was just ok.  The dishes here run around $10 per dish and they aren't that big.  I had to eat In & Out after dinner for dessert.  Moral of the story I will go back.
author: Fatty A.

description: I've eaten here a number of times and have been impressed each time. The food is amazing and customer service is even better. Although long waits can be frustrating, this place is completely worth any amount of wait, but to make it even more bearable the owners will often bring out complimentary glasses of wine to tide you over :) . I'd give a 6th star if available!
author: Amanda I.

description: I have been here a few times and love it because it looks like its permanently decorated for Christmas.  Gives a nice nostalgic feeling.  The food is good..don't forget coconut rice and samosas.  Bring your own wine and they will nicely open it for you.  The staff is friendly and very helpful in making suggestions for you.  They are always crowded so, make a reservation just in case.
author: Kra C.

description: Few dishes are good, but don't order green papaya salad, not good.
author: Caroline C.

description:
chicken satay wasn't good - plain, kinda dry, and the sauce did nothing for it.
