tea leaf salad - just tea leaf and peanuts, wasn't impressed.

MANGO CHICKEN WAS SO DELICIOUS THOUGH!!!  8D
author: Ethan L.

description:
The food is great and the service is excellent, but what I really wanted to write about is the history lessons in these reviews. It's certainly more controversial than one might think to say that "Burma" doesn't really exist considering the circumstances under which the English name was changed from Burma to Myanmar. Several countries, including the U.S., Ireland, Australia, and the U.K. do not recognize the name "Myanmar". And yes while the adjective of Myanmar is Myanma, it's still commonly accepted to use the adjective "Burmese" even if you refer to the country as Myanmar (as the NY Times does).

All that said, Mandalay Restaurant is a great find.
author: Jim R.

description:
I've been coming here with my brother since about 1991. The La Pat Doc (Tea leaf, peanut, chili salad) makes me salivate just thinking about it. I do complain that over the years they changed the kind of tea leaves they use. They used to claim that the leaves were soaked for a month in a river in Burma and imported - but I think they may now soak it in a bathtub in the Richmond. Who knows - its still super good - only not as super good. Memory does that.

When I was in Burma a few years ago they served La Pat Doc everywhere, and it tasted just like home to me.

They do have other things on the menu that seem like Burmese too, but it tends to slip across the border into Chinese territory often. I say free the Burmese food Mandalay.

I like to call in my order as I approach the Golden Gate Bridge heading back into the City, then swing by for the quick pick-up and rush home to enjoy. The big entertaining fish tank is now gone so you have to time your pick-up just right

Free Burma!
author: Jack K.

description: I was pretty excited about trying this place after seeing it in the neighborhood so often. I was slightly disappointed. I had the mango chicken salad as an appetizer and it was very good at first but steadily got saltier as we ate it. After finishing the dish I felt a little nauseous from the saltiness and the fish sauce. Then we got mango chicken and lamb curry (or something like that), and those were alright. The lamb was quite flavorful but the coconut rice was pretty dry. The mango chicken was totally nothing special. Just mango, and hard salty chicken pieces. We got the mango lassi and the tapioca coconut milk. The tapioca was pretty good but I wasn't crazy about the lassi. Overall too salty, but I don't regret trying it.
author: Shizuka L.

description: The tea leaf salad was quite possibly better than Burma Superstar, and that is saying a lot because I lurve Burma Superstar's tea leaf salad.  I did not get to try the samosa soup but I will def be back and I'll try it then.  The highlight of our meal was their Special Noodle dish made with their own hand -made flat noodles.  The noodles were amazing and the dish perfectly balanced between savory coconut chicken and the zesty seasoning.  This dish would be a great sunny afternoon snack and it was large enough for three people to share, even though I wolfed more than half of it down myself.  The only thing we tried that was better at BS was the beer/lemonade cooler.  BS uses crushed ice and their lemonade is less sugary-sweet.  Even this one quibble doesn't stop me from giving this 4.5 stars. I will be back. Often.
author: Mr. B.

description: Mandalay is right by my work but I don't eat here enough.  I always get the green beans with tofu lunch special.  I've never had a bad meal here.  We love it at work soo much that we actually have the food catered for us too.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
We were concerned about coming here because it was Mother's Day and I remember it being pretty crowded during our last visit about two years ago. But we arrived at 5 and thus beat the crowd (which did eventually filter in). The food? Better than I even remembered. We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad (a must!) again which the server mixed thoroughly in front of us. They asked us if we wanted lettuce with it and I'm so glad we opted out. It would just take away from the wonderful flavors. The other winning dish? Mandalay Special Noodle with tofu. Oh. My. God. Something like pad thai meets fettucine alfredo with the best elements of both. No cream - just "white bean powder" with lemon, fried onions, and cilantro. Our party was dying and tempted to order another serving. We also ordered eggplant and string beans with tofu. Both were good but the other two dishes were out of this world. Can't wait to come back!!
P.S. Our entire group is vegetarian and we couldn't have asked for more...
author: Caroline N.

description:
40 minutes to get a salad? Really!? Totally unacceptable. 

We saw several people who came after us getting their food and finishing it before we even got our first dish. After that we had to wait another 20 minutes to get the rest of the food. At the end we even had to walk over to the cashier and hand them our bill, no one came to pick it up. And no, we didnt get a free dessert or even fortune cookies.

But, the food here is always good, 4 stars for it. I do prefer Thai food though, more flavor and spices.
author: Maggie X.

description:
Samosa soup!  Droooooool!

This little hidden gem on California blows Burma Star away in every sense.  Once you are seated (which happens almost immediately, because there is not a hipster-ridden line to wait in - yay!), you are greeted by lovely and friendly ladies who typically wear traditional Burmese outfits.  The interior is decorated with really cool tapestries, tea lights and flowers and makes the whole restaurant feel like a little escape.  The waiters are very prompt and friendly (another plus over Burma Star) and make you feel at home.  

But you don't go to a restaurant to chew the scenery, do you?  The food is the best Burmese I've ever had.  The samosa soup is to die for.  It's perfectly spicy and creamy all at once, the little chunks of samosa and what tastes like falafel add the right amount of texture, and one portion is enough for 3 people.  

In addition to the Samosa soup, you should definitely order one of their many salads.  My personal fave is the tea leaf salad, but the rainbow salad is also quite good.  The presentation is impressive - the salad arrives with all the ingredients (there never seems to be less than 12) separate and the waitress, after explaining what each ingredient is, deftly mixes them into a super duper tasty concoction.

The entrees are all very good, my new favorites being the rangoon chicken and walnut chicken.  The walnut chicken has more Chinese flavors, but it's like the best Chinese food you've ever tried.  The rangoon chicken comes with a tangy and spicy dipping sauce and is perfect with the coconut rice.  I also recommend ordering the beef satay at the same time as your entrees - it's so tasy on the coconut rice!

I could go on forever about this place, because yum!  Already planning my next visit!
author: Alisa N.

description: I don't know but once you go to Burma Superstar and then you come here, the food just doesn't compare.  The rice, the curry the desserts - all don't match up to the standards set by it's competitor.
author: M W.

description: It is a real shame that Thai restaurants seemingly have a hold on SE Asian cuisine in the US. The Burmese, Malaysians, and Indonesians really have fantastic food as well. We had the honor of dining at Mandalay some months ago and it was like diving head first back into SE Asia. The only thing better than the staff was the food. I could have roti everyday at every meal, Mmmm roti!
author: A R.

description: Some friends let us here last night and it was SO good!  Had never eaten Burmese food before and loved it!  The food reminded me quite a bit of the Southeast Asian cuisine at Lime Tree--one of my favorite SF restaurants--but there were easily 20x as many things to choose from on the menu.  That means we'll have to go back, many times, to try it all!
author: Chuck P.

description:
Just got back from Mandalay. We were first planning to go to Burma Superstar but found that they had 30 parties ahead of us. Imagine that on a Sunday night! 

The yelp reviews for Mandalay were very encouraging so we decided to try it out. I have to tell you, people, Mandalay is not just a place where the overflow from Burma SS goes (it certainly benefits from the overflow, though). This is an excellent restaurant that stands on its own. The staff is really nice and yes they take reservations. Woo hoo.

We ordered the following:

Chin Mong Jaw
Burmese Style Noodle (Kaw Soi Dok)
Nan Gyi Dok
Mandalay Noodle

All of these were from the vegetables section of the menu and we ordered all of them with tofu. All our dishes came without a lot of wait. They didn't all come together but that was fine with us because we shared everything anyway.

Yummy mummy! All the dishes were really awesome, and I have to say, better then the overpriced, over-hyped, Burma SS. Don't get me wrong, I'll probably order take out from BSS from time to time because I really like their Sambosa soup but Mandalay's food is definitely superior overall. There, I said it!

Oh, yes..I also ordered their Burmese iced tea which was as delicious and as identical to its Thai cousin. They also served water with a cherry rather than a lemon wedge. The water tasted pretty good too.

Don't believe me? well, go find out for yourself. You won't be disappointed. Unless, of course, you like hanging out with the crowd waiting to be seated at BSS.

Update: They are really nice. When the wait becomes long then they usually offer a free wine glass. Today, they even gave us some complimentary yummy mango pudding! They are great. I love this place.
author: Doble V.

description:
courtesy of my boss, the world traveler and the greatest pediatrician ever,  he introduced me to burmese food. and now, I'M A HUGE FAN. and yes, the food can you make you huge and addicted. 

for 1st timers, i recommend: 

appetizer: 
Balada- Burmese crispy pancake with curry dipping sauce 

soup: 
Ong No Kaw Soi (Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup)- Coconut noodle soup with chicken, onion, cilantro, and lemon
THIS IS THE BEST SOUP IN THE WHOLE ENTIRE WORLD!

beef dish:
Mandalay Beef
Fried beef slices sauteed with garlic and chef's delicious hot sauce
MINES AND BUNKY'S ALL TIME FAVE!

noodle dish:
Mandalay Special Noodle (Available with Tofu)
Burmese fat noodle with mild coconut chicken, yellow peas, powder lime juice, onion, and fried thin noodle on the top

coconut rice (each person should get their own. trust me, you're going to want your own!)

I absolutely love this place! It is better than Burma Superstar in taste and in price! oh yeah, the lady who owns this restaurant has a sister who owns another burmese restaurant in burlingame, MINGALABA. another one of my faves.
author: T V.

description: A great neighborhood place.  Very good food.  Respectable prices.  Service is fine.  Must order the pan fried string beans.
author: Matt G.

description: It's a good spot wish there food was a bit more filling. The tea leaf salad is off the hook but I think it's extremely under portioned. Not everything was but some things seemed seemed a bit off. for 5 people we ordered the tea leaf salad x2 and a chicken salad,samosa . Than a order or beef, chicken, Tofu, fried rice, noodle.  Well in the end it wasn't enough. We all left with belly half full. And we ended up putting 20 each. The food tasted great though but It felt like it was a bit under portioned. I'm a big guy though so I am a little indifferent but we spent a good amount of money. Sad. Had to grab crepes after lol.
author: steven l.

description: I love this place. If you have never tried Burmese food and you like chinese and indian food then this is must for you. It has a great atmosphere to it and the lady remembers me when I come in. She taught me how to say thank you in burmese. Oh yeah bonus they always seem to give me free appetizers or tea while I wait. Also, make sure to try the Mandalay chicken fried rice...its a long story and I don't think it's on the menu but it is the best.
author: Chris S.

description: Burma Superstar too crowded and loud?  Walk two blocks here to where it's quiet and peaceful, the staff is attentive, and the food is similar and almost as good.  Brought my parents here when Superstar was full, and we were SO much happier here.
author: Alicia D.

description: From the ambiance to the intricate spices in the meals, this place is top notch.  I love this restaurant.  Love the Samusas, the lamb curry is delectable and the tea leaf salad puts B-Superstar's to shame.  Great spot to get good, "authentic" for the american palate burmese food.
author: Halima T.

description:
Love love love this neighborhood spot!!  Great food, especially for vegetarians - our favorites are the walnut tofu broccoli, the tea leaf salad & the samosa soup.  We literally order the same thing every time we go here....it's that good.

An added plus is not having to wait forever for a table - also, you can call ahead to put your name on the list - only needed on a Friday or Saturday night, and even then, you won't wait that long.
author: N. J. K.

description: Back again and again.  Still delicious, efficient without being too pushy.  The dessert faluhdah (spelled wrong i am sure) is great!!
author: Jorah N.

description: came here last night for a girls night out dinner, i was disappointed by the service and food. we were seated without the full party being there, but when we ordered our food took forever to come. and whenever we asked if where our drinks or food were, they would "go check" and not come back. we had the samusas for appetizers it took like an hour for those to come out. after that we waited another 45 minutes we finally got our main dishes which was rice, rainbow chicken, mandalay noodles, and tea leaf salad. the tea leaf salad doesn't even need to be cooked and it came out last, plus they put way too much jalapeno peppers in it because all we tasted were those. i would say go to b star or burma superstar, the wait is definitley longer, but its way better than mandalay
author: Stella J.

description:
I LOVE MANDALAY SOOOO MUCH!!!!!
I was telling a friend on mine that I LOVE pumpkin curry..She said "Have you ever tried Burma Superstar" and I was like no, so one day I went to BS (haha!!!) with my fiance and the wait for and hour and a half...are you KIDDING ME!!!! F that!  Some girl in line told me to try Mandalay just down the street.  Well, it is now my new favorite restaurant.  They decor is really cool and they always have fresh flowers are the tables.  The food is wonderful, and it's made fresh, not like they made it earlier in the day, but they actually made the food specially for you!!  It's awesome.  The pumpkin curry is served inside of a pumpkin which makes it AWESOME!!
They explain to you exactly whats in the food, then they mix it up for you the way you should eat it.  The staff is SOOO wonderful and they ALWAYS give me extra fortune cookies (I LOVE FORTUNE COOKIES!)
Anyways, please go here...you will love it.
author: Elise H.

description:
waiter, " are you done?"
me, " Not yet."
waitess # 1," are you done?"
me, " I'm still eating."
waitess # 2," are you done?"
me, "No, No"
waiter, " Can I take this?"
me,"HELL NO, we are still eating. I don't think we are eating that slow, do we? How many times I gotto say same FXXXin' thing! Leave us alone, dumb Ass!"

I didn't say that out loud. 
It was Monday night. Can we take it easy?
I felt that these wait staffs were trying to kick us out.

Food was GOOD.
Great Burmese, I loved it.
But, why there is Mongolian Beef in the menu?
Yeah, that's true, Mongolian Empire took all over Asia once before.
author: Nobu K.

description:
while driving, i had this big "pie in the sky"  that this top-rated southeast asian restaurant will be readily available for us...fantastically wishing that there will be no wait.

when he open the door, it was truly a great blessing!

there was no one in sight waiting & the waiting list pad was empty...that was really awesome.

comfortably and very well-liked where we were seated, we ordered two appetizers: samosa (very flavorful and neatly wrapped) and lap pat dok/tea leaf salad (the combination of likable ingredients were mouth-watering).

as for the main entree we had: the mandalay beef (it was cooked "mandarin" style, but to me it's like an enjoyable, tasty americanized chinese food) and the mango prawns (this dish has a very strong taste of fish sauce, though the mango was delightfuly ripened).

all foods were excitedly devoured, albeit the mango prawn dish was not that good...we  still had a satisfying, great dinner!

the service was cordially rendered and the total charge came out quite expensive.
author: Nelle A.

description:
finally had a chance to try this out after a friend recommended it. unfortunately decided to come with a friend that was on a budget, so didnt get to try as much things as i wanted to. had the:

chicken samosa - A mixture of grounded curried meat and potatoes

mandalay mango chicken - Pan fried chicken sauteed with fresh mango, onions, and green chili

chicken rangoon - with spices and sauteed with fresh tomato & onion

everything was pretty good, but nothing really extraordinary. gonna have to come back tho and try some more of the menu! 4stars for now
author: David D.

description:
we be crazie.  i feel like its more powerful with an ie at the end.  throw 16 drunk yelpers into an already crowded restaurant, at our most obnoxious, and we would be tough to take by anyones standards.  Mandalay however, didn't even flinch.  they let us in...set up two large tables of 8, and even proceeded to serve us MORE alcohol.  probably wasn't needed, but the kirin was a perfect accompaniment to the abundance of food we ordered.  as i have stated in earlier reviews, its always key to have one knowledgeable asian at the table when eating unfamiliar asian fare, so ours came out swinging...

we had lots of good food.  lots of dishes.  mango something....tea leaf something...coconut something...rice something or other....some purple vegetable i think they call eggplant....and some other stuff....whatever it was...it was good.  so was the beer.  and....as our table dined with forks, and the other dined with chopsticks, we actually discussed how the Burmese don't eat with chopsticks....so eat that other table!  we were right...you were wrong.

thanks for putting up with our debacherous crew.  hope it was worth the 5 stars.
author: Lauren F.

description: Found it on Yelp, and the first meal I had in San Fran during a 2-week California trip with my 4 teens. We loved it. It's in the Clement St district, the "new Chinatown," so it has an authentic but not-so-touristy vibe. Seemed like a collection of regulars and tourists. The atmosphere is colorful and vibrant; the service is solicitous and helpful. I have 1 vegetarian and he had a lot of options to choose from, not including Mandalay's ability to convert regular dishes to vegetarian. We started with an order of vegetarian and meat egg rolls that the kids devoured. Our entrees were excellent--the Burmese style curry chicken (very mild, better for kids), the Mongolian beef, and the spicy tofu with vegetables. A great meal and a great start to our trip.
author: Bruce S.

description:
i am a mandalay lover and here are the reasons why:

- excellent burmese food that fills the mouth with rapturous joy. each dish is bursting with intense flavors and a fusion of spices, fried onions, garlic, chilis, and frequent mild undertones of coconut. fresh ingredients and simply well-executed flavor combinations.

- i brought a burma superstar lover here last night, and was incredibly surprised to find that he actually liked the restaurant and food in comparison. who woulda thunk....a discerning palate is able to LIKE BOTH RESTAURANTS AT ONCE?!?!? (ok, so he didn't have a "taste orgasm" here, but those are so few and far between and are oftentimes once-in-a-lifetime events, even at consistently good restaurants) can we achieve world peace now? how about freeing tibet without any further bloodshed?? or, more importantly, can i find a hot date now??? PLEASE????

- the service is so much better than most asian restaurants. they even play "happy birthday" in both mandarin and english versions over a stereo system in the restaurant if it's a birthday celebration!!! WTF...SCHWEET!!!! (note to self: have next birthday dinner here with lots of friends and MAKE them sing both versions)

- i just like being able to babble incessantly to my patient friend at a table without fear of someone eavesdropping or scrutinizing our choices for dinner or being rushed in and out of the restaurant like cattle. being able to have a good laugh and talk about politics at a restaurant with an average noise decibel is a plus in my book. and, usually, a glowing, neon green palm tree would be rather disturbing, but mandalay somehow makes it work along with the christmas ornaments hanging from the ceiling. they figured out the fine line between charming and borderline kitschy-trashy.
author: May T.

description:
Come here not Burma Superstar!
The food has been excellent every time I've been here.  I especially like the rainbow salad.  Plus the staff is friendly and let you take your time with a leisurely dinner.  A great dining experience every time.
author: Jimmy C.

description: The food here tastes just the way my grandma used to make it. I can count on this place to give me my quick burmese food fix when I need it. The portions are very generous and the service is extremely attentive. Make sure you try their coconut tapioca drink - it's fabulous.
author: Alex M.

description: The food is great. The onion pancake and mango salad are two of the more memorable dishes we always get. The staff is always super friendly, and you have to appreciate the random Xmas decorations hanging from the ceiling.
author: ryan c.

description:
Took the wife here for our anniversary and we were really excited to try it after reading all the great reviews.  My wife had been here about 20 years ago, before they got popular and said it was really good.  And it was.  The food was incredibly tasty.  The meat was a little on the sweet side for me, but still delicious.  Portions were small though - much smaller than I expected for the price.  The place was packed and a bit too loud for any sort of romance.  The hostess was really nice and quick, but the servers (although somewhat attentive) first brought us something we didn't order, and then forgot to bring us something else that we HAD ordered.  Regardless, I would still go there again, but not for any special occasions.

Oh, and parking is a nightmare on a Friday night - if you spend less than 10 minutes circling the neighborhood to find a place, you're one lucky duck!
author: Steve W.

description: Excellent food - very authentic and tasty. I love the ambience here too. Not as crowded as Burma superstar and no long line, so that was a bonus.
author: buddie l.

description: We've been coming here for almost 25 years.  By far our favorite restaurant!  The mandalay chicken is perfectly fried and the sauce not too sweet.  Consistently good!  And the garlicky green beans are so crunchy and well spiced, I could eat them everyday.  The samosa soup has a wonderful spice and crunch that's just perfect.  All of the noodles dishes are excellent.  You just can't miss with anything on the menu.  The service is so helpful and friendly.  It's one of the few places we never mind waiting for a table.  And the atmosphere is very charming.  The best of all of the Burmese restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Lisa H.

description:
im not sure if you guys heard of this place. its pretty much a well kept secret so dont tell too many people about it, i dont want it getting around theres a cool burmese joint in the inner rich. 

you should try the tea leaf salad. yeah crazy concept huh, but trust me its pretty good. 

ive also heard about another burmese place very close by, when i find out about it, ill let you guys know.

ssssshhh!!!!
author: Euge L.

description: Try this place. Our party had 5 so we were able to secure a reservation. Great vegetarian selection and they were happy to modify non-veg dishes to comply accordingly. A real treat.
author: Dan K.

description: Why wait 2 hours at Burma Superstar when you can walk into this place? The service is so much better, the place has more breathing room, it's less chaotic and the menu is probably more extensive.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
No crazy long wait like the other place. Spacious seating. No need to fight other customers to get the waitresses' attention.

Tea leaf salad- was good and NOT salty. I wanted more dried shrimps though. We also had to ask for lemon to give it a kick.

Hot & spicy soup- wasnt spicy at all! But it was had an interesting taste.

Rangoon beef- tasty and the portion was really big.

This place is much better and less stressful than B.S.
author: Retired B.

description: My buddy and I went for lunch, no wait, no line, no worries! I was happy looking at the menu, and  ecstatic when I saw on the last page the lunch specials. Service was prompt, friendly and helpful, the food came quickly and we learned that everything tasted delicious as we shared all of our plentiful combinations. Try the "young coconut water" served in your very own coconut - a taste of the tropics ! We tipped over 20% and still paid less than 20 bucks each !
author: Lee P.

description:
parking was quite easy around 6:30 p.m.
the staff were nice and the service was great.
traditional and beautiful artwork on the walls.
nice and cozy place.....
by 7:30 p.m. the place was packed.

between the two of us, we ordered:
-balada (delicious pancakes with curry sauce)
-rainbow salad (instead of the usual 22 ingredients i have at burma 
 superstar, there were only 8 ingredients, but it still had good flavor)
-catfish chowder (very good soup; me must learn how to make this 
 soup!)
-ginger beef (not very good because i'm not a fan of cooking beef
 with baking soda, it's got a weird texture to it and it doesn't taste 
 natural)
-tofu tebat (so so dish, i don't hate it but i wasn't too impressed)

thanks connie c.!  now i have another cool place to get my balada, rainbow salad, and catfish chowder! 

i'll be having left overs for breakfast today :)
author: Paulina C.

description: Not nearly as good as Burma Superstar, nothing exceptional about the dishes and certainly not worth the drive and hassle of parking.
author: Lisa B.

description:
yum!  this is a little hidden gem and the oldest burmese restaurant in SF.  they take reservations which works well if you have to book something for special occasions, such as birthday parties.  they were able to accomodate a group of 10 a day in advance.  

we ordered the beef satay, tea leaf salad, mango chicken, mandalay chicken, chicken with woodear mushrooms, beef curry with potatoes, pan fried string beans with seafood, and mandalay special noodles.  

the tea leaf salad is very good, it's the kind of salad that i think everyone should at least try at least once.  lots of flavors and textures including tea leafs, sesame, fried garlic pieces, hot peppers, and peanuts.  my favorite dishes were mango chicken, beef curry with potatoes, pan fried string beans with seafood, and the mandalay special noodles.  definitely get the noodles!  the ingredients for this dish is all separate, and then everything is combined at the table.  good stuff!  i wasn't into the satay, which you can get anywhere...
author: Wendy S.

description: Came here. Good salads (loved the tea leaf salad) and the curries/meat dishes were great. I'd definitely come back here again. Portion sizes were about average - probably one entree per person plus a few salads would be an average sized dinner.
author: A I.

description:
After last nights experience I feel compelled to write my first review.

I will NEVER return to this restaurant after the treatment my friends and I received!! 

We dared ask that we order the special meal for all the adults except the vegetarian who obviously needed to order separately. This was not taken lightly, the waitress told us it couldn't be done but after consulting with another waitress came back to tell us with much contempt that she would allow it ONLY this one time because we had waited over an hour (despite the fact that we had ordered separately on previous occasions). I mean, it wasn't as if we didn't spend as much on the separate meal as the set menu, the vegetarian ordered two entrees...  

We were totally baffled by the pursed lips and disdain, it was totally uncalled for. Seriously, it was like getting in trouble at school with the headmistress, and for what, just so we could enjoy a meal we were paying for??  Somehow we had pissed them off and that was the end of it for us... the nightmare continued. 

One of the three soups came late, we had to ask for it and was told it was coming, no apology. It finally came after we asked a second time but not before the entrees arrived. The last of the three set menu dishes also came much later than the rest, by the time it came there was little rice left. When we tried to ask for more rice, we were ignored TWICE, quite obviously too just to be sure we knew we weren't welcome. 

Midway through our dining 'experience' a waitress comes to ask for their 5 business cards back that my child had been playing with. Sure business cards are costly to print but would you really disturb your patrons over a mere 5?? after such atrocious service and average food...  Don't worry, there's no way would I pass along those cards of yours even if I got to keep them!!

As the nightmare is coming to an end, the original nasty waitress comes to take our plates away and despite seeing that my toddler was still picking from her plate (she hesitated midway so she knew) she still took it anyway as my baby reached for it to get more. Thankfully I caught this and managed to give my baby back her food from the mean lady. You don't take a plate from someone who's eating, regardless of their age, crazy woman!

Nope, not coming back, the food ain't worth the insult.
author: tweet y.

description:
For my first time, I went on a week night where I expected a smaller crowd. I was shocked to see that the place was buzzing with people even in today's economy. 

I was pleasantly surprised. This is perhaps my new favorite Burmese restaurant!! "Mandalay" was the word of the evening... the Mandalay Chicken Salad and the Mandalay Special Noodle. I also had the Rangoon Lamb to go with the fragrant coconut rice. Everything was so delicious. The ingredients were rich in flavor and well balanced with hints of rare herbs and spices. And to top if off, their Sangria was the best I've EVER had!! I don't usually drink sangria in general but, I will be ordering a whole pitcher the next time I return. 

For those of you that value exceptional customer service like myself, you will also find that the staff here is extremely friendly and courteous. They took the time to explain the various unique dishes served. When the food arrived, the waitress took the time to teach us how to prepare it so that all the flavors will be nicely married. Overall, the experience was beyond my expectation. I will look forward to my return and spread the word about this fabulous neighborhood gem.
author: Mary L.

description: This place is YUM!!!!! Five stars all the way --- from the food to the service to the restaurant's ambiance!! A co-worker and I got there just before 12 noon and we got seated right away. Two glasses of water and a tea pot were placed on our table seconds after we got seated. (And may I say that their tea rocks! So good....) With the help of Yelp, we  knew what to order and ordered right away. May I suggest their mango chicken, ragoon beef and their "balada" appetizer (crispy pancake with curry sauce). Every dish was wonderful ---- great spices and exquisite flavors! I can't wait to go back and try their other dishes......Our entire lunch only set us back about $22 for the both of us. The food was really amazing, I can't say it enough!!
author: La C.

description: I don't know why I have waited so long to write a review of this place, but it's pretty much ridiculously awesome.  Their mango chicken is out of control.  Coconut rice is off the hook, veggie samosas insane.  Plus I have never, ever waited to be seated here.  Gotta love some Mandalay.
author: Rachel P.

description: Great restaurant! We had the rainbow salad--awesome.  The Thai/ Burmese ice tea was great, as was the rest of our food.  It's Burma Superstar without the hype [or wait] !
author: Scott H.

description:
To inspire the Yelper in me I have decided to revisit my childhood eats most of which are located in or around the Richmond District.  Mandalay is no exception.  This was THE place to take the out of town family or friends.
The usual "safe" food was always ordered.  Fried Green Beans, Mandalay Beef and Chicken and the coconut rice always!  Nothing too unusual for our guests.  An occasional spring roll and soup if we were feeling crazy.  
Unfortunately it had been a while since my last visit and I anxiously awaited my usual fare.  My tastes have matured in the passing years however, and i wanted to explore the menu a bit more.  I caved and went with the comfort food: coconut rice, fried green beans with tofu, hot and sour soup and the Rangoon Beef.  The soup has been the same since the beginning, AWESOME.  The rice was perfect along with the green beans;  fresh and crisp complementing the crunch of the tofu.  The beef tied it all together marinated, grilled then served with the red and green peppers.  It was one helluva meal.  
The prices have gone up a lot and I never get tired of the ball point price over a bed of faded white out.   The staff has rarely changed over the years and it was good to see a familiar face when I walked in.  The bonus of being a loyal customer??  Getting free dessert after paying the check.  Not a bad deal.  I would give this place 5 stars but I think the portions don't fit the price.
author: Casey C.

description: My daughter wanted  me try this place for the soup. As she put it. "Mom, it's the best soup in the world." The coconut chicken soup was over the top FLAWLESS!  Each sip was a "close your eyes moment" for me.  It was pure bliss. This soup has ruined me for all other soups.  Makes the old fashioned  chicken noodle soup bland by comparison. My daughter was right.
author: Isabella L.

description:
first, lemme just forewarn the ladies about the bathroom door so i could save you all an embarassing moment and awkward rest of the time in the restaurant with the waitress --

the door is kinda busted so make sure you pressed the door/knob all the way until it *clicks* -other wise it freaking still pushes open even if its "locked"!!!


moving on.. aside from getting walked in on by the waitress while warming up the porcelain throne, the food was pretty damn delicious. if you've never had burmese food before, its basically a blend of mandarin chinese + thai.. many dishes are like chinese, but they also use basil, and fruits such as coconut, papaya, mango, etc.. a lot like in thai cuisine. 

and a must-try dessert: sui ji mok, with the "PUPPY seeds" (as stated on the menu.. haha. i know they meant POPPY seeds but we still got a kick out of that from the urge to say "arf arf"). the sui ji mok is a dessert made from sweet potatoes they say. not too sweet, and has a nice chewy texture with the "puppy" seeds sprinkled on top.. a perfect way to wrap up a spicy burmese meal :)

**recommendations (this list will probably grow as i continue making trips back there, haha):
-rainbow chicken
-mandalay mango chicken
-basil chicken
-sui ji mok (dessert mentioned above)
author: Jennie L.

description: What did MB do to deserve that? What part of the chicken tastes like that? Better than Burma SS? No chance. MB's father frowned, but tried to be polite. Monkey face flushes pink.
author: Monkey B.

description: I love their stir-fried green beans - they are incredible.  The mango chicken and green papaya salad are good too.  A polite staff and you can almost always get a table within minutes, even on a Saturday night.  Parking is a pain, so I usually order takeout and double park.
author: V T.

description: The Wait was 30 minutes, but they graciously offered us some hot tea. My mos favorite part of this experience was the arrival of fresh ingredients courtered off into sections on the plate and then they mix it with care on your table. Their special noodle dish rocked! The tea salad was most interesting: I loved it and my boyfriend enjoyed eating it but said he wouldn't get it again, its an experience for sure. Will be returning :)
author: Sari G.

description: The Rainbow Salad here is just as yummy as the one over at Burma Star except the portion is much bigger!  The dressing had just the right amount of tang.  Overall, little saltier than the one at Burma Star.  Also tried their Mandalay Special Noodle which is flat noodles with coconut chicken and seasoned with lemon and lemongrass.  Quite tasty.  Not as crowded as Burma Star and more roomier/comfortable.  Also, larger menu here to choose from.  I'll be back to try more!
author: Mick S.

description: I love this place. Why wait 2+ hours for Burma Superstar when you can get the same scrum-diddy-licious food at Mandalay without the wait??? There's more room, the staff is uber nice, and I love getting the Mandalay Noodle Special. And you can't beat their lunch specials.
author: Tiny H.

description: My favorite place to eat in San Francisco!  The food is delicious, especially the Tea Salad and Mango Prawns.  Highly recommened for Asians food addicts (like me).  I always bring my friends and out-of-towners here and they love it, even the less adventurous eaters.
author: Catskill S.

description: Come here if you want to avoid the long lines of Burma Super Star. This place serves just as good Burmese food and is much quieter than Burma. Now I'm afraid that more people will discover this little gem and make it Burma #2. Nooooooo!
author: Helena H.

description: If you're thinking about going here, don't think twice, just go. Seriously legit/amazing food. I had a Burmese friend with me while we were there and he was floored by how delicious and authentic the food was. The owners are just really amazing/nice people and the restaurant seems to always be packed. The atmosphere/ambiance is really conducive to group meals.
author: Zain A.

description:
the first time i ate here was my first time eating burmese and i think i just soaked in the whole experience the tea leaf salad was good i remember.  my second time at this place and i had to write about it this time.  its all about what you order..."hot and sour soup" and "rainbow salad".  the soup is made in a great tomato base and all the vegetables are cut into small bite size pieces so you get a little of everything in each spoonfull.  it has a tiny bit of heat, just enough to linger on the tongue.   

the "rainbow salad" was really my absolute favorite.  it has 3 different types of noodles, garlic chips (gives a great crunch), little cherry tomatoes, yellow bean powder, pepper flakes, and jicama.  they bring it to you on one plate but all the ingredients seperate on the plate.  they tell you all the things on the plate and they mix it for you.  this dish was perfect in that it wasn't over powering yet it had so much flavor.  

the service is something i must also talk about also.  they are very attentive yet not a hint of hovering.  you are free to enjoy your food and the company you are with yet when a dish is done you don't even know when they took the plate away.  

bottom line: go order and enjoy you meal.
author: junie k.

description:
Perfect for hump day, a few of my co-workers decide to stroll into Mandalay Restaurant on 6th and California.  They had a pretty extensive menu of both Burmese and Mandarin cuisines, but we opted to try familiar and not so familiar Burmese dishes as we've heard this restaurant is often compared to Burma Superstar (a favorite of ours).  I order one of the lunch combination which includes basil chicken and a tea leaf salad.  (At $9.95 also served with the soup of the day, it's a deal!)  The basil chicken was tasty.  I loved the fact that it was all chicken breast, and the pieces were perfectly bite-sized.  It was prepared with very little veggies, just sparse thin slices of green and red peppers and onions.  My major gripe is that the dish was swimming in sauce.  Thankfully, though, it wasn't served over rice, but in its own serving dish and rice in its own bowl as well.  (I was able to control my sauce intake nicely.)  The tea salad, that ironically was served a little after my entree, was delectable.  However, its not as dynamic as the one at Burma Superstars as there was no lettuce, noodles or veggies in Mandalay's version.  (Basically, it was two types of nuts, tea leaves and garlic pieces.)   
 
The restaurant is spacious and well lit.  The walls are nicely decorated with what we could only assume is authentic Burmese framed cloths and  artwork as well as nice large mirrors that matched the motif.  The ceilings are high and red and green scrolls almost drape the entire ceiling just before the open pillars that line the ceiling.  Strange-- they have green (Christmas) garlands that line the ceiling pillars and Christmas ornaments hanging from the pillars.
 
I'd definitely go to Mandalay again...there's so much more to try like the mango chicken, samusas, various noodle dishes and the Mandalay chicken (tried a piece, it was divine!)...next time I'll go with my boyfriend and make a more accurate assessment and answer the question: Which restaurant is better, Mandalay or Burma Superstar?
author: Marie B.

description:
the food here is utterly delectable!  i have been meaning to eat here for a long time, but have never got around to it.  i finally was able to come here this week, and i savored every bite.  the food tasted fresh and was not heavily coated in oil.  

i may have to say that i prefer this place over the popular burma superstar.  and even better, you bypass that ridiculous wait that is incurred at burma superstar.  

a word to the wise:  when dining during lunch hours DO specify if you are ordering from the lunch menu.  otherwise, they will charge you the regular dinner fare.
author: Sheri N.

description: Really awesome place! They have a great variety of food! Recommend tea leaf salad (warning: distinct flavor, strong and easy to love or hate), the coconut noodles, Burmese curry, and the Mango chicken are all good.  Desserts not quite as strong, but the coconut jello thing (kyauk kyau or something) is fairly good, unusual texture. The interior isn't bad, just nothing special, but service has been good for 5 times I've been there, and prices aren't bad.
author: Ben B.

description: Now I'm a big Burma Superstar fan. But I am NOT a fan of their long, impossible lines filled with the Paris Hilton Ms. Thang-alikes and their Justin boy toys all awaiting to get into my joint on a crowded weekend night. So about face and take a hike one block down to Caly and hit up the more out of the way yet superb Mandalay. Start with the Balada pancakes which are sorta like Roti. I prefer BSS's Tea Leaf Salad but Mandalay's is a fab alternate. Green Papaya salads I love and the Mandalay Papaya Salad is outstanding. The Basil Spiced Eggplant is amazing. There's so much to try hear that you'll come back to sample something that you missed on the last visit. And no BS lines.
author: Johnny C.

description: Props to my roommate for introducing me to this place.  I like trying new dishes and the Tea Leaf salad was something that I never had before, so I thought I'd give it a whirl.  But as I was eating it, I just kept thinking that it was pretty much the same as eating chocolate covered coffee beans.  So i asked the waitress if this "salad" contained caffeine since I'm super sensitive to it, and guess what....I'll be staying up late tonight.
author: Cindy L.

description: After a long rainy drive I quickly found parking and the brightly decorated restaurant. I was meeting with a book club to discuss the boring book,  Finding George Orwell in Burma.  There were about 7 of us comfortably seated at a round table.  We started with the rainbow and tea leaf salad.  Both were fresh and mixed at the table after an explanation by the friendly, attentive staff.  All the dishes had lots of garlic and none were too spicy.   Rainbow chicken was the only meat dish in order to accommodate a semi vegi in the group.  The chicken was crisp and accompanied by colorful veggies.  Many of the dishes had fresh mangoes.  My favorite dish was the three Rangoon with large soft pieces of calamari, shrimp and scallops joined by tasty tomatoes.  I definitely would return to revisit the rainbow salad and explore some of the meat dishes.
author: erin k.

description: With over 3,000 restaurants in San Francisco, I picked this one for Mothers' Day dinner with my kids. . . . since my adorable grandson arrived, we try to find places that are kid friendly and just about every table had a little pea pod in residence. . . .we had rainbow prawns (my favorite) fried squash, sizzling beef platter, mango chicken, green papaya salad- all freshly prepared.  My favorite to-go dish is the Mandalay Special Noodles. . . . flat noodles with 2 mini tubs of coconut chicken sauce that you mix in with the cilantro and seasonings. . .quite the yummy dish. . .
author: Kea C.

description: We found Mandalay on Yelp when looking for Clement Street lunch spots. Very happy that we didn't wait in line on Clement Street and came here instead!  For lunch, although the restaurant was mostly full, the seating was immediate.  Good & helpful service with reasonable prices.  The Tea Leaf salad was DELISH, as were our other dishes.  Definitely will be back to try more!
author: Karen J.

description: The tea leaf salad is more on the authentic side here, no lettuce like at Burma Superstar.  We had to ask for lemon though, weird.  The sour soup was great and came with shrimp, which wasn't on the menu.  The rangoon beef was just ok, tasted like an Americanized dish.  Lunch specials were cheap, but we went for a la carte.  Still a good deal.
author: Derrick V.

description:
two words: not impressed.

first off, this place is noooo burma superstar, and is only successful because its burmese food, close to burma, and gets all the customers that burma would have gotten if the wait wasn't like 5 hours long.

first off, this place is more expensive burma and not good at all. the chicken sataay is pitiful, and for 8 bucks I got 6 tiny little skewers. I got the walnut prawns, and for 12 dollars got 6 pieces of shrimp. It was decent, but I expected way more. My boyfriend got the Mandalay beef, which basically tasted like some greasy fried beef from the panda express.

Even P.F. Chang's has more authentic asian food. We waited for 20 minutes, and the food was not worth it. To give them credit, the waiters and waitresses were very nice and attentive. However, the place was crowded, cramped, and loud. There were babies screaming, and there our table was sandwiched between other parties so closely that I could barely escape.

Lesson learned-if you want burmese food, just wait in line for Burma Superstar; it's well worth it. If you want americanized asian food, check out P.F. Chang's before you check this place out. Also, if you MUST try Mandalay, come here for lunch. You can get the same type of generic food for half the price.
author: Stephanie L.

description: As the 573rd reviewer, I don't have much new to add.  It was my first time eating burmese, but I had it with a friend who had just returned from Burma who said that Mandalay was authentic.  Loved the tea salad thing, didn't love the 20 minute wait (with a reservation).
author: Olivia L.

description: yum. great service, great food. really felt welcome. looking forward to our next jaunt there
author: Laurie A.

description: My absolute most favorite Burmese place! Lunch specials are nice, $10 can get you rice and an entree which is enough to fill you up right. Dinner is always enjoyable and usually busy. More people are learning of this place and are venturing over from the hyped up Burma Super Star. Mandalay beef or chicken are a favorite. Other suggestions are the mango chicken, rainbow chicken, pan-friend stringbeans (a must have!) and the special noodles. The Ginger lemonade is super yummy too. It helps balance out all those spiced up dishes you are enjoying. Great accompaniments are the coconut or saffron rice (order and try both even!- I like the two equally).  The decor of the place is interestingly pleasant as well.
author: Tracy N.

description: Been going here on and off for 20 years! so glad to see they are doing so well. 20 m inute wait was more like 40 but well worth the wait. They are so gracious and nice, service is so wonderful. And the food, OMG, my two faves wewre the rainbow salad and the special noodles, thought I died and went to food heaven!! Other dishes were also excellent, as was desert. Reasonable price as well. You cannot go wrong with anything on the menu, Enjoy!!
author: Fabienne M.

description:
Update: 9/17/2009

Man, whoever says that Mandalay can even hold a candle to Burma Superstar is nutz!  Went to BSS for dinner tonight and it's no contest, simply good food minus the kitsch.

------------------------------------------------

Spent the day hiking around the Presidio, afterwards, we were dragging our tired sunburned bodies along California street looking for something to eat and we happen to find Mandalay - looking like it could be promising.  We head into the restaurant and were seated immediately.

We ordered:

1. Broccoli, walnuts and tofu w/ brown rice.
2. Mandalay Special Noodles.

After waiting around for a bit, the restaurant starts to fill up pretty quickly, so it's definitely popular.  I look around at the decor and I'd describe it as kitschy, there is a large shrine to buddha at the front, an oversized purple oblong geode water feature w/ a wet spinning white orb (the whole thing was very phallic) in one corner, a palm tree in the other corner covered in green christmas lights, and christmas ornaments hanging from all over the ceiling.  Sweet...

Our food finally arrives, it looks like there are a lot of Chinese, Thai, and Indian influences on Burmese cuisine - no surprise.  1. came first, it was quite heavy on the walnuts, wish there was more tofu and broccoli, the sauce was pretty good - we gobbled every bit of it up quickly, then waited some more for 2. to arrive.  While patiently waiting, the owner comes up to our table and asks if we are enjoying ourselves, we say we are fine.  Then he stands there and says, can I get you anything else?  Uh...He was trying to hurry us out before we even got our 2nd dish!  We said, yes you can get us the rest of our order!  He replied, oh sorry, right away.  Our send dish comes (handmade noodles, fried shallots, tofu, lemon grass, cilantro, and crispy fried noodles), the waitress brought the dish, explained the ingredients, tossed it together and left us to serve ourselves, this dish was OK, the 1st dish was better.  Nevertheless, we ate every bit, paid the check and headed out.

I will say the food really hit the spot after a long day of hiking.  

May have to come back another day without the hiking to make sure it's still good even when not ravenously hungry enough to eat my own hand...
author: Burrito M.

description:
if you're tired of waiting for a table at burma superstar, then come here!!  there was no wait at 830 pm last night, and the restaurant was quite empty, actually.  we ordered the veggie samusas, ginger salad, mandalay noodles, dried green beans, and coconut rice.  my bf didn't like the samusas here as much, but everything else was delicious.  i loved the ginger salad and the noodles, which you can get vegetarian w/ tofu.  

i think this restaurant has more of a chinese angle to it, so the dishes were less heavy.  i would definitely come back.
author: Helen T.

description: Goddamn, kilogram!  I may never go to Burma Superstar again.  This place is just as good and that's to say it's incredible.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
Mandalay,
Mandalay,
Your food is delicious.  
I could eat here everyday.

Your service is excellent.  
Your prices are fair.  
Your ambiance warm.  
Your food shows love and care.

The Mandalay noodles with chicken
 So tasty,
 I can't stop thinking about them.  
It's making me crazy!

The tea leaf salad is flavorful 
and has great texture and crunch
Lighter on the nuts for balance
And I'll eat it for dinner, breakfast, and lunch!

The green beans are divine, 
and so is the prawns with okra
You could eat here a lot
And never go broke-ah!

The ginger lemonade beer is so sweet
The servers are neat
What a lovely treat
Mandalay can't be beat...
author: erin k.

description: Ok, I'm being selfish- but the only reason I'm skimping on the 5-stars is because i don't want this place to become like Burma Superstar! I used to come here to avoid the lines down the street, but now it seems like people are catching on. The food is really consistent, and it gets better every time. I almost feel like the owners are improving weekly in order to overtake Burma. Last time I went, there was a long wait- but the service was still excellent. They gave everyone who was waiting a complimentary (big) Thai lemonade. The Tea Leaf Salad, Shredded Chicken, and Sizzling Beef were excellent the last time we dropped by (as always). Even though I was full afterwards, my waiter gave me a delicious Mango pudding on the house! Only one complaint- please please update your specials.
author: Sandra D.

description: This place is outstanding. Mandalay is almost always crowded at dinner time, and having a reservation does not always mean having a table, BUT it is worth the wait. Bring a large party here to share as many of their dishes as you can possibly eat. Enjoy the glowing palm tree, enjoy the maraschino cherries in the water glasses.(?) There is really something for everyone here, and each dish is really unique. Try the green beans, crispy veggie samusas, basil prawn, Mandalay noodle (prepared at the table), ginger beef, and definitely the coconut rice. If you have room, go for the fried banana dessert, which comes with alarmingly good coconut ice cream. (If you go there often enough, they'll start sending over dessert. Which is either a blessing or a curse, depending.)
author: Caitlin P.

description:
I have been a regular customer at the Mandalay since they first opened. Over the years, I have sampled just about every dish that they offered and I must admit that the majority of the dishes were wonderful.
However, it seems like the "beancounters" have taken control. For example: There used to be 6 pot stickers per order...then 5 and now there are only 4 pot stickers per order. WTF is that all about? The owner explained that the costs have gone up! So what! Just raise the price. Traditionally there are 6 pot stickers per order every where in town. When they 1st downsized to 5 ps....& I took home an order....my wife & I got in a big fight because she accused me of eating one on the way home.
I have also noticed that the other portions have been downsized by about a third. There used to be 2 shrimp & 2 black mushrooms in the Chow-Mein & combination fried rice & now there is only one of each and sometimes none at all. It really breaks my heart to award only two stars.
I used to litterally stop people on the street to recommend this place. No more. The new customers of the Mandalay weren't around in the past so they can't relate what is happening now. If this strategy continues....pretty soon you will be able to fit your entree in a tea cup.
author: Jack M.

description: Burmese food is a gem in the sea of ethnic cuisine. the Tea leaf salad, coconut rice and Chin mong jaw make my heart sing! While BurmaSuperstar is also delicious, Mandalay is my favorite, there is something a little more down-home about the taste, preparation, etc.
author: gemma h.

description:
I'm always debating with people which place is better: Burma SS, or Mandalay.  I think both do dishes that are slightly better/different than the other.  In terms of price, Mandalay wins handsdown.  Food wise, it's a toss up.  Back to my review on Mandalay.

What's good:
*Platha (Balada) - Buttery naan-like pancake bread
*Fish Chowder - a TRUE burmese family peasant dish served with Noodles!
*Mango Chicken - Not mind blowing nor burmese, but the sweet/tangy of the mango goes well with the stir fried chicken
*Paluda - burmese dessert is goooood
*Chin Mong Jaw - my wife loves this dish.  I don't like the veggies (sour) in it, but they do make it very good here
*Dry Stir Fried String Beans - YUMM
*Somusa - Almost a must have appetizer 

Not So Good:
Burmese style Noodle Salad -  don't recall what it's called, but it's not that great.  

Service is great...if you get serviced by one of the 2 sisters that work there.  Some of the waitstaff are sort of ditzy and discombobulated.  They will pick up dishes w/out asking if finished or even noticing that there's actually 1/2 a plate of food on there.  Just not attentive, but also not a deal breaker not to come here.
author: james c.

description: I love Mandalay and have been going for 5 years. My favorite dishes are the gin dok salad, tea leaf salad, papaya salad, mango chicken, balada and green beans. YUM!!!! I love how they do not put lettuce in their gin dok or tea leaf salad.
author: Reena P.

description: We were motivated to give this place a try after it received a rare unanimous recommendation on the local PBS dining show "Check Please, Bay Area." After two visits I'm still in the "honeymoon period," having tried only a few dishes on the menu, but so far, so good...every one has been a winner. Mandalay's offerings are full of tasty surprises in that culinary middleground between Indian and Thai cuisine. Some influences are recognizable as being similar to the cuisines of Burma's neighboring countries, whereas some are just totally novel, delicious and intriguing. Start with the mind-blowing, flavor-popping Tea Leaf Salad and go from there. Have fun drinking/eating a coconut while enjoying the Burmese decor. So many more savories to explore... I may be sitting at the next table. Oh, though my Indian and Thai dining experience has been extensive this is only the third Burmese place I've tried...definitely the best, though!
author: Jose S.

description: This place was so disappointing. I was intrigued after watching Check Please Bay Area but I think the restaurant couldn't handle the new popularity. The waiters were ok, but the hostess had a sour look on her face the whole time we were there and totally rushed us out. The portions were incredibly small, especially for the price. I would much rather go to Burma Superstar or B Star Bar, where the people are friendlier and the food is much better.
author: Keromi K.

description:
This was the first Burmese restaurant I'd eaten at, and although there is no other for me to compare it to, I really liked the dishes here. My friends and I each got our own dish and shared, so I tried quite a few different dishes. The one I liked the most was the Mandalay chicken that they are famous for. Second prize goes to the curry chicken. 

People that work there are EXTREMELY nice! The guy that served us gave us a brief history of the place (apparently this was here since 1984-go figure!) and was very very patient and understanding.

They also have a map of where Burma is located at geographically right on their menu. Apparently it is bordered by Thailand, China, Laos, Bangladesh, and India. Very educational and yummy experience. Highly recommended.

P.S- I got the coconut drink and it was too thick! The first few sips were great but then I just couldn't gulp down more than half of it. But if you think you are man enough to handle it then it's definitely worth a try.
author: Anthony J. C.

description: I love Burma Superstar but I hate waiting. Unfortunately going to Burma Superstar usually involves at least an hour wait.  Luckily I found Mandalay which has a practically identical menu AND takes reservations. Love! I ate here with some friends who had just moved back into town and we had an amazing dinner over great conversation. Their tea leaf salad is just as good as Burma's and we had this pumpkin curry which they were nice enough to make vegetarian for us, it was really delicious with tofu. Also splurge on the coconut rice, it was delicious and combined with the curry made it a delectably creamy indulgence. I will definitely add this to my list of restaurants to frequent.
author: Cathy T.

description:
excellent excellent Balada, crispy, chewy, warm, layers of oily goodness... err, i did use my napkin to soak up some of the oil, so that made it healthy right??? The curry that came with it was great too. it's not too runny nor too spicy. Even though I was beyond full by the end of the meal I still managed to finish all the balada. and the tea leaf salad. .=\
the tea leave salad is not as "magical" as "the amateur gourmet' claims to be, however, I do like the fragrance of the tea leave a lot, and I normally hate fried garlic cuz it's usually bitter, but it's done well in Mandalay. 
The staff are super friendly and refills water promptly. The space is nice, clean and quiet, reminds me of one of the more upscale Thai restaurants in San Diego.
The food are more on the sweet/fruity side, both the Mandalay chicken and the basil chicken were sweet and sour. Those two dishes were good, but not great, nothing I would want more of. I was disappointed to not be able to find the pumpkin chicken on the menu (i must be blind), so I'll update once I try that dish. =)
author: Mika J.

description: Mandalay is very good food. Burmese food is a nice alternative to Chinese or Thai; very flavorful. The service is nice if a bit slow at times, especially when they get busy. The dining room isn't fancy; the atmosphere isn't much, but that is OK IMHO. I don't think this place would impress a date, but it's great for a group of friends. Parking in the neighborhood sucks! Which isn't a problem if you use Muni on the 1 to get there. Also, reserve ahead! Even on weekdays it fills up.
author: Steven G.

description: As my friend and I were looking at the menu , we were formally welcomed by one of their friendly staff members which was pretty nice . I had a ginger lemonade which tasted alright ... not really a big fan of it though . I also had a coconut rice which tasted kinda weird . My friend and I shared the Balada ( Burmese crispy pancake ) , Mandalay chicken salad , and Nan Gyi Dok . The Balada was alright ... the dipping sauce didn't really impress me though . The Mandalay chicken salad was alright but the chicken was kinda dry . The Nan Gyi Dok was what really impressed me about this restaurant . The Nan Gyi Dok was very delicious ! The sauce tasted very interesting ... mysterious , but in a good way . The sauce was kinda cheesy but the cheesiness was not too overpowering . I don't know what they put in their secret sauce but it sure is addicting ! Will definitely be back for their Nan Gyi Dok ...
author: Eileen L.

description: well, this place is near mY house and it's the best Burmese restarant that I have tried so far. Presentation is good as well as the tastes and sights. U should try the Samosas and Mango chicken!! I took my friends here last Christmas Eve a year ago and theY were impressed!!! Always wanted to go to the BURMA SUPERSTAR on Clement St. but that place is always too crowded!!
author: herm p.

description: Burma Super Star this place is not. I'm more than willing to try other Burmese places where the wait isn't two hours in hopes I'll find something that rivals. I will say that the Tea Leaf Salad is comparable and I finished it optimistic with a glimmer of hope that I've found my new Burmese spot. Then the main dishes arrive and quickly crush my dreams. Nothing I tried was close to the what I've had at the bottom end at BSS. A plus star for friendly service and free desert. A minus star for uninspired food.
author: Bryan E.

description: *********************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************.  This is how many stars I give this oasis of Burmese delights!  The food and the service was unbelieveably perfect!  The tea leaf salad was the best I ever had.  A friend introduced me to Mandalay the first time and I had to take my friends to taste a bit of heaven.  Have you tasted heaven before?  Well, I haven't, but I'm sure heaven would taste like the food from Mandalay.  mmmmmmmmmmmmkay *snaps* for Mandalay!!
author: Walter C.

description: Had potstickers, mango salad, and maybe the tea salad (whatever's the 1st thing on the salad menu), which was awesome.
author: Heewa B.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants. My husband and I eat here at least every other week. The host always remembers us, remembers that we're vegetarian, and very frequently sends out a free dessert. (They have good veggie options but will make almost anything veggie if asked.) They are a much better choice than the over-crowded, over-rated Burma Superstar. I have recommended this place to a wide variety of friends and it is always gets a great review. They can accomadate large groups easily. Definitely try the walnut broccoli tofu dish (also a chicken version)--it's fantastic.
author: Daneen A.

description:
Delicious and reasonably priced food.  Lurking, but relatively attentive wait staff.  Christmas tree ornaments hanging from the ceiling.  Maraschino cherries in the water.  No wait on a Friday evening!   Despite the two aforementioned oddities, based on my initial experience last night Mandalay has the Inner Richmond Burmese contest won.  More research is definitely in order.  

Of course I like Burma Superstar.  I just like Mandalay more.  The tea leaf salad was tasty, it has a great earthy flavor and I enjoyed the varied consistencies present.  The Chin Mong Jaw (sour vegetables) was incredible.    Fermented tangyness.  Walnut broccoli tofu was also good, the toasted and sweetened walnuts made an otherwise average entree noticeably more enjoyable.     

Despite the fact that many of the "vegetable" entrees and appetizers contained ingredients like shrimp and prawns, exclusion and substitution of these items to accommodate for vegetarians was easy and hassle-free.

Bottom line:  I won't hesitate to recommend Mandalay to friends and will definitely return in the near future.
author: Colin P.

description: This restaurant is also a good choice for Burmese food and has a larger seating capacity.
author: miriam b.

description: You'd never know how fancy the place is before you get there.  It's a really quaint restaurant where you dine in such delectable delights.  Whatever you magically chose from the menu was a great meal.  As a group we all picked whatever we wanted to eat and shared amoungst each other.  It was a nice treat for ourselves.
author: Daphne A.

description: Great food. Prices are decent for the quality, maybe not for the quantity. However, the food is great, the service is amazing, and I keep going back. It's not packed like Burma Superstar or B-Star, so it's a lot easier to get in. From appetizers to desserts, the whole meal is memorable and is consistent.
author: Katia T.

description: This place is amazing. Everything is so fresh and flavorful. Every time I come here I leave so happy. I will wait for an hour any day. I get cravings for this place every few weeks. My Burmese friend recommended it and we always come here together. Try it you wont regret it.
author: Jin S.

description: BEST OF THE BEST!!!  LOVE WITH FIRST SIDE!!!   I  live in Bay Area  for last 20 years, was introdused to this place  in October 1991, by my uncle.   Since  then, for us best place  to just come and eat, celebrate birthdays.   We always recomend  this place to people.  Food is always  PERFECT and  beyond PERFECT.  The owner  already knows as so good, that  she tells as, what  diches we'll order, we only  do some corrections, if we in the mood to try something new. Going  here again  this coming Sunday, for my ded's birthday.  Just  to think  how I'm gona enjoy  my dinner there make me hungry.
author: Yelena G.

description: The service was good and the staff very nice.  Try the Tea Leaf Salad.  It is an explosion of flavor.
author: Curtis B.

description: The "other" Burmese restaurant...I had gone here after finding out there was a 3 hour wait at Burma Superstar. I had gone here with a large group of 8 people and the wait was about 1.5 hours. We were finally seated and this place does have more room to roam around but the food here is not as impeccable as the other place. We ordered tons of dishes to basically sample the menu. The rainbow salad here is very weak compared to the 22 ingredient loaded version. Mandalay's version is 12-15 ingredients which don't mix well and leaves an odd taste in your mouth. The walnut prawns and everything else was good but I still prefer Burma Superstar. The coconut drinks are served straight from the nut itself but does need some sweetners. Go to Mandalay for group dinners while go to Burma Superstar for more intimate dinners with your honey. If all else fails, order to go and eat at the numerous parks and beaches in San Francisco. Trust me, the food at both places are good but we all have time, and time should not be wasted.
author: Danster L.

description: Really love the Mandalay. Sometimes service can be spotty, but the food has been consistently good. Their lemonade is awesome, and for whatever reason their spinach is wonderful. Spinach - so simple - but it's great here. There's some dish with broccoli, candied walnuts, and spicy chicken that's really excellent. And they have a rice option that's good (with raisins, bay leaves, and a spice) that's quite good but much more of a side dish than a rice option. I'd stick with plain ol rice if you just want something to accompany your other dishes.
author: Jen D.

description: I believe this was my first time trying Burmese food. Burmese dishes remind me of malaysian...with the similar belacan flavors. It was my first time having the tea leaf salad, which is what they're well known for. I loved it. I could eat this often but because i'm some what of an ayurvedic freak, i know this is a "hot" food and "hot" foods always give me pimples, sore throats and dried mouth, which i hate! But this isn't a review about my bodily reactions to food..hehe.. The restaurant has a homey feel, the staff is very nice and the food's great for what it is and at great prices!
author: Sandra P.

description: The decor is better than Burma Superstar, the service is better than Burma Superstar, the wait is much shorter than Burma Superstar, and the food is just as good as Burma Superstar.
author: Will H.

description:
Wow this food is great. The first time I came here it was by mistake. We ended up at this location thinking it was a sushi place we'd found online. . . but i think it happened for a reason that my boyfriend and I ended up at these AMAZING FOOD! Full of flavor, great atmosphere, and you see all the awards the restaurant as been given as soon as you walk in. It's a great place to get a taste of flavors that you aren't usually used too! Went for the second time tonight and I think I'm gonna call this my favorite restaurant in the city. Mix of asian, thai, indian flavors (atleast that was my responce). Everyone is raving about the tea leaf salad (?) but I have yet to try it. You also see people ordering drinks with umbrellas in it (they have a list of special drinks- nonalcoholic)- and it looks great so next time I'm gonna have to try it.

$9-12 a dish and I think fully worth it :-D
author: Ava A.

description: Although Burmese food would not top my list of cravings (normally) I have to give these guys their props. I think what makes the food even better is the genuinely friendly service -- the first time I went I felt like my satisfaction was their main goal for the night. Later one of my friends had her birthday gathering here and they not only put together several tables right in the middle of the floor, they got her a gift! You have to love businesses who care about their customers.
author: Robert M.

description: I'm hooked.  Seriously, I wish Mandalay didn't make such a mean tea leaf salad.  This restaurant has ruined it for all other Burmese restaurants.  The pungently sour and savory leaves are my FAVORITE starter on their menu.  I'm happy, oh so happy, with just the Tea Leaf Salad and my hot and sour soup.  Their complimentary tea warms my heart.  We go there at least once a month and I'm always impressed with the service and food.  I must admit, the dinner crowd is quite bustling these days and that is annoying *ha*. The last time that we were there (Sat, June 7, 2008), we brought two "out of town" visitors and they liked the food, as well.
author: Hiromi N.

description: I ordered the tea smoked duck, thinking it would be the best example of their cuisine.  ....  .....  Nothing really special.  I've had more succulent roasts from cheaper Chinese stands.  It eally doesn't stand out and taste freshly cooked over the hearth, rotisserie, or whatever would be used.  Really unexciting.  No Burmese tea to actually show that it was used as an ingredient or a culinary motif.  Sigh.
author: Jeff L.

description:
small portions but great favors

kind of odd, though, how the funniest moment came late one night, as "handsome rob" and i were finishing our meal and an employee rolled the giant industrial garbage receptacle out the front door [illegally], coming within 6 inches of our table.

[brief pause] 
me: "um, isn't that illegal?"
rob: "uh, i think so..."
me:" well, shit, if all the restaurants in this city were brought up to code, all the good ones would close!"
rob: "you're damned right. cheers to that."

come back for the food, but don't come late as you might have another illegally close encounter with a giant garbage can.
author: Charles C.

description: This place is *almost* as good as Burma Superstar, but much easier to get a table and less claustrophobic.  Great for taking a large group out for Burmese food.  I am particularly fond of the tea leaf salad and the rainbow salad.  I could eat those and nothing else.  The servers seem less stressed here, too, than at Burma Superstar.  So I guess my rating is based more on the food, giving them four stars instead of five, but overall, their service and atmosphere is better than Burma Superstar, so they probably should get five stars, too.
author: Melaina E.

description:
if you've had the tea leaf salad at burma superstar and ordered the same thing at mandalay you'll notice a distinction.  it was pretty funny when my co-workers and i came here the other day for lunch and one of them who could probably eat the tea leaf salad in her sleep was appalled at the lack of the leafy greens that she normally sees in this salad marriage. she mourned a little, and even questioned the waitress, but she got over it quick because it was just as yummy.

on my second visit, i was pleasantly surprised because the first time i came, the food was too much like typical chinese fare and of course my comparison to the other "superstar" was unavoidable.  but the second time was like finding that 10 dollar bill in your front jacket pocket that was long forgotten. maybe i ordered the wrong stuff on my first try, but i can happily say that this place can stand on its own.
author: Jen C.

description: I am going to make mention of the roti bread.....probably the best fried bread until you at least reach polk street. ( actually, i think its probably one of the greatest rendtions city-wide. i was just making a "locals" guffaw churn. ha......ha......) Other than that, you can probably guess which restaurant takes control, though. I know the people who say this is better feel that way as well, but persist in being generous. By all means eat here though, this place is certainly a place to between 6-9:30 pm. on a friday, with a group, you don't want to wait for the burma, park your fanny in one of these seats, order something with basil and coconut rice, and extrapolate the notion that it will probably do the job. And i say it will, sucka.
author: Christopher J.

description: Forget yuppie, hipster, trendy Burma Star.  Walk down the street for no line and food just as good.
author: Jeff B.

description: I am a regular at Mandalay, almost every other week i am craving for some burmese food already. Owners are really nice and friendly. Food is just delicious! My favs - Moo hin gar (fish chowder soup), Nan gyi touk (noodle) and mandalay chicken salad is always what I'd start with. It's the best Burmese food in town right now. I am from Burma and I'd say Mandalay is the closest to authentic Burmese food in town! Give it a try people, the que is not as bad as Burma Superstar and yet the food is even tastier! yummm.....
author: Sarah O.

description: Hidden in the quiet neighborhoods on California, this place is a jewel. We have been here on multiple occasions and this place is great for an intimate date to a large-group birthday celebration. The food is outstanding and very reasonably priced. The service is excellent. You do have to get here early or expect a wait.
author: Sofia S.

description: Everyone always talks about Burma Superstar on Clement for Burmese food so that's where I headed first.  Maybe it was the almost 2 hour wait that did it, but I just wasn't that impressed.  But I did develop a taste for Burmese - kind of like a cross between all other Asian cuisines - Thai, Chinese, Vietnamese...So I was happy to find Mandalay just a few blocks away.  It's not really a hidden gem anymore either (Zagat Rated) but I've never had to wait longer than 10 minutes and the food is delicious!  My perfect order for 2 (stuffed) or 3 (satisfied), is a Green Papaya Salad, Walnut Broccoli Chicken, Green Beans and Coconut Rice.  The Coconut Rice is amazing.  I also like the Mango Chicken and like to get sticky rice with Mango for dessert...more coconut.
author: Genevieve L.

description: This place is a great place to "experiment" food with friends. I went on a Saturday evening to have dinner and was consumed by the romantically dim setting. Since my friends and I did not make a reservation, we had to wait, but that only took about 5 minutes, so it wasn't too bad. We wanted to try the tea leaf salad because I had heard all the rage about. It came in a platter all sorted out and the waiter demonstrated by mixing the whole concoction together; it was so good. We then ordered sour noodles, mango chicken, and coconut dessert, which were all delicious. It was the loveliest meal I've had in a while. Oh, and there was a free show too.
