This one girl fainted and caused a major commotion. Paramedics and firemen rushed in to check up on her and found out her blood sugar was too low. She was fine and acted as if nothing happened. I plan on coming back.
author: Alex Y.

description: We were regulars here for a very long time, for quick lunches and birthday dinners. At first, it was a great alternative to the usual Chinese food. Everything was zesty, exciting, unique! I'm a big fan of soups, and both the hot and sour and coconut soups hit the spot every time! However, over the years, this place has gotten more expensive and the unique dishes have grown dull. Despite being regulars, the last couple of times we were here we got overcharged, experienced poor service, and were rushed out. It seemed like all of the dishes were over fired and used the exact same sauce! Maybe we'll give it another try soon.
author: Igor B.

description: Slow lunch service and food is way overrated.  Most of the stuff we got tasted like an MSG truck crashed in the kitchen.  Their special chicken was like popcorn fried chicken w/ a sweet sauce.  not.  special.
author: John K.

description: This was the first time I ever had Burmese so I have nothing to compare it too. I was thinking of going to Burma SuperStar but it's always crowded and this was the next best alternative. The food has a blend of its neighboring countries. I didn't have the tea leaf salad. I don't like peanuts in my entrees. I had the fried fish cake as an appetizer and the rangoon beef and mango chicken for entrees. The portions were smaller than what I was used to but the food was different and a pleasant change from Chinese cuisine.
author: Armstrong B.

description:
my boy & i have been wanting to try burmese cuisine for some time now. not wanting to put up with the indefinite wait of burma superstar, we decided to try mandalay. it was a friday night & the place was packed but we got a table fairly quickly.

our waiter greeted us almost immediately and, with us having stated it was our first visit, he gave us the shpeal on the restaurant. we ordered a bottle of wine and the pre-set dinner for 2, i don't quite remember what it was called. the highlights of the meal were the ginger salad (like nothing i have ever had before) & the coconut chicken noodle soup (served with lemon & cilantro on the side). the entrees were great but more on the chinese take-out side. next time, i want to dive in to the more exotic dishes... it's about time i tried duck.

i must mention that the service was amazing. we were checked on multiple times throughout the meal but multiple servers & even the manager. i will be back many times!
author: Lizzy L.

description: I know, you think i'm crazy for giving this place 5 stars. Well, it deserves it. The service is amazing, the owners make the time to talk to you (sometimes take your order). If you've read my other reviews, you know i love me some chicken. OK so get their chicken samusas and/or tea leaf salad or hot and sour soup for appetizers. Then for dinner try their mango chicken or basil chicken. MANGO chicken is so good, it's got the right balance of sweet and savory. Get it with coconut rice though, it's a good compliment. Oh and at the end the owners were nice enough to give us this custard dessert, complimentary. mango flavored i think. They're so nice. Their food is so good, and don't get me wrong, i love Burma Superstar but this place is just as good but without the wait.
author: S K.

description: Heard about this place from a friend and wanted to check it out. The ambience, food and staff were awesome! It's a big restaurant and was completely full! Make sure to try their Sangria (with the lychees) and Basil chicken.
author: Rish B.

description: very elegant set up, food was amazing, had he mango chicken with coconut rice, my favorite dish. great for dates, business,or just to go enjoy a great environment, and really great service, and amazing food of course. highly suggest tis place, parking can be difficult though
author: Erik K.

description:
What sets this restaurant apart from others is the elegant atmosphere and decorations.  Some Southeast Asian restaurants feature an Elephant or Royal theme.  Mandalay has precious artifacts, art and tasteful tapestries hung high above the dining room. Okey enough fru fru.
The food is not as spicy and pungent at Thai or Vietnamese but has a very varied menu featuring all sorts of Asian dishes.
The much talked about Tea Leaf Salad( Lap Pat Dok) is light and tangy but not overwelmingly delicious or notable.  Nevertheless interesting and exotic.
Green Papaya Salad is traditional in Cambodia, Laos and Thailand with the citrusy, fish sauced and spicy dressing laced with shrimp and roasted peanuts. Spicy and refreshing.
The Burmese national dish (Moo Hing Nga) Catfish Noodles was simple and homey.  Not fishy at all because made from dried catfish powder. Long clear rice noodles and a light soup base, the dish was a great transition to main courses.
Pumpkin Shrimp Burmese Curry: Yellow curry delightfully served in a hallowed out pumpkin with large prawns and a rich spicy gravy
Pan Fried Pompano: Another common Southeast Asian speciality deep fried to the extent that the fish is edible saved for the middle bone and smothered with a fragrant, spicy chili glaze with red peppers.  Not one morsel was left by out hungry group

Overall an enjoyable dining experience enhanced by the superb and attentive service wait staff.
author: Harrybobo L.

description: I used to be a huge Burma Superstar fan but the insane wait has turned me off.  My hubs and I tried out Mandalay recently to see if it would be a good BSS back-up place.  But looks like Mandalay has gotten a lot of hype recently and I was shocked that we had to wait over 45 minutes for a table.  Like BSS... not worth it!  If you can get in early or later and avoid the wait, the food here is solid.
author: L W.

description: This place is a gem.  All the dishes I've tried have been wonderful.  I've never had to wait for a table and you can't beat the price.  The customer service is great.
author: simple g.

description: Great little alternative to the long wait at Burma Superstar two blocks away. In fact, I've come here so many times because of the Burma wait that I now defer to this place. Excellent food. Try the Balada appetizer...and the Mandalay Chicken.
author: charles p fa t.

description: Well, I went here because the line at Burma Superstar was just crazy. Unfortunately, this restaurant paled in comparison. The dishes we ordered were so-so.. The spicy green beans were not spicy enough. The basil shrimp was pretty good. The noodles with tofu were mediocre. Also the service was not that great as the waitress confused our order with someone else. NO WE DID NOT ORDER THE BEEF!!!!!!!! Or whatever that was. Yeah the best dish we had was the cream of wheat gelatin thing. yeah that was yummy. weird texture. like malted milk JELLO. JELL-O!! Next time I will wait the 1.5 hours for Burma Superstar, which also has a much more fun and lively atmosphere.
author: O K.

description: The original plan was to go to Superstar but we ended up coming here based on yelp reviews and lack of patients for the hideous wait. The service was very attentive, price was decent,  and food was good but not great. I've been growing tired of your ordinary Chinese or Thai food so it was a nice little twist of change in Asian cuisine. The menu wasn't as unique as Superstar but I've only been here once... definitely need to come back and give the other things on the menu a go.
author: Richard K.

description: Seems kind of lonely if you compare it with the crowd of restaurants in Clement, I guess that's why they painted yellow, as if it  was telling you "I'm here, come in". You enter and you try their Rainbow Salad, and then, the yellow blends with the rests of the colors
author: Alex A.

description: Can't hold a candle to superstar.  yes service is better and the wait is soooo much better but just lacks the creativity.
author: Herbert W.

description: Initially, I wanted to meet up with some friends at Burma Superstar.  It was a Wednesday night and we were having a late dinner around 8, so we assumed there wouldn't be a long line.  When I got there, there were already 10 parties of 2-3 in front of me.  So we decided to go to Mandalay which is only a few blocks away.  There was no wait and the service was great.  We ordered a tea leaf salad, rainbow salad and a chicken salad, which were all very delicious and flavorful!  I am definitely coming back here the next time I'm craving Burmese food!
author: Siu L.

description: Nice, light, and reasonable. Server was friendly and and the food hit the spot. I found myself enjoying the ginger lemonade so much that I jokingly asked if it contained booze. Only minor annoyance was the small wait to be seated, but more than anything that signals a good joint!
author: Dave M.

description: Blah!  I didn't hate this place - but everything we got (tea leaf salad, spciy chicken with asparagas, lamb curry) was quite uninspired - not bad, per se, but not good either and a little greasy, so I felt guilty and unsatisfied.  This was particularly frusterating as I was looking for an alternative to Burma Superstar.  This is sooo not it - it just wasn't good enough or flavorful enough to fill my craving for burmese.  Sigh...just so disappointing.  But, service was very nice and friendly and we didn't have to wait for a table.
author: Tesia H.

description: Excellent burmese food - best I've had! My suggestion would be to skip the chinese dishes and stick to the burmese ones. Kaw Soi at Mandalay is the best I've had anywhere and probably the most authentic - you have to try it! I come back to san francisco from chicago just for that! Tea leaf salad is great as well.
author: Rayid G.

description: Walked up to Burma Super Star 10 min before it opened and expected maybe a couple people waiting, but A LINE HALF A BLOCK LONG!!!  Screw that, so we went 2 blocks over to Mandalay and got pretty good food.  I'll never say that Mandalay is better or even comparable to Burma Super Star, but it is definitely good food at a decent price with very good service.  If you cant deal with the craziness at Burma S.S. then head over to your quiet friendly neighborhood Burmese restaurant, Mandalay.
author: Dane H.

description:
I love coming here with my daughter.  I love the food that they serve, and the family-friendly atmosphere along with the reasonable prices.

If you like Burmese food, and who does not, come here for a great meal.  Don't expect anything upscale.  Just great food and friendly (but not super friendly) service.
author: Ella S.

description: This place. Oh, this place. Just when i think about eating here I get excited. I usually get Burmese style noodles... or the walnut green beans w/tofu. (as i am a veggie) and the food is just AMAZING. There are so many delicious flavors..and for the appetizers the balada! oh, my god. the crispy pancake,, and that sweet and spicy curry sauce.. absolutely fabulous! The service is also wonderful.  The only reason im giving four stars is because of that weird period when they are closed..i always end up there right then
author: kristen n.

description: Burmese food is so delicious.  Some of my favorite flavors: fried onions/garlic, coconut, cilantro, spice, etc. This place was solid but not as good as Burmese Kitchen in the Tenderloin or Burma Superstar/B-star. More like 3.5 stars.  Got there early so wait was not too bad but when we left there were a ton of people waiting. I thought the hostess was a little rude. Service was ok, a little slow especially at first and more team style than a dedicated server. Overall I thougth the portions were a little small.  We had: rainbow salad--delicious but small portion; mango chicken--just ok, would not order again...very salty and flavor just ho-hum; mandalay special noodles--very good, great flavors, could have been temperature hotter and also a little salty; spinach with garlic--pretty good, just as it sounds; coconut rice--god, why is this stuff so good? $5 for ginger lemonade? Jeez.  A solid meal overall. Fun crazy atmosphere, all bright yellow and christmas? ornaments and Burmese stuff everywhere.
author: D R.

description: Excellent all around.  The food is great and just unusual enough when you're in the mood for Asian but tired of Chinese or Sushi.  The place is spotless & welcoming, the portions generous and the ladies there are oh-so-sweet.
author: Marcus H.

description:
my visit to mandalay was a reunion of a few things concurrently with my first experience of burmese dining. the first reunion dealt with a visiting friend i have not seen in a few years with her boyfriend and some of their friends who are much more familiar with burmese than i was. the second was a reunion with my latent passion for new things. getting caught up in the amazing yet cheap selections san francisco has to offer for dining options, i sometimes forget to try new things. and i am glad burma superstar was closed for renovations as it offered us the visit to mandalay - as much as i hate to offer up the opportunity as a second choice option.. combining definitive burmese options with indian and thai influences, the options here astound anyone interested in some serious dining.

those uncomfortable with sharing entrees are seriously limiting themselves in life. sharing truly is caring, in general. and, with options such as the balada appetizer, the tea leaf salad, and my personal favorite, the honey walnut prawn, one could not enjoy all of these alone, although each is worthy of their weight in gold. the balada is a great appetizer, but would double as a great dessert with how sweet and soft it is. the tea leaf salad is an experience in textures and a new understanding of what a salad can truly mean much more than lettuce and tomatoes. and the honey walnut sauce which covers the giant prawns is pure brilliance.

the service we experienced at mandalay was shared among three different women serving the entire restaurant, so we were well-cared for. after we all declined dessert, they brought us a complimentary dish of sweet potato dessert. although this was my first experience with burmese food and mandalay in particular, rest assured i will be doing both again soon.
author: Jeremiah W.

description:
Three words.
Bland, Dry. Bland.
Oh my fellow Yelpatologists, you hath led me astray. Are you all high?
My cohorts and I ordered the Ginger salad and the Chicken Satay for starters. While I'm not an expert by any means on Burmese food and culture, I believe this ginger salad, a combination of nuts, dry garlic, ginger, lentils, and bits of hemp twine, was developed to keep the Burmese army regular. Ironically, the Thai's have a similar dish which is eaten in a rolled up piece of lettuce, which is out of this world. When we were eating this salad, I kept thinking the Burmese Ashton Kutcher from Punked was going to jump out from behind the Christmas-festooned [see review date]  swags that 'decorate' the restaurant. This dish is nasty.
The satay was served with bland peanut sauce, and chicken which was so dry, it could only please Oo Min Kyaw himself. For entrees, we had the spicy Mango Chicken, which can be noted for neither being spicy nor containing any substantial amounts of anything resembling fowl. If you like stir-fried mango, this dish is for you. The beef in the Beef Curry was extremely chewy and had to be chewed at length in order to be forced down the gullet. Good news, my teeth are white and my coat is shinier than ever!
The Singapore Noodle dish was a mound of intertwined, dry noodles  barely worthy of the Panda Express in the food court.
The big selling point, as I initially understood it, was related to the huge line and long wait to get in to the Burma Superstar...well, maybe there's a good reason for that. Ya think?
author: Mr. S.

description: In comparison to Burma Super Star, this place has more of a Chinese flair to their food.  I prefer Burma Super Star, but overall the food here was still good.  I made reservations and we were seated promptly when we got there.  Service was good.  We had an enjoyable dinner without the cramped tables like Burma Super Star.
author: hello k.

description: Excellent service, very attentive and prompt. Food was very tasty, though how authentically Burmese, I have no idea. I will most certainly return for more.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description: hella good. period. GO NOW! first time i tried burmese food. will go again. pretty romantic too. go there go there. good food. price is reasonable. i paid $35 including tip for 2 dishes and coconut rice. it was awesome. service is great. the lady bows at you everytime when she asks how the food is. highly recommend.
author: Glen L.

description:
This is one of my regular restaurants - both to eat there and for take-out.

The Mandalay chicken here is one of my absolute favorite dishes in the city.

Also, if you go, make sure to try the lemonade with ginger.  Sounds a little strange, but is actually very good.
author: Morgan M.

description: Came here with Michael for Valentine's Day this year. The food was rich and flavorful, I am pleased to report. His Burmese iced tea, which was slightly less sweet than a Thai iced tea, was served in a swanky, tall swirled glass. My ginger lemonade was quite sweet but tempered with mint leaves. I can get behind our dishes - tofu and veggies in a yummy sauce and Birds Nets [sic] seafood - and our appetizer - a pancakey thing with an oniony sauce. The best part was the numerous typos and occasionally awkward names in the menu. Michael's eyes alighted immediately upon "Happy Family Sauteed." He says that he doesn't think he would be very happy as part of a sauteed family.
author: Deb T.

description: This is a super cute place.  I ordered the mango salad and the mango prawns.  Both dishes were awesome.  We ordered coconut rice to go with that, which definitely added more flavor to the food.  The beef curry actually wasn't all that good.  I wouldn't recommend ordering that.  The staff is nice, and plus there's a cool fake palm tree right when you walk in that will keep your eyes entertained.
author: Kim N.

description: Great foood, and much less of a line than Burma superstar. There wasn't much of a crowd inside when we went and it's more romantic than Burma. The mango chicken was amazing.
author: Sarah R.

description:
The service was friendly, but burmese are a friendly people.

The food was pretty darn good.  However, I don't believe it is authentic burmese food.

I spent a few weeks backpacking through Burma two summers ago.  The food was terrable.  For three weeks, I survived on a diet of diarhea inducing indian food (a lot of Indians live in Burma), as the diahrea was more pleasant than what was available at burmese restaurants and noodle shops.

The best burmese dish I had in Burma was a bowl of stomach soup that I had at a food stall at an animist festival about 30 miles outside of Mandalay.  It was surprisingly delicious.  The woman that served it to me had the most beautiful, perfectly aligned, pearly white teeth.  More beautiful than said teeth found in the typical mouth of your upper middle class american college student whom had the benefit of braces in his/her youth.  Teeth such as her's are not  common in the third world, and even less so in betel nut addicted Burma.

Go to Burma for its beauty, the unique temples of Bagan, and to meet some of the most good hearted people in this not always friendly world.    If you are going to burma for the food, I would skip the long, multiple layover flight and  head down the street to Mandalay Restaurant, as it tastes better than stomach soup.
author: Mark K.

description: This is my alternate place if burma superstar gets way over packed. They offer a set meals for 2 or more. My friend and i decided to try this place out and it wasn't bad. the price is definitely reasonable. they did offered a set dinner for two with six different dishes on their menu including dessert (fried banana with ice cream *drools*). it wasn't bad and the servers are really nice and is willing to recommend dishes. one thing i would avoid is the ginger salad. it's way to strong in taste. that dish is not for me =P
author: Lynn P.

description:
Now to be fair, this is a very hard review to make because the experience was such a mixed one. Let me begin with the fact that food was really great so ordinarily I would rate in the 3-4 range. However, and this is the main however, the service was abysmal. I made a reservation for my birthday a week in advance for a party of 12. The restaurant was very crowded though it being a Saturday, I shouldn't have been surprised. We were offered drinks to order while waiting but even so, they took their time getting to us. Once we got there, the fact that we made reservations made absolutely no difference because we were not seated for over 40 minutes.The waiters took their time to us menus and take our orders. Once the food order was actually placed, it took over another 40 minutes for all of us to get our orders. In fact several wrong dishes were brought to our table first and we had to ask several times where the rest of our order was. At one point, one of the waiters even spilled a drink on one of my attendees. 

Now given all that, I rate the food with a 4.5 but the service with a 1 so to be fully fair, overall it was and is a 2 start experience. Mandalay was a good idea because the food when it actually got there, was awesome, but the fact that it took so long to come and that we frankly did not get a feeling of being appreciated for our patronage makes me unhappy with the experience. I imagine it's lovely for small groups, no more than 4 people but for large groups, please seek other venues.
author: Eugenia S.

description: I love this place. Great food, really nice employees and conveniently close to me. Everyone raves about burma superstar, but I've eaten at both places and quite frankly I prefer Mandalay.  Not too busy on weekdays, though weekends can be pretty packed.  Fortunately they take reservations, so plan ahead and it's no problem at all.  Parking is pretty difficult but it's the city, of course parking is difficult.  It's a little expensive but for such a nice meal in the city, it is probably about average or even a little cheaper than most places. In summation, go here you won't be disappointed.
author: Jonathan H.

description: I have been having weirdly bad luck with restaurants lately!  I think places are just overbooking and becoming stretched beyond capacity, which, in turn, stretches everyone -- the kitchen, the staff and the patrons -- likewise beyond capacity.  At least, that theory is consistent with my experience tonight at Mandalay.  We were seated about 45 minutes late for our 8:15 reservation, as were the other two groups who had that reservation.  (In fairness, we actually had a better experience in this regard than one table of three that were seated at a two-person table and had to squeeze in -- then didn't get drinks or anything else for half an hour or so.)  More than 50 minutes then passed until we got our appetizers.  In light of this, I was hoping that the food would be good, but it seems like the kitchen was overburdened and really letting things go.  The noodle dish that I had tasted like cold, overdone spaghetti with coconut curry sauce.  I had about a quarter-cup and couldn't eat anymore.  Others were equally impressed with their dishes.  The best thing that the table adjacent to us said about their dishes was, "I don't mind it."  The salads were bland and unimpressive -- the tea leaf salad in particular, which I generally like a lot, was best described as peanuts in green sauce.  Overall, we spent about fifteen minutes of our total two hours here with food, almost none of which we actually ate.  A thing like that really ruins your night -- it's not worth paying for, and I wish we had not stayed.  The only positive thing was that the staff, although obviously stretched thin, was not totally unpleasant, although relations were a little strained.
author: Danielle G.

description:
without comparing to burma superstar, i would give this place 3 stars because their food is tasty and very well priced, and the portions are decent.  they give free tea, which is always nice, and have a cheap lunch menu with lots of variety.  

minus two stars because i felt the food was a bit heavy and greasy (our squash fries were so greasy i had to dab them with my napkin and there was so much grease i had to ask for another napkin), and i thought the entrees were very panda-express.  also, i felt our service was sub-par.  to be fair, we ate there during lunch on a Friday, and the restaurant was full, but there was sufficient staff and management.  we had to ask someone to take our order, ask someone to refill water, ask someone to give us plates for sharing dishes although we had told the server we would be sharing... it was just a poor showing.  we even had to ask them to remove empty serving plates to make more room on the table.  then all of a sudden, every two minutes we were being asked if we were finished with our food and needed boxes, when we were clearly still eating.  

now, to compare to burma superstar, i would say the food here was not as flavorful or refreshing.

howver, the food here was decent enough that i would eat here again to give it another chance.. but if they don't impress, that's it for me.
author: asia c.

description: It took my bf's friends, who were out-of-towners, to introduce me to this place. Definitely not a disappointment. We ordered the tea leaf salad, rainbow salad and two more dishes. Everything was tasty, service was great (came by several times to fill water glasses, without us asking) and price was reasonable. We came on a Sunday for lunch and there was no need to wait for a table of four.
author: Janel Y.

description:
I was fully prepared to be disappointed with Mandalay after passing it on the bus several times and promising myself to give it a chance. With Burma Superstar just a stone's throw away, why roll the dice on an unfamiliar Burmese place?

On sitting down and perusing the menu, I was made even more suspicious when I realized the place offered Chinese AND Burmese cuisine and I heard some kitchen staff speaking Mandarin. If there is one thing I have learned about Asian food in my time living on the continent and eating at countless Asian joints in America, it's that the fewer cuisines/dishes offered on the menu, the better the food usually is.

Trying to keep an open mind, I ordered only Burmese dishes from the menu. Each dish impressed me more than the last. The tea leave salad was exceedingly flavorful, packed with enough roasted garlic to punish my friends for the rest of the weekend. And the balaka (?) Burmese pancakes achieved the perfect balance of oil and flakiness. 

The staff, from the owner who opened the door for us when we walked in to the waitress who stirred our salad with a smile and a clear explanation of the ingredients, obviously took pride in their work. And you could tell that the staff was well taken care of by the staff dinner that began about halfway through our meal. They had a nice spread, but I think we did a bit better for ourselves.
author: Douglas S.

description: I recommend the Mandalay Special Noodle entree. An excellent combination of ingredients - light and refreshing. When are noodles ever light and refreshing?!
author: Aaron B.

description: We came here on a whim and I didn't know what to expect from Burmese food. Thanks to Yelp, we saw the good reviews and gave it a chance. I definitely recommend the fish chowder which absolutely delicious=) The one thing I wish was that we didn't take the motorcycle so we could have taken home the left overs.
author: Angela L.

description: Gotta agree with the crowd - this is a solid choice for Burmese food.  Not quite as cheap as Yamo, but better in my opinion.  Be careful as there are a number of "lemon chickenesque" dishes (heavily battered and with a sweet sauce).  I've found that the dishes whose name start with "mandalay" should usually be ignored.  The salads are all very good, and I really love the coconut noodle soup.  Much less crowded than Burma superstar and they'll do take out orders!
author: She-Ra ..

description:
After our friends raving about this place for a long time, we came to enjoy their food. 
Tea leaf salad was bit heavy but good. Lamb curry was bit different than other Burmese restaurants.  Okra with shrimp was excellent. Special noodle, fish dish were very good.  Service was excellent.  When I am in the neighborhood and craving for Burmese food, I will definitely come back here.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: Tasty Burmese food that rivals the quality of nearby and much hyped Burma Super Star.  I never go to the latter anymore, knowing I'll get just as great a supper here (with superior balada to boot) without the killer wait if I happen to stumble in after 7PM.
author: Alfonso E.

description:
Really enjoyed this place. The interior is a bit cheesy, but that is to be expected. Its a fun mash up of traditional Asian decor with a giant neon palm tree. I suppose the tree complements the building's color scheme of green and yellow. YIKES! 
Went there on a Friday night around 8pm. The place was full but the wait was only 5 minutes for a party of 2. The shrimp won-ton soup was really tasty with 4 tasty dumplings and fresh spinach in a wonderful mild broth. The rainbow prawns were ok - but I am sure that people who like fruit with their meat would love it. The tea leaf duck is out of this world tasty. A half order for $12.is plenty to share. I thought the coconut rice was a bit to cold and hard. I wasn't a fan, but ordered it after reading several positive reviews. Perhaps it was an off night? 
Overall I am excited to add this restaurant to the rotation now that I live in the outer richmond. I'll be sure to sample the Mandalay chicken and the string beans, which looked mighty tasty. I wish I had ordered what my neighbors had. Next time!
author: Stacy T.

description: As most others have noted, a solid alternative to Burma SuperStar. I think I still prefer Burma Super Star's food, just a tad, but the tea leaf salad here was great, and we had no wait (although we did have a large party reservation at 5:30). I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could, but I suppose despite the nice service, and solid food, the nothing special decor bumps it down to plain old 3.
author: J C.

description: Their mango chicken is awesome! Waiting time can be long (even when you have made a reservation), but sometimes you get wine while you wait, and the food is worth it.
author: Patricia C.

description: I always come here around lunch time. The tea leaf salad is a MUST! The service is always nice. Every server I have had has been attentive, while not stopping  by out table every 5 seconds. I live in this neighborhood and whenever I have visitors from out out town, this is is where I take them. Will try their dinner service soon!
author: Tiffany J.

description:
Just came back from Mandalay, and I just don't get what the big deal is. Came for dinner with two stoney guys who could not stop raving about the service and tasty grub.  I raved along to be polite, but the food just didn't sit well in my mouth.  Had the 1) tea leaf salad, 2) samosa salad 3) dry fried green beans, 4) basil eggplant, 5) coconut rice and brown rice and I would say the tea leaf salad was the best, abeit very small.  I liked the two salads because they were different from the usual asian offerings, but still, they did not blow my mind.  The vegetable dishes were very very very average, perhaps even below average. I don't eat meat and I am often disappointed in the vegetarian offerings at restaurants, especially asian restaurants.  These places think that just because you can't use meat in a dish, you should load it with a super oily and salty sauce.  I am an awesome cook, so I am very picky about food when I eat out. I know it is not hard to make a stir-fry - all you need is fresh veggies, spices, and a little bit of oil. So anyways, because I cook, it makes it very difficult for me to eat out and actually feel impressed.  When I am impressed, I become a very loyal customer because I feel the care the cooks put into their food.  
The best part of Mandalay is the service.  The hostess and our server (a 50-ish gentleman) were amazing.  They were very excited about us trying their establishment and took great care of us.  
Will I be coming back? Sadly no.  There are just too many great restaurants in San Francisco to come back to something you are not so excited about.  I came to Mandalay because I was not so impressed with Burma Superstar.  However, I think I might just come back to Burma Superstar because I felt their food was more authentic and there is just more care put into their food.  Burma Superstar has subpar service, but when I am going out, it is all about the food.
author: trang n.

description: Go here for lunch and save! Their lunch specials are less than $10 and really fill you up. My favorites are Mandalay Pork and Samosas. The art and decor is really nice. The staff is okay, but should learn to be more welcoming. Sometimes I walk in there with friends and I feel like they don't want to serve us. But again, it's all about the good food for a good price.
author: Zell C.

description: From the outside, i thought this place might be dead inside (it looks a little old-fashioned) but, i learned that this was the first Burmese restaurant in the city.  Everything was good (we cleaned the plates) and served in a relaxed atmosphere.  The burmese beef curry wasn't as tender as at Superstar.  I wasn't able to compare all of my favorites to Superstar but, I will probably go back.
author: Dawn P.

description: I had their special of the day, which was pumpkin chicken curry. It was incredible! The service was excellent, too, even though they were busy.
author: cm j.

description: Pretty good but was expecting Burma Superstyle level of food. Food is a lot lighter in flavor than Superstar's.
author: Helen H.

description: I love this place. Not only because the wait time is SO much less than Burma Superstar, but it feels much more family run, its a little less expensive, there's more space and the food is fantastic. Try my favorite, Mandalay Special Noodle, or Walnut Broccoli Chicken - and of course the Rainbow Salad (i think thats what its called).  When its really busy, the service can be a little slack - but it seems that every employee serves every table, so you get taken care of before too long. Try this spot, for sure!
author: Alexa S.

description: TIred of waiting for 1.5 hours to get a table at Burma Superstar? Hang in there...Mandalay tries to mirror pretty much all the same stuff they have just a few blocks away from Burma Superstar, but definately does not come close. I thought the Tea Leaf Salad (B.S.'s specialty), was nothing too spectacular. It was a much more bland flavor...not that giant explosion you get over at B.S. The food IS however cheaper, so if you're starving and craving burmese food, this would be a decent place to go to...but what can I say, Burma Superstar is unbeatable!
author: Jessica h.

description: If you want Burmese but don't want to wait it out at Burma Superstar, come to Mandalay.  The menu is similar, if not more extensive.  I went with S and we started off with the mango salad, which was the perfect mix of sweet, salty & tart.  The Rangoon three ingredients was a nice blend of shrimp, scallops, and squid mixed with tomatoes and red and green peppers.  The lamb curry was the perfect cover for the coconut rice and dip for the balada (similar to the Chinese scallion pancake without the scallions).  The mango pudding at the end of the meal was a nice touch as well.  However, I do note the food does seem a tad heavier than at Burma but all in all, a good substitute when you don't want to brave the wait at Burma.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Mandalay is definetly a great place to enjoy some good burmese food. I love the ambiance, and have noticed the constant change of decorations, thats awesome! The food is great, especially that mango chicken, that is some great stuff. I had the basil eggplant, which was great, but could have been spicier, and less greasier. Oh, and this was by far the best hot and sour soup I have had anwhere. Keep up the good work
author: yana Z.

description:
We went here to try out the competition. These portions are only a bit bigger than BS but its not like it makes that much of a difference. I can't say I enjoyed this restaurant as much as the other reviewers. I was prepared for this place since most of the reviewers are not Asian.  No, I'm not being racist. The only way you can tell if the ethnic cuisine restaurant is good is when you see their own people go there. Although.. I don't know of too many Burmese people. In my whole entire life, I've only met 2 Burmese people. One of which introduced me to BS. 

Anyhow.. on with the review.. We had a party of 4 and ordered the following:
Tea Leaf Salad - its got crunch but the flavors did not meld together very well. I would have preferred that the lady left the lemon behind so I could squeeze more in there
Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup - I like this because it comes with parsley and lemon wedges. I'm a condiment lover. The taste was good. Too bad they were cup sized. I would've liked more.
Burmese Curry Beef - you get to choose between coconut rice, saffron rice, or Balada; we chose balada. This dish was not that great and balada wasn't that memorable either. I tried to dip it in the curry but the curry was not smooth. There were floating chunks of the sauce with the beef and potatoes. I would've preferred for it to be a bit saltier and more curry flavor.]
Dry pan string bean - this is pretty good. Just like Cantonese style, they fry the beans first then saute them with sauce. I'd order these again.
Mandalay special noodle - mixed at the table, i thought the consistency was a bit weird but the flavor was pretty good. I'm not sure if i like the texture though. I'm not into slimy flat noodles. But I would order this again.
Coconut rice - I am starting to like coconut rice. First time I had it was at an Indian restaurant. This one was simple. Small coconut flakes in rice. I'd order it again because I have a love for coconut. I used to hate flakes but I'm liking them as I'm growing older. Go figure...
Water - they give this to you with a maraschino cherry in it. I like it but I tell Mr. C not to eat it since its bad for guys to eat them. Something about lowering their sperm count? (more for me.. hehee)

Overall, I would only order a few things from here if I was ever dragged here again. I thought the service was great and the ladies were nice but the food doesn't satisfy my taste buds. If I have to wait at BS, I won't go here instead. I'd  go eat at a diff't restaurant that's not necessarily Burmese. With SF, there are many types of cuisines that would satisfy my tummy.
author: Luna L.

description: Having eaten for dinner half a bag of tortilla chips, a hot dog, and a pear, my stomach feels a lot better than it did after dinner at Mandalay.  It wasn't particularly good compared to Burma Superstar or B Star and not compared to Larkin Street Express...  really, the best part of the meal was the ginger lemonade.  Not planning on going back.
author: Nora B.

description: My first time trying Burmese food so I can't really compare with other Burmese restaurants. I eat a lot of other Asian foods though, and compared with the ones I've tried I thought the food was pretty good. My favorite dishes here were the catfish soup, the pancake dish, and the green beans. I thought it was a bit pricier than what I'm used to, but I came out with a happy tummy and nothing disappointed.
author: Nhi T.

description: They take reservations which instantly gives it a leg up in my book.  I hate waiting hours for a table.  It's only a few blocks from Burma Superstar.  I thought the wait staff was nice, the decor to be a little too kitschy for me.  The food was good.  The Mango Chicken is the same as Mandalay Chicken just with mango.  (I preferred the mango one.)  I got the Moo Hin Nga (fish stew) which is not for the faint of heart.  It is literally ground up fish in a spicy stew.  Perfect for helping me get over the cold I had.
author: Joann C.

description: Pretty good.  20-30 Minute wait on a Sunday evening, friendly waitstaff, and free desert.  Food was pretty good, although I think I like Thai better than Burmese.  The service was excellent, and the free custard desert was a nice surprise.  We sat next to the kitchen, but it wasnt too loud or uncomfortable even in that spot.  I'd go back.
author: Martin S.

description: There wasn't ever a wait the few times I've been here, and I'd recommend rainbow salad, mango chicken (not a dish i would normally order), any of their tofu dishes (tofu kabat), and their singapore noodles...um, those dishes were prolly the only ones I've tried there, and they were all pretty darn good. And go for the coconut rice!
author: Verna L.

description: Overall, good food, tad pricey.  The decor, lighting is calming... however, if you find yourself in need of practice for the up coming worlds hot dog eating contest then this is the place for you!!  The waitress/staff expects you to woooff down your food in minutes in order to accommodate the those standing at the restaurants entry.    And god forbid if you have an empty to low level beer glass next to you... you will be well covered by the staff like pigeons on a piece of bread on the sidewalk.. More beer? beer?  beer? beer? by muliple staff withing 10 minutes.  AND prepare to be bombarded as you near finishing your course, with a few bites to go these same waitress will be all over you to finish so they can remove your plate!!   So if you looking to enjoy  a nice conversation without an abundance of interruptions then this place may not be your best choice to decompress after a long week.
author: Gary L.

description: Really friendly, very good food, and much less of a scene than Burma Superstar (which I also like).  The noodles are really, really good.
author: marie m.

description:
Not a bad restaurant. The staff are nice, the food is great. The service was a little slow- we got our food before our sangria. But the quality of the food made up for it. Their tea leaf salad is not as good as burma superstar but it was still yummy!

I give it a 4 stars but i give burma superstar a 5! Absolutely worth a visit!

Oh, it is worth phoning ahead to book a table, otherwise i believe the wait can be long.
author: Chris G.

description: I love their Rangoon and their soups, even their Balada.  But for goodness sakes, write down orders.  Usually my order is correct but every so often, I get dishes I haven't ordered nor would not order.  I've even got the wrong leftovers before. If they would just use a notepad to take orders I'd give them another star.
author: Bruce B.

description: Mandalay was my first experience eating Burmese food & I am totally addicted! I am hooked on their Mandalay Special Noodle--I order it to go & when I eat there, I always order an extra serving to take home. Their service has always been great & the food is fresh & delicious! The only thing I've tried that I didn't care for was the sake, oddly enough. It may not be one that is not good served hot, so I just order wine. Love this place!
author: Jane W.

description:
So a couple of weeks ago, my friends and I tried Burma Superstar. We were thoroughly unsatisfied considering our expectations. We've always heard great things about this place, but it really didn't match up to our standards on what would be amazing Burmese food. Although I'm not Burmese, but felt we like we could find most of the dishes at a Chinese restaurant. Now I feel like I'm writing a negative review for BSS. ANyway....

Mandalay on the other hand was purely incredible. OUr expectations were high, and then totally met. We had heard of this BSS competitor thru the grapevine. So let's cut to what we ordered:

1. rainbow salad -- some great ingredients mixed with some great noodles. it was literally a burst of flavor.
2. catfish chowder - oh my god this was too good to be true. make sure you get it with noodles! they are super soft and goes down like water
3. mandalay special noodles -- absolutely delish!
4. crispy chicken - generally good. the breast meat was a little dry which is expected. but it was super crunchy and made it more fun to eat

p.s. make sure you get the hot sauce paste! it's enough spicy so that it's not too hot and not too bland. it goes perrrfect with everything, especially the coconut rice. makes for a perfect complement to the milky flavor!

yummmmmy yummmmmmy
author: Connie N.

description: I have been to Mandalay on several occasions and am always really impressed with the excellent food and service.  Today at lunch we had Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken, Lamb Curry with Coconut Rice, and Burmese Noodles with Coconut Chicken. For an appetizer we had Chicken Samusas.  The sauces are delicious and perfectly compliment the food.  The drinks such as Lemonade Ginger and Burmese Iced Tea are yummy.  The restaurant is decorated in a warm, charming fashion with art work from Burma.  Definitely the place for Burmese cuisine!  I have been to Burma Superstar, and it cannot compare to Mandalay.
author: barbara f.

description: Burmese..i went twice, the first time i didnt know what to order and didnt like it too much..the second time i had mango prawns(awesome), soup(forgot the name but great) and grilled asparagus(very good)..its a no frills kind of place but friendly service..
author: Not M.

description: Mandalay serves up Burmese food, which seems to be a strange mixture of Thai, Chinese, and Indian influences in a rather unique combination.  This place has decent food, great options for vegetarians, and good prices.
author: Apollo L.

description:
Good alternative, and very close to that OTHER place. Interior and wait staff is welcoming. Never felt so attended to in my life. Waitress was so kind to keep asking us about our meals, giving us more refreshments, etc. And did a great job of explaining the ingredients before mixing and what is Burmese food. Think I am still trying to find that out!

Rainbow salad and the curries were great, nice to see plates of food with color. Although I was taken aback by some of the ingredients in the dishes, they actually paired up well.

Be adventurous here and try new dishes that might startle your taste bud and you will be hooked, and skip that OTHER place.
author: David B.

description: Got lunch here yesterday with a friend. The atmosphere is very nice and easy not to mention the service was wonderful and quick. I had the lemon chicken and my friend had some noodle dish with coconut chicken. Sooooo goood :} the Lemon chicken was perfect. Will definately go back.
author: S ..

description:
I love Mandalay. It is The yumminess. But why does spinach with garlic cost the same amount as chicken? 

I always get the Mongolian Beef. Interestingly enough,  If you eat at the restaurant and order wine, they bring out this god-forsaken, clumsy, metal contraption for pouring wine. It takes up way too much space on the table! Mandalay, don't try to be fancy. The bottle will do just fine. 

Another story: when my pooky bear and I were dining in one night, we overheard some couple asking for no garlic with their food. No garlic!  Thats is the most fantastically retarded thing I have ever heard of. That's like going to a Mexican restaurant and not wanting anything with onions, cilantro, or cheese. What the hell did you come for?

If you are that ridiculous don't come. More room for real Asian food lovers. 

Oh! And try the eggplant! The eggplant is delicious. Actually everything is delicious.
author: Niya M.

description: I really like this place. It is way better than Burma Superstar and you never have to wait. The coconut noodles are da bomb!
author: Nina B.

description: I agree, the alternative to Burma Superstar on Clement if it's busy.  The food is good here, but I don't recommend bringing a large party because their "family style" is not really fit for a group.  Their thai iced tea is not that good either.
author: Josie W.

description: awesome food. Better than Burma Superstar. And you don't have to wait for an hour to get in.
author: Joy T.

description: This is a fantastic option when Burma Super Star is packed. Just 2 blocks from BSS on California. They have a lot of the same dishes and friendly staff and nice setting. The samusas are equally good as BSS, but the tea leaf salad, while yummy, is somehow not as good.
author: Julie L.

description: Mandalay is on of my favorite restaurants in the world.  It is so yummy. I highly recommend their special noodles, walnut broc tofu and tea leaf salad.  They also take reservations, so it's a great place for a bunch of friends to meet up. mmm
author: Talia S.

description: Much better than the over-hyped Burma Superstar down the street. The food was pretty good, though not necessarily anything special. Their "spicy" food isn't that spicy, so if that's what you're looking for you might want to order up a notch.
author: Rob T.

description:
As a big fan of Burma Superstar, I wanted to try my taste buds at another Burmese restaurant.  When I read other reviews, I was excited to see Mandalay was rated #1 under Burmese cuisine.  There were mentions of this as "the other burmese restaurant in the city", so I knew it had to be good.  Plus, there were promises of not having to wait!  

I  called at about 5pm and made a reservation for 630 and that was no problem. We arrived a little late, not to mention the lack of parking and the really annoying construction going on in the area, but the restaurant was full yet, so I was glad to be seated right away.  The workers there were really nice and friendly.  The waiter asked if it was our first time there and when we said yes, he continued to explain what the restaurant was all about.  We decided to try Mandalay's version of our favorite dish from Burma Superstar - Rainbow Salad.  They did the whole explanation of the dish and mixed it at our table just like at BS. I found the dish a little smaller, but it was comparable.  We also ordered Rainbow shrimp (with pineapple and mango) and Mandalay Beef.  We couldn't help be feel like these dishes tasted just like.. Chinese food. Now Mandalay does claim to be Burmese/Mandarin Chinese cuisine, but we were looking forward to a little more on the Burmese side. The shrimp dish was pretty good, but the Mandalay Beef (claimed to be Burmese style) tasted just like Chinese sesame beef... not too impressed.  At the end of the meal, we mentioned the ad that I read on their yelp page for a free desert and they were really happy that I mentioned it.  The dessert was a really simple mango custard thing, but they were really appreciative of us coming based on what we read on here, so it was really cute.  And our meal was cheaper than it would have been than at BS.

I think I am better impressed with BS, but I liked that there was no wait and the workers here are so friendly.  However a recent discovery of a second BS in Alameda with hardly any wait has been great too!

PS - I ordered the "Burmese Thai Iced Tea" after the waiter told me it is  better than Thai Iced Tea because they use Burmese Tea Leaves, but...  it tasted the same...
author: Joyce S.

description: This place is a great alternative to Burma Superstar, when the wait is unbearable. The menu is pretty extensive, we loved the pancake starter, fried doughy yumminess. The atmosphere was cute and you could definitely bring a larger party here with no trouble, and little wait!
author: Kai H.

description:
I wish I could find it in me to say this place is awful so that the crowd that frequents Burma Superstar doesn't migrate on over to Mandalay.  But, I cannot tell a lie.

Mandalay is fantastic.  The best Burmese food I've ever had.  The broccoli walnut tofu is amazing, and I find it impossible to try other things knowing that I could have this.  

Great.  Awesome.  Delicious.
author: Amanda H.

description:
Hate to give them two stars since the service was really friendly and attentive, but here is what I thought...

parking sucked - might as well gone to a Clement St. restaurant. Both areas have no parking, but at least after eating on Clement St. you can walk around and find other things to do (desert and drinks)
long wait - just like those restaurants on Clement St.
food was good - but we had one dish that smelled like ass and kind of tasted like it too. I think it was the sweet and sour vegetable. One of the waiters had to ask us what it was, so how are you going to expect me to remember exactly what it was.
author: CGI I.

description: I've been here about 4 or 5 times and each time, I've been impressed. The wait is a little shorter than at BSS, and totally worth it. It is also slightly less crowded as the space is a little bigger. The food is wonderful ... mango chicken and curry anything are yummy. The samusas are good and the catfsh chowder too. It's definitely one of my favorite places. But, I still can't decide if I like Mandalay or BSS better for "Burmese" food.
author: Samantha H.

description: Huge fan of Asian foods but this place SERIOUSLY rocks! Love the chill down to earth atmosphere, very friendly service and great explanation of items. If you like Thai, Malay Cuisine then you're gonna love Burmese! DEF try their tea salad, mandalay noodle, and there fried spicy tofu dish and basil eggplant (Love eggplant!) . Worth the value, and truly a great find in the city! Can't wait to go back soon!
author: sue c.

description: Delicious. Identical quality as Burma Superstar but at 20% lower prices. I will go here now instead of Burma Superstar when I want Burmese food. :D
author: Robert S.

description: I love this restaurant.  Have loved it for years.  The tea salad is one of the best, most exciting types of salads I've ever had.  YUM.  I go there whenever I get the chance!
author: Melinna G.

description: I love the fact there are Christmas ornanaments hung up through the restaurant. Very chic! When you order to go, they will serve you tea while you are waiting. The walnut prawns are impeccable here, and I am very picky about the dish. The prawns are huge! Fairly good, I would eat here again.
author: Mama C.

description:
i am a creature of habit.  when i find a dish i love, i have a problem ordering anything else from the menu. at mandalay, this dish isn't just a habit, its a damn addiction.  mango chicken and a side of white rice... i wish i could quit you.  

i always have it in take out.  i bet the food is even better fresh off the stove.
author: Lucy M.

description: If the line is TOO long at Burma Superstar walk a block to California and try this place. Bigger dining area, super friendly staff and the food was fantastic.  If you don't know what to order ask the waitstaff they are very knowledgable and will lead you in the right direction given your tastes.  They serve Saki (Hot & cold) and the atomosphere is pleasant.  We really liked it - and didn't spend nearly as much money here as we do at Burma!
author: J S.

description: I love this place. It has the best, best Shrimp with Okra and their Mango Chicken is awesome.. Their house noodles are delish!  Reasonable, consistenly yummy, great staff.  A satisfying dining experience.
author: Luri S.

description: We had a reservation for a party of 9 for 7 pm on Saturday evening and had to wait over an hour for our table. Kinda defeats the purpose of a reservation! They did not offer us anything as compensation, nor did they apologize for the delay. Lousy service in my book, and despite the excellent food, I will not return.
author: Teri G.

description: I remember how I use to come here pretty often. The food doesn't ever disappoint me. Oh how I love their walnut prawns, large crunchy prawns! so good and satisfying. That has to be my favorite dish!! Their mandalay chicken is also pretty good. The service is attentive, they are nice friendly people. I must come back soon!!
author: Flora W.

description: LOVED the fried pompano. I had my fill of the fillet meat, when my friend piped up to tell me that the best parts were the parts I left on the plate. I had no idea that the fins and bones were edible, and absolutely DEE-LICIOUS. Yes, I said delicious. I hesitated when she told me that the fins and bones were crunchy and tasty, but I took a nibble and then we proceeded to decimate that fish. We left nothing but the head on the plate. Sick, but true. That was one TASTY fish. I can't get enough. I'm going back for more.
author: Katherine L.

description: A standard on my list of restaurants.  Service is always excellent, food is delicious, and we've never had to wait for a table.  Win.
author: C. M.

description: I have not found a restaurant in San Francisco that will make something so spicy that I can't eat it.  Mandalay gets five stars for 1) bringing chili paste to the table without me having to ask 2) me not actually needing to use it.
author: Pinky S.

description:
This place is amazing.  We first came here when Burma Superstar had a ridiculuously long wait.   Now, to be honest, we  prefer Mandalay.  Every one of the soups and salads is incredible(don't miss the Tea Leaf Salad or the Hot and Sour Soup), the main courses are quite tasty, and the service is beyond compare.

Check it out!
author: Leo S.

description: Oh, soooo good.  While the potstickers are of the thick skinned variety, everything else is just well conceived and well executed.  It can get busy, especially on Sunday nights,but there's a reason.  Prices have gone up in the past couple of years, but everything has.  Go with a big enough group so that you can divide dishes into four parts.
author: Barry R.

description: Had dinner here last night with some friends from out-of-town who happen to be going to Burma soon for the holidays. Love the family atmosphere and excellent food. The tea leaf salad was absolutely delish and so unique (not for those with peanut allergies). Other hits included the Rangoon Lamb, Mandalay Special Noodle, Pumpkin and Pork Curry, Stir-Fried Peashoots with Garlic, and Crispy Chicken. Don't forget to order the coconut rice to go with some of these dishes, and if you like spicy, be sure to lop on the hot sauce!
author: yvonne l.

description: The food is delicious and the service is great. The samusa is to die for and the Mandalay beef was great but beware it is spicy. I def. will come back.
author: Sylvia R.

description: Tried this place out by the recommendation of my boss and coworkers.  Their tea leaf salad was not as good as Burma Super Star but their beef satays were the bomb!  Was a little taken aback by the Chinese influence on their menu.  To add to the awkwardness, they had Christmas decorations up in the middle of February and had what seemed like a shrine of fruits at the main entrance, but whatever!  The service was very good and quite friendly.  Worth another try!
author: D. E.

description: Mandalay is not quite Burmese and not quite Chinese.  They seem to have a little bit of everything.  The string beans with prawns are awesome!  Spicy but awesome.  Their walnut prawns are great too.  The tea salad is better at Burma Superstar as are most things.
author: T N.

description: The mango chicken was pretty good...not quite what I expected, but pretty good. The spicy basil eggplant was very good, and the mongolian beef was REALLY good. Prices were reasonable. Oh, and the fortunes were a mixed bag. Mine was "your dearest wish will come true", which is a bit lame, but happy, and not quite as lame as "you have a great appreciation for the arts and music", which one of my conspirators got.
author: Jose L.

description: I love this place. The Mango Chicken is great and always tastes the same every time I go.  Which is good and I like consistency.  The wait staff are always nice and smile at you. At one point I was going so much they started to recognize me and gave us free dessert. The papaya salad is also good and they use toasted garlic pieces on it. Yum.  The place is spacious and I never have to wait long for a table. I definitely recommend this place for a nice casual dinner and the experience of eating something different.
author: Ginger A.

description: The tea leaf salad was off when I went.  The texture was too grainy.  The rest of the food dishes tasted like regular Chinese fare.
author: Big e.

description: I have gone here a few times with friends, and this place is great !! I have tried several different dishes, all of which were absolutely wonderful, and the service is perfect - the waitstaff is very attentive and friendly - if only it were closer to my house !!
author: Kara E.

description: GREAT FOOD. great memories. great service. you get fortune cookies with your bill!
author: Diem V.

description: Great walnut prawns!TRY THEM also best lemonade EVER!!!
author: Malendrina D.

description:
i  love it, i love it , i love it. 
a plethora of salads!
the samusa salad,my new love ; the ginger salad,  the tea leaf salad... at first strange, then curious, then so incredibly delicious that you want it again the very next day.
 did i mention that the staff is so nice? well they are. 
 try the smoked duck, the string beans, the coconut soup.
 mmmmmmmmmm.
author: k g.

description: I've never been to Burma Superstar.  In fact, I'd never tried Burmese food before I moved to the Richmond.  Mandalay is close to my apartment and has an eye-catching funky green facade, so we decided to give it a whirl.  Everything is good (Mongolian Beef and Mango Chicken are my favorites), it's never too crowded to get a table, and it's well priced.  I don't think I'll even bother to try Burma Superstar.
author: L Y.

description: Absolutely AMAZING food and great, friendly service (even had some nice tableside presentations).  I had never had Burmese food before, but I now have a new favorite cuisine thanks to Mandalay!  It's a shame they don't deliver anymore!
author: Kris T.

description: Anything you order... excellent. Order the tea leaf salad and samusas for starters. Amazing, friendly service. Local, in-the-neighborhood type place - overtly-disguised destination restaurant. Never a wait. Opens at 5. Cool Italian cafe with wine/beer next door if you get there early. "Rock star parking." - SF magazine
author: Hillary L.

description: I only rate those great places in the City, and this is definitely one of them. Perhaps the nicest serving staff...and the food is great too. Just as good as Burma Superstar...without the hour plus wait to be seated. Between myself and the many people that I have brought there, the sole complaint has been that the food isn't spicy enough. Tasty is all that matters to me.
author: Chris S.

description: Don't ask me to judge between here and Burma Superstar because I haven't been back to Burma Superstar in a while(seriously who wants to wait around for two hours).  Instead, we came here where there was no wait and the food was supposed to just as good....and they delivered.  We ordered the Green Tea Salad, Ong No Kaw Soi(Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup), and Pumpkin Chicken Curry.  The green tea salad was delicious, flavorful in every bite.  The Ong No Kaw Soi(my favorite growing up) was as splendid as it always is, creamy and just rich enough (Don't forget to add some lemon!).  The pumpkin curry was a little disappointing.  It had the right texture, but lacked spice and flavor.  We finished it off with falooda(honestly I've been saying these things forever without actually knowing how to spell them), a dessert with jelly, tapioca, and ice cream mixed together in rose syrup and milk.  It was as good as my aunt's version (though my aunt definitely gave us a little more ice cream) and I could not complain.  All in all, it was a meal I definitely approved of and I will  be back.
author: David L.

description: This place is awesome. Before going here, I had never even known what Burmese food was.  The Mandalay Special Noodle, the Moo Hin Nga, and some of their appetizers are excellent.  I don't live in San Francisco, but visit family there every year or so and I always make it a point to stop by there.
author: Jake M.

description: A friend recommended this place. Food is pretty good and other items on the menu look tasty...I want to come back and try more. Dessert #1 rocks! Clean, pleasant ambience, not too noisy. Of course parking is impossible but I won't ding the restaurant on that account. I'd never had Burmese before but will definitely add it to the rotation.
author: Bambooo S.

description:
Mandalay is 100 times better than Burma Superstar.  No, 200 times better.  

Why Mandalay Kicks Burma Superstar's Scraggly Ass:

*Food that has flavor and is at the correct temperature (at Burma Superstar both entrees that my friend and I had were lukewarm)
*Bigger portions for same or less price
*You're not crammed in, there's actual tables with more than 3 feet of clearance.
*Much friendlier service
*15-25 minute wait for a table vs 45mins-1hour at BSS
*Bigger and better menu
author: James M.

description:
there is always a huge line outside Burma star. I DON'T UNDERSTAND IT!!!!!!
burma star sucks!
mandalay is tastier, better quality, and cheaper too! and casual but not a stupid yuppie hangout like burma star.
its only a few blocks away from burma star, don't be lazy!!! walk the few blocks up to california and over to 8th ave. for the best Burmese food in SF!!!
author: Sasha R.

description: There is no need to wait in line at Burma Superstar. This warm, comfy restaurant right around the corner serves up top flight, fresh, veggie-friendly Burmese food with excellent service and great prices.  Everything about this place leaves me yearning for more. The ginger salad, like most Burmese salads, was as pleasing visually as it was in my mouth. The spicy tofu with veggies was cooked beautifully, with the outer edges of the tofu seared crisp, while the inside melts in your mouth.  As pleasing as the amazing food was the attentive service we received from multiple, smiling and friendly staff, that cleared my plate, refilled my water and got me the check before I even realized I needed them.  All in all, I emerged immensely satisfied. And I waited less than one minute for a table.
author: Neil C.

description: I am either a love it or hate it restaurant critic and I must say... I love Mandalay. I live near by and chose to judge the book by its content rather than its cover. The first evening my wife and I ate here, we were greeted by the friendly owner and shown to our table. Within 1 minute of being seated, our water was in front of us and our drink order was taken. The procrastinated drink order is by far my biggest pet peeve and Mandalay passes with flying colors. We ordered the samosas and the pot stickers and shared an order of the walnut shrimp. All fantastic and in fact some of the best samosas and pot stickers I have ever had. The food was great, the staff is friendly and attentive and even at peak times there is very little wait. I bring all those who visit to this establishment with a sort of pride, knowing they too will love their food.
author: ahern k.

description: One of my favourite places in town. I just can't skip the tofu dishes they serve. Although I try my best to try something new  in my next visit, I always end up with the tofu. Besides that, you will find very good value, fresh vegetables and a warm staff.
author: amynthasfranco f.

description: I have been here twice - lunch was very good (4 stars), but dinner was definitely a full five stars! For appetizers, we had lovely vegetarian samusa, a unique and wonderful ginger salad. Dinner was Basil Prawns -- absolutely delicious; great Mango Chicken, and Mandalay eggplant - also great. Everything was extremely fresh and totally yummy. We had regular rice and coconut rice -- the latter was delicately flavored with coconut and was fabulous. I will be back! Service was also excellent and very friendly.
author: Katrina M.

description: I LOVE this place. My favorites are the Mandalay special noodle, Walnut broccoli Tofu, Green papay or green mango salad and coconut rice !
author: jill f.

description:
waiting in line to get into burma "im so overrated" superstar?  head north a couple blocks and eat at  "im so underrated" mandalay.   you dont have to wait... what..... 1+ fucking hours?..... cmon...... and the food in many respects is superior.

if you like flaky fried starch then order the balada (its like roti chanai at a malaysian restaurant).  the fish curry coconut flavored dipping sauce that accompanies is awesome.  be careful though because this appetizer fills you up so make sure you share with several people at the table.  i consider the sour vegetables a signature burmese style dish that is too ethinic to be served at that other place (warning... this dish has stinky bamboo shoots).  i have had this dish at least a dozen times, and all but one were fantastic (the last time i had it, the bamboo shoots werent washed enough..... UGH!)  i have tried four of their soups, and they were all excellent.  their tea salad is wonderfully intense, so much so, i like to eat it over rice.  i have tried a few of their noodles dishes, and they've all been great.  same can be said about their salads.   i always get their coconut tapioca drink.  its so yummy good, and its huge!  mandalay is a staple in my routine.
author: Curtis Y.

description: What a great Burmese restaurant!! The BEST in the City for sure!  Stick with the Burmese dishes and ignore the Cantonese and you can't go wrong with anything but you must must try the Tea Leaf Salad!!
author: k k.

description: mmmmyum!! i've tried many times to eat at burma superstar nearby.   and to my dismay (as many have posted here) - always a line and too long of a wait. as for mandalay, waited about 10 minutes for a table around 8 pm on a thursday night. had the satay for an appetizer.. mango prawns, some beef dish with basil as main dishes.. all very good with coconut rice! good sized portions. i'd say the food tastes similar to thai and malaysian food but better. the peanut satay sauce tasted sweeter and syrupy compared to thai satay which tastes more like coconut milk and curry. mango prawns dish had lots of slices of mango and veggies which i loved. and the beef basil dish.. seems like they used real fresh basil instead of sprinkled basil as they do as at some thai places. waitstaff was a tad slow but not too bad. they even gave mango pudding for dessert that i believe comes with dinner. mmmyum.
author: ally o.

description:
attempted to go to burma superstar on a monday night at 8:45pm... and they had shut down the sign up list and had a crowd of 15 waiting. dear god.. that place better be awesome when i finally get in. anyway a friend recommended  this place because it was such a short distance away. we walk in and there is no wait, thank god because i was starving! we sit down and without asking we get hot tea (score! it was freezing balls outside) and water. without asking! that's rare nowadays. 
we look at the menu and can't decide because the choices sound sooo good. since we were starving we order the samusas with chicken, fried onions, mandalay beef, and walnut broccoli chicken. she asks us what kind of rice and we chose the basmati rice (out of choices of coconut rice, white rice and basmati). appetizers arrived really quickly and we chomped down. both were absolutely yummy. the fried onions were seasoned really well, not like normal onion rings. the samusas were pretty tasty. add curry to anything and i'm there! shortly after we were done, the main entrees came out. ohmigod... the walnut broccoli chicken!? to die for. i coulda stabbed the boyfriend for attempting to take some! so flavorful. and what i loved even more was the fact that they used white meat! and it wasn't even dry. mmmm, drooling right now. wish we had leftovers. so then out came the mandalay beef. kinda wish it wasn't fried, but it was yummy nonetheless. the portions were perfect and we actually came home with some leftover beef. but... the star of the meal was the basmati rice!!! i was a little weary when they brought it out and it had peas, bay leaves, was a little brown, and had raisins and stringy things in it. but i dug in and was given a taste sensation in my mouth. as borat would say, "sexytime explosion..." except less sexual. it was soooo good. we asked what was in it and the waitress was very coy about telling us. but she did give us bay leaves (obvious) and cinnamon. interesting... cinnamon.... but sooooo good. 
anyway, the service was awesome. our water was never empty. we never asked for anything, they were always there by our table when we needed anything, not that we did. i really enjoyed my experience here... i'll come back. i still need to compare to burma superstar, but at least i know that if burma is better than this... i still love mandalay and have no qualms about coming back!
author: Erin D.

description: This place is really a two and a half star establishment. No way is it better than Burma Superstar!!!!! The only thing it has over Burma is there is no wait, but the correlation is that its not worth the wait like Burma. The mango chicken is the best dish in the house and the green beans are pretty tasty as well. Try it if you are in the hood, but the restaurant is not worth taking a special trip to.
author: Mama L.

description: This is the absolute best Burmese resturant I have ever been to.  Everything I had was fresh and very flavorful.  The service was also excellent!  I will definately go back.  Try it you wont be sorry.
author: Michael F.

description: Great Burmese food. Portions a bit smaller than average, but quality is there. Service is really good, and pricing is good, too. Parking's impossible, and often there's a wait (no resos).
author: Matt G.

description: it's no burma superstar- but it IS good.  their coconut chicken soup is a must.  hot and creamy and totally amazing.  thier chicken is good quality, and their tea leaf salad is good.  they also have wonderful service!! burma will always be my first choice but if i just can't stand the wait then i'll just make my way over to mandalay.
author: Shanti G.

description: Was visiting San Fransisco for two days, and during this short stay we wanted to try exotic dishes that we can't get back home in TX. We chose Mandalay because I tried a Burmese restaurant in NY before, and was craving for more. To our surprise, the food was the best Burmese food we ever tried.  We ordered tea leaf salad, pork curry stew and house special noodle.All the dish were extraordinary and out-of-ordinary, both were exactly what we were looking for. We noticed their custom of serving the plate with the ingredients separated, before the waitress mixed them up in front of us immediately before we ate them. The result was excellent concoctions that  were savory in taste and retains the freshness/crispiness of every ingredients. Such a delight! For you who love Asian cuisine, you are still missing something if you haven't tried Burmese cuisine. With it's being influenced by three major cuisine centers (Chinese,Indian and Thai) all combined into their own style, Burmese cuisine is an underrepresented culinary offerings that should not be missed by most.
author: Jeffrey D.

description: great food and excellent service. if you dont know what to order, the servers do know what to recommend to fit your appetite. from what i remember, the mango chicken was great. our table had 2 orders of that with the rest of our food. there is something on the menu for everyone, even the less opened minded ones. so please, check this place out!
author: marlene m.

description: My husband and I like this restaurant so much that we have decided that we will order too much food every time so we have enough to take home with us.  We live in North Beach and are sometimes kind of lazy about going elsewhere to eat unless it's really special ... and this definitely qualifies on that list.  The mango chicken is delicious, as is the basil beef, but the best thing, as far as I'm concerned, is the crispy pancakes.  Those are basically my crack.  Having had those once, I'm pretty sure I'm going to have intermittent cravings for them for the rest of my life.  And the great thing about this restaurant too is it's cheap - we ordered 3 meals worth of food for about $60 plus tip.
author: Emily H.

description: With all the great reviews on Burma Superstar, we were going to try out Burmese Food for the first time there.  We got there and asked for the wait time...1 HOUR!! so we decided to try out the second best burmese restaurant on yelp: MANDALAY.  My trust for yelpers did not betray me because the food, customer service, and environment was excellent.  They welcomed us warmly, had delicious food, and I felt comfortable being there.  I LOVE BURMESE FOOD.
author: Karen C.

description: i have been going to this place for years and its awesome, must try mandalay chicken and/or beef.
author: Dennis K.

description: deeeeeeelish - must get tea salad and mandalay noodles.  a little bit crowded but worth the wait.  probably never going back to burma super star after trying this place.  i have a sneaking suspicion that they use msg, but i'm chinese so what do i care.  yum!
author: Grace Y.

description:
mandalay, will you marry me? i promise to never cheat on you with burma superstar. 

food is terrific, but even the service rocks. there was a wait the evening we went, but the host brought out complimentary refreshments for everyone while we waited.
author: kirti p.

description: you know i was going to write a negative review of that damn burma superstar but i decided not to waste my energy and instead to give a little love to one of my favourites instead. i have been coming to the mandalay for almost 30 years and have seen it slip a little in quality but it still has some of my favourite dishes in this city. yes, there are some items that are better over at superstar but the same goes the other way around. while the samusa soup is great at superstar, the beef satay, samusa (by themselves), and chicken curry 'hands down' kick major fukkin' ass over at mandalay. it is very sad to me to see people who are waiting for two hours to get a table at superstar when they could just walk a few blocks and get seated in 20 minutes at mandalay.
author: shanti s.

description: This place was pretty good, but not excellent. Burma Superstar is way better.
author: K. S.

description: I have to give Mandalay five stars instead of my usual four for excellent restaurants.  It's just so damn good and reasonably priced and has such friendly staff people that four stars just doesn't seem like enough.  I've been three times now and have had three great meals with a different dish on each occasion.  The Mandalay Special Noodles with coconut chicken, cilantro, lime leaf, ground yellow split peas, and fried onions is really special and the servers mix all the ingredients of the dish together when they bring it to the table.  And they make sure to identify each ingredient so you know exactly what you're getting.
