The black pepper soup is also delicious, with thin slices of cucumber, chunks of whitefish, mushrooms, and glass noodles in a mild broth with enough black pepper to give it a little kick.  It's beautifully simple and the perfect antidote for a chilly Inner Richmond afternoon.  Ditto for the Burmese hot and sour soup, with shrimp, sour leaves, mushrooms, chili peppers (be careful with these -- I almost coughed one up and my girlfriend laughed at me), and lemongrass in a robust tomato broth.  This is refined Burmese food, expertly and lovingly prepared and served in a warm, comfortable atmosphere for affordable prices.  And they give you free hot tea with your meal!  Even without the free tea, I'd give Mandalay five stars.  It's just that good.
author: Dan L.

description: went last night in a group of 4. we waited about 10 minutes, but it appeared we got there just before the crowds. the service time was a bit lacking and i had to ask 3 times for my young coconut juice but once we got the food it was all delicious and very fresh. they also gave a free dessert! i'm all about free:)
author: Jennifer M.

description: The coconut curry soups and dishes are tasty, albeit perhaps a little too heavy & creamy. Best string bean stir fry in San Francisco. Doesn't seem to get too crowded (and if it does, it's all Burma Superstar overflow).
author: A. T.

description: Definitely 4 stars for this restaurant.   Food, service, decor, ambience are all very good.   A very enjoyable place to dine.
author: Ken J.

description: Our food was no disappointment.  I will definitely go back! And I don't feel the crappy heavy feeling I sometimes feel after a good meal. The Samusas are super yummy!!
author: m. e.

description: One of my favorites. Great food, friendly staff and great non alcoholic beverages. Try their mango salad its my favorite.
author: Erica K.

description:
I love this place.. I think I might like it equally as much as I like Thai food, because I absolutely adore thai food. 
I went with 3 other people and ordered 5 dishes. For appetizer, we had the deep fried eggplant.. a little greasy.. but the sauce was good. then off to the tea leaf salad... this is impressive. you do feel like you're a hamster for a couple of minutes, but the textures all blending together.. heaven. We then had the walnut prawns.. nothing too special.. it's better at those chinese joints.. The mango chicken!! I loved this. the combination of mango and chicken. just the best!! then finally, (i think it's called.. ) the Mandalay Special Noodle.. just insane!! The ingredients are nothing too special, but somehow they all come together in harmony.. 
I've been to Burma Superstar, like everyone else, but this place is better!! The plates are bigger, the place itself is bigger so not much of a wait.. Crazy!! If you've been to Burma Superstar, this is the place to try!! Seriously.
author: Mari K.

description: Ate here for my birthday dinner...I arrived late because it was difficult to find parking on a Saturday night. When I sat down, my friends had already order (which is great because they knew what to order). You'll have to read Shannon L's and Angela C's review for a better description cause I went with them. I really enjoyed the Burmese dishes (samusa, balada, rainbow salad, moo hin nga). We ordered a lot of food and ended up eating most of it. Service was great also!
author: Gabrielle V.

description: I visited San Francisco for the first time and I stumbled upon Mandalay by accident while exploring the city. Funny thing was my friends later recommended we go there for dinner, without knowing I went there earlier that day for lunch. The prices were fair and the service was excellent. My waiter so happen to be the manager and she was very helpful in picking my dish. I ended up getting the lamb curry and it was spot on to her description. Well seasoned and not too spicy. Plenty of healthy sized slow cooked pieces of lamb in a red sauce. The decor was also interesting. I highly recommend going in for lunch if you are in the area.
author: Robert M.

description:
tea leave salad, is a must.  1 of the best dish.    

mandalay noodles was really good too, but that is if you like coconut.

spicy eggplant, mandalay beef, mandaday chicken was okay...  something that i won't get again.

ginger lemonade was pretty good, with an umbrella on top.
author: chris l.

description: I so-- wanted to love this place as I can't stand the ordeal with going to Burma Superstar.  It was good, but definitely not better than Burma Superstar.  Admittedly, I've only been here once butI tried to order all the Burmese as opposed to Chinese dishes.  We had the balada (I think the curry dipping sauce could be better - I like Straits version), the tea leaf salad (I think this is much better at Burma Superstar) - the tea leaves were clumpy so it didn't mix properly making some bites very bitter, the curry chicken was quite good, rangoon beef and string beans pretty good.  Service was very sweet but the timing was off.  The curry chicken and coconut rice was served as we were finishing the tea leaf salad and then the next two entrees came out one by one when we were alrady done with the last.  I would have preferred to have all the entrees together.   Overall, it'll do the job if you need a fix of Burmese food, but because the tea leaf salad is an absolute must when I go for Burmese, I'll have to stick to the Superstar!
author: Amina B.

description: I don't understand why this place was so crowded on a Sunday night, but I just had one of the worst experiences here. It was fine initially, the manager sat us down and we were then addressed by at least 3 waitresses. One waitress took our drink order, another one came and got our food order but didn't write it down, then another lady asked us if we wanted water. After we got our burmese tea, we waited for 20min for our papaya salad, which smelled like clorox, but we ate it because we were starving by theb. We proceeded to wait another 20 mins for our curry, which came out in a small bowl, 11 bucks for two scoops! The meat was slightly chewy and the potatoes were hard! Saving grace of that meal was the added 3.50 for the naan bread. We waited another ten mins to get our check, not wanting to wait for the fried rice which we never got, and of course was on our bill! Wow, as much as I thought burma superstar was packed, they at least bring out their food in a timely matter and the long lines are justified.I would never suggest that place to anyone and would not wish that service on people as well. Burmese fans beware.
author: SF Diner A.

description: Excellent food but service could use some improvement.  Pumkin curry isn't quite as good as Marnee's, but it's good.  Ambiance is adequate at best; we'll be getting takeout from now on.
author: WP D.

description: I eat - a lot - and I eat often. I LOVE it! Rarely do I come across a dish that EXPLODES with flavors like Mandalay's Tea Leaf Salad. It's not a "Salad" in the traditional sense. No lettuce here (the consistency is closer to tabbouleh) - finely chopped tea leaves. Mixed with peanuts, a little oil, lemon juice, garlic, tiny hot peppers and a few other bells and whistles. They mix it for you at your table. It's amazing and FUN! I really like "fun" food experiences. Seriously - don't go here and miss the Tea Leaf Salad! The prices are fair. I LOVE the decor. Somewhat traditional Thai - with the occasional disco-ball ornament hanging from the ceiling next to a gourd. And a neon Palm Tree in the corner. Seriously...I don't really understand it - but I get it. And love it! Their other dishes are good - nothing so spectacular as the Tea Leaf Salad - but good. Spicy Basil Eggplant with Tofu, I had a really good flat noodle dish here once. I think it had peanuts and ginger in it. There's only a few noodle dishes - but that was great too. Mango chicken - good. You have a few rice choices. Jasmine, Saffron with cinnamon and raisins, coconut. All good. Paluda Ice Cream for desert was fun. Had bits of tapioca and sat in a cup of coconut milk. A nice dish to end on. This place is definitely worth checking out - if you leave without ordering the Tea Leaf Salad - you will likely regret it later.
author: Eli S.

description: i've been going to mandalay for, oh, three or four years now.  i can see that the owners are the same but the waitstaff has changed and the service has suffered.  they are still very friendly and pleasant but slower and more forgetful (but that could be due to the increased volume of customers, i dunno).  the food is still incredible, though- superior to burma superstar, in my opinion.  i will still keep on coming here whenever i can.
author: Missed F.

description: fthey claimed they are the first burmenese restaurent in SF. food was good, price was right and our waiter was very funny. need to go back again.
author: larry l.

description: This place is wonderful.  I came here for lunch on a weekend day and it was not crowded.  The service is excellent: very attentive waitstaff and managers.  The food was great, too.  We had the samusas (similar to Indian samosas), and I got #2 of the noodle dishes (came with chicken and sauce).  Delicious.  Burmese iced tea was great, too--I think it's even better than it's Thai counterpart.  I would highly recommend this place, especially since it is a block north of the very crowded Clement Street.  A little bit on the pricey side for non-sushi Asian food, but well worth it!
author: E. C.

description: the people who work here must be so sick & tired of everyone talking about burma super star all the time.   but you know what?  this place was great!  we went last night with 5 others and were seated right away.  the waitstaff were friendly and accomodating, we got served quickly and the food was fantastic!  we tried the tea leaf salad (which didn't make anyone sick), the hot & sour soup and sizzling rice soup were nice, the samusas were tasty, the chicken & beef satay was very good, the basil shrimp was excellent, the mandalay chicken with mango was yummy, the curry lamb with roti was flavorful, and the mandalay noodles were creamy and delicious. we also had coconut rice and hot tea too.  it was all wonderful!  all that food plus a bunch of beers all around only came out to $23 per person including tax and tip!  i think that's a pretty good price.  a great find!
author: Cyn B.

description: Yes I go here when I don't feel like dealing with Burma's wait. It's quiet and the employees seem to be pretty friendly. Not as exciting of an atmosphere as Burma, but they have a much tastier pumpkin curry here.
author: Tami H.

description: after discovering mandalay i went almost every week for a few months. the tea leaf salad is to die for, the green bean and asparagus dishes are also amazing. The best part though, the great staff who make good recommendations and are consistently friendly and helpful, oh and the complimentary tea with every meal is always great. I do often choose Burma superstar but at manadaly you dont have to wait an hour in the middle of the day to get a table
author: Genevieve H.

description: I agree with Karen..the mango chicken was so good.  Also, the coconut rice was worth it.  The service was really nice even though there was a long wait (we still felt quite welcome).
author: Mark S.

description: this place is so cute! all the female employees are dressed in traditional burmese clothing and the service was awesome. you don't have to wait in line like at burma superstar and the food was surprising good. what a great surprise =)
author: Rosa K.

description: great service, fun times. got seated right away!
author: Katherine F.

description: I have eaten here twice. I am a vegeterian. The choices are less than BurmaSuper star. And the food tends more towards Chinese cuisine  than Burmese. It is decent food. But comparing the two okra dishes between here, and burma super star, it is a world of difference. Burma super star is way better, and has more choices.
author: Kuldeep T.

description: amazing, this is my first time using yelp, i thought it was to worth it to rate mandalay the food is amazing and very authentic, not to mention it's spicy if you like that type of stuff, the service is amazing and the menu is amazing I need to go many more times to taste all of it
author: Aaron R.

description: It's a cozy little restaurant! Service was great, food absolutely delicious, and the best part is that the menu is very affordable!! Tea leaf salad is tastey, pan fry okra prawns - okra was cooked perfectly (not overdone and mushy), and the mandalay special noodle was amazing!!!!
author: Alice P.

description: I just remember that they had good chicken.  I think that's all we ordered, chicken dishes.  It was damn good though.  I'd go there more if it wasn't so difficult to find parking.
author: James C.

description: I've eaten authentic Burmese food in Burma and have eaten with my friend and his family who are from Burma.  Please note, Mandalay's menu offers Chinese dishes as well.  I only order and rate the Burmese dishes.  In my opinion, Mandalay's Burmese dishes are much better and authentic compared to Burma Superstar's dishes.  The service and portions are very good and the prices are very reasonable.  There is a wait as more people are hearing of Mandalay and many Burma Superstars are defecting to Mandalay.  My wife and I live in the East Bay and we travel to eat at Mandalay at least once a month.  I'd rank Mandalay first in comparison to Burma Superstar.  BTW, don't even think about going to Nanyang in the East Bay.
author: Hafa C.

description: Golden Mandalay's alright. I used to live on 5th about a block away, so got food from here often. Burmese cuisine seems to be a cross between Thai and Indian food, with maybe some Chinese thrown in for good measure, so on the menu you find things like samosas, shanghai noodles, tea leaf salad, mandalay beef, etc. You can order the garden variety sweet and sour chicken here. Most meat dishes come with the standard rice-vinegar-soaked carrots or papaya in cute shapes. The ladies are almost always dressed in nice bright silk skirts, and the interior is midly interesting to look at since they renovated - depending on what time of day you arrive, the place is packed or empty. I've had them tell me it was a 45 minute wait for a table before, and there are other times which I was immediately seated. If you're hungry and there's a table, have some food here. It's roomier than Burma Superstar, and IMHO, the seats are more comfortable.
author: Kid F.

description:
OK OK, so like most people who end up at Mandalay I was told it is almost as good as Burma Super Star, but much easier to get a table. So I ending up eating there last night with grandesque expectations, but left with mearly a grandesque stomach ache . 

The first difference I noticed between Mandalay and BSS was that I struggled to find something on the menu that I wanted to order, whereas at BSS I'm already thinking about what I'm going to order on my next visit. My starters were good, but certainly not great, and my main course was plain awful. I felt like I could have been in any random Chinese restaurant where MSG is still the prodominant ingrediant. To end on an even worse note, we were presented with a "complimentary" dessert which was cleary old stock that they were trying to unload. I'll try anything once, so despite the strangly chewy yet flaky texture of this oddly shaped gelatin rectangle, i stuck my fork in and took a bite. I could have been chewing on an eraser and I would not be able to tell the difference. Seeing my face turn south, my girlfriend quickly cut hers into little pieces to create the illusion that she actually ate some of hers. With the check we were given fortune cookies, another bad sign. I would however like to point out that our waitress was very friendly and attentive.

Typically I never eat at restaurants that claim two, let alone three completely different ethnic cuisines (Mandarin, Burmese and Thai in Mandalay's case), and anyone who knows anything about south east asian cuisine will tell you those three are distinctly different, despite their close geographic proximity. In this Yelper's opinion Mandalay and Burma Super Star should not even be mentioned in the same breathe. Anything worth doing is worth doing right, if you want the good stuff suck it up, put your name on the list and wait it out like a champion.
author: Casey W.

description: Since Burma Superstar has become a hipster codeword, not that there's anything wrong with that particularly since its for good reason, I often have to walk one more block from my compound at 7th & Fulton to get my tea leaf salad jones sated. While they don't have the Burma Cooler, which is unfortunate, they do have friendly service, a comparable quality of cuisine, and typically a shorter wait. One of the other benefits here over the Superstar is that seating is a bit more private so if you're doing the date thing you'll be able to converse more intimately. While I tend to think that the Superstar still may have the edge in pure deliciousness (Mandalay's about a 3.65 stars compared to a B.S. 3.9 stars, to me 5 is for an outstanding experience that food alone couldn't usually provide.) Mandalay provides a great dining experience with typically easier accessability. Oh and one more hint stay away from the deep fried appitizer stuff. Not that its not good, it just ruins the healthy goodness that is part of the Burmese experience.
author: Marc W.

description: I really can't say enough about this place. The food is great, the people are friendly, and the service is spot-on. There is no attitude like the other place down the street. I am working my way through the menu and, after three visits, the only thing that I wouldn't order again are the pot stickers - they weren't bad but they just weren't out of this world like everything else I've tried. A particular favorite which I order every time is the Mandalay Special Noodle - somewhat like Pad Thai but so much lighter and more flavorful - really terrific!
author: Walter A.

description:
We had been excited about trying out Burmese food for a while and, having been put off by reports of the crazy lines at the famous Burma SuperStar, decided to try this place instead. Apparently they only take reservations for parties of 6 or more, so the two of us turned up on Saturday night at prime dinner time hungry and hopeful. As we got there we realised we were nevertheless in for a wait...  of just over half an hour, as it turned out, but the guy in charge kept us up to date with progress and brought us some ginger lemonade while we waited, so we didn't mind quite so much.

After we were seated came the difficult task of ordering, and quite frankly, this is where we took advice from all you fellow yelpers and ordered the tea leaf salad - it seems to be almost obligatory if you come here. It really is good though - such an unusual taste, and not like anything we had tried before. We also tried the samusa soup (tasty but not quite as special), the pan fried okra with prawns, the Rangoon beef and some coconut rice. Yum. The prawns were delicious and succulent (though not quite as spicy as I was expecting), the rice was tasty and my husband reported that the Rangoon beef was also very good. I thought we'd need to take leftovers home but not a chance (maybe that's where the 30 minute wait helped us out!). We even managed to share a dessert - a Burmese speciality made out of sweet potato, no idea what it was called but it was excellent. Then we paid and rolled home.

This was definitely a great experience and I'm sure we will be back (possibly not on a Saturday night though - we really, really hate waiting). Good food, good company and a lot of fun.
author: Laura J.

description: Spent some time in SF over the holidays recently & wanted to try Burmese food. Went to Burma Superstar first but looked like they closed for renovations, so we headed to Mandalay. The wait wasn't too bad. Everyone here writes about the Tea Leaf Salad so we had to try that, along with the Mango Chicken and Coconut rice. The salad came and our waitress prepared the salad tableside. It was a good presentation. But after tasting it though, gotta say, it was nothing special. I found it to be salty and didn't taste like anything worth ordering again. For those unfamiliar with it, after all the ingredients are mixed together, it looks like a dark green paste with a slightly pungent (likely fish sauce or Vietnamese mam), salty flavor and crunchy with the fried garlic and lentils. After having it, I really don't know why so many people talk about it. It is a dish different than most other Asian dishes. But it doesn't go in the "taste good" category to me. It's ok to try once, that's about it. The Mango chicken was good though. The flavor of the mangoes really came through. The coconut rice was also flavorful (but average as far as coconut rice goes). Overall, I found the restaurant to be decent for what it serves. If Burmese is what you want, I don't think you would be unhappy with it. But I realized on looking at the menu, that Burmese food is mostly Chinese and Indian food with some Thai tossed in. I didn't seem to notice any distinctive Burmese line of flavors, which may mean that you probably can get better Burmese dishes by going to Chinese, Indian, or Thai restaurants. Also interestingly, as someone else had mentioned, there were barely any Asian diners there at all. For a busy restaurant in that area and not get many Asian diners maybe telling of something.
author: Shin H.

description: 2/19/07. Saturday night reservations for 8 people at 7:30pm. Not seated until 8:15pm. Free wine was a nice touch, but that's the only thing nice you'll hear me say. Brought tea, but no cups. Took half hour before they brought beers, but still no cups & no water. Finally brought water 10 minutes after the beer. I started drinking tea from the spoon on the table and they finally got the message. Ordered food, half the table getting the "special dinner" the other getting the "royal dinner'. Neither were Royal or Special in the least. They were, however, the smallest portions I'd ever seen in my life. When they finally did bring the food, it was the at least 9:30pm at this point. The first dish went to the "special people" on the other side of the table, so I can't comment on that. My side was straight-up royalty. The Royal treatment so it seems, includes hair in your food, because the first dish that came our way contained one long black one. (that's what she said) We sent it back only to get the exact same plate sans hair. How do we know it was the same plate? well it was the same color and it's a salad that was originally mixed in front of use. The replacement plate was pre-mixed. Hair and service aside, the food was only so-so and not Zagat worthy. By the end of the meal, there was a little food left (due to everyone being to afraid to look like a fat hog taking more than one tablespon of food each) Anyway, we asked if they'd wrap it up and they never did. It supposedly got a 96 rating from the H.D. If hair in the food = 96 I'll be next door at the 100 rated sushi place. And if you're thinking of getting the set meal (special or royal), it only makes sense if you're a couple. Four plates for two people. If you add two more people to that order, they only bring two additional plates of food, not four. And no, they're not any bigger.
author: Aaron L.

description: It's so good. It is decently priced, usually not that hard to park & they have a pretty good vegetarian selection. We eat here constantly & are never disappointed.
author: Fidel M.

description: Bad times.  Finding plastic in your food is inexcusable!  The whole dinner was a mess, actually.  It's unfortunate because I had been here twice before, and found the food to be pretty good.  Tonight, I think our luck ran out.  First, they forget to bring a dish out.  It's not so bad at first, because at places like this, food doesn't always come at once.  It soon becomes apparent, though, that they completely forgot one of our orders because it still had not come after we finished off our first dish.  So we ask for it.  We wait a very long time, and still, no mu shu shrimp.  We had just about finished our second dish, and then my boyfriend bites into a piece of hard plastic.  It's unclear where this came from, but we suspect it was the chicken curry.  We tell them about it, and they were very apologetic and said that they would deduct this dish from our bill.  It was a nice gesture, but at this point, our dinner was kind of ruined.  And still no mu shu shrimp!  Finally, after what seems like an eternity, the shrimp arrives.  We manage to eat some of it, and then we ask for a box for the left-overs.  The bill comes, we pay, they make change, and we wait again.  No left-overs.  So we ask , and finally they bring our boxes.  In short, not a pleasant dining experience.  Watch out for plastic bits in the food!
author: J d.

description: cute place, great food, good service - you NEED to try their food, and they have the best mango sticky rice.....
author: Cianna X.

description: i'm a huge fan of burmese...so naturally, i think mandalay is pretty good....a bit more on the chinese style....but still tasty....AND the wait is not bad at all...unlike the other burmese restaurant a couple blocks away. although i prefer burma superstar for the diversity of items and tastes, mandalay doesn't make my colon spazz like burma superstar does....to be truely honest.
author: bloopie s.

description: yes, it's burma superstar's slightly less appealing little brother, but it's been there a lot longer and i've been eating there since i was a little kid.  i love the weird mysical merlin-esque fountain and all of the fake plans.  i love the birthday song.  i love that when you walk in, it's a little like walking into a jungle.  and oh, yeah, i like the food a lot.  they often bring out a complimentary custardy dessert that i take one cursury spoonful of not to be rude, before i walk up to toy boat to get actual dessert (necessary to satisfy my chocolate pocket, which is next to my stomach)
author: K H.

description: Mandalay serves some of the best Burmese food that I have ever heard, actually, my first and only Burmese experience so far.  The samosas are triangles of crispy deep fried dough filled with your choice of tender ground chicken, peas, onions, potato's, and curry or vegetarian which is everything without the chicken.  Fish cakes are crispy discs of fresh fish fried and spiced with Burmese spices served with a lemon grass dipping sauce.  The chicken satay is tender skewered strips of chicken marinaded in coconut milk and grilled to perfection with a peanut peanut sauce.  The Burmese onion bread with curry sauce is soft, chewy flat bread with a spicy curry dipping sauce that packs a one-two punch.  The rainbow fish is fresh rock cod braised in a spicy chili sauce with fresh vegetables.  The mango chicken is tender chunks of chicken sauted with mango in a mango sauce that is sweet, not too sweet.  Noodles with chicken in coconut sauce have tender chunks of chicken, aldentae flat noodles in a mild coconut sauce.  Noodles with chicken and lemon grass have tender chunks of chicken and flat aldentae noodles in a lemon grass type of sauce.  For dessert, the cream of wheat-like rectangular pastries with poppy seed are a great way to end with creamy wheat and nutty poppy seeds.  The other dessert, which The dessert of cold taro jello was not my favorite as it was cold and just tasted of chilled taro which I am used to having cooked various ways in Chinese restaurants.  The service is lively with Burmese decorations and music which is American songs being sung in Burmese which is cool.  The service is friendly, the staff very knowledgeable and answering any questions that you may have.  So, for Good Burmese food at reasonable prices with friendly and knowledgeable service in a lively, clean atmosphere, Mandalay cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: pretty good - went with a group and tried a few things: tea leaf salad was great, so were the mango salad and the rainbow salad. great service and reasonable prices.
author: M K.

description: This place is AWESOME and in my opinion waaaaaaaaaay better than Burma Super Star.  First of all you do not need to wait hours to get a table but usually can get in pretty quickly, second you are not rushed to finish your meal but left to enjoy your tea and linger as long as you want,  third the staff is attentive and super friendly and finally but most important the food is cheaper and better.  Start with the Balada it's very flavorful with a yummy dipping sauce.  The rainbow salad is a cataclysm of flavors.  The mango chicken, okra prawns and ragoon beef are very good and the Mandalay noodles are a definite must.  Also be sure to try the coconut rice.  In fact I have never had a bad dish here.  And I don't think I've ever paid more than $25 for a meal  (the bill for 2 to share an appetizer, and 2-3 dishes with rice)  This is definitely one of my favorite ethnic places to eat in the city
author: Melanie -.
